The weighted price index was down 103.31 points at 6,920.75 on a turnover of NT$2.51 billion (US$82.05 million) at the open. The index lost 46.29 points, or 0.65 percent, to close at 7,024.06 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: One more carrier cancels flights on Taiwan's western corridor

TEXT.P: Domestic flight services on Taiwan's western corridor will be slashed further after Trans Asia Airways decided to suspend all its Taipei-Kaohsiung and Taipei- Tainan flights from Friday, due to the strong competition from the more convenient and less expensive high-speed railway.

The cancellation will leave Mandarin Airlines -- an affiliate of China Airlines, Taiwan's largest carrier -- as the only carrier plying the route between Taipei in northern Taiwan and Kaohsiung in the south, while the Taipei-Tainan air route will close for good.
A spokesman for Mandarin Airlines said Thursday that they will consider also closing the Taipei-Kaohsiung route if passenger loads in August continue to make the route a money-loser.

The high-speed railway that opened in January 2007, coupled with rising crude oil prices in the international market, are to blame for the flight service cuts, said Mandarin Airlines Director of Public Affairs Irving Hsu, who noted the difficulty of maintaining profitable flight operations on the western corridor.
He pointed out that the only profitable domestic passenger flight operations are those serving the eastern cities of Hualien and Taitung, as well as the outlying islands.

As a result, Mandarin opened a Taipei-Taitung air route that same day and was to begin offering flights from Taipei to the Penghu islands Friday in an effort to balance the losses incurred on the western corridor, Hsu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to seek talks with China over relaxed bourse investment

TEXT.P: The government will ask its quasi-official intermediary body to negotiate with China over the signing of an agreement for a possible relaxation of rules governing Chinese investment in Taiwan's stock market, an official said Thursday.

The remarks came after the Cabinet decided at a meeting earlier in the day to allow qualified domestic institutional investors (QDII) from China to invest in the Taiwan bourse from October at the earliest.

At the meeting, Lai Shin-yuan, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), Taiwan's China policy planner, described the opening policy as an important step in capital liberalization across the Taiwan Strait.
However, she cautioned that the policy will not deliver the desired results if China does not launch related measures and sign a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Taiwan.

Without a MOU with China, Taiwan's new policy would be able to attract only 3 percent of Chinese QDII investment into the local stock market, which would represent a combined investment of NT$33.8 billion (US$1.1 billion).

Lai said the council will ask the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to negotiate with its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, to facilitate the signing of such an agreement.
The two quasi-official intermediary bodies were set up to engage in cross-strait negotiations in the absence of diplomatic ties between the two sides.

Meanwhile, local securities companies said they believe the policy should help boost Taiwan's stock market in the long run, but they also called for a full opening to Chinese capital investment in Taiwanese stocks.
Taiwan International Securities Corp. predicted that Chinese investors will particularly want to invest in Taiwan's technology stocks, as the local high- tech sector is globally competitive.
However, the company said China's stock markets have also fallen a great deal recently and speculated that not many Chinese investors will be willing to invest in Taiwan in the near future.
Meanwhile, the Taipei-based Capital Securities Corp. also said that the policy might not immediately drive up Taiwan's stock market, but still hailed the move as a "good beginning."
The company said the policy will be more effective if the MOU is inked and Chinese investors are permitted to pour capital into Taiwan.
However, Chen Po-chih, chairman of a private thinktank advocating Taiwan-centric policies, warned that the new policy will tie Taiwan's stock market closely to China's.
Any turbulence in China's stock markets will immediately affect Taiwan's, Chen said, describing China's stock markets as "relatively unstable."
Beijing could also use its investments to achieve its political purpose -- forcing Taiwan to accept unification with China, Chen speculated.
China does not have a free economy and much of the Chinese capital is controlled by the government or state-run companies, he went on.
Therefore, the Beijing authorities can dominate the decisions of more qualified institutional investors, he said.
Chen also warned that Chinese investors could intervene in Taiwanese companies' management decisions if they control just 3 percent of the companies' shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to open doors to 5 more Chinese media outlets

TEXT.P: Five more regional Chinese media outlets will be allowed to post journalists in Taiwan, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) announced Thursday.

The new measure follows the council's lifting of a ban in late June on the posting of correspondents from the two foremost Chinese national news organizations -- the Xinhua news agency and the People's Daily newspaper.
MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said the Cabinet-level MAC has already begun accepting applications from prospective regional media outlets from all over China, with a Sept. 30 application deadline.
The new measure, Liu said, will allow Chinese journalists to stay for up to three months per visit.

Since the MAC, the country's top China policy coordinating agency, began in 2000 to open Taiwan's doors to Chinese newsmen seeking to cover events in Taiwan, five Chinese national media organizations have been granted the green light to post journalists in Taipei. In 2005, two Chinese regional newspapers -- the Nanfang City News and the Xinmin Evening News -- were also permitted to post correspondents in Taiwan.

In 2006, the then-Democratic Progressive Party administration revoked licenses for Xinhua and People's Daily to post correspondents in Taipei over their biased reports on Taiwan's reaction to China's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

With cross-Taiwan Strait relations warming up following the inauguration of the China-friendly Kuomintang government, the MAC has decided to open the doors wider to Chinese media outlets with an aim to promote mutual understanding.

Noting that city and regional media outlets in China have consistently shown keen interest in covering news in Taiwan, Liu said the MAC decided to further relax the entry restrictions, adding that if the new opening measure gives satisfactory results, the duration of stay for Chinese correspondents might also be extended.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 central government budget up 6.9%

TEXT.P: The central government's expenditure for 2009 is budgeted at NT$1.83 trillion (US$60 billion) , marking a 6.9 percent year-on-year increase, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Thursday.

The increased budget will mainly be used for new economic development projects, more social welfare services and additional spending on education, culture and technology research, the DGBAS said in a press statement.

According to the statement, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan presided over abudget planning meeting in the morning, during which the central government's budget plan for the coming year was tentatively projected.

As the government's 2009 tax revenues are estimated at just about NT$1.7 trillion, the statement said, the government will have to issue state bonds and use budget surpluses accumulated in the previous years to make its ends meet.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 1, or the first day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: British chemist Sir Joseph Priestley announces that he has discovered oxygen.
1834: Robert Morrison, the first English missionary to go to China and translator of the Bible into Chinese, dies.
1894: War between China and Japan over the question of Korea breaks out. The Treaty of Shimonoseki was signed the next year, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaotung Peninsula, Taiwan, and the Pescadores to Japan.
1915: The Peking government mints its silver coin, known as "Yuantatou," bearing the likeness of Yuan Shih-kai.
1926: Kwangtung University changes its name to National Sun Yat-sen University.
1927: The Chinese communists stage the Nanchang Uprising against the Nationalist government.
1928: The Central Broadcasting System is set up in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1941: American volunteer aviators form the "Flying Tigers," with Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault as commander. They help China combat Japanese air superiority in the early stages of World War II.
1943: Lin Sen, chairman of the Nationalist government, dies at the age of 76.
1949: The Office of Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang is established in Taipei.
1958: An insurance program providing 180,000 government employees with coverage for maternity leave, illness, injury, disability and death is put into effect.
1966: The Chinese Communist Party opens a plenum meeting that declares the start of the 10-year Cultural Revolution.
1971: The Tainan Giants of the Republic of China win the Little League Asian and Pacific play-offs.
1973: The Economic Planning Council (EPC) of the Executive Yuan is inaugurated. The EPC replaces the Council for International Economic Cooperation and Development.
1973: Gen. Kao Kuei-yuan takes over from Gen. Cheng Ta-ching as the Republic of China's minister of national defense.
1976: The National Reconstruction Seminar opens in Taipei with 130 local and overseas Chinese scholars participating.
1984: ROC athlete Tsai Wen-yee wins a bronze medal in weightlifting at the 1984 Olympic Games.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves a slight increase in the premium rate of laborers' occupational injury insurance. The rates for thirty-two occupations are raised.
1987: The Council of Labor Affairs is formally established under the Executive Yuan.
1989: A foreign currency call loan market designed to make the metropolis an international financial center is established in Taipei.
1992: The National Unification Council defines "one China" as "one country and two areas each ruled separately by a different political entity."
1992: The Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters, the ROC's highest security institution, is disbanded, and the Coastal Patrol General Headquarters is established under the Ministry of National Defense.
1999: The U.S. Defense Department announces the sale of two E-2T Hawkeye 2000E airborne early warning aircraft and related equipment and services to Taiwan.
2000: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh pays a visit to New Party leader Hau Lung-bin, a move Hsieh said is aimed at showing respect to the opposition.
2000: Taiwan resident Huang You-fu becomes the 10 millionth traveler to pass through Macau International Airport.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By attending to the cleanliness and purity of his person and the propriety and dignity of his dress, and in every word and act permitting nothing which is contrary to good taste and decency, that is how the ruler puts in order his personal conduct."

DOC.HEADLINE: Employees of American Institute in Taiwan donate blood

TEXT.P: Sixty employees of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Taipei Office, the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan, donated blood Thursday to help resolve a local blood shortage, the office said in a statement later that day.

"As a member of the community here in Taiwan, we are happy to sponsor this blood drive to help those who are in need of blood transfusions, " said AIT Director Stephen Young. "We also hope to encourage more people to become blood donors."
Young himself was not qualified to donate his blood on the day because he has recently visited several epidemic areas.
It was the first time AIT staff had organized a blood-donating drive, according to the statement.
The Taipei Blood Donation Center said that blood reserves in Taiwan's capital often drop in summer and that the center is now in dire need of blood types A and O, the statement read.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Reference to 'Chinese Taipei' an important development: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou once again expressed welcome to China's reference to Taiwan as "Chinese Taipei" in the Olympic Games Friday, saying that it represents an "important development" in cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Ma said China's official media outlets have referred to Taiwan's Olympic team as "Zhonghua Taipei" -- Chinese Taipei -- rather than "Zhongguo Taipei, "which means "Taipei, China" in mandarin and implies that Taiwan is part of China.

"It's a significant change in Beijing's stance on Taiwan and it would not have happened if we had not made efforts to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations over the past two months, " Ma said to Stephen Waters, representative of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei.
Ma said he reiterated in his inaugural speech May 20 that cross-strait relations will go nowhere if Taiwan continues to be isolated by China in the international arena.

"I also reiterated that China and Taiwan should cooperate and show respect to each other in the international community, rather than locking horns in malicious competition that are unnecessarily wasteful, " Ma told Waters during a brief meeting at the Presidential Office.

Ma said he had repeated his ideas on various occasions during visits he made to Australia two years ago that if Taiwan wants to cease meaningless competition with China, the key should not only rely on diplomatic solutions, but also on improving cross-strait relations.
"We have now started working toward that direction," Ma told Waters.
He noted that after his administration pronounced a "diplomatic truce" proposal, the idea raised the eyebrows of China, the United States and other nations concerned about cross-strait relations.

As to another proposal that he has spelled out on seeking cross-strait reconciliation in the international arena, Ma said that so far, the two sides have not exchanged views on the issue, although there have been many discussions on each side.

He pointed out that Chinese media called Taiwan's team "Zhongguo Taipei" or "Taipei, China" during the last two Olympics, but after his administration expressed a firm stance on the designation issue, China's state media outlets are now referring to Taiwan as "Zhonghua Taipei," in accordance with International Olympic Committee protocol.
"This is a positive and significant development for both Taiwan and China, as well as for the international community," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung Hospital wins health promotion excellence award

TEXT.P: Taichung Hospital has recently won the first health promotion excellence award presented by the Taiwan Society of Health Promoting Hospitals and the Taiwan Network of Health Promotion Hospitals and Health Services.

Hsu Yung-nien the president of Taichung Hospital who received the award from Vice President Vincent Siew in a July 27 ceremony, said the award is a great honor for the medical facility, which was established over 115 years ago.
Taichung Hospital beat out over 20 hospitals in Taiwan that participated in the Health Promoting Hospitals program.
Hsu said that one of the keys to Taichung Hospital's success is the fact that all the doctors, nurses and administrative staff follow the principle of "treating patients like family."

In 2006, Taichung Hospital became the first hospital in central Taiwan to be awarded an accreditation certificate from the World Health Organization Collaborating Centre's (WHOCC's) Network of Health Promoting Hospitals and Health Services.

At last year's 1st National Conference of Health Promoting Hospitals in Taiwan held at the Taiwan Adventist Hospital, WHOCC Director Hanne Tonnesen accredited 17 health promoting hospitals in Taiwan, bringing the number of hospitals in the country with accreditation certificates to 22.
There are currently over 600 hospitals around the world taking part in the program.

Under the program, hospitals incorporate health promotion concepts, values and standards into their organizational culture and services, allowing all of a hospital's employees and their families, patients and their families, and residents of the community to participate in health promotion together.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei MRT use up amid rising fuel prices

TEXT.P: The average number of passengers on Taipei's Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system reached 1.15 million per day in July, the city government's Department of Transportation said Friday.

The figure marks an increase of 5.5 percent over the level of 1.09 million riders per day for the same month of the previous year, according to Hung Tsang- lang, head of the department's Planning and Development Division.
Meanwhile, rider numbers on Taipei City public buses stood at 1.64 million per day for July, Hung said.
Although the figure was down from the 1.67 million of the year-earlier level, the average number of riders per day from July 16 to the present rose to 1.72 million, he added.

The Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. said at a city government meeting that passenger numbers on the Maokong cable car system have averaged 13,000 per day since its inauguration last year, with the highest daily total reaching 32,000, demonstrating that the system has been well-received by the public.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said that public transportation use has been rising, largely due to the increase in fuel prices at filling stations, with many city residents opting to leave the car at home to save money.

He added that the city will continue to expand and improve public transport services in the city, pointing out that the public's satisfaction rate with the city's public transport system has a significant influence on the municipal government's overall approval rating.

DOC.HEADLINE: Writer claims China's economy close to collapse

TEXT.P: The author of a controversial 2001 book titled "The Coming Collapse of China", predicted Thursday that the Beijing Olympics, as China's coming-out party, has accelerated the upside of China's economy and that it will also accelerate the downside afterward.

Speaking to some 50 international journalists and academics at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, Gordon Chang said that during a recent trip to Beijing he saw gigantic infrastructure, including sports facilities, an airport terminal and hundreds of hotels, built in Beijing for the Olympics.
"Chinese dream large, but their fear is even larger," said Chang.

He pointed out that in Beijing, security concerns prevail, with restrained Internet access and large deployments of police, paramilitary forces and volunteers for the Olympics. The extraordinary security measures might not return to normal after the Olympics, he claimed.
With high inflation, the economy remains an especially difficult challenge in the future for China, and Beijing is due for a post-Olympic recession, according to Chang.

He suggested that sponsoring the Olympics has had a positive effect on China in the past few years, however, with an upside is bound to come a downside, and China's economy might take a hit in the coming years, he speculated.

Reaffirming predictions he made in "The Coming Collapse of China" almost a decade ago, Chang said it is very difficult for the Communist Party of China (CPC) to sustain its power monopoly. The regime is seeking to keep this monopoly by enhancing nationalism and delivering economic prosperity.

Chang said that from his observations, Chinese society is progressing forward quickly, with more and more people conscious of their individual rights. On the other hand, the system today has become more repressive, he claimed, forecasting that the CPC will collapse.

Answering a question on the warming of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Chang said that despite of what the leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait have said, anything involving sovereignty is still a zero-sum game with no compromise.
According to Chang, the next two to three years, maybe the next half-decade, is not a time for Taiwanese to invest in China, especially in China's financial market.
Chang graduated from Cornell Law School in 1973. He lived and worked in China and Hong Kong for almost 20 years, most recently in Shanghai as counsel to an American law firm.

In addition to contributing to such publications as The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times, The New York Sun and The Far Eastern Economic Review, he has appeared on CNN, BBC, Fox News Channel, CNBC, MSNBC and Bloomberg Television, and is often invited to speak at think tanks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Postal company restores name to `Chunghwa Post Co.'

TEXT.P: The board of the state postal company decided Friday to restore the company's original name -- Chunghwa Post Co. -- more than a year after it was renamed "Taiwan Post Co." by the former pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration.

The move was made in line with a resolution adopted in April by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) -dominated Legislative Yuan, which required the company to reinstate the original name within six months, on the grounds that the name change process was unlawful.

"The company has always been referred to as `Chunghwa Post Co.' in related laws, although it was changed to `Taiwan Post Co.' under a policy (of the former DPP administration), " explained Chunghwa Post Chairman Wu Min-yu during a news conference held after a board meeting.
Wu said signboards at post offices nationwide will all be changed by Monday.

The company adopted the name "Taiwan Post Co." in February 2007 amid a DPP- backed campaign to change the names of state-owned enterprises that contain references to China. "Chunghwa" means "Chinese" or "China" in the Chinese language.
Also renamed in the campaign were Chinese Petroleum Corp., which was changed to "CPC Corp., Taiwan, " and China Shipbuilding Corp., which was changed to "CSBC Corp., Taiwan."
The DPP argued that the name change campaign would help avoid confusion resulting from Taiwanese organizations carrying names similar to those used by organizations in China.

However, despite the name change, bills introduced by the DPP administration to amend the Postal Service Act and a statute on the establishment of the Chunghwa Post Co. to change the laws' references to the company were stalled by the legislature after failing to win support from the majority KMT.

Following his election victory, President Ma Ying-jeou of the KMT expressed disapproval for the name change and of the DPP administration's decision to print "Taiwan" in Chinese and English, rather than the country's official title "Republic of China, " on postage stamps issued by the postal company.

Soon after the KMT administration's inauguration in May, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications decided that stamps printed solely with "Taiwan" will be issued for the last time Aug. 1 and that the issuance of stamps printed with "Republic of China" will begin anew Aug. 20. The new print will read "Chunghua Minkuo" in Chinese and "Republic of China (Taiwan) " in English, according to the ministry.

From Feb. 28, 2007 until Aug. 1, 2008, Taiwan Post Co. has issued a total of 33 sets of postage stamps printed with "Taiwan." As an exception, a set of stamps issued May 20 to mark Ma's inauguration were printed with "Republic of China" at the request of the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for August fell 88 points to close at 6,914, with 66,371 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September lost 86 points to finish at 6,881, with 423 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 80 points to close at 6,852, with 57 contract transactions.
March futures decreased 51 points to finish at 6,840, with 25 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 7,002 for August, 6,967 for September, 6,932 for December, 6,891 for March and 6,906 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index lost 21.52 points to finish at 7,002.54, on turnover of NT$70.87 billion (US$2.31 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

August TE futures dropped 3.4 points to close at 268.55, with 3,129 contracts traded, while September TE futures decreased 1.5 points to finish at 269.2, with seven contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

August TF futures moved down 12.8 points to close at 870.6, with 4,944 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures decreased 8.4 points to finish at 869.8, with 52 contracts traded. December TF futures lost nine points to end at 871, with two contract transactions, while March TF futures shed 10.4 points to end at 868, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Control Yuan reopens after three years of paralysis

TEXT.P: After more than three years of inactivity, Taiwan's Control Yuan reopened Friday, with new Control Yuan President Wang Chien-shien vowing to rebuild the prestige of the government branch and restore justice in the country.

I promise that all Control Yuan members will investigate cases with only right and wrong in mind, without the intervention of any political forces, declared Wang at the swearing-in ceremony for him and the body's 24 other members, who will serve six-year terms.

He said the new members were determined to restore the "glory of the institution's investigative powers" and uphold the principles of the five-power consitution laid out by Dr. Sun Yat-sen, the founder of the Republic of China.
The Control Yuan is one of Taiwan's five branches of government, responsible for monitoring and investigating the behavior of civil servants and public officials.

Authorized to impeach, censure, and audit members of government, the Control Yuan had been paralyzed since the previous members' terms expired on Jan. 31, 2005, when the Kuomintang-controlled legislature began a prolonged boycott of then-President Chen Shui-bian's nominations of new members.
The election of a new administration in March 2008 paved the way for new members to be nominated by President Ma Ying-jeou of the KMT and confirmed by the lawmaking body.

After Friday's swearing-in ceremony presided over by Ma that was held at the Office of the President, Control Yuan President Wang and the 24 members gathered at the Control Yuan for the inauguration ceremony, attended by Vice President Vincent Siew.

Amid high expectations for the new members because of pervasive corruption in the country, Wang said the Control Yuan is committed to fullilling its role of restoring integrity to public insititutions.
"Righteousness will exalt a nation; only when there is righteousness can the country be developed, said Wang, citing a passage in the Bible that he encouraged all members to keep in mind.
Wang, a devout Christian, is nicknamed "saint" for his integrity and toughness.

Vice President Siew encouraged the members to transform the current state of political ethics and raise the quality of Taiwan's democracy, so that one day they will no longer have any cases to investigate.

DOC.HEADLINE: More human resources needed in social welfare efforts: first lady

TEXT.P: More human resources are required for the country's social welfare efforts to provide better support for the disadvantaged, first lady Chow Mei-ching said Thursday.

Chow made the remarks at a seminar held by the World Vision Taiwan charity on the learning environment for disadvantaged children that was attended by many representatives of non-profit groups, government officials and scholars.

Chow said the country's social welfare groups have made great strides in improving the living environment for the disadvantaged, but added that more participation by groups and individuals is needed to help greater numbers of people in difficulty.
"Software" rather than "hardware" is more a problem in terms of helping disadvantaged children, especially those living in remote areas, Chow said.

For example, she went on, some schools that have been given computers are allowing them to lie idle as they lack the personnel capable of teaching computer skills to students, while one tribal community left boxes of donated books sealed for six months as they had no-one to take care of them.
This lack of human resources has created barriers to the learning opportunities for disadvantaged children, Chow said.

In addition, she went on, good social work skills should be an important requirement for teachers in remote areas. Caring teachers without good social work skills can frustrate students who tend to be easily offended by unintentionally hurtful words, Chow said.

The first lady also pointed out that school books designed for most children in Taiwan are not necessarily suitable for children in remote areas. She suggested designing learning materials and classes according to local cultures to better fit these children's daily lives.

Chow said children in remote areas are often raised by their grandparents, who are often unable to help with the children's learning, and she expressed hope that improvements in the economy will draw children's parents back to work in their home areas. That way, she said, more normal families will be seen in remote areas, which will support the education environment for disadvantaged children.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ferry services on Matsu-Mawei route increased

TEXT.P: Ferry services on the route between the Taiwan-held outlying island of Matsu and the port of Mawei in China's Fujian Province have been increased by one crossing per day from Friday to deal with increasing passenger numbers following the expansion of the "mini three links" in late June.

From Friday, the Minchu will depart from Fuao port in Matsu's Nangan township every day at 9: 40 a.m., bringing the number of daily crossings to three. The other two ferries depart from Matsu and Mawei, respectively, at 2 p.m.
The average number of passengers using the route has risen to over 225 daily since the Cabinet issued an executive order lifting restrictions on ferry services to Fujian Province June 19.

Following the directive, anyone with valid travel documents for entry to both Taiwan and China can travel by ship to the Fujian ports of Xiamen, Quanzhou and Mawei. Previously, only residents of the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, as well as Taiwanese businessmen and their dependents, could use the route.

Liu Teh-chuan, head of the Lienchieng Province transportation bureau, said the extra ferry has been added to deal with growing passenger numbers. Lienchiang is the name given to the Matsu administrative region.

Immigration officials, customs officers, coast guard patrol forces and related officials have undergone training to deal with the increase in passenger numbers and to speed up customs clearance at Matsu's point of entry, Liu went on, adding that adjustments to ferry services on the route will be made in the future based on demand and practical considerations.

DOC.HEADLINE: New TSEC head promises more global, open capital markets

TEXT.P: Schive Chi, the new chairman of the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corporation (TSEC) pledged Friday to foster a more internationalized capital market, saying his key missions were to attract more overseas investment, develop new financial instruments and upgrade Taiwan's status to "developed market" rank.
Schive made the comments during his inauguration ceremony today at the TSEC.
Shive said that in the past, economic and financial constraints -- including the cap on Taiwan-based firms' China-bound investment -- had driven away substantial overseas capital.
On July 17, the Cabinet relaxed the cap on China-bound investment to 60% of a firm's net worth, effective this month. Before, such investment was limited to 40% or less of a firm's net worth.

That relaxation was designed to encourage more foreign and local investment in Taiwan, since foreign enterprises should now be more willing to base their businesses on the island in order to indirectly access the China market.

In another bid to attract overseas capital, the Cabinet decided Thursday to allow qualified domestic institutional investors (QDII) from China to invest in the Taiwan stock market beginning as soon as October. That initiative is seen by many as an important step in cross-strait capital liberalization.

These new measures can help Taiwan transform itself into a regional financial hub, said Schive, an economics scholar who was formally vice minister of the Council of Economic Planning and Development and the head of the Taiwan Academy of Banking and Finance.

Schive said that in order to expand the local securities market, TSEC will promote greater variety in investment instruments, such as exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and index warrants. He said such instruments will offer more investment choices.
Schive said he will seek to upgrade Taiwan's financial status, as ranked by the Financial Times Stock Exchange Group (FTSE) , from "advanced emergingtodevelopedmarket rank.

The TSEC will develop a more internationalized trading system to ensure security and order in the markets, while pursuing more opportunities to cooperate with foreign securities companies,Schive said.

The FTSE Group, an independent company which originated as a joint venture between the Financial Times and the London Stock Exchange, is a provider of more than 120,000 equity, bond and alternative asset class indices.
The new chairman said he will collaborate with the government's plan to streamline market operations and management, upgrade efficiency and boost the competitiveness of Taiwan's capital markets.

The government plans to establish a holding company to oversee market trading. The company will integrate supervision of Taiwan's stock exchange, futures exchange, securities central depository, and over-the-counter market.
Combining the four authorities is in line with global trends, " Schive said.
He said there's not yet a timetable for establishing the holding company.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:Pakistanis Aided Attack in Kabul, U.S. Officials Say
The conclusion that Pakistanzs powerful spy service helped to plan the bombing of Indiazs embassy has strained relations between the U.S. and a longtime ally.
The Wall Street Journal: Wal-Mart Warns of Vote's Impact
Wal-Mart is warning store managers and supervisors that if Democrats win power in November, they'll likely change federal law to make it easier for workers to unionize companies -- including Wal-Mart. 12:19 a.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices down on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 21.52 points, or 0.3 percent, to close at 7,002.54.

Finishing lower for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 6,920.75 and fluctuated between 7,008 and 6,903.85. A total of 3.3 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$70.87 billion (US$2.31 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up 1.2 percent and paper and pulp issues advancing 0.1 percent.

The six other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 4.8 percent. Foodstuff issues, textile stocks and machinery and electronics shares all dropped 0.2 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares and banking and financial shares both shed 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,434 to 584, with 432 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$1.82 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCKU witnesses restoration of UNESCO-designated cultural heritage

TEXT.P: Guatemala has recently completed the renovation of a historical and cultural heritage site, work that was documented by a team from National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) and supported by financial assistance from Taiwan's government.

The NCKU team, led by Hsu Ming-fu, director of the NCKU College of Planning and Design, has been in Antigua, Guatemala, since July 2007 to keep records of the restoration of the former Las Capuchinas Monastery and the Sor Juana de Maldonado Convent in the city.
In participating in the project, NCKU is the first Taiwanese academic institution to partake in any restoration work abroad involving UNESCO- designated historical and cultural sites.

Taiwan also recently donated US$400,000 to support the projects and has pledged another US$300,000 to the Guatemalan national relic conservation committee that is converting the two sites into museums.

According to the university, the renovation of the Capuchinas Museum was completed recently, with the museum opened to the public July 25, while the Sor Juana de Maldonado Museum is scheduled to be inaugurated in April 2009.
Antigua was founded in 1543 as the seat of the Spanish colonial for the Kingdom of Guatemala, which covered part of Mexico and much of Central America.
It was largely destroyed by an earthquake in 1773, which forced many of its residents to relocated, but was never completely abandoned.

Today, its monumental bougainvillea-draped ruins and its preserved and carefully restored Spanish colonial public buildings and private mansions form a city of charm and romance unequaled in the Americas.
UNESCO recognized Antigua, a town with just over 30,000 people, as a Cultural Heritage of Mankind site in 1979.
Because of its work in Antigua, NCKU has developed a friendship with Guatemala's prestigious University of San Carlos, and the two tied a sisterhood knot recently.
In 2004, former Taiwan Vice President Annette Lu initiated a historical site conservation project during a visit to the city.
On another visit in 2005, she signed a letter of intent with her Guatemalan counterpart, under which Taiwan would cooperate with Guatemala to restore and preserve its historical sites.
The agreement stated that Taiwan would donate a total of US$700,000 in two stages to assist with the restoration of the two historical and cultural sites in Antigua.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG David Miliband ordered to cancel trip as Gordon Brown seeks to restore authority Gordon Brown has pressed David Miliband to cancel a trip to India as he prepares the way to reshuffle his Cabinet. The Prime Minister has ordered a series of meetings with his most senior ministers at the start of next month as he seeks to restore his authority, The Times has learnt.

DOC.HEADLINE: Meeting between heads of Taiwan and Paraguay being arranged

TEXT.P: Paraguay's ambassador to Taiwan said Friday that diplomats are arranging a formal meeting between President Ma Ying-jeou and Paraguay President-elect Fernando Lugo ahead of Ma's visit to the South American ally, a signal the two countries remain committed to strengthening diplomatic ties.

"Yes, ...we are arranging (the meeting for President Ma and President Lugo) , " Ambassador Ramon Diaz Pereira told the Central News Agency, ahead of Ma's Aug. 12-19 trip to Latin America to attend the inaugurations of Lugo on Aug. 15 and Dominican Republic President- elect Leonel Fernandez on Aug. 16.
He added that he is scheduled to leave a day earlier than Ma to Paraguay to arrange for his visit.

Pereira's comment was seen as an encouraging sign just days before Ma's planned trip, as Lugo has said many times that he wants to switch diplomatic recognition to China, giving rise to speculation that Taiwan might lose its only diplomatic ally in South America.

Asked about the state of current relations between Taiwan and Paraguay, Pereira replied, "we hope that we will maintain the relationship as before...as ambassador of the government, that is my hope. "

Ma's planned visit is seen by some analysts as the first major test of his new government's approach to China on the diplomatic front, which hopes to set aside competition between Taiwan and China for allies.

After taking office, Ma declared he would seek a "diplomatic truce" with China in an attempt to end the "checkbook diplomacy" used by both sides to solicit recognition by offering large sums of money to mostly poor nations.

A meeting between Ma and Lugo could signal that Paraguay might be less keen to switch allegiances than is widely portrayed. Simon Ko, director-general of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Department of Central and South American Affairs, said the ministry is currently consulting with its Paraguayan counterpart to set up the encounter.
"Based on diplomatic protocol, we are now trying to arrange a meeting for President Ma and Lugo to meet privately, " Ko said.
"Although no concrete result has been obtained on the time and location of the meeting, we hope that all details will be confirmed before Ma leaves for Paraguay."
Taiwan, which now has 23 formal allies, has held diplomatic ties with Paraguay since 1957.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alternative service still needed despite volunteer system: minister

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi said Friday that Taiwan's alternative military service would still be necessary even after the country adopts an all-volunteer military force.
Liao made the remarks one day after Taiwan's military said it will adopt an all- volunteer system as soon as 2014 to fulfill an election pledge made by President Ma Ying-jeou earlier this year.
The Ministry of National Defense (MND) plans to implement the volunteer system beginning in 2010, decreasing the number of conscripts by 10 percent annually, Defense Minister Chen Chao-min said.
Under the ministry's plan, those who do not volunteer for military service will still need to receive three or four months of basic military training.
The ministry aims to establish a 200,000-member force eventually, down from more than 300,000 at present.

Liao told reporters after speaking to alternative service conscripts at a ceremony held at a military training base in the central county of Taichung that he hopes alternative military service will remain in the future.

He explained that the some 80,000 to 100,000 male citizens in Taiwan who will not volunteer for military service every year will be able to fulfill their military duties by receiving military training in schools or participating in alternative service.
Taiwan now has 14,000-16,000 alternative service conscripts serving at local schools, fire departments and high tech companies, according to interior ministry.
Some of them are also serving at government agencies in the fields of sports, diplomacy, tourism, medicine, culture and environmental protection.
Liao argued that such service prevents the waste of human resources or time.

For example, he said, allowing alternative service conscripts to serve at local technology companies can both meet the companies' needs for technology and people, and help the conscripts keep their skills up to date.

The interior ministry also launched a program in 2007 to help disadvantaged children with their school studies, with more than 400 alternative service conscripts joining the program this summer to assist more than 1,700 children.

On Friday, the defense minister said that Taiwan would follow the United States and Japan in switching to an all-volunteer military, but added that further planning for financing military spending and restructuring the troops is needed.
At present, Taiwan's conscription system targets males over the age of 18. Starting from Jan. 1 this year, Taiwan cut military service to one year.
Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Chai Trong-rong said Friday that the defense ministry should first solve existing problems before adopting an all-volunteer force.
Chai said many people find it difficult to adjust to military life after volunteering to become soldiers or officers.
There is no mechanism in place, however, to allow them to leave the military, which forces them to intentionally behave inappropriately to try and get kicked out of the military, he observed.
He urged the ministry to set up such a mechanism soon.

Also, after related regulations take effect, those who serve four years in the military will be designated as "veterans" and become eligible for a retirement payment of at least NT$150,000, Chai said.

With another system already in place under which more than 300,000 conscripts have retired after three and a half years but without a lump-sum payment, Chai wondered if they would be allowed to volunteer to rejoin the military as officer trainees or officers for another six months to get the benefit.
Chai also noted that he had received complaints accusing the defense ministry of exaggerating benefits or hiding negative aspects of military life when recruiting volunteer soldiers and officers.

Another issue questioned by the lawmaker was whether the increase in number of personnel recruiters from 120 to 2,700 to 3,000 to handle the all-volunteer system would affect the military's operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.055 to close at NT$30.645.
A total of US$1.41 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$30.610 and closed at the day's high of NT$30.719.
