DOC.HEADLINE: Drug control bureau warns of dangers of new 'club drugs'

TEXT.P: The government warned the public Friday of the hazards -- including coma and death -- of three designer drugs that have recently been seized in raids on night clubs and from passengers entering the country from New Zealand and Australia.

Liu Chia-juey, a drug analyst at the National Bureau of Controlled Drugs under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) , said that justice and aviation officials have informed the bureau of three problem drugs: BZP, TFMPP and DOB.
The three are often sold to unsuspecting users as the popular club drug "ecstasy" (the common name for the amphetamine MDMA) or promoted as an ecstasy alternative.
BZP is a synthetic stimulant, TFMPP is a hallucinogen, and DOB, or Brolamfetamine, is a psychedelic hallucinogen.

According to Liu, BZP and TFMPP are listed as first-grade medical drugs in the United States, while DOB is banned. But in Taiwan, the use of BZP and TFMPP has not been restricted, while DOB is listed as a second-grade medical drug whose possession or sale is illegal.
There have been several cased of DOB-related deaths in other countries, Liu said. He added that even low doses of the drug can cause vomiting, cramps and even coma.
The combination of BZP and TFMPP produces a range of side effects, including pronounced visual effects and a "hangover" effect. The use of TFMPP on its own can cause insomnia, nausea or headaches.
Dr. Yang Chen-chang, from Taipei Veterans General Hospital's poison control center, said that a patient he treated died from liver and kidney failure after taking the illicit drugs at a home party.
Yang warned the public to avoid the three drugs, since their effects vary dramatically from one person to another based on body chemistry, age, gender and dose.
He warned that a "cocktail" mix of the three drugs, even in low doses, could cause stroke or psychosis. endiem /JA

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City to design cap with reflectors for the elderly

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government plans to design a cap with reflectors to be worn by senior citizens in order to make them more highly visible to vehicle drivers on the roads, Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Friday.

The idea came from the observation that seniors seem to favor wearing caps when they go out, Hau said, adding that light reflectors on the hats will allow drivers to clearly see pedestrians and thus help to prevent accidents.

Luo Shiaw-shyan, director-general of Taipei City's Department of Transportation, noted that many senior citizens like to go out for exercise at night or at dawn when visibility is lower than in the daytime.

According to Chen Ming-cheng, commander of Taipei City Police Department's Traffic Division, there were five traffic deaths in the city in June, with four of the victims being elderly people, 80 years old on average, who were hit by cars while walking on the street.

Taipei City introduced a pedestrian safety measure for the elderly four years ago when it provided 800,000 free wristbands with reflectors to residents over 65. The city government also encouraged senior citizens to wear bright colors that they would be more highly visible to drivers, Luo said.
He said that his department will disclose more details of the new plan to improve elderly pedestrian safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourists haven't boosted business: store operators

TEXT.P: Businesses that joined the "Travel Shopping Assurance System" said Thursday that their business hadn't improved since Taiwan began allowing more Chinese to visit the country last month, despite high expectations.

The number of Chinese tourist arrivals over the past two weeks averaged only 200-300 per day. That amount was far lower -- less than a tenth -- of the 3,000 Chinese tourists permitted to visit Taiwan per day under a tourism agreement reached by Taipei and Beijing in June.
Business representatives said that those low numbers meant that sales at their shops weren't as brisk as expected.

They made the remarks at a ceremony to mark the joining of 54 businesses to the Travel Shopping Assurance System. That system was developed by the Travel Quality Assurance Association to ensure that foreign tourists get a fair deal for all products sold at member stores.

More than 150 stores nationwide have joined the system. Of those, 18 sell agricultural and fishery products, including those that produce Alishan tea. The newly-added members also include many 3C consumer electronics outlets, eyeglasses stores, and vitamin and supplements shops.
Among the 150 stores in the system, only about 20 received orders from their Chinese customers in July.

Association chairman Boggy Lin admitted that Chinese tourist arrivals to Taiwan were lower than expected. But he expressed optimism that the companies' sales would get a boost in September and October, when Taiwan is expected to see great numbers of inbound Chinese tourists.

Meanwhile, Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai said that Chinese tourist arrivals were lower than expected in part because it takes two weeks for Chinese tourists to apply to visit Taiwan, and because seats on non-stop cross-strait weekend charter flights are still scarce.

Several of the system's new member companies have experience of serving Chinese tourists who arrived in Taiwan via a third location or hold a second passport from another country. Such Chinese tourists have been allowed to visit Taiwan since 2002.

Vendors also commented on Chinese tourists' distinct shopping habits. Hsu Jun- chin, a representative of the Taipei County-based Paoyee watch and spectacle store chain, said that Chinese tourists' favorite watch brands were Longines, Rado, and Omega. Most Chinese visitors prefer watches with a metal strap, rather than the leather strap favored by Taiwanese customers, she said.

Hsu expressed confidence in future business from Chinese tourists, saying that Taiwan offers a wide range of options for tax-free watches, allowing mainland customers to avoid the 20% luxury tax levied on high-end watches in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: President praises award winners for overcoming limitations

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has received winners of this year's Presidential Awards for Education in recognition of their efforts in overcoming limitations with extraordinary fortitude and courage, the Presidential Office said Friday.

The president posed with the award winners after presenting them with the awards at the Presidential Office Thursday. Also present were Vice President Vincent Siew and Minister of Education Cheng Jei-cheng.
Twenty of the 68 award winners are disabled students -- 10 are wheelchair-bound, eight are visually impaired, and two are hearing impaired.

Ma said he highly admired the disabled students for making the best of a difficult situation by overcoming their physical disabilities, and praised them as setting good examples for their peers, the Presidential Office said.
The Presidential Awards for Education are awarded annually to outstanding elementary, junior high, senior high and vocational high school students.
A total of 509 students have received the awards since they were established in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: Buckwheat allergy can be lethal

TEXT.P: Buckwheat allergy cases have been rare in Taiwan, but a 57-year-old businessman has nearly been killed three times in the past three years after unwittingly ingesting food items containing small amounts of buckwheat flour.

The businessman, whose name was withheld and who was identified only as a Taiwanese businessman operating in China, was first struck by a buckwheat reaction in October 2005 after eating a bowl of buckwheat noodles in China, according to Hsu Shih-tah, director of the Department of Allergy and Immunity of Mackay Memorial Hospital in Taipei.
Within half an hour of consuming the noodles, the businessman suffered an itchy throat and tongue and a skin rash.
He then fell unconscious from shock and was rushed to a nearby hospital but was saved by Chinese doctors, who suspected afterward that he had suffered an allergic reaction to buckwheat flour.

In 2006 in Taiwan, according to Hsu, the businessman again went into shock after eating one of five small grain buns he took with him while hiking on a hill in suburban Taipei. He was rushed to Mackay Memorial for emergency treatment.

After recovering, the businessman returned to the store where he bought the buns and was told they contained buckwheat flour, convincing him that he was fatally alleric to buckwheat, according to Hsu.
Yet, despite his best efforts to prevent further problems, the businessman fell victim a third time in China in April this year while being entertained by friends at a restaurant.

The man began enjoying a bowl of noodles after double checking with his hosts that they were not made with buckwheat, but he quickly developed an acute asthmatic attack after eating about half the noodles and then went into shock before and after being rushed to an emergency room.
Afterward, they discovered that the chef at the restaurant unwittingly added buckwheat flour into regular wheat flour to make the noodles.

Buckwheat, often used in a variety of foods, including pancakes and Japanese soba noodles, is popular for its rich flavor and high nutritional value. Being gluten-free, it is also a sought-after alternative for those who are gluten intolerant.
According to Hsu, buckwheat allergy cases are extremely rare in Taiwan, with the most common allergic cases involving mites.
Hsu suggested that patients who know they are allergic to buckwheat should carry adrenaline with them at all times to inject into themselves if they suffer an allergic reaction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nine hospitals honored for excellence in promoting health

TEXT.P: Nine hospitals in Taiwan received awards from the Taiwan Society of Health Promoting Hospitals recently for demonstrating excellence in promoting health.
Vice President Vincent Siew presented the awards to the nine hospitals at a ceremony on July 27 on behalf of the association.

Taiwan Adventist Hospital, a teaching hospital that serves the greater Taipei area, won the Model Health-Promoting Hospital Award for not only providing integrated professional medical care, but also promoting a healthy lifestyle as part of its preventive medicine program.

The other eight hospitals that won the Health Promotion Excellence Award are Taichung Hospital in Taichung City; Cardinal Tien Hospital's Yung Ho Branch in Taipei; Changhua Christian Hospital in Changhua City; National Taiwan University Hospital's Yunlin County Branch; Tzu-ai General Hospital in Yunlin County; Taipei City Hospital's Renai Branch; and Lishin Hospital in Taoyuan County.
Changhua Christian Hospital received an additional Friendly Workplace Award, while Taipei Medical University Hospital and Lishin Hospital were each honored with an Organizational Reform Award.

The Yunlin branch of National Taiwan University Hospital also won a Creativity Award for running a successful methadone maintenance treatment program in the local community, while the Buddhist Dalin Tzu Chin General Hospital in Chiayi County was honored with two Creativity Awards for launching a community health- promoting program and for turning a stairway of the hospital into a healthy walkway.

The Taiwan Society of Health Promoting Hospitals, founded in August 2008, is working in conjunction with the Taiwan Network of Health Promotion Hospitals, which became a regional member of the World Health Organization's network of health promoting hospitals in November 2006.
The Taiwan network is authorized by the WTO network to issue accreditation to hospitals acknowledged for their health-promoting programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor returns from inspirational Singapore trip

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung mayor Chen Chu returned Friday from a four-day visit to Singapore to study the island city-state's tourism and development.

Chen Chu said in a press conference by the city government that her delegation had stopped at a bird park, ridden a gondola lift, visited a traditional market and toured Sentosa Island -- one of Singapore's most popular tourist attractions.

Chen said the visits to Sentosa Island and the gondola lift inspired her with the idea of developing a tourism zone ni Kaohsiung's seaside Cijin district. She said that Singapore's Jurong Bird Park was a model for the future development of Kaohsiung's Shoushan Zoo.

Kaohsiung City has a population of 1.5 million and boasts Taiwan's largest harbor. The city has been pursuing revitalization efforts in recent years as it prepares to host the 2009 World Games. By Elizabeth Hsu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Human rights group to conduct Thai, Taiwan prison surveys

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Association for Human Rights (TAHR) will work with the Thailand government to conduct surveys on the conditions of Thai inmates in Taiwan jails, and Taiwanese inmates in Thai prisons, the association's chairman said in a press release Friday.
According to TAHR Chairman Chang Hsueh-hai, the association will design a questionnaire for Thai prisoners in Taiwan to gain a better understanding of their conditions.
Thailand's Trade and Economic Office in Taipei will help provide a translation of a similar questionnaire for Taiwanese prisoners in Thailand, Chang said.
Results of the surveys will serve as a reference for future improvements in inmate's living conditions, Chang said.

The association will also recruit Thai people in Taiwan to take translation courses so that they can provide translation services in future legal proceedings to prevent misunderstandings caused by language barriers, Chang said.

Chang expressed the hope that Arbhorn Manasvanich, executive director of the Thailand Trade and Economic Office, will support the association's push for an inmate exchange program between Taiwan and Thailand -- something long hoped for by prisoners' families, since such a swap would make it far easier for them to visit jailed relatives.
The Thailand Trade and Economic Office is Thailand's de facto embassy in Taiwan, in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Book fair opens to promote reading

TEXT.P: An exhibition featuring books and magazines nominated for the 32nd Golden Tripod Awards opened at the Taipei Public Library Friday as part of a monthly reading promotion program launched by the government.
On display are 146 books and magazines nominated to compete for 34 Golden Tripod Awards, said the Government Information Office, which organized the book fair and is sponsoring the awards.
The winners will be announced at the awards ceremony Aug. 15.
A series of activities will be held to coincide with the book exhibition, which ends Aug. 31, including an exhibition of high-quality books at the Taipei Metro Zhongshan underground book street.
A countrywide book fair will also tour cities around Taiwan to cultivate interest in reading among all citizens.
Additionally, three lectures on culture will be held at the Taipei Public Library on August 8, 23, and 30.

Two of the speakers will be the winners of this year's Golden Tripod Special Contribution Award, Wang Rong-wen and Chang Hsin-ju. Also speaking will be "Backpackers" site master Ho Hsien-jui and media figure Shu Hao-ping, who will share their reading experiences with the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Palace Museum southern branch needs more funds: curator

TEXT.P: It may require an additional NT$2 billion (US$65.57 million) to NT$3 billion to complete the National Palace Museum (NPM) southern branch, given the recent surge in consumer prices, NPM Director Chou Kung-shin said Friday.
Chou made the remarks after inspecting the site of the NPM southern branch in Chiayi County near the Chiayi county government, accompanied by the county's Magistrate Chen Ming-wen.
Chen, who wants to make the southern branch one of his major legacies when his second term expires in December 2009, said the construction has been seriously delayed.
The construction project, which includes clearing land and building an artificial lake, is only 42 percent complete, according to Chen.

He urged Chou to help obtain additional funding for the project, saying that the government has appropriated more than NT$2.4 billion over the past three years in special budgets and that another NT$4 billion will be required after 2008.

The southern branch project, designated as a museum of Asian arts, was approved in 2003 by then-Premier Yu Shyi-kun. Constructed on 70 hectares of land, it was originally estimated to cost NT$6 billion.
Chou had earlier signed an agreement with Chen for an exhibition of NPM Asian art pieces at the Chiayi Performing Center later this year.
The exhibition, entitled Exploring Asia: Episode One of the NPM Southern Branch, will feature 108 pieces of Asian art on loan from the NPM, between Oct. 24, 2008 and Jan. 4, 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fuel prices go unchanged, but for how long?

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run oil refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan, opted Friday not to increase domestic fuel prices to help stem inflation, but the freeze may only last a week as the government decided to adjust the mechanism it uses to determine prices at the pump.

After discussions with its supervisory authority, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), CPC Corp. decided to help stabilize domestic consumer prices and meet the public's expectations of a price freeze, a company spokesman said.

With the two typhoons arriving in July that caused domestic prices to rise even higher, we decided to absorb the rising costs to help the people get through this critical period, Chu Shao-hua, CPC Corp.'s vice president and spokesman, said Friday at a news conference announcing the decision.

CPC Corp.'s chief domestic rival, privately-owned Formosa Petrochemical Co., followed the state-run oil giant's lead in keeping its prices unchanged, citing a need to remain competitive at its 600 gas stations, including 200 franchises.
Friday's announcement countered widespread speculation in the news media Thursday that gasoline prices would be increased by NT$0.8 per liter.
The MOEA and CPC Corp. had been mulling increasing fuel prices in August under a floating price mechanism used to adjust prices on a monthly basis.

With international crude oil prices rising 2.05 percent in July to US$131.85 per barrel from US$129.20 per barrel in June, gasoline and diesel fuel prices should have been increased by NT$0.5 to NT$0.6 per liter under the monthly price adjustment system.
An increase would have been highly unpopular and hard to explain, however, because of the nearly US$20 per barrel dropoff in international crude prices since exceeding US$147 per barrel in mid-July.

To more accurately reflect fluctuations in global oil markets, the MOEA announced later Friday that in the future, local fuel prices would be reviewed on a weekly rather than monthly basis, a change Chu believed would benefit the company's pricing decisions.
"With international oil prices changing each day, adjusting fuel prices every week will help the company more efficiently reflect costs," the spokesman said.

Keeping domestic prices at their present levels in August without reflecting the higher price of crude in July would add NT$600 million (US$19.73 million) to the company's losses for the month, Chu said.

The company has already been pounded by the combination of soaring international crude prices and a freeze imposed on domestic fuel prices in the first five months of the year by the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration.
From January to May, CPC lost NT$43.15 billion, including losses of more than NT$10 billion in March, April and May, Chu said.
The new Kuomintang government restored the floating price mechanism after taking power May 20 and promptly hiked local fuel prices by NT$3.9 per liter on May 28.

The move helped limit the company's losses to NT$3.45 billion in June, but despite another NT$1.5 liter hike on July 1, Chu estimates CPC Corp. lost NT$4.5 to NT$5 billion in July because of the higher cost of crude.

Chu emphasized that Taiwan's fuel prices were still relatively cheap compared with those in other Asian countries, saying prices at the pump here were around NT$6.65 lower per liter than elsewhere in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ministry of Education to subsidize lunches of more students

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Cheng Jei-cheng said Friday the ministry will subsidize the lunches of more students in elementary and junior high schools starting in September.
Cheng said the government will fully fund the lunches of 223,000 students at a cost of NT$1.27 billion (US$41.69 million).

The ministry is already subsidizing students from low-income families, from families that have encountered unexpected difficulties, or from families that teachers think need the subsidies after paying them visits.

Starting from September, students from "low- or middle-income families" will also be included in the program, meaning 52,000 more students will have their lunches paid for than during the previous academic year.

Students in five administrative districts considered to have more abundant financial resources -- Taipei City, Taipei County, Kaohsiung City, and the two outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu -- have not and will not have their lunches subsidized by the Ministry of Education, Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei area Housing market feels pinch of economic downturn

TEXT.P: Housing markets across most of Taiwan were sluggish in July, with the greater Taipei area in northern Taiwan the most affected, real estate insiders said Friday.
The housing market in the greater Taipei area contracted noticeably in July, both in terms of property values and transactions, continuing a severe decline seen in May and June.

Over the past three months, housing sales in Taiwan's capital have plummeted, with transactions down 60 percent in July compared to April, when the housing market in Taiwan's capital began losing steam.
A big reason for the lack of activity, real estate brokers said, was that property investors have been pulling out of the market.

They have been beset by higher mortgage payments driven by higher interest rates and a need to sell property to cover losses on the local stock market, which has lost around 20 percent of its value since early June.
Most potential buyers, industry insiders say, are now those seeking to purchase a house of their own.

An executive at real estate broker Evertrust Rehouse Co., Ltd., said market indicators in July suggested a continued decline in August -- "ghost month" on the lunar calendar -- despite the recent sale of two plots of land in a prime district in downtown Taipei City at near record prices.

Housing prices in the greater Taipei area averaged NT$267,000 (US$8,783) per ping (equal to 3.3 square meters) in July, down by 10 percent from June, Evertrust Rehouse statistics showed. Transactions in July also decreased by 15 percent compared to the June figure.
Property prices in Taiwan's prime districts have corrected by less than 5 percent month to month.

The housing market in Taichung City in central Taiwan also contracted slightly last month, as the average price per ping fell by 5 percent from June to NT$91,000, while the number of deals also plunged by some 30 percent, according to Evertrust Rehouse figures.

The residential property market in the Kaohsiung area in southern Taiwan was the only one in Taiwan to show some strength. The average price per ping in the area remained at around NT$90,000 in July, while transactions were up 5 percent compared to June.

Although the U.S. subprime loan crisis jolted the global market in many sectors when it erupted in July 2007, Taiwan's housing market has performed even worse a year later, one housing property broker commented.
But he predicted that the overall housing market could rebound in the fourth quarter if international oil prices stabilized or fell.
According to a report published in late April by the Institute for Physical Planning and Information, a housing bubble was already looming in Taiwan, particularly in Taipei City.

Residential property prices in Taipei City have surged by 50 percent over the past three years, while average local household income has grown by only 2 percent over the same period -- a stunning contrast that shows housing prices have irrationally outpaced local residents' earnings, the report stated.
In the first quarter of this year, the average price per ping (3.305 square meters) for pre-sold houses in Taipei City reached NT$530,000 (US$17,377), the report noted.

Some economists believe that the overheated housing market caused by speculation over possible Chinese investment and the popularity of real estate as an investment to fight inflation have artificially pushed up residential property prices by about 30 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Relationship among U.S., China, Taiwan in 'better place': Bush

TEXT.P: United States President George W. Bush has said that the relationship between the U.S., China and Taiwan is in a "better place," the South China Morning Post reported Friday.
Accordig to the front-page report, Bush made the remarks in an interview at the White House with the paper and three other regional papers.
Bush also said he sought to highlight the consistency of U.S. policy in his time in office.
Addressing U.S. policy on relations across the Taiwan Strait, Bush said he made it abundantly clear that there were some red lines for the U.S. on this issue.
He said there would be no unilateral declaration of independence by Taiwan and that U.S. policy was still the same.

When asked about Sino-U.S. relations, Bush warned against calling China either a strategic competitor or a potential partner of the U.S., saying the nations' "good, solid" relationship had grown too complex for labels.
One reason for him to call it complex, he said, is that in America, trade with China is not necessarily universally accepted as good.
The president also said he is worried that Americans have become isolationist and protectionist.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nantou County has its first environmentally friendly grocery store

TEXT.P: Nantou County certified a traditional grocery store as an environmentally friendly green store Friday, the first of its kind to earn the green label in the landlocked county.

Chiao Hsin Supermarket, located in the town of Puli, earned the distinction after passing the county government's screening process, allowing it to join some of the biggest names in retailing in the country to obtain the "green store" label.

Ten other stores in the county had already earned the honor but were all part of big chains, such as Carrefour and the Tsann Kuen Group, which operates the "3C" chain of stores selling electronic and IT products, according to the county government.
County officials praised the Chiao Hsin market for its efforts in environmental protection and expressed the hope that more local stores would follow the model and turn "green."
Encouraging local business operators to go "green" is part of the central government's efforts to save energy and cut carbon dioxide emissions to combat the threat of global warming.

Under Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) regulations, stores labeled as "green" must sell "green products, " develop marketing strategies in the spirit of environmental protection, and manage the shop in ways that protect the environment, such as using energy-saving devices and packing materials.
A certified green store must also be devoted to promoting environmental protection concepts and take active measures to encourage consumers to purchase green products.
Such a store is also required to be a gathering spot for recyclables and to promote the idea of recycling, according to the EPA.
The so-called green products are those produced, sold, used, and abandoned in a spirit of recycling, low-pollution and energy-saving.
The stores that sell these products, legally registered and holding a for-profit business registration certificate, are entitled to apply for the EPA's "green store" label.
Currently, there are 360 certified green stores around Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bazaar to be held Sunday in front of Presidential Office

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) will sponsor a bazaar Sunday in the square in front of the Presidential Office which will also be open for public tours.

High-quality farm and fishery produce and organic goods, such as fruit, honey, shampoo, tea and butter, will be displayed at the bazaar to allow the public to acquire locally produced top quality items that are not common on the market, as part of the government's efforts to raise public awareness of environmental protection.

According to COA officials, more than 90 percent of the products to be displayed at some 40 booths will be items certified by several licensed and famous institutes. The products will include 200 gift bags containing four popular fruits -- pineapples, mangos, star fruit and guavas.

The gift box will be one the COA's major promotions during the upcoming Beijing Olympics. Throughout August, passengers on the Beijing subway will see a series of advertisements featuring the four Taiwanese fruits, COA officials said.

In September, the COA will target local distributors by launching a new wave of promotions in which gift bags of fruit will be sold during the Mid-Autumn Festival, one of the main holidays on the Chinese calendar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Experts from Taiwan and China elected into WTO group simultaneously

TEXT.P: Experts from Taiwan and China were elected simultaneously into an influential World Trade Organization group Thursday, breaking a political deadlock and easing antagonism that had lingered since both became WTO members in 2002.

The WTO announced Friday that the Committee on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures elected four members of the Permanent Group of Exports (PEG) , including Lo Chang-fa, a well- known scholar in international trade law in Taiwan and China's Zhang Yuqing.

A senior economic official cautioned that one should not read too much into a single event, but acknowledged that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait "at least did not boycott each other's candidate in the selection process."

The otherwise routine elections for other member states epitomize the political struggle between Taiwan and China in the WTO. It would be the first time that both sides of Taiwan Strait reconciled on major personnel arrangements, an encouraging sign of better interaction in the international arena.

Lo, a distinguished law professor at the prestigious National Taiwan University, was first recommended in 2005 to be a member of the PEG, but the nomination was blocked by China's delegation, which questioned Lo's qualifications. The vacancy has been left open since then.

Taiwan in turn retaliated last year by initially objecting to the candidacy of China's Zhang Yuejiao to be a member of the Appellate Body under the WTO's trade dispute body, but under tremendous pressure from other member states and the secretariat, Taiwan eventually gave in.
The overall atmosphere of this year's PEG selection provided a dramatic contrast to the acrimony of previous years.
According to sources in Geneva, Taiwan and China reached a tacit agreement to support each other's candidate prior to the election while lobbying for support from other countries.
The relationship between Taiwan and China in the WTO would normally be best described as confrontational due to political differences.

It is still unclear if the turnaround has anything to do with the transfer of power in Taiwan to President Ma Ying-jeou, who has strongly advocated a "diplomatic truce" and better relations with China.
Senior officials, trying to play down the political significance of the latest development, said all WTO member states claimed that they elected the experts on the basis of "merit."

The PEG is a body of five independent experts that may be requested to assist a panel, provide an advisory opinion on the existence and nature of any subsidy, or be consulted by any members on the nature of any subsidy it intends to introduce or currently maintain.

The term for a PEG member is five years, and the results of the election are retroactive to the time when the vacancy opened. Due to the three-year delay, Lo's actual term will be shortened to two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nine hotels in Tainan offer discounts through earth-friendly program

TEXT.P: Nine hotels in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan signed an agreement Friday to join an earth-friendly program that gives up to 55 percent discounts to customers who bring their own towels, tooth brushes, soap, toothpaste and shampoo.
The program was presented with the blessing of the Environmental Protection Bureau under the Tainan City government.

The nine hotels are Evergreen Plaza Hotel, Tayih Landis Hotel, La Plaza hotel, Hotel Tainan, Hotel Dynasty Tainan, the Taipung Suites, Wei-Yat Toong Mao Grand Hotel, Cambridge Hotel, and Top Royal Hotel.

The Evergreen Plaza Hotel, one of two five-star hotels in Tainan, pledged to lower the price for a single room from NT$5,600 to NT$2,599 and the price for a double room from NT$6,200 to NT$2,799, if customers bring their own personal hygiene necessities.
The Wei-Yat Toong Mao Grand Hotel also offered to reduce the price for two from NT$4,800 to NT$2,188, if the same requirement is met.

Officials at the Environmental Protection Bureau noted that some of the hotels had already offered the earth-friendly program for some time, and that the agreement they signed was intended to increase awareness among the public to join the world's efforts to slow the global warming trend.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait detente will benefit East Asia: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that improvement in relations across the Taiwan Strait will benefit East Asian countries by ensuring regional stability and peace.

Ma made the remarks while meeting with Masaki Saito, the new head of the Taipei Office of the Japanese Interchange Association which represents Japanese interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
In the talks, Ma recalled that he had met with current Japanese Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda during a visit to Japan two years ago in his capacity as chairman of the then opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

At that time, Ma told Fukuda, who was then a member of the lower house of the Japanese Diet, that if the KMT regained power, Ma would take active steps to improve cross-strait relations and promote bilateral exchanges.

Ma said he admires Fukuda's insight, as the prime minister had given a thumbs-up to Ma's proposal by indicating that improved cross-strait relations and regional peace were basically in Japan's interest.

Over the past two years, Ma said, Tokyo-Beijing relations have made great strides, as evidenced by the frequent exchange visits by high-ranking officials and by military vessels. China and Japan have also reached a consensus on joint exploration of oil reserves in the East China Sea, he noted.
"All these developments are hard-won achievements over the 60 years since the end of World War II, " Ma noted, added that the new developments will contribute much to East Asian peace.
Moreover, Ma went on, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are also moving on a reconciliatory course and actively improving their relations.

"The simultaneous improvements in Taipei-Beijing and Tokyo-Beijing relations are new in the post-war East Asian arena and will definitely have a profound impact on East Asian peace, " Ma observed. Many American academics and think tanks share his views and are cautiously optimistic about East Asian developments amid improved cross-strait ties, the president added.

Turning to Taiwan-Japan relations, Ma said some people were worried about a possible negative impact on bilateral ties following the June 12 incident in which a Taiwanese recreational fishing boat sank after colliding with a Japanese coast guard patrol ship in waters near the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands.
Although the incident seemed to spark a confrontation between the two sides, no conflict actually erupted thanks to the mutual trust between the leadership of the two countries, Ma said.

"After Fukuda publicly called for a reasoned peaceful resolution of the issue, I immediately lent my full support to his appeal, and the two sides then resolved the issue step by step through peaceful consultations, " Ma recalled, adding that mutual trust was crucial to the satisfactory settlement of the issue.

For his part, Saito said he is lucky to be assuming his post at a time when Taiwan-Japan relations are proceeding very smoothly. With the mutual granting of visa-free entry for tourists from the two countries, Saito said, a total of 2.5 million visits have been recorded annually.

Japan is now Taiwan's second largest trade partner and Taiwan ranks fourth among Japan's major trade partners. Saito said he looks forward to the further strengthening of relations between the two countries during his tenure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Farm hotshots to cycle around Taiwan to promote rural tourism

TEXT.P: Two enthusiastic cyclists have been selected to cycle around Taiwan to help attract tourists to the country's 123 "charming villages, " a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Friday.

Chen Yu-chieh and Lu Ying-lung will team up to cycle through the 123 selected villages from Aug. 4 to Sept. 17 to promote domestic rural tourism and cycling, the official from the COA's Soil and Water Conservation Bureau said.

The duo were selected from five two-member teams of cycling enthusiasts under a "farm hotshot" project initiated by the bureau to champion cycling and rural tourism in line with the government's new "green policies" of energy conservation and carbon dioxide emission reduction, the official noted.
The selected team of "farm hotshots" is required to complete the cycling tour of 123 selected "charming villages" in 45 days, the official said.
They must also post articles detailing their cycling experiences and rural visits on the bureau's specially designed "Let's Go For Farming Fun" Web site every day during the tour.

At the end of the tour, the team will be given gifts worth more than NT$100,000, including brand-name bicycles and full accessories, multifunctional GPS equipment and mobile phone cards, the official added.

The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Japan to negotiate compensation to boat owner

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Andrew Hsia said Friday that representatives from Taiwan and Japan will begin negotiations to compensate a Taiwanese captain whose recreational fishing boat sank in a collision with a Maritime Safety Agency of Japan (JMSA) vessel in June.
Hsia made the remarks after presiding over a meeting with the boat owner Ho Hung-yi and officials from Taiwan and Japan.

"Both sides reached an agreement in the meeting that they will each designate legal experts and representatives to negotiate in Taipei on the compensation issue so as to settle the matter quickly," Hsia said.
The Japanese side took with them the details of the damage, provided by Ho, and will indicate "within one week" when the negotiations will start, Hsia added.

A ministry official also said that Ho, his crew members and the anglers who were onboard the boat when it sank all wanted the negotiations to be held in Taipei. They agreed that the Taipei county government will provide a lawyer, and that the MOFA and the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture will help to negotiate with Japan on compensation.

The official related that Japanese officials from Interchange Association, the de facto Japanese embassy in Taipei, expressed confidence that the Japanese government will honor its pledge and will handle the compensation issue in accordance with the relevant law.
The Japanese will respect Ho's wishes and the JMSA will hire a lawyer to negotiate with him on the compensation matter, according to the official.
On June 10, Ho's ship carrying recreational anglers sank in waters near the Tiaoyutais after it collided with a Japanese patrol vessel.
The Tiaoyutais, located 102 nautical miles to the northeast of Taiwan, are claimed by Japan, Taiwan and China.
The boat owner Ho Hung-yi was released three days after he was detained by Japanese authorities on the Japan-controlled island of Ishigaki.

Director of the General Affairs Department under the Taipei Office of the Interchange Association later called on Ho at his home in Rueifang, Taipei County and expressed regret on behalf of the Maritime Safety Agency of Japan over the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 2, or the second day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: William II, known as "William Rufus," king of England from 1087, is slain by an arrow while hunting in New Forest. He was succeeded by his younger brother, who became Henry I.
1798: A 14-vessel naval squadron commanded by Rear Adm. Horatio Nelson scores a brilliant tactical victory over a French fleet of 17 vessels in the Mediterranean.
1918: British, French, and U.S. troops try to smash Lenin's communist revolution by supporting the White Russian forces and seizing Archangel.
1921: Enrico Caruso, the Neapolitan with the golden voice known as the world's greatest tenor of his time, dies at the Hotel Vesuvio in Naples at the age of 48.
1922: Alexander Graham Bell, Scottish inventor of the telephone in 1876, dies at the age of 76.
1923: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, dies in office at the age of 58. He made several misguided appointments that led to a corrupt administration.
1924: The Kwangchow government sets up the Central Bank of China with T.V. Soong (Soong Tzu-wen) as governor.
1934: Paul von Hindenburg, German general, politician, and president of the Weimar Republic, dies at the age of 86. He was succeeded by Adolf Hitler who declared himself "Der Fuhrer."
1938: Chinese troops blow up a bank along a section of the upper Yangtze River in an attempt to slow a Japanese advance.
1939: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, writes to U.S. President Roosevelt urging him to start an atomic project.
1944: Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., U.S. Navy pilot and elder brother of John F. Kennedy, is killed when his plane explodes over the Belgian coast.
1945: The Potsdam Conference, the final Allied summit of World War II, comes to an end.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Dahomey, Niger and Upper Volta.
1961: President John F. Kennedy and visiting ROC Vice President Chen Cheng issue a joint statement in Washington, D.C., opposing the admission of mainland China into the United Nations.
1964: President Lyndon B. Johnson orders a retaliatory strike after a torpedo attack on the U.S. Navy ship Maddox in the Gulf of Tonkin.
1980: The International Telecommunications Administration inaugurates direct dialing station-to-station telephone service between Taipei and major cities in Britain, France and West Germany.
1985: Kuo Yu-hsin, former member of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, dies of illness in Washington, D.C., at the age of 77.
1986: The ROC delegation to the Aug. 4 ROC-U.S. trade talks, headed by Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Vincent C. Siew, leaves for Washington, D.C.
1990: Saddam Hussein makes good on Iraq's claim to the oil-rich state of Kuwait by invading it. Thousands of heavily armed Iraqi troops quickly cut through the defenses of their tiny Gulf neighbor and gain firm control of the capital city of Kuwait City.
1996: Michel Debre, former French prime minister, dies at the age of 84. He was Charles de Gaulle's trusted aide and the architect of the Fifth Republic.
1996: Typhoon Herb roars across northern Taiwan, leaving nearly 60 people dead or missing.
1999: The ROC representative to Japan, Chuang Ming-yao, expresses his grave concern to his Japanese counterpart about a plan by a group of Japanese lawmakers to land on the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea.
2000: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan leads a delegation of senior KMT officials to pay a courtesy call on ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh at the DPP headquarters in Taipei.
2000: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records announces two of Taiwan's record-setting fathers as part of celebrations for Father's Day, which falls on Aug. 8. One of the record-breakers is Lo Tseng-wen, who has five children serving as police officers, and the other is Chang A-piao, a centenarian who is living with four generations of offspring under the same roof.
2001: The final section of the 11.307-kilometer New Kuanyin Tunnel of the North Link Railway is blasted through, making it the longest two-way railway tunnel in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By banishing all flatterers and keeping away from the society of women; holding in low estimation possession of worldly goods, but valuing moral qualities in men: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to worthy men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Former president receives threatening letter

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian received Friday a threatening letter allegedly written by an individual sympathetic with a man who assaulted him around two weeks ago, the former president's office said.
The letter demanded that Chen retract a lawsuit filed against Su An-sheng over the violent incident and offer an open apology within three days, according to the office.
The letter threatened to harm Chen and his family as well as opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen unless Chen complies with the demands.
A similar letter was also received by the DPP, which later reported the situation to police.

Su, a staunch member of the pro-unification Concentric Patriotism Association of the Republic of China, kicked Chen in the lower back as he was entering the Taipei District Court building July 21 to defend himself in a defamation case.
Su was immediately sentenced to three days in jail by a summary court, and Chen, who sustained an injury to his lower spine, filed a suit against Su for physical assault.
Su had previously been convicted on attempted homicide, forgery and theft charges. He is high on a police watchlist as he has often taken part in public demonstrations and petition activities.
