DOC.HEADLINE: Number of Taiwan-backed digital centers to total 41 by end 2008

TEXT.P: Taiwan will have helped establish 41 digital opportunity centers in seven developing nations by the end of 2008 under an Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) initiative to bridge the digital divide, the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Saturday.

From August 2004 until mid-July 2008, 34 such centers had been set up in Chile, Indonesia, Peru, the Philippines, Papua New Guinea, Vietnam and Thailand, with more than 51,000 information and communications technology professionals in these countries trained through the program, according to the ministry's Bureau of Foreign Trade.
The APEC Digital Opportunity Center (ADOC) initiative was put forth by Taiwan in 2003 during an annual informal APEC leadership summit held in Bangkok, Thailand.
The goal was to use Taiwan's edge in information technology and digital experience to assist developing APEC member states in upgrading their information technology capabilities.

Through the project, Taiwan also hopes to enhance its global visibility, strengthen its friendship with other APEC member states, and help expand business opportunities for the country's businesses, the bureau said.

In preparation for the conclusion of the first phase of the ADOC initiative at the end of 2008, senior officials and business leaders from Taiwan will meet with their counterparts from other APEC member states during ADOC Week 2008, set for Sept. 29 to Oct. 4 in Taipei, to discuss issues concerning the promotion of the second phase of the initiative.

The proposal to launch a second-phase ADOC initiative was raised during the 2007 informal APEC leadership summit in Sydney, Australia by Stan Shih, founder of computer vendor Acer Inc, who attended the meeting as a special envoy of then- President Chen Shui-bian.

APEC is one of the few international organizations that admits both Taiwan and China as members. Due to China's opposition, Taiwan's president has been barred from attending the annual informal leadership meeting in person and instead has had to name a special envoy on his behalf.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cheap vegetables on sale at Taipei Hope Plaza this weekend

TEXT.P: The Agriculture and Food Agency is promoting fresh leafy vegetables from the central Taiwan county of Yunlin at Hope Plaza in Taipei this weekend, with bak choy on sale at NT$10 per bundle, agency officials said Saturday.
Yunlin County is Taiwan's largest leafy vegetable production center, and the major vegetable supplier to the Taipei metropolitan area.

Despite the devastation wrought by Tropical Storm Kalmaegi and Typhoon Fung-Wong to crops in the county over the past month, the county government will offer cheap vegetables at the plaza this weekend to offset surges in produce prices in recent days triggered by the storms.

A special sale on bak choy will be held every hour Saturday and Sunday, and consumers will also have a chance to buy limited quantities of garlic at the bargain price of NT$50 for 600 grams, the agency said.

Hope Plaza, located on the corner of the intersection of Xinsheng South Road and Bade Road, was built in 2001 by the Council of Agriculture (COA) to serve as an outlet for agricultural products from farms in central Taiwan that were destroyed by the 7.6-magnitude earthquake in 1999.
It has since evolved into a market where farmers' associations from around the country sell their produce directly to consumers.

Meanwhile, the COA will hold an activity at the north square in front of the Presidential Office to promote premium locally-grown agricultural products, and offer information on tours giving people a chance to experience the farming live in the countryside.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seminar on stadium project transportation ends in chaos

TEXT.P: Chaos erupted Saturday at a seminar on the transportation assessment of the Taipei Dome Complex, with local residents accusing the city government and the project's contractor of colluding for profit and ignoring their concerns.

Charging that the project was planned and approved in a "black box," residents in the Xinyi, Daan and Songshan districts surrounding the designated site for the indoor stadium demanded that the contractor and the city reassess the project, and call it off if necessary.
Shouting matches erupted among the participants, with residents angry that they had been left out of three previous meetings at which transportation plans for the stadium complex were assessed.

The Farglory Group, which signed a contract with the city government in October 2006 to manage the project on a BOT (build-operate-transfer) basis, plans to invest more than NT$23 billion (US$ 700 million) in the 429,000 square meter complex -- called the Taipei Culture and Sports District or "Taipei Dome."

Before it can begin work on the complex, however, the city government must assign the land rights to Farglory and give it the necessary building permits, which are contingent on passing a transportation assessment.

The complex, to include a 40,000-seat indoor stadium with surrounding shopping and residential districts and scheduled to be completed by 2010, will be located on the site of the historic Songshan Tobacco Factory at the corner of Zhongxiao East Road and Guangfu South Road in Taipei.
Local residents fear that the stadium will create traffic nightmares in an already congested part of the city.
"This is collusion between businessmen and government officials," one of the residents shouted.It is self-evident that the government is profiting a certain conglomerate.

Aaron Huang, a consultant of the nongovernmental Global Talentrepreneur Innovation and Collaboration Association and area resident, told the Central News Agency that the opinions of the residents were totally excluded from the decision-making process.

No one from the company or the government has ever consulted us and every meeting they have had was under the table, he said.We will not accept the fact that they are holding this seminar just to 'notify' us of what they plan to do.

But Tsai Chung-yi, an executive in Farglory's public affairs department, told the Central News Agency that on the advice of the city government, the company had invited transportation experts to previous meetings to help assess congestion issues related to the plan.
Those experts, Tsai said, were in fact representing the interests of local residents.
At the seminar, Farglory presented supporting measures to ease congestion, but Kuomintang Taipei City Councilor Lee Ching-yuan, said the measures were useless and impractical.
To build such a big complex right in the heart of the city is absolutely preposterous, Lee said.No advanced countries or even the Olympic stadiums in Beijing were built in the city center.

He urged the project to be reviewed again, arguing that Taipei City Mayor Hau Lung-bin should not accept the deal without questioning an incorrect decision made by his predecessor and now Taiwan's president, Ma Ying-jeou.
Democratic Progressive Party Taipei City Councilor Hung Chien-yi said the project would definitely paralyze transportation in the area.
"It is not only a joke but also has no chance to succeed, Hung said.The rights of the general public are sacrificed for the profits of a big company."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan banks' overdue loan ratio down slightly in June: FSC

TEXT.P: Domestic banks' overdue loan ratio stood at 1.55 percent at the end of June, down 0.06 percentage points from the previous month, the Executive Yuan's Financial Supervisory Commission said Saturday.

As of the end of June, Taiwan banks' outstanding loans amounted to NT$18.11 trillion (US$589.04 billion), up NT$119 billion over a month earlier, while their overdue loans stood at NT$281.2 billion, down NT$8.7 billion, the commission said.
Of Taiwan's 37 banks, a total of 36 had outstanding loan ratios of lower than 5 percent, including 29 with outstanding loan ratios of under 2.5 percent, according to the commission.
It said that Taiwan banks' outstanding loan ratio has been declining gradually since July 2007 when the figure stood at 2.35 percent.
The commission added that it will continue to monitor banks with high outstanding loan ratios and take active steps to improve the quality of their assets and financial structures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan gearing up for Pony League World Series

TEXT.P: Taichung City's Shi Yuan Senior High School will be looking for its second global crown in three years when it represents Taiwan at the 57th Pony League Baseball World Series set to kick off next Saturday in the United States.
The Taiwan squad will take on the U.S. North Zone winner Aug. 8 in its opening game at the eight-team tournament for 13-14 year olds being held at Lew Hays Pony Field in Washington, Pennsylvania.
Shi Yuan High School gained the right to represent the Asia-Pacific Zone at the world series with victories over Japan and South Korea in a qualifying tournament in Seoul on July 22.
Taiwan has been a dominant force in the Pony League over the past decade, representing the Asia-Pacific zone at the world series seven times since 1997.
The string of success included Shi Yuan High School's appearance at the 2005 tournament, which they won in convincing fashion.

If Taiwan beats the U.S. North Zone team in next Saturday's opening contest, it will go on to play the winner of the matchup between Gurabo, Puerto Rico and Johnstown, Pennsylavnia for a spot in the semifinals.
The championship game is slated for Aug. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 20% of soybean-based food products in Taipei sub-standard

TEXT.P: Nearly 20 percent of soybean-based food products recently tested in Taipei City were found not to meet food safety standards, the municipal government's Department of Health said Saturday.
Chiang Yu-mei, head of the department's Food and Drug Division, said that of the 61 products tested around the city in June, 12 failed to meet the city's food safety standards.
Six of the products contained excessive levels of the food preservative benzoic acid, while six contained hydrogen peroxide, which is banned in food products in the city, Chiang said.
Five of the soy-based products that failed the safety test were sold in Huan-nan Market. A majority of such items sold in Taipei City are processed at factories in Dasi township, Taoyuan County.
Hydrogen peroxide, which is chiefly used to kill bacteria and as a bleaching agent, can cause damage to the human body if ingested in large amounts.
Some of the symptoms of ingesting the chemical include headaches, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and even ulcers, Chiang said.
She urged citizens to thoroughly wash and soak tofu products they purchase for at least 20 minutes to get rid of any hydrogen peroxide that the food items might contain.
Chiang added that although benzoic acid can be used in soybean-based food products in amounts of up to 0.6 grams per kilogram, it can cause damage to the kidney and livers.

Noting that washing and soaking are not helpful in removing benzoic acid because it does not dissolve in water, Chiang urged people to cook their tofu products in a covered pot and then remove the lid just after the tofu is ready to allow any residual benzoic acid to evaporate.
She added that this is also effective for removing hydrogen peroxide.
The department urged residents of the city to only purchase soybean-based products produced and sold by reputable companies and retail outlets in order to avoid substandard products.
It said that anyone who suspects a food product may not measure up to food safety standards can report the matter to the municipal government by phoning the 1999 hot line or dialing (02) 2720-8889.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expects progress in U.S. arms procurement in September
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 1 (CNA) 08/02/08 16:29:52 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes the United States will make progress in pushing through its arms procurement requests in September, following the conclusion of the Beijing Olympic Games later this month, Taiwan's Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng said in the United States Friday.
Wang made the remarks prior to his departure from New York for Taipei after wrapping up his nine-day U.S. visit that also took him to Washington, D.C.
Wang said he had good discussions with U.S. officials on the arms issue and that the process should have helped resolve U.S. doubts about Taiwan's determination to acquire the weapon systems.

Wang said the U.S. side repeatedly reassured him that the administration of President George W. Bush has not frozen arms sales to Taiwan and will definitely comply with related provisions of the Taiwan Relations Act in handling the matter.

According to the speaker, if the items are to be passed before the U.S. Congress adjourns on Sept. 16, the Bush administration would need to submit notifications for the weapon systems to Congress for review by Aug. 16, midway through the Beijing Olympics, which end Aug. 24.
"We hope there will an outcome in September," he said.

Wang said he does not think China will try to pressure the United States into scrapping the deals during Bush's upcoming China visit to attend the Aug. 8 Olympic opening ceremony, because they are requests that have been under discussion for a long time.
There have been reports that the Bush administration is holding back on the congressional notifications so as not to upset relations with China ahead of the Olympic Games.
Timothy Keating, commander of the U.S. Pacific Command, fueled speculation last month that Washington might indeed have frozen the screening process when he talked about defense ties with Taiwan.

He said policy-makers in the administration have "reconciled Taiwan's military posture, China's current military posture and strategy that indicates there is no pressing, compelling need for, at the moment, arms sales to Taiwan."

The list of military hardware reportedly being held up include anti-tank missiles, Apache helicopters, Patriot PAC-3 missile batteries, diesel-powered submarines, P3C anti-submarine aircraft and sea-launched Harpoon missiles.
However, in response to Keating's remarks, the U.S. Department of State reiterated that Washington has not changed its policy on arms sales to Taiwan.

State Department spokesman Sean McCormack said July 18 that the administration "faithfully implements the Taiwan Relations Act" and that there is an "internal interagency process" for the U.S. government to consider all military exports, including sales to Taiwan.
"When the interagency process achieves a final decision for specific arms sales, we will notify Congress," he said.

Concerned about the administration's delays in screening the pending weapon sales to Taiwan, a group of 23 members of the U.S. House of Representatives sent a joint letter to Bush July 31 urging his administration to expedite consideration of the sales.

Also, the group of congressmen, led by Shelley Berkley (D-Nev.) and Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) , co-chairs of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus, requested that the administration brief Congress on the status of sales.
The move came one month after a group of 14 senators sent a similar letter to Bush June 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ball teams to miss out on cash award if they finish last in Beijing

TEXT.P: Are Taiwan's taxpayers ready to pay NT$21.6 million to reward a team finishing in last place at the Beijing Olympics?

The Sports Affairs Council decided on Friday that they were not, issuing revised guidelines that will require Taiwan's baseball and softball teams to finish at least sixth in their eight-team Olympic tournaments to earn cash prizes.

The council announced on Friday adjustments to its guidelines on paying "Guo Guang scholarships" and awarding medals to athletes who excel at the Olympic Games to account for the specific competition formats of the 15 events in which Taiwanese athletes are entered.
Under the Sports Affairs Council's existing program, athletes finishing in the top eight in their events are eligible for cash awards.

Gold medalists will receive NT$12 million, silver medalists NT$7 million, bronze medalists NT$5 million, fourth-place finishers NT$3 million, fifth- and sixth- place finishers NT$1.5 million and seventh- and eighth-place finishes NT$900,000.
But the council faced a dilemma as the Olympic baseball and softball tournaments feature only eight teams.

Had the baseball team finished last in its event, which would likely include an embarrassing loss to host China, each of its 24 players would still have received NT$900,000, or a total of NT$21.6 milion, under existing guidelines.
Under the revised reward program, the baseball and softball teams will receive monetary rewards if they place sixth or better and will receive a medal for finishing seventh.
The original guidelines will still apply to athletes competing in track and field, swimming, weightlifting, archery, shooting, rowing, sailing and cycling.
In taekwondo and judo, competitions that finish with two third-place, fifth- place and seventh-place finishers, local athletes will be awarded based on those placings.

In tennis, badminton and individual table tennis events, where no distinction is made between quarterfinal losers (fifth to eighth place) , local athletes in those tournaments who are ousted in the quarterfinals will receive an NT$1.2 million award.

Medal winners will be able to collect their rewards in a lump sum or as a lifetime monthly annuity, with gold medalists earning NT$75,000 per month, silver medalists NT$38,000 per month and bronze medalists NT$24,000 per month.

Taiwan will send 80 athletes to the games, to be held in Beijing Aug. 8-24. They will hope to improve on the country's showing in Athens in 2004, where Taiwan won a total of five medals, two golds, two silvers and one bronze.

Taiwan's four entries in taekwondo could all contend for medals, depending on their draws and the mood of the often arbitrary judges. Taiwan's archery teams are also seen as having chances to repeat their medal-winning performances at Athens.
Other hopefuls include Chuang Chia-jung and Chan Yung-jan, who hope to overcome some stiff competitors from China, Spain, Ukraine and the United States to win glory in the women's doubles in tennis.

DOC.HEADLINE: More local Olympians to set off for Beijing Sunday

TEXT.P: The second of five groups of local Olympians will set off for Beijing, China, on a China Airlines (CAL) flight via Hong Kong Sunday.

Taiwan's Olympic delegation, comprising 80 athletes and 57 coaches and administrators, is heading to Beijing in five separate stages based on their different competition timetables, with Sunday's group the biggest of them all.

Headed by Chef de Mission Tsai Szu-chuen and Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) Secretary-General Chen Kuo-i, the delegation will include 19 athletes competing in badminton, archery, swimming, shooting, rowing and judo, nine coaches and 17 administrators.
The first group of Olympians -- five weightlifters and a sailor -- and their coaches left for China Thursday.

Athletes competing in tennis, softball, women's table tennis, and track and field will depart this Thursday, and the high-profile baseball team, as well as the men's table tennis and cycling teams, will set off next Sunday.

Taiwan's four taekwondo athletes, who are likely to carry the aspirations of their country for gold on their shoulders, and their coaches will leave for Beijing on Aug. 15, ahead of the opening of the taekwondo competition on Aug. 20.
Taiwan's Chu Mu-yen hopes to become the country's first repeat gold-medal winner as he defends the under 58-kilogram flyweight crown he won in Athens in 2004.
The travel schedule will enable popular tennis players, Chan Yung-jan and Chuang Chia-jung -- dubbed the "Golden Doubles Duo" -- to take part in the Games opening ceremony Aug. 8.
Chan and Chuang were runners-up in women's doubles at two grand slam events -- the Australian Open and U.S. Open -- in 2007 and will be the top seeds in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung promotes hot line for male victims of domestic violence

TEXT.P: The Taichung City Government promoted Saturday a hot line targeting male victims of domestic violence ahead of Father's Day on Aug. 8 to help them overcome their disinclination to seek help for fear of losing face.

Jhang Guo-huei, chief of the city's Department of Social Affairs, reminded the public that the 0800-013999 hot line was set up especially to provide male victims a viable channel to deal with their problems and urged victims of abuse not to hesitate to call.

"Confined by their traditional social image, most men suffering from domestic violence lack the courage to speak up, resulting in many male victims hiding in different corners of society, " Jhang noted.

According to statistics compiled by the city's domestic violence and sexual assault prevention and control center, a total of 784 cases of violence among married couples were reported in the city during the first six months of this year, and in 6 percent of the cases, or 47, the victim was the husband.

The results of a survey of 512 residents released Saturday by a Taichung-based civil group revealed that 85 percent of respondents had no idea there is a hot line for male victims of domestic violence.
Among the 174 male respondents, only 20 percent said they would ask for help in the event of them becoming a victim.
The reasons mentioned by respondents for not seeking help included that doing so would embarrass them or make them laughed at by others and that the hot line number was difficult to remember.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to define his concept of 'workable diplomacy'

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will meet with former foreign affairs ministers Sunday to discuss his ideas on the nation's diplomacy, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Saturday.
Wang said Ma will host a dinner in honor of former foreign affairs ministers at the Taipei Guest House during which he will address his concept of "workable diplomacy."

Ma first floated the notion, under which Taiwan would engage China in discussing Taiwan's international space, during a trip overseas while serving as chairman of the Kuomintang between 2005 and 2007.
Ma will also visit the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Monday to discuss the idea of a "diplomatic truce" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
"The president hopes to elaborate on his ideas on Taiwan's diplomacy through the two events," the spokesman said.

Wang noted that the previous administration, under then-President Chen Shui- bian, had engaged in "bull in a china shop" diplomacy, which although helping Taiwan gain new diplomatic allies, also let many more slip away.
Taiwan currently maintains diplomatic relations with 23 nations.
"The new government cannot identify with the confrontational and scorched-earth approach adopted by the previous administration, " Wang said.
A Presidential Office official said "workable diplomacy" will form the basic tenet of Taiwan's diplomatic activity.

Ma has stressed in the past that China and Taiwan should stop their "meaningless competition" in the international community, and that the two sides should not only stop the diplomatic tug-of-war, but should also improve cross-strait relations.
The improvement of cross-strait relations will form the basis of the nation's diplomatic development, the official added.
Since Ma's inauguration on May 20, frosty cross-strait relations have gradually thawed, with Taiwan easing restrictions on commercial exchanges and opening weekend cross-strait charter flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: NGO urges enterprises to hire more disabled people

TEXT.P: The Eden Social Welfare Foundation on Saturday urged the government to strengthen training programs for the disabled in preparation for a new regulation that will create more job openings for people with disabilities next year.

Under revisions to the Protection Act for Rights and Interests of (Physically and Mentally) Disabled Citizens that will take effect next July, at least three percent of the positions at public companies, government agencies and education institutions with staffs of more than 34 workers should be reserved for the disabled.
Also, private enterprises and institutions with staffs of more than 67 workers will be required to staff 1 percent of their workforce with disabled workers.
At present, the staffing requirements only apply to public institutions with at least 50 employees and private companies with at least 100 employees.
The foundation estimates that the law's revisions will create 4,000 job opportunities for the disabled next year.

"Having a mental or physical disability is not equal to lacking capability, " said Huang Jow-song, the foundation's chief executive officer, who hoped that the value of the labor of local disabled workers would be reassessed.
Advertising executive Jerry Fan, himself confined to a wheelchair, urged enterprises to hire more disabled people, who are, he said, stable and optimistic and have high EQ (emotional quotients).
"If you think that blind people can only make a living by giving massages, they will never have a chance to do other things, " Fan said.

Fan gained prominence for his political commercials that helped former President Chen Shui-bian win the presidency in 2000 and later was one of the organizers of a campaign to oust Chen in 2006 because of suspected corruption in the Presidential Office and the first family.

Dorothy Tao, president of the Chinese Human Resource Management Association, said that while the existing law had helped some disabled individuals to find jobs, there were still companies that preferred to be fined rather than adjust their hiring practices.
Citing a survey that the foundation conducted in July, Tao noted that more than 70 percent of employers are satisfied with the attitudes of disabled workers on the job.
Many of them, however, also criticized professional training programs for the disabled as not meeting their needs.

Tao acknowledged that the programs provided by the government and welfare organizations may be outdated and not aligned with Taiwan's labor market, and stressed that cooperation between the government, welfare organizations and the private sector was necessary to raise the employment rate of disabled people.
The foundation said existing training programs tend to focus only on document processing, which is already a basic skill in Taiwan.
In 2006, the unemployment rate among the disabled was about 15 percent, according to the foundation, nearly four times higher than the 3.92 percent rate for society as a whole.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nine foreign women nabbed for prostitution in Yunlin

TEXT.P: Nine foreign women and 22 men have been arrested in Yunlin County in south- central Taiwan for involvement in the sex trade, the Coast Guard Administration said Saturday.
Coast guard said the nine women -- three from Vietnam, five from Indonesia and one from the Philippines -- were engaged in prostitution.
Of the 22 men, some were customers while others were suspected of being involved in smuggling the women into Taiwan.
All 31 suspects were turned over to the Yunlin Prosecutors Office by the coast guard after questioning.
The coast guard noted that the nine women had not had HIV tests administered by health authorities, and suggested their customers may be at risk of contracting the sexually transmitted disease.

Coast guard officials said the latest raid followed a previous bust in the county July 29, in which a human trafficking ring formed by a trio of two Taiwanese men, Tsai Hsi-yen and Sun Wen-ping, and a Vietnamese woman was taken into custody.
The coast guard also arrested 13 foreign women during the raid.
Yunlin prosecutor Lee Wen-chieh decided to expand the investigation after questioning the suspects and the 13 women.
Lee mobilized nearly 160 policemen and law enforcement officials to mount the raid Friday night and Saturday morning at eateries, karaoke bars, shrimp farms and barber shops in the county.

DOC.HEADLINE: Concert marks Studio Classroom founder's 60th anniversary in Asia

TEXT.P: Peng Meng-hui, the founder of Studio Classroom, is a household name in Taiwan, a symbol of learning English for many generations of Taiwanese citizens.
The name Studio Classroom and the image of the silver-haired teacher Peng tend to well up in their minds when they study English.

Now at 82, Doris Brougham, Peng's real name, is still energetic and exuberant. She gets up early to work, recording English classes in the studio, editing English teaching magazines, learning computer skills and teaching swimming and music.
She has even secured a diving license, enabling her to roam beneath the sea to get a closer look at the dazzling marine world.
Having grown up in a classic American Christian family in Seattle, Brougham traveled to China in 1948 at the age of 21 to serve as a missionary.
Three years later, she evacuated to Taiwan due to the civil war raging on the Chinese mainland. She has since taken residence in Taiwan and has obtained permanent residency status.

Local Christian groups organized a thanksgiving concert Saturday to celebrate Broughan's 60th anniversary in Asia. Sixty pastors from three generations gathered to extend their highest esteem for her through lyrical songs.
Many of her students from around Taiwan also attended the concert to express their gratitude for her tireless service in Taiwan.
Broughan remained humble despite the praise and thanks heaped on her. After 60 years of dedication to ministering, education and social services, Broughan said she has never thought of retirement.
"I always think that I'm in my 60s. The celebration party only reminded me and even let more people know that I'm actually 82 years old," she jokingly complained.

Broughan recalled that her life is full of challenges and surprises. "Whenever an ideal or goal occurs to me, I tend to strive to realize it. I never thought that I might not be able to do it or easily abandon the goal," she recalled.

When she was young, she admired the sound of the trumpet and immersed herself in music study. She attended a music college and received a diploma after completing a rigorous musical education. In Taiwan, she has not only taught English on air but also music at many local colleges and universities.
Full of curiousity, Brougham finds interest in many things. She began to learn scuba diving at the age of 56 and began to learn computers at 60.

"I never think that I'm old. Keep on going is my motto. Now, I not only have a diving license and have often taught others swimming and diving. I'm now also a computer geek and I'm trying to promote English study online," she added.
With three-fourths of her life spent in Taiwan, Brougham said she still has many dreams to be realized. "Retirement is not in my dictionary," she added.
Taiwan's economy was still underdeveloped when Brougham arrived in the island. She first worked in Hualien, a backwater on the country's east coast.

She traveled around rugged mountain villages for five years, ministering to aboriginal people there. Later on, she moved to Taichung and then Taipei to spread the Christian faith, recording radio programs to get out the word of the gospel.

In those years, many Taiwanese students were not good at English and were too poor to study English at cram schools. She decided to dedicate herself to English education, founding Radio Classroom to offer English courses over the air.
On Aug. 1, 1962, the Studio Classroom English radio program was broadcast for the first time and over the years became a "mecca" of English study for many young Taiwanese students.

Over the years, Brougham has also spent much time raising funds for disadvantaged people and prison inmates. She sent Studio Classroom magazines to prisons and encouraged inmates to study English to enrich their lives.
Saying Taiwan has become part of her life, Brougham said she will stay here for good. "I hope Taiwan will 'keep on going' like me," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing Olympic torch displayed at Taipei computer show

TEXT.P: A Beijing 2008 Olympic Games torch appeared at the Taipei Computer Application Show Saturday and will be on display until the event ends Monday.

The torch was flown in from Beijing Saturday morning but it was unclear if it had been used in any part of the torch relay that circled the world amid controversy earlier this year, or if it was a spare model held in reserve.
The main Olympic torch currently touring China was in Tianjin Friday and Saturday and was scheduled to circle Sichuan province for three days beginning Sunday before returning to Beijing.
The worldwide Olympic torch relay did not stop in Taiwan due to protests against a move by the Beijing Games organizers to list Taiwan as one of the domestic stops on the route.

Benjamin Ou, general manager of the Lenovo Group's Taiwan branch, said that the show provided a rare occasion for people in Taiwan to view the torch, which was designed by Lenovo, the largest personal computer manufacturer in China.
It took 10 months for a premium design team organized by Lenovo and comprised of 34 specialists in 10 scientific fields to create the torch, Ou said.
Named "xiang yun, " literally "lucky clouds, " the torch was selected for the 2008 Olympic Games after beating out the designs of 387 other international and Chinese teams.

Ou said the torch's design was inspired by three elements -- the traditional Chinese symbol that represents "luck, " paper, one of four major inventions of the Chinese people, and the color red, which represents good fortune and joy in Chinese culture.
On the Beijing Olympic Games's official Web site, the torch, made of aluminum, is said to embody the concepts of a "Green Olympics, a High-tech Olympics and the People's Olympics."

The torch relay triggered protests in many countries, coming soon after Beijing's bloody suppression of a protest launched by monks in Tibet in March that called for greater cultural and political autonomy.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGScramble to rescueG12bn deal for nuclear plants
Ministers are fighting to salvage a G12 billion deal to secure Britainsfuture as a nuclear power producer after rebel shareholders blocked the sale of British Energy to the French company EDF at the eleventh hour.

DOC.HEADLINE: Model father sad about old fishermen's life

TEXT.P: Lin Liang-chun, 69, a fisherman from the remote Niaoyu islet in offshore Penghu County, shined with joy after being honored as a "model father" Saturday, but expressions of sadness still flashed on his wrinkled face when he reflected on the life of an old fisherman.
A resident of Niaoyu since birth, Lin said there was once a time when local fishermen could always depend on a good catch of silver herring.

Now, he lamented, the area's fish resources seemed exhausted as the size of local catches were slumping badly. This year, fishermen caught no fish at all in the traditional silver herring season in July, Lin said.

Without fish to catch and constant hikes in fuel prices, Lin said, he has seldom ventured out on his fishing boat over the past few months and has survived on the NT$6,000 monthly pension he receives from the central government.
He did sail his own boat to Makong, the main island of the Penghu archipelago off the western coast of Taiwan, for the award ceremony, even if it cost him NT$500 in gasoline to make the trip.
Despite his hardships, Lin received the honor for raising four children on limited means and participating in social welfare activities to help his fellow islanders.
He now hopes that the government will understand the difficult life he and other fishermen like him face and take better care of them in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: President demands better flood control planning

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou ordered the Taipei county government Saturday to come up with a comprehensive flood control plan within one month.
Ma gave the directive after inspecting a water pumping station in the northern county's Sinjhuang City to review its Taliaokeng River cleanup and flood control work.
The president was accompanied by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, Deputy Magistrate Lee Hung-yuan and Sinjhuang Mayor Hsu Ping-kun.
Lee, a hydraulic power expert, said Taiwan has spent much money on flood control projects over the past years, but the results have been lackluster.

Noting that the Legislative Yuan already passed an eight-year NT$110 billion special budget for various flood prevention projects around Taiwan and is expected to pass another budget plan worth NT$40 billion in the near future, Lee said he doesn't think that all those projects will be able to settle Taiwan's thorny flooding issue once and for all because they were designed with "old thinking."

"Traditional ways, such as building sluice gates, embankments and pumping stations, cannot resolve our nightmarish flooding problems," Lee noted, adding that Taiwan needs a new way of thinking to tackle the issue.

Pointing out that flood prevention work requires a broad vision and comprehensive planning, Lee said the central government should not have had a single agency -- the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs -- assume the tough task solely.
"Inter-agency coordination as well as cross-city and cross-county cooperation are needed to draw up and carry out a comprehensive flood control project," Lee explained.
In his view, Lee went on, the existing Taliaokeng River flood control project embodies the flaw of the logic of traditional flood prevention measures.

Under the existing project which was initiated by Chou's predecessor Su Tseng- chang, the Sinjhuang water pumping station has been built, which can pump out 100 tons of floodwater a second. To date, the project has cost more than NT$8 billion and an additional NT$2 billion will be spent in the future.

But Lee said the river's upperstream is located in neighboring Taoyuan County where many land development projects have been underway. During stormy days, floodwaters in the Taliaokeng River often reach 250 tons per second.

"Against this backdrop, the pumping station is no cure to the nightmare of flooding in Sinjhuang, " Lee lamented, adding that building a water catchment in Taoyuan County will be a more effective way to alleviate the headache.
Echoing Lee's view, President Ma said he hopes the Taipei county government can come up with a new macroview flood prevent project within one month for the Cabinet's reference.
For his part, Premier Liu said that if necessary, the central government will assist in cross-county coordination to facilitate flood control work.

Moreover, Liu said he will direct the central-level Water Resources Agency to refer to Taipei county's flood prevention experience in reviewing various flood control projects in other parts of the country in two weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mirage readiness rate higher than standard: MND

TEXT.P: The readiness rate of Mirage jet fighters has consistently stood above the standard set by the Ministry of National Defense (MND), the military said Saturday.

The Military Spokesman's Office (MSO) issued the statement after a local evening paper reported earlier in the day that the Combined Logistics Command was negligent and slack in carrying out its Mirage spare parts procurement mission.

According to the United Evening News, the logistics command spent six months procuring just 41 of the more than 400 Mirage spare parts that the air force needed to meet it emergency demand. The shortage embodied the command's serious dereliction of duty.
In response, the MSO said in the statement that the average delivery period for overseas procurement ususally needs 22 to 24 months.

The statement further said the Combined Logistics Command has never been lax in fulfilling its duty. Noting that the command has categorized the air force's spare parts procurement into three classes -- principal, urgent and crucial importance, the statement said the command has often nudged foreign contractors or suppliers to deliver on Taiwan's orders on schedule.

With an above-standard availability rate, the statement added that the air force's Mirage fleet can effectively implement their mission of combat preparedness. Taiwan now has 57 French-made Mirage flighters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 3, or the third day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
216: An army led by Carthaginian General Hannibal defeats a huge Roman army, seizing its supply depot in the Battle of Cannae and killing some fifty thousand Roman soldiers.
1460: Scottish King James II is killed by the English during the siege of Roxburgh Castle.
1492: A flotilla of three ships, led by Christopher Columbus, sets sail from the Spanish port of Palos de la Frontera in search of a land called India.
1867: Stanley Baldwin, British Conservative prime minister three times between 1923 and 1937, is born.
1872: Haakon VII, Norwegian monarch who refused to surrender to the Germans in World War II, is born in Denmark.
1881: William George Fargo, American pioneer of long-distance express service, dies at his home in Buffalo, New York, at the age of 65.
1904: The Dalai Lama flees Lhasa as British troops invade Tibet. The Ching court on Aug. 26 orders the Pachen Lama to take over Tibetan affairs from the Dalai Lama.
1916: German troops launch a surprise attack on British forces in the Sinai in Egypt. Some 5,000 German soldiers are killed, while British loses amount to 1,100 men.
1929: Emile Berliner, German-born American inventor, dies in Washington D.C. at the age of 78. He greatly improved the telephone and invented the gramophone in 1887.
1940: Lithuania is formally incorporated into the Soviet Union as the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic.
1958: Nautilus, the U.S. atomic submarine, becomes the first vessel to reach the North Pole under the ice.
1959: Japan Airlines formally inaugurates its Tokyo-Taipei route.
1967: The ROC Executive Yuan decides to extend the period of compulsory education from six to nine years beginning in 1968.
1969: Minister of Economic Affairs K.T. Li (Li Kuo-ting) receives the 1968 Ramon Magsaysay Award for government service.
1972: Sheng Chin-lai is appointed dean of the Engineering College at Chiaotung University.
1972: Brig. Gen. William C. Buttows, new chief of staff of the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command, arrives in Taipei.
1973: The Flying Tiger Line inaugurates air freight services between Kaohsiung and New York.
1974: Economics Minister Y.S. Sun and Paraguayan Minister of Industry and Commerce D. Ugarte Centurionuan sign an agreement in Taipei to boost economic cooperation between the Republic of China and Paraguay.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives eight members of the U.S. 14th Air Force Association, including Mrs. Anna Chennault, widow of the 14th Air Force's commander, Maj. Gen. Claire Lee Chennault.
1977: A US$100 million loan agreement is signed in Taipei between the Taiwan Power Company and 17 banks from five foreign nations.
1981: President Ronald Reagan orders the firing of 12,000 striking air traffic control workers.
1986: Construction of the Synchronous Radiation Research Center under the Executive Yuan is started at the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park. It is scheduled for completion within five to six years.
1988: Mathias Rust, a West German youth who landed his light air plane near Moscow's Red Square in 1987, is released from prison and expelled from the Soviet Union.
1999: Nine renowned scientists and former intelligence and military officials send a letter to all 100 U.S. senators calling for the prompt ratification of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty to prevent the weaponization of stolen nuclear secrets by Communist China.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian directs the ROC Air Force to draw up a forward- looking blueprint for developing a new generation of warplanes to ensure supremacy in the skies over the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By extending the powers of their functions and allowing them discretion in the employment of their subordinates: that is how a ruler gives encouragement to the high ministers of state."

TEXT.P: The readiness rate of Mirage jet fighters has consistently stood above the standard set by the Ministry of National Defense (MND), the military said Saturday.

The Military Spokesman's Office (MSO) issued the statement after a local evening paper reported earlier in the day that the Combined Logistics Command was negligent and slack in carrying out its Mirage spare parts procurement mission.

The statement further said the Combined Logistics Command has never been lax in fulfilling its duty. DOC.HEADLINE: President demands better flood control planning

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou ordered the Taipei county government Saturday to come up with a comprehensive flood control plan within one month.
Ma gave the directive after inspecting a water pumping station in the northern county's Sinjhuang City to review its Taliaokeng River cleanup and flood control work.
The president was accompanied by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, Deputy Magistrate Lee Hung-yuan and Sinjhuang Mayor Hsu Ping-kun.
Lee, a hydraulic power expert, said Taiwan has spent much money on flood control projects over the past years, but the results have been lackluster.

Noting that the Legislative Yuan already passed an eight-year NT$110 billion special budget for various flood prevention projects around Taiwan and is expected to pass another budget plan worth NT$40 billion in the near future, Lee said he doesn't think that all those projects will be able to settle Taiwan's thorny flooding issue once and for all because they were designed with "old thinking."

"Traditional ways, such as building sluice gates, embankments and pumping stations, cannot resolve our nightmarish flooding problems," Lee noted, adding that Taiwan needs a new way of thinking to tackle the issue.

Pointing out that flood prevention work requires a broad vision and comprehensive planning, Lee said the central government should not have had a single agency -- the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs -- assume the tough task solely.
"Inter-agency coordination as well as cross-city and cross-county cooperation are needed to draw up and carry out a comprehensive flood control project," Lee explained.
In his view, Lee went on, the existing Taliaokeng River flood control project embodies the flaw of the logic of traditional flood prevention measures.

Under the existing project which was initiated by Chou's predecessor Su Tseng- chang, the Sinjhuang water pumping station has been built, which can pump out 100 tons of floodwater a second. To date, the project has cost more than NT$8 billion and an additional NT$2 billion will be spent in the future.

But Lee said the river's upperstream is located in neighboring Taoyuan County where many land development projects have been underway. During stormy days, floodwaters in the Taliaokeng River often reach 250 tons per second.

"Against this backdrop, the pumping station is no cure to the nightmare of flooding in Sinjhuang, " Lee lamented, adding that building a water catchment in Taoyuan County will be a more effective way to alleviate the headache.
Echoing Lee's view, President Ma said he hopes the Taipei county government can come up with a new macroview flood prevent project within one month for the Cabinet's reference.
For his part, Premier Liu said that if necessary, the central government will assist in cross-county coordination to facilitate flood control work.

Moreover, Liu said he will direct the central-level Water Resources Agency to refer to Taipei county's flood prevention experience in reviewing various flood control projects in other parts of the country in two weeks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Cementing Taipei-Washington ties should be top priority: ex-rep
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 2 (CNA) 08/03/08 16:14:53 (By Chiehyu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's departing representative to the United States stressed on Saturday the importance of maintaining close ties with Washington and suggested that Taipei give U.S.-Taiwan relations priority over relations with other countries and areas.

"The administration should make efforts to bolster Taipei-Washington relations as its top diplomatic and national security strategy," said Joseph Wu, who wrapped up his 15-month stint as Taiwan's top representative in the U.S. capital Friday.
Wu and his wife and son departed from Washington, D.C., Saturday for Los Angeles, where they will spend one day before heading back to Taiwan Tuesday.

Wu, the first Democratic Progressive Party member to serve as Taiwan's top envoy to the U.S., said before leaving the U.S. capital that he felt proud to have lived up to his promise to act in the interests of the country rather than any specific party in strengthening U.S.-Taiwan relations.
"My most important achievement is traveling all over America and raising Taiwan's visibility in the U.S. and the world, " Wu said.

He explained that over the past 15 months, he has toured around America to meet U.S. officials, academics, mass media and mainstream Americans to sell Taiwan and help U.S. leadership and opinion leaders better understand it.
Wu said he is especially moved and appreciative of the support he received from Taiwanese expatriates across the U.S. during his tenure.

He was originally scheduled to return to Taiwan July 26 but stayed on for another week in order to host four visiting legislative delegations, including one led by Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng.
The lawmakers were in Washington, D.C., recently mainly to iron out U.S. concerns and doubts about Taiwan's plans to purchase defensive weapon systems from the U.S.
Wu is being succeeded by Jason Yuan, Taiwan's former representative to Canada who has been the Kuomintang and People First Party representative to the United States since 2004.
Yuan, set to assume office Monday, said recently that his top priority after assuming the post will be to mend fences with the United States and rebuild mutual trust.

DOC.HEADLINE: Buddhist Tzu Chi group urges Taiwanese to be earth-friendly

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Tzu Chi Foundation is urging the people of Taiwan to be more earth- friendly by changing some of their rituals during "ghost month" -- the seventh month of the year according to the lunar calendar.

Master Cheng Yen, a Buddhist nun and founder of the foundation, is spearheading a campaign to turn "ghost month" into an "auspicious month" by encouraging people to change worship rituals that are detrimental to the earth's environment.

During this year's "ghost month," which runs from Aug. 1 through Aug. 30, many local residents will observe the time-honored tradition of offering sacrifices and burning incense and ghost paper money in temples or in front of their homes to appease the wandering spirits.
According to legend, on the first day of the ghost month, the gates of the netherworld are opened to allow the ghosts a month of feasting in the land of the living.
The Ghost Festival -- the high point of "ghost month" that comes on the 15th day of the seventh lunar month -- is mainly a Taoist practice.
It coincides with the Buddhist Ullambana Festival on the same day when monks will feed hungry ghosts to deliver them from suffering in the spirit of promoting filial piety.

In an appeal posted on its Web site, the Tzu Chi Foundation urged people observing the festival not to burn ghost money, because every kilogram of paper money they burn will release 1.5 kilograms of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere -- a practice that will cause air pollution and harm human health.

The foundation quoted a United Nations task force as saying that humans are 90 percent responsible for the global warming problem, which has triggered repeated natural disasters and plunged mankind into a crisis that should not be neglected.
"The resources on earth are limited. Insatiable human desires will only bring unfathomable calamities. The single best solution lies in reducing greenhouse gas emissions," the foundation said.
The foundation called on people to donate the funds originally intended for burning ghost money to charities and use flowers and fruit in lieu of animal sacrifices for their worship rituals.

In their respective messages delivered in memory of the 28th anniversary of the 1980 bomba attacks at the Bologna railway station, Speaker of the House of Deputies Gianfranco Fini urged the citizens to leave the shadow of the massacre aside, while Bologna Mayor Sergio Cofferati criticized those who are in power for trying to rewrite the history.

DOC.HEADLINE: Registration required for lobbying, lobbyists

TEXT.P: People who lobby government officials for help will be required to register and publicly disclose their activities beginning Aug. 8, when the Lobbying Act goes into effect.
The Legislative Yuan passed the lobbying bill in July 2007, making Taiwan the third country after the United States and Canada to enact such legislation.

The law defines lobbying as any direct contact with lobbyable public officials, by verbal or written means, with the purpose of influencing the official's or his agency's attitude toward the formation, enactment, passage, alteration or annulment of legislation, policies or initiatives.
Lobbyists can be individuals, legal entities, or civic groups soliciting help on their own behalf or individuals or corporations that lobby on behalf of others.

The lobbyable officials are elected or appointed public officials at national or local levels, including the president, vice president, elected representatives, heads of local governments and political appointees.

The legislation prohibits lobbying on matters related to national defense, foreign affairs, China policy, national security, civil servants' duties, or the activities of foreign governments or international nongovernmental organizations in Taiwan.
According to the legislation, agencies that are potential targets of lobbyists must designate a special unit or official to accept the lobbyists' registration.
Within seven days after being approached, the officials should register with the designated unit or official to record the date, venue, method and content of the activity.
Lobbyists must also report lobbying expenditures to the concerned agencies by May 31 every year, and the concerned agencies should publicize financial reports quarterly.

Within three years of their leaving office, the president, vice president, political appointees appointed by the president and heads of local governments cannot lobby, in person, through their proxies or on behalf of others, agencies that they served in for five years before leaving office.
Any foreign governments, legal persons or groups intending to lobby Taiwan public officials must entrust a domestic lobbyist to do so on their behalf.

However, no individuals, legal entities or groups from China, Hong Kong and Macau are allowed to lobby Taiwanese public officials, regardless of whether they lobby directly or operate through proxies.
In addition, any persons who have been convicted of sedition, treason, graft, organized crime, fraud, embezzlement or breach of trust are forbidden from lobbying on others' behalf.
Incumbent elected representatives and their associates cannot lobby for enterprises that they operate or those in which they have a stake of more than 10 percent.

Any undisclosed lobbying activities, violations of the revolving door restrictions, and unlawful lobbying by elected representatives and their associates are punishable by fines of up to NT$2.5 million (US$82,000), according to the legislation.

The National Teachers' Association welcomed Sunday the imminent implementation of the act, saying that it would force lobbying activities to move in a more positive direction as the law requires open and transparent operations.

The John Tung Foundation, an anti-smoking group seen as one of the most effective nonprofit lobbying groups in Taiwan, also welcomed the legislation, but worried it would give commercial interests a greater edge in influencing legislation and policy-making.

Lin Ching-li, a foundation official in charge of public affairs, said the requirements forcing lobbyists to register in advance and report their expenditures afterward would considerably increase the administrative costs of social welfare groups but have little impact on wealthier corporate interests, such as tobacco companies.
Lin was concerned the moneyed interests would end up "crowding out" the voices of public interest groups.
Lin Lu-hung, a top aide to Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Huang Sue- ying was also skeptical.
"There will be a big grey area between 'lobbying' and 'written requests,'" the legislative aide said, noting that lawmakers' offices receive many written requests for help every day.

Since the Lobbying Act does not regulate written pleas from constituents, future lobbyists may use this option to make their case, which would force legislative aides to determine on their own if these documents constitute "lobbying" or are simple "requests for help, " Lin Lu-hung said.
If they were defined as "lobbying, " the aide wondered if that meant constituents would have to register their approach in advance.
"Just thinking about having to help register on behalf of others gives me a headache," she lamented.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Chinese dissidents denied entry to Hong Kong before Olympics

TEXT.P: Two overseas Chinese dissidents who traveled to Hong Kong Saturday to push for political reform in China ahead of the Beijing Olympic Games were denied entry and deported to Taipei Saturday night.

Pan Qing, chairman of the Chinese Liberal Democratic Party, and Qin Jin, vice chairman of the Federation for a Democratic China, arrived in Taiwan a few days ago to visit friends and then flew to Hong Kong Saturday to join a protest march cheduled for Aug. 6.

But when Pan, a citizen of New Zealand, and Qin, a citizen of Australia, arrived in Hong Kong on a morning flight from Taiwan, they were denied entry by immigration authorities for violating Hong Kong's Immigration Ordinance.
They were put on a flight bound for Taipei Saturday night after being questioned by Hong Kong immigration authorities.

The pair said they had planned to use the stage of the Olympic Games, slated for Aug. 8-24 in Beijing, to raise political issues, including calling for an end to one-party rule in China and pushing for economic reforms and social security.
Rejected by Hong Kong, Pan and Qin said they will hold activities in Taiwan in the coming days to express their concerns.

DOC.HEADLINE: Search for missing businessmen off Madagascar continues

TEXT.P: Stung by criticism from the victims' families, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday it would continue to assist in search efforts for seven Taiwanese nationals missing off the coast of Madagascar since July 11, even after the first round of search operations ends Sunday.

The ministry said in a statement that it understands the sorrow of the victims' families and would continue to provide whatever help necessary to continue the search, such as translation, legal consultation and other technical assistance.
The help will be given through a 13-member task force composed of Taiwanese expatriates in Madagascar and former diplomatic officials posted in the country, the statement said.

The ministry's statement was issued after members of two of the victim's families returned to Taiwan from southern Africa and expressed their dissatisfaction over the ministry's handling of the incident and over reports that it has decided to stop funding the search for those missing.
Eight Taiwanese businessmen went missing July 11 after the boat they chartered to tour an ocean aquaculture facility off the coast of northeastern Madagascar ran into trouble.
Among them, Liu Shou-chin was found dead July 14.

Following the conclusion of the first phase of search operations, the ministry insisted it would continue to keep in touch with relevant rescue agencies in Madagascar and send personnel stationed in South Africa to help the families deal with the aftermath of the incident.

Since learning of the case, the ministry has assigned more than 160 tasks/missions to staffers and overseas diplomatic officials and spent over NT$3 million to help with the search mission, including arranging for a 10-hour helicopter search, a 22-hour aircraft search and 32-hour search at sea, but to no avail, the statement said.

The ministry attaches great importance to the search mission and has been providing legal assistance to the families as prosecutors in Madagascar are still waiting for the results of an investigation to determine the cause of the incident.
The ministry also said it was told that Madagascar rescue teams have not stopped their search for the missing businessmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Web page apathy not related to diplomatic truce: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is looking into why a MOFA Web page listing examples of China's suppression of Taiwan has not been updated since the end of last year, but denied it had anything to do with the government's desire for a "diplomatic trucewith China.
"We are now looking into the matter and will update the information as soon as possible, MOFA spokesman Henry Chen told the Central News Agency.

According to the Chinese-language daily Liberty Times, the foreign ministry should update the site every three months to inform the public of incidents in which Beijing thwarts Taiwan's participation in various international political, economic, trade, sports or cultural events.

However, such information has not been updated since December 2007, which the Liberty Times contended could be misinterpreted by the international community as an indication that no such incidents had occurred this year.

The report said Beijing, in fact, has not relaxed its suppression of Taiwan's international space this year, citing its successful effort to block Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization on May 19 and recent attempts to downgrade Taiwan by changing the name of Taiwan's Olympic team.

Although the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration was in power until May 20, the paper described the failure to update the page as "self- disarmamentunder the government's "modus vivendi" diplomatic strategy that involves a "diplomatic truce" with China.
After taking office May 20, President Ma Ying-jeou declared he would seek adiplomatic trucewith China in an attempt to end a longstanding diplomatic tug- of-war between the two countries.
In response to the report, Chen said posting such information is a routine job similar to posting public travel advisories or information on overseas diplomatic missions.
It has nothing to do with a diplomatic truce,he stressed.
Chen said the government took office May 20 and the foreign ministry did not know why the previous administration failed to update the information from January to May.

DOC.HEADLINE: Regulatory maze restricts imports of fine European foods

TEXT.P: Gourmets in Taiwan may feel frustrated at having to do without Italian Parma ham, fresh foie gras, or other fine meat-related items from Europe that are being kept out of Taiwan by the country's time-consuming and complex export application procedures.

During an informal conversation with Central News Agency reporters, a frustrated European diplomat complained that they were denied access to some high-quality European foods because of the byzantine Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures (SPS) imposed by Taiwan's authorities.
He thought it was a shame that local gourmets, including himself, are being deprived of the pleasures of some of the finest foods in the world.

According to the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, only ham from Hungary, Sweden, Denmark, Holland and Finland has been approved to be exported to Taiwan, leaving the famous Italian prosciutto di parma out of reach.
As for fresh fois gras, don's even think about it unless you can evade the stringent SPS regime.

"It may take a long time, from several months to two or three years, for foreign companies to complete the filing of an (export) application, " said a bureau official, and even then, there is no guarantee the permit will be granted.
The official said the European exporter is first required to file an application with Taiwan's government, before local officials visit the company for an on- site inspection.

More often than not, those foreign companies give up in the initial stage, faced with an endless barrage of questions that can prove overwhelming, said the European diplomat who insisted on anonymity.
"But Taiwan's regulations are not stricter than in other countries, " the Taiwanese official argued, adding that Italian and French companies have never filed an application.

The official admitted that some individuals may bring in small quantities of foie gras or ham from abroad, but that is a matter for the Customs' Bureau to investigate when travelers arrive at Taiwan's international gateways.
Regardless of the restrictions on certain delicacies, top restaurants in Taiwan still have to find a way to satisfy, or lure, clients with deep pockets who care little of the price tag.
When approached by CNA reporters, chefs and owners of those restaurants described the dilemma they faced between following regulations and serving heavenly dishes.

A law-abiding owner of a French restaurant in Taipei said that in the case of fresh foie gras, he followed the government's regulations and tried to make do with less flavorful canned foie gras, or by using chicken and duck livers as a substitute.
But some restaurants admitted that they can still find access to obtain ingredients that have not been approved for import.
"It is always possible to get fresh foie gras through certain traders, " a person in charge of a high-class French restaurant said candidly. "We can find everything in Taipei."
His restaurant provides genuine foie gras to satisfy fastidious clients, but certainly the price doesn't come cheap.
As a pragmatic businessman, he admitted it would not serve his interests to stubbornly negotiate with government agencies on the issue.

Whether merely strict or in fact excessive, SPS measures often constitute non- tariff trade barriers. But the European diplomat noted that since the trade volume is too small, the EU has not considered bringing the case to the World Trade Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vehicle catches fire in Hsuehshan Tunnel; no one injured

TEXT.P: A sedan caught fire in the Hsuehshan Tunnel shortly after noon Sunday, but firemen from Taipei County were able to rush to the scene within 10 minutes to put out the blaze. No one was injured.

According to the National Highway Traffic Control Center, the car was traveling northbound on the National No. 5 Freeway when it caught fire 5.5 kilometers into the tunnel, apparently as a result of spontaneous combustion.
The center immediately enforced emergency traffic control in the tunnel, allowing firemen to reach the scene swiftly and extinguish the fire.

The 12.9-km Hsuehshan Tunnel is the second longest road tunnel in East Asia and the fifth longest road tunnel in the world. Inaugurated in June 2006, it is the centerpiece of the 55-km No. 5 Freeway linking Taipei with Yilan in northeastern Taiwan.
The tunnel has cut travel time between Taipei and Yilan County from more than two hours to about 30 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Kaohsiung men than women take their own lives in 2007

TEXT.P: Considerably more men committed suicide than women in Kaohsiung in 2007, according to statistics released Sunday by the city government's Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
The statistics show that 276 residents of Kaohsiung -- Taiwan's second largest city -- committed suicide last year, comprising 173 men and 103 women.
Most of the men who died by suicide were aged between 35 and 44, while most of the women who took their own lives were aged between 25 and 34.
A report prepared by the statistics agency said many of those who committed suicide were either jobless, disabled or suffering from a chronic illness.
It said the city government needed to improve the employment environment in Kaohsiung and provide timely emergency aid to help reduce the suicide rate.

Suicide now ranks ninth among the top 10 causes of death in Kaohsiung, with cancer being the No. 1 cause, followed by heart disease, diabetes, stroke, pneumonia, kidney disease, accidents, liver cirrhosis, suicide and hypertension- related diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former mayor's whim has become a city's white elephant

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Mounted Police Unit, the brainchild of former acting Mayor Chen Chi-mai, has become a white elephant in the cash-strapped harbor city and may soon be disbanded.
After failing to find a stable that will lease them horses, the 20-odd police officers of the unit, which was one of Chen Chi-mai's proudest achievements, could soon be laid off.

Founded in 2005, the unit became the country's first mounted police force and was the pride and joy of the city with its members chosen among the ranks of the city's policemen for their good looks and excellent physical condition.
They spent a month and a half developing their horsemanship and were dressed in specially designed uniforms that carried a price tag of more than NT$100,000 (US$3,256).
When they were on duty, usually at the city's scenic sites, tourists rushed to take photos of them sitting atop their horses.

The then-acting mayor created the unit to boost tourism in the city, and, in fact, it was always more of a tourist magnet than a force dedicated to maintaining law and order, as it rarely issued tickets or fines.
The fate of this beautiful prop now hangs in the balance, as no stable has been willing to lease horses to the unit for the NT$6 million budget earmarked by the city for the purpose.

Under the contract proposed by the city, the stable must provide four horses for the unit per day on weekdays and more than four on weekends and holidays when more visitors descend on the city's popular scenic areas.
That means the contracted stable needed to send out its horses 500 times a year for NT$6 million, or NT$12,000 per horse per day out on Kaohsiung's streets.

It may sound lucrative, but with the prices for horse feed and other items needed to care for the horses having increased sharply recently, no bidder is interesting in the contract, leaving the officers of the unit stranded in their splendid uniforms in their office since the beginning of this year.

Many city councilors have branded the mounted police unit as a whim of Chen Chi- mai and called for its dissolution, but Mayor Chen Chu is reluctant to ax it out of concern that it will offend her predecessor in City Hall.
With half of the year already gone, the officers of the unit are still confined to their office waiting anxiously, wondering if they will ever again be able to rejoin their equine partners on duty.

DOC.HEADLINE: China to get less of Taiwan's outward investment in 2008

TEXT.P: The share of Taiwan's outward investment directed at China is expected to decline dramatically this year as a result of China's harsher investment climate, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Sunday.

MAC Vice Chairman Fu Dong-cheng predicted new outward investment by Taiwanese businesses in China this year will be less than 50 percent of all local investment made abroad, a steep decline from China's 60.7 percent share in 2007.

Fu said the share of local investment headed to China is declining due to its implementation of a new labor contract law and higher corporate income taxes since the beginning of the year, coupled with an appreciating Chinese currency.
Citing statistics compiled by the Investment Commission, Fu said "China fever" hit its peak in 2005, when 71.7 of Taiwan's outward investment was directed at China.

He attributed the 2005 figure to regulatory approvals allowing contract chipmakers Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and United Microelectronics Corp. to produce less sophisticated wafers in China.
In 2006, the amount of China-bound Taiwanese investment declined to constitute 63.9 percent of Taiwan's total outward investment, a figure that shrank further to 60.7 percent last year, Fu noted.

The MAC vice chairman believed that the continuing decline in 2008 reflected the growing trend of Taiwanese businesses to further globalize their operations and recognition that China is no longer necessarily the best option.

Since the implementation of China's new labor contract law at the beginning of the year, the owners of Taiwanese companies in China who did not have well- structured human resource policies have seen their labor costs rise, particularly for workers who have served over 10 years.

At the same time, corporate income taxes for businesses located in China's coastal cities have risen to 25 percent from the 15 percent preferential tax that was previously in place for foreign-invested companies.

Exporters in China have also had to contend with the appreciating Chinese yuan, which has gained 18 percent in value compared to the U.S. dollar since July 2005, when the Chinese authorities reformed statutes governing currency exchange.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan orchestra kicks off Berlin music festival
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Aug. 3 (CNA) 08/03/08 21:17:36 (By Lin Yu-li and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Philharmonia Moment Musical, a non-professional symphony orchestra, gave the opening concert at the Young Euro Classics Festival in Berlin Friday and earned the acclaim of an audience of nearly 1,500 people.
The festival is one of the few music festivals dedicated to the advancement of international youth orchestras and the promotion of new compositions.
Since it was founded in 2000, the festival has each year attracted more than 10 orchestras composed of top young musicians from all over the world to show off their talent.
The festival is considered to be one of the most important events on the city's summer calendar.

This year's concert was opened by Philharmonia Moment Musical, conducted by young violinist Chiang Ching-po and composed of around 65 musicians aged 17-28. It marked the first time an orchestra from Taiwan had performed at the festival.

Although Germany maintains close economic and cultural ties with Taiwan, its people's understanding of Taiwan is still limited, and the concert gave Germans a good opportunity to get to know Taiwan better, an official from the Berlin city government said prior to the performance.
This year's festival will also include concerts staged by orchestras from China, Germany, Britain, Finland, Azerbaijan and Kazahstan, the official added.

The repertoire of the Taiwanese ensemble included Lai Deh-ho's "Moment Musical" -- a concerto for the bamboo flute, a wind instrument called a "xiao, " the "pipa, " or Chinese lute, and a chamber orchestra -- and Mahler's Symphony No.5.
At the end of their performance, the young musicians were given a standing ovation, and the conductor stepped forward and bowed many times thanking the audience for its applause.
Chiang said he was proud of the ensemble members' performance since they had to overcome many challenges in performing a concert in a foreign country.

Lu Li-li, head of the group, said it was an unforgettable memory for all of the members to perform in an international music festival, but worried that the orchestra still was NT$2 million short of the NT$7 million it has cost to perform overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: President touts "workable diplomacy" to strengthen foreign ties

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Sunday that his first state visit next week to Paraguay and the Dominican Republic will be based on "workable diplomacy, not only to cement bilateral ties with Taiwan's allies but to rebuild mutual trust with countries that do not have formal relations with Taiwan.
We want everybody to know that we will not use the stopovers (in the United States) to do anything that conflicts with the purpose of transit stops, Ma said.
"We hope that such efforts will be fully understood and will reverse some of the distrust (between Taiwan and the U.S.) that has resulted in the past eight years.
Ma will stop over on the west coast of the U.S. on his way to and from Latin America during his Aug. 12-19 trip.

Speaking at a dinner attended by former foreign ministers at the Taipei Guest House, Ma said his concept of "workable diplomacy, " formally translated by his aides as a "modus vivendi" strategy, built on their work.
The spirit of workable diplomacy is very much in line with the 'pragmatic diplomacy' promoted by former foreign ministers in the past, Ma said.
"That is how to use the strength we have -- hard power and soft power -- to cement ties with diplomatic allies and expand cooperation with other countries,he said.

The strategy's goal, the president said, is to safeguard the rights of the Republic of China while consolidating diplomatic relations with allies and restoring mutual trust with countries that heavily influence Taiwan even without formal diplomatic ties.

Those concepts will be tested during his trip to Latin America, where he is scheduled to attend the inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo on Aug. 15, and the inauguration of Dominican President-elect Leonel Fernandez Aug. 16.
Lugo hinted during his campaign that he was considering breaking ties with Taipei to recognize Beijing.

Noting that bilateral relations between Taiwan and China play an important part in the island's foreign diplomacy, Ma said that the significantly improved and stable relations between Taipei and Beijing since he took office on May 20 have also contributed to a better relationship with the U.S.
I'm pleased to see that U.S. President Bush expressed his satisfaction two days ago regarding current relations on both sides of the Taiwan Strait,he said.

In an interview Friday in Washington with the Peoples Daily and the Central China Television network on the eve of his trip to Beijing to attend the opening of the Olympic Games, Bush said that relations between Taiwan and China are currently in abetter place."

Since Ma's inauguration on May 20, frosty cross-strait relations have gradually thawed, with Taiwan easing restrictions on commercial exchanges, opening weekend cross-strait charter flights and allowing in more Chinese tourists.

President Ma was joined at the dinner by Kuomintang honorary Chairman and former foreign minister Lien Chan, KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi, foreign minister Francisco H.L. Ou, and former foreign ministers Frederick Chien, Ting Mao-shih, Jason Hu, Tien Hung-mao and Chen Chien-jen.
Ma will also visit the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Monday to discuss the idea of adiplomatic trucebetween Taiwan and China.
He has stressed in the past that China and Taiwan should stop theirmeaningless competitionin the international community and also improve cross-strait relations.
