DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 4, or the fourth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1578: The Portuguese King Sebastian and his court are killed in a failed crusade to Morocco.
1875: Hans Christian Anderson, Danish writer famous the world over for his fairy tales and stories, including "The Princess and the Pea" and "The Ugly Duckling," dies in Copenhagen at the age of 70.
1906: The Education Ministry of the Ching court promulgates a set of "regulations on education for women" governing the establishment of schools for women.
1914: World War I breaks out when German troops invade Belgium. Britain declares war on Germany as the United States declares its neutrality.
1916: Denmark sells the Danish Virgin Islands to the United States for US$25 million.
1922: Fighting breaks out in Italy between the fascists and the socialists.
1938: The Nationalist government moves its offices from Wuchang and Hankow to Chungking in order to cope with the lengthy War of Resistance Against Japan.
1940: Italian troops invade the country of British Somaliland in East Africa.
1942: David Russel Lange, New Zealand Labor politician, is born. He served as prime minister from 1984 to 1989 and was controversial for his refusal to allow nuclear-armed ships to dock in New Zealand.
1944: Anne Frank, a 14-year-old German Jewish diarist, and seven other Jews in hiding in Amsterdam, are captured by the Gestapo and sent to concentration camps.
1950: Gen. Douglas MacArthur dispatches a high-ranking aide to Taipei as a liaison officer as the United States begins providing military aid to Taiwan.
1954: The P-1 English Electronic Lightning, Britain's first supersonic fighter plane, makes its maiden flight.
1960: Chung Li-ho, a noted Taiwanese folk tale author, dies at the age of 45.
1963: The Foreign Ministry declares that the Republic of China will not recognize the border treaty signed between the Peking regime and Afghanistan.
1967: Malawian President Dr. H. Kamuzu Banda arrives in Taipei for an eight-day state visit.
1972: Ugandan President Idi Amin declares that his country will expel 50,000 Asians with British passports within three months.
1976: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang extends its "deepest sympathy" to victims of the earthquake that struck northern China.
1979: Ho Yen-sheng, former Saigon correspondent for the China Times of Taipei who had been stranded in Vietnam since 1975, arrives in Taipei from an isolated island in the South China Sea where he spent 70 days as a refugee.
1986: ROC-U.S. trade talks begin in Washington. During the five-day talks, the ROC agreed to abandon its use of duty tables as of Oct. 1, 1986.
1990: Iraq installs a nine-man puppet government in Kuwait and sets up a new "People's Army" to control the regime while 12 European Community nations ban oil imports from Iraq, impose an arms embargo on the country and suspend most trade with Iraq.
1993: Japan formally apologizes for the first time to women forced to serve as sex slaves for Japanese soldiers during World War II.
1993: The Japanese Cabinet resigns, ending 38 years of rule by the Liberal Democratic Party.
1999: British Defence Secretary George Robertson becomes the new secretary- general of NATO, succeeding Javier Solana.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Mayor Tarmile Ishoda of Majuro sign a pact of alliance in Taipei, making Majuro, capital of the Marshall Islands, the 44th sister city of Taiwan's capital.
2000: Government Information Office Director General Chung Chin says that the GIO is mapping out procedures for setting up exchanges across the Taiwan Strait of journalists for long-term postings.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By dealing loyally and punctually with them in all engagements which he makes with them and allowing a liberal scale of pay: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to men in the public service."

DOC.HEADLINE: Try lobbying law first: legislative speaker

TEXT.P: Commenting on the impending institution of the Lobbying Act, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said although there is ample room for improvement regarding the design and implementation of the law, people should try it first and discuss it later.
"It surely takes time before a law can be legislated perfectly and implemented smoothly," Wang said.

With the Lobbying Act slated to go into effect Aug. 8, Wang suggested that the people try to live with it and reach a consensus on questionable points and then seek amendments to eventually perfect the law.
"Amendments can be made in the future, if necessary," he added.
The Legislative Yuan passed the lobbying bill in July 2007, making Taiwan the third country after the United States and Canada to enact such legislation.

The law defines lobbying as any direct contact with lobbyable public officials, by verbal or written means, with the purpose of influencing the official's or his agency's attitude toward the formation, enactment, passage, alteration or annulment of legislation, policies or initiatives.
Lobbyists can be individuals, legal entities, or civic groups soliciting help on their own behalf or individuals or corporations that lobby on behalf of others.

The lobbyable officials are elected or appointed public officials at national or local levels, including the president, vice president, elected representatives, heads of local governments and political appointees.
People who lobby government officials for help will be required to register and publicly disclose their activities, according to the law.
Within seven days after being approached, the officials should register with the designated unit or official to record the date, venue, method and content of the activity.
Lobbyists must also report lobbying expenditures to the concerned agencies by May 31 every year, and the concerned agencies should publicize financial reports quarterly.

Any undisclosed lobbying activities, violations of the revolving door restrictions, and unlawful lobbying by elected representatives and their associates are punishable by fines of up to NT$2.5 million (US$82,000), according to the legislation.

DOC.HEADLINE: More foreign enterprises thinking about moving away: local job bank
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, August 4 (CNA) 08/04/08 14:02:59 (By Yeh Fang-hsun and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: A recent poll conducted by a local job bank showed that over one-third of Taiwan-based foreign enterprises have no plans for recruitment this year and more than half of them are cutting back on personnel costs, with over 2 percent planning to close their Taiwan operations.

"With the slowdown in global economic growth and widespread inflation thinning the consumer market everywhere, internationally based enterprises are suffering a bigger blow than locally based ones," 1111 Job Bank's Chief Operating Officer (COO), Ryan Wu said at a press conference at which he announced the poll results Monday.

According to official tallies updated in June, there are 3,271 foreign companies currently registered in Taiwan. Although there is no clear evidence to indicate that most of these companies are thinking about moving out, there have been some recent runaway cases such as British department store Marks & Spencer and Japanese hypermarket Jusco, both of which closed their Taiwan business in the last eight months.
"Some 71.89 percent of the respondents in the poll said their business in Taiwan is shrinking compared to a year earlier," said Wu, citing a major problem facing foreign enterprises in Taiwan.

He said out of the 51.35 percent of respondents that indicated they are cutting back their expenses in the personnel area because of global inflation, 5.26 percent said they will retreat from Taiwan, which means that 2 percent of the total 185 companies surveyed are likely to quit the Taiwan market.

In addition, out of the 30.81 percent of respondents that said they have no recruitment plans for this year, 8.77 percent indicated that they intend to leave Taiwan, which also points to around a 2 percent departure, Wu said.

The results of the poll, conducted between July 18 to August 1, should send a warning to the government that Taiwan needs to improve its market conditions to entice foreign companies to stay, as they have been playing the important role of spurring industrial development in Taiwan's economy, Wu stressed.
"In addition to the negative global economic outlook, the changes in Taiwan's policies could also lead to falling revenues among foreign companies," the COO noted.

Wu suggested that the government upgrade local industries to higher knowledge- and-technology-concentrated business models, while putting together a better academic-industry cooperation plan in a bid to create more specialized human resources.
"With these potential changes, more international companies could be attracted to invest in Taiwan and increase their stakes here, " Wu said, adding that more jobs would also be created.

Representatives of foreign enterprises said at the news conference that the admission of more visitors from China as well as an injection of Chinese investment in Taiwan could help to improve the situation.
"As part of the service sector, we look forward to more cross-Taiwan-Strait visitors, " said Hiraide Soji, president of the Japanese Yakinku Restaurant in Taiwan.
He noted that over 1 million Taiwanese workers, who are paid relatively higher than most local employees, are based overseas, especially in China.
"The return of those workers with high purchasing power could bring more business opportunities to the service sector, " said Hiraide.

In another survey conducted by the job bank to identify the foreign companies that local office workers find most ideal, Citigroup Inc. topped the financial sector, Google Inc. the service industry and 3M Co. the manufacturing industry.

Meanwhile, 80.28 percent of the office workers surveyed said they wanted to work for foreign companies so that they could obtain good benefits, have a positive outlook on the companies' future and improve their foreign language skills. However, that percentage was lower than last year's 96.03, the job bank said.

In making their top picks from a multiple choice list, 56.8 percent of the respondents said they favored U.S. companies, 47.36 percent Japanese companies and 24.06 percent selected Singaporean companies.
The poll collected 1,187 valid samples, with a margin of error of plus or minus 2.8 percent at a 95 percent level of confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: Orphans from Malawi pay thank-you call on foreign ministry

TEXT.P: Thirty-five orphans from a shelter in Malawi founded by Taiwan-born Dharma Master Hui Li paid a call on the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Monday to express their gratitude to the MOFA for its long-term support of humanitarian aides in Africa.
The group of children, many of whom were orphaned by AIDS, are all from the Buddhist Amitofo Care Center (ACC) in Blantyre, a large commercial city in southern Malawi.

In addition to performing songs in Mandarin to express their sincere appreciation to the foreign ministry for its help over the years, the children also presented a short Taiwanese folk opera act. The presentation, which won resounding applause, was included Sun Tsui-feng, lead actress and wife of the founder of the well-known Ming Hwa Yuan Taiwanese Opera Company.

Over the past 17 years, the foreign ministry provided the greatest support to help us send love from Taiwan to Africa, " said Master Hui Li. "I believe that such humanitarian care and charity are what Taiwan should demonstrate to the world."

Praising Master Hui Lis devotion in helping impoverished families and educating thousands of children in Africa, MOFA Vice Minister Lin Yung-lo said that "these accomplishments are not only a reflection of Buddhist beliefs, but also of the kindness and concern of the people of Taiwan."

Seeing just how happy, optimistic and polite you children all are, I see in you a bright future for Africa and a reflection of the love that the people of Taiwan have shown you," he said. "I very much hope that the warmth and enthusiasm you feel here will make you want to call Taiwan your second home."

Fourteen-year-old Musiyen, who studied Chinese for three years, told the Central News Agency in Chinese that he would like to thank his Taiwanese adoptive parents for the chance to receive an education.
"When I grow up, I would like to become someone like Master Hui Li so that I can help other children like myself," he said.

During its trip to Taiwan Aug. 2-19, the group is slated to perform singing, dancing, Taiwanese folk opera and Shaolin kungfu in major Taiwan cities, including Taipei, Kaohsiung, Taichung, Tainan and Chiayi.
The Amitofo Care Center, operated by the Amitofo Care Association (ACA), has provided shelter, care and education for more than 2,000 Malawian orphans since its establishment in 2001.
ACA is building a similar care center in Zimbabwe, which will become operational early next year.
Dedicated to helping African children whose lives have been affected by AIDS, Hui Li has traveled around many African countries, including Malawi, Swaziland, South Africa, Zimbabwe and Cameroon.
Over the past 16 years, he has adopted or provided care and shelter for nearly 10,000 African AIDS orphans, earning the sobriquet African monk,while many children call him "daddy sent by Buddha."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Flower prices jump ahead of Chinese Valentine's Day

TEXT.P: Flower prices on the wholesale market Monday were up more than 20 percent in Taipei City ahead of Chinese Valentine's Day, which falls on Aug. 7 this year.
According to the Taipei Flower Auction Co., the average price of a bundle of flowers reached NT$71.9 (US$2.35), up 22 percent over the previous trading day's level.
The volume of flowers traded amounted to 95,809 bundles, up 17 percent over the previous trading day, the company said.
A flower industry source said that despite the increase, flower prices are roughly the same as during the period prior to Chinese Valentine's Day last year.

He suggested that consumers shouldn't worry about being forced to dish out large amounts for a bouquet for their loved ones, as a wide variety of roses -- the typical Chinese Valentine's Day flower of choice -- will be available at prices ranging from about NT$100 to NT$4,000 per bundle.
"You don't have to buy the most expensive kind of rose on the market, because after all, it's the thought that counts when giving a gift," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. trip focused on strengthening ties: legislative speaker

TEXT.P: Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Monday that his just-concluded U.S. visit was aimed at strengthening ties between the two countries in order to consolidate Taiwan's national security and help cross-Taiwan Strait interactions advance in a more peaceful and cooperative manner.

Wang made the comments while speaking with reporters outside the Legislative Yuan one day after his return from a nine-day visit to the U.S. at the invitation of the Heritage Foundation, which included stops in New York City and Washington, D.C.
Wang said the objectives of his visit reflected the direction in which the Taiwan people and government want to move in order to create a "win-win situation for everyone."

He said that although Taiwan and the United States are old friends, the relationship needs a "new beginning" and "new mutual trust" in order to strengthen the decades-old friendship between the two sides.

Wang related that he met with National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi prior to his U.S. visit at the request of President Ma Ying-jeou to exchange opinions and to be briefed on areas in which he could help the government's efforts in improving ties with the United States.

The topics discussed included the government's hopes for progress by Washington in pushing through Taiwan's arm procurement requests, expanding Taiwan's international space, and signing a free trade agreement with the United States, Wang said.
The legislative speaker said that he brought up these issues with high-level U.S. officials and legislators and that they now have a better understanding of Taiwan's position.

DOC.HEADLINE: Residents in Taipei urged to choose cold noodles carefully

TEXT.P: Residents in Taipei City should pay special attention to the hygiene conditions in places where they buy cold noodles, a popular dish in the hot Taiwan summer, a city health official said Monday.

The warning came after the city's Department of Health recently inspected 25 cold noodle products, 11 of which selected from local convenience stores, three from hypermarkets and 11 from other stores and vendors.
The inspection was aimed at checking levels of bacteria, hydrogen peroxide and borax in cold noodle products, said Chiang Yu-mei, director of the department's Food and Drug Division.

Initially, 10 of the samples failed to pass health standards, Chiang noted, adding that the health department demanded immediate improvements but later discovered that one noodle store's product was still below acceptable safety standards.
Violators face fines of between NT$30,000 (US$977) and NT$100,000, according to Chiang.
She pointed out that none of the inspected products were found to contain hydrogen peroxide or borax, but reminded customers that cold noodles should be kept at temperatures below 7 degree Celsius.
Chiang warned that bacteria in cold noodles will quickly multiply if they are kept at room temperature for more than four hours, which can render them dangerous.
She called for good hygiene management at local stores and warned that the bureau will continue to conduct random checks to ensure food safety.
In July, the Consumers' Foundation also conducted a similar check and found 80 percent of 20 cold noodle samples in the Greater Taipei area contained excessive levels of bacteria such as e. coli.
All of the products selected from local vendors failed to pass the health inspection at that time, the foundation pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP urges Control Yuan to be neutral, impartial

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party's caucus in the Legislative Yuan submitted a request Monday for the newly reinstated Control Yuan to investigate 18 cases, including the assassination attempt on former President Chen Shui-bian on the eve of the 2004 presidential election.
The caucus also urged Control Yuan president Wang Chien-shien to make sure that the watchdog body does not become a platform for political conflict.
Ker Chien-ming, convener of the DPP caucus, noted that two of the 18 cases involved Wang himself when he was finance minister from 1990-1992.

Ker said that Wang in his capacity of finance minister had authorized the establishment of 16 new banks in Taiwan, leading to huge losses to the government's coffers and financial chaos. In addition, Wang may have served the interests of the ruling Kuomintang by selling public lands at a low price, Ker said.

"We don't want to see the Control Yuan become another platform for political conflict or a tool for sparring between different political forces, " said Ker in front of the Control Yuan before he filed the request to investigate the 18 cases.
He specifically challenged Wang's impartiality, saying that Wang is a man of political ideology and only intends to investigate cases involving the former DPP government.

Wang has vowed to investigate major scandals in the Chen's former administration, including an attempt to forge diplomatic ties with Papua New Guinea through brokers, and the establishment of the "Taiwan Goal" company to handle arms procurement deals.
Ker urged that the Control Yuan investigate the election eve attempt on Chen's life on March 19, 2004.
"This case has been the cause of division among Taiwan citizens, therefore, the Control Yuan should fully investigate it and let the public know the truth," Ker said.
Chen Feng-yi, the Control Yuan Secretary-General, said later that Wang did not respond to Ker's remarks concerning the two cases in which the Control Yuan president was allegedly involved.
The Control Yuan is not a place for political posturing, the secretary-general added.
He promised that all petitions filed by individuals or policial caucuses will be probed with political impartiality.
The Control Yuan was reactivated last Friday after being inoperative for more than three years due to a political deadlock.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP blasts Taichung mayor for traveling abroad during typhoon

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus in the Taichung City Council lashed out at Taichung Mayor Jason Hu Monday for traveling abroad last week as a typhoon swept through Taiwan.

Members of the DPP caucus hung banners in front of the Taichung city hall, claiming that Hu ignored the Taichung residents' safety and wellbeing during Typhoon Fung Wong while he was in the South Pacific island nation of the Marshall Islands.

"Hu should be fully aware of his job description as mayor, which is to take care of the Taichung residents and oversee the city's development, rather than promoting Taiwan's diplomacy abroad like a foreign minister," said Chen Shu-hua, a DPP city councilor.
Chen described as "deceitful and full of holes" Hu's explanation late last week that he had traveled to the Marshall Islands "at the request of an upstairs authority."

Noting that Hu, a former minister of foreign affairs, was paid by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to make the trip to the Marshall Islands, Chen asked exactly how much Hu was paid and for what purpose.

"Is there something wrong with Taiwan's diplomatic relations with the Marshall Islands, or is the sitting Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco H.L. Ou is so inept that he has to ask Hu to travel to the South Pacific nation to mend fences there?" Chen asked.

Hu was one of the local government chiefs who have been taken to task by the DPP recently for making overseas trips during the typhoon period. The others include Taitung Magistrate Kuang Li-chen and Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei.
Kuang offered her apologies to Taitung residents upon her return from Germany Monday.

Chou, who returned to Taiwan from Nanjing, China last week, ahead of schedule as Typhoon Fung Wong approached the island, announced Monday that he has canceled his plan to visit Beijing for the opening of the Olympic Games and will not go abroad again until the beginning of 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Games opening, closing ceremonies to have Taiwan-centric theme

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Organizing Committee (KOC) said Monday that the opening and closing ceremonies of the 2009 Kaohsiung World Games will center on themes that display Taiwan and Kaohsiung's special characteristics.
The committee made the comments ahead of its scheduled announcement on Aug. 8 of the winning bid to organize the activities and performances for the opening and closing ceremonies.

In order to make the three-hour ceremonies as dazzling and attractive as possible in showcasing Kaohsiung and Taiwan, the KOC has allocated NT$140 million (US$4.56 million) to the arrangement of the events.

Liu Hsiou-mei, deputy head of the Kaohsiung city government's Department of Cultural Affairs, said that as the 2009 World Games will represent the first time that Taiwan is hosting a major international sporting competition, the government will definitely select a bidder whose proposals for activities and performances at the ceremonies focus on showcasing the value of the local culture.

She said that in order to market the upcoming games, the KOC recently held a presentation in Taipei City to invite bids from companies in Taiwan's capital, ranging from TV stations to cultural companies, to organize the ceremonies.

Liu added that various Taiwan high-technology companies have shown an interest and have expressed the hope that the ceremonies will incorporate technological elements to display Taiwan's modernity and advancement.

Meanwhile, Hsu Chau-chuan, chief executive officer of the KOC, said that the three-hour ceremonies will include 99 minutes of thematic performances, and he expressed the hope that these events will "let the world see Taiwan and Kaohsiung."

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,915 for August, 6,881 for September, 6,852 for December, 6,840 for March and 6,819 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index lost 25.18 points to finish at 6,977.36, on turnover of NT$60.68 billion (US$1.98 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

August TE futures rose 1.55 points to close at 270.3, with 2,320 contracts traded, while September TE futures decreased 0.2 points to finish at 269, with 15 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

August TF futures moved up 10.8 points to close at 881.4, with 2,315 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures advanced 10 points to finish at 879.8, with 27 contracts traded. December TF futures increased 12 points to end at 880, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices down on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices slipped below 7,000 points Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 25.18 points, or 0.35 percent, to close at 6,977.36.

Finishing lower for the third consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 6,947.25 and fluctuated between 7,010.93 and 6,927.31. A total of 3.3 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$60.68 billion (US$1.98 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks and banking/financial shares both moving up 0.3 percent.
Machinery and electronics shares remained unchanged.

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 4.4 percent. Plastics and chemicals shares dropped 1.7 percent, paper and pulp issues shed 1.4 percent, cement issues dropped 0.3 percent, and foodstuff shares lost 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,187 to 782, with 489 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$2.5 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Children recite classical literature in Penghu

TEXT.P: Some 1,300 children participated in a classical literature recitation activity in offshore Penghu County Monday, doing their best to recite old and ancient texts they didn't necessarily understand.
The recitation, held at Wen Ao Elementary School in Penghu's capital Makung, was divided into two categories: Chinese classical literature and English classical literature.
Although there was no age limit for joining in the activity, all of the participants were students under 12 -- including some still in kindergarten or nursery school.

For the Chinese classical literature recitation, the children selected one of 33 passages from the I Ching (Book of Changes) , Lun Yu (the Analects of Confucius) , San Zi Jing (the Three Character Classic) , the philosophy of Laozi and Zhuangzi and poems from the Tang Dynasty.
For the English classical literature recitation, the children chose one of 12 passages from William Shakespeare's Sonnets and A Midsummer Night's Dream.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait detente will not affect Taipei-Tokyo ties: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that cross-Taiwan Strait detente will not affect Taipei-Tokyo ties, as the situation will benefit the entire region, including Japan.
Ma made the remarks during a meeting at the Presidential Office with a group of visiting Japanese dietmen led by Tetsurou Yano.

He assured his Japanese visitors that the long-term friendship between Taiwan and Japan will not be eroded by improved links between Taiwan and China, because warming Taiwan-China relations will help forge peace and prosperity in the strait, which is in Japan's best interests.

Noting that he is fully aware that some pro-Taiwan Japanese dietmen are deeply concerned that improvements in cross-strait links might undermine Taipei-Tokyo ties, Ma said that "the aim of pursuing cross-strait peace is to build peace and prosperity in the region, and a positive development in this regard will be beneficial to East Asia, and certainly Japan."

Ma said he is upbeat about the prospects of Taiwan-Japan relations, as current Japanese Premier Yasuo Fukuda and then Foreign Minister Taro Aso seemed to also endorsed this viewpoint during a meeting in 2006 when he visited Japan. Fukuda was a dietman at that time.
Taiwan also welcomes improving China-Japan ties, since cross-strait peace and prosperity is a common desire among East Asian countries, and Taiwan is poised to move in this direction, he said.

Over the past half century, Japan has had to carefully weigh the leverage between Taiwan and China within a confined space, he pointed out. However, he went on, this should be eased as Taiwan-China relations continue to improve.

The United States, which has a huge stake in the region, has found itself in a similar position, with President George W. Bush having expressed pleasure recently over the improved cross-strait ties, he said.
Ma also highly praised the efforts by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Mainland Affairs Council to improve Taiwan's ties with China, the United States and Japan since he took office May 20.

Commenting on a collision that took place last month between a Taiwanese recreational fishing boat and a Japanese coast guard patrol ship near the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands northeast of Taiwan, the president said he supported at the time a peaceful and rational resolution to the dispute.
"My viewpoint and stance in this regard fully coincided with that of Prime Minister Fukuda," he noted.

"Those who see me as anti-Japanese might not have read my three books that delve into the Tiaoyutai issue, " he argued, adding that all the resolutions he suggests in his books are peaceful and rational.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.021 to close at NT$30.666.
A total of US$1.09 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.665 and fluctuated between NT$30.665 and NT$30.744.

DOC.HEADLINE: O'seas visits help local chief achieve better performance: publisher

TEXT.P: The founder of a prestigious monthly magazine said Monday that overseas trips made by Hsinchu Mayor Lin Jung-tzer's have helped him improve his performance.

Charles H.C. Kao, founder of the Global Views monthly, also said in the face of controversy and accusations that local government chiefs are squandering taxpayers' money with their frequent traveling that Lin should "make more overseas visits if needed." The mayor has made 17 such visits over the past two years.
"Lin is not only concerned about the needs of the public, he is also keen on joining the world," Kao said.

The controversy has been further fueled by a trip made by Taitung Magistrate Kuang Li-cheng to Europe when Typhoon Fung-Wong battered her county, but Kao said that what counts is not the number of visits made but rather the purposes and itineraries of such trips.

He made the remarks as he honored Lin at Hsinchu City Hall for ranking first in three categories -- approval rating, contributions to the local economy and pride of residents of their city or country -- in a competitiveness survey conducted by Kao's magazine of Taiwan's 25 cities and counties in 2008.
Kao said that in the overall performance of the city and county chief survey, Lin was first, followed by Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and Taoyuan Magistrate Eric Liluan Chu.

Lin for his part said he has learned a great deal as a result of his overseas visits, citing as examples the sofas made of turf with floral decorations that he ordered to be placed at Shihpachien mountain -- a popular spot among the locals -- after a visit to Thailand, while a trip to Malaysia gave him the idea of deploying garbage collecting vehicles that patrol the city emptying the municipal street-side garbage cans.
Lin noted that "it takes time to find the best way forward for city development. This time can be shortened if we learn directly from other countries."

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County launches Web site to sell farm specialties

TEXT.P: The Changhua county government launched a Web site Monday to allow people in Taiwan to buy vegetables, fruit and farm specialties online.

The Web site -- http: //agec.chcg.gov.tw -- is part of the county government's efforts to provide another sales channel to help the central county's 26 townships sell their farm and fishery products, Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan said.

The Web site is also aimed at advertising the county's farm produce, said Chiu Shih-ping, head of the county's Department of Agriculture. The site features latest agricultural information, products of the season, and food preparation tips, Chiu noted.
To ensure food safety, the county government is currently cooperating with 15 local farms to sell goods with traceability certification on the Web site, he said.
Local governments in other parts of Taiwan have also launched similar efforts to promote or market their farm produce on the Internet.
Taiwan has an Internet population of some 14.8 million, up 1.7 percent from a year ago, according to a study released by the Taipei-based Institute for Information Industry in February.

DOC.HEADLINE: Neihu MRT line to start operations by next June: mayor

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government is confident that the city's Neihu Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) line will start commercial operations by the end of next June as scheduled, Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Monday.
An extension of the existing Muzha line, the Neihu line starts where the Muzha line ends at the Zhongshan Junior High School Station and finishes at the Taipei Nangang Exhibition Center.

The city government began testing the trains Sunday, and a full series of test rides, evaluations and adjustments will be carried out once all of the line's 12 stations are completed in December, said Chang Chi-te, commissioner of Taipei City's Department of Rapid Transit Systems.

Hau, meanwhile, called for the understanding of residents living near the new line and the Muzha line for any inconvenience caused by the tests, most of which will have to be carried out late at night.

Spanning 14.8 km, the line has 12 stations, including the Taipei Songshan Airport, which will allow passengers to travel between the Taipei Main Station and the airport in 14 minutes -- about half the time it takes to make the trip by road, said Chang.
The line's automatically controlled trains are produced by Canada's Bombardier Corp. and are equipped with luggage racks to provide convenience for passengers heading for the airport, he went on.

The new line will provide much easier access to the city's Neihu and Nangang areas, which will be even further improved with the inauguration of the Nangang line, which is scheduled to be completed by 2010 and will connect with the Neihu line at the Taipei Nangang Exhibition Center, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Some 60 metric tons of contraband fish seized off Taipei County

TEXT.P: Coastal patrol officers seized nearly 60 metric tons of contraband fish from a Taiwanese fishing vessel in waters off the Taipei County in northern Taiwan Sunday, the Cabinet-level Coast Guard Administration (CGA) reported Monday.

According to the CGA, the fish was discovered aboard the Yungsheng, a fishing boat registered in Hsinchu County, when it was caught allegedly trying to smuggle its cargo into Taiwan from waters off Taipei County's Fugui Cape Harbor.

The skipper, surnamed Hsu, and his crew of four told the CGA officers that they bought the 56,626 kg of squid and mackerel, among others, at a harbor in China's Fujian Province, intending to resell the fish in Taiwan to chalk up greater profits.
Fujian Province lies opposite Taiwan across the Taiwan Strait.
As the fish appeared abnormally white in color, the CGA officers suspected that the fish might have been processed with illegal substances in order to preserve it better.

The smuggled fish, which had an estimated market value of about NT$10 million (US$328,947) , was confiscated and destroyed, the CGA officers said, adding that the case has been handed over the Taoyuan Prosecutors Office for further investigation.

The CGA warned the public not to consume smuggled products even if the lower prices are enticing, and urged them to report suspicious items to a special 118 hotline to help safeguard public health and stamp out trade in contraband goods.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's state-owned postal company restores original name

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-owned postal company on Monday restored its original name, Chunghwa Post Co., reversing the former pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's controversial move 18 months ago to change the firm's name to Taiwan Post Co.

At a ceremony held in the auditorium of the company's head office in Taipei, chairman Wu Min-yu announced that effective immediately, the company will be renamed Chunghwa Post Co. -- a name it first adopted when the postal service became a company fully owned by the Ministry of Transportation and Communication in January 2003.

The move was made in line with a resolution adopted in April by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) -dominated Legislative Yuan, which required the company to reinstate its original name within six months on the grounds that the previous name change in February last year was illegal.

According to Wu, it will cost about NT$8 million (US$260,000) to have the signboards at all the post offices in the nation replaced again. The amount was less than the NT$12 million for the previous name change, because the post offices have kept the old signboards.

The former DPP administration decided to change the name of the firm to Taiwan Post Co. on the grounds that this would help avoid confusion, because "Chunghwa" means "Chinese" or "China" in the Chinese language. Many observers saw the move as part of a broad campaign to highlight Taiwan's distinct identity.

Subsequent efforts by the DPP administration to amend the Postal Service Act and amend a statute on the establishment of the Chunghwa Post Co. failed in the KMT- controlled legislature, leaving the name change without a firm legal basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait trust should be extended to diplomatic arena: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that the idea of "workable diplomacy" is based on the hope that both Taiwan and China will be able to extend the mutual trust restored in the past few months to the international arena, so that the two sides can work out a dialogue pattern on the issue of Taiwan's international space.

Ma made the remarks during a visit to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) in which elaborated on his ideas of a "diplomatic truce" between Taiwan and China and his concept of "workable diplomacy, " formally translated by his aides as a "modus vivendi" strategy.

"Just as I said in my inauguration speech, if Taiwan continues to be isolated in the international community, there will be no meaningful growth in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, " Ma said. "The two are inter-dependent," he added.
The president said the reconciliation of bilateral relations should be extended to the diplomatic arena.

"Diplomatic truce does not mean vacation time, but it should mean the end to vicious competition or the wasting of resources to lure each other's allies, and it should mean treating each other's people according to humanitarian principles," Ma said.
He noted that the difficulties Taiwan has encountered in the international community over the years are the result of conflict and confrontation with China.
"Diplomacy should not be a zero-sum game and the spirit of `workable diplomacy' is in line with `pragmatic diplomacy, ' both of which are based on the principle of pragmatism," the president said.

Although some might feel the strategy is too idealistic, Ma went on, the key element for its success is that both Taiwan and China should establish a certain degree of consensus -- the will to create a mutually beneficial situation for both countries.
He said that based on the development of bilateral relations between Taiwan and China over the past few months, it is obvious that mutual trust is increasing.

Since Ma's May 20 inauguration, the previously frosty cross-strait relations have gradually thawed, with Taiwan easing restrictions on commercial exchanges, allowing weekend direct cross-strait charter flights and opening up to more Chinese tourists.

Ma said Taiwan faces a very serious challenge in that not only should the country try to maintain the status quo in terms of bilateral and multi-lateral relations with other countries, it should also try to expand the friendships it already has.
"We should ponder the question of whether we want to confront China on every international occasion or whether it is possible for us to find a patter from which we can talk," he said.

The president said that given the fact that Taiwan and China are so close to each other, the two can complement each other in a number of areas and this kind of development should come naturally, with a minimum of government control.
"No matter what ideology a government might hold, it cannot use subjective ideology to change objective reality," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government pushes vendors to slash wheat flour product prices

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs on Monday called for domestic bakeries, confectioners, supermarkets and other outlets to give consumers relief by lowering prices on their products made with wheat flour.
Unlike other rising global food and commodity prices, international wheat prices have actually fell last month, prompting the government to make the appeal.

An Economics Ministry official acknowledged that Taiwan's bakeries and noodle makers were still using more expensive wheat flour obtained before prices fell, because wheat-based products typically don't make it to retail shelves until two to three months after the wheat is imported.
But he said that the ministry hopes that such businesses will immediately lower prices in order to "take care of consumers' feelings."
Two recent typhoons have accelerated food price hikes, and analysts expect July inflation to hit 5.0 to 5.6 percent.

The official added that the ministry has already instructed the state-controlled Taiwan Sugar Corp. (Taisugar) to take the lead in lowering prices of flour- based products on the shelves of Taisugar-run stores.
Meanwhile, Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung said Monday that price cuts in flour products will be included on the agenda of the Executive Yuan Price Stabilization Panel's upcoming meetings.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGBlairites plot to hasten Gordon Brownsexit
Gordon Browns enemies are preparing to accelerate a campaign for his removal from No 10 after he was left weakened by David Milibands move to stake a claim as Labours next leader.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legal controversy creates health insurance card dilemma

TEXT.P: The Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) may be forced to issue 800,000 temporary paper insurance cards in the coming months to avoid a potential conflict of interest between the vendor of the IC cards and Premier Liu Chao- shiuan.
The bureau said Monday it had decided not to renew its contract with IC card supplier Teco Electric and Machinery Co. because the company's chairman, C.K. Liu, is Premier Liu's brother.
"Due to the Public Officials' Conflicts of Interest Prevention Act, the BNHI cannot renew the contract with Teco, " said Chu Tzer-ming, the president and CEO of the health insurance bureau.

Teco won an NT$3.8 billion contract in 2001 to issue 1.6 million IC cards per year, but because of the bureau's decision, Teco will not be able to issue any cards after the contract expires on August 6.

Chu said it will take six months to choose a new vendor through an open bidding process. During that time, the bureau estimates 800,000 people in Taiwan, including newborn babies, foreign spouses and workers, and people who lose their cards, will need new cards.
They will be given temporary paper cards in their place, and will be required to present them along with their identity cards when they seek health care services.

Although Premier Liu was sworn-in on May 20, the bureau said it did not realize that Teco's chairman was the premier's brother until early June. At that time, it asked the Ministry of Justice for an interpretation of the conflict of interest law.
The ministry informed the insurance bureau in the past week that working with Teco might violate the law, forcing the bureau to seek a new IC card supplier, the BNHI said.

In Taiwan, almost every citizen holds a health insurance IC card, which is nearly as common as an identity card. Since the holder's medical history is recorded on the chip, the IC card raised privacy concerns when it was first issued in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese American students to attend culture camp in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 3 (CNA) 08/04/08 20:10:53 (By Lu-sheng Chu and Grace Kuo)

TEXT.P: A delegation of Chinese American students from Los Angeles set off Sunday for Taiwan on a study tour aimed at seeking their roots and experiencing traditional Chinese culture.
The group, composed of 34 middle school and elementary school students aged 10 to 18, will attend a study camp sponsored by the Kuang Hua Senior High School for girls in the southern city of Tainan.

During their two-week stay in Tainan, they will be given lessons in Chinese reading, Taiwanese customs and cultures, traditional religions, international etiquette, Chinese painting and Chinese calligraphy. They will also be taken to traditional marketplaces.
In order to gain the fullest possible experience of local culture, the students will stay with local host families.

"They will assist their local peers in learning English, while simultaneously learning Chinese themselves. We expect that this will facilitate friendship and interaction between overseas students and Taiwanese students, " said Yeh Min- fen, the leader of the camp.

At the end of the camp, the students will receive a certificate, and they will be presented by their schools with a social service certificate when they return to the U.S., to certify that they provided English teaching assistance. This certificate can be used to boost their chances of being accepted by top colleges.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City luring film, TV producers to port city

TEXT.P: Financial incentives to draw film and TV producers to Kaohsiung City to shoot movies and programs have proven effective, with a number of production teams taking up the offer to film there in the past few months, the city government said Monday.

Since Kaohsiung's Department of Information passed a measure earlier this year to pay subsidies to film or TV producers of NT$300 (US$9.83) per day for each production team worker, at least 10 films and TV programs have been shot in the southern port city, a municipal official said.
Among them was noted director Wu Nien-jen's new film "Take Me to the Faraway Place." Wu's best-known work is his autobiographical film, "A Borrowed Life."

"There are many ways and channels to market Kaohsiung, but certainly having film and TV drama producers shoot scenes in the city is a very good way to show the beauty of Kaohsiung, " the official from the city's Department of Information said.
Under the incentive's provisions, film or TV drama production teams are eligible to received subsidies of up to NT$600,000, he said.

The official said that the department has already budgeted NT$1.5 million in subsidies for producers to help pay for their crews' accommodation and signed a long-term contract with a hotel which provides rooms to film or TV crews at a reasonable price.
The city has also gone out of its way to "provide administrative assistance, " the official said, in one case lending Kaohsiung's famous "Mounted Police Unit" to promote a film in late May.

Another incentive drawn up to encourage film producers to use Kaohsiung as a backdrop for their stories is an NT$10 million cash award for any picture where shots of the city account for at least a quarter of its length and that wins an award at any one of six major international film festivals, such as the Berlin International Film Festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Jet-setting county chief returns to a storm of criticism

TEXT.P: Taitung County Magistrate Kuang Li-chen arrived at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Monday amid harsh criticism for being away on a 13-day trip to Europe while her county was being pounded by a typhoon last week.
Surrounded by reporters at the airport, Kuang, from the ruling Kuomintang, apologized to Taitung residents for being absent as Typhoon Fung-Wong devastated her southeast coast county.

The storm brought heavy rains and floods to central and southern Taiwan, claiming two lives, including one in Taitung, and causing an estimated NT$1.1 billion (US$35.8 million) in agricultural losses.

Asked whether she had decided not to fly abroad again for the rest of the year, the flight attendant-turned-politician nodded in agreement. She complemented other county officials, including her deputy, who managed the local government's response to the typhoon.
She added that although she was overseas when Fung-Wong made landfall between Taitung and Hualien last Monday, she had monitored information about the typhoon's movement and damage.
Kuang explained that her travels aimed to promote Taitung, which she said was a "dispossessed" place that "no one cares" about in the international community.
However, that explanation failed to calm a storm of discontent with her and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, also from the ruling Kuomintang.
Kuang and Hu were the only two of the nation's 25 city and county chiefs who were not on the island when the typhoon came.
The opposition Democratic Progressive Party denounced Kuang and Hu for "ignoring the most important task of a local government leader," which the party said was to stand together with the people.
Kuang, who took office on April 17, 2006, is the first female magistrate of the agricultural county, an economic backwater. She won the post on April 1that year with 63 percent of the vote.

Since then, however, her administration has received poor marks. In a survey on public satisfaction with the performance of 25 county and city administrators published in July's Global Views Monthly magazine, Kuang ranked dead last.

Kuang has drawn fire for her frequent overseas visits on the taxpayers' dime. She has flown abroad eight times over the past two and a half years, visiting nine countries: Japan, Egypt, Greece, Hong Kong, Britain, Thailand, New Zealand, Germany and Italy.

Taichung's Mayor Hu earned the highest public satisfaction ranking in the same Global Views Monthly view survey, but was also absent when the typhoon hit his city. At the time, Hu was visiting the Marshall Islands, one of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies.
In his first day at work Monday after returning from his trip, Hu urged the public not to "smear" the legitimacy of foreign visits by local government heads.
Hu said he visited the Marshall Islands to help solidify Taiwan's diplomatic ties. He said his visit benefited both Taichung and the nation, and that he never expected to be criticized for the trip.

Hu said that he had overseen preparations for a possible typhoon before departing, adding that he believed it was more important to have a good city government team in place, than for him to remain in Taichung constantly to help protect the city from storms.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tunnel of Nine Turns in Taroko National Park closed for two days

TEXT.P: The Tunnel of Nine Turns -- the most beautiful section of the Taroko National Park in eastern Taiwan -- will remain closed for at least two days until Aug. 5, the park administration said Monday.

Administration officials said the decision to temporarily close the tunnel was made out of concern for the safety of tourists, because falling rocks along the walkway inside the tunnel posed a serious hazard.

The officials explained that the heavy rain brought by Typhoon Fung-Wong late last month had saturated the rocks with moisture along the walkway in the tunnel, causing some of the rocks to become loose.
"If the conditions within the tunnel have become stable, we expect to reopen the tunnel on Aug. 6," they said.
The Tunnel of Nine Turns, constructed in 1996, is considered the most magnificent part of Taroko Gorge.

The walkway in the tunnel is an ideal place for visitors to feast their eyes on the natural wonders of Taroko Gorge, where the white marble cliffs face each other at a distance of only 10 meters, forming a narrow channel for the Kelan River to rush through.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung County to launch musical instrument festival

TEXT.P: Taichung County will hold a four-day musical instrument festival beginning Aug. 7 to promote the central Taiwan county's musical instrument manufacturing prowess and tourism.

The festival will be held at a horse farm in Houli township, a small town in the northern part of the county with a rich 60-year history of producing saxophones, said Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng.
About two-thirds of the country's saxophone manufacturers are still located in Houli, which is also known for its jazz drums, guitars, and flutes.

During the four-day bash, professional groups and individuals, as well as school bands, will perform on a wide variety of musical instruments, such as the accordion, harmonica, oboe, violin, cello, piano, flute, and drum, as well as traditional Chinese instruments.
Two separate competitions, for saxophonists and jazz drummers, will be held on the first day of the event, with the drum competition drawing musicians from around the country.

Since the festival will be held during Chinese Valentine's Day and Father's Day, the organizers have all cast some musical performances to create a more romantic atmosphere for participants, Huang said.

Those who would rather be in on the action than simply listen to the music will have a chance to perform themselves, as they can try their hands at a number of instruments on display in a special pavilion, an attraction has been the show's most popular feature over the past two years, Huang said.
Visitors can also bring their own instruments to the festival venue where experienced instrument makers will provide a "diagnosis" of their instruments in pursuit of better sound performance.
For those interested in actually buying an instrument, festival-goers can head to the on-site instrument shop to find the best deals with guidance from professional instrument makers.
There will also be activities targeted at children, where they can paint their ocarinas or learn how to play little bamboo flutes, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese parents in Dongguan want full tuition subsidies for kids

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese business association in southern China has called on Taiwan's government to fully subsidize their children's education at schools there, as a worsening business environment in China has severely eroded their profits.

Andrew Yeh, chairman of the Taiwan Merchant Association based in the industrial city of Dongguan in Guangdong province, said Monday that with their businesses suffering from rising inflation and deteriorating investment conditions, an increasing number of Taiwanese businessmen in the area can no longer afford the cost of the special schools set up for their children.

The negative economic conditions have saddled them with a heavier financial burden, and many hope Taiwan's government can provide them with full subsidies for their children's education in China, he said.

According to Yeh, the parents of two-thirds of the 1,760 students at Dongguan School for Children of Taiwan Businessmen are merely employees of Taiwanese- invested companies in the area, with more limited financial means, while the other third are business owners.

Now that overseas schools for Taiwanese businessmen's children are viewed as an extension of the compulsory education system at home, the government should offer full educational subsidies for their children on an equal basis with those in Taiwan, Yeh suggested.
At present, Taiwan's government grants NT$120,000-NT$140,000 (US$4,605) per year in subsidies to each elementary or junior high school student in Taiwan, Yeh said.

But the Taiwan's Ministry of Education provides only some NT$30,000 in financial aid to each Taiwanese child attending the special schools in China, falling well short of the average school fees of about 33,000 Chinese yuan (NT$130,000) per year, he said.

Yeh urged relevant agencies, such as the Mainland Affairs Council and the Straits Exchange Foundation, to join with the Legislative Yuan in passing legislation to provide full economic handouts for the children of Taiwanese businesspeople in China.
"Taiwanese kids studying in the schools dedicated to them in China are entitled to receive an equitable subsidy from the government in Taiwan, " he contended.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu City proves popular with new residents

TEXT.P: Hsinchu City, host to Taiwan's best-known science park and some of its most prominent companies, is one of the best places to live in Taiwan, if population statistics are any indication.

The city has seen its population grow faster over the past five years than any other city or county in the country, according to the results of a survey on domestic migration released Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The survey found that the city's population had grown by 12.1 percent, or 54,000 people, over the past five years, faster than anywhere else in the country, bringing its total population to 500,000.

The survey also discovered that 102,000 more people were living in the city than were officially registered as city residents, a 25.47 percent gap, larger than any other city or county that recorded such a gap, including Taipei, Taichung and Tainan cities and Taipei and Taoyuan counties.
DGBAS officials attributed Hsinchu's popularity to pragmatic public policies, vigorous industrial and commercial activity, and high-quality employment and education environments.

The survey, conducted last November, also found that 7.83 percent of Hsinchu residents work outside the city, a rate higher only than that of Taipei County and considerably lower than the national average of 13.71 percent.
On Monday, Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-Tzer was awarded by a local media group for his excellent administrative performance that "connects the city to the world. "

In the 2008 city/county competitiveness survey conducted by the group, he ranked number one in three categories: "satisfaction with government performance, " "leader's contribution to the economy" and "city pride."
The Hsinchu Science Park hosts the headquarters of many international high- tech manufacturers, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., the world's largest made-to-order chip factory.

DOC.HEADLINE: Culture chief outlines policy visions during visit to Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 4 (CNA) 08/04/08 23:35:11 (By Yang Ming-chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will open a cultural center in Tokyo next year, the country's top culture official said in Tokyo Monday.
Huang Pi-twan, minister in charge of the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) , made the remarks during a meeting with Taiwanese journalists posted in Japan.

Huang, who was invited by Japan's Aichi University to attend an international seminar, said the planned Tokyo cultural center will be the third of its kind established by the CCA to introduce Taiwan's culture to foreigners, following similar ones in New York and Paris.

Noting that cultural development and publicity has been one of the most effective vehicles to inspire foreign interest in Taiwan, Huang said Europeans knew little about Taiwan 20 years ago but now hold it in high esteem because of exposure to Taiwanese artists.

World-class movie directors such as Hou Hsiao-hsien, Edward Yang and Tsai Ming- liang as well as internationally acclaimed performing troupes, including the Cloud Gate Dance Theater, the Contemporary Legend Theater, Han Tang Yuefu and U-Theater, have all raised Taiwan's profile internationally, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Card slave' freed of most of his debts in precedent-setting case

TEXT.P: A low-income "card slave" has been forgiven of most of his debts after a court ruled that he only has to pay about 14 percent of his NT$600,000 credit card balance.

"I felt total relief the night the lawyer called me about the court's ruling," said Huang, who became the first person in Taiwan to emerge from a cloud of credit card debt under a court-monitored special settlement mechanism that took effect in April of this year.

"I had a good night's sleep, and I don't have to worry any more about repaying my debts, " Huang said at a news conference organized Monday by the Legal Aid Foundation, which handled Huang's case and has been the leading proponent of the credit card debt settlement process.
The court ruled that Huang will have to pay NT$83,000 over six years to settle his accounts.
Although creditor banks argued that the amount is far too low, the court nonetheless approved his petition for debt forgiveness.
Huang, who has suffered from polio since childhood, lives on income from selling recyclables and government subsidies.
To get married, he borrowed NT$200,000 (US$6,557) from friends and used credit cards to borrow more money, eventually owing banks about NT$600,000.

The Legal Aid Foundation helped him petition the court to settle his debts so he could get a new lease on life. The foundation said Huang would repay his obligations with whatever money he had left after deducting basic expenses from his monthly wages and benefits.
Lin Yung-sung, a lawyer and head of the Legal Aid Foundation, said that when the court handles such cases, "it attaches great importance to the sincerity of the debtors in repaying their debts."
"As long as the debtor's proposal can be accepted by the court, there is no need to convene a meeting of all creditors. The court will make its own decision," Lin said.

"Whether the debts can be completely repaid will not be the major focus, " he said, adding that "the court will even take into account rising consumer prices to gradually reduce the amount repaid over time.

Citing Huang as an example, Lin said the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, has set the minimum living expenses of a Taipei resident at NT$14,100 per person per month.

But Huang proposed that he would only deduct NT$9,990 for living expenses for him and his wife and three meals of NT$100 per person daily, leaving him NT$1,500 a month with which to make payments during the first 18 months.
The monthly payments will then be reduced gradually until the NT$83,034 is repaid over 72 months.
The court believed that Huang "is not squandering any money, and he is sincere in repaying his debts."

Chen Feng-feng, a lawyer with the foundation, said that Huang's case has shown that card debtors who want to settle their accounts will be able to get aid from the foundation and other groups in petitioning the court to settle their problems within their means.

"Card slave" is a term coined in Taiwan to refer to people who can only pay the minimum balance on their credit card debt every month. Reports have said that hundreds of thousands of Taiwanese are struggling to repay their growing debts.

After dozens of "card slaves" committed suicide because of what they saw as the hopelessness of their situation, the government and civic groups stepped in to help card slaves negotiate repayment programs with creditor banks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Arts Festival to open Aug. 7

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government will launch one of its annual cultural highlights, the Taipei Arts Festival, on Aug. 7, showcasing an array of theater performances by both foreign and local performance groups, a local official said Monday.
According to the official, the festival's opening day will begin with a show called "I La Galigo, " which is a story based on an Indonesian creation myth.

Directed by American theater director Robert Wilson, the three-hour performance presents the story of the quest for love through blended elements of music, dance, poetry and theater skills, the official said.
Performances by four other foreign groups will be presented after the first show, the official said.

Performances by domestic groups include a melodrama called "Happiness Part 1 and 2, " a musical called "Turn Left, Turn Right, " and a modern crosstalk show called "Total Women, " plus the festival's only dance, "La dame aux camelias, " choreographed by Taiwanese dancer Allen Yu.

In addition to the performances, the public can also attend free seminars which will be hosted by artists in the festival, and an exhibition of a collection of original drawings by the Taiwanese illustrator known as "Jimmy," the official said.
More details about the shows and ticket information can be found on the event's Web site.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmakers to restore name of Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) said Monday that the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall -- renamed by the former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration as Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall in May last year -- will have its original name restored in the next legislative session.

Legislator Chiang Yi-hsiung, a co-convener of the Education and Culture Committee, said that during the next legislative session beginning in early September, he will include on the agenda a resolution by the former DPP administration to scrap the organic law for the establishment of Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
Chiang said the KMT-dominated legislature will defeat the resolution, thus allowing the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to have its original name restored.

However, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi told reporters later that there is no urgency in giving back the memorial its original name, and said it would be better to consult public opinion first in order to form a consensus on the issue.
The Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall is a monument erected in memory of the late President Chiang Kai-shek, who ruled Taiwan for 25 years until his death in 1975.

On May 19 last year, then-president Chen Shui-bian renamed Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall as National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall without going through a legislative process to provide a legal basis for the new name.

The name change was part of a campaign by the former DPP administration to rid the country of vestiges of Chiang, considered by many in Taiwan to have been a brutal dictator, and boost its popularity.
The DPP administration forcibly removed statues of Chiang from public places across the island, deleted his name from the international airport in Taoyuan, and closed his mausoleum in Taoyuan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Whereabouts of Taitung magistrate unknown

TEXT.P: Controversial Taitung County Magistrate Kuang Li-chen went into hiding Monday after her return from a trip overseas as prosecutors were trying to summon her for questioning over suspected irregularities related to her just-concluded tour.

Kuang, accompanied by 13 Taitung county government officials and township chiefs, returned to Taipei Monday morning after visiting several European countries, including Italy, in the name of learning about their tourism promotion measures.

Kuang originally planned to give a news conference after returning to the eastern county of Taitung, an agricultural backwater, to clarify allegations that the trip was a reward to her grassroots campaign operatives at taxpayers' expense.

A chief Taitung prosecutor led a team of investigators to Taitung's Fengnien Airport to wait for Kuang and her entourage and bring them in for questioning. Because of bad weather, the plane returned to Taipei.

Kuang and her chief secretary Hou Shih-min then took a flight from Taipei to the eastern county of Hualien that borders Taitung. She originally planned to give a news conference at the Taitung county government building after her return. But she went missing after noticing that prosecutors were trailing her car on the way from Hualien to Taitung.
Other members of her entourage returned to Taitung in two groups in the evening and all of them have been taken to the Investigation Bureau's Taitung office for questioning.

Kuang came under fire after taking 10 township chiefs and other county officials on a 13-day trip to Europe in late July despite knowing that Typhoon Fung Wong was approaching. She has also been criticized for spending millions of taxpayers' money on frequent overseas trips since taking office two years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lured by discount, 2.05 million households lower power use

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) said Monday that a program to give discount rates to households that cut electricity consumption is paying dividends.

An initial estimate by the state-run utility showed that 2.05 million households cut power use in July to earn the discounts, using 480 million kilowatt/hour less than last year to save NT$610 million (US$20 million) from their electricity bills.
To encourage energy conservation and reduce carbon dioxide emissions, Taipower increased electricity rates in July by nearly 8 percent for residential users.

But it offered 5 percent discounts to those families, elementary and high schools that maintained their electricity consumption at the same level or cut use by less than five percent compared to the same period last year.
Those who cut electricity use by between five and 10 percent were to get a 10 percent discount, and those who cut electricity use by more than 10 percent would get 20 percent off their bills.
Of the 2.05 million households that consumed less electricity in July from the same month last year, 70.2 percent of them, or 1.44 million households, cut power use by more than 10 percent.
Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming said he was amazed to see the good result.
"Handsome rewards can bring out the most valiant, " Yiin said, noting that the measure had proven effective so far based on the obvious impact of local residents' cooperation in conserving energy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu City proves popular with new residents

TEXT.P: Hsinchu City, host to Taiwan's best-known science park and some of its most prominent companies, is one of the best places to live in Taiwan, if population statistics are any indication.

The city has seen its population grow faster over the past five years than any other city or county in the country, according to the results of a survey on domestic migration released Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The survey found that the city's population had grown by 12.1 percent, or 54,000 people, over the past five years, faster than anywhere else in the country, bringing its total population to 500,000.

The survey also discovered that 102,000 more people were living in the city than were officially registered as city residents, a 25.47 percent gap, larger than any other city or county that recorded such a gap, including Taipei, Taichung and Tainan cities and Taipei and Taoyuan counties.
DGBAS officials attributed Hsinchu's popularity to pragmatic public policies, vigorous industrial and commercial activity, and high-quality employment and education environments.

The survey, conducted last November, also found that 7.83 percent of Hsinchu residents work outside the city, a rate higher only than that of Taipei County and considerably lower than the national average of 13.71 percent.
On Monday, Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-Tzer was awarded by a local media group for his excellent administrative performance that "connects the city to the world. "

In the 2008 city/county competitiveness survey conducted by the group, he ranked number one in three categories: "satisfaction with government performance, " "leader's contribution to the economy" and "city pride."
The Hsinchu Science Park hosts the headquarters of many international high- tech manufacturers, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., the world's largest made-to-order chip factory.

DOC.HEADLINE: Culture chief outlines policy visions during visit to Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 4 (CNA) 08/05/08 10:30:05 (By Yang Ming-chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will open a cultural center in Tokyo next year, the country's top culture official said in Tokyo Monday.
Huang Pi-twan, minister in charge of the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) , made the remarks during a meeting with Taiwanese journalists posted in Japan.
