DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 5, or the fifth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: Henry I, the youngest son of William the Conqueror, is crowned king in Westminster Abbey, three days after his brother William Rufus was killed in a hunting accident in the New Forest.
1858: The laying of the world's first transatlantic telegraph cable between Ireland and Newfoundland is completed.
1792: Frederick North, British politician known as "Lord North," dies at the age of 60. He served as prime minister (1770-1782) under George III and instituted policies that led to the rebellion of the American colonies.
1861: A national income tax is introduced in the United States, initially to fund the Civil War.
1895: Friedrich Engels, German socialist theorist and writer, dies at the age of 75. He met Karl Marx in Paris in 1844 and collaborated with him on "The Communist Manifesto" in 1848.
1930: Neil Armstrong, American astronaut and the first man on the moon, is born.
1948: The Republic of China and the United States agree to organize the Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction, with Chiang Meng-lin, James Yen and Shen Chung-han from the ROC, and Dr. Raymond T. Moyer and Dr. John Earl Baker from the United States as commissioners.
1949: The United States issues a "White Paper" on Sino-American relations, blaming the Nationalist government for the occupation of the Chinese mainland by the communists.
1950: A Kuomintang Central Reform Committee is set up in Taipei.
1950: The U.S. 13th Air Force is stationed in Taiwan to help the ROC guard against possible mainland Chinese air attacks.
1952: The first Japanese Embassy in Taiwan officially opens on Taipei's Chungshan North Road following the exchange of diplomatic notes ratifying the Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Liberia.
1958: The nuclear-powered submarine Nautilus completes a historic 2,000-mile (3,200-km) underwater journey from Point Barrow in Alaska to the Greenland Sea, passing directly under the North Pole during its five-day voyage.
1958: Vice President Chen Cheng, who was appointed on July 1 to the concurrent post of Executive Yuan president, presides over a ceremony laying the foundation for the construction of the NT$3,200 million Shihmen Dam.
1971: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with the Republic of Turkey.
1973: The Hua Hsing Junior High School baseball team leaves for Gary, Indiana, to represent the Far East in the Senior League World Series.
1974: The Republic of China Amateur Big League baseball team leaves Taipei to participate in the 1974 Amateur Big League World Series in Ft. Lauderdale, Fla.
1976: The Executive Yuan approves the extension for two years of the Sino- Panamanian pact on technical fishery cooperation.
1984: Richard Burton, Welsh-born actor and twice husband of actress Elizabeth Taylor, dies of a stroke at his home in Switzerland.
1986: The Chinese Taipei women's basketball team leaves for Moscow to compete in the 10th Women's Basketball World Championships.
1991: President Lee Teng-hui receives Fijian Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara.
1999: The 18th International Baseball Association World Amateur Big League Baseball Championship opens in Kaohsiung County with 12 teams from Cuba, Japan, South Korea, Panama, the United States and Taiwan participating.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh announces the list of members for his inter-party task force on cross-strait relations, which he said will be an advisory body for the ROC president and not a policy-making unit.
2001: National Defense University President Gen. Hsia Ying-tsou says that Taiwan's first state-financed military think tank, the National Center for Strategic Studies, will be inaugurated on Sept. 1.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By strictly limiting the time of their service and making all imposts as light as possible: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to the mass of the people."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Tropical storm to bring more rain to eastern Taiwan

TEXT.P: The outer edges of a tropical storm located south of Taiwan is expected to bring downpours to the eastern part of the island Tuesday, although the weather system will not have any direct impact on Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said.

"Heavy" or "extremely heavy" rainfall is expected in the Hengchun Peninsula and southeastern coastal areas, and strong rains are also likely in the eastern and northeastern parts of the island, the bureau said.

From midnight until 11: 20 a.m. Tuesday, 143 mm of rain had accumulated on Green Island, about 33 kilometers off Taiwan's southeastern coast, 99 mm had accumulated in Taitung City, and 74.5 mm had accumulated in Taitung County's Dulan area, according to CWB data.

Centered more than 90 kilometers southwest of the Pratas Islands at 8 a.m. Tuesday, Tropical Storm Kammuri was packing maximum sustained winds of 65 kph and moving toward Hong Kong on a west-northwest course at 12 kph, the bureau said.
The bureau advised ships operating in the Bashi Channel, and in waters surrounding the Pratas Islands and off China's Guangdong province to be extra cautious.

DOC.HEADLINE: 31% of salary earners moonlighting: survey

TEXT.P: Thirty-one percent of salaried workers in Taiwan are moonlighting and earn on average an additional NT$22,000 (US$721) per month, a survey conducted by an online outsourcing company showed Tuesday.

The survey by www.jcase.com.tw also found that the most common second jobs were "case by case" jobs at 57.7 percent, followed by Internet auction work and jobs at special promotional events at holiday plazas or big malls.

Easing the pressure of high inflation has been the main motivation behind looking for second jobs, some 58 percent of salary earners said. The figure was higher than the 53 percent in 2007 and 34 percent in 2006.

The survey found that the top 10 items whose price rises have hit salary earners the hardest are: gasoline, electricity, basic goods such as tissue paper, natural gas, bread and other baked goods, local delicacies such as meatballs and oyster omelets, housing, lunch boxes, pork, instant noodles and crackers.
Overall, the salary earners have spent an additional NT$5,378 per month to cope with the latest wave of inflation.
If gauged by a 1-10 misery index where 10 was the most miserable, the misery index of salary earners currently stands at 7.93 points.
The survey was conducted between June 15 and July 5 with 1,488 effective questionnaires collected. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.5 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Deputy Kaohsiung mayor heads to Beijing for Olympics

TEXT.P: Deputy Kaohsiung Mayor Chiu Tai-san led officials to Beijing Tuesday to observe the upcoming Olympics and to promote the World Games to be held in the southern Taiwan port city next year.
Chiu said the group plans to attend the Beijing Olympic Games, which open Aug. 8, to observe its media services division and main press center.
During their stay in Beijing, all members of the group will don T-shirts emblazoned with the Chinese character "Kao" in purple to promote the World Games to be held in Kaohsiung in July 2009.
Chiu's group also bring with them brochures, pens and flags to distribute to Chinese groups as gifts.
The group will return to Kaohsiung Aug. 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interior ministry sets income criteria for housing subsidies program

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) finalized Monday the income criteria for a housing subsidy program targeting young couples who do not own a home, which is set to be launched next year.

Under the program, the government would provide a subsidy of NT$3,600 (US$117) per month for two years for those renting a home, or subsidize the full cost of interest on up to NT$2 million in home loans for the first two years of mortgages given to new homebuyers.

According to the income criteria set Monday by the MOI, applications for the rental subsidy will be open to households whose annual incomes fall in the bottom 60 percent of income earners in their places of residence.

Estimated to fall within this range will be households earning no more than NT$1.58 million per year in Taipei City, those earning no more than NT$1.14 million per year in Kaohsiung City, and those earning no more than NT$1.04 million per year in the rest of Taiwan, the ministry said.
In terms of the government-subsidized home loan, households whose annual incomes rank below the 80th percentile in disposable income will be eligible to apply.

This will cover households earning no more than NT$2.18 million per year in Taipei City, no more than NT$1.57 million per year in Kaohsiung City, and no more than NT$1.4 million in the rest of Taiwan.
In considering the applications, the government will also take into account the number of dependents the applicants are supporting, the MOI said.

According to other details already unveiled by the ministry, during the first year of the program, up to 20,000 households will receive the rental subsidy and up to 10,000 can receive the government-subsidized home loan.

In addition to meeting the income criteria, applicants for the rental subsidy must be couples aged 20-40 who were married within two years of the application date or who have children under 20 or adult children who are still studying.
Meanwhile, the preferential home loan is for couples aged 20-40 who were married within two years of the application date or those aged 20-45 who are upgrading to a bigger home after having children.

DOC.HEADLINE: Teco offers equipment to keep IC health cards flowing

TEXT.P: The supply of national health insurance IC cards will not be interrupted after Teco Electric and Machinery Co. offered to make available the manufacturing equipment needed to print the cards, the Bureau of National Health Insurance said Tuesday.

"In consideration of the public interest, Teco took the initiative in informing us yesterday evening that it will provide IC card manufacturing equipment for four months, " Chu Tzer-ming, the bureau's president and CEO, said Tuesday.

The arrangement ensures that the supply of IC cards, in which the medical records of the holder are stored, will remain normal after the existing contract with Teco to supply the cards expires Aug. 6.

The bureau said Monday that renewing the contract with Teco would violate the Public Officials' Conflicts of Interest Prevention Act, since Teco Chairman, C. K. Liu, is Premier Liu Chao-shiuan's brother.

It had originally anticipated having to issue about 800,000 temporary paper cards over the six months needed to find a new vendor to people who needed new cards, such as newborns and foreign spouses and workers.

Chu said that late Monday, Teco offered to make its card-processing equipment available to the government to process the 500,000 blank IC cards still in inventory from a two-year contract requiring Teco to provide 3.58 million IC cards.

The bureau will purchase the 500,000 blank cards and prepare them as needed with equipment provided by the company until the bureau finds a new supplier through an open bidding process, Chu said, now expecting the process to be completed in four months rather than the six months he estimated a day earlier.
Asked if the 500,000 blank IC cards will be sufficient to meet demand during the four-month period, Chu said "it should be", adding that paper cards were no longer an option.

Teco won the initial NT$3.8 billion contract to produce the cards in 2001, issuing the first national health insurance IC card in 2002. Since then, the contract has been renewed twice, in 2003 and 2006.
Teco on Monday said it was considering challenging the bureau's decision by applying for an interpretation of the Constitution so that the meaning of "conflict of interest" would be better defined.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TAIEX Index futures for September lost 156 points to finish at 6,744, with 577 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 146 points to close at 6,719, with 71 contract transactions.
March futures decreased 138 points to finish at 6,716, with 25 contract transactions, while June futures dropped 147 points to close at 6,700, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,934 for August, 6,900 for September, 6,865 for December, 6,854 for March and 6,847 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index lost 163.96 points to finish at 6,813.4, on turnover of NT$99.46 billion (US$3.23 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

August TE futures dropped 3.45 points to close at 266.95, with 4,262 contracts traded, while September TE futures decreased 3.4 points to finish at 265.6, with 48 contract transactions. DOC.HEADLINE: Wanan air raid drill postponed to Aug. 28

TEXT.P: The Wanan No. 31 air raid drill, originally scheduled to be held Tuesday night and then later set for earlier the same day, has now been postponed to the daytime of Aug. 28, the chief of staff of the Ministry of National Defense's Armed Forces Reserve Command said Tuesday.
Speaking at a news conference, Maj. Gen. Pi Hsueh-wen said the move was made in consideration of public concerns about the holding of the air drill at night.

The drill had been slated to be held in an area north of the counties of Hsinchu and Yilan between 10: 30 p.m. and 11 p.m. on Tuesday, but the scheduling drew criticism from many quarters, including Legislator Chai Trong-rong.

Chai argued that holding the drill at night would have caused disruptions by requiring homes, shops, commercial buildings and night markets in the area to turn off all lights and suspend operations during the drill.
In response, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan later issued orders for the drill to be held on Aug. 5 during the daytime.
At Tuesday's press conference, Pi said that a meeting was held Aug. 1 with interior ministry officials and representatives of local governments in the areas where the air drill is to be held.
It was agreed at the meeting that the air drill should be rescheduled to a later date, he said.
The air raid drill will now be held between 2: 30 p.m. and 3 p.m. on Aug. 28, he added.

Speaking at the same news conference, Lt. Gen. Wang Hsing-wei, chief of staff of the defense ministry's armed forces reserve department, said that the air raid drill was rescheduled for the daytime because the media and public had not been informed well enough in advance to avoid inconveniences.
He said that the ministry has not ruled out the possibility of holding air raid drills at night in the future if required and that adequate advance notice will be given to the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.055 to close at NT$30.721.
A total of US$1.06 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.695 and fluctuated between NT$30.602 and NT$30.758.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly half of Taipei high school students have fallen in love

TEXT.P: Nearly a quarter of junior high school students and 41.5 percent of senior high school students in Taipei City say they have experience of falling in love, according to a survey compiled by the city's Department of Health.

The survey recently conducted among students at 116 middle schools in the city shows that falling in love is a common phenomenon among high school students in the city, regardless of whether their parents are strict or permissive, according to department official Kao Wei-chun.
Junior high students struck by Cupid's arrow tended to have more permissive parents, while senior high students who had fallen in love were more likely to have strict parents, Kao noted.
Among junior high respondents who had fallen in love, 70.22 percent said they had been through a break-up, and among that group, 76.87 percent said they could accept it.
Just over 81 percent of senior high respondents who have been in love revealed they had suffered a break-up, with 83.28 percent of them saying they could accept it, the survey revealed.
The survey showed that the ratio of students who had been in love rose with their age and that the older the students were, the more accepting they were of breaking up.
In the survey, falling in love was defined as both sides admitting they were in love with each other and that a third party knew about the relationship.

On their feelings about falling in love, some 42 percent of junior high students and 48 percent of senior high students who had been in relationships said falling in love made them feel they were not lonely, as there was somebody to keep them company, Kao said.

That finding coincided with another of the survey's conclusions, which discovered that a high proportion of students who had been in love had parents who spent less than one hour per day keeping them company.
The survey also suggested that students who had been in relationships suffered emotional disturbances more often than those without the experience, Kao added.
In response to the survey, several education professionals said that it is now common for boys and girls to date on school campuses, and argued that banning dating would only have an adverse effect.

They suggested that schools strengthen gender and health education to help students to understand the differences between genders and instill in students proper concepts on how to get along with the opposite sex.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's de facto ambassador to U.S. assumes office
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 4 (CNA) 08/05/08 16:59:12 (By Jorge Liu and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new representative to the United States Jason Yuan said upon arriving in Washington, D.C. Monday that he expects the U.S. government will eventually approve pending sales of defensive weapons to Taiwan and that he will restore mutual trust between the two sides.
Yuan received a warm welcome from 100 Taiwanese officials and expatriates upon his arrival at a Washington, D.C. airport Monday.
Barbara J. Schrage, managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), also showed up to welcome Yuan.
Schrage said at the airport that the U.S. and Taiwan have long had a solid relationship and that she hopes bilateral relations will become more solid in the future.
Yuan, Taiwan's de facto ambassador to the U.S., agreed but claimed that the mutual trust between the U.S. and Taiwan has been undermined due to "human factors" over the past few years.
Yuan, who was sworn in on July 22 in Taipei, was referring to Taiwan's previous Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration, which governed Taiwan from 2000 to 2008.
The former DPP administration's strong advocacy of a Taiwan-centric identity led to friction with Washington during its term in office.

Relations grew particularly strained in 2007 when the DPP pushed a referendum asking local voters if they agreed to have Taiwan join the United Nations under the name "Taiwan," which Washington saw as a proxy vote on independence and provocative to China.
The U.S. is Taiwan's most powerful ally despite an absence of formal diplomatic ties.
At the airport, Yuan said he will use his sincerity to rebuild mutual trust.
As bilateral relations are solid, he said he believes that rebuilding trust will not be too difficult but will take time.

Asked about Washington's apparent freeze on weapons sales to Taiwan in recent years, Yuan noted that U.S. government agencies -- including the Department of State, the Department of Defense and the National Security Council -- have never used the word "freeze."
He said the U.S. is a country that follows the law and that the Taiwan Relations Act is "a U.S. law."
Under the Taiwan Relations Act, the U.S. must ensure Taiwan's security and supply necessary defensive weapons to Taiwan, he said.
As a result, he said he does not believe that any U.S. government official would violate the act and freeze arms deals with Taiwan.
The U.S. passed the Taiwan Relations Act in 1979 when it switched recognition to China.

Noting that the U.S. Congress is now in recess, Yuan said he believes that after Congress reconvenes, the U.S. government would notify Congress of its approval of the sale of an arms package to Taiwan.
He said he also believes that Congress would not object to the approval.
Congress will adjourn on Sept. 26, meaning the notification, which Congress has 30 days to respond to, would have to be submitted later this month for the arms deal to be finalized this year.
Asked about a specific time frame, Yuan responded that even if the arms package were to pass today, it would take years before Taiwan received the weapons.
The focus, he said, should be on whether the U.S. is willing to provide weapons and whether Taiwan is willing to buy them, and at this time, neither presents a problem, Yuan believed.

Asked if Taiwan worries that a new government in the U.S. next year will change the U.S.' policy on weapons sales to Taiwan, Yuan dismissed the concerns and said there will be continuity in government policies.
Meanwhile, he said Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou will keep a low profile and has no public activities scheduled for his stopovers in the U.S. on his way to and from Latin America later this month.

Ma is slated to depart Taiwan on Aug. 12 and will make a stopover on the U.S. west coast before attending presidential inaugurations in Paraguay and the Dominican Republic, two of the 23 countries that recognize Taiwan's statehood.
It will be Ma's first overseas visit since he took office in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's state visit itinerary unveiled

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will make two stopovers in the United States during his upcoming visit to Taiwan's diplomatic allies in South America and the Caribbean later this month, diplomatic sources said Tuesday.
The state visit will be Ma's first since he took office in May.
Ma will make low-profile U.S. stopovers and therefore will not meet Taiwanese expatriates or U.S. officials, lawmakers and scholars, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs sources said.
Ma's low-key efforts are aimed at repairing relations between the two sides, which critics said were strained by former President Chen Shui-bian.

Chen, who favored pushing a Taiwan-centric identity and asserting Taiwan's de facto sovereignty while he was in power from 2000 to 2008, was accused of using transit stopovers in the U.S. to strengthen his political support at home.
Ma has vowed not to follow his predecessor to capitalize on the state visit for political purposes.
The president will lead a delegation to attend presidential inaugurations in Paraguay and the Dominican Republic, two of the 23 countries that recognize Taiwan diplomatically, the sources noted.
He will depart Taipei on Aug. 12 on a China Airlines flight and make an overnight transit in Los Angeles, the sources said.
He will take a charter flight on Aug. 13 from Los Angeles to Paraguay, during which his plane will stop over in Panama to refuel, the sources said.
During his brief stay in Panama, Ma will meet his Panamanian counterpart, Martin Torrijos, to exchange views on bilateral relations, the sources said.
On Aug. 15, Ma will attend Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo's inauguration ceremony and head to the Dominican Republic later that day, the sources added.
Ma will take part in the inauguration of Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez, who was re-elected to a third term, on Aug. 16, the sources said.

Ma plans to board a charter flight to stop over in San Francisco the next day, the sources disclosed, adding that Ma's plane will stop in Austin, Texas, to refuel for one hour en route to San Francisco.
He will take a brief rest at a local hotel before flying home on another China Airlines flight, the sources said.
Ma is slated to arrive in Taiwan on Aug. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: President welcomes Nauruan counterpart with full military honors

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou welcomed visiting Nauruan President Marcus Stephen in a grand ceremony that included a 21-gun salute outside the Presidential Office Tuesday morning.
It marked the first time that Ma has welcomed a visiting foreign head of state with a formal ceremony complete with full military honors since assuming the presidency on May 20.
During the ceremony, Ma and his wife, Chow Mei-ching, accompanied Stephen and his wife in reviewing the Republic of China honor guard.

Ma said in his speech that Taiwan and Nauru have promoted many cooperative projects and that the Republic of China is more than happy to share its experience in public infrastructure construction to assist in Nauru's development.

He noted that the Republic of Nauru is a young country with which the Republic of China has maintained formal diplomatic relations for over 20 years. The two countries established formal ties in 1980.
The president also expressed his appreciation for Stephen's attendance at his inauguration ceremony in May.

In his speech, Ma said he was honored to welcome Stephen and his wife on behalf of the ROC government and people and expressed the hope that the Nauruan head of state could stay in Taiwan a little longer to visit some of the country's many places of interest to gain a better understanding of its development achievements.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top officials mark central science park's fifth birthday

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew and Premier Liu Chao-shiuan attended a ceremony at Taichung County's Central Taiwan Science Park Tuesday to mark the fifth anniversary of the founding of the high-tech stronghold.
Siew and Liu hailed the park's achievements, praising it as the leading engine of high-tech development in central Taiwan.
Siew attributed the park's success to its competitive strength, which is integrating advanced technology and traditional businesses.
"The Central Taiwan Science Park has set several records on several different fronts in terms of its rapid development, " Siew said.
The Central Taiwan Science Park has developed into a cluster of businesses focused on the optoelectronic and precision machinery sectors.
Liu promised that the government will do its best to help push the park's fourth-phase expansion, so that it can accommodate more companies and ramp up industrial development.

Based on President Ma Ying-jeou's plan for the "12 mega development projects," the government is committed to launching major construction project, boosting local and foreign investment and reducing investment barriers to drive sustainable growth, Liu said.

Yang Wen-ker, chief of the Central Taiwan Science Park Administration, reported that the park's projected investment capital is estimated at NT$1.7 trillion (US$55.92 billion) and its 2008 revenue is expected to hit around NT$360 billion.
Local government chiefs from central regions, including Taichung County Magistrate Haung Chung-sheng, Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan and several legislators also took part in the ceremony.

According to National Science Council (NSC) Minister Lee Lou-chuang, his council has not yet made a final decision on where to build the park's planned 600-hectare fourth-phase expansion, despite enthusiastic efforts from central Taiwan local government chiefs to lure the project to their districts.
Many companies are keen to open shop in the central science park, thanks to its profitable operations and sound management, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's mother's vital signs stable, hospital says

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's 86-year-old mother's vital signs are now stable, following her hospitalization Sunday for impaired blood flow to the brain, a Taipei hospital official said Tuesday.

Chin Hou-hsiu was hospitalized at Taipei's Wan Fang Hospital for vertigo caused by cerebral ischemia, said the hospital's deputy superintendent Hsu Chun-sen. Cerebral ischemia is a condition in which the brain doesn't receive enough blood to maintain normal functioning.

Various factors, such as high blood pressure and abnormal contraction of blood vessels, contribute to cerebral ischemia, Hsu said. But Hsu said that an examination of Chin's blood pressure and other indicators by a special medical team found her to be in stable condition.

The hospital suggested to the president's family that Chin remain in the hospital for a week to ensure that she recovers well. That means Chin will be discharged from the hospital on Aug. 11 at the earliest.
Ma visited his mother in the hospital on Monday and Tuesday, Hsu said.
Presidential Office Spokesman Wang Yu-chi thanked the public for their concerns about Chin's health, and said she should be fine after a period of rest.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 energy saving, carbon reduction plans will need NT$100 billion

TEXT.P: The government's energy saving and carbon reduction plans for next year will need a budget of more than NT$100 billion (US$3.25 billion) , an official of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Tuesday.
The package covers projects proposed by different government departments in line with the guidelines on the country's energy policy developed by the Executive Yuan in June, the official said.

The guidelines emphasized strengthening research and development of energy conservation, developing carbon-free renewable energy, and looking at nuclear power as an option for carbon-free energy, according to the official.
Increasing energy efficiency, phasing out old electricity power plants, and promoting green industry and green architecture were all highlighted in the guidelines, the official said.
The government's energy policy aims to reduce the annual level of carbon dioxide emissions in Taiwan to 2008 levels by 2020, and to 2000 levels by 2025, the official said.

The official said the projects in the budget package covered a range of proposals, such as promoting cycling as an alternative means of transportation, dispensing with the use of paper in offices, and planting forests.

The CEPD, which is responsible for drafting overall plans for national economic development, evaluating development projects and coordinating the economic policymaking activities of ministries and agencies, will submit the projects to the Executive Yuan for final approval, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Coast Guard saves over NT$8.79m on energy use in 1st half of year

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration said Tuesday that it saved more than NT$8.79 million (US$286,000) on energy use over the first six months of this year by following the Executive Yuan's energy conservation, carbon reduction and sustainable energy programs.
The savings came in the form of reduced water, electricity, diesel, gasoline and paper use, according to the Coast Guard.
Following the example set by its chief Wang Chin-wang, all of the Coast Guard's offices and patrol units around the country have been working in line with the energy conservation programs.

According to the Coast Guard's tallies, the coast guard's gasoline use for January-June was down by more than 167,400 liters over the same period a year earlier. However, due to rising fuel prices, the Coast Guard actually spent NT$118,000 more on gas year-on-year.

The Coast Guard's greatest success was in the reduction of diesel use, with the amount consumed for the first six months of this year dropping 1.38 million liters over the same period last year, for a savings of NT$5.41 million.

Second on the list was electricity use, which was down by over 662,000 kilowatt- hours, translating into savings of NT$2.41 million, followed by paper use, down by over 24,000 kilograms for NT$616,000 in savings, and water use, which the coast guard reduced by more than 100,000 cubic meters for savings of NT$470,000, according to the Coast Guard's tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police get tips for spotting bogus Chinese bills

TEXT.P: The National Police Agency (NPA) sponsored a seminar Tuesday to help police officers from cities and counties across Taiwan to better detect fake Chinese currency.

Fake yuan have become increasingly common since June 30, when Taiwan allowed convertibility between local New Taiwan dollars and the Chinese yuan at 1,500 branches of 13 local banks. The government timed the measure ahead of the arrival of greater numbers of Chinese tourists in early July.
At the seminar, experts displayed bogus Chinese yuan that had been seized in raids, to give police a better idea of what to look for.
"Once police officers become familiar with the methods for telling fake bills from real ones, they can also teach the public how to avoid counterfeit Chinese yuan bills," NPA officers said.

Police said that three features on Chinese yuan are hard to fake: a watermark of the Chinese characters of the bill's denomination in the center of the bill, a security thread similar to that on Taiwan's paper money, and features that appear to change color when observed from different angles.
Since the beginning of this year, police nationwide have seized 713 fake yuan bills in seven cases, the officers noted.
The counterfeit bills that police seized were made with advanced techniques, making them difficult for the general public to detect, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices down sharply on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 163.96 points to close at 6,813.4.

Finishing lower for the four consecutive day, the local bourse opened at the day's high of 7,005.17 and posted a low of 6,809.96, as the market failed to hold at the psychologically important 7,000-point barrier.
A total of 4.17 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$99.46 billion (US$3.23 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 6.5 percent. Foodstuff issues declined 5.9 percent, construction issues dropped 5.4 percent, paper and pulp issues fell 3.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares, textile stocks and banking and financial shares all shed 2.6 percent, and machinery and electronics shares were down 1.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,762 to 325, with 377 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$5.51 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of Chinese tourist arrivals far from satisfactory: DPP

TEXT.P: An opposition lawmaker argued Tuesday that the low number of Chinese tourist arrivals over the past month indicated a lack of success of President Ma Ying- jeou's efforts to attract Chinese tourists to boost the country's economy.

According to Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Gao Jyh-peng, Taiwan must curb its economic reliance on China because "China is insincere toward Taiwan" and "is still controlling the number of Chinese citizens allowed to visit Taiwan."
Gao noted that over the past month, since the first group of ordinary Chinese tourists arrived on July 4, only 5,664 China citizens have visited Taiwan for pleasure.
That number translates into an average 183 Chinese tourists per day, which is only 6.1 percent of the target number of 3,000 tourists per day set by Ma, Gao said.
Even if one counted only the 18 days from July 18 when Chinese tourists were officially allowed admission, the average daily arrivals still amount to only 299, he said.

While Ma claimed consumption in Taiwan spurred by the entry of 3,000 Chinese tourists daily would amount to more than NT$164 million (US$5.36 million) per day, or NT$60 billion per year, the actual consumption over the past month was estimated at only NT$9,862 per day, Gao said.
Though unsuccessful, the Kuomintang administration's policy to woo Chinese tourists has seriously affected the desire of Japanese tourists to visit Taiwan, the lawmaker said.

In June alone, Japanese tourist arrivals totaled only 86,022, down 6.63 percent from the same month last year, Gao pointed out. With each Japanese tourist spending US$264 per day in Taiwan on average, the decrease meant a loss of US$1.5 million in tourism income in June, he said.

Taiwan had opened its doors to group tours by certain categories of Chinese citizens since 2002, but ordinary Chinese citizens were only officially allowed to make sightseeing visits to the island from July 18, 2008, under an agreement signed between Taiwan and China in Beijing in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: German couple awarded tea artist certificates in Taiwan

TEXT.P: A German couple was awarded Alishan tea artist certificates after passing an examination on knowledge of tea and the tea-brewing process held by the Meishan township office in the southern county of Chiayi Monday.
Dressed in traditional Chinese Tang-style garments, the Germans Andy Yang and Yang Hung-feng, who were among the 10 examinees taking the test, drew a lot of attention from local residents.

Yang Hung-feng, who is of Chinese ethnicity, and her German husband Andy Yang are both fond of tea and are dedicated to the study of tea culture. They said they traveled to Taiwan specifically to take the exam after they learned that it was being held by the Meishan office.
The couple runs a tea house in Germany and has organized many training courses in tea culture for tea lovers there.

The exam included three categories -- subject tests, the identification of tea leaves, and the art of tea-brewing. Examinees are required to score more than 75 percent in order to obtain a certificate.

According to Huang Shi-yu, chief of Meishan township, despite its famous quality high mountain tea and advanced tea-drying technology, the township had long neglected the importance of promoting tea arts and tea lore.
However, the office began last October to offer the tea-brewing examination and to grant certificates to those who passed, according to Huang.

As part its efforts to promote tea arts, the office has also organized workshops in communities and schools to train local residents and students in the skills of tea brewing and to teach them tea culture, Huang said. As result, a total of 98 people passed the exam last October, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet pondering 4th-stage project of Central Taiwan Science Park

TEXT.P: Two counties in central Taiwan expressed interest Tuesday in providing land as a site for the Central Taiwan Science Park's fourth-stage development project, but Cabinet authorities said the location of the project had not yet been finalized.

The science park celebrated its fifth anniversary Tuesday, with Vice President Vincent Siew, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, other high-ranking government officials and many industry leaders attending the occasion to express their good wishes.

Over the past two years, the Cabinet has approved the second- and third-stage projects of the Central Taiwan Science Park, as the park's 413-hectare main base in Taichung can no longer meet the needs of high-tech industries.

The second-stage project will entail the development of a 97-hectare area in Yunlin County's Huwei township, while a 246-hectare tract in Houli township of Taichung County has been chosen for the third-stage development plan.
The Cabinet is now considering finding another tract of land for the fourth stage.

Attending the anniversary celebration, Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan told the vice president and the premier that his county is ready to be a part of the science park by providing the land for the fourth-stage project.
"Taichung City, Taichung County and Yunlin County all have a finger in the pie, and it would unfair to skip Changhua County," said Cho.

Another guest, Lee Ying-yuan, deputy magistrate of Yunlin County -- the only county in central Taiwan controlled by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party -- said the Cabinet should make the decision based on the park's needs rather than by considering a candidate county's political connections.
Lee said Yunlin County is also ready to provide the land and that its close proximity to the Sixth Naphtha Cracking Plant would be an added advantage.

In his congratulatory remarks, the vice president set forth a plan to build a high-technology corridor in western Taiwan, incorporating Taichung City, Taichung County, Yunlin County and Changhua County. This immediately prompted speculation that Changhua County might have been selected as the site for the fourth-stage development plan.

However, Lee Lou-Chuang, head of the Cabinet-level National Science Council, said the fourth-stage plan has not been finalized and that the Cabinet has not yet made a decision on the location of the project.
The Central Taiwan Science Park at present hosts more than 90 high-tech firms, with total business turnover expected to reach NT$360 billion (US$11.7 billion) in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Financial and insurance workers experience highest fatigue level: CLA

TEXT.P: Employees in the financial and insurance sector ranked at the top of a survey on work fatigue conducted by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) , according to the results released Tuesday.
They were followed by workers in the real estate business, and those in the fields of medical care and social work, the survey showed.

The survey conducted last September asked the respondents whether their work left them emotionally drained, made them feel frustrated, physically exhausted, depleted at the thought of another work day, and whether they found it hard to get through every minute at the work place?

For each of the five questions, there were five possible answers -- always, often, sometimes, seldom, and never. The score for each answer was 100, 75, 50, 25, and 0, respectively, with the higher score representing the higher level of fatigue.

Those workers who receive a combined score of 40 points and above were considered at the highest fatigue level. The average score of workers in the financial and insurance sector was 35.5 points, followed by those in real estate (35.2 points), and in the medical field and social work (29.9 points).

The fatigue level of employers and the self-employed was generally lower than that of employees, with workers in the transportation and warehousing sector recording an average 28.7 points, those in the accommodation and eatery business 26.2 points and those in the manufacturing sector 25.8 points.
In terms of gender, the fatigue level of female workers was higher, at 29.2 points, than that of the male workers, at 27.2 points.
The survey also found that for those employees who said they were tired at work, their level of dissatisfaction and feeling of unwellness was also higher.
The factors that usually contribute to fatigue include psychological problems, injustice and lack of safety in work place and low levels of participation in the decision-making process.

The survey on fatigue levels was conducted last September on a sampling of 19,000 employees and 5,000 employers and self-employed people, with 24,996 effective questionnaires, or 88 percent of the distributed questionnaires returned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese taekwondo ace seeking IOC Athlete's Commission seat

TEXT.P: An Olympic silver medal-winning Taiwanese taekwondo athlete is vying for a seat on the International Olympic Committee's (IOC's) Athlete's Commission, sports sources said Tuesday.
Huang Chih-hsiung, who is now a legislator, was nominated by the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee to run for four seats that will be up for grabs.

According to IOC regulations, the Athlete's Commission is composed of 19 members, seven of whom are designated by the IOC chairman, with the other 12 made up of eight summer sports athletes and four winter sports athletes.

Huang will compete with 28 other candidates recommended by the Olympic committees of their respective countries. Among Huang's competitors are Chinese gold medal hurdler Liu Xiang, Hong Kong table tennis player Li Ching, Australian swimmer Grant Hackett and Belgian tennis star Justine Henin-Hardenne.

The winning candidates, elected by formally registered Olympian athletes, will serve as full IOC members for the next eight years. The 10,600-plus Olympians eligible to vote in the election will cast their ballots in the 2008 Olympic Games host cities, including Beijing, Shanghai, Qingdao, Tianjin, Shengyang and Qinhuangdao. The voting time will be longest in the Beijing Olympic village -- until 02:00 p.m. Aug.20. The election result will be announced Aug. 21.
Huang, a bronze medalist at the Sydney Olympics in 2000 and a silver medalist in the 2004 Athens Olympics, was elected to the Legislative Yuan in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: Passenger load on cross-strait charters increasing gradually: CAA

TEXT.P: One month after the launch of direct weekend cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Tuesday that the number of passengers has been increasing week by week, and that the most popular air route is Taoyuan-Shanghai.

According to CAA Director General Lee Long-wen, during the first month of operation, the average passenger occupancy rate on the flights climbed from 83 percent on the weekend of July 4 to 89 percent on the fourth weekend of the month.
Some 52,000 passengers traveled on the charter flights in July, he said.

Among all the air routes, the Taoyuan International Airport to Shanghai route was most in demand, showing an average passenger occupancy rate of 93 percent, followed by the route Songshan airport in Taipei to Shanghai, China, with an occupancy rate of 87 percent, Lee said.
The average passenger occupancy rate in general was 87 percent, Lee said, adding that some airlines have already switched to larger aircraft to provide more seats.

"As the high occupancy rate means that demand is strong, it is possible that new negotiations on destinations and the number of flights will be held after the Beijing Olympic Games, " said Lee at a press conference.

He further indicated that during the period July 4 to Aug. 3, 5,381 Chinese tourists traveled to Taiwan on the weekend direct charter flights, implying that most of the passengers taking the flights are Taiwanese nationals.

Under an agreement signed June 13 by Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, Taiwan opened its doors to larger numbers of tourists from China, and weekend direct charter flights between the two sides were launched July 4.

In the initial stage of the opening, the daily ceiling on the entry of Chinese tourists was capped at 3,000, allowing for a total of 1.1 million Chinese visitors per year. In four years, the ceiling is expected to be raised to 10,000 per day.

DOC.HEADLINE: AmCham pleased to see eased economic restrictions

TEXT.P: The newly inaugurated president of the Taipei-based American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) applauded Tuesday the general direction of the government's economic policies, saying that the government should have as few restrictions on business as possible.
Andrea Wu made the remarks in her first media gathering after she took office July 1.
"We are pleased to see the general direction in which the new government is heading, even though details of the de-regulation measures have yet to be finalized," Wu said.
She said AmCham believes that it is better for businesses if the government intervenes less and lets the market mechanism take the lead.
"In the international economy, the more restrictions there are, the more harmful it is to business," Wu contended.

President Ma Ying-jeou's administration, which took office May 20, relaxed a number of economic policies, including making the decision to allow semiconductor firms to set up advanced 12-inch wafer factories in China and increasing the cap on China-bound investment to 60 percent of a firm's net worth, from 40 percent or less under the previous administration of former President Chen Shui-bian.
Asked about Taiwan's poor economic performance, she described it as a reflection of a global financial downturn rather than a result of wrong economic policies by the new government.

"It is too early to make judgment, as the government has been in office for a little more than 60 days, " Wu said. "Especially when most of the strong economic bodies in the world are suffering, it is very hard for Taiwan to perform differently."

Speaking of AmCham's annual "doorknock" trip to Washington, D.C. in June, Wu said that compared to the rather "challenging" trips made over the past few years, the atmosphere this year was very positive.
She said that in terms of Taiwan-U.S. economic relations, the encouraging atmosphere presents a window of opportunity for the government to work with the Bush administration.

Wu noted that there are several important things the government should address immediately to enhance economic relations between Taipei and Washington, including a Bilateral Investment Agreement (BIA) , a Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) and a Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA).
She said a GPA, BIA and TIFA can serve as building blocks toward a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) , which is something Taiwan is keen to sign.

Another message that the doorknock team brought back to Taipei was the suggestion that Taiwan should try to find more budget to help fund fellowships, scholarly exchanges, research grants and other programs for young U.S. academics engaged in Asian studies.
The goal for that, Wu said, would be to ensure over the long term that more American experts on the Asian region have some familiarity with Taiwan and concern about its future.

Prior to her AmCham appointment, Taiwan-born Wu was general manager of United Airlines, and she also served as AmCham vice chairwoman for two years before becoming the chamber's first female chair in 2004.
Established in 1951, AmCham, which consists of more than 950 individuals representing more than 500 companies, is the oldest, largest and most active foreign business organization in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Taiwan teas picked as 'Olympic First Teas'

TEXT.P: Two high quality, Taiwan-grown organic teas were among 12 recognized by Beijing Olympics organizers as "Olympic First Teas, " the Association of Taiwan Tea said Tuesday.
The two winners from Taiwan were the premium "Yipaohong" black tea and "Yipaolong" oolong produced by the Fofashan Organic Ecology Tea Farm in Taichung, central Taiwan.

They defeated several thousand Chinese and Taiwanese farms in a "battle of the teas, " winning the right to be displayed and served along with 10 other teas at the Beijing International Media Center during the Olympics.
"It is an honor to have the chance to join the 'cultural' dimension of the Games, " said Buddhist monk Shang Lun, the founder of the Fofashan Temple that operates the organic tea farm.
Olympics organizers are displaying tea, porcelain and silk in Beijing as three core elements of Chinese culture.
Master Shang Lun built the Fofashan tea farm in Dakeng of the Taichung county 15 years ago to grow tea through natural cultivation -- that is, without using chemical fertilizers or herbicides.

Association of Taiwan Tea Secretary Liang Ming-chan touted the farm's organic tea as "Buddhist tea that is injected with the Zen spirit in its planting, production and consumption." Taiwan's teas were the only organic teas selected to be "Olympic First Teas."
The honor recognizes Taiwan's efforts to promote environmentally-friendly "green agriculture," Liang noted.

In July, Fofashan's Yipaolong tea won the top prize in the oolong category of a national organic tea competition co-sponsored by the Taichung-based association and the Agricultural and Food Agency. The Yipaohong was the top prize-winner in the black tea category in the 2007 competition.
Liang said that Beijing Olympics organizers screened popular tea products from around China and Taiwan, inviting more than 100 Taiwanese tea producers to enter their best teas in the contest.
Teas were selected in six categories: oolong tea, black tea, green tea, white tea, yellow tea, and dark tea.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City animal neutering plan nearly 70 percent complete

TEXT.P: Taipei City animal health officials urged citizens Tuesday to seize the opportunity to have their cats and dogs neutered quickly to take advantage of a subsidy program that is already 60 percent complete.

According to the officials from the Taipei Municipal Institute for Animal Health, the city government had spent NT$2.546 million, or 67 percent its total annual budget, as of the end of July on the animal sterilization program that was launched at the end of last year.
The figure means that a total of 1,996 animals -- 1,354 female cats and dogs and 640 males -- have been neutered under the municipal subsidy program, the officials noted.
As some NT$1.64 million of the budget remains intact, municipal health officials encouraged Taipei citizens who have not yet done so to take their pets to get neutered.

Stray animals are a serious problem in Taiwan, particularly in Taipei City, where only 36 percent of the strays are sterilized -- well below the average 70 percent level in the United States, according to the institute.

As a result of the limited number of shelters available to hold stray cats, animal protection groups have aggressively encouraged adoption. They have also urged the government to increase its budget for animal contraception and its trap, neuter, release project, while reducing the amount spent on slaughtering unwanted animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung Mayor visits Scotland to learn about hosting arts events

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu visited Edinburgh City Council Deputy Leader Steve Cardownie Monday in the Scottish capital to learn from the city's experience in holding arts festivals, according to a press statement released by the Kaohsiung city government Tuesday.

Chen arrived in Edinburgh Aug. 3 to visit groups of performers from Kaohsiung City taking part in the Edinburgh Festival Fringe -- commonly known as the Fringe -- which takes place over three weeks every August.
The Fringe, alongside several other arts and cultural festivals is collectively known as the Edinburgh International Festival.
According to the statement, Cardownie said the Fringe, which was established in 1947, brings in revenue of US$234.28 million every year for the city.

Chen expressed admiration for the city's ability to organize successful arts festivals and exchanged views with Cardownie on how a city's image can be enhanced through such festivals, the statement said.
Chen expressed hope that she will be able to apply what she has learned in Edinburgh to planning events for her southern port city, according to the statement.

She also invited Cardownie to visit Kaohsiung City to attend a folklore festival that will begin Oct. 11, and a lantern festival that will be held at the beginning of next year, in the hope that Cardownie will give advice on improving Kaohsiung's event organization and planning, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to shine at Venice architecture exhibition

TEXT.P: Taiwan will have a fruitful year and shine in the international architecture industry as it is showcasing two of the country's outstanding architectural works at the 11th International Architecture Exhibition in Venice in September, Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) Minister Huang Pi-twan said at a news conference Tuesday.

The 11th Architecture Biennale -- La Biennale di Venezia -- will take place in Venice from Sept. 14-Nov. 23 with the theme of "Out There: Architecture Beyond Building, " which emphasizes the experimental aspects of "work using means, venues, images and forms that come before, go beyond, do without or supersede autonomous buildings."

In addition to a project titled "Dark City, " which was chosen by the CCA to represent Taiwan at the world-renowned exhibition, "Somewhere Out There," a work created by a group called Interbreeding Field -- a team from Tainan National University of the Arts -- received an unprecedented invitation from the biennale to be presented in the central building at the Padiglione Italia along with various Italian projects.

"With this invitation from the biennale, Interbreeding Field has written a new page on the art of Taiwan's architecture, said Huang. "We believe that the two projects demonstrate the strength of Taiwan's architecture talent and will bring a Taiwanese flavor to the biennale," he added.

Lu Li-hung, director of Interbreeding Field and associate professor of the Tainan National University of the Arts, said the team is honored to be invited and is anxious to demonstrate its work to the world.
"We will do our best to showcase Taiwan's creative strength, " Lu said, adding that "I hope our work can win international recognition."
Featuring several large installations of LED bulbs in hundreds of white plastic containers, Lu said the work aims to create a relationship between the spectator and the environment.

"The project examines the possibilities of experimental constructions in the fields of joy, life meditation, indulgence, trance and tranquility in order to create an interaction between the spectator and the object within the emotional memory and atmosphere of the overall construction of the space," he said.

Using video footage and graphic collages, Kuo Chao-lee, director of the "Dark City" project, said the work proposes the concept of "meaning installation" and that its objective is to disclose the undercurrent energy and the secretive affairs of the city at night, as well as to challenge the legitimacy of the popular practice of "designing for the day."

"It returns space to a `primordial' state before building, " he said. "It is a space of body, a space of tectonics and illusion. It is also a local representation of the dark urbanism of Taiwan, allowing the visitor to converse with it directly with bodily senses and letting meanings be nomads roaming from one world to another," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local women think exercise can help men be more energetic: survey

TEXT.P: Taiwanese wives often advise their better halves to get more exercise to keep their energy levels up, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by the Taiwanese Association of Andrology.
The survey was conducted among women aged 18-40 by National Chengchi University and was commissioned by the association.
The results show that over half of the respondents described President Ma Ying- jeou as representative of "Taiwan's energetic man."
Ma, an avid jogger and swimmer, maintains a regular exercise regime.
Among the country's other high-ranking political figures, former Premier Frank Hsieh was also rated as an energetic man by 10 percent of the respondents.

Among the nation's city and county chiefs, 4.5 percent of those polled described Taichung Mayor Jason Hu as the most energetic local chief, ahead of Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin and Taoyuan Magistrate Eric Liluan Chu.
Asked how they try to make their partners more energetic, 90 percent of those surveyed said they ask their men to "exercise more," while 4.5 percent said they feed them tonics.
In terms of locality, women in Taichung City have most confidence in tonics, followed by women in Taipei City and Kaohsiung City.

Wang Chi-chieh, president of the association and director of the Department of Urology at Kaohsiung Medical University Hospital, said that "more exercise is the right approach" and expressed reservations about the efficacy of taking tonics or eating seafood, saying that random tonics can actually pose a health hazard, especially as most people get enough nutrition from their regular diet, so that more tonics simply place an added burden on the body.

Wang also said that when men experience symptoms of low energy and endurance, as well as erectile difficulty or dysfunction, they should not take tonics but should seek professional advice from doctors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan firms' credit outlook seen as stable despite emerging risks

TEXT.P: The credit outlook for Taiwan's top 100 corporations was largely stable in 2007, although they faced higher risks due to the weakened economic environment around the globe, a local credit rating company said Tuesday.

Taiwan Rating Corporation (TRC) announced its latest credit evaluations of Taiwan's top 100 enterprises, selected on the basis of sales revenue, and indicated that credit quality generally remained stable among the top-tier corporations in 2007.

Credit ratings, usually assigned to straight bonds, convertibles, subordinated debt and syndicated loans, can be used as a tool for investor relations, transparency and disclosure with the aim to facilitate creditors as well as investors to check the financial health of a company.

"Taiwan's corporations have done fairly well throughout the economic cycles because of their cost competitiveness, " Daisuke Fukutomi, TRC's vice president and chief ratings officer said at a press meeting Tuesday.
According TRC, 40 percent of the top companies showed strong credit quality, while another 40 percent had moderate credit quality, and the other 20 percent were ranked as weak.

Daisuke added that conservative financial leverage could also help Taiwanese companies to get through a possible recession, admitting that the global economic downturn and widespread inflation had increased credit risks in the performance of local enterprises.

The other analysts at the press meeting agreed that while Taiwan enterprises still have an edge among their Asia-Pacific competitors, capital liquidity will be a vital factor in weathering the economic slowdown.
Daniel Hsiao, TRC's director of corporate & funds ratings, said that the export-driven operation model of Taiwan's enterprises was at some level hurt by the shrinking U.S. and EU markets.
"Companies would need more capital liquidity and better operation management to sustain their credit standards," Hsiao said.
Another analyst, Frank Fan, TRC's associate director of corporate & funds ratings, said Taiwan industries have unique global advantages.

Improved cross-Taiwan Strait economic ties, led by financial deregulation, would specifically give Taiwan's enterprises more room to operate, Fan said, adding that the potential benefit would be long-term.

He was referring to the relaxation of financial regulations proposed by the Kuomintang government since it took office earlier this year. The administration has said that it intends to implement 66 categories of deregulations, including 20 related to cross-strait affairs, by the end of this year.

Asked if Taiwan's enterprises generally represent a better investment target compared to Asia's three other little dragons -- Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea -- Hsiao said Taiwan's industry sector, especially its hi-tech industries, stand out because of superb cost management.

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, Foxconn, Chunghwa Telecom and AU Optronics ranked as the top four Taiwanese companies in the terms of cash flow and liquid financial assets, which reached NT$174.8 billion, NT$145.8 billion, NT$95.2 billion, and NT$91.2 billion, respectively in 2007, according to TRC.
"A healthy cost structure is normally the competitive edge that Taiwanese companies have in competing with global players, " Hsiao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AthenaWeb to broadcast short science films by NCCU students

TEXT.P: AthenaWeb, the world's leading Internet audiovisual communication platform for scientific information, will feature a series of short science films made by students of National Chengchi University (NCCU) in Taipei, the European Economic and Trade Office in Taiwan said in the latest issue of its monthly EU Newsletter.

The films, to be presented from August, will be "the first student-produced programs ever to be posted on AthenaWeb," the July newsletter said, adding that this new development will be followed by the launch of an international competition for Internet films by science students later this year.

The films by NCCU students are works from the Science Talent Training Program of the Cabinet-level National Science Council, which has encouraged science students to form teams, create scripts and shoot their own films in an attempt to allow the students to bring their skills into full play.

"Every one of the short movies created by the NCCU displays the students' deep understanding of their selected scientific subjects and their excellent teamwork in a most playful and entertaining manner," according to the newsletter.
AnthenaWeb, launched in 2005, is supported by the European Commission's Research Directorate-General and is run by the Brussels-based media agency Lab to Media.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alien bird threatens survival of native species, researchers warn

TEXT.P: An alien bird species popular among local bird-fanciers, the white-rumped shama thrush (copsychus malabaricus), has invaded many low-altitude forest areas around Taiwan, posing a great threat to the survival of native species, the state-operated Endemic Species Research Institute warned Tuesday.

The bird is a small passerine that originates in South Asia and is found from India to southwestern China and Malaysia. With a beautiful voice and the ability to mimic the sounds of other birds, it was introduced to Taiwan by bird-fanciers and was a popular cage bird until the global outbreak of avian influenza in 2003.
Institute researchers said they have been found to be increasing in number in the wild in Taiwan over the past few years after being either accidentally or deliberately released.
With the ability to adapt themselves quickly to new environments, the bird has succeeded in colonizing Taiwan and now breeds in great numbers, the researchers said.

In field observations, the researchers said they have found that shama thrush feeds on many different kinds of arthropods, earthworms, frogs and lizards, posing a threat to these species as well as to local bird species with which they compete for food.

DOC.HEADLINE: July CPI the highest since October 1994: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Led by a 13.61 percent hike in food prices, Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) rose 5.92 percent year-on-year in July to 106.88, the highest since October 1994, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Tuesday.

In its monthly CPI report, the DGBAS indicated that the country's inflation rate, core CPI, and wholesale price index (WPI) had all hit the highest levels in recent years, mainly due to two storms and rising domestic fuel and electricity prices.

"The CPI increase in July was the highest since October 1994," said Chao-Ming Wu, a DGBAS section chief, at a news conference Tuesday. He noted that the inflation rate in September 1994 was 6.69 percent.

Wu said the 13.61 percent hike in food prices represented the largest rise of any category in the index's basket of goods, as the prices of cooking oil, fruits, and meats rose by 42.02 percent, 25.52 percent and 24.76 percent year- on-year, respectively.
"Food prices in July were responsible, for the most part, for the inflation, and represented 3.48 percent of the overall index," he said.
Wu hinted at the possibility that food prices might fall in the coming months, as international grain prices have dropped by nearly 40 percent in the last half year.

Domestic transportation costs also increased considerably, with the transportation index rising 6.80 percent year-on-year, representing 0.97 percent of the overall CPI growth rate, according to the report.

"This increase has to do with gasoline prices, which were hiked by 1.5 percent in the beginning of July," Wu said, adding that generally fuel prices rose by 23.26 percent, the biggest jump in the transportation category.
The core CPI, which excludes the prices of energy, fresh vegetables, fruit, and seafood, also rose by 4.06 percent year-on-year, the highest since March 1996.

When asked if the annual inflation rate is likely to increase, Wu declined to speculate on the possibility, saying the bureau will need to further evaluate the situation before adjusting its forecast of 3.29 percent made in May.
The growth rate of consumer prices was 4.18 percent for the period January to July this year, leaving a slim possibility for the annual index to drop to the level of the DGBAS May forecast.

Wu said that because of the two typhoons that caused severe damage to the island's agriculture sector in July, the CPI had peaked in summer. He said that the growth rate could decline in September and October.
Inflationary pressure could be seen in the WPI for imported commodities, which rose by 11.49 percent year-on-year, he said.

"Excluding the impact of the Taiwan dollar's appreciation, the WPI for imported commodities, valued in U.S. dollars, soared by 26.50 percent in June, the highest since March 1980," Wu said. The the index rose 26.90 percent in February 1980 because of the second oil crisis, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Photovoltaic Power Expo Taiwan 2008 to take place Sept. 9-11

TEXT.P: The 2008 Photovoltaic (PV) Power Expo Taiwan will take place Sept. 9-11 at the Taipei International Convention Center, organizers announced Tuesday.

Held by SEMI -- the global association of the semiconductor industry -- and the Taiwan Photovoltaic Industry Association, the event is expected to attract the participation of most of the key players in the industry, the organizers said, adding that it is expected to draw 10,000 visitors.
Experts from leading companies in the field have also been invited to give lectures during a series of forums on the sidelines of the show.

The event will be held along with two other exhibitions -- Semicon Taiwan 2008 at the Taipei World Trade Center's Hall 1 and Hall 3, and International IC- Taiwan Conference and Exhibition at the World Trade Center's Hall 2.
Taiwan's PV solar cell production value reached US$1.56 billion in 2007, ranking fourth in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan succeeds in propagation of rare salmon species

TEXT.P: Much to the excitement of local researchers, artificially raised Formosan landlocked salmon -- a critically endangered species -- have been successfully breeding since being introduced into new habitats in the wild, an ichthyologist announced Tuesday.

Researchers from the Wuling Formosan Landlocked Salmon Conservation Center in the Sheipa National Park in central Taiwan have released about 1,000 of the artificially bred rare salmon into the park's Sihjielan and Nanhu rivers over the past two years.
According to Liao Lin-yen, the center's director, a new generation of Formosan landlocked salmon, numbering about 80 to 90, were seen swimming in the Sihjielan river in June.
"It marks the first time that the rare fish species -- a holdover from the last Ice Age -- has survived and reproduced in a new habitat," Liao said.
In the past, the fish could only be found in the Cijiawan river, a protected sanctuary for the Formosan landlocked salmon in the Sheipa National Park.
In the Nanhu river, Liao went on, only previously released salmon bearing identification tags have been seen so far, meaning that they have not yet spawned.

The migration propagation of the rare fish, however, has drawn mixed reactions, with opponents saying that the species should not be propagated in a location where the fish has not previously been documented in history, while proponents say migration propagation is vital to preserve the salmon, which faces the threat of extinction.
Liao said the conservation center remains neutral toward the issue and is more concerned about conservation of the center's water supply.

"As the water in the Cijiawn river tends to be very turbid following typhoons, the conservation center needs to store water in advance to ensure that fry being raised at the center can survive, " Liao said.

Although the environmental devastation caused by rampant overcultivation of orchards and vegetable farms in the nearby Wuling Farm area has been brought under control, landslides in the upper reaches of the river continue to occur, causing serious turbidity downstream in the wake of typhoons or heavy rain, Liao said.
Without a large storage pond, the water supply is often insufficient, Liao said, adding that the center is considering drilling wells as a second water supply source.

Meanwhile, Liao said although the national park administration has built a special structure in which the rare fish can take refuge in emergencies, the number still suffers a steep decline after every typhoon or rainstorm.

"Salmon numbers in the Cijiawan river have declined by about 25 percent to some 1,500 animals at the moment, due to the effects of Tropical Storm Kamaelgi and Typhoon Fung Wong that swept across Taiwan in the past few weeks," he noted.

The Formosan landlocked salmon (Oncorhynchus masou formosanus) , one of the rarest fish in the world, is a subspecies of the seema, which is also found in Taiwan. The subspecies is critically endangered and classed as being at high risk of extinction.

Once a staple of the Taiwanese aborigine diet, overfishing meant that there were barely 400 of the salmon left before efforts to conserve and protect them began. Today, their biggest enemy is pollution, as the fish requires very clean and cold water to thrive.
The salmon became landlocked during the last glacial epoch in frigid mountain streams, and thus its discovery in Taiwan -- a subtropical island -- is considered a biological miracle.

Formosan landlocked salmon grow to about 30 cm in length and inhabit cold, slow- flowing streams with gently sloping beds at elevations above 1,500 meters, such as the Cijiawan river in the upper reaches of the Tachia river.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitung magistrate released after being questioned

TEXT.P: Controversial Taitung County Magistrate Kuang Li-chen was released Tuesday after being questioned by prosecutors for more than four hours over suspected irregularities related to a just-concluded trip she made to Europe.

Prosecutors, however, listed Kuang as a suspect to be subject to further investigation into whether she had squandered public money or rewarded her grassroots campaign operatives at taxpayer's expense.

Kuang, accompanied by 13 Taitung county government officials and township chiefs, returned to Taipei Monday morning after visiting several European countries, including Italy, in the name of learning about their tourism promotion measures.

Prosecutors originally planned to question her upon her return from Taipei to Taitung, an agricultural backwater in eastern Taiwan, Monday. But Kuang and her chief secretary disappeared on their way from Hualien airport to Taitung Monday evening after noticing that prosecutors were trailing them.
Kuang took the initiative to contact prosecutors Tuesday and showed up at the Investigation Bureau's Taitung outpost in the afternoon.
After more than four hours of interrogations, prosecutors released Kuang but listed her as a suspect for subsequent probes into graft charges.
Members of her entourage were also questioned after their return to Taitung Monday evening and all of them had been released, pending further investigations.

Kuang, a stewardess-turned-politician, came under fire after taking 10 township chiefs and other county officials on a 13-day trip to Europe in late July despite knowing that Typhoon Fung Wong was approaching. She has also been criticized for spending millions of taxpayers' money on frequent overseas trips since taking office two years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug.6, 2008

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open sharply higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened sharply higher Wednesday.
The weighted price index was up 128.10 points at 6,941.50 on a turnover of NT$4.27 billion (US$138.99 million) at the open. The index lost 163.96 points, or 2.4 percent, to close at 6,813.40 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Wednesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$30.799 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.078 from Tuesday.
