DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan succeeds in propagation of rare salmon species

TEXT.P: Much to the excitement of local researchers, artificially raised Formosan landlocked salmon -- a critically endangered species -- have been successfully breeding since being introduced into new habitats in the wild, an ichthyologist announced Tuesday.

Researchers from the Wuling Formosan Landlocked Salmon Conservation Center in the Sheipa National Park in central Taiwan have released about 1,000 of the artificially bred rare salmon into the park's Sihjielan and Nanhu rivers over the past two years.
According to Liao Lin-yen, the center's director, a new generation of Formosan landlocked salmon, numbering about 80 to 90, were seen swimming in the Sihjielan river in June.
"It marks the first time that the rare fish species -- a holdover from the last Ice Age -- has survived and reproduced in a new habitat," Liao said.
In the past, the fish could only be found in the Cijiawan river, a protected sanctuary for the Formosan landlocked salmon in the Sheipa National Park.
In the Nanhu river, Liao went on, only previously released salmon bearing identification tags have been seen so far, meaning that they have not yet spawned.

The migration propagation of the rare fish, however, has drawn mixed reactions, with opponents saying that the species should not be propagated in a location where the fish has not previously been documented in history, while proponents say migration propagation is vital to preserve the salmon, which faces the threat of extinction.
Liao said the conservation center remains neutral toward the issue and is more concerned about conservation of the center's water supply.

"As the water in the Cijiawn river tends to be very turbid following typhoons, the conservation center needs to store water in advance to ensure that fry being raised at the center can survive, " Liao said.

Although the environmental devastation caused by rampant overcultivation of orchards and vegetable farms in the nearby Wuling Farm area has been brought under control, landslides in the upper reaches of the river continue to occur, causing serious turbidity downstream in the wake of typhoons or heavy rain, Liao said.
Without a large storage pond, the water supply is often insufficient, Liao said, adding that the center is considering drilling wells as a second water supply source.

Meanwhile, Liao said although the national park administration has built a special structure in which the rare fish can take refuge in emergencies, the number still suffers a steep decline after every typhoon or rainstorm.

"Salmon numbers in the Cijiawan river have declined by about 25 percent to some 1,500 animals at the moment, due to the effects of Tropical Storm Kamaelgi and Typhoon Fung Wong that swept across Taiwan in the past few weeks," he noted.

The Formosan landlocked salmon (Oncorhynchus masou formosanus) , one of the rarest fish in the world, is a subspecies of the seema, which is also found in Taiwan. The subspecies is critically endangered and classed as being at high risk of extinction.

Once a staple of the Taiwanese aborigine diet, overfishing meant that there were barely 400 of the salmon left before efforts to conserve and protect them began. Today, their biggest enemy is pollution, as the fish requires very clean and cold water to thrive.
The salmon became landlocked during the last glacial epoch in frigid mountain streams, and thus its discovery in Taiwan -- a subtropical island -- is considered a biological miracle.

Formosan landlocked salmon grow to about 30 cm in length and inhabit cold, slow- flowing streams with gently sloping beds at elevations above 1,500 meters, such as the Cijiawan river in the upper reaches of the Tachia river.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese Americans urge U.S. to 'unfreeze' Taiwan arms sales
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 5 (CNA) 08/06/08 11:49:59 (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The leaders of 19 Taiwanese-American groups have jointly written to U.S. President George W. Bush urging him to "unfreeze" the US$11 billion worth of arms sales to Taiwan that reportedly have been held up by the Bush administration.

In the letter dated Aug. 1 that was delivered to Bush ahead of his departure for Beijing to attend the opening ceremony of the 2008 Olympic Games, the leaders said the "real and grave threat" posed by China's military deployment targeting Taiwan "requires that Taiwan possesses a credible national defense."
They asked Bush not to forget Taiwan, a "beacon of democracy" to which he pledged "whatever it took" to help it defend itself in 2001.
They recalled that in his second inaugural address, Bush told his nation that "the survival of liberty in our land increasingly depends on the success of liberty in other lands."
"The success of liberty is not to be found in China where you are visiting. Rather it has been achieved in Taiwan across that narrow strait," they noted.

There have been reports that the Bush administration is holding back on congressional notifications for the pending arms sales to Taiwan so as not to upset relations with China ahead of the Olympic Games.

The list of military hardware reportedly being held up includes anti-tank missiles, Apache helicopters, Patriot PAC-3 missile batteries, diesel-powered submarines, P3C anti-submarine aircraft and sea-launched Harpoon missiles.
Taiwan fears that if the notifications are not sent a month before the U.S. Congress adjourns in September, approval of the sales will be pushed to 2009 and a new U.S. administration.
Responding to speculation surrounding the delay in processing the sales, the U.S. Department of State reiterated last month that Washington has not changed its policy on arms sales to Taiwan.

State Department spokesman Sean McCormack said July 18 that the administration "faithfully implements the Taiwan Relations Act" and that there is an "internal interagency process" for the U.S. government to consider all military exports, including sales to Taiwan.
"When the interagency process achieves a final decision for specific arms sales, we will notify Congress," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Giant bike dealer joins final Beijing Olympic torch relay
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 6 (CNA) 08/06/08 14:08:15 (By Chen Yen-chun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessman Lin Ching-fa, who runs the flagship store in Beijing for Taiwan-based bicycle maker Giant Manufacturing, was the only citizen from Taiwan to join the final Olympic torch relay in Beijing, which started Wednesday.
Lin, 54, was the sixth person in the Beijing relay on Wednesday, which began with Yang Liwei -- China's first astronaut -- at the Wumen Square in front of the Forbidden City at 8:05 a.m.

Lin received the torch from Han Meilin -- the designer of Fuwa, the official mascot of the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games -- at 8:10 a.m. and passed the torch to Chang Hao -- one of China's ace Go players -- at 8:11 a.m.

Other runners on the Beijing Olympic torch relay name list include NBA star Yao Ming, film director Zhang Yimou, China's Deputy Foreign Minister He Yafei, pianist Lang Lang, Singaporean song writer/singer Lin Junjie, and 29 other foreign nationals as well as two Hong Kongers.

A total of 841 people will join the final stage of the Beijing Olympic torch relay in the run-up to the official opening of the Games in Beijing at 8: 08 p.m. on Aug. 8. The identity of the last runner who will carry the torch to the top of the Olympic Stadium and light the Olympic flame remains a secret.

Lin, a veteran road cycling coach, whose student Hsu Jui-teh has served as the coach of Taiwan's Olympic road cycling teams in 2004 and 2008, felt extremely proud to join the final torch relay in Beijing.
Lin bought an office/shop near the Olympic Stadium, known as the Bird's Nest, in 2002 to open Giant's flagship store, which Lin said has since tripled in value.
He was elected chairman of the Taiwan Business Association in Beijing in January this year and two months later, he was informed by the Beijing authorities about the final torch relay activity.

As a liaison for Taiwan Olympic committee in Beijing, he will enjoy special privileges during the Games, including access to all competition venues and locations, exemption from driving restrictions, and seating reserved for honorary guests at the opening ceremony Aug. 8.
"Good things come to those who are prepared," a proud Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor council to review minimum wage

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will hold a screening committee meeting at the end of this month to discuss whether to raise the minimum wage, CLA spokesman Pan Shih-wei confirmed Wednesday.

Pan, who is also a CLA deputy minister, said that the council will respect the decision of the screening committee, which is comprised of 22 members, including the CLA minister and two deputy ministers, representatives from other government agencies, and scholars.
The conclusion of the committee will then be sent to the Executive Yuan for a final decision, Pan said.

The nation's minimum monthly wage was raised to NT$17,280 (US$566) from NT$15,840 in July 1, 2007, benefiting about 1.41 million "marginal" members of the country's 8.8 million laborers -- including foreign laborers, part-time workers, senior citizens who have returned to the employment market after retirement and female workers.

Due to recent surges in consumer prices, many laborers have expressed the hope of a further wage increase, and labor groups have appealed to the CLA for an increase in the minimum wage on their behalf.

But as labor insurance and health insurance premiums are calculated based on the minimum wage, the CLA has expressed worries that a basic wage increase will put an extra burden on these low-paid workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Officials call for FTA negotiations with Thailand

TEXT.P: Taiwan pushed Wednesday for the opening of negotiations on a free trade agreement (FTA) with Thailand, as part of the government's pledge to promote economic integration in the Asia Pacific region.

At an annual meeting of trade officials and industry leaders from Thailand and Taiwan, local economic officials said that following a pact on economic and trade cooperation signed between the two sides in 1989, FTA talks should be next step in intensifying trade cooperation.

Alfred F. L. Chen, the chairman of the Thailand Committee of the Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association, a local semi-official trade promotion body, raised the FTA initiative to Thai economic officials at the meeting, saying Thailand is becoming more important to Taiwan's economic expansion.
He called on the governments of the two countries to seriously consider starting FTA negotiations and consultations as soon as possible.
The signing of an FTA would be highly conducive to the expansion of both economies and the enhancement of bilateral trade and investment, Chen said, explaining the main goals of a trade agreement.

Taiwan has tried in recent years to forge FTAs with major economies such the U.S., Japan, Singapore, Korea and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries, but to no avail because of political obstacles.
Chen hinted that there could be some movement on FTA bids under the new Kuomintang government because of its commitment to trade expansion throughout neighboring regions.

In the face of the recent global economic downturn, Chen said it is time for Taiwan and Thailand to enhance economic cooperation and market expansion, and build on recent growth in bilateral trade, which rose 11 percent in 2007 to US$8.67 billion (NT$265.30 billion).
Fadah Hsieh, the vice economics minister, echoed Chen by calling for support from Taiwanese and Thai industrial leaders to help Taiwan join in the economic integration process of neighboring regions.
Hsieh said Taiwan is the world's 19th largest economy, and the absence of Taiwan in any economic integration process would not be in the interest of its international trading counterparts.
An integration process without Taiwan is imperfect, Hsieh said.

The vice minister hinted that a free trade deal with Thailand could help expedite regional integration by giving Taiwan access to ASEAN's 10-country, 550-million people market, which is expected to form a unified economic community by 2015.

Participating Thai officials, including Mangkorn Dhanasarnsilp, vice chairman of the Federation of Thai Industries, and Arbhorn Manasvanich, executive director of Thailand Trade and Economic Office, however, did not respond to the FTA issue in their initial remarks.

Hsieh also said Taiwan will welcome the participation of Thai investment in the government's major infrastructure program. The projects outlined under the plan will need an estimate NT$3.9 trillion in funds.
Taiwan is currently the third largest foreign investing country in Thailand, with its total investment of US$12.17 billion there lagging only behind Japan and the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for August rose 239 points to close at 7,017, with 63,636 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September gained 237 points to finish at 6,984, with 688 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 232 points to close at 6,951, with 82 contract transactions.
March futures increased 223 points to finish at 6,939, with 13 contract transactions, while June futures advanced 228 points to close at 6,928, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,778 for August, 6,747 for September, 6,719 for December, 6,716 for March and 6,700 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 212.84 points to finish at 7,026.24, on turnover of NT$115.01 billion (US$3.73 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
August TE futures rose 11.85 points to close at 278.6, with 4,457 contracts traded, while September TE futures increased 11.7 points to finish at 277.3, with 60 contract transactions.
March TE futures gained 9.55 points to end at 270, with two contract transactions, while June TE futures advanced 4.9 points to close at 270, with one contract transaction.
August TF futures moved up 32.2 points to close at 891, with 2,889 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures advanced 25.6 points to finish at 887, with 78 contracts traded.

December TF futures increased 26 points to end at 879, with four contract transactions, while March TF futures advanced 23.8 points to end at 880, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative watchdog to publish assessment report

TEXT.P: A nonprofit group monitoring the Legislative Yuan said Wednesday it will publish a report with assessments of Taiwan's lawmakers next month.

Ku Chung-hua, the chairman of The Citizen Congress Watch (CCW) , said its assessment panels will rate the performance of the 113 legislators during the body's first session, which began in February and should have ended in May, but was extended to July 18.
"The duty of lawmakers is to improve public welfare, and the performance of each of them is especially important given the fact that it is the first streamlined legislature," he said.
Ku said the watchdog body will form eight assessment panels to monitor the performance of the lawmakers in the eight legislative committees.
The panel will be comprised of scholars, and representatives from the media and civic groups, Ku said.
The assessment is expected to be complete at the end of August and be published by Sept. 15, he added.
CCW Executive Director Ho Tsung-hsun said that the group will assess the performance of individual legislators, conveners of the legislative committees, and caucus members.

Taking a legislator as an example, the group will gauge the performance based on attendance and speaking rates, commendable behavior, bill screening, information disclosure, erratic performance, and improper motions.
The group "welcomes any legislators who take the initiative to provide information, so that we can compare their information with the information we've received."

Ho noted that Legislators Wu Yu-sheng and Chao Li-yun of the ruling Kuomintang; Chang Hwa-kuan, Wang Sing-nan and Yu Jane-daw of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party and Lin Pin-kuan of the Non-partisan Solidarity Union have provided their own information to the group.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 212.84 points, or 3.12 percent, to close at 7,026.24.

Ending a four-day losing streak, the local bourse opened at 6,941.5 and fluctuated between 7,026.24 and 6,921.97. A total of 4.24 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$115.01 billion (US$3.73 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 5.4 percent. Machinery and electronics shares advanced 4.1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares rose 3 percent, banking and financial shares increased 2.9 percent, paper and pulp issues gained 1.9 percent, and textile stocks were up 0.8 percent.
Foodstuff issues lost ground, decreasing 1.9 percent.
Cement shares remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,675 to 484, with 320 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyer of shares worth NT$10.73 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Contraception, pregnancy issues concern students: survey

TEXT.P: Many students who sought sex consultation at community pharmacies were concerned about contraception and pregnancy, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday by the Bureau of Health Promotion.

Compared with 30 percent of students who visited the pharmacies simply for consultation purposes, 19.3 percent intended to buy contraceptive products and 17.3 percent wanted to buy pregnancy test kits, the results showed.
There were also 2.6 percent who asked for abortion pills.

The survey was conducted by the Union of Pharmacist Associations among 1,349 students aged 24 and younger who visited the sex education consulting stations at 150 drug stores nationwide between March and June this year.
The issues most commonly raised by the students during the consultations included acne treatment, height, menstruation, ejaculation and weight control.
Of the 261 students who visited the pharmacists to buy contraceptive products, two were under 12 years of age, 24 were aged 12-15, 73 aged 15-18, and 162 aged 18-24.
Of the 233 students who went there to buy pregnancy test kits, three were under 12 years of age, 11 were aged 12-15, 74 aged 15-18, 145 aged 18-24, according to the results.

Lin Chen-shun, a leading member of the union, urged parents to pay closer attention to their children and offer them assistance if necessary, noting that many young people who sought sex consultation were obviously lacking in sex knowledge but would not approach their parents for information.

For example, Lin said, among the visitors to the sex consultation stations was a girl in fourth grade of elementary school who was concerned about becoming pregnant after having had sexual relations with her boyfriend.

There was also a junior high school girl who was threatened, followed and treated violently by her boyfriend because she wished to break up with him, Lin said, adding that she was forced seek shelter at a pharmacy.
Both cases were resolved after the responsible pharmacists helped to inform the parents of the situations, according to Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bat exhibition opens at Taipei Zoo

TEXT.P: A bat exhibition promoting life technology concepts through biology, the arts and technology opened at the Taipei Zoo's education center Wednesday.

The exhibition, jointly organized by the National Science Council (NSC) , the Tainan National University of the Arts, and the Taipei Zoo, is being held as part of this year's NSC-sponsored Science Season activities.

The NSC said the bat was chosen as the topic of this year's Science Season exhibition featuring "life and the sciences" because of its symbolic significance as the only mammal with the ability to fly.

The exhibition features three main themes, including "bat structure and senses, " which will include displays on "robot bats, " bats' use of sonar for navigation, and sketches of artist Leonardo Da Vinci's flying machines based on the wing structure of bats, to name a few.

The exhibition's second main theme, "bat ecology and species, " will include displays introducing bat behavior in nature, special bat species indigenous to Taiwan, as well as vampire bat skulls borrowed from the New York Museum of Natural History and shown in Taiwan for the first time.

The third major theme, "bats and humans, and bat conservation, " will also feature a variety of interesting displays on folk images of bats, as well as exhibits introducing threats to bat survival and the need to protect bats' natural habitat.
The exhibition is set to run through Dec. 7, according to the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nauruan president visits sport university

TEXT.P: Visiting Nauruan President Marcus Stephen, an award-winning weightlifter, gave a demonstration of the sport Wednesday at the National Taiwan Sport University (NTSU) in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan, winning enthusiastic applause from students and his Taiwanese host, President Ma Ying-jeou.

The visit to NTSU was not on Stephen's scheduled itinerary in Taiwan. It, however, turned out to be "an amazing trip, " Stephen said, adding that to him, talking with athletes is more delightful than holding discussions on political issues.
In his address, Ma said President Stephen, who began weightlifting training at the age 14, has won three British Commonwealth gold medals in the sport.
Stephen is still young, 39 years old, Ma noted, praising Nauru's ability to produce world-class athletes in a country that is the world's smallest in terms of land mass.
Nauru is 21 sq km and its population is around 13,000, according to 2005 statistics. It is one of 23 countries around the world that maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

President Stephen, a former chief executive of the International Weightlifting Federation, said the tour of NTSU reminded him of the days when he was an athlete, particularly when he smelled the familiar scent of sweat.

He suggested that Taiwanese athletes take full advantage of the modern equipment and training venues, which he said Nauru does not have. He added he supports government's role in pushing for the development of sports.
President Stephen, accompanied by his wife and officials including Minister of Finance Kieren Keke, arrived in Taiwan Aug. 4 for a five-day state visit. He will depart on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's rice exports skyrocket in first half of year

TEXT.P: Taiwan exported 6,634 tons of rice during the January-June period, more than 20 times the amount exported by Taiwan all of last year, the Council of Agricultural Affairs' Agriculture and Food Agency said Tuesday.

Of that amount, 3,520 tons were exported to Libya, while 3,000 tons were sent to Turkey, marking a shift away from Taiwan's traditional export markets, namely Japan and Hong Kong, which have absorbed over 90 percent of Taiwan's total rice exports in recent years.
Yu Sheng-fen, deputy director-general of the agency, said the increase in Taiwan's rice exports this year will not affect domestic rice supplies or prices.
Taiwan's rice reserves currently stand at over 370,000 tons, well above the three-month supply mandated by law, Yu noted.
He also pointed out that Taiwan's first harvest of this year was abundant, yielding 1.07 million tons of rice, a significant increase of more than 110,000 tons, or roughly 10 percent, over last year.
"These amounts are more than enough to meet domestic demand, " Yu added.

Expanding rice production and overseas sales are an important part of Taiwan's industrial development, Yu said, adding that the agency will give top priority to ensuring stable domestic rice supplies and prices while pursuing more export opportunities amid rising prices.

He noted that the agency on April 24 announced restrictions on rice exports, with a minimum price limit of at least US$1,200 per ton being imposed on those applying to export rice, and the condition that the exporter must "maintain the international image" of Taiwan's domestically produced rice.
As for the agency's performance, Yu said that amid the huge fluctuations in international rice prices in recent months, Taiwan's prices have remained relatively stable.
He added that in order to increase domestic supplies, the agency has mapped out plans to grow rice, as well as corn feed, on Taiwan's fallow land for part of the year.

The agency predicts that more than 500,000 tons of rice will be harvested in the second growing season of this year and that the country's rice reserves will reach 400,000 tons by the end of the first harvest in May 2009, ensuring sufficient supplies for the domestic market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Young Bunun aboriginal cancer patient wins Love of Life Award

TEXT.P: A Bunun aboriginal teenager, who has battled cancer since he was 11 months old, was presented with the Love of Life Award for his courage in facing the deadly disease, at a ceremony to mark the opening of an exhibition featuring his artwork Tuesday.

The 15-year-old Ma Han-chung was chosen for the award because of his bravery in combating cancer and living his life with love, according to Chou Chin-hua, the founder of the Chou Ta-kuan Cultural and Educational Foundation that sponsors the award.
Ma is one of 26 recipients from eight countries of the award, with the remaining 25 to be honored at a ceremony to be held in Taiwan in September.

The exhibition of his poetry and paintings, along with artworks by late teenage cancer patient Chou Ta-kuan, is being held at the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall to raise the visibility of the awards and publicize the September event, Chou said.

Ma said after receiving the award that his physical suffering has made him realize the significance of facing the pain in life with perseverance and courage and the importance of being grateful and cherishing life.
The teenager likened his cancer to a grain of sand which makes an oyster uncomfortable at first when it gets into the oyster shell but it helps turn the shell into a pretty pearl eventually.
He added that once he overcame the mental and physical torment caused by his disease, he gained fortitude and courage.

Ma, who has long dreamed of becoming a writer and enjoys expressing his views through painting, said he doesn't know how long he will live. All he can do is to defy death and live every day as though it's his last.

The youngster, who recently passed the high school entrance exam to get into National Taitung Senior High School, was born in 1993 in Taitung, eastern Taiwan. His father Sun Chang-wu is a Korean missionary who has preached in Taiwan for nearly 20 years, and his mother Ma Chiu-ching is a Bunun Aborigine.

Ma Chiu-ching said since his son was diagnosed with a malignant brain tumor at the age of 11 months, he has undergone surgery and various forms of therapy, including chemotherapy and electric therapy, that have left him with muscular dystrophy and limb deformation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Twins prone to lower academic achievement: survey

TEXT.P: Twins are not likely to perform as well academically in early adulthood as their single peers, probably due to a shorter gestation period, lower birth weight and less attentive parental care, researchers at Mackay Memorial Hospital said Wednesday.

Twins who take the college joint entrance examination tend to score significantly lower in Chinese, mathematics, and natural sciences than singletons, said Tsou Meng-Ting, an attending physician and assistant professor at the hospital.
"The percentage of university admission among twins is also 2.2 percent lower than that of children born individually," Tsou said.

According to the researchers' report published in British Medical Journal, the main factors that affect the difference in academic performance include the twins' birth weight, gestational age, birth order, and sex, as well as their parents' sociodemographic characteristics.

After studying 1687 twins and 21,897 singletons born in Taiwan between 1983 and 1985, as well as their respective performance in the college admission exams in 2002 and 2003, the researchers speculated that a child's weight at birth might be the factor most affecting academic performance.
They observed that twins born weighing less than 2.5 kilograms were the most likely to suffer academically.

Tsou said that compared to twins with normal birth weights, twins with low birth weights are 8.5 percent less likely to be admitted by a university while singletons with low birth weights are only 3.2 percent less likely than those who were heavier at birth to get into a university.
Citing the study's results, researchers involved in the projects suggested that an improved environment, health care, and day care services can help bridge the gap between the twins and singletons.
They also advised mothers who expect to give birth to twins to seek medical assistance in extending the gestation period and allow the babies to gain more weight before being born.

DOC.HEADLINE: Excessive fatigue of workers takes toll on businesses: CLA

TEXT.P: Excessive fatigue among employees has caused an "invisible loss" to businesses, a survey conducted by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) indicated Wednesday.
The CLA said fatigue of the employees means loss of working hours or days because of ill health, especially in those areas of work where employees are most at risk of excessive fatigue.
The CLA, in its latest survey on 24,996 laborers in 19 trades, found that employees in the financial and insurance trade ranked top in work fatigue levels.
They were followed by workers in real estate, and medical care and social work.
Among employers and the self-employed, the high risk groups for fatigue were in the transportation and warehousing sector, accommodation and eatery sector, and the manufacturing sector.
The survey found that workers in the high risk groups lose an average of 0.57 days per month due to fatigue.
If those workers account for 2 percent of total work force, then this will translate into 1.1 million people who cannot work one day each month, the survey showed.

Psychological burdens are the main reasons for feelings of tiredness in workplace, and this could be caused by rapid working pace, hard work, heavy workload, insufficient time to finish tasks, the need for sustained concentration over a long period of time, and insufficient staff.

The CLA has made suggestions for lowering work fatigue levels, such as employers working out a reasonable schedule with staff, slowing down the working pace, workers resting for longer and more frequent periods, and reshuffling staff.

The survey asked the respondents whether their work left them emotionally drained, made them feel frustrated, physically exhausted, depleted at the thought of another work day, and whether they found it hard to get through every minute at the work place.

For each of the five questions, there were five possible answers -- always, often, sometimes, seldom, and never. The score for each answer was 100, 75, 50, 25, and 0, respectively, with the higher score representing the higher level of fatigue.
Those workers who receive a combined score of 40 points and above were considered at the highest fatigue level.
A combined score of between 25 and 40 points was considered as medium-high fatigue level, a score of between 15 and 25 as medium-low fatigue level, and a score of lower than 15 as low-level fatigue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Actor-turned-diplomat becomes American Cultural Center director

TEXT.P: Scott Robinson, a former professional actor, took up duties Wednesday as director of the American Institute in Taiwan's (AIT) American Cultural Center, the AIT announced in a press release.

Robinson was born in Los Angeles and grew up in Santa Monica, California. He joined the U.S. foreign service in 2003 and has served in Chennai, India, and Beijing. Robinson doubles as Cultural Affairs Officer in AIT's Public Affairs Section.
Prior to becoming a diplomat, Robinson worked at the New York City law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore.

Before that, he was a professional actor, appearing in productions of Shakespeare's Henry VI and Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard at the Utah Shakespearean Festival, the world premiere of Barry Manilow's musical Harmony at La Jolla Playhouse and the feature film Chasing Sunsets.
Robinson holds a Bachelor of Arts degree from Brown University and a Master of Fine Arts degree from the University of California, San Diego.
Robinson's predecessor, Nicholas Papp, served as the center's director for about three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Financial institutions no longer the "golden bowl" for employees
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 6 (CNA) 08/06/08 18:35:25 (By Yeh Fang-hsun and Emmanuelle Tzeng)

TEXT.P: A job at a financial institution was once considered the "golden bowl" by young job hunters, but in reality this may mean heavier pressure, longer working hours and higher risk of fatigue than even in blue-collar jobs.

According to the results of a survey conducted by the Institute of Occupational Safety and Health under the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), employees in the financial and insurance sector ranked highest in terms of work fatigue levels, followed by workers in real estate business and those in the fields of medical care and social work.

"Blue-collar workers have fixed working hours, but many white-collar employees work under a system of job responsibility, which means they are under intense pressure, " said Ngou Giok-siong, president of the Taiwan Labour Front, a non-governmental organization that advocates the rights and well-being of workers.
Under the system of job responsibility, employees usually have to devote as much time as needed to complete their daily tasks, which often means working more than eight hours a day.

According to the Labor Standards Law, financial businesses can moderately prolong the normal eight-hour day of some employees without offering extra pay, but only for those at or above managerial level. Other staff should be paid overtime if they work more than eight hours per day, the law stipulates.

Ngou further noted that most workers in the financial sector -- in private banks in particular -- dare not ask for overtime pay, due to the deep-rooted concept that work runs into overtime only if the employee has not been efficient during regular working hours.
In public banks, workers usually do not ask for overtime pay due to limited budgets, he noted.
The financial predicament brought about by U.S. sub-prime crisis has made the situation grimmer for bank employees, who now face a new risk of losing their jobs.

Asked what kind of role the union can play to promote workers' rights, Ngou said that it is difficult to negotiate with employers, since the entire society and the education system focus mainly on the importance of competition.
In addition, because of the intense corporate culture and computerized staff rating systems, work in the financial sector is no bed of roses.

Once known as the "golden boys" who kept regular working hours, and had relatively reasonable workloads and high job security, financial employees, including bank staff and investment consultants, are now facing a very volatile and competitive environment, some local bankers indicated.
"The good old days are over for financial workers," said a senior bank manager with 30 years experience, speaking on condition of anonymity.
The manager told the CNA that with the increased number of banks in Taiwan, workers need to compete with each other to earn a bonus, or even to keep their jobs.
"Nowadays work performance is recorded and evaluated by computer systems," he noted,
He said that banking staff, especially those with sales tasks such as attracting more housing loan clients, are rated based on the number of business deals they bring in each week or month.

Hsieh Ching-feng, the vice president of Cathaysite Securities Investment Trust, said the competitive nature of the corporate culture could be also observed in the multiple roles of financial employees, which leads to longer working hours.
"Since the beginning of the 1990s when the government began allowing the establishment of more private banks, supply in financial services has outstripped market demand," Hsieh noted.
The number of employees in the financial service sector was 373,281 in 2007, almost triple the number 20 years ago, which was 140,542.
The number of banks in Taiwan reached 44 in recent years, double the number before the 1990s, according to Hsieh.

Under the higher demands of work performance, a bank's counter staff might be asked to take on the task of opening bank accounts or even providing financial management advice, in the institution's bid to be more competitive and cost- efficient.
Because of increased workloads, the average bank worker now gets off work no earlier than 7 p.m., approximately two hours later compared with two decades ago, Hsieh said.
A market watcher said the global financial turbulence that has resulted from the U.S. credit crunch has exacerbated the work situation, as financial jobs are no longer iron-clad.
"The crisis has forced many local banks and investment companies to downsize their work force in order to control costs, " Chiu Wen-jen, the market director of 104 Job Bank told CNA.
As part of their cost reduction measures, many local financial institutions are choosing not to fill vacancies, which means longer working hours for the existing staff, Chiu said.
As a result, "employees who wish to keep their jobs become more diligent, voluntarily extending their work hours and adding to their responsibilities," added Chiu.
For Taiwan bank workers, the massive lay-offs by major financial institutions in the U.S. mean more work and higher pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Christian volunteers from Taiwan help Cambodia's poor

TEXT.P: Members of Taiwan's Mustard Seed Mission built classrooms and donated teaching materials as part of an 11-day charity activity in impoverished, mountainous areas in remote northern Cambodia, a mission official said Wednesday.

The 20-member group -- including 16 Taiwanese college students and four mission workers -- traveled in Cambodia from July 22 to Aug. 1. During the trip, the students and workers lived in remote villages with no electricity or running water, and took open-air baths with collected rainwater, said mission official Liao Hsia-hui.
At a village in Aural County in northern Cambodia's Kandal Province, the volunteers helped build a classroom for more than 100 students at Chrok-Cha Elementary School.
Before the school was built, more than 100 students in the first through third grades took classes in a thatched hut with no blackboard.

Taiwan's Mustard Seed Mission delegation was the first foreign social services group to enter the Aural region and contact local residents. Cambodia's highest mountain, Phnom Aural, is located in the area.

The volunteers also distributed rice, oil, soy sauce and other foodstuffs to needy residents in Prek Anchon village, on the other side of the Mekong River. The impoverished area used to be tightly controlled by Khmer Rouge rebels.
Villagers were treated to a free meal hosted by Rotary Club Taipei ex-chief William Choi. A Taiwan-funded garment maker donated 30,000 articles of clothing to impoverished children in the area.
Six or seven members of the Mustard Seed group suffered sunstroke and several had diarrhea, said Liao, the mission official.
Mustard Seed is a U.S.-based Christian missionary group that carries out volunteer charitable work across the globe.

DOC.HEADLINE: Animal extravaganza in Kenting

TEXT.P: A staff member of the Kenting National Park Administration Office reminded parents Tuesday that August at the Kenting National Park in the southernmost county of Pingtung is a good time to see barn swallows and land crabs.

The sight of hundreds of swallows perching on telephone cables and crabs crossing the road to spawn on the seashore provides children with a great opportunity to learn about the natural environment, said Tsai Yi-jung.

Hengchun is one of the two main places barn swallows use as a resting place during their migration in and out of Taiwan, Tsai said adding that they are among the most common birds seen on the peninsula, along with brown shrikes, herons, birds of prey and waterfowl.
Land crabs making their way down to the sea in huge numbers to lay their eggs is another spectacular scene in Kenting during the month of August, Tsai went on.

As there is a road separating the crabs' normal habitat and their spawning grounds, the animals are often crushed beneath the wheels of passing cars, which has prompted the enaction of traffic restrictions at peak times to protect the creatures.
Banana Bay and Port Village are the two main crab spawning areas, according to Tsai.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Stock Exchange initials to be changed

TEXT.P: The initials of the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp. (TSEC) will be changed to TWSE from Aug. 11 in order to better differentiate its name from designations given to other national stock markets, TSEC managers announced Wednesday.

A TSEC official said the name-change was initiated as the name TSEC is widely mistaken for the Tokyo Stock Exchange, The Stock Exchange of Thailand, the Toronto Stock Exchange or the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange.
"Using TSEC will presumably hamper the company's efforts in promoting its globalization," the official said.

The TSEC's Web site address will also be changed to www.twse.com.tw from Aug. 11, the official went on, adding that the existing and new Web site addresses will remain functional simultaneously for six months before the old one goes out of service, for the convenience of all parties concerned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai set to deepen roots in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Gou announced Wednesday that the group will increase investment in high-tech manufacturing and research and development in Taiwan to turn its existing business operational headquarters into a global logistics hub.
Hon Hai is the world's largest contract maker of electronics by revenue.
The group is set to develop a "digital, environmentally friendly tech town" in Taiwan mainly aimed at accommodating increased numbers of "Hon Hai citizens" and their dependents, according to Gou.

Hon Hai will also allow its overseas operations to list on Taiwan's bourse, Gou said after meeting Premier Liu Chao-shiuan for a closed-door talk lasting over an hour at Hon Hai's headquarters in Tucheng, Taipei County.

According to Hon Hai Precision officials, Foxconn International -- one of the overseas operations of the Hon Hai Group -- which makes cell phones for Nokia and Motorola, is planning to list in Taiwan.

Gou said at a news conference after the meeting that to boost the function of its headquarters, Hon Hai will continue to increase its investment in R&D and manufacturing in optoelectronics, medical equipment, digital content electronics, precision production equipment and the automation industry.

These increased investments are expected to generate some 20,000 jobs for R&D specialists, of which 90 percent will be recruited in Taiwan, and 5,000 technical workers, as well as 5,000 office workers for the global operations and management areas, of which at least two-thirds of the manpower will be sourced domestically, Gou said.

Meanwhile, he said, to take root deep in Taiwan and take better care of the "Hon Hai citizens, " his group will channel at least NT$100 billion (US$3.27 billion) into various projects to build a "digital, environmentally friendly tech town."

Gou said the "tech town" -- the location of which will be determined after assessing the willingness of local governments to accommodate such an idea -- will be a digitalized city of about 240,000 residents, where high-tech know-how, including solar power, wireless broadband systems, electronically controlled transportation systems and digital-content medical services will be applied to make it not only environmentally friendly but also a comfortable and easy-to- live-in community.
Gou was reluctant to make known the location of his envisioned town, saying that "land prices will skyrocket as soon as I announce it."
He noted, however, that his company will submit the investment plans to the Executive Yuan within six months for government approval.
Liu gave a thumbs-up to Gou's proposals, saying that after the administration put forth a series of policies of "great vision, " their implementation needs the support from the private sector.
"With plans from the private sector, such as those expected to be put forth by Hon Hai, the administration's policies could be materialized soon," Liu predicted.
"The government is very willing to back up Hon Hai in its visionary development plans," Liu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Restaurant chain, Website to expand into Southeast Asia

TEXT.P: Local steakhouse Wang Steak and matchmaker website Doctor Match have decided to expand their reach into Southeast Asia after an overseas trip led by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) in July, company officials said Wednesday.

Wang Kuo-hsiung, vice president of Wang Steak -- a subsidiary of the Wang Group, the country's largest food chain enterprise -- and Wu Jia-hsin, president of Doctor Match, expressed interest in venturing into Thai and Malaysian markets after joining the TAITRA-organized market-inspecting trip.

"There is a great opportunity for Japanese-style restaurants under the Wang Group to expand their territory in Thailand. We estimate that 60 restaurants can be opened in Bangkok, bringing in US$600,000, while 25 restaurants can be opened in Malaysia, worth US$200,000 in terms of income, " said Wang.
Wang Steak will cooperate with Southeast Asian enterprises in tapping into Thailand and Malaysian markets after the company's market expansion stabilizes in China, Wang added.
Doctor Match is a matchmaker website built by three physicians. Currently, they have more than 7,000 members, mostly composed of doctors, lawyers, engineers, and teachers.
Wu said his company has begun planning for setting up branches in Thailand and Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC fuel prices to be announced every Friday

TEXT.P: The government will from this week announce new retail prices of fuel sold by the state-owned CPC Corp., Taiwan every Friday for implementation the following Saturday, instead of every month as was the case in July, Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming said Wednesday.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs had previously also considered the possibility of announcing new fuel prices every Saturday for implementation from Sunday.

Yiin explained that the ministry decided that the announcement should be made every Friday because it could cause inconvenience to the public if they are "supposed to pay attention" to changes in fuel prices even on holidays.

The Kuomintang government restored in July a floating pricing system that reflects fluctuations in global oil prices, after hiking CPC fuel prices by NT$3.9 per liter May 28, ending a six-month freeze on fuel prices imposed by the former Democratic Progressive Party administration in an attempt to curb inflation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan folk culture to be displayed at Shanghai folk exposition
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Aug. 6 (CNA) 08/06/08 19:14:30 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The annual Shanghai folk custom and civil culture exposition will feature the essence of Taiwan folk custom and culture at its 2008 exhibition that will open Sept. 10 at the Shanghai Stadium, the organizer said Wednesday at a press conference.
The eight-day exposition will display the complete cultural and folk custom images of Taiwan, said Wu Jiachang, an executive official of the exposition's organizing committee.

Wu noted that a Taiwan tour pavilion will be erected at the venue to mark the increasing civic exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and the cross-strait economic cooperation in a wide range of fields.

According to the organizers, the venue will accommodate 200 booths divided into four sections. The first will be a Taiwan night market snack section in which visitors will have the chance to taste popular Taiwanese snacks such as oyster omelets with sweet and sour sauce.

The second will be a tourism zone in which visitors will be able to obtain complete information on sightseeing in Taiwan. Special Taiwanese foods will be on display and sold in the third section, while the fourth will gather popular restaurants in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Emulsified oil fuel can save energy, reduce pollution: study

TEXT.P: A new technology developed by National Cheng Kung University in southern Taiwan, if applied nationwide, could not only reduce air pollution but also save some NT$30 billion (US$974.1 million) in fuel consumption, researchers at the university said Wednesday.

Lee Wen-jhy, a professor at the university's Department of Environmental Engineering who led the research team, said the results of the seven-year research program on emulsified oil fuels were published earlier this year in Environmental Science and Technology, an American bimonthly journal.
Lee said the aim of the study was to find out whether using oily waste water emulsified fuel could save energy and reduce air pollutant emissions.
The study used waste water characterized by a high chemical oxygen demand and petroleum hydrocarbons-gasoline to make an emulsified oil containing 20 percent waste water with 0.1 percent surfactant.
For comparison, the study also conducted experiments on two other systems -- emulsified heavy oil fuel and water-emulsified oil.
The results show that all three emulsified fuels could reduce flue gas pollutant emissions, with the waste water-emulsified oil fuel yielding the most significant results.
Furthermore, the new technology could save energy to the tune of 14 percent, Lee said.
According to Lee, National Cheng Kung University is in the process of applying for patent rights for the new technique and is discussing technology transfer with a listed company in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City making soap from waste cooking oil

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government has turned 109,899 kilograms of waste cooking oil into some 35,717 soap bars over the past four years, a city official said Wednesday.

The city government in southern Taiwan provided the soap bars free of charge to local government agencies and schools, and allowed for the soap to be exchanged at flee markets, Environmental Protection Bureau Acting Director Chen Kai-ling said.
At the flee markets, local residents can exchange used batteries or discarded CD-ROMs for the soap bars, Chen said, noting that the soap is quite popular.
In May 2004, the city government began working with fast food restaurants, school cafeterias and restaurants in government agencies to recycle their waste cooking oil, Chen noted.
The city's garbage trucks also collect waste oil from local communities on a daily basis, Chen added.
One kilo of waste cooking oil can produce about three bars of soap, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese ship to call at Keelung Harbor in mid-August

TEXT.P: A Japanese ship of the Mokichi Okada International Association (MOA) is slated to call at the Keelung Harbor later this month to promote two-way cultural exchanges, Keelung Harbor Bureau officials said Wednesday.

The vessel, carrying 436 Japanese youth and 111 workers on board, is slated to arrive at Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan Aug. 12, bureau officials said. The bureau will host a welcome ceremony and a news conference at its headquarters on the ship's arrival, they added.
Japanese workers said the activity is aimed at promoting a purifying therapy that focuses on natural healing power, creating a world of beauty and establishing happy families.
The MOA was set up in 1935 by Mokichi Okada (1882-1955), a poet, artist and visionary businessmen. His ideal was to create a world of peace, health and prosperity for all the people of the world.
The MOA's theme is "working to create a new civilization" through natural farming, natural food and art.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan city government to designate every Friday as 'bicycle day'

TEXT.P: The Tainan city government announced Wednesday that it will designate every Friday as "bicycle day," starting Aug. 15, in an effort to conserve energy and cut carbon emissions.
Government officials said that on "bicycle day" city staff will be required to take the bus, ride bicycles or walk to work instead of driving or riding motorcycles.
The Tainan city government is the first public office to take such an initiative in the nationwide energy conservation campaign.
The city government said 51 percent of its employees have indicated that they will be able to join the "bicycle day" activity, while 49 percent said that they will have difficulty doing so.

Those who said they will have difficulty cited reasons such as frequent bicycle thefts, lack of bus stop near their homes, the need to use cars to transport their children to and from school, long distances to the city government offices and the inability to ride a bicycle.
Some female employees said they were unwilling to walk or ride bicycles to work because of personal safety concerns, while others pointed to the poor quality of the city's roads.

The officials said that staff members who have problems cooperating with the initiative could report to their superiors, and the government will help them overcome their difficulties. Meanwhile, the launch of "bicycle day' will proceed as planned, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan pushes for prisoner exchange pacts with other countries

TEXT.P: The Taiwan government has been pushing for the signing of prisoner exchange pacts with other countries in recent years to better protect the human rights of prisoners, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Tuesday.
For example, the ministry said, Taiwan recently initialed such an agreement with Panama to allow convicted nationals from either side to serve their prison terms in their home countries.
The agreement will be finalized soon, according to the ministry.
Language problems, food, culture and religion make it difficult to help rehabilitate foreign prisoners, the ministry explained in a statement.

At the same time, allowing prisoners to serve jail terms in their home countries would make it more convenient for their families to visit them, the ministry said, adding that this will also help rehabilitate prisoners.
After more than two years of negotiations, ministry officials reached consensus with their Panamanian counterparts on the terms of the draft agreement in Panama Aug. 1, the ministry said.
At present, Taiwan has no Panamanian prisoners, but Panama is one of the 23 countries that recognizes Taiwan diplomatically.
The ministry began pushing for the signing of the agreement in September 2005 when the Panamanian court convicted a Taiwanese national of murder and sentenced him to almost 20 years in jail.
Although the agreement has not been signed, the Panamanian government repatriated the murderer, identified as Duanmu Wei-kai, on July 4.
Duanmu was the captain of a Panama-registered bulk carrier owned by Taipei-based Shih Wei Navigation Co., when it sailed from the Dominican Republic to Houston, Texas, in March 2003.
As the ship was about to enter the harbor at Houston, several crewmen discovered five Dominican stowaways, who were cast adrift at sea on two flat wooden rafts and left for dead.
Two of the stowaways drowned, while three others were arrested when they managed to reach the shore.

Zhang Xue-hai, president of the Taiwan Association for Legal Education, said Tuesday that after the Taiwan-Panama agreement, he hopes the government will also negotiate with the Thai government to repatriate 115 Taiwanese nationals serving sentences in Thai jails.
Thailand, however, has refused to sign such an agreement with Taiwan as it does not recognize Taiwan's statehood, Zhang said in a statement.

At present, 115 Taiwanese nationals are serving prison terms in Thailand, 80 percent of whom are convicted of drug-related crimes and are serving average sentences of 25 years and eight of whom are on death row, according to Zhang.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.017 to close at NT$30.738.
A total of US$1.879 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.745 and fluctuated between NT$30.655 and NT$30.849.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition promotes sustainable shark harvesting

TEXT.P: An exhibit on sharks is being held at the National Taiwan Museum in Taipei, in an effort to educate the public on the importance of conserving the marine predators.

Hong Ching-feng, deputy minister of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs, said at the opening ceremony Tuesday that it's critical to educate the public about sharks, whose numbers are dwindling due to overfishing.
The exhibit, titled "The Endangered King of the Seas, " runs through Oct. 12 and is co-sponsored by the National Taiwan Museum and the Life Conservation Association.

According to a 2006 study published in "Ecology Letters", up to 73 million sharks are killed each year worldwide. Many species have become endangered, particularly those prized for fins that go into expensive "shark fin" soups, Hong said.

Sharks are the top of the food chain in many marine ecosystems, and so are a key indicator of the overall health of ocean environments. They keep fish populations further down the food chain in equilibrium, so overfishing sharks can throw an entire ecosystem out of whack.

Also Tuesday, Government Information Office Minister Vanessa Yea-ping Shih and Legislator Tien Chiu-chin of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party announced the launch of a TV public service spot promoting shark conservation.
In the ad, 11 Olympic medal winners urge the public not to eat shark's fin, at a ceremony marking the opening of the Taiwan National Museum shark exhibit.
The TV spot will air through Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Rows within government over Olympic games.
An appeal by Italian Youth and Sports Minister Giorgia Meloni and the ruling People of the Liberty Party's Senator Maurizio Gasparri for being absent at the opening ceremony of the Beijing Olympic Games in protest against China's poor record of human rights sparked a row among government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Avant-garde theater festival to heavily engage audiences in shows

TEXT.P: An avant-garde theater festival in Taipei City will engage audiences and encourage them to play a pivotal role in the staging of the presentations this year, organizers said Wednesday.

The two-week festival, called "New Wave Guling, " will begin Aug. 15 at the Guling Street Avant-garde Theater, with the aim of providing audiences with a better understanding of the dynamic possibilities of theater in Taiwan through six experimental works, said an executive of the Body Phase Studio, which is organizing the event.

All six works adopted cross-interdisciplinary talents and approaches, such as action art, video art, installation art, dance, literature, and architecture, the executive said, adding that the borrowing of talents from various fields and the blending of different artistic elements are the special characteristics of the presentation.

The audience will contribute to finding new possibilities through interaction with the performers, the organizer said, adding that the interaction could take the form of eye contact, small sounds, or movement.

The first day's activity will begin with a show called "Play in the dot" which features visually impaired people's engagement with sounds in daily life. It is an "unfinished" work, and much of its unknown parts will have to be completed by the audience, the organizer said.
Another play called "Easy Come Easy Go" will be staged on that same day. The show is a combination of stand-up comedy and multimedia elements, the organizer explained.

The New Wave Guling activity was launched in 2006 by the Body Phase Studio, which is a progressive and alternative theater group founded by senior theater artist Wang Mo-lin to provide theater lovers with an opportunity to experiment with the art form.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: 'Fakeproofe-passport is cloned in minutes
New microchipped passports designed to be foolproof against identity theft can be cloned and manipulated in minutes and accepted as genuine by the computer software recommended for use at international airports.

DOC.HEADLINE: Oil prices to be reviewed weekly instead of monthly: MOEA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Wednesday that, under its floating oil price mechanism, the price of oil will reviewed on a weekly basis instead of monthly so as to more accurately reflect fluctuations in global oil markets.
Effective August 8, oil prices will be reviewed every Friday and adjusted based on the international average oil price during the previous trading days within the week.

With the introduction of the new measure, the state-run oil company CPC. Corp. will announce its prices every Friday, starting this week, Shih Yen-shiang, vice economic minister said at a news conference Wednesday.

Shih said that CPC, supervised by the MOEA, will absorb an extra NT$0.5 and NT$0.6 of the cost per liter of gasoline and diesel, respectively. Since May 28, CPC has been subsidizing the price of the two fuels by NT1.3 and NT$1.4 a liter, respectively.
The subsidies will cost CPC a monthly deficit of NT$2.05 billion.

Because of a freeze on fuel prices implemented by the former Democratic Progressive Party government, CPC lost a total of NT$43.15 billion from January to May this year, including more than NT$10 billion in each of the last three months of that period.

After it took office on May 20, the Kuomintang government restored the floating price mechanism and promptly raised local fuel prices on May 28 by NT$3.9 per liter, which helped limit the company's losses to NT$3.45 billion in June.
Apart from having CPC absorb part of the cost of fuel, the government has also reduced the tax on imported oil commodities by NT$1.3 a liter, in a bid to keep down domestic oil prices.

Asked if oil price increases will indeed be limited to 3 percent of the overall prices as was reported by the local media, Shih said the government is still discussing the details with the experts and that more decisions will be announced at the end of the month.
Shih declined to comment on whether the prices would be adjusted upward or downward in light of a drop of nearly 17 percent in international oil prices over the last month to US$117.32 a barrel.
"We will not speculate on the range of the adjustment to be made this Friday," Shih said, adding that the range will be decided after a weekly average had been determined.
According to the MOEA, the announcement of fuel prices will be made on Fridays so that the general public will not have to worry about it on the weekends.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker to visit Japan

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will depart for Japan Thursday to attend the 39th annual conference of the Asia Pacific Parliamentarians' Union (APPU).

During the APPU meeting, which will open Sunday in Tokyo, Wang will meet with several political heavyweights, including dietman Taro Aso. The legislative speaker will also try to lobby for support for Taiwan's bid to host the 2009 APPU annual meeting.
Aso, a former foreign minister, recently accepted an offer to serve as secretary-general of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, the number two position in the party.
More than 10 Taiwanese lawmakers will accompany Wang to Japan, and they are slated to return to Taiwan Aug. 13.

Taiwan-Japan ties became the focus of attention after a collision between a Taiwanese recreational fishing boat and a Japanese coast guard patrol ship last month in waters near the dispute Tiaoyutai Islands. Taipei, Beijing and Tokyo all claim sovereignty over the disputed island chain in the east China Sea.
However, both President Ma Ying-jeou and Wang have repeatedly said that Taipei- Tokyo ties will not be affected by the incident or by the improved relations between Taiwan and China.
Wang also paid a visit to the United States late last month, where he lobbied for continued U.S. arms sales of defensive weapons to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's taekwondo athletes expected to win four medals

TEXT.P: Taiwan's taekwondo team has a good chance of winning four medals, including at least one gold, in the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games, a former award-winning taekwondo athlete said Wednesday.

Huang Chih-hsiung, a legislator of the ruling Kuomintang who won a bronze medal in the Sydney Olympics in 2000 and a silver medal in the 2004 Athens Olympics, said that if everything goes as well as hoped for, the Taiwan team, officially called Chinese Taipei, should be able to capture four medals, with at least one of them being gold.
The four Olympic medal hopefuls in the Taiwanese taekwondo team are Chu Mu-yen, Yang Shu-chun, Su Li-wen, and Sung Yu-chi.
Chu, fighting in the men's under-58kg division, won Taiwan's second gold medal in the 2004 Athens Olympic Games at the age of 22. He is under pressure to retain his title in Beijing.

Yang, who is Chu's girlfriend, was the champion in the women's under-49kg event in the Asian taekwondo tournament in April. She is hoping for success in the women's competition in the Beijing Olympics.

Su captured a gold medal in the women's under-63kg event in the Doha Asian Games in August 2007, while Sung won the gold medal in the men's under-72kg category in the 2007 Beijing WTF World Taekwondo Championships.

Taekwondo is one of a few sports categories in which Taiwan has a good chance to win medals. In the Athens Olympics in 2004, three of the country's five medals were won in the taekwondo competition, including two gold medals. The other two medals were won in archery.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE required to compensate female university post applicant

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court ruled Wednesday that the Ministry of Education (MOE) and a screening committee member should compensate a female applicant for a top university post to the tune of NT$2 million (US$65,570) and publish apologies to her in four major newspapers.

The plaintiff in the case, Chen Jean-lien, vice president of National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, filed the lawsuit after she was rejected in the screening process to fill a post as president of National Ilan University in April 2006. Chen was one of three applicants interviewed for the position.

TEXT.P: The government of Kaohsiung county, which hosts Taiwan's five last shadow puppet troupes, said Wednesday that its efforts to preserve and promote traditional puppetry have borne fruit, as up to 600,000 people from at home and abroad have attended the shows over the past six years.

In a statement released Wednesday, the Cultural Bureau of the southern Taiwan county outlined its efforts to revive the art form. Its works included building the country's only Shadow Play Museum, publishing educational materials for junior high and elementary school students, and organizing puppetry contests among schools to encourage young performers and to upgrade the theater art.

Over the past six years, 1,700 Kaohsiung county school students and teachers took part in shadow puppet shows, and five professional shadow puppet troupes staged 81 performances around Taiwan from 2002 to 2007, attracting audiences of almost 150,000, according to the statement.

Shadow puppetry was brought to Taiwan from southern China over 300 years ago, and was once popular in the farming areas in the south of the island. Older puppeteers in the county have estimated that at least 100 shadow puppet troupes existed in southern Taiwan in the final years of the Qing dynasty (1644-1911).

Traditionally, the shadow plays, commonly known as leader shows, are performed with figures made from leather. The figures are moved behind an illuminated backdrop and the shadows are actually silhouettes seen by the audience in profile or face on.
This form of puppetry is now seen by the local government as a valuable cultural asset.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police arrest 13 Bamboo Union gangsters

TEXT.P: Police raided 21 locations around Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan Wednesday and arrested 13 members of the Bamboo Union gang.
The 13 gangsters all belong to the same cell called Hsin Tang -- one of the gang's 24 cells.
Among the detainees was the cell's 40-year-old leader, identified by the surname Chang.
According to police, Chang turned himself in under an amnesty program in 1997 and was exempted from punishment after giving the assurance that he would withdraw from the gang.

However, police found recently that he was still active in the Bamboo Union and had been promoted to cell leader. Furthermore, Chang even joined the Taiwan District of Kiwanis International and became a director of its cultural division.

Citing the offenses allegedly committed by Chang and his followers, police said they used a financial consultation firm as a cover to engage in giving usurious loans to those in debt and using intimidation and force to obtain repayment at exorbitant interest rates.
The 13 gangsters were being interrogated and will be referred to the local public prosecutors office to face a series of charges.
The Bamboo Union is the largest of the three gangs in Taiwan, the other two being the Four Seas and the Celestial Way.

The number of Bamboo Union members is estimated at more than 10,000. Their criminal enterprises include gambling, drug trafficking, prostitution, construction rackets, and extortion. The gang is also active in China, other parts of Asia, Europe and North America.

DOC.HEADLINE: Applications for lump-sum labor pension payment decreasing: CLA

TEXT.P: There have been fewer applications for lump sum labor insurance pension payments since a new payout system was approved July 17, a Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) official said Wednesday.

The new system will allow retired workers, 60 and over, the choice of collecting their pensions in one lump sum or accepting monthly benefits until death. The current system stipulates that retired laborers can only receive their pensions in one lump sum, the value of which risks being eroded by inflation and improper investment.

According to Tsai Chi-an, president of the CLA's Bureau of Labor Insurance, the newly approved system, which will go into effect from Jan.1, 2009, will guarantee better pensions for some 8.8 million Taiwanese wage earners after retirement.

Monthly pension payments to retired workers over a period of eight years and one month will exceed the lump sum payment, and if a worker dies before the monthly sums reach a total equivalent to the lump sum amount, the difference will be paid to the family of the deceased, a CLA official explained in July.

The country's labor insurance fund had shrunk rapidly from NT$420 billion at the end of last year to NT$327 billion at the end of June because lots of retired workers had chosen the lump-sum payment, Tsai said.

There were about 2,290 applications per day for the single from January to July 17 this year, but the number dropped to 1,066 from July 18-31, Tsai said, adding that the new system is influencing retired workers' decisions on the issue.
There were more than 40,000 applications for the lump-sum payment in July, Tsai added.

Luo Wu-hu, the bureau's vice president, said that previous to July 17, the bureau had recorded an average 17 cases per day of applicants revoking their decision to apply for the lump sum payment. That number jumped to 40 per day after the new system was approved, Luo said, adding that this was an indication that more people are now aware of the benefits of the monthly pension payment.
Applicants for the lump sum payment can change their minds before the money is remitted to their accounts, Luo said.
They have less than two weeks to change their decision, Luo said, emphasizing that once the money is paid into the applicants' accounts no reversals can be made.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma annuls predecessor's classification of state affairs funds files

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has nullified the classification of a collection of documents allegedly implicating his predecessor in a high-profile "state affairs fund" embezzlement case, a Presidential Office official said Wednesday.

The move to annul former President Chen Shui-bian's classification of the collection of files will assist prosecutors in investigating whether Chen was involved in the NT$14.8 million "state affairs fund" abuse case.
The files in question are mainly receipts and records of Chen's use of discretionary "state affairs funds" from 2000 through June 30, 2006.

"After careful reflection, President Ma decided to remove the documents from the Presidential Office's 'strictly confidential' category," Presidential Office Secretary-General Chan Chun-po said at a news conference.

The Taipei District Court obtained the documents from a prosecutorial team that indicted Chen's wife and three of Chen's aides in November 2006 on charges of corruption and forgery for allegedly misappropriating NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the "state affairs fund" -- a special allowance set aside for the president's discretionary use for official purposes.

Chen proclaimed the files as "strictly confidential" Sept. 6, 2007 in accordance with the Classified National Security Information Protection (CNSIP) Act. The declaration has since stalled the district court proceedings.

Although the Special Investigation Task Force under the Supreme Prosecutors Office listed Chen as a co-suspect in the alleged embezzlement case almost immediately after Chen stepped down from the presidency May 20, investigations into his suspected role in the case have made little progress because of the classification of the files.
The task force asked President Ma to declassify the files shortly after he assumed office. Ma then formed a special team to scrutinize the collection of files.

Chan said Ma and the special team have pored over every file and record in the collection and have concluded that "there will be no such problem as endangering the country's interests in making public the documents in question."
Chen's office denounced the move, arguing that according to the law, documents classified as "strictly confidential" should not be declassified ever.
"President Ma's decision has run counter to the law and the Constitution," Chen's office said in a press statement.

However, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi rebuffed Chen's argument, claiming that those documents and records should not have been classified in the first place as they did not meet the standards of "strictly confidential" as prescribed in the CNSIP Act.
Chu Chao-liang, spokesman for the Special Investigation Task Force, hailed the nullification of the classification, saying the move will be very helpful to the investigation.
The district court also said it will resume handling of the roles of the former first lady and three former officials in the case.
Chen has denied any wrongdoing in the case, insisting that judicial process will eventually clear his name.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT suspends Taitung magistrate's membership rights

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) suspended controversial Taitung County Magistrate Kuang Li-chen's membership right Wednesday after her recent trip to Europe drew a storm of criticism and investigations by prosecution authorities.

"The punitive measure was based on a suggestion passed by the party's ethics and integrity commission with a vote of 11-6, " said Juan Kang-meng, chairman of the party's Evaluation and Discipline Committee.
Chang Po-ya, convener of the ethics and integrity commission, said Kuang's move has marred the party's image as her overseas trip caused wide attention and controversy.

Moreover, Chang said prosecutors have launched a probe into suspected irregularities related to Kuang's latest overseas trip which took her to several European countries in the name of learning from their experience in tourism promotion. The Control Yuan, the country's supreme watchdog body monitoring senior officials' integrity, is also investigating the case.
Juan said the KMT discipline committee will decide whether to mete out harsher penalty for Kuang in terms of the results of judicial and Control Yuan investigations.

Kuang, a stewardess-turned-politician, came under fire after taking 10 township chiefs and other county officials on a 13-day trip to Europe in late July despite knowing that Typhoon Fung Wong was approaching. She has also been criticized for spending millions of taxpayers' money on frequent overseas trips since taking office two years ago.
