DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 7, or the seventh day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1858: Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa as the capital of the Dominion of Canada.
1903: Louis Leakey, British anthropologist, is born. He uncovered crucial evidence of man's early evolution, including a 1,750,000-year-old skull.
1904: Ralph Johnson Bunche, American diplomat, is born. He helped found the United Nations and won the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the 1949 Arab- Israeli truce.
1912: Japan and Russia sign an agreement determining their spheres of influence in Manchuria and Mongolia.
1913: Samuel Cody, American aviator, becomes Britain's first air fatality when his plane crashes at Famborough.
1942: U.S. marines land on Guadalcanal in the Pacific during World War II.
1945: The Soviet Union declares war on Japan seven days before the Japanese surrender in World War II.
1948: The Yangtze River overflows its banks, forcing three million people into homelessness.
1952: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the designation of July 1, instead of January 1, as the beginning of the fiscal year.
1957: The ROC Navy sinks four Communist Chinese warships south of Kinmen.
1957: Oliver Hardy, the husky one in the Laurel and Hardy comic-duo who made more than 100 films from 1926 until 1950, dies of a stroke at the age of 65.
1959: The worst floods in more than 60 years hit central and southern Taiwan, killing 1,075 people, injuring 852, and causing more than NT$3.4 billion in property damage.
1974: Pingtung's Mei Ho Senior Little League baseball team leaves for Gary, Indiana, to participate in the 1974 Little League World Series.
1974: Paul Hogberg, president of the International Handball Federation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: Vice Foreign Minister H.K. Yang meets with President Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay.
1976: Kin Aziwa, newly-appointed deputy chief of the Japanese Interchange Association, Taipei Office, arrives to assume his post.
1983: Communist Chinese air force pilot Sun Tien-chin flies his MiG-21 jetfighter to South Korea to seek political asylum. He arrived in Taipei on Aug. 24.
1987: The leaders of Nicaragua, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Costa Rica sign a 14-page peace plan in Guatemala City aiming to settle a 10-year-old conflict in the region.
1990: President George Bush orders U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia to defend against Iraq.
1992: Beijing signs an agreement with Washington promising to probe any allegations that goods produced by prison labor are being shipped to U.S. markets.
1998: Bombs explode almost at the same time outside the American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, killing more than 80 people and injuring over one thousand others.
1999: The Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew ends a five-day visit to Macedonia after a meeting with his Macedonian counterpart Ljubco Georgievski.
2000: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng says the KMT is happy that President Chen Shui-bian has decided to hold a multiparty roundtable meeting to discuss major national issues with the heads of the opposition parties.
2001: The third cross-strait symposium about sports terms opens in Taipei, with sports representatives from Taiwan and mainland China sitting down to discuss the "unification" of various sports terms between the two sides.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT chairman leaves for Beijing to attend Olympics opening ceremony

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung departed Thursday for Beijing to attend the opening ceremony of the 2008 Olympic Games.

Wu said Taiwan must not be absent from such a grand sports event that attracts the attention of billions of people around the world, because "our participation represents our desire for international space."

Wu said that apart from attending the opening ceremony, he will visit the Olympic athletes' village to cheer on Taiwanese athletes and will watch a baseball game featuring the Chinese Taipei team before returning home next week.

He revealed that other than that, he also "has some serious work to do" during his trip, as he did on his last visit to Beijing in May, when he discussed with China authorities matters concerning the launch of direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights and the admission of Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

Asked if he will complain to China about the low number of Chinese tourist arrivals to Taiwan since the July 18 opening to sightseers from China, Wu explained that China had recently imposed stricter controls on overseas travel by its citizens because it was busy preparing for the Olympic Games.
Wu said he believes the situation will improve significantly after the Games end in late August.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party has expressed strong disapproval of Wu's plans to attend the Olympics opening ceremony, even as the government is trying to dissuade the heads of states of Taiwan's diplomatic allies from joining the event.

The DPP has also suggested that Taiwan's Olympic team boycott the opening ceremony to protest against the arrangement of the opening ceremony procession, saying that it implies a downgrading of Taiwan's status to that of an administrative region of China.

During's Friday's ceremony, the order of appearance of the procession will be based on the countries' names in Chinese. Under this arrangement, Taiwan's "Chinese Taipei " team and Hong Kong's "Hong Kong, China" team -- translated in Chinese as "Zhonghua Taibei" and "Zhongguo Xianggang, " respectively -- will be positioned very close to each other, with only the Central African Republic in between.
This model is different from past precedent, in which the processions were arranged in alphabetical order and Taiwan was grouped under the "T" section.

Under an agreement signed in 1981 between the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee and the International Olympic Committee (IOC), the "Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee" was abbreviated as "TPE" and was thus listed under the "T" section in the IOC's directory.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker on visit to Japan

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng left Thursday for Japan to attend the 39th annual conference of the Asia Pacific Parliamentarians' Union (APPU) and seek to allay Japan's concern over recent improvement in Taiwan-China ties.

Speaking prior to his departure at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, Wang said he will assure the Japanese side that the traditional Taipei-Tokyo friendship remains unaffected by warming cross-Taiwan Strait ties, to help defuse Tokyo's reservations regarding the issue.
"Taiwan and Japan should further advance their ties based on mutual trust and understanding, and this is the goal of our efforts," he said.

According to Wang, a five-member panel of key officials from the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has set this as the major purpose of his current eight-day visit to Japan.
More than 10 Taiwanese lawmakers are accompanying Wang on the tour, and they are slated to return to Taiwan Aug. 13.

The legislative speaker is slated to meet leaders of Japan's ruling and opposition parties and lawmakers, including dietman Taro Aso, a former foreign minister who recently accepted an offer to serve as secretary-general of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, thus becoming the number two figure in the party.

In response to allegations that President Ma Ying-jeou harbors anti-Japan sentiments, Wang said the Japanese side should be clear on the president's stance since Ma explained his position in this regard to a group of visiting Japanese dietmen early this week in Taipei.
Meanwhile, the APPU meeting will open Sunday in Tokyo.
The legislative speaker will also lobby for support for Taiwan's bid to host the 2009 APPU annual meeting.

Taiwan-Japan ties became the focus of attention after a collision between a Taiwanese recreational fishing boat and a Japanese coast guard patrol ship last month in waters near the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands. Taipei, Beijing and Tokyo all claim sovereignty over the disputed island chain in the east China Sea.
Both Ma and Wang have pledged that Taipei-Tokyo ties will not be affected by the incident nor by cross-strait detent.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Steel's gross revenue hits record high in July

TEXT.P: China Steel Corp.'s gross revenues for July reached NT$25.996 billion (US$842.66 million), marking a new monthly record high for Taiwan's largest and only integrated steelmaker, the company announced Thursday.
The figure represented an increase of 52.5 percent over the NT$17.046 billion recorded for the same month last year, and a rise of 9.65 percent over the previous month's sales.
It also marked the sixth time in China Steel's history that its monthly sales surpassed NT$20 billion.
The company produced a total of 872,202 tons of steel products in July, up 1.65 percent over June, and sold 891,044 tons for the month, up 4.68 percent.

China Steel management said that because mid- and down-stream manufacturers usually make inventory in June and because heavy rains during the month slowed down progress on building projects, the volume steel products delivered for the month was down.

However, with orders from manufacturers gradually returning to normal in July, coupled with a 17.8-percent increase in wholesale prices for steel products, the company's gross revenues rose for the month, according to management.

Analysts have said that China Steel's sales volume could decline in the third quarter amid slipping demand but that the company could register further record- high gross revenues because of soaring wholesale prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Diplomatic fraud case turned over to Control Yuan: foreign ministry

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it will leave it up to the Control Yuan to determine whether there were any administrative errors in a diplomatic farce in which the ministry was duped out of US$30 million in foreign aid funds.

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said at a regular press briefing that an internal investigation had found that the process of allocation of funds had fallen short of the foreign ministry's standards of professionalism, therefore, the investigation report has been submitted to the Control Yuan to determine whether there had been administrative errors in the fiasco.

"The ministry's investigation into the Papua New Guinea case did not target anyone, but teh MOFA did have the responsibility to look into the case, and the general public also had high expectations regarding the details of the incident, " Chen said, denying that any names or specific positions were mentioned in the report.

Chen made the remarks in response to a reporter's reference to a United Daily report that Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou had delivered the internal investigation report in person to the Control Yuan, and had submitted a request for his predecessor to be investigated.

In accordance with the Law on Discipline of Civil Servants, Ou has formally requested the Control Yuan to investigate former Foreign Minister James Huang and Huang's close aide Chang Chian-sheng in connection with the diplomatic fraud case, the paper claimed.
The news report noted that it was unprecedented for an incumbent foreign minister to submit a request for his predecessor to be investigated.

Huang, who said he remained "upright and honest" in the case, resigned May 6 as foreign minister. Chang's appointment as deputy representative to Malaysia was later canceled, as he was one of the few persons with access to information on Taiwan's secret diplomatic endeavors.

Chen said Ou, who met with Control Yuan President Wang Chien-hsuan on Aug. 4, gave the assurance that the foreign ministry would do all it could to facilitate the Control Yuan's investigation into the case and it would set up a rigorous monitoring mechanism to prevent any repeat of the incident.

The case first came to light on May 1 when a Singaporean daily reported that the country's High Court had approved Taiwan's application for an injunction to freeze an account held jointly by two middlemen, Ching Chi Ju and Wu Shihi-tsai.
Wu and Ching were commissioned in 2006 to broker a deal between Taiwan and Papua New Guinea for the establishment of diplomatic relations.

Taiwan's foreign ministry by Sept. 14, 2006 had remitted US$29.8 million into a Singaporean bank account held jointly by Wu and Ching. However, after the negotiations with Papua New Guinea fell through, Ching went missing, along with the funds.

The diplomatic bungle not only disgraced the then ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which was already mired in several corruption scandals, but also embarrassed Taiwan in the international community.

Taiwan's government has long been criticized domestically for engaging incheckbook diplomacy-- using money to convince usually small impoverished countries to establish diplomatic ties with Taipei instead of with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Issuance of 'Republic of China' stamps to resume Aug. 20

TEXT.P: The state postal company Chunghwa Post Co. announced Thursday that on Aug 20 it will officially resume the issuance of postage stamps bearing the country name, Republic of China, after a suspension of more than one year under a Taiwanization policy of the former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration.

The first issue marking the resumption will be a souvenir sheet comprised of four NT$5 stamps featuring the Yimin Festival, the company said. The festival, mainly celebrated by the Hakka people, is observed on the 20th day of the seventh lunar month and falls on Aug. 20 this year.
The print on the stamps will read "Chunghua Minkuo" in Chinese and "Republic of China (Taiwan) " in English, according to the company.
Chunghwa Post, which was renamed "Taiwan Post Co." in February 2007 by the former DPP government, officially reverted its original name Aug. 4.

From Feb. 28, 2007 until Aug. 1, 2008, "Taiwan Post Co." released a total of 33 issues of postage stamps marked "Taiwan" in Chinese and English. As an exception, an issue released May 20 to mark President Ma Ying-jeou's inauguration bore the words, "Republic of China, " at the request of the president, who believes the country's official name should be used on postage stamps.

The name "Taiwan Post Co." was adopted as part of a DPP-backed campaign to change the names of state-owned enterprises that contained references to China. "Chunghwa" means "Chinese" or "China" in the Chinese language.
The DPP argued that the name change campaign would help avoid confusion resulting from Taiwanese organizations carrying names similar to those used by organizations in China.

However, the new Kuomintang administration insisted that the name change process was unlawful, because bills introduced by the former DPP administration to amend the Postal Service Act and a statute on the establishment of the Chunghwa Post Co. to change the laws' references to the company were never approved by the Legislative Yuan, in which the KMT enjoys a strong majority.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for August fell 10 points to close at 7,006, with 64,790 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September lost five points to finish at 6,978, with 631 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 10 points to close at 6,941, with 74 contract transactions.
March futures decreased nine points to finish at 6,926, with 13 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 7,016 for August, 6,983 for September, 6,951 for December, 6,935 for March and 6,928 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index lost 1.66 points to finish at 7,024.58, on turnover of NT$99.92 billion (US$3.24 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

August TE futures rose 1.3 points to close at 279.9, with 3,755 contracts traded, while September TE futures increased 1.15 points to finish at 278.45, with 65 contract transactions. December TE futures gained 3.35 points to end 277.2, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

August TF futures moved down 18 points to close at 871.4, with 2,728 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures decreased 17 points to finish at 870, with 41 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Government employees and magistrates in opposition to cutting expenditure program.
Government employees and magistrates expressed their strong opposition to a three-year expenditure reduction program proposed by Finance Minister Giulio Tremonti.

DOC.HEADLINE: 44% of Taiwanese have experienced violence in relationships: survey

TEXT.P: A total of 44 percent of married and single Taiwanese have been on the receiving end of some form of violence from their spouses or companions, according to the results of an online survey released Thursday.
A total of 11,626 valid samples were collected from Taiwan residents in the survey, which was jointly conducted by the Modern Women's Foundation and Yahoo! Taiwan News between July 24 and Aug. 3.
Lai Fang-yu, a lawyer and foundation board member, said at a press conference held to unveil the results that the survey revealed three major findings.

First of all, the survey showed that most people's awareness of violence in a relationship has increased, with 52 percent of the respondents saying that the definition of "violence" is not only restricted to physical violence and intimidation but also includes verbal abuse and insults, controlling of another's behavior, and emotional harm, Lai said. Only 4.9 percent of the respondents said they thought violence was defined only as physical abuse.

Secondly, Lai continued, the survey found that men and women have different feelings regarding violence in a relationship, with men saying that what they fear most is being insulted or degraded by their partner, while women said they most feared bodily harm and physical threats against themselves or their family members.

The third major finding of the survey was that women were more conscious of violence in a relationship, Lai said, pointing out that 46.1 percent of female respondents said they had been the victims of such violence, as compared to 39.7 percent of the male respondents.

The survey also asked respondents how they would react the first time they felt like the victim of violence in a relationship. In response, 39.3 percent said they would try to communicate with their partner to try to improve the situation, 24.4 percent mentioned they would break up with their partner, 18.3 percent said they would ignore the problem and try to find some form of escape, 12.5 percent said that they would seek assistance from a third party, and 5.5 percent claimed they would respond in kind with violence.

Among those who were actual victims of violence in a relationship, 22.6 percent said they had been successful in putting an end to it by using one of the above mentioned methods, 43.7 percent said they had broken up with their partner, and 33.7 percent said they continued to endure the violence, with some doing so even after their relationship ended, according to the survey results.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices close marginally lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed marginally lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 1.66 points, or 0.02 percent, to close at 7,024.58.

Suffering a drop from the gains of the previous day, the local bourse opened at 7,022.28 and fluctuated between 7,082.36 and 6,993.2. A total of 3.94 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$99.92 billion (US$3.24 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up 1.9 percent and machinery and electronics shares advancing 0.7 percent.

Four of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 2.7 percent. Banking and financial shares declined 1.8 percent, plastics and chemicals shares dropped 0.9 percent, paper and pulp issues shed 0.4 percent.
Textile stocks and construction issues both remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,095 to 938, with 449 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua to hold youth sexual abuse prevention activity

TEXT.P: The Changhua County government said Thursday that a youth sexual abuse prevention activity will be held outside the county hall Aug. 17 to educate young people about the threat and how to avoid becoming a victim.

The county government's Department of Social Affairs held a news conference at the county hall to announce the program for the upcoming event, which will feature street dance performances, a music concert, games and other activities.
The event is being jointly organized by the bureau, the Changhua police department and several civic organizations.

Changhua Deputy Magistrate Chang Jui-pin, noting that the threat of youth sexual abuse usually increases during the summer months, urged that the government, police and social groups and members of the public work together to create a "safety network" to protect young people from such crimes.

The activities will include guidance and instruction from Chang, as well as from Social Affairs Department Director Chen Chih-ming, Changhua police chief Chen Lien-chen and others on methods that young people could use to protect themselves from potential predators and to avoid any sort of verbal, physical or other forms of harassment of a sexual nature.

DOC.HEADLINE: University volunteer student team works in Malaysia

TEXT.P: A student volunteer team from Chinese Culture University in the northern city of Taipei worked in Malaysia July 24-Aug. 3, a university official said Wednesday.
The volunteer team was comprised of 12 outstanding leaders of student's clubs at the university, said Chen Tsung-hsien, director of the university's extracurricular activities division.
The volunteer team was the first of its kind from the university, he stressed.

During their stay in the Southeast Asian nation, the volunteers communicated with disabled people at a mental development center, using sign language, and drilled a sense of esprit de corps into orphans at a care center through team competitions and group work. They also danced and sang along with elderly residents during a visit to a rest home, according to Chen.
The team members raised MYR$1,000 (US$305.2) by auctioning off Taiwanese delicacies at a charity bazaar, and donated the proceeds to social welfare associations, Chen explained.
The student volunteer team returned to Taiwan Monday, according to Chen.
The university has decided to send student teams to do volunteer work in foreign countries in the summer and winter vacations each year, he disclosed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's students spend little time outdoors: survey

TEXT.P: Taiwan's children appear lukewarm about engaging in outdoor activities, as nearly 60 percent of elementary school students in the country said they were spending most of their leisure time "playing at home," according to a recent survey.

The survey on school children's leisure activities compiled by the Education, Parenting and Family Style magazine was conducted May 26 to June 17. A total of 4,037 valid questionnaires were collected, including 3,122 from fifth to eighth graders, 852 from classroom teachers and 63 from school principals.

When asked about the activities they most frequently engaged in, 56.8 percent of the students who responded to the survey indicated "Internet surfing," while 54.8 percent pointed to "doing exercise, " and 54 percent mentioned "watching TV or DVD," the data showed.

Over 70 percent of homeroom teachers who responded to the survey thought their students had serious problems with interpersonal relationships, and that those who did not have enough time to play had more difficulties making friends and were more reluctant to go to school.

More than 90 percent of the teacher respondents agreed that the main reason behind Taiwanese students' lack of learning motivation is that their time is usually filled with assigned learning sessions. The survey showed 60 percent of student respondents attended after-school classes or cram schools, with one- third of them spending more than three hours every day at cram schools.
In another survey on parents' anxiety conducted among 656 parents from July 20-22, 90 percent said they did not think that "education in Taiwan had improved over the past decade."
Meanwhile, 76 percent of the respondents said they were not confident about their children's future, and 56 percent did not believe public schools could equip their children for the future.
Most parent respondents said "strengthening character training" and "improving teacher evaluation" were the priority issues they most wanted the Ministry of Education to address.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier pushes for efforts to tap Chinese fruit market

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan directed two government agencies Thursday to help local fruit growers explore the Chinese market, taking advantage of weekend cross- Taiwan Strait charter flights and Taiwan's opening to ordinary Chinese tourists in early July.
Liu asked the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the Council of Agriculture (COA) to assess the feasibility of allowing Chinese tourists to place orders in Taiwan and take delivery in China.
He made the request during the weekly Executive Yuan meeting.

COA officials suggested that special stores be set up at Taiwan's major gateway -- Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport -- to sell locally grown fruit to departing Chinese visitors. Such visitors could then take delivery of their orders at designated pick-up spots in the Beijing and Shanghai airports.
The COA officials suggested that the MAC resolve quarantine issues through negotiations between the two sides.

In the meeting, COA officials also briefed the premier on a current campaign to promote four popular types of Taiwanese fruit to Chinese consumers during the Beijing Olympics. They also discussed issues relating to cross-strait tourism and direct passenger and cargo flights between the two sides.
Beijing and Taipei in June inked a deal on weekend passenger charter flights, but don't yet have a similar deal for cargo flights.
Liu instructed COA officials step up their efforts to help local fruit farmers better distribute their products in foreign markets including the United States, Europe and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese ICT market opportunities await Taiwan vendors

TEXT.P: In the face of the global economic downturn, the Chinese market for information and communication technology (ICT) products will continue to outstrip other markets, and Taiwanese vendors should capitalize on this, a local research body said Thursday.

"Because of the slow growth in both the international and domestic market demand, China's integrated circuit (IC) production value in 2008 is estimated to rise by only 20 percent, compared with 40 percent in 2006, " Eirc Chang, the vice president of Topology Research Institute, said Thursday at a seminar.
According to the research unit, China's IC production value in 2007 was 125 billion yuan (US$18.24 billion), representing an annual growth of 24.4 percent.

China's economic growth, presented as gross domestic product (GDP), also showed a slower growth rate of 10.4 percent in the first half of 2008, down from the 12.2 percent recorded in the same period last year.

However, Chang and other analysts from the research unit noted that China's IC industry is still the envy of the world, as the overall production value of the global IC industry grew at a meager 5 percent in the first two quarters of 2008.
"Taiwan's vendors should focus on the three most popular ICT products in China -- LCD TVs, mobile phones and notebook computers -- when exploring business opportunities there," Chang suggested.

The second quarter market output of LCD TVs in China grew at a stellar 82.7 percent year-on-year, reaching 2.8 million units, due to higher demand sparked by the Beijing Olympic Games in August, according to the research unit.

When a big sporting event is about to be held, consumers usually buy more electronic appliances that would allow them to receive the good quality game broadcasts, he noted. Chang suggested that local display panel manufacturers, one of the stronger sectors of Taiwan's ICT industry, should collaborate with brand companies in China, which have the edge in terms of cost, to compete with global brand names.
Korean and Japanese companies together captured 51.12 percent of the China ICT market, while Taiwan companies took only 34.36 percent, Chang said.
As for Taiwan's mobile phone makers, the market focus should be upstream production, in areas such as key components, another TRI analyst said.
"The strength of the Taiwan companies lies in original equipment manufacturing (OEM)," said Kevin Gao, a TRI researcher manager based in Shanghai.
The demand in China for high-quality mobile phone accessories such as phone keys and printed circuit boards (PCBs) will rise at a fast pace to match the expanding telecommunication market, Kao said.

According to the research unit's statistics, there are currently eight million new cell phone subscriptions each month in China, an indication that the country's mobile phone production output will surpass 100 million by 2011.
Touching on the business outlook for notebook computers in China, Chang said thanks to the low-price of the products, the market output is expected to reach 10.6 million in 2008.
"Local notebook OEM vendors such as Quanta Computer and Inventec should be able to secure business there," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president will be summoned for questioning: investigators

TEXT.P: The Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office said Thursday that former President Chen Shui-bian will be summoned shortly for questioning regarding the high-profile "state affairs fund" embezzlement case.

A Special Investigation Division spokesman said the group was notified by the Presidential Office earlier in the day that the office had declassified documents allegedly implicating the former president, paving the way for the task force to resume its probe.

Chu Chao-liang said the Taipei District Court will summon Chen for questioning shortly, probably at the Special Investigation Task Force headquarters, rather than at Chen's office, his home or a third place.
The declassification of documents will assist prosecutors in investigating whether Chen was directly involved in the NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) "state affairs fund" abuse case.

The Taipei District Court obtained the documents from a prosecutorial team that indicted Chen's wife and three of Chen's aides in November 2006 on charges of corruption and forgery for allegedly misappropriating NT$14.8 million from the "state affairs fund" -- a special allowance set aside for the president's discretionary use for official purposes.

Chen was listed as a co-offender in the alleged embezzlement case after he left office May 20, but investigations into his role in the case have made little progress because he refused to make public several key documents on the grounds of national security.

Chen proclaimed the documents -- mainly receipts and records of Chen's use of discretionary "state affairs funds" from 2000 through June 30, 2006 -- as "strictly confidential" in September 2007 in accordance with the Classified National Security Information Protection Act. That declaration stalled court proceedings.
The Special Investigation Division asked President Ma to declassify the files shortly after he assumed office. Ma then formed a special team to scrutinize the documents.
After combing through the files, the Presidential Office declassified them Wednesday, saying that making the documents public would not "endanger the country's interests."

Denouncing the declassification of Chen's files Thursday, Lee Sheng-chen, the former president's lawyer, said Ma may have violated sedition laws by ordering the declassification. He said he will file for the Council of Grand Justices to issue a Constitutional interpretation on special presidential powers.
Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi on Thursday continued to defend the decision to declassify the documents, saying that the move simply aimed to "allow the truth to come out."
"No political considerations or maneuvers were involved in the declassification," Wang said.
Wang said Ma would bear responsibility for the move, saying "every head of state is obliged to shoulder the consequences and responsibilities for what he does during his tenure as president."
Chen has denied any wrongdoing in the case, insisting that the courts will eventually clear his name.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, increasing NT$0.132 to close at NT$30.870.
A total of US$1.185 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.782 and fluctuated between NT$30.670 and NT$30.948.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tzu Chi to promote earth-friendly ghost month rituals at event

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Tzu Chi Foundation will hold an event Friday night in front of Taipei City Hall to promote the idea of replacing Taiwan's "ghost month" rituals that are harmful to the environment with more earth-friendly practices, and to pray for the well-being of all people.

Supported by the Taipei city government's Department of Civil Affairs, the event aims to increase local people's awareness that with global warming an increasingly serious issue, the so-called ghost month -- the seventh month of the year according to the lunar calendar -- should no longer be observed in the traditional manner, which includes burning large volumes of "ghost money."
Studies have shown that burning paper money releases benzene -- a carcinogen -- lead and other chemicals that pollutes the air and could potentially damage human health.

Dharma Master Cheng Yen, a Buddhist nun and founder of Tzu Chi, has called for turning the ghost month into an "auspicious month" -- a time for people to be grateful and be filial to their parents, to practice fasting or vegetarianism, to benefit the world's masses with good deeds, and to refrain from burning ghost money and preparing wasteful sacrificial offerings in order to protect the earth.
This year's ghost month runs from Aug. 1 through Aug. 30. According to legend, the gates of the netherworld are open during this month to allow the ghosts to feast in the land of the living.
Many people in Taiwan will observe the time-honored tradition of offering sacrifices and burning incense and ghost money in temples or in front of their homes to appease the wandering spirits.
The rituals usually climax on the 15th day of the lunar month, which falls on Aug. 15 this year.
The Tzu Chi Foundation called on people to donate the funds originally intended for burning ghost money to charities and use flowers and fruit in lieu of animal sacrifices for their worship rituals.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taichung County Musical Instruments Festival opens

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taichung County Musical Instruments Festival opened Thursday for a four-day run at the Houli Horse Farm in Houli township.

According to Taichung Magistrate Huang Jhong-sheng, this year's festival is particularly meaningful because the event coincides with Chinese Valentine's Day -- the seventh day of the seventh month according to the lunar calendar -- on Aug. 7 and Father's Day on Aug. 8.
He said the festival has lined up 100 saxophonists to play and 100 drummers to beat taiko drums at a ceremony Aug. 9.

There will also be various music performances and competitions during the festival, Huang said, adding that members of the public can bring their own instruments and get up on stage during a series of free jams.
Huang said he chose Houli as the venue for the event because the agricultural township is famous as the world's third-largest producer of saxophones.
Houli also produces other musical instruments, including flutes, drums and guitars.
This is the third consecutive year that the Taichung county government has held the festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pro-independence groups drum up support for anti-Ma rally

TEXT.P: Wu Shuh-min, chairman of the pro-independence group Taiwan Society, urged the public Thursday to participate in a protest scheduled for Aug. 30 -- the 100th day after President Ma Ying-jeou took office -- to express their anger at what he called Ma's misguided political and economic policies.

Wu made the remarks at a press conference, where he was joined by former senior presidential advisor Koo Kuang-ming, Taiwan Society Secretary-General Lo Chih- cheng, Taiwan Guts Executive Director Freddy, and Huang Kun-hu, president of the Taiwan Friends of President Lee Teng-hui Association.

"The Aug. 30 protest aims to make the government understand the people's thoughts, " Wu said. "I hope everyone can stand up and express their anger so that the government will correct its wrong policies."
He was referring to Ma's moves to improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations, including easing restrictions on commercial exchanges and seeking a "diplomatic truce" with China.

"People are really worried because the government keeps tilting toward China," Wu said. "Where will Taiwan go in the future, with the government giving up its sovereignty in the international arena and making concessions [to China] on every occasion?"
Koo said the name change of the state-run postal company was an example of the Ma government's compromising on sensitive issues of sovereignty.

The board of the state postal company decided on Aug. 1 to restore the company's original name -- Chunghwa Post Co. -- more than a year after it was renamed "Taiwan Post Co." by the former pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration.

The company adopted the name "Taiwan Post Co." in February 2007 amid a DPP- backed campaign to change the names of state-owned enterprises that contain references to China. "Chunghwa" means "Chinese" or "China" in the Chinese language.

"What everybody fights for are the interests of the land, Taiwan, instead of for a particular party or person, " Koo said. "Will the same thing have to occur all over again if there's another transfer of power?"

Lo said some might argue that the government should be given more time to perform. However, he thought the issue was not how long Ma had been in power, but rather his wrong-headed move toward "de-Taiwanization" and embrace of China.
"The attitude of the government is so arrogant, and it will only get worse if the people don't express their anger," he said.
The Aug. 30 protest is being organized by eight pro-independence groups, including Taiwan Society, Taiwan Guts, Taiwan Heart and the Taiwan Friends of President Lee Teng-hui Association.

Two groups of protesters will march separately from the business and shopping area of Zhongxiao East Road, Section 3 and from Lungshan Temple before joining up for a rally on Ketagalan Boulevard, in front of the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Administration's focus is deregulation: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Thursday that the focus of his administration is deregulation and development.
The premier made the statement at a weekly meeting of the Executive Yuan as he listened to Minister Without Portfolio Chu Yun-peng's report on "financial deregulation and tax reforms."

The premier asked all government agencies to get down to work based on a national development blueprint drafted at a Cabinet seminar late last month, which included the investment of NT$4 trillion (US$131.14 million) in major development projects over four years.
The government agencies will have some leeway in implementing the national development projects by the end of next year, but their main task now is "to get down to work," Liu said.

He said that in order to upgrade Taiwan's international competitiveness, the government has accelerated the pace of financial deregulation in the hope of luring overseas capital and talents and rejuvenating the economy.

Chu reported in the Cabinet meeting that the government is planning to amend the law in 2009 to allow domestic banks to open branches in China and allow foreign and Chinese investment in domestic banks.
Chu also said that the deregulations and tax reforms are aimed at turning Taiwan into an asset management and fund-raising center in the Asia-Pacific region.
During the meeting, the premier also said that all other countries are facing the problem of inflation, and Taiwan should not take the issue lightly.

Amid media reports that the price of toothpaste, canned foods and laundry detergents have risen by as much as 20 percent, Liu instructed the Fair Trade Commission to pay attention to possible price gouging on basic goods.
"The government will not allow unreasonable increases in consumer prices," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Women's groups call for more paternal involvement in child-rearing

TEXT.P: Representatives of several women's rights groups urged Taiwanese fathers Thursday to take a more visible role in child-rearing, a responsibility that remains far heavier for mothers.

Making the appeal on the eve of Father's Day, the representatives suggested that the government take steps to encourage paternal involvement in child-rearing such as designating a day of the year as "Father's and Children's Day" and implementing as soon as possible a plan to offer a monthly subsidy to workers on parental leave.

They argued that these measures are essential to creating a women-friendly work environment, enhancing the labor force participation of Taiwanese women and boosting the country's declining birth rate.

"Confined by traditional notions, the public generally believes the mother should take the major role in taking care of children," observed Fang Yun, chairwoman of the Awakening Foundation. "This has restricted women's career development."

Although the Gender Equality in Employment Law of 2002 allows either of the parents to take unpaid parental leave for up to two years until their children reach three years old, only 996 men covered by Labor Insurance have taken the leave since the law's implementation. That accounts for just 4 percent of the total of 23,823 insured workers who have been absent from work for child care purposes.
Between June 2007 and May 2008, a total of 1,768 civil servants took parental leave, but only 92 -- or 5 percent -- were men, Fang said.
Meanwhile, none of the 44 military personnel who took parental leave during the same period were men, she pointed out.

Citing data from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Fang said that more than 50 percent of women who were absent from the labor force in 2006 did so for family reasons, compared with only 0.04 percent of men weren't working for family reasons.

Pointing to the example of Sweden, Su Chien-ling, a supervisor of the Taiwan Gender Equity Education Association, noted that the participation rate of men was only 4 percent when Sweden first introduced parental leave in 1974.

However, that rate rose to 45 percent after the Swedish government in 1995 required that at least one out of the 18 months be used by the father, and then in 2002 extended that mandatory time to two months, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to promote traditional industry training

TEXT.P: A total of 1,829 college seniors will win a chance to take courses specially designed for meeting industry needs before graduation, an official of the Industrial Development Bureau said Thursday.

According to Chen Tie-yuan, a section chief of the bureau, 98 courses will be provided by various college departments in the new academic year in four traditional industry fields: precision machinery, surface treatment, die casting and textiles.
Designed under a national program to narrow the gap between academic learning and workplace practice, each course was crafted based on special characteristics of regional industry sectors.
Designing these courses allowed schools to update their teaching to cover knowledge of newly emerged industry sub sectors and to raise students' skills and competitiveness, Chen said.

College seniors who have taken three professional courses with scores averaging higher than 70 are eligible for the course, which will familiarize them with workplace challenges and inspire them in their future career choices, Chen said.
The government will provide subsidies totalling NT$97.86 million (US$3.16 million) to improve facilities and will grant NT$78 million in scholarships to qualified students, Chen said.

Each student will receive scholarships ranging in amount from NT$30,000 to NT$50,000 in one year, Chen said. He added that the scholarship aims to encourage qualified students to step into new fields to benefit themselves, schools and industry.

Chen said the plan started last year and was welcomed by students and colleges, especially those in the fields of science and technology. The bureau will carry out an evaluation of this year's program to use as a reference for next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records first trade deficit in 28 months: Finance Ministry

TEXT.P: Taiwan's external trade recorded a deficit of US$410 million (NT$12.65 billion) in July, the first for 28 months, as a result of soaring international prices of oil and raw commodities, a Ministry of Finance (MOF) official said Thursday.

"July's import values of mineral products, including crude oil, and steel goods rose 55.7 percent and 61.4 percent year-on-year, respectively, " said Lin Lee- jen, statistics director under the ministry, at a news conference.

According to the MOF, July's average prices of crude oil reached US$126.75 per barrel, a rise of 87.9 percent year-on-year. Despite the volume of oil imported in July being 10.7 percent less than the same period of last year, the import value still rose by an annualized 68.7 percent to reach US$3.38 billion.

The export value for July rose by 8 percent year-on-year at US$22.87 billion, the fifth highest figure in Taiwan's history. But imports rose at a higher annualized rate of 12.3 percent, with the value standing at US$23.28 billion, the second-highest on record.
"The export value of electric machines and textile products were reduced by 17.2 percent and 10.5 percent, respectively, " said Lee, adding that this was another factor leading to the trade deficit.
Lin said the monthly trade deficit is the third since January 1999, as two separate deficits of US$610 million and US$510 million were recorded in February 2006 and December 2004, respectively.
Trade between January and July still marked a surplus of US$7.58 billion, but was down by US$3.45 billion compared with the year-earlier figure.
Exports to China, which is the country's largest trading partner in terms of both exports and imports, only increased by 4 percent to US$8.94 billion, the lowest growth since June 2005.

Attributing the decline to the battered outlook among major consumer markets around the world, Lin said exports to the United States, the nation's second- largest trading partner, also dropped considerably by 6.1 percent to US$2.75 billion.

Asked if the trade deficit will continue in the coming months, the official responded positively, saying that with a drop in crude oil prices in recent weeks, external trade statistics could soon show a surplus.
International oil prices fell by 16 percent over the past month, from US$138.91 per barrel July 7 to US$116.110 per barrel Aug. 7.

Taiwan's export to the emerging economies continued to grow steadily, as the value of goods shipped to the six larger economies in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations -- Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam -- were 21.2 percent higher than same month of last year, reaching US$3.5 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Eight localities in campaign to lure Chinese tourist dollars

TEXT.P: Eight cities and counties in northern Taiwan have decided to collectively promote their speciality products in a bid to build a strong impression among the public and entice potential visitors, specifically Chinese tourists.

Yang Ching-yen, director of the Taipei County Economic Development Bureau, said that in an effort to attract more Chinese tourist dollars, eight local governments -- Taipei County, Taipei City, Taoyuan County, Yilan County, Hsinchu City, Hsinchu County, Keelung City and Miaoli County -- have decided to make a joint effort to promote their speciality foods and other items.
Under the program, the eight local governments agree to showcase their specialty goods collectively at an exhibition center in each of the eight administrative areas, Yang explained.

Wherever visitors go in the eight cities and counties, they will be able to find speciality products from every area at each local exhibition center, such as pineapple cakes from Taipei City, Baochung tea from Taipei County, dry bean curd from Taoyuan County and fresh strawberries from Miaoli County, he said.

The results of several recent opinion surveys show that some 70 percent of the Chinese tourists who visited Taiwan last month support the idea of establishing a pineapple cake museum in Taipei City, while 31 percent picked up pineapple cakes as their preferred gift items.
Baochung tea from Taipei County has long been very popular among the diversified categories of tea produced in different areas of Taiwan.
Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei has on several occasions treated Chinese and other foreign dignitaries to Baochung tea, which has won several prizes in tea and cuisine competitions in Beijing.
President Ma Ying-jeou will attend a bazaar Friday along with seven other local chiefs to help sell speciality products from each of the eight cities and counties.

Based on a deal inked in June between Taipei and Beijing, Ma instituted a wider opening to Chinese tourists and weekend cross-Taiwan Strait in early July in the hope of injecting momentum to Taiwan's economy.

The eight local governments have also jointly organized a series of activities to attract public attention to their typical farm produce or special goods in line with their efforts to promote local tourism, with three fairs to be held across northern regions -- one in Yilan County Aug. 16, one in Banciao, Taipei County Oct. 4, and one in Hsinchu County Nov. 8, Yang said.
Visitors to these exhibitions will be able to have a taste of the eight localities' speciality foods or see their other unique items all in one place, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: New strains of Hepatitis C virus found in Taiwan: researchers

TEXT.P: E-Da Hospital in Kaohsiung has recently found three strains of hepatitis C virus that had never been seen before in Taiwan, which presents a possible threat to Taiwan's public health system, medical researchers at the hospital said Thursday.
Lin Hsi-hsun, chief of E-Da's infectious diseases section, said that to date, there are only three strains of hepatitis C virus endemic to Taiwan -- strains 1b, 2a, and 2b.

"These three strains are well-known to local physicians, and effective treatments have long been developed, " said Lin. "However, the three new strains of 1a, 6a, and 3a are relatively foreign to us, and we may need some time to develop or adopt viable treatments."
During the medical examinations of 243 drug addicts who had been in prison between 2004 and 2006, the 1a, 6a, and 3a strains were found in their blood samples, said Lin.
Among the prisoners, 29.2 percent carried the 1a strain, 23.5 percent had the 6a strain, and 20.2 percent were infected with the 3a strain.
According to national health statistics, 96.6 percent of Taiwan's drug addicts have developed hepatitis C, with most of them having been infected by sharing syringes with carriers of the disease.
Based on the evidence collected in experiments, the researchers, led by Lin, reached a hypothesis that the strains may have been imported from China and Southeast Asia.
"One of the suggestions is that some of the drug addicts visited these areas and shared syringes with addicts there, then returned to Taiwan carrying the Hepatitis virus," said Lin.
Lin noted that although only a few cases of the 3a strain have been found in the general population so far, Taiwan's public health might face challenges if the foreign strain spreads.

Based on the treatments developed in other countries, Lin said, it is relatively easier to contain the 6a and 3a strains, but it is more difficult to treat the 1a strain infection, as it usually takes at least one year to contain such an infection.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei beef noodle festival to open

TEXT.P: Thirty "mystery" juries are now tasting beef noodles around the city as a warmup to the upcoming 2008 Taipei Beef Noodle Festival, the sponsor of the event said Thursday.

The Taipei city government's Department of Economic Development said the juries, comprised of six gourmets and 24 reporters specializing in food, are tasting the offerings of 120 beef noodle shops around the city.

The 120 shops have been recommended by borough chiefs and taxi drivers -- who are said by some to have a reputation of being familiar with local delicacies -- with each administrative district allowed to name 10 shops.
The juries will select five shops from each administrative district, or 60 shops in all, by Aug. 18, the officials said.

The selection will be based on flavor, cleanliness, appearance, service quality and price. If the performance in each of the five categories is of high standard, the shop will be given one star for each.
The city government will present trophies to those shops that collect four or five stars.
The public will be invited to choose their favorite beef noodles starting Sept. 1 and the most popular beef noodle shops will be unveiled Oct. 31.
There will also be an individual competition, with the winner crowned the "beef noodle gourmet king."

City officials noted that this will be the fourth consecutive year the city has sponsored the event, adding that the festival has helped to make beef noodles one of the most famous dishes of Taipei City.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indigenous tribe seeks to rekindle hunting tradition

TEXT.P: A group Rukai tribal men gathered in southern Pingtung County Thursday for a ritual to mark the imminent start of the Rukai traditional hunting season -- a tradition that has been substantially restricted since stricter wildlife conservation laws were legislated in the late 1980s.

More than 100 Rukai from Pingtung County and the neighboring southern county of Kaohsiung and eastern county of Taitung fired their rifles into the air to notify the gods of the Aug. 15 launch of the hunting season.

Addressing the ritual, Yen Chin-cheng, chief of the Wutai rural township in Pingtung County, lamented that hunting has gradually faded out among the Rukai people since the Wildlife Conservation Act was promulgated, creating growing public awareness of the need for wildlife conservation and protection.

Under the terms of the act, indigenous people are allowed to hunt for only two weeks every year, which has meant that most of the former Rukai hunters have been forced to leave their homes to seek menial work in the cities, Yen said.

Yen noted that the Rukai hunters used to hunting over a vast area that stretched from Wutai to the distant Taimali river area in the eastern county of Taitung. The Rukai used to be great hunters of Formosan bears, Formosan sambars, wild boar, goats and Formosan Reeve's muntjacs, he noted.
"The hunting provided an important source of protein for the Rukai people and formed one of the signature traditions of the tribe," Yen said.
"A hunter who killed five male wild boar would be decorated by the chieftain with wreaths made of lilies and would be considered a hero," Yen added.

The glorious citation is now history, he lamented, adding that the central government is risking leading the ancient craft to extinction if they continue to be reluctant to do anything to save the dying tradition.
Meanwhile, the Rukai also declared in the ritual their sovereignty claim over their traditional land.
At the end of the ceremony, they called for the central government to return them their traditional rights to hunt in their traditional hunting grounds.

They urged the Forestry Department under the Council of Agriculture (COA) to talk with the Rukai to allow the two parties to co-manage the reserve areas and forests in their traditional land, which has been taken from them by the government and is now administered by the COA.
They also called for the legislature to amend articles in the Wildlife Conservation Act that run counter to the culture and spirit of the indigenous people.

They further demanded that the administration allocate part of the Employment Stabilization Fund to finance the employment of Rukai people in jobs pertaining to wildlife conservation and environmental protection.
The Rukai, whose population totals around 11,000, is one of the 14 indigenous groups that the administration officially recognizes at present.

Taiwan's indigenous people -- the native groups that predate all other people Taiwan -- originated in southern China according to some anthropologists, although most agree that they came from the vast Austronesian-language region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Straits Exchange Foundation consultant to retain post

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) consultant Pang Chien-kuo, who was tipped to be named the foundation's first deputy secretary-general, will retain his existing post for one more year, according to a press statement released by the SEF Thursday.

The SEF is the country's quasi-official organization established to handle exchanges with China in the absence of official diplomatic ties. At present, the foundation has two deputy secretaries-general, with another post vacant.

The statement said Pang's consultancy post will last until July 31 next year and that he will be tasked with convening meetings on affairs involving the interests of Taiwanese businessmen operating in China.

Pang told CNA that he will not be involved in SEF negotiations with China in the future and will only be responsible for carrying out coordination and communication among the official and private sectors before the SEF makes resolutions.

According to Pang, SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Kao Koong-lian has asked him to also contribute to a project on the cross-strait digital content industry, which, Pang said, will play an important role in future talks with China.
Pang's post of consultant is without pay at present, but the foundation will turn it into a paid position in the near future, the statement added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei's Neihu Sports Center to formally open Aug. 16

TEXT.P: The newly completed Neihu District Sports Center will be inaugurated Aug. 16 after a six-day trial operation Aug. 8-13, the Taipei Sport Office announced Thursday.

The 11-story multifunction building, with three basement floors, was constructed using green technology. It is equipped with sports, leisure and business facilities and will also serve as a service center for the nearby Taipei Neihu Technology Park.

The main facilities of the center include a conference room, several function rooms for company events, an indoor shooting range, an archery range, a basketball court, a golf practice range, a badminton court, a dance classroom, a fitness room, a judo room and a heated indoor swimming pool, plus spa and sauna.
There is also a 15-meter-high outdoor artificial rock-climbing wall, which measures up to international standards and is the highest and most difficult one in Taiwan.

According to the Taipei Sports Office, the Aug. 16 inauguration will be followed by various festivities, including a lion dance, other dance performances, stalls selling delicacies and handicrafts, and free medical diagnoses provided by the Neihu District Health Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese shopping Web sites post double-digit growth

TEXT.P: Taiwan's major shopping Web sites showed double-digit growth in sales revenues during the first six months of this year amid rising inflation and soaring oil prices, Web site executives said Wednesday.
Buying goods online saves on travel costs, the executives said, adding that as oil prices rose during the first half of this year, many locals began turning to local shopping Web sites.
In addition, shopping Web sites offer a wide range of price or product choices and promotional incentives, which is another big advantage in attracting local customers, they observed.
"Online shopping has become a new way of life in today's society," said Charlene Hung, general manager of Yahoo! Taiwan.
"Either home delivery or picking up goods ordered online at convenience stores is quite convenient," she went on.
Hung said that Yahoo! Taiwan's shopping Web site, like many other similar ones in the United States, has posted a double-digit rise in online sales revenues.
Local food specialties are the most popular items on Yahoo! Taiwan, according to Hung.

Moreover, the Taipei-based Far Eastern Group's GOHAPPY Web site -- which was launched June 15, 2007 -- enjoyed double-digit growth during the first half of the year compared with the second half of last year.

GOHAPPY's revenues also increased 20 percent every month during the first six months of this year, said Susan Chiu, marketing assistant manager of Ding Ding Integrated Marketing Service Co., which is in charge of GOHAPPY.
In July alone, the Web site's revenues jumped 43 percent compared with the average monthly revenues of the first six months, Chiu noted.

Best-selling products are home products, entertainment electronic products and computer products, Chiu went on, adding that GOHAPPY mainly sells products of the group's Pacific SOGO department stores and its hypermarket chain, Far Eastern Geant.

Meanwhile, Takkyubin, an express delivery service company owned by President Chain Store Corp., Taiwan's largest convenience store operator with more than 4,800 7-Eleven stores, also benefited from the booming online sales.
Takkyubin said that during the first six months of this year, its online delivery service increased 30 percent in terms of revenue from a year ago.
Most of the delivered goods were food specialties, computer, communication, and consumer electronics products, as well as women's clothes, Takkyubin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 32% of Taiwanese men not keen on having children: survey

TEXT.P: Nearly 32 percent of Taiwanese men are not interested in having children, according to the results of a survey released by an online human resources firm Thursday, the eve of Father's Day.

The survey, conducted by www.1111.com.tw, found that among the childless men, including married and single people, 31.74 percent said they are not keen on having children or do not want children at all.

The reason most cited for not wanting children is that they cannot afford to have children at 57.43 percent, followed by "not wanting to be bogged down by an extra burden" at 34.65 percent, and "no confidence in the educational environment" at 31.68 percent in the multiple choice survey..
On parent-child relations, the survey found that 20.19 percent of fathers polled have never said "I love you" to their children, while 18.75 percent forgot when they last said the words.
This shows that nearly 40 percent of the fathers are not good at expressing their feelings.
However, 18.27 percent of the fathers polled said they say "I love you" to their children every day.

The survey also found that 23.9 percent of Taiwanese men "want very much to help with household chores" and that only 3.82 percent are unwilling to help with such chores as garbage collection and categorizing, sweeping, washing the dishes and laundry.
The survey was conducted between July 22 and Aug. 4 with 523 effective samples collected.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Korean tourists coming to Taiwan

TEXT.P: The number of South Korean tourists visiting Taiwan in the first half of this year grew by a whopping 32.7 percent year-on-year, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) reported Thursday.
The numbers of tourists from Macau and Hong Kong also grew by 29 percent in the same period, according to the Tourism Bureau under the MOTC.
The number of Japanese tourists, however, declined by 5 percent, mainly as a result of the sagging Japanese economy, bureau officials added.

Save for the Japanese, almost all sources of tourists from abroad soared in the first six months of this year, climbing by an average of 10.5 percent, with that from South Korea growing the fastest, the officials said.

They attributed the remarkable increase in the number of Korean tourists to Taiwan to various promotion programs that the Tourism Bureau has launched over the past year -- programs including the production and broadcasting in Korea of a Korean soap opera series called On Air, part of which was filmed in Taiwan under the auspices of the Tourism Bureau.

"The showing of On Air in South Korea has not only let Korean citizens know about Jiufen and Sun Moon Lake, as well as Taipei and Hualien, it has also attracted more Korean tourists, " a Tourism Bureau official said.
Meanwhile, the Tourism Bureau said that the occupancy rate of Taiwan's tourist hotels totaled just 63.7 percent in the first half of 2008, representing a decline of 2.2 percent year-on-year.
Average room rates for tourist hotels, however, increased by 0.8 percent during the same period.
Tourism Bureau officials envisioned that the number of tourists visiting Taiwan is expected to grow substantially in the second half of the year, thanks to the July 4 opening to tourists from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan offers residency to Tibetans' spouses, children

TEXT.P: The government will offer residency to spouses and children of 125 Tibetans who are living in Taiwan based on humanitarian concerns, the National Immigration Agency said in a statement Thursday.
The announcement came after the Ministry of the Interior amended the Regulations Governing Visiting, Residence and Permanent Residence of Aliens, which entered into force Aug. 1.

The amended regulations apply to those married to Taipei-based Tibetans prior to Jan. 26, 2007 and who are allowed to enter Taiwan with travel documents issued by the Indian government, the statement read.
The regulations also cover Tibetans' children under the age of 20 with the same documents, according to the statement.
One hundred and twenty-five Tibetans were allowed to stay in Taiwan after the government launched an investigation to confirm their identities in 2001, the statement went on.
Their spouses, nevertheless, could only stay in Taiwan for 180 days at a time, the statement said, adding that they then had to leave Taiwan and file a new application.

The immigration agency urged qualified Tibetan spouses and children to take their Indian travel documents, proof of no criminal record and health check documents and apply for residency in Taiwan at the agency's branch offices around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Securities Association signs MOU with Australian counterpart

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Securities Association (TSA) has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) in Sydney with its Australian counterpart for cooperation on global market expansion, a TSA executive said Thursday.
The MOU was inked by TSA President Huang Min-chu and Australian Financial Markets Association (AFMA) Chairman Robert Priestley.

It prepares the two associations for exchanges of information on financial market regulations, the establishment of a more effective sanction mechanism and the strengthening of market self-discipline, the executive said, adding that it will also allow the two associations to work together on expanding the market in the Asia-Pacific.

According to the executive, the AFMA has more than 130 members, including both Australian and non-Australian financial institutes, with a total financial transaction amount accounting for over NT$120 trillion (US$3.87 trillion) from 2006-2007.
The AFMA is the pivotal association for Australia's financial market, the executive added.
The MOU with Australia is the TSA's eighth MOU with foreign counterparts and is a continuation of efforts to help Taiwanese financial institutes establish a global network, the executive said.
The TSA signed MOUs with the securities associations of Japan, Mongolia and South Korea in 2007, and with Thailand, Vietnam, Germany, Poland and Australia this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Outbound passengers down 10% in July

TEXT.P: The number of people traveling abroad plunged to 746,000 people in July, marking a 10 percent decline year-on-year, according to statistics provided by the Tourism Bureau.
Yao Da-guang, president of the Taiwan Travel Agent Association, said the hikes in air fares has affected people's willingness to travel to far away destinations, such as Europe and the U.S.
The Japan and Korea routes have also been affected by this wave of inflation, said Yao.
Previously, group tours to Japan filled up as soon as they were opened, but this year it has been difficult to put together such groups, Yao said.
In addition, traveling abroad during August, which is ghost month on the lunar calendar, is considered taboo in Chinese culture, travel sources noted.
The Sichuan Earthquake and the Beijing Olympics have also affected the travel market, according to Liao Pei-yuan, deputy manager of the South East Travel Agency.
Faced with a sluggish market, travel agencies have been cutting prices in order to stimulate sales, said Chen Ming-ming, deputy manager of Star Travel Agency.

Some of the stimulus packages include EZ Travel's five-day Tokyo Disneyland tour for NT$19,900, its six-day Guam tour for NT$9,999, and South East Travel Agency's five-day package to Phuket, Thailand for NT$8,888.

However, the Taiwan Travel Agent Association has reminded consumers that there are lots of limitations attached to these kinds of promotion packages, and has advised that the offers be studied closely before purchase.

DOC.HEADLINE: Full information disclosure needed under Lobby Law

TEXT.P: Lobbyists must register with the institutions of whoever they want to lobby, providing information such as the content of the lobbying and how much is to be spent on the lobbying under a new law, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Thursday.
MOI officials said that after the Lobby Law is put into effect the following day, Taiwan will become only the third country after the United States and Canada to regulate lobbying activities.
Ministry officials said that full disclosure of information will be required and that those who violate the regulations will face fines of up to NT$2.5 million (US$81,967).

The officials said that under the law, those who can be lobbied include the president, the vice president, elected officials at various levels, chiefs and deputies of city and county governments and village, township and city offices, as well as those who are covered by the Statute Governing the Retirement and Consolation Payment to Political Appointee.
The total number in all categories is over 5,800. At the same time, 740 of their governing agencies will also be covered by the new law.

The law defines a lobbyist as one who attempts to influence the formation, formulation, revision or abrogation of a law, a policy, or a bill by directly expressing views to the one being lobbied or his proxies.

The officials said that foreign governments and institutional organizations have to commission local people to lobby on their behalf and that they should not lobby over matters concerning national defense, diplomacy or China affairs involving national security or national secrets.
Individuals, institutional organizations or groups from China, Macau or Hong Kong will not be allowed to engage in lobbying, according to the law.

To avoid conflict of interest, the officials said public office holders, apart from elected officials, cannot lobby the offices in which they have served in the past five years within three years of leaving office.
Elected officials at various levels should also not lobby for businesses run by themselves or their relatives or in which they own a stake of over 10 percent.
Those who violate the regulations regarding avoidance of conflict of interest will risk fines of between NT$500,000 and NT$2.5 million under the new law.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:Officials Say Documents Tie Scientist to Anthrax Attack
The Federal Bureau of Investigation on Wednesday outlined a pattern of bizarre and deceptive conduct by Bruce E. Ivins, an Army microbiologist who killed himself last week, presenting a sweeping but circumstantial case that he was solely responsible for mailing the deadly anthrax letters that killed five people in 2001.
The Wall Street Journal: Chrysler, Nissan in Talks To Team Up on Key Cars
Chrysler LLC is in talks with Nissan Motor Co. about jointly producing midsize cars, a partnership that would move the U.S. auto maker toward a radical new business model.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Foreign Activists Manage to Pierce China's Broad Security Apparatus
China's intense efforts to block any protest that would mar the Olympic Games were challenged Wednesday by foreign activists equally bent on diverting attention to issues as varied as Tibetan independence, the crisis in Darfur and religious freedom.
The Washington Times: McCain takes lead on YouTube hits Paris Hilton may think John McCain is just a " wrinkly white-haired guy, " but the Republican presidential candidate apparently has figured out the younger generation just fine. Over the past two weeks, his " celebrity" attacks have stomped Democratic presidential opponent Sen. Barack Obama in YouTube hits.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Rowan Williams: gay relationships 'comparable to marriage'
Rowan Williams believes that gay sexual relationships can reflect the love of Godin a way that is comparable to marriage, The Times has learnt.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Friday.
The weighted price index was down 23.83 points at 7,000.75 on a turnover of NT$3 billion (US$97.18 million) at the open. The index lost 1.66 points, or 0.02 percent, to close at 7,024.58 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Friday.
The greenback was trading at NT$31.071 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.201 from Thursday.
