DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 8, or the eighth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1549: France declares war on England.
1588: The Spanish Armada is defeated by the British.
1900: The first Davis Cup tennis tournament, named after Dwight Filley Davis, begins in Brookline, Massachusetts.
1901: Ernest Lawrence, the American physicist who won the Nobel Prize for physics in 1939, is born. He invented the first subatomic particle accelerator and the color television tube.
1918: The Battle of Amiens begins when Allied forces advance against 20 German divisions and take 16,000 prisoners in two hours.
1919: A peace conference between India and Afghanistan results in the signing of the Treaty of Rawalpindi.
1923: Esther Williams, the American actress and former champion swimmer, is born. She became best-known for her appearance in "Bathing Beauty."
1944: Adolf Hitler has four of his top men hanged with piano wire for attempting to assassinate him.
1945: The United States drops its second atomic bomb, "Fat Man," on the Japanese city of Nagasaki, days after devastating Hiroshima with "Little Boy," the first such device ever used.
1957: General Chow Chih-jou is appointed governor of Taiwan, succeeding C.K. Yen.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Jordan.
1961: Mei Lan-fang, noted Beijing opera actor, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 67.
1963: In one of the most audacious holdups of all time, robbers involved in "The Great Train Robbery" net an estimated 2.5 million pounds (US$4.6 million) in unused bank notes from a night mail train traveling between Glasgow and London.
1963: The United States, Britain and the USSR sign the nuclear Test Ban Treaty in the Kremlin.
1967: The "Bangkok Declaration" is signed by the foreign ministers of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. The declaration led to the formation of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN).
1974: Richard Nixon makes history as the first U.S. president to resign from office.
1977: The Interior Ministry reports that at the end of June, the population of Taiwan reached 16,655,140 and that of Taipei hit 2,113,030.
1983: A military coup led by Defense Minister General Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores overthrows President Efrain Rios Montt of Guatemala.
1988: ROC swimmer Wang Han and a six-man team swim across the English Channel in relays in 14 hours and 31 minutes.
1988: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa announces the decision to build a new highway linking Ilan and Nankang in Taipei County.
1990: National Defense Minister Chen Li-an announces that the Red Cross Society of the ROC will handle the repatriation of illegal mainland entrants in the future.
1994: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait sign and make public a joint announcement confirming the results of the second round of talks between Chiao Jen-ho and Tang Shubei.
1999: The Fifth Asia Children's Literature Convention opens in Taipei with 300 authors of children's literature from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Malaysia and the ROC attending.
2000: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records names 109 -year-old Hu Chin-yao as Taiwan's oldest father.
2001: Officials from Taiwan and Australia gathers in Taipei to participate in a two-day conference on mineral and energy resources.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If those in authority have not the confidence of those under them, government of the people is an impossibility."

DOC.HEADLINE: All mooncake filling samples tested in Kaohsiung up to par

TEXT.P: All samples of mooncake fillings recently tested by the Kaohsiung city government's Department of Health were found to meet the city's food safety standards, the department said Friday.
The department carried out the spot tests at mooncake retail outlets and factories around the southern port city between July 22-24, with a total of 60 samples tested.

None of the samples were found to contain excess amounts of preservatives or other additives, according to the department, which added that it will conduct a second wave of testing to ensure that mooncake and mooncake filling producers are abiding by the city's food sanitation regulations.
Mooncakes are a Chinese pastry traditionally eaten during the Mid-Autumn Festival, which falls on Sept. 14 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan funds local development projects in Honduras
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Aug. 7 (CNA) 08/08/08 13:26:25 (By Ramon Huang and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has donated US$2.5 million to Honduras to fund development projects in the Central American ally, ROC Ambassador to Honduras Lai Chien- chung told CNA by phone Thursday.

Lai said in Tegucigalpa, the capital of Honduras, that the donation will be used to establish electricity supply systems, promote public health education, boost local production and improve tap water sanitation and drainage systems in the country's rural areas.
Lai added that the donation is part of Taiwan's bilateral cooperation program.

On receiving the donation Wednesday, Honduran International Cooperation Minister Karen Zelaya said that since 2006, Taiwan and Honduras have cooperated on 121 programs to promote the development of rural areas in Honduras, 34 of which have been completed, according to a report from Honduras-based Radio America.

Lai explained that Honduras proposes bilateral cooperation programs on improving its local development every year and that Taiwan earmarks funds to sponsor feasible programs after the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the ROC embassy in Honduras discuss and analyze the proposals.
A previous donation of more than US$370,000 to Honduras from Taiwan in June was used to establish tap water systems in rural areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pro-Tibet groups hold peaceful march

TEXT.P: Several pro-Tibet non-government organizations held a peaceful march Friday in Taipei on the opening day of the Beijing Olympics, urging the world not to forget about what they described as the atrocities committed by the Chinese government.

Members of the Regional Tibetan Youth Congress Taiwan, Friends of Tibet in Taiwan, the Taiwan Association of Human Rights, the Taiwan Youth for Democracy in Asia and Taiwan Guts marched from the 228 Peace Park to the Legislative Yuan.

"Today our Chinese brothers and sisters might be joyfully celebrating the opening of the great Olympics in which people unite and compete in one brotherhood, but we should not forget those who have stood against the tyrannical rule of the communist iron-fisted rulers of China, " said Tashi Tsering, president of the Regional Tibetan Youth Congress Taiwan, before the parade.
Tashi was arrested in Japan April 26 for attempting to disrupt the Olympic torch relay in Nagano and was released May 16 after paying a fine of 500,000 Japanese yen (US$4,899).
The 42-year-old Tibetan activist stated that despite the Beijing Olympics opening later that evening, human rights abuses have been increasing in recent weeks in Tibet and in China.
"The situation has become worse as the Games approach, which is completely against Beijing's promise to improve its human rights, " said Tashi.

"We urge all the countries and human rights organizations around the world in particular to press the government of China to immediately halt all repression and to respect the fundamental human rights and religious freedom of Tibetan people in Tibet," he added.

Chou Mei-li, president of the Friends of Tibet in Taiwan, said the group condemns Beijing for accusing human rights organizations and individuals concerned about the human rights situation in Tibet and China of politicizing the Olympics.
"It is Beijing that is politicizing the games," she said. "If Taiwan does not stand up for Tibet today, it will become the next Tibet," she predicted.
She said it is shameful that Taiwan accepted the procession arrangement of its Olympic team at the opening ceremony, claiming that it completely belittles Taiwan.
The procession of the Beijing Olympic opening ceremony has been arranged according to the number of strokes contained in the first characters of their country names in simplified Chinese characters.

Under the system, Taiwan will be the 24th team to enter the stadium after Japan and before the Central African Republic and Hong Kong, a model that is different from past precedent, in which Taiwan was grouped under the "T" section based on a protocol signed in 1981.

Although the new system will not result in Taiwan being grouped together with China in the opening procession, activists are concerned that if this new precedent is set, Taiwan will be grouped together with China and Hong Kong when taking part in future Olympic Games and other international sports events.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. congressional delegation to visit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 7 (CNA) 08/08/08 14:35:57 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Nine members of the U.S. House of Representatives are heading a delegation that is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan aboard a special military flight this weekend for a three-day visit, a Taiwan official posted in the United States said Thursday.

The group, organized by the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure, will be the largest to visit Taiwan since 2003, indicating the importance attached by the U.S. Congress toward the Republic of China and its new government, said Lai Shui-chih, deputy chief of the Press Division under the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States (TECRO).

During its stay in Taiwan, the delegation will make a fact-finding tour of Evergreen Aviation Technologies Corp., which maintains and services aircraft owned by the U.S. international carrier Delta Air Lines.

According to Lai, trade unions in the U.S. aerospace industry have recently expressed concern over a situation in which American airline companies are sending their aircraft overseas for maintenance, which has resulted in job losses in the United States.
The tour will help the congressmen get a clearer picture of the issue before reacting to the trade unions, Lai said.

The delegation will also take a ride on the Taiwan high speed railway and will pass Taiwan's high speed rail experience on to the U.S. government for its reference, according to an itinerary released by the TECRO.

The congressmen will meet with President Ma Ying-jeou, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco H.L. Ou and Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo. They will also visit the National Palace Museum and the Taipei 101 skyscraper before leaving Taiwan Monday.

The delegation is led by Jerry Costello (D-Ill.), chairman of the Subcommittee on Aviation, with members also including John Duncan (R-Tenn.), Solomon Ortiz (D-Texas), Tim Holden (D-Pa.), Eddie Bernice Johnson (D-Texas), Michael Capuano (D-Mass.), Henry Brown (R-S.C.), Dan Lipinski (D-Ill.) and Mary Fallin (R-Okla.).
Taiwan will be the final leg of the delegation's Asia visit, which has already taken them to Singapore and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taroko Gorge tops among national parks in visitor numbers

TEXT.P: Taroko Gorge National Park in eastern Taiwan saw the highest number of visitors among all of Taiwan's national parks in the first half of this year, according to the latest Interior Ministry tallies released Friday.
Taiwan's seven national parks received a total of 8.21 million visitors in the January-June period, with Taroko Gorge accounting for 2.53 million, the ministry said.

The number of visitors to Taroko National Park, which spans the eastern counties of Hualien, Taichung and Nantou, marked an increase of more than 240,000 over the level for the same period of a year ago.

Second on the list was Yangmingshan National Park -- Taiwan's smallest national park -- which is located in the mountainous suburbs of Taipei and received 2.48 million visitors for the January-June period.

The figure marked a decline of more than 700,000 over the previous year's level, largely due to a lengthy cold spell during the park's famous flower festival during February and March, which kept many visitors away, the ministry said.

Kending National Park, the oldest and southernmost national park, received the third-highest number of visitors for the period at 1.48 million. The figure was also down over the previous year because of the cold spell in February and March as well as a lengthy period of torrential rain in June, according to the ministry.
Since the government passed the National Park Act in 1972 to protect the environment, wildlife and history in its territory, seven national parks have been established around the island.

Dongsha Marine National Park in the South China Sea is the latest and largest of the parks, covering a total area of nearly 3,540 square kilometers, which is more than that of all the other parks combined and roughly ten percent of the size of the whole of Taiwan proper.
As the main purpose of the Dongsha marine park is ecological conservation, the park is not open to visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Record high of 97.1% of applicants can enter college

TEXT.P: The college admission rate reached a record high of 97.1 percent this year, with the exam score required for university entrance hitting a new low of 7.69 points in the country's history of entrance exams, an academic source said Friday.

A total of 81,409 high school graduates out of the 90,894 students who took the battery college entrance tests this year were admitted, marking a record high 97.1 percent success rate, according to the Joint Board of College Recruitment Commission (JBCRC).

With the record high number of applicants succeeding in landing a school, even students with scores as low as 7.69 (1-600) will be accepted into Leader University, a new facility located in Tainan City, southern Taiwan, according to the JBCRC.
Toko University in Taipei City suffered a low recruitment rate of lower than 10 percent, with 12 of its 18 departments open to freshman students receiving fewer than 10 new students.

For the annual joint college recruitment, 46 students filed for only one department in one school to study. Twenty-four of them succeeded in landing in their dream departments. The students are entitled to name up to 100 choices among departments in 164 colleges and universities nationwide.

The JBCRC authorities said Friday that board members will meet in October to discuss whether it is necessary to impose threshold scores for applicants, as allowing entry to low scores like 7.69 makes little sense in terms of entrance exams. The problems pertaining to the existence crisis of new private institutions should also be tackled in the face of ever-declining recruitment rates, they said.
Meanwhile, a student aged 62 was admitted Friday as the oldest freshman this year. He will study at the Hsing Kuo University of Management located in the southern city of Tainan.
A student aged 16 was admitted into the Department of Business Administration under National Taiwan University in Taipei City, making him the youngest freshman this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City invites ex-education heads to discuss issues

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government invited its former education department heads to a roundtable meeting Thursday, at which some of them raised hotly debated issues concerning Taiwan's national identity and educational reforms.

Speaking at the meeting organized by the northern city's Department of Education, Lin Chao-hsien, one of the nine former municipal education heads, claimed that there is a lack of strong national identity among local students.
This, he claimed, has caused confusion over whether the country should be referred to as Republic of China, China, Taiwan, or Chinese Taipei.
He also lashed out at teachers, claiming that they "fail to teach students to be patriotic."

He further accused the government education policy of having placed too much emphasis on localization and globalization in recent years, making national consciousness and national identity "disappear."
Lin said national identity education might not produce obvious results in the short term, but described it as having a long-term influence on the country's future.

The national identity topic has often been at issue in Taiwan in recent years, with those -- including the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) -- that favor closer ties with China preferring the country's national title, the Republic of China.

They reject using the name Taiwan on the grounds that such a move might highlight formal Taiwan independence. China claims sovereignty over self-ruled Taiwan and vows war if it moves toward formal independence.
However, others, including opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), prefer using the name Taiwan.
When it governed Taiwan between 2000 and 2008, the DPP launched Taiwan-centric policies, which often drew harsh criticism from KMT supporters.

Taiwanese identity activists deem the KMT, which came to Taiwan after losing a civil war to the communists in China, as a "foreign regime" and have been pushing for "normalizing" Taiwan as a sovereign country.
Another issue raised at the meeting was Taiwan's decade-long educational reforms.
Huang Kun-huei, another former education head, said that the number of Taiwan's senior high schools and universities has increased rapidly over the years, resulting in supply exceeding demand.
He claimed that today, students can still attend universities, "even if they score zero" on the university entrance exam.
In addition, the excessive numbers of universities and colleges have prompted more young people to study at universities rather than at vocational schools, he observed.
Huang urged the education authorities not to give up on vocational education.
Lin said Taiwan's educational reforms should not be led by private groups, which he attributed to the failure of the educational reforms.
He accused these private groups of having no experience or professionalism and of failing to put their slogans into practice.
Although many have blamed the large numbers of universities for downgrading the quality of today's students, critics have argued that grades should not determine a student's future.

Moreover, in many cases, senior high school courses have nothing to do with university courses, the critics went on, noting that many who perform poorly in high school can do well at university and have successful careers.
Instead, they lambasted universities for not improving the quality of their courses, which they claimed discourages students from learning and developing professional skills.
The critics also said that rising university admission rates in recent years have been predictable, as Taiwan's birth rate has been dropping over the years.
Taiwan's birth rate is now one of the world's lowest, and its university admission rate hit an astonishing 97.1 percent this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for August rose 184 points to close at 7,189, with 87,490 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September gained 184 points to finish at 7,160, with 1,279 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 182 points to close at 7,123, with 108 contract transactions.
March futures increased 177 points to finish at 7,103, with 23 contract transactions, while June futures advanced 172 points to close at 7,089, with seven contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 7,005 for August, 6,976 for September, 6,941 for December, 6,926 for March and 6,917 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 184.46 points to finish at 7,209.04, on turnover of NT$128.75 billion (US$4.15 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

August TE futures rose 9.4 points to close at 289.2, with 5,612 contracts traded, while September TE futures increased 9.4 points to finish at 287.85, with 103 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.
August TF futures moved up 33 points to close at 904, with 4,957 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures advanced 30.2 points to finish at 9,002, with 105 contracts traded.
December TF futures increased 45.4 points to end at 906, with four contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA to enhance service quality in tourism industry

TEXT.P: To enhance the quality of Taiwan's tourism and to cope with the influx of Chinese tourists, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Friday launched a comprehensive NT$150 million two-year training project for workers in the sector.

Taiwan's natural beauty attracts millions of foreign tourists every year, but to earn their loyalty, Taiwan needs to raise service quality in the industry, said CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan in announcing the new initiative at a press conference Friday.
"I seldom travel abroad now, since I've found that Taiwan's scenery is not inferior to that in other countries. But the service attitude in Taiwan sometimes makes travelers uncomfortable, " she said.

Wang said NT$50 million will be allocated to the project this year and another NT$100 million in 2009 to help local authorities train tourist guides, receptionists, drivers and waiters at hotels and restaurants.
Under the project, the government will subsidize local employment and vocational training offices to train people already at work or those who wish to work in the tourism sector.
Chinese spouses holding a work permit or foreign spouses with a residency permit are also eligible for the program.
The CLA expects to train as many as 8,000 tourism workers per year.
The project is being launched in coordination with the government's efforts to boost the number of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan, the council said.

Taiwan signed an agreement with China in June to allow 3,000 Chinese tourists visit Taiwan per day, but to date, tourist arrivals from across the Taiwan Strait have been far lower than the cap, barely averaging in the hundreds.
Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Seh-jen Lai said, however, the training program is a national campaign that would improve the experience of all travelers to Taiwan.
"The official slogan of Taiwan's tourism is 'Taiwan Touch Your Heart, ' and what touches travelers' hearts are those who have direct contact with them, " Lai said.
Saying that Taiwan received 3.72 million tourists last year, Lai expected the number could be increased to 4 million this year and create an output of NT$400 billion.
The Executive Yuan launched a four-year, NT$20 billion project in June to further develop important scenic spots islandwide and build a better environment for tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan party leaders in Beijing to attend Olympics opening
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 8 (CNA) 08/08/08 16:03:41 (By Huang Ming-hsi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Leaders of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the tiny People First Party (PFP) have arrived in Beijing to attend the opening of the Beijing Olympic Games set to kick off Friday at 8:08 p.m.

The politicians -- KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong -- and their wives, were among 80-odd foreign heads of state and political leaders who were met by Chinese President Hu Jintao at a reception held at the Great Hall of the People around noon Friday.
Hu met with the Taiwan political delegation immediately after the reception for a brief talk.
Meanwhile, Wu, Lien, Soong and their wives will be seated among foreign state leaders during the opening ceremony, far away from those of delegates from Hong Kong and Macau.
Observers of cross-strait politics consider the arrangement "smart" and "considerate" and one that leaves little opportunity for critics to suggest China is belittling Taiwan.
The Taiwan political delegation will also be accompanied during the opening ceremony by officials from Hu's office as well the Central Political Bureau of the Communist Party of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, surging 184.46 points, or 2.623 percent, to close at 7,209.04.

Rebounding from a small loss the previous day, the local bourse opened at the day's low of 7,000.75 and rose as high as 7,216.58. A total of 4.94 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$128.75 billion (US$4.15 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 3.6 percent. Machinery and electronics shares advanced 3 percent, construction issues rose 2.6 percent, cement stocks gained 2.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares were up 1.8 percent, foodstuff issues and paper and pulp issues both increased 1.6 percent, and textile stocks rose 1.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,796 to 381, with 355 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyer of shares worth NT$6.05 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei residents cut back car use amid fuel hikes: survey

TEXT.P: Taipei residents have curbed their car use for short trips in recent months amid soaring fuel prices, according to a survey released Friday by the city government's Department of Transportation.

Since May, when the central government began raising fuel prices, more that one- third of respondents who previously drove cars for short trips switched to other modes of transportation, the survey showed.
Of those who stopped driving cars for short trips, most (80%) switched to using scooters instead, according to the survey conducted by a local consultancy on behalf of the city government.
Before the fuel price hikes began in May, 35.2 percent of total respondents used private cars for short trips. In July, that figure dropped to 23.1 percent.

The department said that if fuel prices increase by another 10 percent, the ratio of residents using private cars for short trips will likely drop below 20 percent, and fall as low as 16.4 percent if prices rise by 30 percent.

During the May to July period, the ratio of Taipei residents using bicycles for short trips outside the home rose from 6 percent to 10.5 percent, with the figure expected to rise to 16.5 percent if fuel prices increase by another 30 percent, the survey showed.
In the same period, the ratio of residents opting for public transportation for short trips rose from 10.1 percent to 15 percent.
The survey also showed that only 10.8 percent of drivers of private cars and 17.1 percent of scooter riders switched to public transportation.

For those respondents who have not changed their mode of transportation despite pricier fuel, the top two reasons given were that the distance between their home and destination was too far, and the convenience of using their private vehicle.
The department said that the survey results clearly show that the city's transportation network must be improved and made more convenient in order to attract more riders.
The telephone survey polled Taipei residents 21 years and older between July 22 and 26, with 1,982 valid samples. The results had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA not worried about 'Olympic diplomacy'

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou Friday downplayed concerns that China would use the opening ceremony of the Beijing Olympics to engage in diplomatic maneuvering, as the government has felt the good will demonstrated by its Chinese counterpart.
"We have felt that the Chinese government has made efforts to show us good will, " Ou said in response to a reporter's question after attending the foreign ministry's annual family day event.

The highly-anticipated Olympic Games opening ceremony is slated to kick off at 8: 08 p.m. Beijing time with more than 80 heads of state and hundreds of politicians from all over the world in attendance.
While China is using the event to showcase its rising power to the world, some are concerned that Beijing will use the opportunity to lure away Taiwan's diplomatic allies.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said earlier, however, that Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies will not send their heads of state or vice presidents to the Beijing Olympics' opening ceremony on Aug. 8, dispatching instead sports officials or Olympic Committee chairmen.
The foreign ministry said the development is a positive indicator of solid relations with the allies.

Since President Ma Ying-jeou's May 20 inauguration, the previously frosty cross-strait relations have gradually thawed, with Taiwan easing restrictions on commercial exchanges, allowing weekend direct charter flights and opening up to more Chinese tourists.

Ma has proposed a modus vivendi approach in dealing with China and has proposed a "diplomatic truce" with Taiwan's cross-strait rival that he has argued would end the wasting of resources to lure each other's allies and find a way to let Taiwan have more space in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bacteria plentiful in men's shavers: Consumers' Foundation

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation urged men who shave to sterilize their electric shaver blades and razor blades regularly with a 70-percent ethanol solution because they accumulate bacteria at a rapid rate.

Hsieh Tien-jen, acting chairman of the foundation, on Thursday made public the findings of a random test of five razors and five electric shavers used by consumers aged 28-57 where the blades had been used an average of two months.
The total bacterial count in one of the blades was more than 100 million colony forming units (cfu), Hsieh said.

That was far higher than the 10,000 to 100,000 cfu of bacteria found on children's pool balls in a foundation survey in April and the 100,000 to 1 million cfu found on 12 NT$100 notes in a foundation survey in September, said foundation executive Yu Kei-hsiung.
Total bacterial count is an indicator of the hygienic condition of a sample and an estimate of the total number of bacteria in an object.
The blade with the high bacterial count had been used two to three times for the past two months and only cleaned with water, Hsieh said.

Tseng Hsin-lung, a dermatologist and member of the foundation, said manual razors can be cleaned easily, but given that they are usually placed in higher humidity restrooms, skin follicles and human lipids left in the blades cannot be removed thoroughly simply by rinsing them in water.
That leads to a bacterial buildup, Tseng said. He suggested using ethanol at a concentration of more than 70 percent to sterilize the blades.
He also advised those who cut or scrape their skins while shaving to disinfect the wounds and seek medical treatment to avoid the risk of developing an infection.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing should use Olympics to show political openness: DPP

TEXT.P: It's unfortunate to see China not using the opportunity of hosting the 2008 Olympic Games to demonstrate that it can be more politically open, instead maintaining tight control over activities calling for human rights and democracy, the spokesman for Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday.

Cheng Wen-tsang, the DPP's director of its Department of Culture and Information, said that with the Olympics set to formally open Friday, China is in the spotlight, with the world watching to see whether the communists would grow more open because of the international event.

Beijing, however, has still suppressed human rights and the freedom of the press, Cheng said, accusing the Chinese authorities of putting wiretaps on yellow cabs in Beijing while acting to control Internet reporting.

Worldwide political observers will also be looking to see whether the core problems concerning China's future development will be resolved after the end of the Beijing Olympics on Aug. 24, the spokesman added.
Cheng said there are many things worth seeing on the Olympic stage, including human rights activities, and urged Taiwan's media not merely to focus on individual sports events.

The DPP made its observations on China's political practices ahead of the opening of the world' biggest sporting competition, which attracts over 11,000 athletes from 205 countries and areas around the world to compete for 302 gold medals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Low-enrollment colleges urged to downsize, shut down

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) urged low- enrollment colleges Friday to consider reductions, mergers or shutdowns in the face of recruitment difficulties.

The ministry issued the call after the Joint Board of the College Recruitment Commission earlier Friday published a list of the freshmen recruited this year by every four-year university and college in the country.

A total of 105 departments at 22 colleges were unable to attract enough students, leaving 4,788 vacancies. That gap occurred despite this year's all- time college admission rate of 97.10 percent, the commission said.

Diwan College of Management and Hsing Kuo University, both in Tainan City, and Chiayi County's Toko University were noticeably unpopular among would-be college freshmen. Some departments run by these institutes did not attract a single applicant.

Ho Cho-fei, director of the MOE's Department of Higher Education, asked low- enrollment colleges to study the possibility of staff and department reductions, mergers with other schools, transforming unpopular programs or shutting down completely.
In the meantime, Ho emphasized that such schools should remain committed to giving their students sufficient training, no matter how small their enrollments.
The ministry will require low-enrollment schools to set a threshold for admission and graduation to maintain their students' basic performance.

According to the MOE official, some 125 college or university departments are considering merging with other departments or shutting down by the fall of 2009. Seventy-six college departments are slated to merge or close by September this year, and 103 merged or closed the previous year.
With the nation's birth rate still falling, the ministry is also mulling a reduction in the recruitment targets of some college departments, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP files treason charges against president

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) legislative caucus filed treason charges against President Ma Ying-jeou Friday over his decision to revpke the classification of documents allegedly implicating his predecessor in a "state affairs fund" embezzlement case.

Filing the charges with the Taipei District Court, caucus whip Ker Chien-ming accused Ma of engaging in a "hateful struggle" against former President Chen Shui-bian at the expense of national security and interests, an act which Ker said is totally unbecoming of a national leader.
"The disclosure of the documents in court proceedings will definitely impact national security, the country's secret diplomacy and even relations with diplomatic allies," Ker warned.

In response to the DPP's move, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi stressed President Ma's decision "can withstand public scrutiny" because the documents did not meet the criteria of confidentiality and should not have been classified in the first place.
At issue are files held by the Taipei District Court as evidence in the "state affairs fund" case, in which Chen was named as a co-defendant as soon as he stepped down from the presidency May 20.

The prosecution named Chen as a "joint perpetrator" while indicting his wife, Wu Shu-jen, on charges of corruption and forgery Nov. 3, 2006, after determining she had used receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.

Chen said that none of the money went into his own pocket, contending the confusing accounting system governing Presidential Office expenses made it necessary to use outside receipts to obtain money from the discretionary fund to finance secret diplomatic missions abroad.

However, the Taipei District Court ruled on Jan. 19, 2007 that the six diplomatic missions cited by the president as having been funded by the state affairs fund were not secret as the president claimed, and should be disclosed in court proceedings.
In September 2007, Chen proclaimed the files held by the court as "strictly confidential" and petitioned the court to return them to the Presidential Office.
After his request was turned down by the district court, Chen appealed to the Taiwan High Court and later to the Supreme Court, which has not ruled on the appeal.
The process has since stalled the district court proceedings on the embezzlement case.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County to build longest bicycle route in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Tainan County government plans to build a two-way bicycle route along a 39-km stretch of the No. 1 provincial highway to promote local tourism and bicycle use.

County government official Huang Chun-jung, who is in charge of the plan, told reporters Friday that the bicycle trails will be built at a cost of NT$190 million (US$6.1 million) along both sides of the No. 1 highway, and that the central government has already provided an initial budget of NT$63 million for the first stage of the project.
According to Huang, the bicycle route will link two railway stations in Tainan County -- Houbi in the north and Sinshih in the south -- and have a total length of 77.4km.

He said construction will begin by the end of this year, and that the county government is now applying for a second budget outlay of NT$50 million from the Ministry of the Interior to build rest stops, service stations, parking lots and leisure facilities along the paths.
Huang added that at least two Tainan-based firms -- Quintain Steel Co. and its subsidiary, Asahi Enterprise Corp. -- have expressed interest in operating bicycle maintenance shops along the paths.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Human rights take field in China.
On the cusp of the Summer Olympics, human rights moved into the spotlight Wednesday as critics attacked China for banning Darfur activists, President Bush expressed "deep concerns" about the government's harsh policies and U.S. Olympians selected a former Sudanese refugee to carry the Stars and Stripes in Friday's opening ceremony. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: Researchers film endemic bird's complete breeding

TEXT.P: National bird researchers have documented the complete breeding process of a bird subspecies endemic to Taiwan to enrich the country's wildlife database, a researcher told the Central News Agency Friday.

The video, which recorded the nesting, hatching and brooding of the "Vivid Niltava" subspecies in the southern county of Pingtung, will be a precious resource for bird lovers, said Tang Hsiao-yu, director of the Endemic Species Research Institute under the Council of Agriculture.

The middle-sized Vivid Niltava-- measuring about 15 to 16 centimeters in length -- resides in forests at elevations ranging from 1,000-2,500 meters and breeds from April to August every year, Tang said.

The subspecies, protected under the Wildlife Conservation Act, lays two to four eggs each time, with a hatching period of about two weeks and brooding time a little longer, Tang said, adding that the bird feeds babies with insects such as moths and butterflies or their larvas.

According to Tang, the male of the vivid Niltava subspecies found in Taiwan is deep purple blue on the head and back and bright orange below the throat and face, while the female is olive-brown overall and lighter below, with a light buffy throat and greyish brown crown and nape.

The video was made with a digital camera by a group of researchers at the institute's Medium Altitude Experimental Station in the southern county of Kaohsiung, who have conducted long-term field research on wild animals and plants.

The researchers have contributed much to establishing a database of the life history, distribution and inhabitation of bird species living in areas of medium altitudes, host to about 80 bird species, including eight endemic species and 38 endemic subspecies, Tang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: British crime lords rule G40 billion underworld
A G40 billion underworld economy is dominated by homegrown criminals, with at least 27 Mr Bigs running their empires from inside British jails, The Times has learnt.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Manila Bulletin: All eyes on Beijing
today
All eyes will be on Beijing, China, today as the XXIX Olympic Games begin with lavish opening ceremonies at 8 p.m. on this once-in-a-lifetime date of August 8, 2008, at the National Stadium, the iconic center of the games that has come to be known as the "Birds Nest."
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: North Cotabato folk told to defend selves
As time ticked on a 24-hour deadline for the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) to withdraw from occupied areas in North Cotabato province, local officials Thursday urged residents to defend themselves and vowed they would not allow them to besitting ducks.
The Philippine Star: Leave occupied towns in 24 hours, MILF told
The government has issued a 24-hour deadline for the Moro Islamic
Liberation Front (MILF) to move out its forces occupying several villages in North Cotabato.
The Manila Times: RP gives rebels ultimatum
The government on Thursday gave Muslim insurgents in Mindanao 24
hours to leave villages there that they supposedly are occupying illegally.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Toyota posts bleak results for quarter
Toyota Motor Corp. said Thursday it posted a 28.1 percent drop in group net profit for the April-June quarter as sales in North America, the biggest market for many Japanese carmakers, were hit hard by the U.S. economic slide.

DOC.HEADLINE: Man sentenced to four months for threatening Taipei mayor

TEXT.P: A man from the southern city of Kaohsiung has been sentenced to four months in prison for sending a letter of threat and two goat testicles to Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, which the Taipei District Court ruled as a crime Thursday.

The court said Chuang Shun-kui, who disapproved of Hau's implementation of a "two-step" process in Taipei for a referendum vote and the 7th legislative elections earlier this year, prompting him to send the letter and the testicles to Taipei City Hall in November 2007, with an intention to cause fears to Hau and his staff.
The penalty can be converted to a fine, and is subject to appeal.
Chuang denied that he was intended to threaten Hau, arguing that he was exercising his freedom of speech to protest the mayor's decision.
He further contended that as the testicles were edible, they should not cause fears to any one.
Hau himself testified about the fear triggered by the threat. However, he expressed his respect for Chuang's differing opinions and said he has no intention to press any charge against Chuang.
According to the court, Chuang expressed his discontent in an irrational way and showed no remorse for his actions, and thereby should be given a four months' imprisonment.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.220 to close at NT$31.090.
A total of US$2.512 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$30.915 and closed at the day's high of NT$31.220.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taroko Gorge Marathon to be run Nov. 1

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taroko Gorge Marathon, promoted as the world's only marathon held at a gorge in a mountainous area, will take place Nov. 1 at Taroko National Park in Hualien County, the event's organizer said Friday.

According to an executive of the Chinese Taipei Road Running Association, this year's event will limit the field to 10,000 runners to ensure the safety of each runner on the winding roads through the gorge known for its special topography.

Runners can sign up to participate in the full marathon of 42.195 kilometers to be finished within six hours, a half marathon of 21.0975 kilometers with a time limit of three hours, or a 5-kilometer run to be completed within one hour, the organizer said.
The winners of the full marathon and half marathon will win prizes of NT$80,000 (US$2,565) and NT$10,000 respectively, the organizer said.

Taiwan Power Co. and the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Bureau of Energy will use the opportunity to promote the country's energy saving policies to participants and their supporters at the venue, the executive added.
Those who are interested in the annual event can visit the organizer's Web site for further information. The deadline for entering the race is Sept. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Smart Card Corp. changes name to increase visibility

TEXT.P: Taipei Smart Card Corp. changed its name Friday to EasyCard Corp. to popularize the mass transit stored value card of the same name and expand its business, corporation officials said.
Company officials said 13.8 million Easy Cards had been issued to date to help consumers pay for transporation-relation services in Taipei City and Taipei County.

Through its huge popularity, the name "Easy Card" has gained higher recognition value than the company's moniker, compelling the firm to change its name to support its efforts to expand into Keelung, Yilan, Matsu and elsewhere.
The decision was made by the company's board so that consumers will easily identify it and its services at a glance of the name, the company said.

EasyCard Corp. was founded in March 2000, with the mission of integrating the ticketing system of buses, the mass rapid transit system, and parking lots, providing citizens with a convenient and seamless transportation environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Nation: Bot chief under fire Tarisa 'must step down'.
Suchat Tadatamrongvej, the new deputy finance minister, yesterday adked Tarisa Watanagase, the Bank of Thailand (BOT), to step aside following her unbending position on monetary policy.
Virabongsa Ramangkura,the newlyappointed chief economic adviser to the prime minister, is under fire as pressure mounts on him to resign from all his private-sector positions to avoid conflict of interest.
The Bangkok Post:US to keep pressure on Burma.
United States President George Bush yesterday vowed to continue exerting pressure on Burma's military regime.

DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Prisoner numbers at new low.
When plans were drawn up for a sprawling prison complex in the late 1990s, the authorities thought they might have 23,000 people behind bars beyond 2010.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Whole world focus Beijing tonight.
The Beijing Olympics Game Ceremony will be held at Chinese national stadium.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Beijing Olympic games to open, China challenges Bush.
China challenged rejected U.S. President George W. Bush's criticism over its human rights record by describing it as an interference in its internal affairs. Bush expressed his deep concerns over human rights before flying to Beijing for the inaugural ceremony of Olympic Games.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism on outlying island down in "ghost month"

TEXT.P: Tourism on the outlying Matsu Island has been declining since the start of this month, the beginning of "ghost month" on the lunar calendar, tourism officials said Friday.

Officials at the Matsu National Scenic Area Administration attributed the drop in tourism to fears related to "ghost month." Traditional-minded Taiwanese believe it's unsafe to travel during ghost month, which this year runs from Aug. 1 to Aug. 30.

Group tours accounted for the fall in business, while the numbers of individual travelers did not decrease noticeably, officials said. Most of the tourists visiting the outlying island are backpackers.
During the first half of this year, tourists made a total of 33,000 visits to Matsu, up by some 3,000 visits year on year.
Tourism on Matsu is expected to rebound in September and October -- the peak travel season on the remote island.

Matsu is situated in the Taiwan Strait, just off the coast of China. It has sought to transform itself into a tourist destination in recent years after its role as a military bastion has faded with the relaxation in cross-strait tensions.
Matsu is also the name of the Taoist goddess of the sea who protects fishermen and sailors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan high-tech giants earn record-high revenues in July

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) generated its highest-ever single-month consolidated revenue in July, while in the same month Taipei-based Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. Ltd., the world's largest contract electronics maker, generated its fourth-largest single-month unconsolidated revenue since its 1974 founding.

According to TSMC, the world's largest semiconductor foundry, its July consolidated revenue reached NT$31.81 billion (US$1.02 billion), recording a 7.9 percent rise from the previous month and year-on-year growth of 7.9 percent.
The firm's accumulated consolidated revenues in the first seven months amounted to NT$207.43 billion, registering growth of 22.5 percent compared with the same period in 2007.

Expecting a slowdown in market demand, TSMC executives estimated that the firm's third-quarter revenues this year will be between NT$90 billion and NT$92 billion. Accordingly, single-month consolidated revenue is expected to drop to between NT$29 billion and NT$30 billion in August and September, they said.
Meanwhile, Hon Hai Precision's July unconsolidated revenues reached NT$130.27 billion, posting growth of 21.2 percent from the previous month, or year-on-year growth of 34.93 percent.
Hon Hai spokesman Edmund Ding said that most of the products the firm sold in July were consumer electronics products.
The firms' accumulated revenues hit NT$745.67 billion in the first seven months this year, marking annual growth of 22.8 percent, Hon Hai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: After nearly year of hikes, gasoline prices set to fall

TEXT.P: State-run oil refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan, announced Friday that it will cut gasoline prices by NT$2 per liter and diesel prices by NT$2.2 per liter, effective at midnight, the first drop in fuel prices in Taiwan since last September.
After the adjustment, the prices of 92-octane, 95-octane and 98-octane unleaded gasoline will fall to NT$33.4 per liter, NT$34.1 per liter and NT$35.6 per liter.
The prices of premium diesel will be cut to NT$31.3 per liter, and that of super diesel will also fall to NT$31.3 per liter.

According to CPC, the adjustment was made based on a floating pricing mechanism that revises prices on a weekly basis based on fluctuations in the prices of Dubai and Brent crude oil as quoted on Platts, a leading global provider of energy information.

The mechanism had adjusted prices on a monthly basis in June and July, but CPC Corp. and the Ministry of Economic Affairs decided to change it to a weekly system to be more sensitive to changes in crude oil prices.

Meanwhile, the privately owned Formosa Petrochemical Co. (FPCC) decided the same day to follow CPC Corp.' lead and cut gasoline and diesel prices by NT$2 and NT$1.6 a liter, respectively, also effective midnight.

DOC.HEADLINE: Financial regulator seeking overseas firms to list in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The nation's top financial regulator expressed the hope Friday that it will attract 200 overseas firms to list in Taiwan in four years' time.

Taiwan's government wants to turn the country into an Asia-Pacific financial services, asset management, and capital-raising center, and recently relaxed restrictions on overseas firms listing publicly in Taiwan to help move closer to the goal.
One of the groups targeted to list are the overseas arms of companies already listed in Taiwan.

Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Gordon S. Chen said Friday there are currently around 600 such companies, but the foreign entities might still not meet the qualifications for listing in Taiwan.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange and over-the-counter GreTai Securities Market are now trying to learn more about their intention to return to Taiwan and go public, he said.
The commission will also soon propose other substantive measures to the Executive Yuan to realize the Asia Pacific financial center initiative, Chen said.

The FSC was established in 2004 to promote an integrated financial supervision system. The primary objectives of the commission are to consolidate the supervision of the banking, securities and insurance sectors, and to act as a single regulator for all of these industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Central Taiwan Information Technology Show begins

TEXT.P: The 2008 Central Taiwan Information Technology Show opened Friday at the Taichung World Trade Center for a five-day run, attracting large numbers of bargain hunters on the first day.
The annual event, held every summer, heavily targets students as potential buyers.
According to the Taipei Computer Association, the organizer of the event, some 100 IT-related companies are taking part in the show, occupying 300 booths.

They are providing a wide range of IT products, including all kinds of computers, peripheral products, software, digital cameras, music and multimedia players, and audio-visual home entertainment systems.
Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and City Council Speaker Chang Hung-nieh were among the guests of honor invited to speak at the opening ceremony.

The organizers thanked the mayor for his pledge to make Taichung Taiwan's first "wireless city" -- a plan supported by Yaw Jen Technology Co., which has promised to offer lifetime access to wireless broadband to every resident in Taichung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Earth-loving exhibit kicks off in Taipei

TEXT.P: Local environmental activists repeated their calls for the reduction of carbon dioxide emissions Friday as they kicked off an exhibition in Taipei.

The exhibition -- organized by Philips Taiwan, Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC), Eslite Bookstore and the Environmental Quality Protection Foundation -- focuses on energy-saving illumination, green transportation, green buildings and toxic-free clothing.

The exhibition, which will run through Aug. 24 at the bookstore's branch in the city's shopping district of Hsinyi, will inform visitors about environmental statistics and new information, the organizers said.
"Taiwan is the world's fourth-largest producer of carbon dioxide emissions," the organizers said, adding that the country should work harder to cut such pollutants.
The exhibition also showcases installation art to raise the public's eco- friendly awareness, the organizers said.

For example, the exhibition features two black carbon balls, one 330cm in diameter and the other 30cm, the organizers noted. The two balls are designed to show a stark difference between emissions generated by vehicles and that of the country's high-speed rail, the organizers explained.

The high-speed rail has seen 33 million visits from local residents over the past 18 months, which has helped reduce some 53 tons of carbon dioxide emissions, said Ted Chia, vice president of the company's public affairs division.
It would take more than 14 million trees to offset the reduced amount, Chia said.
Another piece of installation art features a small piece of grass with several cotton-made clothes on top and bottles of toxic pesticide underneath, the organizers said.
The organizers noted that cotton fields account for less than 3 percent of the world's cultivated land, but use excessive amounts of pesticide.
Yeh Shin-cheng, a board member of the foundation, said that one pork chop meal box, a common food in Taiwan, causes some 480g of carbon dioxide emissions.
Yeh called for a simple diet, which he said would also be good for the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitung magistrate listed as defendant in graft case

TEXT.P: Taitung Magistrate Kuang Li-chen, along with her secretary and 13 county government officials, was listed Thursday as a defendant subject to further investigation over suspected irregularities related to a just-concluded trip she made to Europe, according to the local prosecutors office.

Prosecutors said they intend to further investigate whether she squandered public funds or gave taxpayers' money to her grassroots campaign operatives and are seeking a sentence of at least 10 years if she is found guilty of graft.
Kuang was released Tuesday after being questioned by prosecutors for more than four hours over the suspected irregularities regarding her Europe trip.

Kuang, accompanied by the 13 county government officials and township chiefs, returned to Taipei Monday morning from her visits to several European countries, ostensibly to observe and study their tourism promotion measures.

Kuang came under fire after taking the officials on the trip in late July even though she knew that Typhoon Fung Wong was approaching the island. She has also been criticized for spending millions of dollars of taxpayers' money on frequent overseas trips since taking office as Taitung magistrate two years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mayors' trips abroad have positive value: Hsinchu mayor

TEXT.P: Trips overseas by mayors and county magistrates have a positive value if they are beneficial to their administrative districts and do not affect the promotion of the local government's policies, said Hsinchu City Mayor Lin Junq-tzer Friday.

Lin cited his participation in the fifth World Technopolis Association Techno- Mart held in Dubai as an example of a trip with value. The flags of Taiwan and Hsinchu were hung in the Techno-Mart exhibition hall, and Hsinchu was introduced as one of the members in the show brochure for the first time.

He also noted Hsinchu's famous rice noodles and traditional glass industry became recognized and marketed in Japan after he introduced the origins and development of the two products during a trip to Japan.

Lin was recently ranked as the local leader with the highest support among Taiwan's 25 counties and cities in a survey on competitiveness conducted by the Global Views Magazine, which he said resulted in part from his valuing people's opinions and being attentive to their needs.
Besides paving roads, communicating, and setting up street lamps, he has also built bridges and built new roadways, Lin said.

Lin said the unemployment rate in Hsinchu had dropped from 5.3 percent when he took over as Hsinchu mayor in 2006 to the current 3.8 percent as a result of holding six annual employment fairs and requesting companies in the Hsinchu Science Park to offer jobs to local residents.
His principles for promoting administrative policies are absolute respect and effective communicating, said Lin, and he values the opinions of city councilors who represent the city's residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City opens 8th foreign spouse service center

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City's Bureau of Social Affairs opened its eighth foreign spouse service center Friday to offer more help to foreign husbands and wives of local citizens in many areas of their daily lives.

Huang Chao-huan, deputy chief of the Bureau of Social Affairs, presided over the opening of the service center, located in a children's day care center in a local residential community in Cianjhen district.

The Kaohsiung city government began establishing service centers for foreign spouses in seven districts beginning in 2006, with the goal of offering then more comprehensive services, bureau officials said.
In addition to serving as locations for social gatherings, the officials said, the centers offer cultural courses, professional training, and free consultations on family relationships.

Due to an increasingly growing number of new immigrants in the southern Taiwan port city, the city government has been paying greater attention to the welfare of foreign husbands and wives, bureau officials said.
The municipal authorities also encouraged foreign spouses to use these service centers to explore their own social relations and build a backup network through new friendships.
As of the end of July this year, there were a total of 11,693 Chinese spouses and another 7,645 husbands and wives from other foreign countries in the city, municipal statistics showed.
In Cianjhen district, there were 1,676 Chinese spouses and 1,366 husbands and wives from other countries.
Kaohsiung is Taiwan's second-largest city next to Taipei City in the north.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan medical team to offer free treatment in Central America

TEXT.P: A medical team of the Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps, a nongovernmental charity group, left for Central America via Los Angeles Friday to provide free treatment to patients in Panama, Nicaragua and Honduras.
The team, consisting of 27 volunteer medical doctors, dentists, pharmacists, technologists and nurses, was headed by Liu Chi-chun, president of the organization.
Five more Taiwanese doctors from North America will join the team in Panama to participate in the charitable services.
The team brought nearly 1,000 kilograms of medical equipment and supplies. It is scheduled to return to Taiwan Aug. 24.

The Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps, founded in 1995, is a private, non- sectarian, and nonprofit organization dedicated to improving the quality of life in Taiwan and abroad by providing free medical services and health education.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan team makes way into Olympics without incident

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Olympic team drew a rousing ovation as it entered the Beijing Olympic Stadium Friday in the opening ceremony of the 29th Olympiad.

Led by flag-bearer Lai Sheng-jung, the captain of the women's softball team who has competed internationally for Taiwan since 1999, Taiwan was the 24th country to enter the Bird's Nest based on the stroke count in the first character of its name in Chinese, "Zhonghua Taibei."

While opposition forces in Taiwan had warned that Beijing would try maneuvers to belittle or embarrass Taiwan, including calling the team "Zhongguo Taipei, " meaning "Taipei, China, " when it was introduced to the huge crowd, the team's entry went off without incident.
A total of 66 athletes and officials joined the Taiwan delegation out of a total of 137 (80 athletes and 57 officials and coaches) expected to participate in the Olympics.
Taiwan's baseball and taekwondo teams were among those who are still training in Taiwan and have yet to depart for China.

When introducing the team, the public address system announcer introduced Taiwan as being strong in taekwondo, weightlifting and archery, and noted that it had its best performance in an Olympics in 2004 when it won two golds, two silvers and a bronze.
Taiwan's athletes were cheered on as they entered the stadium by a fist-pumping Kuomintang Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, People First Party Chairman James Soong, and KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Poultry association first to register to lobby lawmakers

TEXT.P: The Poultry Association became the first interest group to register after the Lobbying Act went into effect Friday.
Lu Yun-tian and Chen Kuo-tsun, who represent the association, registered with the Legislative Yuan to lobby against a proposed amendment of a poultry legislation.

Under the new act, lobbyists must register with the institution they want to approach and indicate the topic of discussion. After their meetings, they are also required to report how much they spent on their efforts.

Acted in accordance with the law, Lu and Chen registered their names and the person they wanted to lobby -- Legislator Huang Wei-cher of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in this case.

Lu also put his estimated expenses at NT$100,000 (US$3,278) to lobby against the proposed amendment of a poultry law which limit the validity of a poultry farm's registration certificate to five years, at which time it would have to apply for a new one.
Lu argued that this would undermine the interests of the poultry farm operator.

Lu touted the law as a "positive" step. In contrast with past practices when lobbyists had to meet with legislators or administrative agencies privately to discuss issues and problems, he said the law makes the lobbying process "open and transparent."
But several civic groups criticized the new law and urged that it be revised.
DPP Legislator Huang Sue-ying noted that profit-oriented groups are not as trustworthy as nonprofits but are not subject to more rigorous regulations under the new law.

Judicial Reform Foundation Executive Director Lin Feng-cheng said that the lobbyists must register first and begin the lobbying after being approved, and they have to file for financial expenses after concluding the lobbying, a process he termed as "tediously complicated."
But he said that for the rich and powerful, such as big conglomerates, they might reach a tacit agreement with the lawmakers circumventing the registration process.
Taiwan Women's Link director Lin Lu-hung said civic groups should help each other, but the Lobbying Act stipulates that a group should only lobby on matters that are related to its operations.
Lin said that if a women's group wants to lobby on tax issues, it will not be able to register, which she said is in effect a boycott of inter-civic group alliances.

Under the new law, those who can be lobbied include the president, the vice president, elected officials at various levels, chiefs and deputies of city and county governments and village, township and city offices, as well as those who are covered by the Statute Governing the Retirement and Consolation Payment to Political Appointee.
The total number in all categories is over 5,800. At the same time, 740 of their governing agencies will also be covered by the new law.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI pondering having lawmakers' aides covered in Lobbying Act

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will consider whether elected officials' aides, particularly legislators' assistants, should be subject to the restrictions of the newly enacted Lobbying Act, the ministry said in a statement Friday.

The Lobbying Act, which cleared the legislative floor in July 2007 and took effect Aug. 8 this year, requires people who lobby elected and appointed government officials at national and local levels to register their visits and list their activities.
The law drew criticism even before taking effect because of potential flaws and loopholes, including the failure to include lawmakers' aides among those who lobbyists must register to visit.

The MOI said in its statement that the ministry will refer to the U.S. lobbying law in deciding whether to include lawmakers' aides in the act when it drafts an amendment bill to perfect or update its provisions in line with the principles of substantiating the "sunshine law" spirit and establishing clean politics and good governance.

The statement further said the ministry welcomes local citizens to express their opinions about improving the new act and has posted a form for people to express their views on its Web site at www.moi.gov.tw/lobby/.
Taiwan is the third country after the United States and Canada to enact a lobbying law.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 9, 2008

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Opening of an international seminar on Taiwan's security situation since the inauguration of Taiwan's new government. Date and Time: 09:30 a.m., Saturday, Aug. 9, 2008. DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 9, or the ninth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1794: General Napoleon Bonaparte is arrested in France on suspicions of Robespierrism.
1814: Under the terms of the Treaty of Fort Jackson signed between the U.S. government and the native Creek tribe, the Creeks lose 9.3 million hectares of land -- over half of Alabama and part of southern Georgia -- to the United States.
1842: The United States signs the Webster-Ashburton Treaty with Britain, establishing the boundary between the U.S. and Canada from Maine to the Great Lakes.
1867: John Harrison Surratt is arrested for being an alleged conspirator in the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln.
1902: Edward VII, 64, is crowned King of Great Britain and Ireland after a six- week delay due to an emergency appendectomy.
1903: Giuseppe Sarto becomes Pope Pius X following the death of Pope Leo XIII.
1919: India concludes a secret pact with Britain, recognizing Britain as India's protector after Britain promised India a major role in its own government.
1928: Italian divers find precious diamonds in the wreckage of "Elizabethville," a Belgian ship sunk during World War I.
1937: Japanese troops clash with Chinese forces at Hungchiao airport in Shanghai.
1938: Rod Laver, Australian tennis star, is born. He won the singles title at Wimbledon four times.
1942: Mohandas K. Gandhi, leader of the Indian National Congress, is arrested in Britain for his "Quit India" campaign, which demands that the British should withdraw from India.
1945: Soviet troops enter Manchuria after the Soviet Union declares war on Japan.
1946: Henry Pu Yi, who was enthroned as the "Emperor of Manchukuo" in Changchun by Japanese militarists on Mar. 1, 1934, arrives in Tokyo to testify before an international court against Japanese war crimes committed during the invasion of China.
1954: The Republic of China Navy sinks 12 Communist Chinese ships at Tungshan seaport, Dongshan Island, near Fukien province.
1965: Singapore is separated from Malaysia and becomes an independent state within the Commonwealth of Nations.
1973: Ku Cheng-kang, honorary chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, leaves for Washington to attend a WACL Executive Committee meeting.
1974: Gerald R. Ford is sworn in as the 38th president of the United States after the resignation of Richard Nixon.
1979: Councilors in the English seaside town of Brighton cause a furor by agreeing to allow naturalists to bare all on "Cliff Beach," one of the less popular beaches in the district.
1990: Communist China's first airship, with a length of 40 meters, makes its maiden flight over Hupei province.
1994: The U.S. government announces trade sanctions against the ROC under the Pelly Amendment, placing a ban on imports of Taiwan wildlife products effective from August 19, 1994.
1999: The China External Trade Development Council signs a memorandum of understanding on technological cooperation with the Agency for International Development of Technology and Trade under the Trade and Industry Ministry of France.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui says the main reason he voiced the "special state- to-state relations" statement regarding cross-Taiwan Strait ties the previous month was to elucidate the fact that the Republic of China exists in the world.
2000: The Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association is established to promote Taiwan's trade and cooperation with the international community.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to gain confidence for one's authority. If a man is not trusted by one's friends, he will not gain the confidence for his authority."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan team makes way into Olympics without incident

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Olympic team drew a rousing ovation as it entered the Beijing Olympic Stadium Friday in the opening ceremony of the 29th Olympiad.

Led by flag-bearer Lai Sheng-jung, the captain of the women's softball team who has competed internationally for Taiwan since 1999, Taiwan was the 24th country to enter the Bird's Nest based on the stroke count in the first character of its name in Chinese, "Zhonghua Taibei."

While opposition forces in Taiwan had warned that Beijing would try maneuvers to belittle or embarrass Taiwan, including calling the team "Zhongguo Taipei, " meaning "Taipei, China, " when it was introduced to the huge crowd, the team's entry went off without incident.
A total of 66 athletes and officials joined the Taiwan delegation out of a total of 137 (80 athletes and 57 officials and coaches) expected to participate in the Olympics.
Taiwan's baseball and taekwondo teams were among those who are still training in Taiwan and have yet to depart for China.

When introducing the team, the public address system announcer introduced Taiwan as being strong in taekwondo, weightlifting and archery, and noted that it had its best performance in an Olympics in 2004 when it won two golds, two silvers and a bronze.
Taiwan's athletes were cheered on as they entered the stadium by a fist-pumping Kuomintang Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, People First Party Chairman James Soong, and KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan medical team to offer free treatment in Central America

TEXT.P: A medical team of the Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps, a nongovernmental charity group, left for Central America via Los Angeles Friday to provide free treatment to patients in Panama, Nicaragua and Honduras.
The team, consisting of 27 volunteer medical doctors, dentists, pharmacists, technologists and nurses, was headed by Liu Chi-chun, president of the organization.
Five more Taiwanese doctors from North America will join the team in Panama to participate in the charitable services.
The team brought nearly 1,000 kilograms of medical equipment and supplies. It is scheduled to return to Taiwan Aug. 24.

The Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps, founded in 1995, is a private, non- sectarian, and nonprofit organization dedicated to improving the quality of life in Taiwan and abroad by providing free medical services and health education.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City opens 8th foreign spouse service center

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City's Bureau of Social Affairs opened its eighth foreign spouse service center Friday to offer more help to foreign husbands and wives of local citizens in many areas of their daily lives.

Huang Chao-huan, deputy chief of the Bureau of Social Affairs, presided over the opening of the service center, located in a children's day care center in a local residential community in Cianjhen district.

The Kaohsiung city government began establishing service centers for foreign spouses in seven districts beginning in 2006, with the goal of offering then more comprehensive services, bureau officials said.
In addition to serving as locations for social gatherings, the officials said, the centers offer cultural courses, professional training, and free consultations on family relationships.

Due to an increasingly growing number of new immigrants in the southern Taiwan port city, the city government has been paying greater attention to the welfare of foreign husbands and wives, bureau officials said.
The municipal authorities also encouraged foreign spouses to use these service centers to explore their own social relations and build a backup network through new friendships.
As of the end of July this year, there were a total of 11,693 Chinese spouses and another 7,645 husbands and wives from other foreign countries in the city, municipal statistics showed.
In Cianjhen district, there were 1,676 Chinese spouses and 1,366 husbands and wives from other countries.
Kaohsiung is Taiwan's second-largest city next to Taipei City in the north.
