DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu County housing market records strong growth

TEXT.P: The housing turnover in Hsinchu County posted a strong year-on-year growth of more that 30 percent in the first half of 2008, despite a slowdown in Taiwan's overall housing market, making the county the country's top performer in this regard, according to statistics released Saturday by the Ministry of the Interior.

During the first six months of this year, the number of housing transactions around Taiwan dropped 2 percent year-on-year to 211,011, with 14 out of the 23 counties and cities islandwide experiencing negative growth compared with the same period of last year, the statistics show.

Among the nine counties and cities that saw housing transactions increase, Hsinchu County topped the list with growth of more than 30 percent, followed by Taipei City, which recorded a rise of 9.1 percent.

Chang Hsin-min, a marketing consultant with Era Real Estate, Taiwan, noted that in the past, Hsinchu County was not an important local housing market in Taiwan, recording only 2,000-3,000 transactions per year and lagging far behind neighboring Hsinchu City.

However, housing transactions in Hsinchu County have exceeded that of Hsinchu City since 2004, following the development of areas surrounding the Hsinchu county government headquarters in Jhubei and the construction of the high-speed rail system that includes a stop in Jhubei, Chang said.

With the launch of the rail system in 2007 significantly shortening the travel time to Taipei City and Taichung City, where housing prices are higher, many workers in hi-tech companies in the Hsinchu Science Park in Hsinchu City have opted to reside in Jhubei, he pointed out.

He predicted that housing transactions will remain brisk in Hsinchu County in the second half of this year, with the transaction volume for 2008 likely to surpass the 13,516 cases recorded in 2005 to hit a record high.

DOC.HEADLINE: Olympic Preview: Tennis players get tough draws

TEXT.P: Taiwan's "golden doubles duo" may have felt slighted at not being made the top seeds in the Olympic women's doubles event Thursday, but they have a tough road ahead to prove they actually deserved the top slot in the tournament.

None of Taiwan's tennis Olympians got kind draws in the three Beijing Games tournaments in which they are entered, not even the highly regarded doubles team of Chan Yung-jan and Chuang Chia-jung, seen as Taiwan's best hope of winning its first ever Olympic tennis medal.
Local media had widely speculated the duo would be seeded first in Beijing based on having the highest doubles rankings of any team entered in the 32-team Olympic event.
But when the draw was made Thursday, Chan and Chuang were made the third seeds, and some local media speculated -- without any substantiation -- that pressure from China was behind the change.
Not so, says the International Tennis Federation, which set the regulations for the event and was responsible for the method of seeding.

"The Olympic tennis event is unique in that many players play both singles and doubles, " said Neil Robinson, a spokesman for the federation, in an e-mail. "It was therefore decided that for the doubles event in Beijing, a player's best ranking of singles and doubles would be taken and that this would be added to the partner's best ranking for seeding."
The system was actually more targeted at the men's doubles than the women's, with top singles players like Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, and Novak Djokovic entered in the event.

The three, who rarely play doubles on the ATP Tour and have doubles rankings outside the top 100, would have been unseeded without help from their singles rankings. The revised system ensures that none of them will play each other in the early rounds of the doubles.
In the women's event, Chan and Chuang were seeded third, behind Svetlana Kuznetsova and Dinara Safina of Russia and Serena and Venus Williams of the United States.
"The lower seeding will only motivate us to have a fiercer desire to win, " Chan said, while Chuang, after getting over her surprise, saw it as an advantage.
"I really didn't care if we were the number one seeds. Now the pressure won't be on us," Chuang told local media.

But aside from what should be a relatively easy opening match against Alize Cornet and Virginie Razzano of France, neither of whom are ranked in the top 100 in doubles, Chan and Chuang face traps elsewhere in the draw.

If they can get by their second round match against either Alicia Molik and Casey Dellacqua of Australia or the gritty Italian duo of Francesca Schiavone and Flavia Pennetta in the second round, all of whom are accomplished doubles players, they will likely have to face the sixth-seeded Australian Open doubles champions Kateryna and Alona Bondarenko.

And that's the easy part, because in the semifinals, Chan and Chuang will likely come up against Venus and Serena Williams (if Serena's knee stays healthy), who won the Wimbledon doubles crown losing no more than four games in any one set.
In singles, Chan and Taiwan's top men's player Lu Yen-hsun both got difficult draws.

Lu drew 6th-seeded Andy Murray of the United Kingdom in the opening round of the 64-player men's singles tourney, while Chan Yung-jan drew eighth-seeded Agnieszka Radwanska of Poland in the first round of the women's event.

Lu, who had hoped to improve on his first round defeat to Finland's Jarkko Nieminen in the 2004 Athens Games, will have a tough time with Murray, one of the hottest players on tour after winning the ATP Masters Series event in Cincinnati.
"He's one of those players who you can never put away. He competes hard and attacks well, so I'm going to have be a little patient against him," Lu told local media.
Chan is scheduled to play her first round singles match Sunday afternoon, while Lu and the women's doubles team are expected to play their first matches on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Weightlifter Chen Wei-ling wins Taiwan's first medal in Beijing
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 10 (CNA) 08/09/08 14:51:37 (By Chris Wang and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei's Chen Wei-ling won a bronze medal Saturday in the women's 48-kg weightlifting competition at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, picking up Taiwan's first medal of the games.
Chen lifted 84 kg in the snatch event before moving on to lift 112 kg in the clean and jerk event for a total score of 196 kg.
China's Chen Xiexia grabbed the gold medal with a combined lift of 212 kg, a new Olympic record, while Sibel Ozkan of Turkey won silver with a combined lift of 210 kg.

South Korea's Im Jyounghwa also lifted a combined 196 kg, but the Taiwanese weightlifter was awarded the medal in a tie-breaker based on body weight. Chen Wei-ling weighed in at 47.11 kg, slightly lighter than Im's 47.62 kg.

The bronze medal performance marked a significant improvement for Chen over her 11th place finish in the 2004 Athens Olympics when she finished the 48-kg women's competition with a combined lift of 170 kg.

DOC.HEADLINE: Few enterprises choose personnel on school graduation: survey

TEXT.P: Only 5.1 percent of enterprises that responded to a recent poll recruit personnel according to the schools from which they graduated, according to a press statement released by the survey conductor Saturday.
The survey was conducted April 23-28 by the 104 Job Bank, an online job search engine, on enterprises providing job openings on its Web site, with 1,562 valid samples obtained, the statement said.

The five factors enterprises said they were most concerned about in personnel recruitment are job seekers' majors or minors, accounting for 52 percent, active work attitude, 51.8 percent, willingness to learn, 36.7 percent, responsibility, 30.4 percent, and passion for the job, 24.5 percent.
The schools from which job seekers graduated ranked only 12th in order of importance, according to the statement.

Even though some enterprises prefer to hire people who graduate from certain schools, this preference is not their only concern, and whether job seekers' professionalism meets the requirement of the hirer is more crucial in deciding whether to offer the applicant a job, according to the statement.
The job bank encourages college students to seek work-study or intern opportunities during their college life in order to raise their competitiveness in the job market, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP lauds creativity of Beijing Olympics opening show

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew praised the dazzling performances in the Friday opening of the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing for featuring many brilliant innovative and creative ideas borrowed from Chinese culture, and he expressed hope that Taiwanese businesses can learn from the creativity displayed at the opening ceremony.
Siew made the comments Saturday during a visit to Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan.

At a meeting with residents of Tainan County, also in southern Taiwan, the vice president pointed out that there are new industrial sectors forming and emerging in Taiwan and that many of them are involved in "cultural innovation, " such as the magnificent fireworks show at the Olympics opening ceremony.

Many Taiwanese businesses were involved in putting together the show, Siew noted, suggesting that other local businesses should follow the trend set by the opening ceremony, taking advantage of Taiwan's traditional culture in industrial and commercial operations.
Addressing Taiwan's future economic development, Siew reiterated that Taiwan, an island nation with no abundant natural resources, cannot afford to waste any resources it has.
Therefore, he went on, Taiwan must make efforts to boost the development of the industrial sectors devoted to energy-saving and carbon-cutting, as well as medicine and biotechnology.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA to decide on residence for Chinese pandas next week

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will review next week two applications to house a pair of pandas China has promised to offer to Taiwan, an official of the Forestry Bureau under the council said Saturday.

According to Fang Guo-yun, chief of the department of nature conservation of the Forestry Bureau, a panel will be established Aug. 14 to review the submissions of the two applicants, the Taipei Zoo in the capital and the Leofoo Safari Zoo located in Hsinchu County, northern Taiwan.

The Leofoo Safari Zoo has expressed determination to house the pandas and recently signed an agreement with the China-based Chengdu Research Base of Giant Panda Breeding in order to exchange information, experiences and ideas on conservation, according to the zoo.
Even Taichung City in central Taiwan has shown interest in housing the two pandas, although it did not file application with the COA, said Fang.
"The key points of the review will include the training of the animals' keepers and veterinarians, as well as the facilities of the places where the pandas will be kept, " Fang noted.
The two pandas, aged about four, were offered by China as gift to Taiwan after a visit by then-Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan in 2005.
The offer was rejected by the COA under the previous Democratic Progressive Party government as Taiwan did not have adequate conditions to raise the endangered animals.
The issue was brought back to the front burner after President Ma Ying-jeou was elected in March and said he would be pleased to see the pandas to come to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Film about Atayal shows Taiwan's aboriginal cultures to the world

TEXT.P: A documentary about Taiwan's Atayal tribe, which won an award at an American film festival earlier this year, has presented Taiwan's aboriginal cultures to the world, a Ministry of the Interior official said Saturday.
The official made the remarks to mark the world's Aug. 9 celebration of the International Day of the World's Indigenous Peoples, designated by the United Nations in 1994.

The film, titled "A Thousand Years of the Atayal" won the Platinum Award, the highest prize, at the 41st WorldFest Houston International Film Festival in the culture category in late April, the official said.

The Atayal is one of Taiwan's 14 aboriginal tribes to have received official recognition. Its culture includes facial tattooing, the inheritance of a father's first name as the son's last name, weaving and a united community typically occupying a single valley or flood plain.
The documentary revolves around the life of an Atayal man called Yukan who lives in the city and decides to return to an Atayal village to find out his identity.

Directed by Chen Wen-pin, the film was sponsored by the administrative center of Sheipa National Park, home to many Atayal tribal communities, the official involved in the management of the country's national parks said.
Atayal people not only were filmed but also contributed to discussions and production of the film, the official said.

They also constructed an ancient Atayal village for the film's setting, he went on, adding that the shooting site in the northern county of Hsinchu will be turned into a public cultural treasure for the tribe.

The film was also selected as Best Film at the New Beijing International Movie Week held in June and will be screened at the Moscow International Visual Anthropology Festival in October, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT chairman visits Beijing athletes' village
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 9 (CNA) 08/09/08 17:13:10 (By Wu Hsieh-chang and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung visited the Beijing Athletes' Village Saturday to cheer the Chinese Taipei delegation and present the members with an additional NT$200,000 (US$6,396) in spending money.
Wu Poh-hsiung was accompanied by Legislative Yuan Deputy Speaker Tseng Yung- chuan, KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih and other top officials.

Wu Poh-hsiung said the Chinese Taipei athletes' participation in the games will not lead to a downgrading of Taiwan's status, in clear reference to recent claims by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party that Beijing has been attempting to do just that through various means, such as insisting on the use of simplified characters, which are used in China rather than the traditional characters used in Taiwan, on the Chinese Taipei delegation's sign in the Olympic opening ceremony.

Wu expressed hope that the Taiwanese athletes will perform outstandingly at the games, adding that the recent birth of Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee Chairman Tsai Chen-wei's grandson should help bring the team luck.
Tsai, along with Sports Affairs Council Minister Tai Hsia-ling and Chinese Taipei Olympic delegation leader Tsai Szu-chueh, were on hand to receive Wu upon his arrival in the village.

After presenting the NT$200,000 to the delegation, Wu talked about the Chinese Taipei baseball team's first game of the Olympics against the Netherlands slated for Aug. 13, saying that China-based Taiwanese businessmen have mobilized a "Taiwanese cheerleading squad" by buying up most of the tickets for the game.
This, coupled with the Chinese spectators' support for the Taiwanese squad, means that the team will have a virtual "home field advantage" for the game, according to Wu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public supports president's decision to declassify documents: KMT

TEXT.P: The deputy whip of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus predicted Saturday that the public will judge President Ma Ying-jeou fairly for his decision to revoke classification of documents related to former President Chen Shui-bian's state affairs fund case.

Wu Yu-sheng made the comments at a news conference held one day after lawmakers of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) sued Ma for treason for declassifying information Chen had deemed national secrets while he was president.

The documents are being held by the Taipei District Court as evidence in a corruption and forgery scandal in which Chen has been named a "joint perpetrator" and his wife has been indicted for using receipts provided by others to claim a total of NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the president's discretionary state affairs fund.

Wu said at Saturday's press conference that the public and even elements within the DPP support Ma's decision to declassify the documents, claiming that some opposition lawmakers have said privately that the matter will allow the party to finally separate itself from the former president and let new DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen move the party forward.
The deputy whip added that if the DPP continues to protect what he described as "the corrupt former president, " this will only hurt the party in future elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition leader against `diplomatic truce'

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen expressed strong disapproval Saturday of President Ma Ying-jeou's foreign policy advocacy of a "diplomatic truce" with China, saying the idea is tantamount to a "unilateral surrender of arms" on Taiwan's part.

According to Tsai, Taiwan's isolation in the international arena is the result of China's suppression and as the nation's leader, Ma should find a way to safeguard Taiwan's international status and highlight the unreasonableness of China's suppression.

"Instead, the new government is trying to negotiate with the country's persecutor and to offer: `I won't struggle. Don't hit me,'" Tsai said, referring to the "modus vivendi" approach put forth by Ma for dealing with China.

The former vice premier and former chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council made the remarks while addressing the opening of a conference on Taiwan's security situation since the May 20 inauguration of the Kuomintang (KMT) government. The event was organized by the Institute for Taiwan Defense and Strategic Studies.

Tsai claimed that although the new government has only been in operation for less than 100 days, its national security policy is causing "worry, distrust and unease" among the people and is leading Taiwan toward a "dangerous state."
She accused the KMT government of being "narrow-minded" by believing that all the problems currently faced by Taiwan will be solved as long as relations with China improve.

As such a security policy must rely on Beijing's goodwill in order to be successful, the government has already started making various concessions before China has even offered its terms and conditions, Tsai said.

Besides the "diplomatic truce, " what Tsai described as the KMT administration's "reckless" liberalization policy toward cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade activities and the way it is dealing with the reported suspension of arms procurements from the United States are two other examples of such concessions, she said.
According to Tsai, the KMT, which blocked and delayed the arms procurement when it was in the opposition, has adopted an "ambiguous" attitude toward the procurement after coming to power.

This ambiguous approach is demonstrated by the fact that the KMT administration has not taken any effective measures to push the United States to approve the sales rapidly, despite reports and speculation that the administration of President George W. Bush has frozen arms sales to Taiwan to avoid upsetting relations with China, Tsai said.

Asked by the media to comment on KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung's current visit to China to attend the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games in Beijing, Tsai said that as the leader of the ruling party, Wu should be extra cautious about his behavior so as not to give the public the impression that "Taiwan is part of China."

Tsai was referring to a statement made by Wu Thursday in Beijing that the Chinese Taipei baseball team enjoys a "home field advantage" in the Beijing Olympic Games. She said it was regrettable and disappointing that the KMT leader would make such a remark, which she claimed seriously undermines Taiwan's status as a sovereign state independent of China.
In fact, Wu's remark was a reference to the fact that many of the tickets to the Chinese Taipei game against the Netherlands have been purchased by Taiwanese businessmen operating in China.

Tsai also expressed displeasure at a recent statement by Chinese President Hu Jintao that "Taiwan stands great chances of winning medals as one of the home teams, " saying that the statement demonstrates China's insincerity toward Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Ghost' most popular key word on local Yahoo! search in ghost month

TEXT.P: Since the beginning of this month -- the seventh month on the lunar calendar or Ghost month in Chinese society -- the word "ghost" has become one of the most frequently used keywords on the Yahoo! Taiwan search Web site, the Yahoo! /Kimo search engine.

In the latest Yahoo! /Kimo keyword ranking, the Chinese-language phrase "Top 10 Taboos in Ghost Month" ranked second most popular, while many Yahoo! /Kimo surfers were eager to learn more about the most frightening month of the year.
The volume of ghost month-related information and knowledge has accumulated to 3,576 items on the "knowledge +" page of the Yahoo!/Kimo search engine, according to Yahoo!/Kimo statistics.

The statistics on key words for data acquisition between July 28 and Aug. show that the most-used key words were "ghost month," "ghost taboos, " "birth in ghost month, " "hotel packages in ghost month, " "the history of ghost month, " "religious ceremonies in ghost month," "moving home in ghost month, " "buying cars in ghost month" and "songs banned in ghost month," in that order.

The information shows that surfers were keen to find out whether bad things will happen to people who give birth, conduct house renovations, take trips, enjoy water activities, buy real estate or get their hair cut during the month.

Ghost month this year began on Aug. 1 according to the Gregorian calendar. In folk religion, it is the only time in the year when the doors of the hell are opened to allow ghosts to enter the world of mortals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing Olympics total shame, human rights disaster: activists

TEXT.P: Activists who were banned from entering Hong Kong Aug. 6 to take part in a protest rally on the eve of the Olympic opening ceremony, said Saturday in Taipei that the Beijing Olympics is a total shame and a human rights disaster, as the Chinese authorities not only continue to violate human rights but also treat each and every one of its people as the enemy.

Chinese Canadian democracy activist Sheng Xue, international vice-president of the Federation for a Democratic China, was detained along with well-known Chinese activist Yan Jianli when they arrived at Hong Kong airport Aug. 6.
Sheng diverted to Taiwan, while Yang, a Chinese citizen with a U.S. green card, was deported under escort back to New York via Tokyo before Taiwan agreed to permit him entry.

"This Olympics is `One World, One Nightmare' and an endless human rights disaster, " Sheng Xue said angrily in a forum titled "Observation of the Beijing Olympics and Human Rights in China" held by the Taiwan Society North, a pro- independence non-government organization.
She contended that the fact they were banned from entering Hong Kong serves as clear evidence that Hong Kong is becoming China and has submitted all its authority to a central government.
"The Beijing Olympics is full of worry and fear, as the totalitarian Chinese authorities are treating the people like the enemy," Sheng said.

"The world, especially those live in a democratic and free country, should not be blinded by the rosy picture of the Beijing Olympics but should see through the veil and find out what the real society is like -- with people deprived of their basic rights and freedoms," she added.

Dawa Tsering, president of the Taipei-based non-government Tibet Religious Foundation of the Dalai Lama, said that during the Olympics, the Chinese government has beefed up its control over Tibet, declaring that street assemblies of more than four people are illegal.
"This is typical of how colonists treat the colonized, " Dawa said.

Chinese American Wang Min, who also decided to come to Taiwan Aug. 6 after he was denied entry to Hong Kong, said that China might have all the hardware to demonstrate to the world its rising economic power and advanced infrastructure, but what was lacking in the opening ceremony was the software -- democracy and civic awareness.
"The Beijing Olympics -- in which the government is afraid of its people and of human rights -- conflicts with the Olympic spirit, " Wang said.
The activists urged people in Taiwan not to take democracy for granted, as it takes everyone's efforts to protect democracy from being compromised.
"Taiwanese people should have the courage to safeguard society with justice and conscience and help China build one of its own as soon as possible," Sheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Microsoft Taiwan opens certification programs on own management tool

TEXT.P: Microsoft Taiwan Corp. has opened certification programs on its own project management tool, aiming to issue certifications to 500 people within one year, an executive of Microsoft Taiwan said Saturday.

Alec Cooper, Microsoft Taiwan's general manager of business marketing operations, said the company cooperated with Taiwan's Advanced Business Consulting Inc. in providing the certification programs on Microsoft Certified Technology Specialist Project 2007 (MCTS-Project 2007).
The MCTS-Project 2007 is a specially designed tool to help project managers apply best practices and methodologies to result in better project outcomes and optimal resource management, Cooper said.

According to Chang Li-yeh, Microsoft Taiwan's product marketing manager, the number of Taiwanese who received project management professional certification from the American Project Management Institute last year increased by 49 percent from the year-earlier level.
However, these project managers might have the required methodologies, but in practice, they do not have good tools, so the MCTS-Project 2007 is aimed at meeting their needs, Chang said.

There is an increasing need for project management in the industry, Cooper said, adding that the organizing teams of the Beijing Olympics and the Kaohsiung World Games 2009 are both using Microsoft Project to manage their international sports events.
He added that Microsoft Taiwan will work with more partners to provide certification programs to project managers in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Even if my arms break, I won't let go barbell': Taiwanese medalist
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 9 (CNA) 08/09/08 19:36:30 (By Chris Wang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Recalling her Olympian efforts in Saturday's 48 kg-class weightlifting event at the Beijing Olympics, Taiwanese bronze medalist Chen Wei-ling said she kept thinking that "even if my arms break, I won't let go the barbell" when trying to lift 115 kg in the clean and jerk part of the contest.
Unfortunately, Chen failed to make the lift, but she pledged to continue challenging herself to perform better in the next Olympics "so long as the coach doesn't give up on me."
Chen lifted 84 kg in the snatch event before moving on to lift 112 kg in the clean and jerk event for a total score of 196 kg and Taiwan's first medal of the Olympics.

South Korea's Im Jyounghwa also lifted a combined 196 kg, but the Taiwanese weightlifter was awarded the medal in a tie-breaker based on body weight. Chen weighed in at 47.11 kg, lighter than Im's 47.62 kg.
China's Chen Xiexia grabbed the gold medal with a combined lift of 212 kg, a new Olympic record, while Sibel Ozkan of Turkey won silver with a combined lift of 210 kg.

Before coming to Beijing, Chen was not expected to take any medals in the world's largest sports event. She placed 11th at the 2004 Athens Olympics, when she finished the 48 kg competition with a combined lift of 170 kg.
She said she practiced hard day and night only because her coach, Zhang Jiamin from China, told her it was possible for her to win an Olympic medal.
Along with her medal, Chen also won a national award of NT$5 million (US$160,000) given by the government to honor athletes who perform with excellence at international competitions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 700,000 fingerprint files of Taipei citizens destroyed

TEXT.P: All fingerprint files of Taipei citizens collected between 2003 and 2005 have been destroyed by official sanction, Taipei City Government Bureau of Civil Affairs Deputy Director Chen Chi-yung said Saturday.
Chen said hard disks containing the fingerprints of more than 700,000 citizens were cut and smashed at a factory in Taoyuan County a day earlier.

On hand to witness the destruction were officials from the city government's Department of Government Ethics and from the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, as well as a third impartial party.
"In response to demands by the public and to prevent possible leaks of personal data, the information was destroyed," Chen said.

He noted that Taipei launched a fingerprint authentication and identification system in 2002 after the Ministry of the Interior discussed the possible inclusion of such data as fingerprints on new ID cards issued to replace the old ID cards that were issued in 1996.
The proposal was eventually ditched when the ID cards were replaced in 2006 out of concern about infringement of personal privacy.
He explained that the city's collection of fingerprints was made with good intentions, despite the criticism that it could lead to leaks of personal data.

The city government began to permit citizens to use their fingerprint information in late 2002, allowing citizens who had provided fingerprint records to attend to Household Registration Office business without the need to provide their ID cards.

DOC.HEADLINE: Holding billboards on street becomes popular part-time job

TEXT.P: During the current economic recession, people are grabbing all kinds of opportunities to make money, with some even willing to stand for eight hours a day on the streets in heavy traffic and in all weather, holding billboards advertising sumptuous apartments they will probably never afford with their meager wages.

These temporary workers can be found every day at the main intersections in Taipei. Their job is simple and easy: standing still holding an advertising billboard that indicates to drivers the direction of the real estate being promoted.

The phenomenon began after the Taipei City Police Department began to clamp down in 2005 on advertising vehicles occupying parking spaces on the city streets. Since then, temporary staffing agencies have hired people for low wages to hold the billboards.
Most of them work from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., earning just NT$800 (US$25.6) per day.
According to the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) , the minimum hourly wage in Taiwan is NT$95.
The workers are allowed to take a 10-minute rest every hour, but are not allowed to sit down while holding their billboard.
"Our employer sends `patrols' from time to time to see if we are doing what they ask, " said an elderly worker who stands at the intersection of Songjiang Road and Changchun Road five days a week.
Declining to give his name, the man said he was a retiree and wanted to kill time and make some money with any job. He was hired by a temporary staffing agency, as the job requires few skills.
"At my age, I don't have many choices," he said.
Showing his tanned arms, the retiree said the hot sun is not a problem for him. "From 3: 30 p.m., this corner will be shadowed by the neighboring building," he added resignedly.
In addition to elderly people, people of working age also consider holding billboards as a way to earn a little extra income.

One middle-aged man standing at the intersection of Xinsheng South Road and Renai Road told CNA that he has been holding billboards every weekend for four years, even though he has a regular weekday job.
"The high temperature is tolerable, but what is really annoying is the rain, " he said, adding that holding a billboard while standing in the rain wearing a raincoat is not very comfortable.
He also expressed concern about breathing the polluted air all day, as he is always posted at intersections where there is heavy traffic, for the best advertising effect.
Even though the working conditions are far from satisfactory, however, he said he is still willing to do the work at the cost of his weekends and family time.
"The extra earnings -- NT$800 a day -- help boost my earnings, especially during the period when prices are rising," he said.

To protect these temporary workers, Ngou Giok-siong, president of the Taiwan Labor Front, said that if the government will not improve their working conditions, it should at least guarantee their basic rights.
"I doubt that the temporary staffing agencies pay insurance for these temporary workers, who are among the most underprivileged in the work force; the CLA should investigate the issue," Ngou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Russia turns might of its war machine on rebel neighbour Georgia
Russia and Georgia were on the brink of war last night after Moscow responded to a Georgian offensive in the breakaway republic of South Ossetia by sending tanks, troops and war-planes across the border.

DOC.HEADLINE: President demands inter-agency coordination in river cleanup

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that relevant government agencies should step up coordination and cooperation in river cleanup and flood prevention work to improve operational efficiency.
Ma issued the directive while inspecting a Dajia river embankment project in Taichung County's Houli township in central Taiwan.

Noting that the 140.2 km Dajia river -- the county's longest -- often floods during typhoon season because of sediment due to excessive land development in the river's upper reaches, Ma said cleanup work requires the cooperation of many government agencies, including the Council of Agriculture, Taiwan Power Co., which operates several power plants along the river, and the Veterans Affairs Council, which is responsible for overseeing the farms in the river's upper stretches operated by retired servicemen.
Ma said the Water Resources Agency (WRA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs should coordinate with those agencies to come up with a comprehensive action plan.

"If each agency is responsible for cleanup or flood control on different sections of the river without taking into account the work being done elsewhere on the river, the work could lead nowhere, " he added.
Ma was accompanied by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and WRA Director Chen Shen-hsien on the inspection tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: Depression sufferers urged to continue treatment

TEXT.P: Local doctors urged patients suffering from depression Saturday to continue their treatment, after statistics were released showing that the ratio of those who lapse in their treatment is too high.

Chang Chia-ming, an attending physician in the Department of Psychiatry at Chang Kung Memorial Hospital, said that around 30 percent of patients stop seeing doctors after a single visit, even though continued medication for six months would achieve much better results.

Chang said that an analysis of the patients seeking treatment under the National Health Insurance Bureau between 1997 and 2004 shows that the occurrence rate of depression among patients aged over 18 tripled to 0.8 percent in 2004 from 0.28 percent in 1998.
However, up to 35 percent of newly diagnosed depressives would stop seeing doctors after just one visit, Chang said.

He noted that patients who receive fewer than 90 days of treatment had a recurrence rate of 34.7 percent, while those who continue treatment for over 90 days have a recurrence rate of only 5.3 percent.
"Those who discontinue treatment too soon tend to be young female patients, " he added.

He pointed out that an ideal treatment process for depression takes between six and nine months, preferably one year. Treatment in the first 90 days after a bout of depression is especially important, he went on, adding that "uninterrupted treatment is crucial to the treatment of depression."

Lai Teh-jen, president of the Taiwan Association Against Depression, echoed his words, pointing out that depression is curable and that suspending treatment before it is complete could make the disease worse.
Clinical tests have found that with continued treatment and medication for over six months, 80 percent of depressed patients will experience dramatic improvement, Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. shipping line donates to help aboriginal children

TEXT.P: The Taiwan branch of American President Line, a global container shipping company, donated to a foundation Saturday to help 53 aboriginal children.

Chiang Cheng-yi, an assistant president of the company, noted that the company has donated to the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families' Hualien branch since 2006 to help with the food expenses of 53 aboriginal children to the tune of NT$12,000 (US$393) per person per year.
This year, the company has again donated NT$636,000 to the children, providing them with their dinners for a year, Chiang said.
Wang Ching-feng, director of the fund's Hualien branch, said that at present, the fund helps sponsor 2,900 children from 1,350 families.

Past experience has shown that many poor children have to shoulder household chores after school and that because of poverty, they often cannot afford three meals a day, while the free lunches provided by the schools may be the most "luxurious" food they get during the course of an entire day, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAUP organizes mass rally against pro-China policy

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Association of University Professors (TAUP) organized a mass rally at Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office Saturday to protest what it called the current government's tilt toward China.

It was the third TAUP-organized protest rally in Taipei City since the May 20 inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration and drew the largest number of participants. The previous two rallies took place in Dana Forest Park and Yuanshan Park, respectively.

Rally goers waved flags bearing the word "Taiwan" and wore headbands protesting what they called the Ma administration's tilting-toward-China and selling out Taiwan policy. Some disgruntled citizens went up to the podium to lash out at the Kuomintang administration for commodity prices hikes in the past few months.

Several pro-Taiwan independence groups mobilized members to lend their support. Hsu Kuo-yung, a former legislator of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , and Taipei City Councilor Chien Yu-yen served as emcees at the rally.

Among the prominent participants were outgoing Examination Yuan President Yao Jia-wen and Taiwan Society Secretary-General Lo Chih-cheng. DPP Policy Coordination Committee Executive Chaung Shou-han showed up at the rally, but didn't make any public speech.
Lo said the Ma dministration is arrogant as it refuses to admit many of its policy blunders. He also accused Ma of backing away from his campaign promises.

"Ma often expressed his love for Taiwan on campaign trail, but once in power, he moved to get rid of 'Taiwanization, '" Lo argued, referring to the recent resumption of state-run postal company's name "Chunghwa Post." The company's name was changed to Taiwan Post in 2007 in line with the then-DPP administration's desinicization and Taiwan-centric policy.
"In the run-up to the presidential poll, Ma often said he took pride in Taiwan, but now he just likes to say glory of Chinese race," Lo condemned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-Yulon Group chairwoman dies at 96

TEXT.P: Former Yulong Group Chairwoman Vivian Shun-Wen Wu, who assisted her late husband Yen Ching-ling in building Taiwan's first automobile manufacturing company, died from heart and lung failure at Veterans General Hospital in suburban Taipei Saturday at the age of 96, the company said in a statement.

Wu, born in China's Jiansu province, graduated from Shanghai Saint John's University and had a master's degree in international relations from Columbia University. She and her family moved to Taiwan after the Chinese communists took control of the mainland in 1949.

A resourceful and competent woman, Wu emerged as one of Taiwan's most prominent business executives. She took over the helm at Yulon Motor Co. after her husband died and led the company to tide over many difficulties and eventually become a thriving and profitable operation.
Wu was also a respected educator. She once served as president and chairwoman of the private Hsinpu Institute of Technology.

A philanthropist, Wu set up many non-profit foundations to help manpower cultivation and encourage young people to pursue advanced study and career achievements. Wu also had served as a board member of the Straits Exchange Foundation, a quasi-official intermediary body authorized to handle cross-Taiwan Straits exchanges in the absence of official ties.
Wu is survived by her only son -- incumbent Yulon Group Chairman Kenneth Yen, daughter-in-law Chen Li-lien, a former basketball player, and a young granddaughter.
According to the Yulon statement, a makeshift memorial hall will be installed at the company's headquarters in Taipei City Monday for Wu's friends to pay their respects for its former chief.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAC urges China to respect visitors' rights during Olympics

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council (SAC) urged Beijing authorities Saturday to respect spectators' or visitors' reasonable rights during the ongoing Olympic Games.

The council issued the call after Yang Hui-ju, who campaigned for pro- independence Democratic Progressive Party's presidential candidate Frank Hsieh in the run-up to Taiwan's March 22 presidential poll, was repatriated by Beijing after rejecting her entry earlier in the day.
Although Yang had valid travel papers, Beijing authorities denied her entry after questioning her for more than an hour upon her arrival via a weekendend direct cross-strait charter flight.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug.10, 2008

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAC urges China to respect visitors' rights during Olympics

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council (SAC) urged Beijing authorities Saturday to respect spectators' or visitors' reasonable rights during the ongoing Olympic Games.

The council issued the call after Yang Hui-ju, a young Taiwanese woman who campaigned for the defeated pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Frank Hsieh in the run-up to Taiwan's March 22 presidential poll, was denied entry to Beijing and was repatriated via Hong Kong earlier that day.
Yang said after her return to Taoyuan International Airport late Saturday that she was upset by Beijing's treatment of her.
According to Yang, she was held by Beijing's customs authorities upon her arrival even though she had valid travel papers.
"Beijing should not have issued me an entry permit if it would not accept my visit to cheer on Taiwanese Olympians," a visibly tired Yang said.
Yang said Chinese customs officers grilled her for more than an hour and aggressively examined her luggage, notebooks and cell phone.
"I asked why they could treat me so disrespectfully, they replied they were following their superiors' order," Yang recalled.

Yang said she was uneasy and even had a feeling of terror during the several hours of detention. In the end, Beijing officials confiscated her "Taiwan compatriot certificate" or entry permit and repatriated her to Hong Kong. Yang said she will hold a news conference later to recount her ordeal at Beijing airport.

Yang and one of her friends, Lee Kun-lin, traveled to Beijing via aweekend direct cross-strait charter flight Saturday morning. Lee, a backpacking fan who has visited more than 30 countries around the world with a Republic of China flag in his backpack, was also denied entry and repatriated to Hong Kong. He returned via a flight to the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 10, or the 10th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1821: Missouri is admitted as the 24th state of the United States.
1846: The Smithsonian Institute is established in Washington as a center for scientific research with a bequest from English scientist James Smithson.
1874: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, is born. His belief in individual freedom led him to reject federal relief for unemployment during the Depression and lost him the 1932 election to Franklin D. Roosevelt.
1894: Varahagiri Venkata Giri, president of India from 1969 to 1974, is born. He was prominent in India's labor movement.
1904: During the Russo-Japanese War, the Russian fleet suffers heavy loses when the Japanese fleet blocks it from escaping from Port Arthur in the Battle of the Yellow Sea.
1913: The Treaty of Bucharest is signed, ending the second Balkan War and partitioning Macedonia among Serbia, Greece, Romania and Bulgaria.
1926: Northwest Airlines is established in Chicago.
1944: Yicheng County in Hupei Province changes its name to Chihchung County in memory of the bravery of Gen. Chang Chih-chung who died in action during the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1944: American forces recapture Guam from the Japanese after three weeks of fighting in which only 500 of the 18,000 defending Japanese troops survived and surrendered.
1945: Robert H. Goddard, American pioneer of rocket science, dies at the age of 63. He conducted the first successful launch of a liquid-propellant rocket in 1926. The rocket climbed 184 feet (56 meters) into the air at a speed of about 60 miles (97 kilometers) per hour.
1946: Gen. George C. Marshall, a special envoy of U.S. President Harry Truman to China on a mission to mediate the civil war between the Nationalists and the Chinese communists, issues a statement declaring that his efforts have failed.
1950: U.S. State Department official Karl L. Rankin arrives in Taipei as charge d'affaires of the U.S. Embassy.
1961: Britain applies to join the European Economic Community.
1966: Orbiter I, the first American moon satellite, is launched from Cape Kennedy.
1975: Flight service between the Republic of China and Japan resumes after the ROC government announced on April 20, 1974 the termination of the Taiwan-Japan flights of China Airlines and Japan Airlines.
1979: The newly completed Keelung-Suao Highway is opened to traffic.
1981: The joint meeting of the Second Asian Conference of the International Association for Cross-Cultural Psychology and the First Asian Conference of the International Council of Psychologists opens in Taipei.
1990: The ROC government declares its support of a United Nations call for world sanctions against Iraq over its invasion of Kuwait.
1993: The New KMT Alliance breaks with the ruling Kuomintang and forms the New Party.
1993: Shih Yueh-po, a Chinese passenger, hijacks a mainland Chinese Boeing 767 passenger plane to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan.
1998: Some 2,000 people die in floods in China.
1998: Prince Al-Muhtadee Billah, eldest son of Sultan Hassan Bolkiah of Brunei, is proclaimed heir to the throne.
1999: The Republic of China inaugurates Asia's first flight recorder laboratory, allowing local personnel to analyze aircraft flight recorder (black box) data rather than having to send such data to a third country for analysis.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian accuses Beijing of hypocrisy in terms of its definition of "one China," and reiterates Taiwan's rejection of Beijing's demand that it embrace "one China" on Beijing's terms.
2001: After being on death row for almost 10 years, mainland Chinese hijackers Cho Chang-jen and Chiang Hung-chun are executed at the Taipei Prison for kidnap and murder.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to be trusted by one's friends. If a man does not command the obedience of the members of his family, he will not be trusted by his friends."

DOC.HEADLINE: Historic tunnel opens to bicycles

TEXT.P: A tunnel on the historic Caoling trail on the northeastern Coast of Taiwan opened to bicycles Sunday after a year of renovation, making it the country's longest bicycle tunnel.

At the opening ceremony, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said the renovation of the old tunnel was aimed at promoting cycling in line with the government's green policies of energy conservation and carbon dioxide emissions reduction, and at increasing the appeal of railway tourism.
He said it was just a start and that in the future, the government, in conjunction with the tourism industry, will continue to come up with new ways to launch more fun leisure activities.

The 15-minute bicycle path through the tunnel is designed based on the concept of building a "rail tunnel museum" and is decorated with discarded railway relics that allows cyclists to experience Taiwan's old railway history on two wheels, according to the Northeast Coast National Scenic Area Administration, which managed the construction in collaboration with the Taiwan Railway Administration.
The tunnel is also equipped with public toilets and service centers built around old disused barracks and blockhouses.
The 2.1-km Caoling Tunnel was the longest railway tunnel in Taiwan when it opened in 1924. It was closed in 1986 when the railway line was diverted.

The tunnel carries great historic importance in the development of Taiwan's transport system, as it was a main part of the Caoling Trail constructed to provide an important transport link between Taipei and Yilan when Taiwan was still a Japanese colony.

It is also the tunnel referenced in the famous Taiwanese folk song "Diu-Diu Dang, " the title of which is a phonetic rendition of the sound of the water dripping from the walls of the tunnel as the train passes through. Cyclists who ride the tunnel can still hear train whistles from the new Caoling tunnel, which is still used by trains.
To attract more people to attend the ceremony, the TRA also arranged a special passenger train and bus service to the location and offered tickets to enter several amusement parks in the area.

The tunnel will open to the public 8: 30 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day and the Tourism Bureau advised tourists to take advantage of a one-day rail pass introduced by the TRA, as well as other travel packages offered by local camping operators.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Fraud makes up bulk of cybercrime cases in first 6 months: police

TEXT.P: Fraud accounts for the largest percentage -- some 40 percent -- of the total cybercrime cases reported in the first half of this year, the Criminal Investigation Bureau said Sunday.

The bureau said that 12,007 cases of Internet crime were reported during the first six months of this year, down from last year's 13,855, 80.27 percent of which were solved, up from 65 percent from the same period of last year.
During the January-June period, 4,981 cases of Internet fraud were reported, followed by 2,023 cases concerning the infringement of computer usage, the bureau said.

Another 1,871 cases involving violations of the Child and Youth Sexual Transaction Prevention Act, 1,340 cases concerning the infringement of intellectual property rights, and 1,131 cases regarding obscenity, were reported, according to the bureau.
Police busted the fewest cases in the category of computer usage infringement, which the bureau explained includes hacking and acquiring, eliminating, or changing electromagnetic records.
In this category, the police only busted 368, or 18.2 percent, of the 2,023 cases, the bureau said, adding the percentage still went up from last year's 9.5 percent.
The police attributed the lowest rate to difficulty in cracking down on hackers, as they are often traced to China and Hong Kong.
Most of the computer usage infringement cases are related to cyber games, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: No plans for wireless Internet service: local airlines

TEXT.P: China Airlines and EVA Air, Taiwan's biggest air carriers, said Sunday they have no plans to follow their U.S. counterparts' lead in providing wireless Internet services on flights, as doing so would add a heavier financial burden to the already high operating costs.

Following a move by Continental Airlines, many U.S.-based carriers, including Delta Airlines, recently announced that they will provide in-flight Wi-Fi broadband internet access on domestic flights, a bid that will allow millions of U.S. domestic airline passengers to log onto the Internet in the air.

Citing rising costs in the airline business sparked by skyrocketing international crude oil and raw commodity prices, Taiwan's two largest carriers have no plans to offer such a service, which requires expensive equipment and high telecommunication charges.

Bruce Chen, the spokesman of China Airlines, Taiwan's biggest carrier, said the company offered in-air wireless Internet access from 2005 to 2006 but was forced to suspend the service due to rising costs.
"Maybe after the easing of oil prices the company will consider reinstating the service," he told CNA.
Chen added that the infrastructure of the in-flight wireless services requires mainly the installation of satellite antennae, which is very costly.
"Should the technology advance to the extent where infrastructure costs can be lowered, the company will also re-evaluate the option of re-launching the service," he said.

EVA Air, Taiwan's second-largest airline company, has never planned in-flight Internet connection due to little market incentive, according to an EVA public relations manager who spoke on condition of anonymity.

"The high operating costs of Internet services would force the airline to charge passengers an additional fee," the manager went on, adding that this would be another disadvantage of investing in the service.

The Internet service on Delta's planes will charge each user US$9.95 for three- hour in-flight Internet access (US$12.95 for over three hours) during each flight, and will be offered on all of its domestic flights by next summer.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT delegations to attend U.S. democratic, republican conventions

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) will dispatch two five- member delegations to the Democratic National Convention (DNC) and Republican National Convention (RNC) in the United States late August and early September, respectively, a senior party official said Sunday.

In a recent meeting, the KMT decided that Tseng Yun-chuan, deputy speaker of the Legislative Yuan, will lead the delegation to the 2008 DNC to be held in Denver, Colorado Aug. 25-28, while, Chiang Pin-kung, vice chairman of the KMT and chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, will head the delegation to the RNC in Minneapolis-Saint Paul, Minnesota Sept. 1-4.

The purpose of the U.S. party conventions is to officially nominate the party's candidate for president and to adopt the party's platform and rules. Since senators Barack Obama and John McCain have already locked up their candidacies for the Democratic and Republican parties, respectively, the choices of their running mates will be the focus of the conventions.

A senior Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said that traditionally, the ministry does not dispatch delegations to the U.S. party conventions, although high-ranking officials of Taiwan's representative office to the U.S. usually observe them.

Legislators Ting Shou-chung, Chou Shou-hsun, Wu Chih-yang and Shuai Hua-ming are members of the delegation to the DNC, while Pai Wei- kang, Tsai Cheng-yuan, Lai shih-bao and Lu Hsueh-chang will attend the RNC.
The opposition Democratic Progressive Party will also send delegations to both conventions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier presents medal to Taiwanese Olympic medalist' mother

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan extended his congratulations Sunday to the mother of Chen Wei-ling, who won the country's first medal at the Beijing Olympics a day earlier.

In a phone call to Chen's mother Wu Hsiao-lin in Tainan City, the premier lauded Chen for bringing glory to the country by winning bronze in the women's 48 kg- class weightlifting event, the country's fourth Olympic weightlifting medal in 24 years.

The premier also instructed his chief of staff, Hsieh Hsiang-chuan, to visit Wu at her home later Sunday and present her with a medal for her daughter on his behalf bearing the inscription "Gracing the Nation."
Hsieh said Chen
has boosted the morale of her teammates at the Beijing Olympics, and expressed admiration for Wu, who brought up Chen and her two sisters alone.
Showing off various medals her daughter has won, the proud mother told Hsieh she has been overwhelmed with congratulatory phonecalls since her daughter won the medal in Beijing.

However, she said she is worried about her daughter's career as an athlete after the Beijing Olympics and asked Hsieh to help Chen land a job, preferably as a public school teacher rather than a sports coach, which is the only option for most medal-winning athletes.
Hsieh promised to help but did not elaborate on how he plans to do this.

Wu Chun-cheh, secretary-general of the Sports Affairs Council who accompanied Hsieh on the visit, said that as an Olympic medalist, Chen is qualified to coach the national team but not to teach at school unless she completes teaching and education courses at university to obtain teaching credentials.

Chen is one of 80-odd members of the Taiwan Olympic team that is competing at the Beijing Olympics. Taiwan is setting its sight on seven gold medals this year, compared to the two golds, two silvers and one bronze it won at the 2004 Athens Olympics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural council launches workshops targeting eco-experience

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) launched Sunday a series of summer activities to provide a platform for the public to appreciate first-hand Taiwan's natural environment and agricultural achievements.

"The countryside experience, emphasizing the interaction between humans and nature, has become an emerging trend among local leisure activities," COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung said at the opening ceremony of the event.

Due to this trend, a total of 2,000 slots open to children at the farm village workshops were booked during the first 30 minutes of registration at the beginning of this summer's vacation."The council will open up to 5,000 slots to help more children get familiar with Mother Nature and farm villages in the next year," Chen promised.

He said the new initiative has integrated three different categories of venues -- farm villages, national forest recreation areas and botanical gardens -- to allow people to gain hands-on knowledge of ecosystems and farm development while enjoying the "natural lifestyle."
The COA program provides a passport that guides travelers to experience daily life in any of 123 designated farm villages.
In addition, it also arranges workshops in dozens of forest parks and botanical gardens to accommodate summer vacationers in different locations around the country.

Chen said that by integrating the recreational resources of mountain trails, forest parks, forestry culture centers and eco-educational parks, the council will form a brand new holiday experience that pays respect to nature while helping participants to improve their health through exercise.
"The forests will become centers for nature education, " the minister envisioned.

Touching on the Taipei Botanical Garden, one of the event venues that is located at the heart of the city but almost hidden in a bubble of tranquility, Chen said the weekly tour guides in the garden will allow citizens to observe and learn about over 2,000 plants.
To preserve the natural resources, Chen warned the participants not to take away any animals, plants or minerals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan working to develop Chinese market for its fruit

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) , taking advantage of the Beijing Olympics to market Taiwanese fruit in Beijing, is also working on an "order fruit in Taiwan for delivery in China" campaign among Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan, a council official said Sunday.

The promotional efforts were highly commended by Premier Liu Chao-shiuan at a recent Cabinet meeting in which he also ordered the Mainland Affairs Council to work with the COA to expand the Chinese market for Taiwanese fruit, the official said.

Liu said the development of Taiwan's agriculture industry hinges on the expansion of its international marketing network and added that to meet that end, the COA should work with farmers and agricultural groups to strengthen the marketing of Taiwanese agricultural produce to Japan and the West.

Taiwan's high quality fruit is world famous, but as the sales and distribution channels are limited, it is common to see farmers struggle to make ends meet due to plummeting prices caused by local gluts during harvest season, according to COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung, who added that it is unreasonable that good harvests do not bring profits for farmers.

Sometimes, oversupplies also occur when foreign countries abruptly suspend imports of Taiwanese fruit, Chen went on, adding that to prevent this kind of crisis, it is very important to establish additional marketing outlets.

For those reasons, the COA has being targeting high-income consumers in China following the opening of weekend direct cross-strait charter flights and the admission of more Chinese tourists to Taiwan last month, the official cited Chen as saying.
In the initial stage, the COA plans to set up service centers in the Sun Moon Lake area and at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport where Chinese visitors can place fruit orders.

The COA will also select center operators by the end of this year to deal with matters concerning taking orders, promotion, exhibition, sales and quarantine, while handling delivery issues in Beijing and Shanghai.

For those chosen to run the service centers, the COA will provide subsidies to help them set up the centers and assist them with negotiating and communicating with local government agencies and airports to facilitate the operation and promotion of their centers.
Both Taiwanese and Chinese customers will be able to place orders at the centers for fruit to be delivered to Chinese addresses, the official added.

Some farmers in the central county of Nantou have expressed keen interest in the proposal as they are confident it could help the county to sell its well known plum and tea products. Sun Moon Lake is in Nantou County.
Chen was cited as saying that if the plan goes smoothly, the COA will also consider setting up distribution outlets in China in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei urges Beijing to respect visitors

TEXT.P: Taipei urged Beijing to give visitors to China seeking to attend Olympic events "reasonable respect" during the Beijing Olympics.

In response to Beijing's denial of entry to a Taiwanese woman the previous day, Government Information Office Minister Vanessa Yea-ping Shih said Sunday that the Taipei authorities expressed their regret through the Sports Affairs Council (SAC).

The SAC said in a Saturday press release that the Beijing authorities had no reason to deny entry to Yang Hui-ju, who traveled to Beijing with valid travel documents with the purpose of cheering on the Chinese Taipei team at the Olympics.
Yang is known in Taiwan for profiting from benefits offered by local banks to their credit card holders.
Her last claim to publicity was last year during the country's presidential election, when she volunteered her services to help Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Frank Hsieh.
She was turned away Saturday at the Capital International Airport in Beijing by customs officials when she arrived with a self-described group of Taiwanese cheerleaders.
Also turned away was another member of the group, Lee Kun-lin, whose claim to fame is exposing his buttocks in different cities around the globe.
However, the SAC press release did not mention Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ruling lawmakers oppose government plan to phase out death penalty

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers said Sunday that they oppose a Ministry of Justice plan to phase out the death penalty, claiming that a lack of capital punishment would increase the crime rate.

The remarks came one day after the ministry said it plans to gradually achieve its goal through conducting extensive research and discussion, and through proposing complementary measures to win the support of the public.
However, KMT Legislator Wu Ching-chih said it is not the right time to push for eliminating the death penalty.
He claimed that Taiwan's social order is not good and that people do not have sufficient understanding of law and order.
If the death penalty is abandoned, he went on, it will not be conducive to social order and might encourage major crime rings to engage in bigger crimes.

The existence of the death penalty serves as a warning to those who intend to engage in illicit activities, according to Wu, who vowed that if the ministry proposes a draft bill to abolish the death penalty in the next legislative session, he will oppose it.
Chu Fong-chi, another KMT lawmaker, shared the same view, adding that South Africa now has no capital punishment, which she claimed is the reason its social order is deteriorating.
She suggested keeping the death penalty in place, but urged local judges to exert more caution when handing down death sentences.
KMT Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang said the ministry should respect public opinion, since there is no consensus on the abolishment.

A day earlier, the ministry said in a statement that capital punishment uses national power to deprive a criminal's right to life so that the criminal is isolated from the rest of the society permanently.
According to the ministry, such methods are cruel and fail to demonstrate that punishments should also serve rehabilitation purposes.
Therefore, many democratic, advanced nations have abolished the death penalty with or without conditions, it pointed out.
Up to 137 countries have abandoned capital punishment both legally and in reality, while 60 countries still maintain it, according to Amnesty International data released in May.

Only 24 of these 60 countries still carry out death sentences, the ministry noted, adding that the United Nations General Assembly also endorsed a resolution Dec. 18, 2007 to call for suspension of executions.
Although abolishing the death penalty is a world trend, up to 80 percent of the people in Taiwan oppose the idea, according to the results of a ministry poll released in February.
However, the percentage dropped sharply to 43 percent when the ministry asked the respondents if they would agree that the death penalty should be replaced by life imprisonment with no parole.
Under such a premise, another 56 percent supported the abolishment of capital punishment, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City to decide pet zone site by August

TEXT.P: The Taichung city government will listen to the opinions of local civic groups and residents before making a final decision on whether to develop a "pet zone" at the Jioushe Park in the central city by the end of this month, a city government official said Sunday.

The city government originally planned to allot a 1.8 hectare plot of land in the four-hectare park where residents would be able to walk their dogs, but decided to reassess the proposal after it drew criticism from local residents, according to the official.

As many locals have expressed opposition to the proposal, the government will take their opinions into account and has already informed animal protection groups of the situation and asked them to recommend alternative courses of action.

The official expressed hope that the groups will choose "an appropriate site" that will not draw opposition from local residents. "It would also be best if dog lovers themselves are willing to maintain the pet zone should it be established."
Residents near the city's Nantun Park expressed hope that the government can use a 0.6 hectare plot of land in the park, which covers an area of 1.3 hectares, for the purpose.

DOC.HEADLINE: Groups to set up forum to defend Taiwan's sovereignty

TEXT.P: More than 10 groups will discuss Monday how to establish a forum aimed at "defending Taiwan's sovereignty" under what they describe as the "pro-China" government.

Shih Cheng-feng, chairman of the Institute for National Development, one of the organizing groups, accused the Kuomintang (KMT) government of downgrading Taiwanese identity and of leaning toward China since it took office in May.
The KMT's stance has intensified the political confrontations within Taiwan and poses a crisis to Taiwan's sovereignty and diplomacy, according to Shih.
He also blasted the government for opening direct charter flights between Taiwan and China July 4 and for planning to allow Taiwanese wafer manufacturers to invest in 12-inch wafer plants in China.
He argued that these policies will benefit only China's economy, not that of Taiwan.
Shih claimed that the Chinese communists are using political and economic means to help reach the KMT's ultimate goal -- achieving unification with China.
He said Beijing's ultimate purpose is to annex Taiwan and he urged people in Taiwan to monitor the government.
The establishment of the forum is to prevent Taiwan from being further isolated in the international community following the Beijing Olympic Games, according to Shih.
The forum will also seek to prevent the Beijing authorities and the KMT from collaborating to turn Taiwan into a part of China, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 11, or the 11th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1858: Christiaan Eijkman, the Dutch physician who won the 1929 Nobel Prize for medicine for his discovery of Vitamin B, is born.
1863: The French, who occupy southern Vietnam, make Cambodia a protectorate.
1919: Scottish-born American industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie dies at the age of 84. He amassed a fortune in the steel industry and donated millions of dollars for the benefit of the public.
1921: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, formally invites China, Japan, Britain, France and Italy to join a disarmament meeting in Washington, D.C. to cope with an increasingly dangerous international situation after World War I.
1930: Britain goes broke. The United States and France each lend it US$46 million, while American bankers extend another US$111 million.
1932: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, says it is time to scrap Prohibition. He lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt later that same year.
1936: Nationalist Chinese forces of Chiang Kai-shek enter Canton after foiling a rebellion led by Chen Chi-tang in the city in southern China.
1945: The Allies inform Japan that its surrender offer is acceptable.
1945: Communist "Yenan General Headquarters" orders Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the Republic of China government.
1950: The U.N. Security Council rejects a Soviet proposal for the immediate expulsion of the ROC delegation. The Russian delegation walks out in protest.
1960: Chad gains independence from France.
1960: The ROC recognizes the Ivory Coast and Chad.
1966: A peace treaty is signed in Jakarta, ending three years of hostilities between Malaysia and Indonesia.
1972: President Richard M. Nixon completes his "Vietnamization" of the Vietnam War by pulling out the last 92 American soldiers from the Southeast Asian country.
1973: The Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League opens its three-day 19th Conference in Taipei.
1975: The first meeting of the Asian and Pacific Congress on Health, Physical Education and Recreation opens in Taipei with 250 experts from 17 nations and areas attending.
1976: The industrial and commercial panel of the National Reconstruction Seminar opens a three-day meeting to make recommendations to the government.
1986: Sixteen people are killed and 87 others injured in an accidental explosion aboard the tanker SS Canari which is waiting to be scrapped in a shipwrecking yard in Kaohsiung Harbor.
1992: The United States, Canada and Mexico reach an agreement to set up a North American free-trade zone that would rank as the world's largest single trading bloc.
1993: The ROC Cable Television Law goes into effect.
1997: An international meeting called to shore up the shaky Thai economy offers loans of US$16 billion to the financial crisis-hit country.
1999: Taiwan's China Airlines signs an agreement with Boeing Co. of the United States to buy 13 B747-400 cargo planes for an estimated US$2.5 billion.
2000: A "Tzu Chi Village" in South Africa built by Taiwan's Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, a charity organization, is formally inaugurated. Meanwhile, the Tzu Chi Medical Center announces the 99th and 100th overseas cases in which it has supplied bone marrow for transplant operations.
2001: The Bureau of Monetary Affairs under the Finance Ministry and the Central Deposits Insurance Corp. take the initiative to put 36 faltering local financial institutions under supervision, the first phase of a "Monetary Reconstruction Fund" action to consolidate the operations of local banks and farmers as well as fishermen's cooperatives.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to command the obedience of the members of one's family. If a man looking into his own heart is not true to himself, he will not command the obedience of the members of his family."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Over 80% companies see good looks as an asset for job applicants

TEXT.P: A recent poll conducted by a local job bank indicated that over 80 percent of enterprises are more likely to employ physically attractive job applicants, with 14.52 percent of these employers offering higher pay to their relatively more attractive workers.

"Good looks are more than just about physical attributes, but rather indicate of a better level of self-management, " 1111 Job Bank's Chief Operating Officer (COO), Ryan Wu said Monday at a press conference at which he announced the poll results.

In the poll, conducted between July 25 and August 7 among local 455 enterprises, 83.38 percent of the respondents indicated that they are more likely to offer jobs to applicants who look relatively more attractive.

Wu said that 50.95 percent of the respondents thought that good looks reflected self-management ability, while 36.39 percent said an attractive employee can help give the the company or its products a good image.
According to the poll, 81.33 percent of employees think that clothes and make-up contribute the most to a worker's physical appearance.

With the job market in Taiwan becoming increasingly more competitive, recruiters have more choices in selecting ideal job candidates, with the option of picking physically better looking people, Wu said.
However, the advantage of good looks usually stops at the interview stage, as employers still remain practical when it comes to offering salaries, he added.
Nonetheless, 14.52 percent of the respondents in the poll admitted that they would offer more attractive workers a starting salary 4.46 percent higher than the standard pay.
"Outstanding work performance still counts the most, " Wu stressed, adding that job seekers who think they are not as attractive as others should not be discouraged in their search.

As for the types of positions seen most likely to be filled with physically good looking people, 67.28 percent and 57.26 percent of the companies identified salespersons and customer service staff, respectively.

According to another job bank survey conducted among 1,176 local workers, physical appearance is regarded as a big factor in finding employment and in work evaluation. An overwhelming 95.83 percent of the respondents said they thought good looks give an added advantage in job interviews.

Fifty-six percent of those polled said better looking employees stand a higher chance of having their performance noticed by the boss, while 47.45 percent said attractive workers tend to get away with mistakes in their work.

Employers, on the other hand, said they are less influenced by the looks when evaluating job performances, as the first poll showed that only 17.68 percent of respondents said they would provide good-looking employees with more opportunities to showcase the quality of their work.
The second poll, conducted between July 25 and August 7, had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.9 percent anda 95 percent level of confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: Clean government directly proportional to competitiveness: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that building a clean government is the top priority of his administration, as the more honest and clean a government is, the more competitive the country will be.
He made the remarks at the opening ceremony of the 2008 International Anti- corruption Conference in Taiwan.
"Anti-corruption is not only a global trend, but is also the number one task of the government," Ma said.

Ma said that apart from Transparency International's annual corruption perceptions index, several world renowned surveys conducted by the World Economic Forum in Geneva and the International Institute for Management Development in Lausanne also take into consideration the integrity of governments in assessing the national competitiveness of countries around the world.
"The more honest a government is, the more competitive the country is. They are directly proportional to each other," he said.

Ma contended that clean government cannot be achieved solely by instituting strict laws, but also by public servants taking the attitude of "not wanting to be corrupt, seeing no need to be corrupt" and that they "cannot be corrupt and dare not be corrupt."
"Those at the top have to set the example for those below to follow," the president said. "Leaders have to have the political will to oppose corruption and the society also needs to be on board."
Ma said people might be disappointed at a government when the economy is sluggish but they are devastated when a government proves corrupt.
"Peoples trust is the most important asset a government can have, but corruption is the strongest corrosive agent of such trust," he stated.

Quoting the British historian John Baron, the president said, "Power corrupts, absolute power corrupt absolutely, " adding that anti-corruption is a full-time task that requires the efforts of everyone.
During the sessions, the participants will exchanges views on strategies on government ethics, fighting bribery, and corruption control in government, business and the private sector.
