DOC.HEADLINE: President's mother released from hospital

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's mother was released Sunday from Taipei's Wan Fang Hospital where she had been staying for over a week due to impaired blood flow to the brain, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Monday.
Speaking with reporters at the Presidential Office, Wang said that 86-year-old Chin Hou-hsiu returned home after being discharged and that her condition is good.
Chin was admitted to hospital Aug. 3, suffering from dizzy spells caused by cerebral ischemia -- a condition in which the brain doesn't receive enough blood to maintain normal functioning.

Hsu Chun-sen, deputy superintendent of the hospital, said that Chin's body has naturally broken down the blood clots that had impaired the circulation of blood to her brain, according to observations by the hospital over the past week.
Chin's physical functions were not affected by the condition, and she was discharged in good condition, he added.
Hsu said that Chin has been advised to maintain a healthy diet, exercise regularly and seek regular checkups at the hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu Science Park production up 4.25% in first half of year

TEXT.P: Hsinchu Science Park's production reached NT$553.379 billion (US$17.742 billion) for the first half of 2008, up 4.25 percent over the level for the same period last year, the park's administration said Monday.
The integrated circuit and optoelectronics industries accounted for 88.2 percent of the park's production for the January-June period, according to the administration.

The production value of optoelectronics companies within the park amounted to NT$103.03 billion, up 41.86 percent year-on-year, thanks to continued growth of flat panel display manufacturers and individual optoelectronics giants, such as AUO.

The integrated circuit manufacturers' production value totaled N$385.064 billion, rising only 0.28 percent year-on-year largely due to the weak performance of the DRAM industry, the administration said.

Despite the overall increase in production, several industries in the park experienced declines for the first half of the year, including the precision machinery industry, down 2.97 percent to NT$5.604 billion, and the biotechnology industry, down 6.83 percent to NT$1.669 billion.

Randy Yen, director-general of the park's administration, said that although the local economy and manufacturers continue to face challenges brought about by the U.S. subprime crisis, high oil prices and global economic sluggishness, the park's production is expected to increase in the second of half of this year as the various high-tech industries within the park enter their high seasons.
The park's production value is forecast to reach NT$1.198 trillion for this year, which would represent an increase of 4.53 percent over the year-earlier figure, according to Yen.
He further said that the park, with its top quality facilities, has helped bring about sustainable development for Taiwan's economy.
Yen predicted that 500 companies will be established within the park by the year 2011, at which time the park's production is likely to reach the NT$1.5 trillion mark.

The Hsinchu Science Park, which was established by Taiwan's government in 1980, is located in northern Hsinchu County, about 70 kilometers from Taipei City. A total of 441 mainly high-technology companies have set up shop within the 883 hectare park to date, employing some 130,000 workers, according to the administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: New personnel reshuffle based on professionalism: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday that professionalism and ability were the main concerns behind the latest personnel reshuffle in diplomatic posts and denied reports that the removal of Representative to Bahrain Parris Chang has anything to do with his possession of a U.S. green card.

"Regarding political appointees, the two basic principles are first, that the Foreign Ministry respects the will of the personnel concerned, and second, that Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou bases his overall evaluations on ability and professionalism, " said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen in response to reporters' questions.
Since the Kuomintang (KMT) took office May 20, the issue of whether Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) political appointees should resign or be replaced has become a controversial issue.

Important positions such as representatives to the United States, Japan and the European Union have all been replaced, or will be shortly, a move that the opposition DPP claims is political wrangling.

The Foreign Ministry confirmed a day earlier that Chang, who took office in January, has been removed from the post and that his successor will be Robert Sa, former representative to Zaire and former deputy representative to France, Belgium and the European Union.

Chen insisted that Chang's removal is not personal and is not related to his being in possession of a U.S. green card, saying that "our main consideration is to put the most suitable people into the right positions, especially career diplomats with expertise."

The Central Personnel Administration (CPA) under the Executive Yuan recently instructed representatives with permanent residency of foreign countries to either renounce such status or resign. After being named by the CPA, Representative to Japan Koh Se-kai and Representative to Switzerland Kuanping George Liu tendered their resignations, leaving Chang the only one who did not follow the directive.

The Nationality Act forbids Republic of China nationals with foreign citizenship from assuming public office and stipulates that those holding such status should be removed from their posts. The Law, however, does not forbid public servants from holding permanent residency of a foreign country.

In other diplomatic changes, Ambassador to Palau Matthew Lee became director- general of the MOFA's Department of Protocol, effective Aug. 1, while the vacancy he left will be filled by Maggie Tien, former director-general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Sydney.

Representative to the Czech Republic Shen Ssu-tsun will assume the post of MOFA secretary-general, while Raymond Wang, former director-general of the TECO in Honolulu, was designated as the ministry's Congressional Liaison Unit coordinator.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan donates US$600,000 to El Salvador for irrigation systems
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Paraguay, Aug. 10 (CNA) 08/11/08 18:13:52 (By Ramon Huang and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan government has donated US$600,000 to El Salvador for the construction of small-scale irrigation systems in the Central American country, the Salvadoran daily "La Prensa", which was obtained here, reported Sunday.

The new irrigation systems, built in 250 areas in eastern El Salvador, are aimed at helping small- and mid-scale fruit and vegetable growers in the region boost productivity as well as at ensuring a stable source of water for their crops, according to the report.

Since 1972, Taiwan has continually supported a program to develop El Salvador's agriculture and livestock industries, including assisting in setting up the needed infrastructure. To date, irrigation systems have been built in more than 800 farming areas of the country, while 15 large-scale drainage systems have been constructed.

Republic of China Ambassador Carlos Liao recently presented the third installment of the donation on behalf of the Taiwan government to Salvadoran Agricultural Minister Mario Ernesto Salaverria, the report said.

In accepting the donation, Salaverria said that Taiwan's assistance under bilateral technological cooperation programs has not only helped boost the productivity of local farmers, it has also reduced El Salvador's reliance on foreign agricultural imports.

He added that the program has included assisting Salvadoran farmers in developing the marketing and processing of their agricultural products, and expressed the hope that through this type of assistance, the country's "farmers can become agricultural entrepreneurs."

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$500 limit on gifts to remain in place: justice ministry

TEXT.P: The NT$500 limit set by the government on the value of gifts that public servants are permitted to accept in the line of duty will remain in place, despite some controversy over a NT$620 (US$20) gift bag planned by the Council of Agriculture (COA) to promote Taiwanese fruit, Minister of Justice Wang Ching- feng said Monday.
"The Ministry of Justice is not considering raising the limit at present despite the controversy," Wang asserted, adding that the rule could help the government and officials save money.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has asked the heads of agencies when buying gifts to buy locally grown flowers out of their own pockets to avoid contravening official guidelines, Wang said.

Wang made the remarks in response to a report in the China Times daily newspaper earlier Monday that the COA had planned to present each government minister with a gift bag containing four popular locally grown fruits -- guavas, mangoes, pineapples and starfruit -- at last Thursday's weekly Executive Yuan meeting as part of the COA's efforts to sell the fruits at home and abroad.
But the COA was forced to abandon the plan after being told Wednesday night by central ethics authorities that the value of the gift exceeded the NT$500 ceiling imposed by the government.

According to the Ethics Directives for Civil Servants approved by the Executive Yuan in June, public employees are permitted to accept gifts or social hospitality that do not exceed the "standards of ordinary social etiquette" on special occasions such as engagements, weddings, promotions, transfers and new postings.

COA Deputy Minister Hu Hsing-hua said the plan to offer the fruit bag as a gift was not in violation of the Ethics Directives for Civil Servants because the cost of the fruit itself was NT$500, while the basket cost NT$120.
"It is a worldwide practice to give flowers or fruit on holidays and special occasions, and it is natural to accept gifts of these kinds worth less than NT$500," Hu quoted Liu as saying.
"The fruit was to be presented in a gift bag as part of an advertising campaign that was launched late last month in Beijing ahead of the ongoing Beijing Olympics, " Hu said.
The COA has been advertising the fruit at 30 stations in Beijing's metro system to attract Chinese and foreign passengers and to help boost sales of the fruit on the global market.

"It takes time to promote Taiwan's high-end and pricey farm produce in the Chinese market, and this is the reason why the COA filmed the advertisement to court potential customers in the hope of setting up more distribution channels in the future," Hu explained.
Government Information Office Minister Vanessa Shih said Premier Liu firmly supports Taiwan's agriculture and is deeply concerned about farmers' livelihoods.
The premier has asked all public agency chiefs to purchase flowers themselves instead of accepting the gift bags from the COA, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Social welfare organizations feeling the pinch in economic downturn

TEXT.P: The recent economic downturn is so severe and pervasive that the annual sale of moon cakes by many charity organizations to raise funds has been receiving lukewarm response.
Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi has used recently public funds to produce and broadcast a television advertisement to promote moon cakes made by mentally challenged people.

Liao said at a press conference yesterday that the sale of moon cakes by social welfare organizations has fallen way below expectations this year, and that concern for the underprivileged is always an important element of his policies.
His observations on the drop in sales were confirmed by a spokesperson for one such organization.

According to Tsui Pin, director of the Eden Social Welfare Foundation's public relations department, it is clear that charity organizations are having difficulty promoting their hand-made moon cakes due to the economic slowdown.

Tsui said in a telephone interview Monday that her foundation has set a target of selling 15,000 moon cakes gift boxes this year made by about 40 physically and mentally challenged people at three Eden shelter factories located in northern and central Taiwan.

"But at best, sales would total only 10,500 boxes (of moon cakes) this year, " which means a big drop from last year's 25,000 boxes, said Tsui. She added that because of the economic stagnation people are reluctant to help the charities.

This year's Mid-Autumn Festival will fall on September 14. Tsui explained that since it takes longer for the disabled to prepare the moon cakes, the orders should be submitted at least one month in advance.
However, to date, two of foundation's shelter factories have orders for only about 2,000 boxes, Tsui said.

Enterprises that customarily place orders every year have been relatively conservative this year, and some of them have even told the foundation that they have no funds to order moon cakes as they have made donations to survivors of the May 12 Sichuan earthquake, said Tsui.

She further noted that in addition to the poor economic situation, there are more social welfare organizations trying to get a piece of the shrinking pie by selling moon cakes during the festival season.

In order to promote sales, the Eden foundation is cooperating with the OK-Mart convenience stores this year in the hope of making its hand-made moon cakes available to a wider market, though that means the price will increase, Tsui said.

The Children Are Us Foundation, a social welfare organization that helps people with Downs Syndrome fit into the society by providing them professional training courses, has also forecast a drop in sales this year.
Jalen Zou, chief of the foundation's public relations section, said its target this year is 80 percent of last year's NT$20 million.
People with Down Syndrome, dubbed "joyful and naive children" in Taiwan, participated in the moon cake production process, including the making and packing, Zou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Disabled children benefit from Kaohsiung County's free dental care

TEXT.P: Nearly 2,800 physically and mentally disabled children aged under 12 have benefited from free oral health care services provided by the southern county of Kaohsiung from 2002 to 2007, a local official said Monday.

According to the official of the Kaohsiung County Health Bureau, the county government has spent over NT$2.7 million (US$86,581) on providing the service to disabled children who cannot take good care of their teeth on their own.
The subsidy program has helped cover dental examination fees for about 1,100 people and treatment charges for about 1,700, the official said.

The service allows children who have a special dental health care "passport" issued by the county government to receive full subsidies from the county government to pay for examinations or treatment items that national health insurance does not cover, including registration fees, charges for special dental fillings, braces and fluoride treatment, the official said.

A total of 67 oral health care institutes around the county have joined the service network and have received training on how to provide dental care to disabled children, who sometimes require more patience and care during treatment procedures, the official said.
In order to make people more aware of the importance of oral hygiene, the county government also provides a free oral examination for each member of the general public every year, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan succeeds in reducing drug-related harm: report

TEXT.P: Taiwan has achieved significant results in reducing drug-related harm and lowering HIV prevalence among drug addicts, according to a report presented last week at the 2008 International AIDS Conference in Mexico.

The report, presented by National Yang Ming University and China Medical University, assessed Taiwan's achievements in reducing HIV prevalence through a harm reduction program, including needle exchanges and methadone therapy.
Harm reduction refers to any program or policy designed to reduce drug-related harm without requiring the cessation of drug use. It represents a pragmatic approach to managing drug addiction.

According to the report, a research team collected 1,800 needles discarded by drug addicts at 33 recovery points throughout Taiwan in March 2007 and another 1,800 used needles in July the same year in order to conduct blood residue tests, leading to the finding that the HIV prevalence among drug addicts was reduced by half -- from 18 percent to 9 percent.

Chen Yi-ming, director of the AIDS Prevention and Research Center at Yang Ming University in Taipei who serves concurrently as president of the Taiwan Harm Reduction Association, told CNA in an interview Monday that Taiwan launched a harm reduction pilot program in October 2005 after heroin addicts sharing needles caused the HIV infection rate to double between 2004 and 2005.

The success of the pilot program prompted the government to begin a full-scale program in August 2006. By the end of 2007, the program had distributed 3.6 million sterilized syringes and needles at 60 exchange stations and had helped more than 2,000 drug addicts to get onto methadone programs.

According to Chen, one of every five drug addicts newly imprisoned for rehabilitation tested HIV-positive in 2005. Although the HIV infection rate has now dropped to 4.3 percent, he estimated that of the 50,000 drug addicts not currently in prison, about 10,000 are HIV carriers.
"The challenge facing the government is that nearly 40,000 drug addicts are still not participating in methadone programs and that most of them have not been tested for AIDS recently," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA launches tourist railway `cruises' around scenic regions

TEXT.P: A "cruise liner-style" railway train set off from the Hualien railway station Monday carrying more than 300 passengers on a one-day special tour of the scenic southeastern part of Taiwan.
The first tourism-oriented train of its kind was launched by the Taiwan Railways Administration (TRA) as part of efforts to attract people to use TRA trains for sightseeing.

Unlike the usual trains that only stop for a short time at each station, the "cruise train" makes longer stops at certain stations to allow passengers to disembark and tour tourist spots, according to a TRA press release that describes the way in which the train journey has been adapted to a form similar to that of an international cruise liner.
The train departed at 7: 30 a.m., making stops in Jian, Wanrong, Dongli and Fuli before arriving in Taitung County's Guanshan just after noon.

The train also ran at speeds as low as 35 kph to allow passengers good views of the scenic landscapes and vast flower fields along the railway line that runs through the East Rift Valley National Scenic Area.

Hualien Railway Station Director Chen Yu-mou said the special train is a cheap way to tour the scenic East Rift Valley, as the price of a ticket for a round- trip tour between Hualien and Guanshan is only NT$332 for adults, NT$166 for children and NT$184 for people aged over 65.

The passengers on Monday's excursion had a three-hour stopover at Guanshan, where they had the opportunity to do a round-the-town bike tour or visit a local water park before boarding the same train for the return trip to Hualien, Chen added.

In addition to the Hualien-Taitung Line, the TRA has also prepared similar cruise trains for the Taipei-Suao Line along the northeast coast and for the Kaohsiung-Taitung South Link Line. The Suao cruise will depart Aug. 19 and Aug. 30 from Taipei, while the South Link Line train will run from Kaohsiung Aug. 23, and Sept. 6, according to the TRA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cheaper NT dollar should boost stock market: analysts

TEXT.P: The recent depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar is likely to help the stock market, as Taiwan's listed export firms will benefit from the change in exchange rate, market experts said Monday.

Taiwan's currency dropped to NT$31.166 against the greenback at the close of trade Monday, a fall of 0.24 percent. The NT dollar has dropped a total of 2.3 percent in the past ten trading days, down from NT$30.465 on July 29. Currency market turnover surpassed US$900 million during the same period.

Market analysts said a cheaper NT dollar will likely worsen inflation, especially in prices of imported goods. But they said it will benefit exporters, whose goods will be cheaper abroad, and so boost such firms' stock performance.

A large portion of local stocks are in export-focused industries, such as the electronics sector, which will do better with a lower NT dollar, " Wang Lee- rong, director of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research's (CIER) center for economic research, said Monday.

Following the 302.89-point, or 2.65 percent, rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average last Friday, Taiwan's stock index on Monday rose 116.58 points, or 1.61 percent, to 7325.62 points, on turnover of NT$135.37 billion (US$4.34 billion).
Wang told the Central News Agency (CNA) that the NT dollar drop is mainly due to the recent strength of the U.S. dollar in international currency markets.
The downward trend in the local currency does not signal that foreign capital is leaving the island, she noted, adding that the outlook of Taiwan's economy remains positive.

According to the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corporation (TSEC) , foreign investors bought a total of NT$130.5 billion in stocks last week, recording net purchases of NT$6.83 billion. That helped the index rise by 206.5 points, or nearly three percent.
Wang forecasted, however, that in the long term the NT dollar would be more resilient against the U.S. dollar, because Taiwan's economy should continue to outperform that of the U.S. entering 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: New system to be launched for economic crime investigations

TEXT.P: Prosecutors, their assistants and investigators will need to obtain an intermediate- or above level-finance professionalism certificate if they want to investigate economic criminal cases following the implementation of a new system July 1, 2010, Ministry of Justice (MOJ) officials said Monday.

The new finance professionalism certification system, initiated by former Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin earlier this year, is aimed at upgrading the quality of investigation and the conviction rates for economic criminal cases, the officials said.

According to the officials, the Investigation Bureau under the MOJ and the Securities and Futures Institute have already cooperated in training 170 investigators around the country to investigate corporate corruption cases. Cooperation with the Taiwan Academy of Banking and Finance and the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission in offering courses to prosecutors is also expected to be set up in September.

Officials from the MOJ's Department of Prosecutorial Affairs said finance courses at elementary, intermediate and high levels will be offered, with the elementary level focusing on general finance through courses including an introduction to the capital market, banking and stocks practice, company internal control systems, and how to read financial statements.

The intermediate level will emphasize investigation skills, with courses on how to investigate stock market players, embezzlement, insider trading, illegal income, related case studies, and finance checking.
Courses at the high level will include exploration of the merging and acquisition of finance enterprises, and the practice and crime strategies of offshore companies.

The officials added that the intermediate course will last for 48 hours, while the elementary and high level courses will each be 24 hours. The lecturers will be directors of banking and financial agencies or research institutions, professors and prosecutors with experience in investigating significant economic crimes.

Prosecutors and investigators who pass the evaluations conducted at the end of the courses will be awarded a certificate by the MOJ and the Investigation Bureau, the officials said, adding that they will also be awarded a certificate if they attend the courses offered by financial units such as the Financial Supervisory Commission and the Securities and Futures Institute.
According to the officials, July 2008 through June 2010 will be a two-year buffer period to allow for full preparations to be made prior to the introduction of the new system.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Water bills set to soar over next five years
Water bills in England and Wales are likely to rise by up to 3 per cent a year above inflation for five years in the latest blow to British households' finances.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Nation: Corruption cases England exile for Thaksin?
Former premier Thaksin shinawatra and his wife last night failed to return to Bnagkok, sparking speculation the couple might be planing exile in England.
The Bangkok Post:Prapawadee wins gold.
The sky was cloudy and heavy rain fell in Beijing yesterday, but lifter Prapawadee Jaroenrattanatarakoon overpowered her oppents to win a gold medal .

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's top tennis player shocks Murray at Olympics

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Lu Yen-hsun secured perhaps the most significant victory of his career Monday, stunning the sixth-seeded Andy Murray of Scotland in the first round of the Olympic men's singles tennis tournament 7-6 (5), 6-4.

Lu, ranked 77th in the latest ATP rankings, broke Murray in the final game of the second set to secure the victory, his first against a top-20 player since he beat the third-ranked Guillermo Coria at a Wimbledon warm-up event in June 2004.

The 25-year-old, who has battled injuries throughout his career but appears to be healthy now, fought back from two breaks in the first set to win it in a tiebreaker when Murray double-faulted on set point.
After a rain delay early in the second set, Lu gained confidence and held off four break points in the pivotal ninth game before breaking the Scot to clinch the match.

Murray was seen as one of the hottest players on the ATP Tour after winning the ATP Masters Series event in Cincinnati last week, but made too many unforced errors and was kept on the run by an inspired Lu.
The surprising victory sent Lu into the second round of the tournament against clay-court specialist Agustin Calleri of Argentina, ranked 52nd in the world.
To the regret of Taiwan's tennis fans, the match was not televised live by any of the television stations with broadcasting rights to the Olympic Games.

Two networks, Taiwan's China Television System and China Television Co., broadcast images from the last few games of the match on small screens that left the players barely visible during their nightly newscast, but completely missed Lu's match point while reporting other news stories.

In an match that concluded just minutes before Lu's victory, and was also not broadcast, Taiwan's Chan Yung-jan lost in the first round of the women's singles to eighth-seeded Agnieszka Radwanska of Poland 6-1, 7-6 (6).

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Russians Push Past Separatist Area to Assault Central Georgia
Russia expanded its attacks on Georgia on Sunday, moving tanks and troops through the separatist enclave of South Ossetia and advancing toward the city of Gori in central Georgia, in its first direct assault on a Georgian city with ground forces during three days of heavy fighting, Georgian officials said.
The Wall Street Journal:Russia Launches New Raids on Georgia
Swarms of Russian jets launched new raids on Georgian territory Monday while Russian officials accused Georgia of violating its pledge to observe a cease- fire around the breakaway province of South Ossetia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan magistrate urges targeting U.S., European fruit markets

TEXT.P: Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih called Monday for the central government to boost its efforts to help Taiwan's fruit farmers tap U.S. and European markets, since they are having difficulties breaking into China's market.
Su urged the government to craft an agricultural policy to help Taiwanese farmers to upgrade and create more value-added products, instead of harboring wishful thinking about the Chinese market.

The central government and most local authorities have stepped up their efforts in recent months to help Taiwan's farmers ship fruits and vegetables to China. But Su said he believes that Taiwan's farm goods exports to China were still lackluster.

In a bid to help local farmers break into overseas markets, in recent years the southern Tainan County has set its sights on the Japanese and South Korean markets, Su said. He added that the initial results had been satisfactory.
According to the Tainan magistrate, last year his county shipped 786 metric tons of mangoes to Japan, 741 metric tons to South Korea and only 81 metric tons to China.

So far this year, the county has exported over 850 metric tons of the fruit to Japan and more than 500 metric tons to South Korea, boosting local farmers' profits. The Directorate General of Customs has not yet published the figure for exports to China.
As the Chinese market for Taiwan's agricultural products remains small, the central government has the obligation to explore other foreign markets on behalf of local growers' interests, he said.

According to Su, Taiwanese farm products are facing several critical difficulties in the Chinese market, such as commercial piracy and fierce competition from low-priced goods. He said that the root problem is a lack of protection for Taiwan's business interests in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Georgia Retreats, Pleads for Truce; U.S. Condemns Russian Onslaught
The Georgian army, suffering massive casualties in the face of overwhelming Russian firepower, retreated from the breakaway region of South Ossetia on Sunday. Georgian leaders' recent expressions of defiance turned increasingly into pleas for a cease-fire and Western support in the face of a military debacle.
The Washington Times:Russia intensifies attack on Georgia
Russian planes, troops and artillery units pounded the Georgian city of Gori in a " massive" attack, Georgian officials said Monday as the three-day war over an ethnic enclave in Georgia appeared to escalate.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD program to set up national land info system

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) under the Cabinet will hold a series of seminars in Taipei, Taichung, Kaohsiung and Hualien from Aug. 20 to help local governments understand the national geographical information system being planned, the CEPD said Monday.

In a news release, the CEPD pointed out that the government had approved a 10-year plan in July last year to establish a land information system for Taiwan at a cost of NT$25 billion (US$801.62 million).

According to the CEPD, the plan will integrate existing geographical databanks on Taiwan's land, forests and river estuaries operated by various government departments, including the Forestry Bureau and the Agriculture and Food Agency under the Council of Agriculture, the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and the Department of Land Administration under the Ministry of the Interior.
The unified land information databank will be shared by all government agencies and the people to help them more conveniently search for needed information.
The CEPD also plans to ask the Taiwan Geographical Information Center to set up an exhibition ground in September to display Taiwan's land information for educational purposes, the CEPD said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President reiterates need for U.S. arms deal to visiting delegation

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Taiwan's firm desire to buy defensive weapons from the United States to a visiting U.S. congressional delegation Monday, the country's latest attempt to ease Washington's concerns over a pending arms deal.

Ma made the remarks after media reports recently quoted a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker as saying after a visit to the U.S. Congress that the U.S. is highly suspicious of Ma's stance on the weapons deal.
Legislator Lin Yu-fang disclosed on July 31 that the U.S. suspicion stems from Ma's recent efforts to repair relations with China, which claims sovereignty over self-ruled Taiwan.

Ma's administration opened Taiwan to direct weekend charter flights from China and more Chinese tourists from July 4. The president also plans to allow Taiwanese chipmakers to relocate 12-inch wafer plants to China.
Ma told the delegation at the Presidential Office, however, that Taiwan's moves to thaw ties with China will not affect Taiwan's weapons procurement from the U.S.

Taiwan had submitted a procurement list to the U.S. as early as last year, Ma said, adding that he hopes the U.S. would soon begin the necessary legal procedures to push for passage of the US$11 billion arms deal, that includes Patriot PAC-III missile batteries, Apache and Black Hawk helicopters, and diesel electric submarines.
Meanwhile, Ma said Taiwan needs to demonstrate the will to defend itself and that its defense budget will be maintained at no less than 3 percent of the country's GDP.
China deploys more than 1,000 missiles targeting Taiwan.
Ma also said that since he took office on May 20, his administration has been working to improve ties with the U.S.
He continued that Taipei's efforts to improve ties with Beijing marks another important step in Taipei's efforts to warm up ties with the U.S.

He said the confrontational positions between Taiwan and China in the past have also affected Taiwan-U.S. relations and cited U.S. President George W. Bush as publicly noting previously that he was pleased to see an improvement in the cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Moreover, Ma said that he rarely saw such a large-scale U.S. congressional delegation visit Taiwan in recent years and that many members of the delegation were visiting Taiwan for the first time.

He said he believes the delegation from the U.S. Congress' Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure will help the congress better understand Taiwan and looks forward to meeting more congressional delegations in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gains made in minimizing nuclear waste: official

TEXT.P: Taiwan has made considerable gains in minimizing low-level radioactive waste thanks to advanced technology and related regulations, but the selection of a storage site remains unsettled, an official of the Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council (AEC) said Monday.

According to Huang Ching-tsun, director of the AEC's Radioactive Waste Management Bureau, Taiwan's three nuclear power plants have decreased the volume of their solidified nuclear waste with a high efficiency solidification technology developed by the AEC's Institute of Nuclear Energy Research.
The three nuclear plants produced 259 drums of nuclear waste last year, only 2.1 percent of the record-high 12,258 drums produced in 1983, Huang said.
Policies on minimizing nuclear waste volume set up by the AEC in 1989 and the Nuclear Materials and Radioactive Waste Management Act implemented in 2002 both contributed to the achievement.

Huang emphasized that Taiwan's nuclear waste volume surpassed the world's average in the 1970s and early 1980s during the early stages of its nuclear power plants' operations, but said the country had gained a leading position in the world in terms of nuclear waste reduction in recent years.
Despite the progress, the selection of a nuclear waste storage site that has been under debate since 1990, has yet to be made, Huang said.
Nevertheless, a site selection task force under the Ministry of Economic Affairs is expected to announce a list of possible sites before the expiration of its mandate expires in late August.
Taiwan began to develop nuclear power in the 1970s and now operates three nuclear power plants, with a fourth expected to begin operating next year.
A total of 97,672 barrels of low-radiation waste produced before 1996 were stored in 23 trenches on Orchid Island, also known as Lanyu, an island off the southern coast of Taiwan.
The site stopped accepting additional nuclear waste in 1996 due to protests by local residents, and all waste generated since then has been stored at the power plants themselves.
The situation has caused a headache for successive governments, unable to find a permanent storage spot for the waste.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wood packaging for imported goods must be fumigated from next year

TEXT.P: All wood packaging materials used for imported goods into Taiwan beginning Jan. 1, 2009, must be accompanied with certificates to prove that they have been fumigated or heat-treated, quarantine authorities announced Monday.

The Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said that the new measure will be enforced to prevent various vermin from entering into Taiwan, such as Anoplophora glabripennis -- a beetle from China that has already been found in the United States and has become a threat to hardwood trees, with no natural predators.

The bureau said that from now until the end of this year, its officials at ports of entry around Taiwan will use written notices to inform importers about their noncompliance with the new regulation, but will not take further action.

The bureau added, however, that from Jan. 1 next year, any imported goods whose wood packaging materials do not have certificates of fumigation or heat treatment will be destroyed or sent back along with the imported goods to the country of origin.

Previously Taiwan had no regulations regarding the submission of fumigation certificates for wood materials used for packaging import goods. It only required such certificates when wooden cases or crates were shipped into Taiwan as import items.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Chinese men nabbed off Kinmen Island

TEXT.P: Two Chinese smugglers were separately detained Monday off the coast of Kinmen Island while attempting to sneak onto the Taiwan-controlled island county, the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) said.

It was the first time that two cases of illegal Chinese intruders were tracked down in a single day by Kinmen authorities, CGA officers said, adding that an initial probe produced no evidence linking the two men together.

According to an initial investigation by CGA agents, Jia Wei, a 40-year-old ethnic Chinese man from Xinjiang Province in western China, was arrested by officers on patrol after he landed on the island's beach around 6 a.m.
Jia told Coast Guard officers that he was aware of President Ma Ying-jeou's plan to visit Kinmen Island on Aug. 23, and that he had traveled to Xiamen in Fujian province Aug. 9 from Xinjiang.
Kinmen lies just off Fujian's coast.

Jia said he swam nearly eight hours from Xiamen to Kinmen in the hope of meeting Ma and asking him to provide assistance for his family, which he claimed was suppressed by Chinese communists in Xinjiang.
At the time of his arrest, the officers found Jia in possession of a People's Republic of China ID card, two cash notes of one Chinese yuan and a knife.
The Coast Guard's Kinmen branch has initially ruled out any links between Jia and Xinjiang's independence movement.
Later the same day around 11: 05 a.m., soldiers stationed on a small islet off Kinmen's main island arrested another Chinese man who had sneaked into the area.
The 49-year-old man, identified as Yu Shuirong, is from central coastal Zhejiang Province.
Yu told Coast Guard officers that he wanted to look for a job in Taiwan and decided to swim to Kinmen from Xiamen, where he said he had been unable to find work.

The two Chinese men have been handed over to the Kinmen Prosecutors Office for further investigation on charges of breaching the National Security Law, the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area and other relevant laws.

According to the Coast Guard's patrol unit on Kinmen, the island's law enforcement authorities have caught 20 illegal immigrants there during the period from January last year until the end of July this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to hold talks with allies' heads of state during visit

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will hold talks with presidents of Taiwan's diplomatic allies during his eight-day state visit, which will start Tuesday, an official said Monday.
The state visit will be Ma's first since he took office in May.

Ma will lead a 80-member delegation to attend presidential inaugurations in Paraguay and the Dominican Republic, two of the 23 countries that recognize Taiwan diplomatically, Deputy Foreign Ministry Javier Ho said at a press conference at the Presidential Office.

Ma will stop over in Panama to refuel, ministry officials explained separately after the news conference, adding that during his brief stay at the airport, Ma will meet with his Panamanian counterpart, Martin Torrijos.

In Paraguay, Ma will meet Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo and outgoing President Nicanor Duarte, the officials said, adding that he will also have a discussion with Honduran President Manuel Zelaya.
In the Dominican Republic, Ma will hold talks with both Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca and Haitian President Rene Preval.

The officials added that Ma will also interact with U.S. Commerce Secretary Carlos M. Gutierrez and former Congressman Rob Portman, who have been designated by U.S. President George W. Bush as special envoys for the two presidential inaugurations.

At the press conference earlier in the day, Ho said that Ma is not considering proposing any new foreign aid and that if Taiwan's allies propose any plan, Ma will bring it home for further study and respond within the government's ability.
During the election campaign earlier this year, Ma had vowed not to engage in "dollar diplomacy" if elected.

Taiwan and China often use financial aid in a diplomatic war between the both sides. China claims sovereignty over self-ruled Taiwan and has been working to isolate Taiwan from the international community over the years.

Responding to Lugo's vow made during the election campaign that he would not rule out the possibility of developing a relationship with China, Ho said that Lugo did not specify what kind of relationship it would be.
Also, Ho said that Taiwan's embassy in Paraguay has contacted Lugo over the matter several times and that there will not be a change in Taiwan-Paraguay relations.
During the state visit, Ma will make stopovers in Los Angeles and San Francisco, where he is expected to meet some "U.S. friends, " Ho said.
"Some of the friends are officials now, " Ho said, adding that U.S. congressmen are included. He declined, however, to reveal more details.
Despite the meetings, Ma has previously said that he will make low-profile U.S. stopovers as part of efforts to repair relations between the two sides.
Ma accused his predecessor, Chen Shui-bian, of capitalizing on U.S. transits to strengthen his political support at home.

Ma's visit is aimed at consolidating ties between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies, visiting Taiwanese expatriates in central and south America, and raising the morale of Taiwan's overseas diplomatic officials, according to Ho.
Ma is slated to arrive in Taiwan on Aug. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: High calories, sodium found in lunch boxes at convenience stores

TEXT.P: A recent examination of lunch boxes sold at convenience stores discovered that they contain a high level of calories and sodium that exceeded recommended amounts.

The Taipei-based Consumers' Foundation, an independent organization devoted to safeguarding consumers' rights, held a press conference Monday to make public the results of its random survey in June of lunch boxes at 7-Eleven, FamilyMart, Hi-Life and OK stores in Taipei city and county.
The fast food lunches were checked for nutrition, nitrates, artificial coloring and preservatives, as well as the packaging.
A total of 18 lunch box samples were randomly collected, with each sold at a price between NT$50-NT$70.

The foundation pointed out that in only one of the samples did carbohydrates have a share of the food's total calories within the recommended level listed in the "the Republic of China Diet Manual, " published by the Executive Yuan's Department of Health (DOH).
The manual suggests carbohydrates should account for between 58 percent and 63 percent of one's daily caloric intake, protein 10-14 percent, and fat 20-30 percent.

Protein accounted for more than 14 percent of 10 of the lunches' calories, while fat exceeded the 30 percent limit in 12 of the samples, the foundation stated in its report detailing the survey's results.

The report also took the DOH's daily dietary guidelines as a reference, which suggest 3-6 servings of rice, cereal, bread and rootstock vegetables; 1-2 servings of milk or milk products, four servings of eggs, meats, fish and soybean products; three servings of leafy vegetables; two servings of fruit and 2-3 servings of fat.
Only one of the 12 packaged lunches was found to contain more vegetables than the suggested intake, while none of them included fruit or milk products, according to the report.

Meanwhile, the foundation's dietician also found that 12 of the 18 sample lunch boxes contained more than 1,000 mg of sodium, nearly half the maximum recommended daily intake of 2,400 mg, the report said.
One sample -- the "Kuo Min Bien Tang" -- was found to contain 2,184 mg of sodium, a substance that affects the body's metabolic balance.

As a result, the foundation suggested that those who eat lunch boxes on a daily basis should supplement their diets with milk or milk products and fresh fruit while cutting down on the consumption of foods like meat, eggs, soybean products, cereal, rice, and bread.
The foundation did not discover the products to contain irregular amounts of artificial additives but said the plastic sheet packed in 15 of the sample lunch boxes was a safety concern.
Lunch box makers contend, however, that the plastic is used as "heat insulation" to prevent the packaging from changing shape while being microwaved.

If that is the reason for the plastic, it is hard to convince consumers that the lunch boxes are microwave-proof, the foundation said, adding that the survey showed there's still plenty of room for lunch box vendors to improve their products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tennis player's shocker takes sting off archers' setback

TEXT.P: Monday was supposed to be a medal winning day for Taiwan at the Beijing Olympics.
Instead, it produced one of the greatest upsets ever pulled off by a local athlete, referred to in one wire service headline as an "unknown Taiwanese."

Taiwan's Lu Yen-hsun secured perhaps the most significant victory of his career Monday, stunning the sixth-seeded Andy Murray of Scotland in the first round of the Olympic men's singles tennis tournament 7-6 (5), 6-4.
It was the first time a Taiwanese player had won a men's single match at the Olympics and even Lu couldn't hide his surprise over defeating one of the world's best players.

"When I saw the draw and was preparing to board the plane for Beijing, I thought about grabbing my bags and heading back home, " said a joking Lu, who had not practiced intensively for the past week because of recurring back pain.
"I actually wasn't fully prepared, so I'm really satisfied at producing such a result," he said.

Lu, ranked 77th in the latest ATP rankings, broke Murray in the final game of the second set to secure the victory, his first against a top-20 player since he beat the third-ranked Guillermo Coria at a Wimbledon warm-up event in June 2004.
The 25-year-old fought back from two breaks in the first set to win it in a tiebreaker when Murray double-faulted on set point.

After temporarily losing his momentum after a rain delay early in the second set, Lu regained his confidence and staved off four break points in the pivotal ninth game before breaking the Scot to clinch the match.

Lu, who lost in the first round of the men's singles at the 2004 Athens Games, will face clay-court specialist Agustin Calleri of Argentina, ranked 52nd in the world, in the second round of the 64-player tournament.
In a match that concluded just minutes before Lu's victory, Taiwan's Chan Yung- jan lost in the first round of the women's singles to eighth-seeded Agnieszka Radwanska of Poland 6-1, 7-6 (6).
While Lu shined, the men's archery team, winner of a silver medal in Athens in 2004 and one of world's top-ranked teams, disappointed.

One of Taiwan's best bets for a medal in Beijing, the three archers could not shake off their inconsistency or lack of confidence and were eliminated in the quarterfinals of the 12-team tournament by Ukraine, 214-211.

In truth, however, Taiwan's archers beat themselves. In an earlier round of 16 match, Taiwan outscored the United States 222 to 218, hitting 12 10's out of its 24 arrows and consistently have scored at least 220 in practice sessions.
Not Monday.

"We were never confident enough during the match and we had trouble lifting our morale, " said a disappointed Chen Szu-yuan, one of the two members of the Athens silver-mdeal winning team competing in Beijing.
"Technically, we were fine, but the arrows were going right or going left, and as hard as we tried to adjust, we weren't accurate."

Taiwan actually narrowed a four-point deficit to one with three arrows left, seemingly on the verge of an improbable comeback, but managed only three eights with their final shots to hand victory to the Ukrainians.

The result followed a similar disappointment by the women's archery team on Sunday. Having qualified eighth out of 10 teams on Saturday, the women were unlikely to medal with the prospects of facing the unbeatable South Koreans in the quarterfinals.
But even before reaching that stage, the team that captured bronze in Athens fell to Italy 215-211 in misty conditions and placed ninth in the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. to receive Taiwan president based on existing policies
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 11 (CNA) 08/12/08 11:15:47 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government has approved a request by President Ma Ying-jeou to stop over on the U.S. West Coast on his way to and from Latin America in keeping with the unofficial nature of U.S.-Taiwan relations and existing policies, a U.S. State Department official said Monday.

The request was processed based on the criteria of safety, comfort, convenience and dignity of the traveler, the official from the Bureau of East Asia and Pacific Affairs told the Central News Agency.

Ma is scheduled to make a transit stop in Los Angeles Aug. 12-13 on his way from Taiwan to Paraguay and in San Francisco Aug. 17-18 on his way from the Dominican Republic back to Taiwan, the official said.
He said Ma will not engage in any public activities or have any contact with the media during his stops in the two U.S. cities to comply with the private, unofficial purposes of the transits.

The main purposes of Ma's Latin America visit will be to attend the Aug. 15 inauguration ceremony of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo and the inauguration ceremony of re-elected Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez on Aug. 16.

On his way from Los Angeles to Paraguay on Aug. 13, the president's charter plane is expected to stop briefly in Panama to refuel, during which Ma will meet with Panamanian President Martin Torrijos, according to an itinerary released by Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Also, Ma's plane will stop for one hour in Austin, Texas, to refuel before arriving in San Francisco Aug. 17.
Ma is slated to arrive in Taiwan on Aug. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to hold talks with allies' heads of state during visit

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will hold talks with presidents of Taiwan's diplomatic allies during his eight-day state visit, which will start Tuesday, an official said Monday.
The state visit will be Ma's first since he took office in May.

Ma will lead a 80-member delegation to attend presidential inaugurations in Paraguay and the Dominican Republic, two of the 23 countries that recognize Taiwan diplomatically, Deputy Foreign Ministry Javier Ho said at a press conference at the Presidential Office.

Ma will stop over in Panama to refuel, ministry officials explained separately after the news conference, adding that during his brief stay at the airport, Ma will meet with his Panamanian counterpart, Martin Torrijos.

In Paraguay, Ma will meet Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo and outgoing President Nicanor Duarte, the officials said, adding that he will also have a discussion with Honduran President Manuel Zelaya.
In the Dominican Republic, Ma will hold talks with both Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca and Haitian President Rene Preval.

The officials added that Ma will also interact with U.S. Commerce Secretary Carlos M. Gutierrez and former Congressman Rob Portman, who have been designated by U.S. President George W. Bush as special envoys for the two presidential inaugurations.

At the press conference earlier in the day, Ho said that Ma is not considering proposing any new foreign aid and that if Taiwan's allies propose any plan, Ma will bring it home for further study and respond within the government's ability.
During the election campaign earlier this year, Ma had vowed not to engage in "dollar diplomacy" if elected.

Taiwan and China often use financial aid in a diplomatic war between the both sides. China claims sovereignty over self-ruled Taiwan and has been working to isolate Taiwan from the international community over the years.

Responding to Lugo's vow made during the election campaign that he would not rule out the possibility of developing a relationship with China, Ho said that Lugo did not specify what kind of relationship it would be.
Also, Ho said that Taiwan's embassy in Paraguay has contacted Lugo over the matter several times and that there will not be a change in Taiwan-Paraguay relations.
During the state visit, Ma will make stopovers in Los Angeles and San Francisco, where he is expected to meet some "U.S. friends, " Ho said.
"Some of the friends are officials now, " Ho said, adding that U.S. congressmen are included. He declined, however, to reveal more details.
Despite the meetings, Ma has previously said that he will make low-profile U.S. stopovers as part of efforts to repair relations between the two sides.
Ma accused his predecessor, Chen Shui-bian, of capitalizing on U.S. transits to strengthen his political support at home.

Ma's visit is aimed at consolidating ties between Taiwan and its diplomatic allies, visiting Taiwanese expatriates in central and south America, and raising the morale of Taiwan's overseas diplomatic officials, according to Ho.
Ma is slated to arrive in Taiwan on Aug. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: High calories, sodium found in lunch boxes at convenience stores

TEXT.P: A recent examination of lunch boxes sold at convenience stores discovered that they contain a high level of calories and sodium that exceeded recommended amounts.

The Taipei-based Consumers' Foundation, an independent organization devoted to safeguarding consumers' rights, held a press conference Monday to make public the results of its random survey in June of lunch boxes at 7-Eleven, FamilyMart, Hi-Life and OK stores in Taipei city and county.
The fast food lunches were checked for nutrition, nitrates, artificial coloring and preservatives, as well as the packaging.
A total of 18 lunch box samples were randomly collected, with each sold at a price between NT$50-NT$70.

The foundation pointed out that in only one of the samples did carbohydrates have a share of the food's total calories within the recommended level listed in the "the Republic of China Diet Manual, " published by the Executive Yuan's Department of Health (DOH).
The manual suggests carbohydrates should account for between 58 percent and 63 percent of one's daily caloric intake, protein 10-14 percent, and fat 20-30 percent.

Protein accounted for more than 14 percent of 10 of the lunches' calories, while fat exceeded the 30 percent limit in 12 of the samples, the foundation stated in its report detailing the survey's results.

The report also took the DOH's daily dietary guidelines as a reference, which suggest 3-6 servings of rice, cereal, bread and rootstock vegetables; 1-2 servings of milk or milk products, four servings of eggs, meats, fish and soybean products; three servings of leafy vegetables; two servings of fruit and 2-3 servings of fat.
Only one of the 12 packaged lunches was found to contain more vegetables than the suggested intake, while none of them included fruit or milk products, according to the report.

Meanwhile, the foundation's dietician also found that 12 of the 18 sample lunch boxes contained more than 1,000 mg of sodium, nearly half the maximum recommended daily intake of 2,400 mg, the report said.
One sample -- the "Kuo Min Bien Tang" -- was found to contain 2,184 mg of sodium, a substance that affects the body's metabolic balance.

As a result, the foundation suggested that those who eat lunch boxes on a daily basis should supplement their diets with milk or milk products and fresh fruit while cutting down on the consumption of foods like meat, eggs, soybean products, cereal, rice, and bread.
The foundation did not discover the products to contain irregular amounts of artificial additives but said the plastic sheet packed in 15 of the sample lunch boxes was a safety concern.
Lunch box makers contend, however, that the plastic is used as "heat insulation" to prevent the packaging from changing shape while being microwaved.

If that is the reason for the plastic, it is hard to convince consumers that the lunch boxes are microwave-proof, the foundation said, adding that the survey showed there's still plenty of room for lunch box vendors to improve their products.

TEXT.P: Monday was supposed to be a medal winning day for Taiwan at the Beijing Olympics.
Instead, it produced one of the greatest upsets ever pulled off by a local athlete, referred to in one wire service headline as an "unknown Taiwanese."

Taiwan's Lu Yen-hsun secured perhaps the most significant victory of his career Monday, stunning the sixth-seeded Andy Murray of Scotland in the first round of the Olympic men's singles tennis tournament 7-6 (5), 6-4.
It was the first time a Taiwanese player had won a men's single match at the Olympics and even Lu couldn't hide his surprise over defeating one of the world's best players.

"When I saw the draw and was preparing to board the plane for Beijing, I thought about grabbing my bags and heading back home, " said a joking Lu, who had not practiced intensively for the past week because of recurring back pain.
"I actually wasn't fully prepared, so I'm really satisfied at producing such a result," he said.

Lu, ranked 77th in the latest ATP rankings, broke Murray in the final game of the second set to secure the victory, his first against a top-20 player since he beat the third-ranked Guillermo Coria at a Wimbledon warm-up event in June 2004.
The 25-year-old fought back from two breaks in the first set to win it in a tiebreaker when Murray double-faulted on set point.

After temporarily losing his momentum after a rain delay early in the second set, Lu regained his confidence and staved off four break points in the pivotal ninth game before breaking the Scot to clinch the match.

Lu, who lost in the first round of the men's singles at the 2004 Athens Games, will face clay-court specialist Agustin Calleri of Argentina, ranked 52nd in the world, in the second round of the 64-player tournament.
In a match that concluded just minutes before Lu's victory, Taiwan's Chan Yung- jan lost in the first round of the women's singles to eighth-seeded Agnieszka Radwanska of Poland 6-1, 7-6 (6).
While Lu shined, the men's archery team, winner of a silver medal in Athens in 2004 and one of world's top-ranked teams, disappointed.

One of Taiwan's best bets for a medal in Beijing, the three archers could not shake off their inconsistency or lack of confidence and were eliminated in the quarterfinals of the 12-team tournament by Ukraine, 214-211.

In truth, however, Taiwan's archers beat themselves. In an earlier round of 16 match, Taiwan outscored the United States 222 to 218, hitting 12 10's out of its 24 arrows and consistently have scored at least 220 in practice sessions.
Not Monday.

"We were never confident enough during the match and we had trouble lifting our morale, " said a disappointed Chen Szu-yuan, one of the two members of the Athens silver-mdeal winning team competing in Beijing.
"Technically, we were fine, but the arrows were going right or going left, and as hard as we tried to adjust, we weren't accurate."

Taiwan actually narrowed a four-point deficit to one with three arrows left, seemingly on the verge of an improbable comeback, but managed only three eights with their final shots to hand victory to the Ukrainians.

The result followed a similar disappointment by the women's archery team on Sunday. Having qualified eighth out of 10 teams on Saturday, the women were unlikely to medal with the prospects of facing the unbeatable South Koreans in the quarterfinals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 12, or the 12th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1099: The Crusaders defeat the Egyptians at Ascalon on the Palestine coast in the First Crusade.
1813: Austria declares war against Napoleon.
1848: George Stephenson, the British railway pioneer who built the first passenger railway in 1825, dies at the age of 67. He also developed the first practical steam locomotive, the "Rocket."
1877: A group of people witness a public demonstration of a new device, a phonograph that records the human voice, at Thomas Edison's "invention factory" at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1881: Cecil B. De Mille, the American film director, is born. He is legendary for his large-scale Biblical and historical epics such as "The Ten Commandments," "Samson and Delilah" and "Cleopatra."
1898: The United States and Spain sign a protocol ending the Spanish-American War, with Spain relinquishing Cuba and ceding Puerto Rico to the United States. In addition, the Hawaiian Islands are formally annexed by the United States.
1908: The Ford Motor Co. introduces its Model T car, a sturdy, black, four- cylinder number that comes in two versions: tourer and roadster. Both retail at incredibly low prices: the roadster at US$825 and the tourer for just US$25 more.
1912: William Booth, a Methodist minister who founded the Salvation Army in London in 1865, dies of illness in London at the age of 83. The Salvation Army works to foster a love of God and to provide for the needy. It offers its services to people of any race, creed, sex or age.
1914: Britain declares war on Austria-Hungary.
1946: The stolen body of dictator Benito Mussolini is found in northern Italy.
1948: The United States recognizes South Korea.
1954: The last batch of United Nations forces in the Korean War pulls out of Korea.
1961: Chen Chia-keng, an overseas Chinese from Singapore and founder of Amoy University, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 88.
1970: The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and West Germany sign a non- aggression pact in Moscow.
1970: A China Airlines (CAL) passenger plane of the Republic of China crashes into a mountain on its way from Hualien in eastern Taiwan to Taipei, killing or injuring 31 people.
1978: Taiwan's fastest electrified train, the Tzu Chiang Express, makes a test run between Taipei and Taichung.
1978: Mainland China and Japan sign a treaty of peace and friendship in Beijing.
1985: A Japan Airlines Boeing 747 Jumbo jet crashes into Mount Osutaka on its way from Tokyo to Osaka, killing all but four of the 524 people aboard.
1990: Beijing's attempt to restore its tarnished image after the slaughter in Tiananmen Square receives a severe setback. Official documentation of the disturbances now reveals that more than 450 were killed, the majority by bullets, while 750 were injured and 3,000 were detained.
1991: Two mainland journalists arrive in Taipei, marking the first-ever visit to the ROC by the mainland Chinese press.
1995: The United States government decides to stop all nuclear testing.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan departs for the Dominican Republic to attend the Aug. 16 inauguration of President Leonel Fernandez.
1999: CAL signs an agreement with Airbus Industrie of Europe for a US$1.8 billion order for seven A340-300 passenger jets, with an option for one more A340-300 and four A330-300s.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh urges mainland China to produce a president through popular elections so as to bridge the gap between the political systems and public opinion on either side of the Taiwan Strait.
2001: The Taiwan Solidarity Union, a political party formed by some of former President Lee Teng-hui's followers is formally inaugurated, with a written congratulatory message from President Chen Shui-bian read out at the ceremony.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way for a man to be true to himself. If he does not know what is good, a man cannot be true to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: Registration of Taiwan Communist Party accepted

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) accepted Tuesday the registration of the Taiwan Communist Party as the 141st political party in Taiwan, following the revocation in June of a legal clause that banned civic organizations advocating communism.
"The reason based on which the party was denied registration no longer exists," the ministry said in a statement.

The ministry had previously turned down requests by the group to register as a political party on several occasions, in accordance with Article 2 of the Civic Organizations Act stipulating that "the organization or activities of civic groups cannot advocate communism or territorial separatism."

On June 20, however, the Constitutional Court ruled that the article was in violation of the people's freedom of assembly and freedom of speech enshrined in the Constitution and should be revoked with immediate effect.

On concerns that the Taiwan Communist Party might engage in activities endangering the Republic of China's existence or disrupting the country's democracy, the MOI said in the event of such a situation, the party can be ordered to disband if it is determined by the Constitutional Court to have violated the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Premier receives visiting delegation of U.S. congressmen

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan told a visiting delegation from the U.S. House of Representatives Monday that cross-Taiwan Strait interactions have gradually improved since the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May.

The group of nine members, organized by the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure, was the largest to visit Taiwan since 2003. It was led by Jerry Costello (D-Ill.) , chairman of the Subcommittee on Aviation.
Liu said the House representatives' visit demonstrates the United States' affirmation of Taiwan's democracy and the development of cross-strait relations.
He added that the visit is deeply significant in terms of illustrating U.S. Congress' strong support for and friendship with Taiwan.

Noting that this is the first visit to Taiwan by many members of the delegation, Liu expressed the hope that the congressmen could learn more about Taiwan's situation during the trip and that more members of the U.S. Congress will visit the country in the future.
During their meeting, Liu also briefed the congressmen on the government's new energy policy and policies regarding human resources development.
The delegation was accompanied on the visit by Ministry of Transportation and Communications Minister Mao Chi-kuo as well as American Institute in Taiwan Taipei Office Director Stephen Young.

The delegation arrived in Taiwan Saturday for a three-day visit, during which they also met with President Ma and Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco H.L. Ou, as well as visited the National Palace Museum and the Taipei 101 tower.

The delegation includes Costello, John Duncan (R.-Tenn), Solomon Ortiz (D-Texas), Tim Holden (D-Pa.), Eddie Bernice Johnson (D-Texas), Michael Capuano (D-Mass.) , Henry Brown (R-S.C.) , Dan Lipinski (D-Ill.) and Mary Fallin (R-Okla.).
Taiwan was the final leg of the delegation's Asia visit, which has already taken them to Singapore and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan develops new fuel cell technology

TEXT.P: Taiwan has successfully joined the world in developing a solid oxide fuel cell, which generates more power but conserves more energy, a local researcher said Monday.

By 2010, local convenience stores and small supermarkets could be powered by the fuel cell if the government subsidizes the program, said Lee Chien-hsiung, the head of the Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council (AEC) 's Institute of Nuclear Energy Research (INER) fuel cell program.
Lee said the power efficiency of solid oxide fuel cells could reach 40-60 percent, or over 90 percent if combined with heat. The power efficiency of general fuel cells is 20-35 percent.

The fuel cell could first produce electricity by reacting with fuels such as natural gas, diesel fuel, coal and bio-ethanol, and then generate more power through a connection with a heater, Lee explained.
The institute is the only organization in Taiwan that conducts research on solid oxide fuel cells, and the model developed is the culmination of five years of research, he noted.

The solid oxide fuel cell system developed by the institute is large in size, Lee said, adding that the institute will display a 2,000-watt model measuring 155 centimeters high, 120 centimeters wide and 70 centimeters deep in 2009.
A 5,000-watt to 10,000-watt model is enough to power a convenience store or a small supermarket, Lee said, predicting that one system could cost as much as NT$1.5 million (US$48,138).
Taiwan has more than 9,000 convenience stores.

To promote wide use of the system, Lee suggested the government follow the model established in Japan, where the systems are bought with public funds and then rented to private companies at a low price.
This will create incentives for local manufacturers and further boost the market for the systems, he noted.

The United States, the European Union (EU) and Japan are actively promoting the commercialization of solid oxide fuel cell products as part of their efforts to save energy and reduce carbon dioxide emissions, he said.
The U.S. is expected to see large numbers of such products available in the market after 2016, Lee said.

According to the the U.S. Department of Energy's forecast, the solid oxide fuel cell products could generate a combined 72 billion watts by 2025 in the U.S. and help save a combined energy cost of US$50 billion, Lee pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Red Cross collects NT$1.4b for Sichuan quake relief

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China has collected a total of more than NT$1.41 billion (US$45.28 million) in donations for earthquake relief efforts in the Chinese province of Sichuan, the president of the organization said Monday.
C.V. Chen said that of that total, about NT$1.38 billion has been used to build 64 schools, 43 public health clinics and hospitals and a health rehabilitation center in remote areas of Sichuan.
More than 1.5 million victims of the magnitude 8.0 earthquake that struck the southwestern Chinese province in May 12 have benefited from this assistance, Chen said.
He added that much of the Taiwan Red Cross' quake relief assistance in Sichuan over the past three months has focused on more remote areas that have been neglected in reconstruction efforts.

The Government yesterday said it expects non-oil exports to shrink between 2 and 4 percent this year, down from an earlier forecast of 2 to 4 percent growth.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore's 4th university will admit 12,000 students.
Singapore's fourth university will open it's door at 2011, and it will admit 500 students in its first batch. There will be 10,000 to 12,000 students studying in the university in the future.

DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times Kitajima prevails in world-record fashion
Kosuke kitajima became one of swimming's all-time great Olympians on Monday.
