The Supreme Court yesterday issued arrest warrants for former premier Thaksin Shinawatra and his wife Pojaman for failing to appear for a hearing on the Ratchadaphisek land purchase case.
The Bangkok Post:Thaksin a fugitive,escapes to London.
The Supreme Court's Criminal Division for Holders of Political Positions yesterday issued warrants for teh arrest of deposed prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra and his wife khunying potjaman after the couple jumped bail.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices edge lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 31.82 points to close at 7,293.8.
Suffering a drop from the gains of the previous day, the local bourse opened at the day's high of 7,337.67 and posted a low of 7,260.12.
A total of 4.27 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$122.51 billion (US$3.93 billion).

Seven of eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 5.3 percent. Cement stocks declined 3.8 percent, foodstuff issues and textile stocks both lost 2.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares shed 1.6 percent, banking and financial shares fell 1.2 percent, and paper and pulp issues dropped 0.5 percent.
Machinery and electronics shares gained ground, increasing 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,178 to 928, with 468 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$5.89 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Bush to Putin: Yours is a strike.
U.S. President George W. Bush condemned Russia for trying to topple the democratically elect government of Georgia Monday, while Russian troops continuing invasion into the Georgian territories.

DOC.HEADLINE: Olympic Roundup: Women archers fizzle, softball loses critical game

TEXT.P: Taiwan's three women's archers crashed out of the individual competition at the Olympic Games Tuesday, a fitting end for a group that fell far short of its potential in Beijing.
The women's softball team also suffered a deflating, though not lethal, blow, falling to Canada 6-1 on the opening day of the Olympic softball tournament.
Canada was seen as one of the teams Taiwan had to beat to have any chance of finishing in the top four after the round robin phase of the eight-team tournament and contend for a medal.

Later Tuesday afternoon, men's singles player Lu Yen-hsun and the "golden" women's doubles team of Chan Yung-jan and Chuang Chia-jung in tennis, and men's singles star Hsieh Yu-hsing in badminton were hoping to lift Taiwan's morale.

No athlete was more disappointed Tuesday that Yuan Shu-chi, who finished fourth in the individual archery competition in Athens in 2004 but was knocked out in the second round of the 64-women draw on Tuesday by China's Zhang Juanjuan 110-105.

"I never could get the feel of my release point. I tried to do my best but instead was consistently off, " said Yuan, who was unable to hold back the tears after her defeat. "Even though I kept making adjustments, I still wasn't accurate. I was even surprised (by how poorly I performed.)"

Yuan, who finished sixth out of 64 archers in Saturday's qualification round, struggled the entire morning, shooting only one 10 against Zhang and three in an earlier first round 104-101 victory over Alexandra Feeney of Australia.
She stayed even with Zhang after the first three arrows, but four 8's in the next six arrows left her too far behind the consistent Zhang to mount a late comeback.
Yuan's teammate Wu Hui-ju, along with Yuan a member of Taiwan's silver-medal winning team in Athens, collapsed in her first round match Tuesday afternoon, losing 104-98 to Leidys Brito of Venezuela.
The normally consistent Wu shot two 7's in her first six arrows and never recovered.
Taiwan's third women's archer, Wei Pi-hsiu, concluded her nightmarish Olympics with a 108-99 first round defeat to Athens bronze medalist Alison Williamson of Great Britain.
Wei, Taiwan's weak link in the team event, shot three 7's and four 8's to hand Williamson an easy victory.
The women archers were tipped to win a medal in the team competition and Yuan and Wu were both expected to perform well in the individual competition.

In softball, Canada's lineup had little trouble solving Taiwan's pitchers, pounding out 11 hits in the seven-inning game. Taiwan's starter, Wu Chia-yen, gave up four runs (three earned) on six hits in 2 2/3 innings to take the loss.
Canada scored two runs in the second inning and two more in the third to put the game out of reach. Taiwan's only offense was a home run by third baseman Li Chiu-ching in the seventh.
With the U.S., Japan, and Australia considered the medal favorities, China, Canada and Taiwan were seen to be competing for the fourth and final spot in the medal round.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'One red paperclip' bartering legend to visit Taiwan

TEXT.P: Kyle MacDonald, the Canadian blogger who obtained a house through a series of barters that began with a paperclip, will visit Taiwan later this month for a workshop in which he will share his experience with participants, the organizer said Tuesday.

Those who are interested in taking part are required to prepare a school bag filled with stationery to trade during the one-hour session with MacDonald Aug. 27 at The Sherwood Taipei, according to Chiang Hsin-yi, president of the Taiwan-based free classified advertisement Website kijiji.com.tw.
Kijiji aims to collect at least 100 new or used school bags, which will be donated to disadvantaged school children in southern Taiwan, Chiang said.
Potential participants are urged to sign up online by e-mailing their names and telephone numbers to Kijiji at ppan@kijiji.com, she said.

Inspired by a childhood game called "Bigger or Better, " MacDonald began his legendary quest with a post on the U.S.-based free classified advertisement Website Cragslist on July 12, 2005, in which he offered to trade one red paperclip for "something bigger or better."

The 14 trades that followed involved a fish-shaped pen, a hand-sculpted doorknob, a Coleman camp stove, a Honda generator, an instant party, a Ski-doo snowmobile, a trip for two, a cube van, a recording contract with Metal Works, a year's rent in Phoenix, Arizona, one afternoon with Alice Cooper, a KISS motorized snow globe, a role in the film Donna on Demand, and eventually a two- story farmhouse in Kipling, Saskatchewan on July 5, 2006.

Several of the trades were covered by news channels including CNN, ABC News, BBC and CBC Newsworld. MacDonald published the book "One Red Paperclip" in 2007 and now holds the Guinness World Record for the Most Successful Internet Trade.
In Taiwan, online bartering is also becoming increasingly popular as people are seeking an economically viable way of life to cope with inflation, according to kijiji's Chiang.
During the first six months of this year, a total of 134,766 new items were posted under kijiji's barter section, rising sharply by 72 percent compared with the same period last year, Chiang said.
Only around 50,000 items remain on Kijiji at present, which indicates quick turnover, she said.

The largest number of items put up for bartering are in the categories of women's clothing, household products and gifts by credit card companies, with housewives, female office workers and students being the largest groups engaging in the trades, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.023 to close at NT$31.189.
A total of US$902 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$31.190 and dipped to a low of NT$31.096 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan studying feasibility of opening gambling business

TEXT.P: The government will release an assessment report by December on whether to develop the gambling industry in Taiwan, and if it is assessed as feasible, priority will most likely be given to the outlying islands to open this type of business, the country's top economic planner said Tuesday.

Chen Tain-jy, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said that the outlying island county of Penghu, with a view to boosting its economy, has long demanded the legalization of the gambling industry and has been seeking permission to develop gambling as a business there.
Moreover, the northern counties of Miaoli and Taipei are also actively seeking permission to operate gambling establishments there, Chen added.
The calls by local governments for the legalization of the gambling industry have intensified since May 20 when President Ma Ying-jeou took office, as this was one of his election promises.

Chen said the report will include the possible impact of the gambling industry on the society and whether it is good time to open casinos in Taiwan. It will also cover regulations governing the gambling industry, such as licensing issues, casino operation management and methods of income allocation.

He added that if the assessment concludes that the plan is viable, and after all the relevant regulations have been formulated, all local governments would be allowed to file applications to start such businesses.

However, priority would be given to the country's offshore islands, given that a recent CEPD survey showed that most respondents favored opening up the offshore islands to the development of the gambling business, Chen said.

The offshore islands include Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu, Chen specified, adding however that the local governments would be required to show that they have the approval of local residents, that they could obtain investments by appropriate international investors and that the business would create economic benefits.
Chen made the remarks after he concluded a fact-finding tour of casino operations in Melbourne, Australia last week where he attended the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) ministerial meeting.

Chen said Australia's gambling business is not operated any differently from other industries. But in fact, it is a very complicated and difficult business to deal with and requires a comprehensive management system, he said.

He further explained that the country has many rules governing the gambling industry, such as those related to the management of products, betting calculators, odds calculators and gambling operators.

DOC.HEADLINE: Securities association signs MOU with Indonesian counterpart

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Securities Association (TSA) has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the Indonesia Securities Companies Association to boost cooperative ties, marking the ninth such memorandum signed with a foreign counterpart, a TSA official said Tuesday.
TSA officials signed the MOU with their Indonesian counterparts during a ceremony in Jakarta, Indonesia's capital.

The two sides hope to boost the visibility of Asian stock markets and increase their exchange of information on each country's investment laws and investor education and protection, the official said.
The agreement also aims to improve the speed and efficiency of securities transactions and increase investor discipline, the official added.
TSA signed MOUs with Japanese, Mongolian and South Korean securities associations last year, and with Thai, Vietnamese, German, Polish and Australian counterparts earlier this year.
TSA aims to improve relations between its member security companies, coordinate those firms' efforts to promote national economic development and protect investors' interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's U.N. bid will focus on "participation"

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office confirmed today that Taiwan's United Nations bid this year will sidestep the thorny question of what name the country should use to apply, and instead focus on securing Taiwan's "participation" in the organization.

Presidential Office Spokesman Wang Yu-chi told CNA that the approach of the previous pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party government in the past eight years had failed in part because it focused too much on the name issue.
Wang said that under the government of Ma Ying-jeou, U.N. bids this September and in future years would focus on participation, because "only participation is meaningful."

Wang's comments confirmed a report earlier today in the China Times, a local daily newspaper, which cited unnamed National Security Council officials saying this year's U.N. bid would sidestep the issue of whether to apply as "Taiwan" or the "Republic of China."

For the past 15 years, Taiwan has failed in its bid to become a U.N. member due to opposition from China. Last year's failed bid was the first to use "Taiwan" instead of the Republic of China, the island's formal name, in a move to highlight the nation's de facto independence.
China and the U.S. criticized last year's bid using "Taiwan" as an attempt to alter the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo.
The 63rd U.N. General Assembly will convene in mid-September this year, at which time Taiwan is expected to make another bid for participation.
Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Henry Chen emphasized today that the government is still negotiating with the U.S. and Taiwan's diplomatic allies over the details of this year's bid.
Chen said that Deputy Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia will elaborate on the details on Friday.

Senior foreign ministry sources who did not want to be identified also confirmed to CNA that this year's bid will avoid the name dispute. They said this year's bid will follow the principles of "pragmatism and flexibility, " in line with Ma Ying-jeou's call for a "diplomatic truce" with China.
Meanwhile, the DPP's legislative caucus blasted Ma's plan in a press conference today, arguing that the government should continue to bid for full U.N. membership under the name "Taiwan."

DPP Legislator Wong Chin-chu criticized President Ma Ying-jeou for emphasizing his Taiwanese identity on the campaign trail earlier this year, but then downplaying it after winning the presidency in March.
Also today, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen criticized the government, urging it to consider carefully what type of U.N. bid would best suit the nation's interests and its people's common aspirations.

Tsai said that the KMT's thinking does not meet the needs of a majority in Taiwan. She urged the KMT to conduct a comprehensive review of its China policy, its stance on Taiwan's sovereignty and its position on the country's drive to join international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Uproar at plan to hold inquests in secret
Inquests that are deemed a risk to national security by the Government would be held in secret in future under proposed powers to come before the House of Lords this autumn.

DOC.HEADLINE: Large waistline increases health risks: foundation report

TEXT.P: One way to prevent high blood pressure, diabetes and abnormal blood lipid levels is to reduce the waistline, according to a report released Tuesday by the Health Foundation of Millenary Love.
The report says that the foundation asked Shih Hsin University to conduct a survey in late July by interviewing 517 patients aged 40 to 54.

The survey found that 80 percent of the respondents knew that they were a high- risk group that could be affected by various disorders, including coronary artery disease, atherosclerosis, cerebral congestion, stroke, diabetes, kidney disease, fatty liver and heart failure.

However, the study found that 50 percent of them did not know what was meant by metabolic syndrome -- a combination of medical disorders that increase the risk of developing diabetes and cardiovascular disease.

Symptoms of metabolic syndrome include a large waistline, high blood pressure, high blood sugar levels, abnormal triglyceride levels, and abnormal high density lipoprotein cholesterol levels. If someone has three or more such symptoms, they have metabolic syndrome and a higher risk of suffering from life-threatening illnesses.

The results of the survey also showed that nearly 90 percent of the patients were ignorant of the normal levels of blood pressure, blood sugar and blood fat, and that nearly 70 percent did not know the normal healthy waistline measurements, with 43 percent believing that waist measurements are not important.

Sun Lu-chien, a board director of the foundation, pointed out that according to statistics released by the Cabinet-level Department of Health in 2007, people under 70 who contracted cerebral vascular diabetes, diabetes, heart disease and other metabolic syndrome-related disorders lived 12.7 years shorter than average.

"Men should keep their waistlines at less than 90 cm, and for women, the waist measurements should be less than 80 cm," she said, adding that it is important to maintain a healthy diet and exercise regularly to keep the blood pressure, blood sugar and blood fat at normal levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung to subsidize school lunches for disadvantaged students

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City Council passed a law Tuesday to provide lunch subsidies to aboriginal elementary and junior high school students from low-income families.

According to the new law, indigenous students from families with a total income of less than 2.5 times the municipal government stipulated monthly living expenses for an individual, or NT$27,478 (US$881.50), will qualify for the subsidized lunch program.

Ateng Ingay, head of the municipal government's Commission of Indigenous Affairs, said that about 90 percent of the more than 1,820 aboriginal elementary and junior high students in the southern port city will benefit from the program set to be launched from the start of the new school semester in September.

Mayor Chen Chu said that providing nutritional lunches for aboriginal elementary and junior high schol students is consistent with her governing philosophy, adding that she strongly supports the new program aimed at helping one of the city's disadvantaged groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese fishermen's activity area to be expanded

TEXT.P: The activity area for Chinese sailors at an Ilan port has been expanded, the first step in a nationwide effort to improve facilities for such sailors, a fishing official said Tuesday.
Sha Chih-i, director-general of the Fisheries Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, said that Nanfang-ao port had expanded its activity area for Chinese sailors.

He made the announcement after President Ma Ying-jeou said earlier today at a national fisheries conference that the government has agreed to expand areas set aside for Chinese sailors and fisherman at ports island-wide.
The activity area expansion project at Nanfang-ao was completed Aug. 5, Sha said.

Nanfang-ao is the first port to complete its expansion. A similar expansion at Wuci Port will be completed by the end of this year, while the reception center at Badouzih fishing port in Keelung will expand next year, Sha said.

Sha noted that Nanfang-ao's reception center for Chinese sailors was previously located at the end of the port, next to a checkpoint. After complaints from the fishermen and negotiations, fishing officials decided to expand the reception area to 120 meters by 50 meters.
The Fisheries Agency is also willing to provide sports equipment for the sailors and fishermen, Sha said.
According to Sha, the next stage of construction is to drape a canopy over the activity area in order to keep out rain and wind.

DOC.HEADLINE: New cervical cancer vaccine hits market

TEXT.P: The country's second cervical cancer vaccine went on sale Tuesday, providing local women with one more choice of protection against the disease.

The new vaccine, called "Cervarix, " is recommended for females between the ages of 10 and 25. It joins "Gardasil, " another vaccine that hit the market two years ago and is for females aged 9 to 26, according to Chow Song-nan, an obstetrics and gynecology doctor at National Taiwan University Hospital.
The two vaccines spur development of antibodies against human papillomavirus (HPV) types 16 and 18, which cause most cases of cervical cancer.

The new vaccine also blocks infections resulting from HPV types 31, 45, and 52 -- also associated with cervical cancer -- and protects against HPV types 6 and 11, which cause genital warts, Chow said.

As with Gardasil, Cervarix vaccination includes three doses within six months. Complete vaccination costs NT$12,000 (US$385) . Recipients must pay the full cost, as the vaccine is not covered by National Health Insurance.

The Department of Health (DOH) estimated that free nationwide vaccination for 13 -year-old female teenagers would cost NT$1 billion. The Legislative Yuan has rejected a much smaller NT$2.5 million program to provide subsidies for vaccinations.
Currently, women aged 30 or older can receive free, annual Pap smear tests for cervical cancer under National Health Insurance. Chow said such tests are critical for early discovery of the disease.
However, only 30 percent of Taiwanese women have taken the examination in the past 10 years, he said.
According to DOH statistics, every year 5,700 women in Taiwan are diagnosed with cervical cancer, and about 900 die from the disease.
Chow urged females to get vaccinated and get routine cervical Pap smears.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travel warning issued for Mauritania

TEXT.P: The Taiwan government recently issued a travel warning for Mauritania due to the unstable situation in the Northwestern African country, an official of the Bureau of Consular Affairs said Tuesday.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has issued a "red alert" based on the general situation in the desert country, suggesting that it should be viewed as an unsafe destination, the official said.
According to a report by the Associated Press, Mauritania' s renegade army staged a coup Aug. 6 and detained President Sidi Ould Cheikh Abdallahi and Prime Minister Yahya Ould Ahmed Waqef.
Mauritania's radio and television stations have been off the air since the coup, the report stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Newlyweds to benefit from zero-percent mortgage rate

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) might offer two-year interest-free mortgages to eligible young couples in the hope of boosting the marriage rate, MOI officials said at a Tuesday workshop.
The new initiative originated with President Ma Ying-jeou during his presidential election campaign earlier this year.
"The plan has been mapped out in order to encourage young people to get married and have babies, " Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi said at the workshop.

According to the draft plan, newlyweds can file applications twice for loans to a maximum of NT$2 million with zero-percent interest. Within two years of the registration of their marriage, the couple can apply for their first interest- free loan, and can apply again when they have children, or adult children who are still in school.

The eligible applicants will benefit from the interest-free mortgage for two years, with the government providing an annual NT$68,500 subsidy per household, said Huang Ching-mao, acting director of the MOI's Construction and Planning Agency.
From the third year onward, applicants will have to pay low interest rates, with a subsidy of NT$13,200 from the government.
Those who prefer to rent a house or apartment can also benefit from the new program with a maximum monthly subsidy of NT$3,600 per household for two years, he added.

To qualify for the interest-free financing, at least one member of the couple should have a full-time job, and there are quota limitations -- 10,000 for home buyers and 20,000 for rental subsidies in the initial stage.
According to MOI statistics, a total of 131,851 marriages were registered last year.

In order to help people in real need, "rich people, " which the MOI defined as those with annual incomes of more than NT$2.18 million in Taipei City, or NT$1.57 million in Kaohsiung City, or NT$1.4 million in the rest of the country, will be excluded from the program, Huang noted.
In addition, the value of the property that newlyweds plan to buy should not exceed 10 times the couple's annual income, Huang said.
Liao said the draft of the plan will be sent to the Executive Yuan for review and approval and is expected to be put into effect next January.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government's waste recycling rate climbing: EPA

TEXT.P: Government agencies have made steady progress in waste recycling in recent years, with the recycling rate climbing from 72.6 percent in 2002 to 76 percent in 2007, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Tuesday.
Under the resources-saving campaign, government agencies have also saved considerable amounts of money, said Ho Soon-ching, director-general of the EPA's Department of Waste Management.

She added that from 2006 to 2007, with the assistance of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , the industrial sector recycled and re-used industrial waste to a total value of NT$80.5 billion, while the TEF-LCD and chip- manufacturing industries saved NT$640 million in prime costs of TFT-LCDs under the guidance of the National Science Council.

Ho noted that recycled silicon was an particularly important item among the various types of recycled industrial waste, as there is strong global demand due to the development of the photonic and solar energy industries.
In April, the MOEA designated waste silicon as industrial waste that should be recycled.
According to the EPA, the price of silicon on the international market has risen from NT$2-3 million per metric ton in 2007 to NT$8-9 million at present.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ratio of Chinese lawbreakers in Taiwan down

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese coming to Taiwan nearly doubled between 2004 and 2007, but the ratio that engaged in illegal activities while here dropped to 0.86 percent from 5.63 percent during the same period, according to statistics released Tuesday by the National Immigration Agency.

The officials made the remarks on the same day that the Executive Yuan held a meeting on law and order in which an Interior Ministry official reported on Chinese people coming to Taiwan to engage in illegal activities.

They noted that the number of Chinese entering Taiwan legally reached 139,344 in 2004. With the ever-closer exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the number increased to 279,571 last year.
The illegal activities include illegal working, overstaying their visas, prostitution, posing as relatives of Taiwanese citizens and bogus marriages.
The number of illegal activities dropped to 2,392 in 2007 from 7,844 in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier concerned about Chinese lawbreakers in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan expressed concern Tuesday about Chinese people coming to Taiwan illegally and instructed the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) to pay attention to the matter.
"If there is a need to amend the law, government agencies should coordinate their views and include them in discussions under a cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue mechanism," the premier said.

He made the remarks after presiding over the first meeting on law and order since his Cabinet's May 20 inauguration during which he listened to a report from Vice Interior Minister Chien Tai-lang on the management of Chinese people visiting Taiwan.
Chien reported that since the opening of cross-strait exchanges in the late 1980s, Chinese people have had more channels to access Taiwan, although violations are also frequent.

The most common approaches for illegal entry are marriages of convenience, visits to non-existent relatives, posing as fishermen, furnishing false papers, bogus tourism and using legal professional exchanges.
Chien also said that since Taiwan's opening to Chinese professionals, 500,000 Chinese have obtained entry in the areas of trade, business, culture, education and sports.
However, some of them have withheld information about serving in the Communist Party of China or the People's Liberation Army, he said.
The ministry has found that some of the professionals were current or former members of the National People's Congress or had served in the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.
Often, the individuals or institutions that invited them failed to verify or disclose their positions, and the ministry will keep tabs on the issue, Chien said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Russian President Halts Military Action in Georgia
Russian President Dmitri Medvedev said Tuesday he was halting military operations in Georgia because they had accomplished their end, though explosions continued to rattle the now largely abandoned town of Gori.
The Washington Times:Russia halts military action in Georgia
Russian President Dmitri Medvedev ordered a halt to military action in Georgia Tuesday, saying it had punished Georgia and brought security for civilians and Russian peacekeepers in the breakaway South Ossetia region.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Russia Says It Has Ordered Halt to Georgia Military Action
President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia announced Tuesday that he had ordered a halt to his countryzs military operation in Georgia, although he did not say that troops were pulling out and Russian forces were still authorized to fire on enemies in South Ossetia.
The Wall Street Journal:Russia Halts Attack on Georgia
Russian President Dmitri Medvedev said Tuesday that Russia is ending its current military operation against Georgian forces because it has achieved its goals. But Mr. Medvedev, speaking on state television, stopped short of saying Russia would withdraw its troops from Georgia.

DOC.HEADLINE: New research on breast cancer stem cells offers hope for vaccine

TEXT.P: Researchers at Academia Sinica -- Taiwan's leading research organization -- have discovered that the presence of hexasaccharide Globo H and its precursor, Gb5, in cancer stem cells might help scientists develop a vaccine for breast cancer.

According to a news release posted on the Academia Sinica Web site, Globo H has been used as a vehicle in developing an immunotherapeutic vaccine for breast cancer and has successfully passed phase one clinical trials in the United States.

Led by Academia Sinica President Wong Chi-huey and Alice Yu, associate director of the Genomics Research Center, a team of researchers conducted a series of tests to see if the breast cancer vaccine can also target the cancer stem cells.

Since 2003, researchers around the world have been looking for a cure for breast cancer by targeting cancer stem cells, which possess the ability of stem cells to multiply and differentiate into their progenitors, display resistance to chemotherapy and radiation therapy, and could be the root cause for relapse and metastasis of cancerous tumors.

The team's innovative approach has proved quite successful. Using flow cytometry to examine tumor tissue obtained from 53 breast cancer patients at the Tri- Service General Hospital in Taipei, the researchers found that both Globo H and Gb5 can be found in the breast cancer stem cells.

The results of the study show that of all the tests done, Globo H is 61 percent positive on regular breast cancer cells and 20 percent positive on breast cancer stem cells, while Gb5 is 77.5 percent positive on regular breast cancer cells and 62.5 percent on breast cancer stem cells.
"The team is thrilled by the results, which suggest that the Globo H vaccine will not only target the cancer cells, but also the cancer stem cells, in a one- for-all raid," the news release said.

"Researchers are particularly excited about the discovery of Gb5 in cancer cells, since the results shows that Gb5 is even more easily spotted on both regular breast cancer cells and stem cells, indicating that Gb5 may be another candidate for cancer therapeutics study," it added.
In animal experiments, the researchers proved that the Globo H vaccine can induce antibodies against both Globo H and Gb5.
In the second stage of the research, the Globo H breast cancer vaccine will be used in clinical trials on humans by a pharmaceutical company in Taiwan, according to the researchers.
The results of the study were published in the online Early Edition of Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan' s Lu powers way into third round of Olympic tennis
Weightlifter bags Taiwan's second medal in Beijing Olympics

TEXT.P: Taiwan won its second medal Tuesday when weightlifter Lu Ying-chi took bronze in the women's 63-kg category with a total lift of 231 kg on the fourth day of the Beijing Olympics.
Lu, 23, lifted 104 kg in the snatch and 127 kg in the clean and jerk section of the event.

Pak Hyon Suk won North Korea's first weightlifting medal of the Olympics in the event, lifting a total of 241 kg for the gold, while Irina Nekrassova of Kazakhstan took the silver with a total lift of 240 kg.
Lu attributed her victory to her coach Liao Chih-ing and visiting coach Zhang Jiamin from China.
She also said she was "caught by surprise" by the bronze, saying that her coach had told her she would only get eighth place, so that she felt quite relaxed in the clean and jerk event.
Lu said she had made a lot of improvement over the past year due to "continued hard training" and great assistance from Zhang.
Former Minister of Education Ovid Tseng was on hand to witness Lu's victory and said he "almost wanted to cry" when Lu was awarded the bronze.
Another Taiwanese weightlifter, Chen Wei-ling, won bronze in the women's 48-kg category Saturday.

Cheng Chih-lang, a weightlifting coach who first spotted Lu when he was scouting for potential talent in Pingtung County in southern Taiwan, said that Lu is quiet and lives a simple life that revolves around training.
"She goes after her goals singlemindedly, " Cheng said.
He also expressed hope that the government and private sectors will attach more importance to weightlifting, noting that it is not a popular sport in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: President sets off on first state visit

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou embarked Tuesday on his first state visit since he took office three months ago, in a bid to strengthen relations with Taiwan's allies in Latin America.
Ma and an 80-member delegation, who left on a regular commercial flight, will attend the inaugurations of the presidents of Paraguay and the Dominican Republic, two of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies.

Ma will hold talks with other leaders of Taiwan's diplomatic allies during the eight-day state visit to the region, and is scheduled to return to Taiwan Aug. 19, with an overnight stopover in San Francisco.
In a brief speech before his departure, Ma said his trip is different in several ways from those made by former President Chen Shui-bian.
First, he said, cross-Taiwan Strait relations, which were on the verge of breaking down during Chen's tenure, have improved under his administration.

Ma cited the visits to Taiwan since July 4 by hundreds of Chinese tourists traveling on the first ever regular direct cross-strait charter flights after decades' tension as an example of the improvement in bilateral relations.
Ma said the new government is adopting a concept of "workable diplomacy," to cement ties with Taiwan's allies and to rebuild mutual trust with countries that do not have formal relations with Taiwan.
Another difference is that his stopover in San Francisco will be "purely for transit" purposes, he said.
There is no need to take any actions incongruous with a transit stop, as Taiwan has established good communications and mutual trust with Washington since he took office, Ma said.
He referred to former President Chen Shui-bian's high-profile transits in the United States which caused tension among Taiwan, the U.S., and China.

The president said he is pleased to see that Taiwan's relations with Washington have improved alongside Taipei-Beijing relations, and he expressed the hope that his trip will help to carve out more international space for Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese tennis, badminton players advance at Beijing Olympics

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei tennis players Chuang Chia-jung and Chan Young-jan defeated their French rivals Razzano Virginie and Cornet Alize Tuesday to advance to the second round of the women's doubles at the Beijing Olympics.

They won the match 7-6, 6-7, 7-5. Meanwhile, Hsieh Yu-hsing, a badminton player from Taiwan, defeated Wong Choong Hann from Malaysia 14-21, 21-17, 21-18 to advance to the quarter-finals in the men's singles at the Beijing Olympics.
He will nest play China's Chen Jin.

DOC.HEADLINE: New research on breast cancer stem cells offers hope for vaccine

TEXT.P: Researchers at Academia Sinica -- Taiwan's leading research organization -- have discovered that the presence of hexasaccharide Globo H and its precursor, Gb5, in cancer stem cells might help scientists develop a vaccine for breast cancer.

According to a news release posted on the Academia Sinica Web site, Globo H has been used as a vehicle in developing an immunotherapeutic vaccine for breast cancer and has successfully passed phase one clinical trials in the United States.

Led by Academia Sinica President Wong Chi-huey and Alice Yu, associate director of the Genomics Research Center, a team of researchers conducted a series of tests to see if the breast cancer vaccine can also target the cancer stem cells.

Since 2003, researchers around the world have been looking for a cure for breast cancer by targeting cancer stem cells, which possess the ability of stem cells to multiply and differentiate into their progenitors, display resistance to chemotherapy and radiation therapy, and could be the root cause for relapse and metastasis of cancerous tumors.

The team's innovative approach has proved quite successful. Using flow cytometry to examine tumor tissue obtained from 53 breast cancer patients at the Tri- Service General Hospital in Taipei, the researchers found that both Globo H and Gb5 can be found in the breast cancer stem cells.

The results of the study show that of all the tests done, Globo H is 61 percent positive on regular breast cancer cells and 20 percent positive on breast cancer stem cells, while Gb5 is 77.5 percent positive on regular breast cancer cells and 62.5 percent on breast cancer stem cells.
"The team is thrilled by the results, which suggest that the Globo H vaccine will not only target the cancer cells, but also the cancer stem cells, in a one- for-all raid," the news release said.

"Researchers are particularly excited about the discovery of Gb5 in cancer cells, since the results shows that Gb5 is even more easily spotted on both regular breast cancer cells and stem cells, indicating that Gb5 may be another candidate for cancer therapeutics study," it added.
In animal experiments, the researchers proved that the Globo H vaccine can induce antibodies against both Globo H and Gb5.
In the second stage of the research, the Globo H breast cancer vaccine will be used in clinical trials on humans by a pharmaceutical company in Taiwan, according to the researchers.
The results of the study were published in the online Early Edition of Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan' s Lu powers way into third round of Olympic tennis
Weightlifter bags Taiwan's second medal in Beijing Olympics

TEXT.P: Taiwan won its second medal Tuesday when weightlifter Lu Ying-chi took bronze in the women's 63-kg category with a total lift of 231 kg on the fourth day of the Beijing Olympics.
Lu, 23, lifted 104 kg in the snatch and 127 kg in the clean and jerk section of the event.

Pak Hyon Suk won North Korea's first weightlifting medal of the Olympics in the event, lifting a total of 241 kg for the gold, while Irina Nekrassova of Kazakhstan took the silver with a total lift of 240 kg.
Lu attributed her victory to her coach Liao Chih-ing and visiting coach Zhang Jiamin from China.
She also said she was "caught by surprise" by the bronze, saying that her coach had told her she would only get eighth place, so that she felt quite relaxed in the clean and jerk event.
Lu said she had made a lot of improvement over the past year due to "continued hard training" and great assistance from Zhang.
Former Minister of Education Ovid Tseng was on hand to witness Lu's victory and said he "almost wanted to cry" when Lu was awarded the bronze.
Another Taiwanese weightlifter, Chen Wei-ling, won bronze in the women's 48-kg category Saturday.

Cheng Chih-lang, a weightlifting coach who first spotted Lu when he was scouting for potential talent in Pingtung County in southern Taiwan, said that Lu is quiet and lives a simple life that revolves around training.
"She goes after her goals singlemindedly, " Cheng said.
He also expressed hope that the government and private sectors will attach more importance to weightlifting, noting that it is not a popular sport in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: President sets off on first state visit

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou embarked Tuesday on his first state visit since he took office three months ago, in a bid to strengthen relations with Taiwan's allies in Latin America.
Ma and an 80-member delegation, who left on a regular commercial flight, will attend the inaugurations of the presidents of Paraguay and the Dominican Republic, two of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies.

Ma will hold talks with other leaders of Taiwan's diplomatic allies during the eight-day state visit to the region, and is scheduled to return to Taiwan Aug. 19, with an overnight stopover in San Francisco.
In a brief speech before his departure, Ma said his trip is different in several ways from those made by former President Chen Shui-bian.
First, he said, cross-Taiwan Strait relations, which were on the verge of breaking down during Chen's tenure, have improved under his administration.

Ma cited the visits to Taiwan since July 4 by hundreds of Chinese tourists traveling on the first ever regular direct cross-strait charter flights after decades' tension as an example of the improvement in bilateral relations.
Ma said the new government is adopting a concept of "workable diplomacy," to cement ties with Taiwan's allies and to rebuild mutual trust with countries that do not have formal relations with Taiwan.
Another difference is that his stopover in San Francisco will be "purely for transit" purposes, he said.
There is no need to take any actions incongruous with a transit stop, as Taiwan has established good communications and mutual trust with Washington since he took office, Ma said.
He referred to former President Chen Shui-bian's high-profile transits in the United States which caused tension among Taiwan, the U.S., and China.

The president said he is pleased to see that Taiwan's relations with Washington have improved alongside Taipei-Beijing relations, and he expressed the hope that his trip will help to carve out more international space for Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 13, or the 13th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The British formally take over the colony at the Cape of Good Hope, located at the southernmost tip of the African continent, from the Dutch.
1860: Annie Oakley, the American sharpshooter who could hit the edge of a playing card at 30 paces, is born as Phoebe Anne Oakley Moses.
1898: American forces led by George Dewey capture Manila during the Spanish- American War.
1899: Hollywood film director Alfred Hitchcock is born in England. He directed such classics as "Psycho" and "The Birds."
1910: Florence Nightingale, the British nurse known as "the Lady with the Lamp," dies at the age of 90. She organized and directed a unit of field nurses during the Crimean War and is considered the founder of modern nursing.
1923: Mustafa Kemal Ataturk is elected president of Turkey.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander in chief of China's Nationalist Revolutionary Forces, resigns in order to bring about solidarity between the Nanking and Hankow factions of the Kuomintang.
1927: Japanese troops launch a major attack on Shanghai and are met with stiff resistance from Chinese defenders.
1942: The United States and Britain decide to carry out joint research on the atomic bomb.
1949: Mao Zedong names Beijing as Communist China's capital.
1960: The Central African Republic gains independence from France.
1961: Communist East Germany begins the erection of the Berlin Wall, drawing strong protests from Western nations.
1967: Fifteen grand justices nominated by President Chiang Kai-shek are approved by the Republic of China's Control Yuan.
1969: Communist China and the Soviet Union accuse each other of sending troops across their Central Asian border and inflicting heavy casualties.
1974: Mort Young, deputy editor-in-chief of Hearst Newspapers in the United States, arrives in Taipei for a two-week visit.
1975: An eight-member Taiwan dance troupe leaves for La Paz to perform at celebrations marking Bolivia's independence day.
1976: Over 140 youths from 20 nations join in the opening ceremony of the International Youth Recreation Tour to the Republic of China sponsored by the China Youth Corps.
1976: The ROC Cabinet approves extension of the Sino-Uruguayan Agreement on Agricultural Cooperation for two years.
1978: A building serving as the Beirut headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Front and containing the offices of their rivals, Al-Fatah, is ripped apart by a bomb, leaving some 150 people dead.
1984: Six mainland Chinese freedom seekers freed by the Korean government arrive in Taipei. The six hijacked a Communist Chinese Trident plane from Shenyang, Manchuria, to Seoul, South Korea, on May 5, 1983.
1989: Two hot air balloons collide in the worst-ever hot air balloon disaster in Australia, with one of the balloons plunging 182 meters to the ground, killing 12 people.
1993: A hotel collapses in Thailand, killing over 120 people.
1999: The Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan estimates that the ROC's economic growth rate will reach 5.5 percent for the year.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian and his 200-member entourage leave Taipei, beginning a 13-day visit to six states in the Caribbean, Central America and Africa.
2001: Academia Sinica member George C. Tiao becomes the first scholar and the first ethnic Chinese to receive both the prestigious Wilks Memorial Award and the Julius Shiskin Award in statistics in the same year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Trust is the law of God. Acquired truth is the law of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma arrives at Los Angeles in low profile transit stop

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou was extended diplomatic courtesies consistent with visiting foreign dignitaries after arriving in Los Angeles for a low profile transit stop ahead of a six-day trip through Latin America.

After disembarking from his commercial China Airlines flight, Ma was greeted by Taiwan's representative to the United States Jason Yuan, American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond Burghardt and Director-General of Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Los Angeles Kung Chung-chen.

He then proceeded through the "Pershing Gate, " a protocol gate on the edge of the airport used by foreign dignitaries when visiting the U.S., and was then whisked away in a limousine without passing through customs.

In keeping with Ma's desire to keep the overnight transit stop low profile, no Taiwanese expatriates were at the airport to welcome the president, but China Airlines did set up a red carpet and red banner at the Pershing Gate to greet the president.
Burghardt seemed pleased at the understated arrangements, and was quoted by TECO senior press officer Derek Hsu as saying that "I have nothing to complain about."
Hsu stressed, however, that despite Ma's decision to stay low profile, the courtesies he received were no different than for other heads of state.

Ma is stopping in Los Angeles en route to Paraguay and the Dominican Republic, where he will attend the inaugurations of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo on Aug. 15 and Dominican Republic President-elect Leonel Fernandez on Aug. 16.

The president said many times prior to the trip that his stopovers in the U.S. are simply for the purpose of transit and will not do anything that conflicts with the goal -- part of his effort to rebuild the mutual trust between Washington and Taipei that deteriorated in the final years of the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration.
Ma's predecessor Chen Shui-bian often made use of state visits, including transits through the U.S., to shift Taiwan's political struggle over its identity to a broader international stage.
In keeping with Ma's desire to maintain a low profile, he flew a commercial flight from Taipei to Los Angeles with a streamlined entourage of 44 people.
At the same time, 200 Taiwanese expatriates gathered at the Westin Hotel Los Angeles, where Ma is planned to stay, to welcome him, rather than waiting for the president at the airport.
The president waved to them as he entered the hotel, Hsu said.
Hsu noted that around 100 DPP supporters were also at the hotel, and disparigingly shouted "ma-tong" -- meaning toilet bowl in Chinese -- at Ma.

Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi told reporters earlier that Ma will remain in the hotel during his stopover in Los Angeles and will not make any public appearances, a move that he said is aimed at "rebuilding a new image of Taiwan in the international community, and prove that Taiwan is trustworthy and would keep its promise not to be a troublemaker."
Wang said the president will have dinner with several "friends" in the U.S. and have telephone conversations with U.S. senators and congressmen.
"The aim is to simplify the transit stop instead of manipulating it as transit diplomacy," he said.

Ma is scheduled to leave Los Angeles for Paraguay at 6 a.m. Wednesday U.S. West Coast time. On the way, he will make a refueling stop in Panama where he will meet with Panamanian President Martin Torrijos on the way.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
President keeping tabs on Taiwans Olympic team during state visit

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou is keeping tabs on the fortunes of Taiwan's Olympic team in Beijing during his overseas trip, and was informed during his flight to Los Angeles that Taiwan had won a second bronze medal in weightlifting, a Presidential Office spokesman said.

"The president was notified of the good news via a telegram sent by the China Airlines and was delighted to know Taiwan won another medal, " spokesman Wang Yu-chi told reporters during a regularly scheduled China Airlines Boeing 747-400 flight from Taipei to Los Angeles.
"He also sent a congratulatory telegram right away to express his regards to the family of the winner," Wang said.
Taiwan won its second medal at the Beijing Olympics Tuesday when weightlifter Lu Ying-chi took bronze in the women's 63-kilogram category with a total lift of 231 kg.

Ma was seated in the first class section of the China Airlines commercial flight, accompanied by other high-ranking government officials such as Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou, National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi and Chen Tain-jy, minister of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.
There was a female passenger traveling along with the president and his entourage in the first class section.

Another 84-year-old lady surnamed Wang sitting in economy class told reporters that she specifically changed her flight to this one after knowing that the president would take the flight for his first state visit.

On his first state visit since taking office May 20, Ma will attend the inauguration ceremonies of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo on Aug. 15 and Dominican Republic President-elect Leonel Fernandez on Aug. 16.

Given that Lugo has said many times he wants to switch diplomatic recognition to China, Ma's eight-day visit is seen as a bid to cement ties with Paraguay and the Caribbean country and a test of whether Taiwan and China will set aside their competition in the international arena.

After taking office, Ma said he would seek a "diplomatic truce" with China in an attempt to end the so-called "checkbook diplomacy" conducted by both sides of the Taiwan Strait, in which Taiwan and China solicit recognition by offering large sums of money to poor countries.
Apart from 44 government officials and staff, May was also accompanied by 36 journalists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Imported dengue fever cases increasing

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) on Wednesday advised travelers to Southeast Asia to take proper precautionary measures against mosquito bites as an especially high number of imported dengue fever cases has been recorded so far this year.
According to CDC statistics, 107 Taiwanese residents have been infected by the mosquito-borne disease overseas this year, including 59 cases recorded since the beginning of summer.

The number exceeded the 104 cases recorded during the first eight months of 2007, when a total of 179 cases were recorded for the whole year. It was also higher than the 91 cases recorded in 2004 and the 104 cases in 2005 and was comparable to the 109 cases in 2006.
The situation makes it likely that the number of imported dengue fever cases will hit a new high for this year, said CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi.

Shih warned that patients infected with dengue fever overseas can cause an outbreak in Taiwan if they are not detected at airport quarantine checkpoints upon their return, if they return to Taiwan during the highly contagious period running from the day before onset of symptoms to five days after the onset, and if there are Aedes aegypti mosquitos -- the primary vector of the dengue virus -- in their neighborhood.

In July, 10 members of a local religious group were infected with dengue fever while taking part in volunteer relief efforts in Myanmar in the aftermath of Cyclone Nargis, marking the first case of mass overseas dengue fever infections to be recorded in Taiwan in recent years.
The cases were only discovered after one of the patients sought treatment at a local hospital after returning home.
According to Shih, the dengue virus was later transmitted by mosquitos from one of the patients to a woman and her daughter living in the neighborhood.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taiwan Culinary Exhibition to open Friday

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taiwan Culinary Exhibition, which opens Friday and will run through Aug. 18 at the Taipei World Trade Center, will help determine how Taiwan promotes its cuisine around the world, the Tourism Bureau said Wednesday.

Influential gourmets from France, Germany, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, Singapore and other countries have been invited to take part in the activity to help select typical Taiwanese dishes, snacks and desserts most suitable to be promoted in the rest of the world, said officials of the bureau, which is under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

A photo competition featuring Taiwan's gastronomy will also be held on the sidelines of the food festival as part of the government's efforts to promote the country's food abroad and tourism in Taiwan.
Following the warm response to the competition last year, the bureau decided to add more pizazz to the event to arouse greater public interest this time around, the officials added.
Members of the public are welcome to participate in the photo contest, which is divided into five categories -- noodles, snacks, desserts, speciality food and table dishes.
Winners will win awards, including iPods and MP3s, and their photos will be used as exhibition materials by the bureau to help sell Taiwan's fine food both at home and abroad, bureau officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT chairman hints at warming Taiwan-U.S. relations

TEXT.P: American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt strongly hinted at a dinner for President Ma Ying-jeou in Los Angeles Tuesday that bilateral relations between Taiwan and the United States have warmed up considerably in the past eight months.

The last time I welcomed Taiwan's president was on the (freezing) tarmac in Alaska in January and I'm happy that today it is in Los Angeles where the temperature is 82 degrees Fahrenheit, Burghardt was quoted as saying at the dinner by a government official, who refused to be named.
The official declined to elaborate on Burghardt's statement, asking instead the media to draw its own conclusions.

Burghardt, the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of official ties, was referring to the stopover made by Ma's predecessor, Chen Shui-bian, in Anchorage Jan. 13 on his way to Guatemala to attend the inauguration of then Guatemalan President-elect Alvaro Colom.

Washington forced Chen to transit in Alaska rather than on the U.S. continent because of its displeasure with Chen's push for a referendum on joining the United Nations under the name "Taiwan, " which the U.S. called provocative and unnecessary.
At the dinner, at which Ma was joined by 50 overseas Taiwanese leaders, congressmen, and Ma's American friends, Burghardt said interactions between Taiwan and the U.S. were good.

Ma arrived at Los Angeles on Tuesday at 2 p.m. U.S. West Coast time en route to attend the inaugurations of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo on Aug. 15 and Dominican Republic President-elect Leonel Fernandez on Aug. 16.
Due to an agreement between the the U.S. and Taiwan, Ma is making no public appearances during his overnight stopover in Los Angeles, and reporters were denied access to any of his activities.
Prior to the dinner, Ma met with four congressmen and had telephone conversations with four senators and six congressmen, with whom he discussed his "modus vivendi " approach.

Ma has proposed adiplomatic trucewith China, which he said means Taiwan and China should stop their longstanding diplomatic tug-of-war in which both sides of the Taiwan Strait tried to lure each other's allies by offering large sums of foreign aid.

He also floated the notion ofworkable diplomacyormodus vivendiunder which Taiwan would engage China in discussing the country's international space as the island cements diplomatic relations with its remaining 23 allies.

"Cross-strait relations are developing in a good direction. Taiwan will develop its relations with the U.S. while it continues to improve its ties with China,Ma was quoted as saying in the meetings and conversations with the U.S. politicians by the official.

Ma also reiterated that Taiwan is committed to purchasing defensive weapons from the U.S. and said that if possible, the country hopes to sign a free trade agreement with the U.S. in the future, according to the official.
In keeping with Mas desire to keep the overnight transit stop low profile, the official refused to confirm the identity of the congressmen who spoke with the president.
He would only say that Ma did not leave the hotel in which he stayed and would meet with several Taiwanese international students in L.A. later Tuesday evening local time.
Although the president feels that both Taiwan and China as well as Taiwan and the U.S. have established mutual trust, he decided to stay low key, as it is his first state visit,the official said.

Ma is scheduled to leave Los Angeles for Paraguay at 6 a.m. Wednesday U.S. West Coast time. On the way, he will make a refueling stop in Panama where he will meet Panamanian President Martin Torrijos.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former president denies tabloid report about money laundering

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian denied Wednesday a tabloid report that he and his wife remitted NT$300 million (US$9.62 million) overseas in 2006 through his family for the purposes of laundering money.

Dismissing the sensational report through opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Gao Jyh-peng and his lawyer Lee Sheng-chen, Chen said the article was a conspiracy engineered by prosecutors to try to sway public opinion over a "state affairs fund" embezzlement case they are currently investigating.

In a report published in its latest issue, Next weekly magazine said former first lady Wu Shu-jen closed bank accounts belonging to herself and her husband as well as several others created under the names of her son Chen Chih-chung and her daughter Chen Hsing-yu that were used for stock trading, soon after the exposure of the "state affairs fund" case in 2006.
Wu then remitted an amount totaling NT$300 million overseas through various bank accounts belonging to her daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching and her family, according to the magazine.
It said the situation was discovered when prosecutors were scrutinizing the bank accounts of the former first family as part of their probe into the high-profile case.

Wu was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.

Gao, however, said the report obviously "goes against common sense" because the assets of the former first family were under a trust during Chen's presidency, which prevented them from managing the assets on their own.
"Had the trust been canceled (before Chen's term ended in May 2008), everybody would have known about it long ago," Gao said.
Moreover, Gao said, stocks registered under the names of Chen Chih-chung and Chen Hsing-yu have lost value for a long period of time and therefore have not been sold.

Unconvinced by Gao's explanation, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Wu Yu-sheng urged Chen to make public the deposits and withdrawals of bank accounts belonging to members of the former first family for public scrutiny.
Chen, who had immunity from prosecution while in office, was named as a co- defendant in the "state affairs fund" case as soon as he stepped down from the presidency May 20.
On Tuesday, he was questioned by prosecutors for the second time since July.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's baseball team to appeal doping test result
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/08 16:01:02 (By Wu Hsie-chang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Olympic baseball team has decided to appeal the positive doping test result of Chang Tai-shan, one of the country's best hitters, Taiwan's Olympic delegation leader Tsai Szu-chueh said Wednesday in Beijing.
The test result of Chang's urine tube A, collected July 27, was confirmed positive Tuesday, one day before Taiwan opened the Olympic baseball tournament against the Netherlands.
Chang, who was dismayed over the test result, denied taking any banned substances, Tsai said, adding that Chang followed his doctor's instructions on taking his medicine.
Chang had been previously taking male fertility pills, but stopped using the medication before attending the Games, Tsai explained.
Tsai, nevertheless, questioned why Chang was able to pass a doping test at home during the Asian Baseball Championship and the Baseball World Cup in late 2007, but failed to pass the Olympic test.

The Taiwan team will soon file an appeal with the World Anti-Doping Agency -- commissioned by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to conduct a urine test on Taiwanese baseball players on July 27, Tsai said.
If Chang's B sample fails to pass another test to be conducted in Japan on Friday, Chang will be banned from international competition for the next two years, Tsai noted.
Chang is the only member of the baseball team whose urine test result was positive.
Taiwan did not have any substitutes available to take Chang's place, leaving with a 23-man roster to face the Netherlands.

DOC.HEADLINE: Researchers find new marker of liver cancer development

TEXT.P: Gene experts at Academia Sinica have spotted a new referential indicator of liver cancers related to the hepatitis B virus, and the findings may prove helpful to the invention of new diagnostic procedures, sources at the renowned institution said Wednesday.

The indicator, discovered by members of Academia Sinica's Genomics Research Center, involves a DNA examination of the genotype of hepatitis B virus. For example, if a patient is found to carry genotype C, the risks of cancer development will be as high as double that for those with genotype B.
Meanwhile, if mutations are found in the hepatitis B virus, the risks can increase or decrease, depending on which region develops mutations.
The risks are doubled if the mutation occurs in the basal core promoter; the risks will be reduced to the one-third of general standards if the mutated area is the precore region.

The scientific paper, written by the center's Yang Hwai-I, Chen Pei-Jer, Chen Ding-Shinn, Liaw Yun-Fan, and Chen Chien-Jen, will be published by Journal of the National Cancer Institute in its August 20 issue.

Chen Chien-Jen, a distinguished research fellow at the center and the former chief of the National Science Council, explained that the team had spotted an indicator in a previous study published in 2002, but it failed to provide a comprehensive explanation of liver cancer development.

"However, compared to normal people, those patients who are negative for E surface antigen still have relatively higher risks of liver cancers, which indicates that there should another more effective, accurate index for liver cancer diagnosis," said Chen Chien-Jen.
According to Academia Sinica, the team's study followed 4,155 participants from seven towns in Taiwan beginning in 1991.

After the study concluded in 2004, the researchers compared those who carried the DNA segments of hepatitis B virus in their blood and eventually developed liver cancer to the virus DNA carriers that did not develop cancer.
In the process, they found different genotypes of the hepatitis B virus that may be correlated to liver cancer development among patients infected with hepatitis B virus.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices flat on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed marginally lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 1.46 points, or 0.02 percent, to close at 7,292.34.
Finishing lower for the second consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 7,272.49 and fluctuated between 7,311.3 and 7,213.11.
A total of 4.12 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$112.41 billion (US$3.6 billion).

Three of eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.1 percent. Foodstuff issues advanced 0.4 percent and machinery and electronics shares were up 0.2 percent.

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 2.5 percent. Paper and pulp issues declined 1.5 percent, cement stocks dropped 1.4 percent, banking and financial shares lost 1 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares fell 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,073 to 1,018, with 441 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$4.78 billion, after being net buyers in the three previous sessions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Science park revenues top NT$1 trillion in H1 2008

TEXT.P: The total revenues of Taiwan's three science-based industrial parks amounted to NT$1.22 trillion (US$39.12 billion) during the first half of 2008, up 17.16 percent from the same period last year, according to statistics released Wednesday by the National Science Council (NSC).
The council predicted that revenues of the science parks are likely to reach NT$2.18 trillion for the whole year to hit a record high.

During the months January to June, revenues of the Hsinchu Science Park increased 4.25 percent year-on-year to NT$553.4 billion, those of the Southern Taiwan Science Park rose 30.53 percent to NT$301.42 billion, and those of the Central Taiwan Science Park jumped 51 percent to NT$167.38 billion.

Among the six major industries with operations in the parks, the semiconductor sector posted sales of NT$485.57 billion, accounting for 47.5 percent of the total, and the optroelectronics sector recorded sales of NT$451.98 billion, accounting for 44.22 percent of the total.

The sales of the bio-technology sector amounted to NT$3.77 billion, those of the precision machinery sector were valued at NT$19.57 billion, those of the computer and peripherals sector totaled NT$42.24 billion, and those of the communications sector amounted to NT$16.49 billion.

At the end of July 2008, the number of licensed manufacturers in the science parks totaled 691, including 444 in the Hsinchu Science Park, 157 in the Southern Taiwan Science Park and 90 in the Central Taiwan Science Park, according to the NSC.

The council said the government aims to expand the number of manufacturers in the science parks to 800 by 2011, with their total output reaching NT$3 trillion and total number of workers hitting 300,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan tops Netherlands in Olympic baseball opener

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Olympic baseball team rewarded the passion of its local fans Wednesday when it opened its Beijing Games campaign with a 5-0 victory over the Netherlands.
Taiwan's starter, Chen Wei-yin, pitched a brilliant seven innings, striking out seven and walking none while yielding only three hits, to key the victory.

The 23-year-old Chen, who pitches for the Chunichi Dragons in Japan's professional baseball league, allowed only two Dutch hitters to reach second base, in a performance that had even Netherlands manager Robert Eenhoorn gushing.

"Because of Chen, we had almost no scoring opportunities. The difference between the two teams was the pitching, and Taiwan constantly kept us under pressure," said Eenhoorn, who played for the New York Yankees and California/Anaheim Angels in the 1990s.

Chen, who overpowered the Dutch batters with consistent fastballs in the low 90 mile-per-hour range, said the experience he had gained in the past four years since playing in Athens in 2004 paid off Wednesday.
"I throw harder and have a wider variety of pitches. Today I was really satisfied with my velocity and control," Chen said.
Reliever Cheng Kai-wen, a 20-year-old who pitches at the university level in Taiwan, pitched a scoreless two innings to complete the shutout.
While Chen and Cheng shut the Dutch down, Taiwan jumped on Netherlands starter David Bergman for a run in the second and three in the fourth to cruise to victory.
Shortstop Lin Chih-sheng opened the scoring when he walked, advanced to third on a Chiang Chih-hsien's double down the right-field line, and came home on a sacrifice fly by left fielder Lo Kuo-hui.
Taiwan added three more in the fourth, paced by big hits from catcher Yeh Chun- chang and center-fielder Lin Che-hsuan.
"The pitching performance gave the hitters a lot of confidence, and they did a pretty good job, and the fielding was also above average," said Taiwan's manager Hung Yi-chung.
The Netherlands was one of only two teams, along with China, in the eight-team tournament that Taiwan was favored to beat.
But such is the passion for the sport here that fans weren't taking any chances, superstitiously eating poached eggs, or "hebaodan, " which sounds like "Holland posting a zero" before the game.

Next up for Taiwan, however, is Japan, one of the tournament's favorites and a perennial thorn in the side of Taiwan baseball teams, and local fans will need to conjure up more than high cholesterol superstitions to pick up a win.
Japan opened the tournament later Tuesday against another gold medal hopeful, Cuba.

DOC.HEADLINE: Men's archers ousted in individual event
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/08 17:30:23 (By Chris Wang, Luke Sabatier and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's archers, considered as legitimate medal contenders entering the 2008 Olympic Games, will leave Beijing disappointed at failing to advance deep into any tournament draw.

With the men's and women's teams finishing seventh and ninth respectively, and none of the three women able to reach the round of 16 in the individual event Tuesday, it was left up to the men to save the day.

But Wang Cheng-pang and Kuo Cheng-wei both were eliminated in the second round of the 64-man tournament by strong competitors, with Kuo falling to South Korea's Park Kyung-Mo 111-110 and Wang losing to Japan's Moriya Ryuichi 114-109.
Scores of 110 or above are considered excellent.
"When the opponent is shooting that well, what else can you do, " said Wang.

Taiwan's third archer, Chen Szu-yuan never lived up to the consistency he showed four years ago in Athens, barely squeaking by Malaysian Muhammad Marbawi 107-106 with three 10s in his final three arrows.

But he was then trounced by Russia's Tsyrempilov Baljinima of Russia 109-101 in the second round, in match that included a rare 6, a complete misfire at this level. Chen said he had been consistently hitting 9s or better in practice.
The top score for hitting the bull's eye is 10.
Lin Chen-hsian, coach of Taiwan's Olympic team, said the team had never gained momentum at the Games.
"There were high expectations for the team ahead of the games. Sometimes if you don't receive so much attention, it can be easier (for the athletes) to put on a normal performance," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan men's table tennis team gets off to good start
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/13/08 17:31:22 (By Chris Wang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan beat Brazil 3-1 in the men's table tennis team competition Wednesday at the Beijing Olympic Games, but still faced stiff challenges to reach the event's medal rounds.

Taiwan, one of the 16 teams dividing into the event's four groups, plays Sweden later Wednesday and South Korea Thursday in Group C. It needs to at least finish second in the group to qualify for the bronze medal round and must win Group C to vie for gold.
Against Brazil, Taiwan's Chuan Chih-yuan stumbled in the first of the best-of- five match tie, losing to Brazil's Hugo Hoyama 6-11, 13-11, 11-4, 12-10.

But Chiang Peng-lung regained the momentum for Taiwan with a straight set 11-9, 11-5, 11-7 win over Thiago Monteiro, before teaming with Chang Yen-shu to defeat Monteiro and Gustavo Tsuboi 11-9, 11-6, 12-14 and 11-7 in the doubles to put Taiwan ahead.
Chuan clinched the tie with an 11-3, 11-8, 12-10 pasting of Tsuboi.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmentalists seek to save endangered indigenous dolphins

TEXT.P: Environmentalists demanded Wednesday that the government take immediate and concrete actions to save a rare species of white dolphin in Taiwan, which was recently classified as "critically endangered" by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN).

Although the Sousa chinensis species was accorded the highest level of protection under Taiwan's Wildlife Conservation Act, the government has failed to take the necessary steps to protect the dolphins from extinction, environmentalist said at a workshop.

In response, Lee Tao-sheng, deputy director general of the Forestry Bureau under the Council of Agriculture, promised that representatives of Environmental Protection Administration, the Ministry of the Economic Affairs, the Fisheries Agency and the Water Resources Agency will meet within one month to work out solutions to the problem.

"Some people may doubt whether it is worth the effort to try to protect these dolphins, but when a species becomes extinct, it takes human beings one step further to the end of existence, " warned Tien Chiu-chin, a legislator of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party, urging the government to attach greater importance to the issue.

Allen Chen, an associate research fellow at the Biodiversity Research Center of Academia Sinica, indicated that the white dolphin issue is often ignored because Taiwan puts more emphasis on studies and research into biodiversity on the east coast.

The Wild at Heart Legal Defence Association noted that the rare dolphin population, currently around 100, is also threatened by industrial development along the coastline, excessive fishing, and pollution of the water.
The noises from construction close by may be fatal to the dolphins as it can damage their sonar systems, the association warned.
Urging the government to take action to protect the rare species, the environmentalists asked that the dolphins' habitat be designated as a restricted area to prevent overfishing.
Some fishing gear, such as trawl nets, destroy the eco system indiscriminately, they said, adding that researchers have found that one-third of the white dolphin population has been injured.
The activists further demanded that major construction plans be suspended until it can be ascertained that the dolphins will not be affected.

Although the white dolphins were classified as an endangered species by the Council of Agriculture, the Environmental Protection Administration in early June approved a plan by the Dragon Steel Corp. to expand its operations in an area near the dolphins' habitat, raising doubts among environmentalists of the government's willingness and determination to protect the marine animals.

The Sousa chinensis, also known as the Indo-Pacific Humpback Dolphin, is endemic to waters off Taiwan's western coast, between Miaoli County in northern Taiwan and Yunlin County in central Taiwan. The species is isolated from other populations of dolphins along the coast of China, according to the Eastern Taiwan Strait Sousa Technical Advisory Working Group.

The dolphins usually change color, turning from grey to pinkish white, when they reach maturity. They remain in shallow waters within five kilometers from shore and are very sensitive to human activities, the environmentalists said.
The population of the white dolphins was discovered in 2002, though their earliest recorded appearance by fishermen dated back to 40 years ago, the activists said.
