DOC.HEADLINE: Teacher's association demands complementary measures for income tax

TEXT.P: The National Teacher's Association (NTA) said Wednesday that the body is not opposed to income tax being levied on primary and secondary school teachers if such a move is inevitable, but added that the government should offer compensation to relieve teachers of the new financial burden.
The issue of reinstating income tax on teachers, along with military personnel, was included as one of the major agenda items in a Wednesday meeting of Taiwan's tax reform committee.

The committee's financial officials and experts, who are said to have reached consensus in bringing such taxation back, is to discuss the timetable for implementing the tax, as well as complementary measures to alleviate the situation for the estimated 300,000 teachers and servicemen who will be affected.

Before the meeting began, Yeh Ching-rong, an NTA convener who specializes in tax issues, said that the return of taxes for teachers and military personnel would intensify their already heavy financial burden due to inflation, and that the committee should consider whether imposing income tax on teachers and military personnel is appropriate at present.
He said tax-exempt status for primary and secondary school teachers is an important incentive for attracting people to the teaching profession and should not be seen as a wrong measure.
"We demand a series of reasonable complementary measures if the return of income tax is inevitable," Yeh stressed.

In 2002, the NTA successfully boycotted a government plan to recoup income tax from teachers, urging the then-Democratic Progressive Party government to carry out complementary measures before levying the taxes.
Income tax for primary school teachers has been suspended since 1955, while secondary school teachers have been tax-exempt since 1979.

Unlike the U.S., where secondary school encompasses junior high and high schools, the three-year junior high school in Taiwan is classified as secondary education, which is the final stage of compulsory education. Primary education in Taiwan includes both kindergarten and elementary school.

To ease the financial losses for teachers affected by the imposition of income tax, Yeh suggested a reduction of their work hours by reducing the number of classes they have to teach by two per week. "In addition, the monthly subsidies for homeroom teaching should be increased by NT$2,000," he said.
Apart from monetary support, Yeh said teachers will also need more assistance to help them with administrative matters.
Before the meeting, Finance Minister Li Sush-der told the press that the meeting will work out complementary plans to help improve the work environment of teachers and military officers.

According to the ministry's calculations, should the taxation under discussion be implemented, the government's tax revenues would be boosted by NT$15.5 billion (US$500 million) per year, including NT$9.8 billion from the country's 200,000 teachers.
The meeting was also expected to discuss other issues such as the simplification of business income tax, and the conclusions were to be disclosed later in the day after the end of the meeting.
The conclusions of the meeting will be submitted the Cabinet, which will hand over the decisions to the Legislative Yuan to amend the relevant articles in the income tax law.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitung music festival to begin Aug. 16

TEXT.P: An annual music festival in the eastern county of Taitung will begin Saturday with aboriginal music -- a feature of the county -- and pan-Asian reggae as the two genres most strongly represented, a local official said Wednesday.

There will be a series of performances by local and foreign individuals and independent groups, including many of Taiwan's aboriginal musicians, as well as more than 10 top reggae bands from Japan and the Philippines, such as Machaco, Papa-Ugee and Tropical Depression, the official said.

The two-week festival, with major music performances being staged on two weekends, will also feature various music workshops to be hosted by both local and foreign musicians, along with several handicraft fairs showcasing local artists' creations.
The county has diverse musical resources thanks to its abundant aboriginal cultures. About 30 percent of the county's population are aboriginal people, representing six different tribes.
The county's aboriginal music stunned the world music scene with the theme song for the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, which was titled "Jubilant Drinking Song" and was sung by Amis musician Difang Duana.
Many stars of Taiwan's music industry come from the county, such as composers Lee Tai-hsiang and Kimbo and singers/songwriters such as A-Mei, Purdur, Samingad and Biung, the official said.
The festival originated from a small art event in 2002 and has gradually become a great chance for the county to promote its music resources and beautiful landscape, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Enterprises, media urged to assist in fighting corruption

TEXT.P: Enterprises have the obligation to cooperate with the government in fighting corruption, while the media should play an important role of surveillance, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Wednesday.
The appeals were the conclusions reached at a one-and-a-half-day international anti-corruption conference that concluded Tuesday, the MOJ said in a press statement.
According to the statement, a four-point consensus was reached at the conference.

First, the private sector and enterprises in general must cooperate to create a corruption-free environment. Second, national leaders and heads of government organizations must set good examples and establish a superior administrative system.

Third, the media should play a surveillance role and provide information to the public via an open and transparent system. Fourth, international and regional judiciary systems must cooperate to fight cross-border corruption.

Speaking at the closing ceremony Tuesday afternoon, MOJ Vice Minister Hwang Shih-ming said that as stated in the U.N. Convention Against Corruption, it is every country's responsibility to prevent and eradicate corruption.
Although Taiwan is not a signatory to the convention, it is willing to participate and cooperate with international anti-corruption organizations, Hwang added.

The conference, organized by the MOJ and Transparency International- Taiwan, took place in Taipei Aug.11-12. Experts from Denmark, Singapore, Australia and Malaysia, along with local prosecutors, investigation units and some 200 city and county representatives attended.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City has high hopes for Cijin Island tourist area

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government is seeking to transform its Cijin Island into a special tourism zone with an NT$40 billion (US$1.28 billion) development plan for a 100-hectare plot of land, a city official said Wednesday.

Hung Shu-hui, deputy director of the city's Urban Development Planning Bureau, said the Sentosa-style resort plan received a good initial response from the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications after it was submitted to the central Tourism Bureau in early July for reference.
Hung said he hoped the central government will approve the project by early next year so that the Kaohsiung city government can begin public bidding for construction and development.
The Cijin tourism development plan corresponds to one of President Ma Ying- jeou's "12 mega development projects, " Hung said, which is to transform Kaohsiung City into a vibrant, diverse metropolis.
Hung dismissed rumors that the 100-hectare zone would feature casinos.
"The NT$40 billion tourism development plan is aimed at creating a sound investment climate" for Cijin Island to make it "both an energy-effective and tourism-centered area."

Hung said the development plans will include hotels, restaurants, beach facilities, recreational areas and historical sites. He said the city will also promote the solar power industry in Cijin, taking advantage of the island's sunny weather.
In the first phase of developing the island, the government plans to upgrade transportation to Cijin with an electric cable car, second underwater car tunnel and a subway link, Hung said.
According to Huang, the government sector already owns about 98 percent of the 100-hectare plot on Cijin, making it much easier for the city government to move forward with the plan.
Hung said he is optimistic that the tourism development project will draw a large number of potential investors.
A city government "Cijin Panel" has been working on the details of the tourism development plan for three years, he said, meeting every one or two months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiayi County's top water resources official detained by prosecutors

TEXT.P: Public prosecutors detained the top water resources official of Chiayi County early Wednesday after questioning him for the second time as the chief suspect in a corruption case.

According to the Chiayi District Prosecutors Office, Chen Dian-bao, director of the Chiayi county government's Water Resources Department, accepted NT$5 million (US$160,610) in bribes between October 2006 and May 2007 to help four construction companies obtain contracts awarded by his department for improving or building drainage systems in Chiayi County.
Also detained for their alleged involvement in the case were Tseng Yung-chih, a technician in Chen's department, and a middleman, Wang Chao-shun.

One of the owners of the construction companies, identified by the surname Chen, and his wife were released after they confessed to bribing Chen and agreed to become witnesses for the prosecution in return for commuted sentences.

Two other businessmen -- Kuo Chao-liang and Lin Chao-sheng -- were released on bail of NT$300,000 each, while a third businessman, Chuang Yu-chin, was released on bail of NT$200,000, as prosecutors found that they had only violated the Government Procurement Law.

Prosecutors said they received tip-offs a year ago that Chen Dian-bao was working in collusion with the construction companies to help them obtain contracts for some of the county government's construction projects through restricted bidding, in return for a kickback of 15 percent of the contract value.

After placing Chen under surveillance for one year, investigators from the Investigation Bureau of the Ministry of Justice found that he frequented sex- oriented restaurants as a guest of the construction companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Teachers, military personnel to pay income tax from 2010

TEXT.P: Primary and secondary school teachers and military personnel will no longer be exempt from income tax, beginning 2010 at the earliest, but the education and defense ministries will compensate the estimated 300,000 be to affected, Minister of Finance Li Sush-der announced Wednesday.

The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will reimpose income tax on teachers and military personnel when the legislature amends the income tax law," Li said at the press conference after the Tax Reform Committee reached its final decision on the issue.

He said the plan to reinstate income tax for teachers and servicemen will be completed before October, and a draft bill is expected to be sent to the Legislative Yuan, which will amend the relevant article in the income tax law in the first half of next year.

"At that rate, the ministry could reintroduce the taxation in 2010 on annual income earned in 2009," the minister estimated, adding that the additional tax revenues could surpass NT$15 billion (US$484 million) a year.
Local primary school teachers and military personnel have been exempt from paying taxes since 1955, and secondary school teachers since 1979.
Over the last 20 years many financial ministers have called for the exemption to be lifted, arguing that teachers and military officers could no longer be regarded as earning sub-standard pay.

The decision Wednesday will restore social equity in the tax statues, said Li, adding that the central government will allocate the additional tax revenues to the Ministry of Education (MOE) and Ministry of National Defense to fund compensatory measures.

The additional revenue received from the tax payers in the military, estimated to amount to NT$5.73 billion a year, will be included in the military budget to increase the salaries of military personnel, according to the MOF.
"The real income of military personnel will not be reduced, " Li stressed.
Also the revenue obtained from income tax payments by an estimated 200,000 teachers will total around NT$10 billion, and will be allocated to the MOE to improve the education system, he added.

Li said the representatives of the National Teachers' Association (NTA) who were at the committee meeting endorsed the taxation plan, on condition that the additional tax revenues be used as part of the country's educational resources.

To offset the loss of income by teachers under the proposed income tax revision, the NTA suggested a reduction in the number of work hours and an increase of NT$2,000 in the monthly subsidy for homeroom teaching.
However, Li said that the committee did not lay out a specific compensation plan for teachers because the MOE needs to further evaluate and finalize the details.

The standard income tax rates -- 6 percent, 13 percent, 21 percent, 30 percent and 40 percent depending on the salary level -- will be applied to the income of the teachers and servicemen when the law takes effect, said Li.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA to hold seminar on Central, South American market

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will hold a seminar Aug. 29 in the southern port city of Kaohsiung to brief manufacturers on new business opportunities in Central and South America, TAITRA's Kaohsiung office announced Wednesday.

The office said that as a result of rising commodity prices worldwide, Central and South American countries, which are rich in natural resources, have heavily boosted their foreign currency exchange reserves and have become a new driving force behind the world economy.

Citing examples, it said Venezuela and Mexico's petroleum, Chile's copper, Colombia's gem stones, Brazil's rare metals and agricultural products, and Peru's silver and zinc have created new wealth for these countries and turned them into the world's "new markets with the greatest potential."
"These countries are newly emerging markets that Taiwanese businessmen should not ignore," it said.

Official statistics show that Taiwan's exports to Central America in 2007 amounted to US$2.36 billion, up 10 percent from 2006, while its exports to South America in 2007 totaled US$3.17 billion, an increase of 26 percent from the previous year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese official visits Taichung County to promote tourism

TEXT.P: An official of Japan's Tottori Prefecture visited the central county of Taichung Wednesday in preparation for an event to promote the prefecture's tourism in the county next month, according to a county official.
Katsunori Kinugawa, director of the prefecture's Culture and Tourism Bureau, exchanged views on details of the activity with Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng, the official said.

Tottori Prefecture Governor Hsinji Hirai will travel to Taichung aboard a direct charter Sept. 4, at the head of a 100-member delegation, one day before the start of the tourism promotion activity, the official said.
The six-day promotional event will be presented in the form of an exhibition of Tottori Prefecture's food and tourist attractions.

Tottori, the least populous prefecture in Japan, is known for its seafood and fruits such as persimmon and pears. It has beautiful landscapes and many hot springs, which are strong points in promoting its tourism in Taiwan, the official noted.
The official added that Gosho Aoyama, writer of famous Japanese comics "Detective Conan," was born in the prefecture.

Some of the prefecture's cultural attractions, such as bamboo craft, pottery, children's toys, Japanese paper, and textiles, will be on display from Aug. 8 to Sept. 1 in the Taichung county government hall, to give the public a better idea of the features of the prefecture, the local official said.
Meanwhile, Magistrate Huang said there have been frequent interactions and exchanges between Tottori Prefecture and Taichung County, especially in the areas of tourism and agriculture.
Huang expressed the hope that the range of interactions will be expanded to boost bilateral development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu's Olympic run ended by Austrian

TEXT.P: In two whirlwind days at the Beijing Olympics, Lu Yen-hsun went from being an "unknown Taiwanese" to a "Taiwanese giant killer", becoming one of the country's most celebrated athletes at the 2008 Games.
But the momentum that carried him past world No. 6 Andy Murray of Scotland and world No. 52 Agustin Calleri of Argentina petered out Wednesday when he ran into Austrian buzz saw Jurgen Melzer.
Holding his serve throughout the match without yielding even one break point, Melzer established his superiority by breaking Lu in the opening game of the match on his way to a 6-2, 6-4 victory.

"My opponent just played too fast, and I couldn't find a way to counter it at the beginning of the match," Lu said. "In the second set, I began to find a rhythm and avoided playing at his pace. The score was closer and I really didn't play that badly, but (Melzer) played better."

Lu, who turns 25 Thursday, would have faced soon to be world No. 1 Spain's Rafael Nadal in the quarterfinals had he beaten the Austrian, but he took comfort in reaching the third round of the Olympics, something he has failed to do any grand slam tournament.
"After playing in this Olympics, I believe even more that I have the ability to beat top-ranked players. In the U.S. Open (beginning August 25), I hope I can get past the second round," Lu said.
Melzer, ranked 51st in the world but generally a top 30 player until late last year, never let Lu into the match, putting 79 percent of his first serves in play in the first set.
The Austrian broke Lu in the first and seventh games of the first set and again in the first game of the second set, keeping the pressure on Lu throughout.
What makes Lu's exploits these past few days all the more remarkable is that he has done it without a coach or an authorized member of the tennis team with access to Olympic venues.

Taiwan's tennis association originally named doubles star Chan Yung-jan's father and coach as the team's official coach and Lien Yu-hui, one of Taiwan's Davis Cup mainstays in the late 1980s and early '90s, as the "P-card," or support personnel.
But the Sports Affairs Council, overturned the association's recommendation, giving the "P-card" to the father of Chan's doubles partner Chuang Chia-jung.
To compensate, the association paid for Lien to accompany Lu to Beijing, but without the official "P-card" designation, Lien was not given access to any Olympic venues.

"Lu Yen-hsun even had to ask for help from the Chinese players to get court time for him to practice and help him warm up," Lu's older brother Lu Wei-ru told the Central News Agency. "I still have trouble accepting the decision. The women already had Chan's father to work with them, while my brother had nobody who could give him advice and practice with him."
Lu Wei-ru said, however, that the decision may have inspired his brother to his outstanding performance.
The decision made Lu Yen-hsun want to show people that they need to take men's tennis seriously. It may have added to his determination,Lu Wei-ru said.
Lu's Olympic showing, and a run of strong performances by up-and-coming Tsung- hua Yang, should be opening the eyes of local sports authorities.

Lu Wei-ru laughed when it was suggested his brother has become known to more Taiwanese in the past three days than since he turned pro in 2001, and said he hoped his brother would continue his run of success at the U.S. Open.

DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu concerned about losing out on Chinese tourist dollars

TEXT.P: Penghu County Magistrate Wang Chien-fa voiced concern Wednesday that the offshore county is being marginalized amid growing economic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, and asked the central government for greater economic assistance.

"Penghu's future seems gloomy, as it has become an outcast from increased cross- strait exchanges ever since the central government launched direct weekend charter flights between Taiwan proper and China from July 4, " Wang said at a county council meeting, while giving a special report on potential business opportunities for Penghu in direct cross-strait travel links.

Although Penghu was designated as one of Taiwan's eight airports serving inaugural weekend charter flights, Wang said that since then, no charter flights have taken off from or landed on the island. That's made Penghu's tourism industry especially concerned, he said.

Without more weekend charters between the island and Chinese destinations, local tourism-related businesses will be at a distinct disadvantage in competing with other Taiwan cities and counties for Chinese tourist dollars.

Moreover, the July 4 charter flights to and from Penghu were for religious exchanges, not tourism. That day, 180 Buddhist pilgrims flew on a charter flight from Penghu to Xiamen, while 263 Xiamen Buddhists flew into Penghu on the same charter on the return trip.

Wang suggested that the central government permit Chinese tourists visiting Penghu to proceed to Taiwan proper and allow those visiting Taiwan proper to proceed to Penghu, as a means of helping the island attract more Chinese tourists.

The magistrate also urged the government to grant Chinese tourists 96-hour landing visa privilege upon their arrival in Penghu, and allow them to travel on their own instead of being required to join a group tour.
According to county Councilor Yang Yao-wen, Penghu residents are facing economic difficulties now that the Kuomintang (KMT) government has opened the doors wider to China.

Yang urged the central government to grant the Penghu Island the same status as Kinmen and Matsu islands, which are authorized to conduct direct ferry services with three ports in China's Fujian Province.
Over the past eight years, the previous Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration regime was too passive in working to include Penghu in cross- strait exchanges, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker returns from Japan

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng returned to Taipei after concluding a visit to Japan Wednesday.

During his six-day stay in Japan, Wang called on officials and parliamentarians. He also attended the general assembly of the Asia-Pacific Parliamentarians' Union (APPU) in Nara and solicited the right to host the annual conference in Taiwan next year.
In addition, he sought to allay Japan's misgivings about the warming of the cross-strait relations since the inauguration of the Kuomintang administration May 20.
Wang noted that the Japanese side is concerned about who will fill the post of Taiwan's representative to Japan, since Koh Se-kai tendered his registration in June.
Wang said that he told the Japanese side that Taiwan attaches great importance to the post and is now cautiously selecting a suitable replacement.
Wang said he felt that Koh's successor should be someone who can adapt to Japan's political environment and who "has credible experience and good relations with political and business leaders."

DOC.HEADLINE: Development projects to narrow digital divide: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew said Wednesday at the 2008 Digital Cities Convention in Taoyuan that narrowing the digital divide between urban and rural areas and attracting business investment are the main goals of the government's "i-Taiwan 12 Projects."
According to Siew, one of the programs will see the promotion of "intelligent Taiwan" with the aim of creating a superb industrial environment through the application of intelligent technology.

The notion of a "mobile Taiwan" is also to be advanced, leading to the establishment of "wireless cities," said Siew on the first day of the two-day conference organized by the Taoyuan county government and held at Taoyuan County Center for Women. Taipei Mayor Hau Ling-bin and Taoyuan Magistrate Eric Liluan Chu also attended.
Siew added that digital development is considered one of the most important tasks in developing Taoyuan City into an international air transport logistics hub -- one of the "i-Taiwan 12 Projects."

According to the World Information Society Report 2007, Taiwan ranked No. 7 in digital opportunities, with a No. 2 ranking in digital infrastructure, a No. 6 ranking in Internet opportunities, and a No. 23 ranking in digital information applications.
Judging from the statistics, Siew went on, the development of digital hardware in Taiwan has matured over the last few years and the next step is to expand the application of digital technology.

He added that people not only need to work hard but also work smart in the information age, adding that it is only through the use of intelligence that added value will be increased in today's competitive environment.
Siew further expressed hope that in the future, every city in Taiwan can be equipped with broadband and wireless facilities, giving Internet access to all.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan city government workers to observe weekly Bicycle Day

TEXT.P: About 75 percent of Tainan city government employees have expressed their support for a greenhouse gas emission reduction program by pledging to ride bicycles to work every Friday, according to the results of a poll conducted by the city government this week.
The environmentally friendly program, proposed by the Tainan city government, will be launched Friday Aug. 13 and it will not be a mandatory measure in the initial stage.
Under the program, city government officials and employees will be encouraged to go to work by bicycle, by bus or on foot every Friday.

"All city government workers can ride a city bus free by showing their IDs," a city government spokesman said, adding that the purpose of the program is to have Tainan city government employees refrain from driving their cars or motorcycles to work at least one day a week.
The spokesman said the city government will hold a press conference Thursday to reaffirm its determination to implement the program and will provide more details.

DOC.HEADLINE: Control Yuan discloses value of presidential campaign contributions

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou and Vice President Vincent Siew received political contributions amounting to NT$677.4 million (US$21.75 million) for their presidential campaign, according to an official of the Control Yuan, a government branch that monitors the integrity of civil servants and government officials.

Hsieh Yu-nan, director of the Control Yuan's Department of Asset Reports, said the amount received by Ma and Siew, the Kuomintang ticket for the presidential election in March, was computed for the period June 8, 2007 to April 21 this year.
A balance of NT$37.46 million remained after the presidential election, including NT$15.28 million in assets like furniture and cars.
Hsieh said the funds were computed for the period dating from when the bank account was opened to when the contributions were reported.
Meanwhile, Hsieh said, the Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and his running mate Su Tsen-Chang received political contributions totalling NT$404.03 million.
The amount was computed for the period May 31, 2007 to April 13 this year. The DPP ticket had an overdraft of NT$23.65 million after the election, and had no non-liquid assets, the director said.

The Political Contribution Act stipulates that candidates should report political contributions within two months after elections to the relevant authorities, who will in turn announce the findings of their reviews within three months of receiving the candidates reports, Hsieh Yu-nan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Next 4 years crucial to development of cross-strait ties: SEF

TEXT.P: The next four years will be crucial to the development of cross-strait relations, an official of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Wednesday.
SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-general Kao Koong-lien, noting that Chinese leader Hu Jintao's second term will expire in 2012, said Hu will seek to leave a legacy.
In Taiwan, President Ma Ying-jeou will seek his second term in four years' time, and he will need to present a credible performance to ensure reelection, Kao added.
Kao made the remarks during a speech on the development of cross-strait trade relations and the outlook for the future, at a party given by a visiting delegation from China's Fudan University.

"The signing of a cross-strait agreement and a comprehensive economic cooperation agreement (CECA) between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be crucial to the development of cross-strait relations," he said.
The signing of the CECA will prevent Taiwan from being marginalized and will help create a win-win situation through the normalization of cross-strait trade, he said.
He pointed out that peaceful and stable cross-strait relations will help to boost Taiwan's development and also help to maintain stability in China.
"Cross-strait relations are key to peace and stability in East Asia," he added.
North Korea is currently the powder keg in East Asia, Kao noted, adding that he does not want to see the Taiwan Strait turn into a second flash point.

He pointed out that relations across the Taiwan Strait have warmed up since the resumption of cross-strait talks in June, and said he hoped that the cordial relations will continue to develop so that the Taiwan Strait will not become a powder keg in South Asia or a "trouble maker in the international community."
Kao also said that bilateral trade across the Taiwan Strait had increased in three decades from less than US$100 million to more than US$100 billion in 2007.

Addressing concerns that over-reliance on China could lead to a situation in which products "made in Taiwan" would gradually be replaced by "made in China" brands, Kao said there is no need for such worries.
Cross-strait trade figures have clearly shown that the "made in China" products are in essence "made by Taiwanese in China," he said.

But he also suggested that Taiwan upgrade its economy by enhancing research and design on one hand and moving toward high value-added industries such as the development of brands, marketing and distribution on the other.
With upgraded traditional industries and emerging and service industries, Taiwan may create another economic miracle, he said.

On the cross-strait deregulations scheduled for next year, Kao said that the major initiatives will include permitting domestic banks to set up branches and subsidiaries in China and to make direct investments, allowing Chinese capital in Taiwan banks, permitting Taiwan schools to sign alliance agreements with their Chinese counterparts, and extending the time that Chinese students are allowed to study in Taiwan from the current four months to one year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MJIB denies receiving notices about Chen's alleged money laundering

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) denied Wednesday that it has ever received notices from Singapore and the United States about former President Chen Shui-bian's alleged remittance of NT$300 million (US$9.62 million) overseas in 2006 through his family for the purposes of laundering money.

The MJIB issued the statement after the Next weekly tabloid reported in its latest issue that the Egmont Group, an international anti-money laundering organization, had informed the bureau through the United States and Singapore that former first lady Wu Shu-jen had closed bank accounts belonging to her and her husband as well as several others in 2006, soon after the exposure of a "state affairs fund case." The magazine claimed that the accounts were created under the names of Wu's son Chen Chih-chung and her daughter Chen Hsing-yu and were used for stock trading.

Wu also remitted an amount totaling NT$300 million overseas through various bank accounts belonging to her daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching and her family after the state affairs fund scandal broke, according to the magazine.
It further said the situation was discovered when prosecutors were scrutinizing the bank accounts of the former first family as part of their probe into the high-profile embezzlement case.

Wu was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for allegedly using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.

The MJIB statement said the Next report was not factual, and insisted that the bureau had not received any notices from Singaporean or U.S. authorities about the alleged remittance of money by the country's former first family.
Moreover, the statement said, prosecutors have not directed the MJIB's anti- money laundering center to investigate the former first family's overseas bank accounts.

Responding to the Next report, a spokesman for the Supreme Prosecutors Office's Special Investigation Task Force said the panel has probed the domestic and overseas bank accounts of all those involved in the suspected "state affairs fund" embezzlement case. Nevertheless, the spokesman said, the panel has no knowledge of the alleged transactions mentioned in the tabloid report.

Dismissing the tabloid report through opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Gao Jyh-peng and his lawyer Lee Sheng-chen, Chen said earlier in the day that the article was a conspiracy engineered by prosecutors to try to sway public opinion over the "state affairs fund" case that is currently under investigation.

According to Gao, the report obviously "goes against common sense" because the assets of the former first family were held in trust during Chen's presidency, which would have prevented the family members from managing the assets on their own.
"Had the trust been canceled (before Chen's term ended in May 2008), everyone would have known about it long ago," Gao said.
Chen, who had immunity from prosecution while in office, was named as a co- defendant in the "state affairs fund" case as soon as he stepped down from the presidency May 20.
On Tuesday, he was questioned by prosecutors for the second time since July.

DOC.HEADLINE: First lady visits remote aboriginal community in Hualien

TEXT.P: First lady Chow Mei-ching visited a remote aboriginal community in the eastern county of Hualien Wednesday to meet a teenager whom President Ma Ying-jeou has been sponsoring for seven years.

It was the third time since late July that the self-effacing first lady has traveled to remote tribal communities in areas far away from metropolitan Taipei to meet disadvantaged children. All three visits were arranged by World Vision Taiwan (WVT), a Christian charity dedicated to helping local and foreign children and families in need.

As in the past, Chow, a financial law expert who retired from a high-paid banking job just after her husband assumed the presidency in May, kept a low- profile on her Hualien visit in the company of WVT staff.

Besides meeting with the Ma-sponsored boy, identified as Hsiaohui, Chow also attended a WVT-organized seminar on children's character education during her Hualien visit, said the WVT in a press statement.

Chow presented Hsiaohui many gifts, including an English dictionary and books on English grammar and sentence patterns. Knowing that Hsiaohui likes painting, Chow also gave him, a 14-year-old junior high school student, watercolor paints and brush pens as well as school stationery items, the statement said.

According to the statement, Chow was impressed by daylilies and many other dazzling indigenous plants and vegetables in the aboriginal Talanpu community, which used to be known as a "dark village" because it didn't have power supply until a few years ago.

After seeing for herself several community development projects there, the statement said Chow expressed her hope that local schools can include more traditional cultural education courses in their curricula.
Chow made the suggestion because she believes that aboriginal children should be taught the rich cultural legacies left by their tribal ancestors, the statement said.

The first lady also suggested that aboriginal school teachers be given intensive training in aboriginal culture and customs so that they can help young tribal children better understand their own culture, the statement added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Paraguay to maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan: envoy
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Paraguay, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/14/08 01:23:32 (By Ramon Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The incoming Paraguayan government will maintain diplomatic relations with the Republic of China on Taiwan, the ROC ambassador to the South American country said Wednesday.

Amb. Hu Cheng-yao made the remarks in a telephone interview with CNA a few hours before the arrival of ROC President Ma Ying-jeou in Asuncion to attend the Aug. 15 inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo.

Lugo, a former leftist bishop, once said on campaign trail that if he won the presidency, his administration would switch diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing. But Hu said Lugo has promised to maintain official ties with Taiwan after he won the presidential election in April this year.
Hu said he met with Lugo Tuesday. During the meeting, Hu said, Lugo reiterated his determination to uphold his country's longstanding cordial ties with Taiwan after assuming office later this week.
For his part, Hu said he assured Lugo that the ROC government will continue to assist Paraguay in agricultural development, land reform and construction of public housing units.

On his first state visit since taking office May 20, President Ma will attend the inauguration ceremonies of Lugo on Aug. 15 and Dominican Republic President- elect Leonel Fernandez on Aug. 16. Ma's eight-day overseas visit is seen as a bid to cement ties with Paraguay and the Caribbean country and a test of whether Taiwan and China will set aside their competition in the international arena.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan men's table tennis team qualified for bronze medal run

TEXT.P: Taiwan beat Sweden 3-2 in the men's table tennis team competition Wednesday at the Beijing Olympic Games, following its victory over Brazil 3-1 earlier that day.
Taiwan, one of the 16 teams dividing into the event's four groups, will play South Korea Thursday in Group C.
By defeating Brazil and Sweden, Taiwan is now qualified for the bronze medal round. If Taiwan manages to top South Korea, it will secure the right to vie for gold.

In the tennis event, Taiwan's third-seeded "golden pair" of Chan Yung-jan and Chuang Chia-jung lost to the Italian team of Flavia Pennetta and Francesca Schiavone, 6-7, 6-1, 6-8, in a grueling game that lasted for two hours and 54 minutes. The defeat ended Chan and Chuang's Olympic run.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Thursday.

The weighted price index was down 27.33 points at 7,265.01 on a turnover of NT$3.14 billion (US$100.8 million) at the open. The index lost 1.46 points, or 0.02 percent, to close at 7,292.34 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Thursday.
The greenback was trading at NT$31.220 at 10 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.070 from Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 14, or the 14th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1811: The British occupy Java.
1811: Paraguay proclaims independence from Spain.
1900: Forces of eight powers -- Britain, Japan, the United States, Germany, Russia, France, Austria and Italy -- march from Tientsin and scale the walls of Beijing, relieving the foreign legation besieged there since the start of the Boxer Uprising two months earlier.
1917: The Beijing government declares war on Germany and Austro-Hungary.
1937: The Republic of China Air Force shoots down nine of 18 Japanese aircraft which are bombing Hangchow, capital of Chekiang Province in eastern China.
1945: Japan surrenders unconditionally, ending World War II.
1945: The Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance is signed in Moscow.
1945: Nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek invites Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong to come to Chungking for a conference.
1947: Pakistan gains independence from Britain.
1949: Konrad Adenauer becomes the first chancellor of West Germany.
1951: Randolph W. Hearst, the newspaper publisher known as the king of America's "yellow press," dies at the age of 88. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire comprising 28 major newspapers.
1951: Seamen aboard the Ta Han, a 2,000-ton mainland Chinese freighter, defect to Taiwan, sailing their ship to the port of Kaohsiung.
1958: The ROC Air Force shoots down three Communist Chinese MiG-17s over Matsu.
1958: The United States decides to maintain an embargo on trade with Communist China, North Korea and North Vietnam, despite NATO's announcement of a relaxation of trade restrictions with the Soviet bloc and Communist China.
1971: Ground for the construction of Taiwan's north-south freeway is broken near Linkou.
1973: Over 300 Chinese and foreign computer scientists meet at the Academia Sinica for the First International Symposium on Computers.
1974: The Taipei Century Symphony Orchestra leaves for the United States on a three-week goodwill tour.
1977: The ROC Air Force celebrates the 40th anniversary of its victory over the Japanese at Hangchow, with Gen. Szetu Fu presiding.
1979: Wang Yun-wu, senior advisor to the president of the Republic of China, dies of heart failure at Veterans General Hospital at the age of 92.
1980: More than 360 scholars from home and abroad take part in the International Conference on Sinology at the Academia Sinica.
1985: The ROC Executive Yuan issues a report on the investigation of official administrative responsibilities regarding the 10th Credit Cooperative scandal. Fifteen financial officials are reprimanded, given demerits or dismissed.
1988: Major racial conflict breaks out in the African country of Burundi, with more than 24,000 people being killed in the conflict.
1999: The United States defeats Chinese-Taipei 10-9 to win the 18th International Baseball Association Big League Championship in Kaohsiung.
2000: Premier Tang Fei instructs the Ministry of Justice to review and revise relevant laws and regulations so as to enable the government to effectively crack down on the types of crimes that are increasingly harming Taiwan society.
2001: Former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez, a 1987 Nobel Peace Prize winner, says in Kinmen that Taiwan and mainland China should engage in dialogue to ease the tension across the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who intuitively apprehends truth is one who, without effort, hits what is right, and without thinking understands what he wants to know; whose life is easily and naturally in harmony with the moral law. Such a one is what we call a saint or a man of divine nature."

DOC.HEADLINE: Arrangements for U.S. transit stops very appropriate:president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday his low profile transit stop in L.A. en route to Latin America on his first state visit since he took office in May was very much appreciated by the United States and served as an important step to mend mutual trust between the two countries.
"The transit stop arrangements (in Los Angeles) were very appropriate and were highly appreciated by the U.S. authorities, " Ma said aboard a charter flight from Los Angeles to Paraguay.

This (low profile transit stop) would allow them build faith in Taiwan, and that is very important, " the president said, adding that "I believe it will be to very good effect if we take one step at a time."

Ma noted that in planning the trip, Taiwan made no requests for a stopover on the East Coast of the U.S. or to engage in any activity that would conflict with the purpose of a transit stop. This approach was taken to allow for the mending of mutual trust between Taiwan and the U.S., which had eroded over the past years, he said.

Ma's predecessor Chen Shui-bian often used state visits, including transits through the U.S., to shift Taiwan's political struggle over its identity to a broader international stage -- a practice that often displeased the U.S.

Ma arrived in Los Angeles on Aug. 12 local time where he made a transit stop en route to Paraguay and the Dominican Republic. He is slated to attend the inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo on Aug. 15 and of Dominican Republic President-elect Leonel Fernandez on Aug. 16.

In keeping with his desire not to create any waves during his U.S. overnight stopover, the president did not leave his hotel. However, he met with four U.S. congressmen and had telephone conversations with four senators and six other congressmen.

He also attended a dinner held by Taiwanese expatriates. Other guests at the dinner included 50 overseas Taiwanese leaders, some of Ma's American friends and some U.S. congressmen. The president also met with several Taiwanese international students.

Asked whether he had made contact with anyone from the presidential campaigns of Democratic candidate Barack Obama or Republican candidate John McCain, Ma said cryptically that he had "met and talked with the people he was supposed to meet and talk with."
The president also told reporters that he is keeping tabs on the performance of Taiwan's Olympic team in Beijing.

"The 5-0 victory of the Taiwanese baseball team over the Netherlands on Wednesday (Taipei time) shows that our players are extraordinary and I was very excited when I was notified of the victory," Ma said.

Ma said that he hopes other Taiwanese Olympics athletes will also perform well so that his visit to the training camp in southern Taiwan to boost morale among the athletes before he left for South America and the Caribbean would not have been in vain.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan mulls extending stay of Chinese students

TEXT.P: The government is planning to extend the maximum stay in Taiwan by Chinese students from the current four months to one year, as part of its efforts to encourage cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian said Thursday.
The long-stalled issues concerning the recognition of academic qualifications awarded by Chinese schools will only be addressed after that, Kao said.
"But the opening to students would not be unlimited, in light of the non-uniform quality of schools in China," he said.

While the Chinese government has long recognized academic qualifications awarded by Taiwanese schools, Taiwan has not reciprocated, mainly because the Taiwan government lacks sufficient information about the academic system in China and the quality of Chinese schools, he noted.
Kao made the remarks in response to questions by the media on the government's policy on cross-strait educational exchanges.
Kao was participating in the opening ceremony of a Taipei workshop organized by the SEF for Taiwan students studying at higher education institutions in China.
In his opening address, Kao expressed his support for a proposal to promote dual degree programs and mutual recognition of academic credits between Taiwanese and Chinese universities.
Such measures will allow universities from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to share their merits and will expand the opportunities for students to make friends, according to Kao.

He said that compared with three months ago, cross-strait relations have improved significantly thanks to the increase in cross-strait interactions, especially in terms of economic, trade and cultural exchanges.

Meanwhile, Kao stressed the importance of establishing a viable channel of communication across the strait and again proposed that Taiwan and China establish reciprocal representative offices to more effectively address problems encountered by both sides in dealing with each other.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Panama relations very good: foreign minister

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said Wednesday that the warm welcome President Ma Ying-jeou received from his Panamanian counterpart, President Martin Torrijos, in Panama City during a refueling stop en route to South American and the Caribbean can serve as an indicator that bilateral relations between Taiwan and Panama are very good.

Ma arrived in Panama City around 2: 45 p.m. local time and was given a red carpet welcome that included a military guard of honor and the playing of the national anthems of the Republic of China and Panama. Dozens of Taiwanese expatriates were also at the airport to greet the president.
Ma and Torrijos held a meeting at the airport in which they discussed bilateral cooperation and exchanged views on economic and energy saving issues.

"When we requested a refueling stop in Panama, (the authorities) expressed their warmest assent and immediately responded that the president would like to meet with us, " Ou said. "This shows that bilateral relations are very good.

Ou made the remarks aboard a charter flight from Panama to Paraguay, where Ma will make his first state visit since he took office May 20. Ma will attend the inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo on Aug. 15.

Ma was the first head of state from Taiwan to visit Panama since Sep.1, 2004, when his predecessor Chen Shui-bian attended the inauguration ceremony of the incumbent Panamanian President Martin Torrijos.

Bilateral relations between Taiwan and Panama seemed to be wavering during the final years of Chens administration, as Chen stuck to a diplomatic approach that China saw as confrontational, while Panama tried to develop economic and trade relations with China.
The Panamanian government rejected Chen's request for a stopover in Oct. 2007, a decision that was interpreted by many analysts as an indicator of unstable diplomatic ties.

Although Ma's short stop in Panama on his way to Paraguay was for refueling purposes, it was generally viewed as a major effort by Taiwan to consolidate its ties with the central American country which has been a Republic of China ally since 1909.
Unlike most of Taiwan's other allies, Panama in recent years has withheld support for Taiwan's bid to participate in the World Health Organization and the United Nations.

Ou, however, contended that this was the result of a longstanding diplomatic tug-of-war between Taiwan and China. Now that the new Taiwan government has adopted a different diplomatic approach from the previous administration, the ties with Panama are getting stronger, he added.

"It is easier for our allies and other countries with which we do not have diplomatic relations to voice their support for Taiwan's participation in international organizations if Taipei and Beijing can set aside their problems," the foreign minister said.
He said Ma's proposal to seek a "diplomatic truce" with China was well received by the Panamanian president, who described the approach as a "wise" one.

Ma has stressed many times that China and Taiwan should stop their "meaningless competition" in the international community, and that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should terminate their efforts to poach each other's allies by offering large sums of foreign aid funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government employees to enjoy 110 days off in 2009

TEXT.P: Government employees will have a total of 110 days off next year, the Executive Yuan's Central Personnel Administration said Thursday as it unveiled the 2009 work schedule for civil servants.
Holiday periods of three or more days will include the Chinese New Year break, between Jan. 24 and Feb. 1, and the Dragon Boat Festival, from May 28-31.
The work schedule only applies to government employees, as regulations concerning holidays for workers in the private sector are covered by the Labor Law, the administration said.
It further said that if a folk holiday falls on a Thursday or Tuesday, the Friday or Monday of that week will be given as a holiday so that employees can enjoy a long weekend.
However, employees will be required to make up the extra day off by working the Saturday in the week previous to or following the holiday weekend, the administration explained.
The adjustments will not apply to memorial holidays such as the Founding Day of the Republic of China, 228 Peace Memorial Day, and Double Tenth National Day, according to the administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: President meets his Panamanian counterpart
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Aug. 13 (CNA) 08/14/08 15:21:15 (By Ramon Huang and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: In a meeting between President Ma Ying-jeou and his Panamanian counterpart Wednesday morning at Panama International Airport, the two men reaffirmed the strong bilateral relationship between their two countries.

Speaking with reporters after the meeting, Panamanian Foreign Minister Lewis Navarro, who also serves as first vice president of the Central American country, said that President Martin Torrijos reiterated to Ma his country's strong support for Taiwan.

Navarro said that the two heads of state exchanged views on a variety of issues, including the current state of bilateral ties and world developments, in a sincere manner during the meeting, which lasted for more than an hour.
On cross-Taiwan strait issues, Navarro reiterated Panama's hope that the two sides can resolve the issues.
He added that Panama will continue to maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan while also maintaining an economic relationship with China.

President Ma's charter plane made a refueling stop in Panama City en route to Paraguay and the Dominican Republic, where Ma will attend the inaugurations of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo on Aug. 15 and Dominican Republic President-elect Leonel Fernandez on Aug. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma taking 'wise' diplomatic approach: Panamanian president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's proposal to seek a "diplomatic truce" with China and his "modus vivendi" strategy for Taiwan to obtain more international space were commended by his Panamanian counterpart President Martin Torrijos, who described the approach as a "wise" one, a Presidential Office official said Wednesday.

Torrijos made the remarks in a meeting with Ma after the Taiwan president arrived in Panama City around 2: 45 p.m. local time on a refueling stop. Ma is on his first state visit since he took office May 20. He will attend the inaugurations of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo on Aug. 15 and Dominican Republic President-elect Leonel Fernandez on Aug. 16.

During the hour long meeting between Ma and Torrijos, held in a state VIP room at the airport, they discussed bilateral cooperation and exchanged views on energy-saving, according to Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi, who briefed reporters later during a charter flight from Panama to Paraguay.

"What Taiwan is doing now is to change the nature of its relations with China and reopen negotiations, " Ma was quoted by Wang as saying. "By launching the direct weekend cross-strait charter flights, Taiwan also aims to normalize economic links with Beijing, " Ma added.

The president elaborated on his proposal for a "diplomatic truce," with China, which would mean that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait would stop the "vicious competition" to lure each other's allies, and instead would seek to cement existing ties. It would also mean that Taiwan would have more international space, according to Ma.

Describing the atmosphere of the meeting as "very relaxed and harmonious, " Wang said Ma also expressed Taiwan's interest in assisting Panama with its plan to widen the Panama Canal and voiced the hope that Taiwanese businesses could participate in the project.
Ma was the first head of state from Taiwan to visit Panama since Sept.1, 2004, when his predecessor Chen Shui-bian attended the Torrijos' inauguration.
Wang said that Ma invited his Panamanian counterpart to pay a state visit to Taiwan, and that Torrijos agreed to do so if there was a chance in the future.

Panama has been an ally of the Republic of China since 1909, but has maintained close business links with China. Rumors have abounded for a long time that the Central American country is swaying between Taiwan and China, in terms of its diplomatic leanings.

Although Ma's short stop in Panama on his way to Paraguay was for refueling purposes, it was generally viewed as a step toward improving the sometimes lukewarm diplomatic relations and cementing ties in general with the Central American country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Paraguay rolls out red carpet for President Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou, on arrival in Paraguay around 11: 30 p.m. local time, was given a high-level state welcome, with a red carpet, a guard of honor and hundreds of overseas Taiwanese waiting to greet him.

Before he disembarked from the charter plane, Ma was greeted by director-general of the Paraguayan foreign ministry's Department of Protocol and by David Hu, Taiwan's ambassador to Paraguay. He then disembarked and walked along a red carpet with a military honor guard lined up on both sides, to be received formally by Paraguayan Interior Minister Libio Florentin and his wife.

The minute Ma stepped off the Miami Airlines charter flight, around 300 hundred Taiwanese expatriates, who were lined up along the red carpet, began waving national flags of the Republic of China and calling out, "Greetings, President Ma."

Lin Shih-wei, first secretary of the Republic of China's Embassy in Paraguay, told the Central News Agency that many of the expatriates were from nearby countries such as Chili and Argentina, and that some had traveled to Paraguay a few days earlier just to greet Ma.

The purpose of Ma's first state visit since he took office May 20 is to attend the inaugurations of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo on Aug. 15 and Dominican Republic President-elect Leonel Fernandez on Aug. 16.

After acknowledging and shaking hands with the Taiwanese expatriates, Ma delivered a three minute speech at the airport, saying that he was deeply moved by the warm welcome, especially in light of the fact that he had arrived close to midnight.

"Taiwan and Paraguay have had 51 years of deep and solid friendship, " Ma said. "I would like to take this opportunity to consolidate our diplomatic relations and further develop the existing bilateral cooperation.

Noting that the outgoing Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte had visited Taiwan twice and that former Taiwan President Chen Shui-bian and former Vice President Annette Lu had also visited Paraguay, Ma said the links between the two countries are "very close"
Lugo had said many times that he would like to switch diplomatic recognition to China -- a statement that spurred speculations that Taiwan might lose its only diplomatic ally in South America.

Media reports from Paraguay said that the country's Vice President-elect Federico Franco has requested US$71 million in foreign aid from Taiwan and has threatened to sever ties with Taiwan before Lugo's inauguration if it does not receive the funding.
Lugo, however, told the Asuncion-based ABC Color daily news Tuesday that his government will maintain ties with Taipei -- a message that was welcomed by Taiwan.

Since President Ma Ying-jeou took office on May 20, he has sought an end to the longstanding diplomatic tug-of-war with China, in which both sides compete for recognition by giving large sums of money to developing countries desperate for funds, a practice that critics call checkbook diplomacy.

Speaking to reporters on the charter flight from Los Angeles to Paraguay after making a refueling stop in Panama, Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said he did not know what made Lugo change his statement, adding that Taiwan welcomed the assurance.

"The foreign ministry's stance is that any new bilateral cooperation between Taiwan and its allies must be project-oriented, and the ministry will make evaluations before deciding whether to approve foreign aid," Ou said.
From now on, Ou said, he will ask the ministry to monitor all foreign aid and will grant funds depending on the efficiency with which these projects are implemented.
However, "it is the transfer of technology and experience that is most effective in helping these countries," Ou added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung medical journal recorded in SCIE database

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Journal of Medical Sciences, a publication of Kaohsiung Medical University in southern Taiwan, has been accepted for indexing and abstracting in the Science Citation Index Expanded (SCIE), an international, multidisciplinary index of journal literature of the sciences.

At a ceremony at the university Wednesday, Yu Hsin-su, president of the university, accepted a certificate of accreditation from Garry Liang, regional head of the scientific business of Thomson Reuters in Taiwan and Hong Kong, which publishes the SCIE.
Yu said that he was pleased to see the journal, established in 1985, being covered in SCIE, along with a few professional journals in the country and about 7,000 others worldwide.

The medical journal is aimed at promoting clinical and scientific research in the medical sciences in Taiwan, and disseminating this research to the international community of medical and health care professionals, according to Yu.

The periodical is published monthly by Elsevier (Singapore) Pte Ltd, and solicits research papers in medicine from around the globe. It has published papers submitted by Indian, Japanese, Iranian and Iraqi academics.
Its subscriptions have reached some 1,000, while an additional 400 copies are usually sent out in journal exchanges with universities in the United States, Japan, China and Hong Kong, Yu noted.

The magazine serves as the main source of medical information in southern Taiwan and its reports have often been cited by domestic media outlets. It continues to retain Chinese extracts, although the journal was revised in 1997 and has been published in English since then.
The academic periodical offers prizes in two categories for excellent papers, in order to encourage medical researchers to contribute reports on their findings, Yue said.
The journal has won two awards from the Ministry of Education for teaching excellence and outstanding research achievements, Yu added.

In the near future, the journal's goal will be to seek sustainability by creating a platform for medical experts in Asia and medically emerging countries to present their research results in the areas of acute and chronic diseases, according to Yu.
He expressed hope that the periodical will be upgraded and promoted overseas and will be able to employ academics from abroad to work as editors.

Yu also said there are plans to issue a regular special edition that will cover themes such education, sciences and health reform, as well as issues related to environmental medicine, tropical medicine, health and behavioral sciences, national health insurance, health policies and medical education.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government's development agency makes first investment in film

TEXT.P: The Taiwan government's National Development Fund (NDF) has decided to make its first investment in a local film to help boost the country's cultural industry.

The management of the NDF announced in a statement Monday that it will sponsor Taiwanese filmmaker Hou Hsiao-hsien's science-fiction kung fu film, Nie Yin Niang, to the tune of NT$81.6 million (US$2.6 million).

The NDF made the decision based on the recommendation of the Cabinet-level Government Information Office (GIO), which oversees the country's film industry, GIO Deputy Minister Albert Lin said Thursday.
Lin noted that it is the first time that the GIO has made such a recommendation, adding that his office has also offered an additional grant of NT$15 million to the world-renowned director.
The production will cost an estimated NT$270 million, the highest ever in Taiwan's film industry, he said.
The shooting of the film is slated to begin this year and to be completed in 2010.
The government has decided to make the investments as it hopes that the production would help to expand Taiwan's film industry, widen its commercialization and draw higher box office sales, he said.

Traditionally, the government has used national development funds to boost local industries, with most of the money being invested in Taiwan's high tech industry, Lin said, citing as an example Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) , now the world's largest contract chipmaker.
If the government's investment in the film proves successful, this will help substantially to expand Taiwan's cultural sector, Lin forecast.
Taiwan's film market has been dominated by Hollywood movies over the years, although there have been several Taiwanese films that have won international awards.
The GIO often subsidizes local films, but according to Lin, the GIO will focus more on box office performance in the future.
It is believed that Hou's strong production team and the film's business- oriented plot based on an ancient Chinese novel will help to earn high revenues overseas, Lin said.
Hou's films have won awards at international festivals, including the Venice Film Festival and Berlin Film Festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics ministry pushes for cross-strait industry platform

TEXT.P: Taiwan will establish a cross-Taiwan Strait platform to promote exchanges and cooperation between local and Chinese industries, in order to jointly explore global business opportunities, Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming said Thursday.

This will serve as a bridge between enterprises on both sides of the strait, " Yiin said, adding that the various industry sectors would be able to work hand- in-hand in the areas of manufacturing, research development, and marketing.
Speaking at a press conference after a Cabinet meeting, Yiin said companies would even be able to launch joint ventures to access the mainland market.

In one of the Cabinet's key moves to boost Taiwan's industrial competitiveness, the platform is being established to explore global business by attracting international companies to take part in multilateral industrial cooperation, Yiin said.
"With the participation of multinational enterprises, industries across the strait could come up with new operational patterns that would lead to more business opportunities," he said.

The platform, to be implemented by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), is part the Kuomintang government's bid to deregulate cross-strait economic exchanges, following its raising of the cap on China-bound investment by local enterprises from 40 percent to 60 percent of their net worth, in July.
Yiin said that during first year of the latest initiative, the efforts will focus on getting companies from both sides to know each other.
In December a seminar will be held to facilitate strategic alliance in the field of Chinese herbal medicine," the minister said, indicating that this will mark the launch of the measure.

The series of the seminars, to run from 2008 to 2009, will include industries such as solar photovoltaic, electric motor, aviation. textiles and fibers, telecommunication, and cycling, according to the MOEA.
Each of these seminars will be attended by representatives of 200 to 300 companies, including 40 to 50 Chinese firms, Yiin said.
During the second and third years of the initiative, the MOEA will push for more substantial business cooperation, Yiin said, but he did not specify the areas of the cooperation.

Meanwhile, Yiin said that during the period January to July, Taiwan attracted NT$810.1 billion (US$26.13 billion) in private investment, about 75 percent of the annual target of NT$1.08 trillion from private capital.
"We should be able to meet that target, " Yiin said, adding that his ministry estimates that private domestic investment for the next four years could surpass NT$4 trillion.
