DOC.HEADLINE: MasterCard eyes purchasing power of cross-strait business travelers

TEXT.P: MasterCard International announced Thursday the upcoming launch of what it called "the most lavish incentive program" in the greater China region, setting its sights on the strong purchasing power of Taiwanese business people who travel frequently across the Taiwan Strait.

The program, to run from Aug. 15 to Nov. 30, is expected to give away up to 50 BMW Cruise bicycles -- valued at approximately NT$70,000 each -- to holders of Taiwan-issued Mastercards who make transactions accumulating to US$50,000 in China, Hong Kong or Macau, according to Tina Chiang, general manager of the company's greater China operations.
Card holders who spend an accumulated amount of US$5,000 will win a Samsonite rolling tote, Chiang said.

"As the launch of cross-strait weekend charter flights has significantly enhanced the mobility of Taiwanese business people in the greater China region, we are optimistic about the purchasing power of business people traveling frequently to and from China, Hong Kong and Macau," she said.
In Taiwan, 13 banks are issuing platinum business credit cards targeting owners of small- and medium-sized businesses, she pointed out.
For travelers between Taiwan and China, credit cards are an important means of payment for items such as flight tickets, hotels, dining, drinking and shopping, she added.

According to the MasterCard Worldwide Index of Travel report released last week, 17.6 percent of Taiwanese business travelers said that over the last 12 months, they needed to travel more compared to the previous period.

As many as 60.8 percent of the respondents mentioned China as their most frequent business travel destination, which made the country the most visited destination by Taiwanese business travelers. Japan was the second-most visited destination, followed by the United States.
The report forecast that Taiwan will record 4.6 million outbound travelers during the second half of 2008, a rise of 1.7 percent over the same period last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Group urges public to practice safe 'ghost money' burning

TEXT.P: Environmental groups and academics on Thursday urged the public to collectively burn "ghost money" in environmentally-friendly incinerators run by local governments or temples during Friday's "Ghost Festival."

According to the Environmental Resources Development Foundation, temples around Taiwan burned an average of nearly 35,000 metric tons of ghost money and 4,190 metric tons of incense each year for the past three years. That figure does not include ghost money burnt in homes and private shops.

Government officials said that ideally no ghost money would be burnt at all, because the process releases toxic chemicals that pose a health risk. Officials from the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration's Department of Air Quality Protection and Noise Control said burning ghost money releases benzene -- a carcinogen -- and other pollutants.

Wu Chia-cheng, chairman of the Consumers Foundation and a chemistry professor at National Taiwan Normal University, said that most of the incense and ghost paper money for sale in Taiwan is imported from Southeast Asian countries. Almost all such imported ghost money falls short of environmental protection standards, he said.

Many prominent religious groups in Taiwan, such as Fo Guang Shan Monastery, Longshan Temple, the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and the Dharma Drum Mountain Culture and Education Foundation, have dropped the tradition of burning ghost money in order to protect the environment, foundation officials said.

In recent years, several city and county governments have offered to collect and burn ghost money on behalf of residents in environmentally-friendly mass incinerators. Some temples have also installed more environmentally safe furnaces for burning the sacrificial money.

"Ghost Festival" falls on the 15th day of the seventh lunar month, which is known as "Ghost month." According to traditional Chinese folk belief, souls are released from hell during this month to freely wander the earth.

Burning ghost money began as a ritual to "bribe" such spirits so they don't create mischief or harm. Believers burn money year-round, but the activity reaches a peak during Ghost Month, and especially on the 15th day of the month.
In addition to curbing the use of ghost money, environmental groups hope to push temples and religious devotees to burn less or no incense while worshipping, foundation officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Luodong Fringe Festival to climax Aug. 16

TEXT.P: The 2008 Luodong Fringe Festival, sponsored by Luodong township in northeastern Taiwan, will culminate Saturday with a street parade of 20 floats and teams of samba dancers, along with 61 performance teams from Taiwan and abroad.

Township chief Lin Tsung-hsien told reporters Thursday that the samba dancers and foreign performers from Brazil, Mexico, the United States and Thailand will join teams from Taipei, Keelung, Nantou, Taitung and Yilan County during the two-hour parade that will begin at 4 p.m.

According to Lin, the festive mood is expected to continue from 7 p.m. until the close of the festival, with the samba dancers sharing the stage with performers from the local community, followed by other colorful entertainment programs.
The Luodong Fringe Festival, now in its seventh year, is modeled on Scotland's Edinburgh International Festival and France's Avignon Dramatic Art Festival.
The annual event represents Luodong's attempt to promote local tourism through cultural activities that are ideal for families throughout the summer.
This year's festival began July 19, with most of the activities taking place at Luodong's Jhongshan Park and at the Luodong Exhibition Hall.

The activities have included modern dance and music performances, a national street dance competition, story-telling, demonstrations by spinning top performers, performances by rock bands and elementary school orchestras, and children's films from the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany Italy, Spain, Iceland, China, India, Thailand and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suspended particulate emissions down at Yunlin construction sites

TEXT.P: Total suspended particulate (TSP) emissions at construction sites in Yunlin County have dropped 47.3 percent following the implementation in April of air pollution regulations at the sites, the county government's Environmental Protection Bureau said Thursday.

According to the department, TSP emissions at construction sites in the southern county were recorded at 2,502 tons between April and July, down by 1,182 tons from the level for the previous three months.

Under the air pollution plan, the bureau has stepped up TSP testing at the county's construction sites, as well as inspections to determine whether companies are following various related regulations, including dust clean-up and greening of open areas at the sites.

The bureau said it conducted more than 950 spot checks at over 750 construction sites in the county during the April-July period, and issued over 30 fines for violations of the regulations, including eight for excessive TSP levels at tested sites.
The bureau urged residents who notice any construction sites that may in violation of the county's air pollution control regulations to call (05) 536-2468 to report the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 33.73 points, or 0.46 percent, to close at 7,326.07.

Ending a two-day losing streak, the local bourse opened at 7,265.01 and fluctuated between 7,353.31 and 7,253.63. A total of 4.27 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$100.33 billion (US$3.21 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 3.3 percent. Cement stocks advanced 2.1 percent, textile stocks rose 1.6 percent, paper and pulp issues increased 1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares gained 0.6 percent, banking and financial shares were up 0.5 percent.
Foodstuff issues lost ground, decreasing 0.4 percent, while machinery and electronics shares remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,231 to 873, with 467 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$5.54 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prisoner passes entrance exam for national college

TEXT.P: A prisoner in Hualien County, eastern Taiwan, has passed the entrance examination for a national college with a score substantially higher than the threshold, a Ministry of Justice (MOJ) official said Thursday.

According to the official of the MOJ's Department of Corrections, the 37-year- old inmate, identified by the pseudonym Lee, scored 220.8 in the national exam, surpassing many students who are not incarcerated. This year's lowest score for entering a college was registered at 7.69.
Lee was sentenced to 14 years for collecting payments for illegal loansharks with violence in 1996 at the age of 26, at which point he had only an elementary education, the official said.

According to a prison official, Lee did not show much inclination to pursue his education until his father's accidental death in 2000. He acquired the admission to a school at the prison in 2002 and completed his junior and senior high school education in the ensuing years.
Lee's mother moved to Hualien County in 2003 and visits him twice a week to offer support for him. He has returned top scores every semester, the official said.
Despite the fact that Lee passed the entrance exam, he still has three more years to serve.
The MOJ has ruled out the possibility of allowing Lee to attend classes under guard and protection, as it would mean he would suffer serious discrimination from society, according to the official.

Justice Minister Wang Ching-feng said Lee can apply for parole this month and if the application is approved, he will be able to start his college life at the National Hualien University of Education.
Wang expressed hope that Lee and other prisoners who pass the entrance exam will be able to study at colleges like ordinary students and that society will accept them.
In addition to Lee, another 12 prison inmates passed this year's college entrance examination, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese, French hand puppets to meet at Taipei Arts Festival

TEXT.P: Taiwanese traditional hand puppets and France's Guignol puppet tradition will share the stage in a play titled La Boite (The Box) at the 10th Taipei Arts Festival, telling a story of an intercultural voyage beyond the language barrier, Philippe Auchere, director of the Compagnie des Zonzons -- a French puppet theater group -- announced Thursday.

In the trilingual play performed in French, Mandarin and Hoklo, a Taiwanese dialect, the audience will enjoy the rare experience of exchange of the two different cultures through the blending of Chinese hand puppets and the French Guignol puppets, as well as a musical amalgamation of accordion, harp and Nanguan, a wind instrument that originated in southern China.

La Boite refers to the boxes in which the puppets are kept, the two theater companies explained at a press conference, adding that the play is like a gift box waiting to be opened and leads the audience on an intercultural journey.

"The play is more an intercultural voyage than a story, it is about sharing and communications, an acceptance of each other such as they are, " said Auchere to CNA reporter, adding that spectators will play a role of witnesses of the exotic encounter.
He said that at the start of the collaboration, the two groups had difficulty communicating due to the language barrier, but as they worked together, they finally found a common language -- art.
The project was first initiated in 2005 and was finally brought to the stage in Lyon, France in April to celebrate Guignol's 200th birthday, winning an overwhelming response from audiences.
Guignol is a traditional puppet created by Laurent Mourguet in 1808 in Lyon.
The Chinese hand puppet originated in 17th Century Fujian Province in southern China.
La Boite will be performed Aug. 15-17, at the Zhongshan Hall in Taipei City, with projected subtitles in Mandarin and English.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan men's table tennis team loses to South Korea

TEXT.P: Taiwan lost to South Korea in the men's table tennis team competition Thursday at the Beijing Olympics, losing the opportunity to vie for a gold medal.
South Korea beat Taiwan 3-1. Taiwan will fight for the bronze medal Friday.
The defeat came after Taiwan beat Brazil 3-1 and edged out Sweden 3-2 a day earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president says wife wired campaign funds to overseas account

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday said that his wife Wu Shu-jen had wired abroad an unspecified amount of money that Chen had received as campaign contributions.
The surprise announcement is likely to add to Chen's legal woes, since it comes as the former president is already battling charges that he misused public funds.

In a televised news conference, Chen apologized to the public for not clearly accounting for his campaign contributions, saying the failure to make such a report was "something that is not permitted by the law."
But he insisted his wife had made the wire transfers without his knowledge, and argued that at the time he received the campaign donations there was no law requiring he report their receipt.
Chen said the funds wired abroad were left over from four of his campaigns -- two for Taipei mayor and two for the presidency, the last one in 2004.

Chen said that his wife had stashed the funds overseas in case he needed them after he stepped down from the presidency on May 20. He said he only learned about the transfers earlier this year, and then decided he would use the funds in the future for Taiwan's diplomacy.
He denied that there was any link between the funds his wife wired abroad and the recent scandal over a botched attempt to win Papua New Guinea as a diplomatic ally.
He said many prominent politicians besides him also had failed to fully report campaign funds.

Under Taiwan's campaign laws, candidates are required to report campaign spending. But candidates were not required to report all political donations until the passage of the Political Contributions Act in 2004.

Chen made his announcement one day after the Next Weekly tabloid reported that the Egmont Group, an international anti-money laundering network, had alerted Taiwan authorities that the former first lady had made large money transfers to several foreign bank accounts.

The weekly cited anonymous sources saying that Wu had closed Taiwan bank accounts belonging to her and her husband, as well as several others, in 2006, soon after the exposure of the "state affairs fund" scandal. In that scandal, Chen's wife and three close aides were charged with misuse of public funds.
Chen himself was immune from charges while a sitting president, but prosecutors launched a probe against him immediately after he stepped down from office on May 20.
Next Weekly claimed that the Taiwan accounts were created under the names of Wu's son Chen Chih-chung and her daughter Chen Hsing-yu and were used for stock trading.

Shortly before Chen's news conference, Kuomintang Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu alleged that Swiss prosecutors had asked Taiwan authorities to verify the origin of a huge amount of funds in a Swiss bank account in the name of Chen's daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.
The Foreign Ministry later confirmed that the Swiss had requested Taiwan's cooperation in an unspecified case.
Meanwhile, local cable news station TVBS reported that more than US$20 million was deposited in the Swiss account in Chen's daughter-in-law 's name on Feb. 8, 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese frozen ducks gaining popularity in Singapore
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 14 (CNA) 08/14/08 20:42:40 (By Charles Kang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Several Singaporean newspapers have recently reported that frozen ducks imported from Taiwan are gaining popularity since they began being imported into the city-state in April.

The English-language Straits Times and the Chinese-language Lianhe Zaobao and Shin Min Daily News said the ducks taste similar to the live ducks that Singaporeans are accustomed to and that a lot of roast duck vendors have now turned to frozen ducks from Taiwan.
A 54-year-old roast duck shop owner told the Straits Times that frozen ducks from Taiwan are cleaner and he does not have to spend a lot of time preparing them.
He also said the Taiwanese ducks are cheaper than live ducks from Malaysia.

Another frozen meat importer told the Lianhe Zaobao that the recent world oil price surge has added transportation costs, making live ducks from Malaysia more expensive but presenting an opportunity for Taiwanese frozen ducks.
Previously, the price of Taiwanese ducks from Hualien and Pingtung was higher than live ducks from Malaysia, but is now between 8 percent and 10 percent cheaper, giving them a competitive edge.
Roast ducks are popular in Singapore and the country mainly relies on Malaysia for supplies. Singapore imported 6.4 million live ducks, or 12,800 tons, from Malaysia last year.

In comparison, the ratio of imported frozen ducks is much smaller, with only 603 tons imported last year, 90 percent of which came from the United States, with the rest coming from France and the Netherlands. However, one roast duck vendor said the American ducks are too mushy for Singaporean tastes and that the tougher Taiwanese ones are more to their liking.

As inflation in Singapore has reached a 26-year high, the government is looking for cheaper sources of high quality food, and approved imports of frozen duck from Taiwan to ensure the diversification of food sources.
Since Taiwanese imports began in April, the volume has reached 35 tons as of the end of June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker upbeat about post-Olympics cross-strait ties

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait ties should move in a positive direction after the Beijing Olympics amid high public expectations, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday.

"If Taiwan-China relations fail to improve after the Olympics, it will disappoint many Taiwanese people who hope for an improved situation across the strait, " Wang told reporters following a seminar sponsored by the Democratic Pacific Union to mark its third anniversary.

"There remains ample room for Taiwan and China to further enhance their exchanges and cooperation, but if the two sides fail to achieve this aim, it will mean that previous efforts by both will have been in vain, " he said.

Thanks to the success of the Beijing Olympics, China will definitely emerge as a regional and global superpower after the Olympics, despite several incidents that have occurred so far and regardless of the country's tainted human rights record, he predicted.
With the greater leverage that will come with its stronger clout, China is set to play a prominent role in critical international issues, he said.

Although President Ma Ying-jeou has been seeking to improve Taiwan-China ties by implementing a series of economic opening measures since he assumed office May 20, Wang pointed out that Taiwan- U.S. and Taiwan-Japan ties are equally important.
Wang visited the United States and Japan recently, respectively, to lobby for continued support from the two countries for Taiwan in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gambling decriminalization needed prior to offshore casinos

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said at a regular Thursday Cabinet meeting that before the government can outline plans to build casinos on the outlying islands, it will first have to decriminalize gambling on the islands.

No decision was made on the controversial issue of construction of offshore casinos, as Liu said only that "in principle, one of the major efforts in the development of the outlying islands is the construction of the tourism industry."

Opening casinos on Taiwan's outlying islands -- especially the Penghu Islands -- to attract tourists has not been able to achieve consensus despite years of discussion, mainly due to the fact that gambling is illegal.
The Penghu Islands, located in the Taiwan Strait, are in a poor economic and financial situation thanks to its lack of economic activity apart from fishing, and tourism has become its lifeline.

It has been suggested that the decriminalization of the Offshore Islands Development Act would boost the economy by helping to introduce the gaming industry to the islands, thereby attracting more visitors.
Liu said the Cabinet will need to push for the decriminalization of gaming before the casino plan can be outlined by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
Should the Legislature Yuan legalize the gaming industry on the outlying islands, the Cabinet will then need to draft a statute to regulate gaming.

While the present Cabinet bid is a long way from actually building the gaming industry, Liu's statement nevertheless marked a step forward and suggests that the casino plan might finally see the light after decades of debate.

President Ma Ying-jeou has shown his support for the casino plan, saying before his May 20 inauguration that once Penghu residents reach consensus on the casino issue, the central government will spare no efforts to help facilitate the development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Biologists spot the largest patch of algal reefs in eastern Taiwan

TEXT.P: Marine biologists at Academia Sinica have spotted a new patch of algal reefs along the coast of Shanyuan Bay in Taitung County, with a total surface area estimated to be larger than any other algal reef in eastern Taiwan, sources at the institution said Thursday.

"It is quite a surprise to find so large a patch of algal reefs that is relatively undisturbed by human activities, " said Chen Chao- lun, an associate researcher at Academia Sinica's Research Center for Biodiversity.
Algal reefs, formed by crystalline calcium carbonates left by dead calcareous algae, usually grow at the extremely slow rate of 0.1 centimeters to 0.2 centimeters in thickness per year.
The largest patch of algal reefs in Taiwan is located off the northern county of Taoyuan and is four kilometers long and 500 meters wide.

To date, the largest patch of algal reefs found in eastern Taiwan is located in Kenting National Park's Chialoshui area. However, based on preliminary estimates, the reefs in Shanyuan Bay could be bigger than those in Chialoshui, said Chen.

Chen -- who was commissioned in 2008 by the government to conduct a decade-long survey of the marine ecology in Shanyuan Bay, Green Island, and the Penghu Islets -- spotted new coral reefs and new coral species in Shanyuan Bay early this year.

Chen said that according to observations in the past, the sea water temperatures are higher than normal in Shanyuan Bay, which would usually inhibit the development of algae reefs. However, the new findings contradict this premise, he said.

"Since some areas of the algae reefs have already been damaged by discarded fish nets, the government should step up its efforts to preserve the area and to facilitate further research on algae reefs," Chen suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: Five longan farms in Tainan County open for DIY harvesting

TEXT.P: Five leisure farms in Tainan County's Dongshan township will join a month-long pick-it-yourself program organized by the county government from Friday, Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih announced Thursday.

At a press conference held at the Senwho Leisure Farm in the township's Nanshih village, Su said longans are an important summer crop for Tainan County, with the planted acreage totaling over 1,000 hectares, yielding more than 12,000 metric tons of the fruit a year.

Su said visitors to any of the five orchards need only pay an entry fee of NT$100 (US$3.20) per person, with children under 110 cm tall admitted free. They can eat as many freshly picked longans as they want before taking an additional 1.8 kg of the fruit home at no extra charge.
Visitors to the participating orchards will also be able to see how longans are dried in traditional kilns, Su said.
Three of the participating orchards are managed by coffee ecological farms, which specialize in coffee cultivation and also offer their products to visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Fringe Festival to showcase ingenuity of young talent

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taipei Fringe Festival is slated to open Aug. 30, marking the first time that it will be held in the capital city, according to the event's executive director.
During the 16-day festival, various performances -- including drama, dance, music and mime -- will be staged, executive director Wang Wen-yi said Wednesday at a warm-up news conference.
A total of 61 arts companies have signed up to perform at the festival, since the organizers launched a month-long campaign in late April to solicit performance applications.
The arts companies will stage 166 performances produced by artists who are, on average, 30 years old.
The performances are aimed at presenting various dimensions such as alternative culturalism, cross-culturalism and cultural pluralism.
Taipei is the sixth Asian city to sponsor the fringe festival. The other five cities are Seoul, Macao, Bangkok, Singapore and Shanghai.
Launched in Edinburgh in 1947, the annual Fringe Festival has become one of the world's most popular artistic activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative delegation to visit Turkey

TEXT.P: A legislative delegation is to visit Turkey in a bid to enhance Taiwan-Turkey relations, Legislator Lin Yu-fang, convener of the legislature's Foreign and National Defense Committee said Thursday.
Lin said the delegation will visit Ankara and Istanbul to call on Turkish parliamentarians, local chiefs and think tanks.
"We hope the legislative diplomacy will enhance bilateral ties, " he said.

Lin noted that Taiwan used to maintain good relations with Turkey and that Turkey used to issue landing visas to Taiwanese tourists, and said the delegation hopes Turkey will reinstate its visa privileges for Taiwanese tourists.
The delegation also hopes to establish direct air links with Turkey and to see the establishment of a pro-Taiwan caucus in the Turkish parliament.
Lin noted that Turkey has in recent years developed good relations with China, with bilateral trade reaching US$15 billion, compared with trade with Taiwan at just US$1.6 billion annually.
With Taiwan registering a trade surplus of around US$1.3 billion, and 15,000 Taiwanese visiting Turkey every year, Lin said there is ample room for an upgrading of relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: LED lights expensive, not energy-saving: foundation

TEXT.P: Local light emitting diode (LED) lights, which are generally believed to be energy-conserving, do not necessarily save power and are more expensive than average fluorescent ones, according to test results released Thursday by the Consumers' Foundation.
The foundation conducted the tests on 11 samples from local hypermarkets, home retailers, chain bookstores, electronic product markets and the Internet in June.
The samples included four bulbs, three lamps and four USB lights, according to the foundation.

After conducting the tests, the foundation said in a statement that it discovered that small wattages are enough to power LED lights, compared with the dozens of watts needed for incandescent or fluorescent lights.

However, under the same lighting demands, LED lights do not necessarily outperform other types of lights, the foundation observed, attributing this to the LED lights' low luminous efficiency and power factor.
As a result, it is better to use LED lights as purely decorative lights rather than as reading lights, the foundation went on.
In addition, the foundation said the prices of local LED lights are three or four times higher than those of average fluorescent ones, and demanded a price decrease.
The foundation also pointed out that LED lights are new products and there are currently no regulations governing the application of LED lights in home products.
It urged authorities to formulate regulations on LED products and to require them to meet a certain level of energy conservation.
When buying LED devices, consumers should turn them on for a period of time and choose ones with lower temperatures, the foundation suggested.
LED devices are commonly used in traffic lights, store signs, billboards, flashlights and vehicle lights.
Taiwan started developing its LED industry in 1986 and has grown rapidly since then, according to government statistics released a day earlier.
From 2000, Taiwan's LED industry has had the world's highest production volume and the world's second-largest output, the statistics show.
In 2007, Taiwan's LED industry generated NT$53.9 billion (about US$1.7 billion) in output, accounting for 25 percent of the world's total production value, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Zoo to house two Chinese pandas

TEXT.P: The COA made the decision after on-site inspections earlier in the day of the two zoos that filed applications to house the pandas -- the Taipei Zoo and the Leofoo Safari Zoo located in Hsinchu County, northern Taiwan.

The Taipei Zoo was picked over Leofoo as it provides better conditions in the areas of education, research plans and medical care, said COA representatives at a press conference after the review meeting.

"Taipei has prepared for many years to receive the pandas; we will consider them as our own children and provide them with the best care, " Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin was quoted as saying by Taipei city government spokesman Yang Hsiao- tung.

According to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), the Taipei Zoo should apply first for authorization from the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Due to the import procedures and quarantine measures, the two pandas might not arrive in Taiwan before the end of the year, according to the Taipei city government.
The two pandas, named Tuan-tuan and Yuan-yuan by the Chinese, which means "reunion," were offered as a gift to Taiwan after a visit to China by then- Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan in 2005.
The offer, however, was rejected by the COA under the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration as Taiwan did not have adequate conditions to raise the animals.

According to a survey conducted in July by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Executive Yuan, 56.1 percent of the Taiwanese are in favor of receiving the Chinese pandas, and 60.1 percent believe the pandas will help Taiwan's tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei-Kaohsiung flights to continue until late September

TEXT.P: Domestic flights between Taipei and Kaohsiung will be maintained for another month, despite a request from Mandarin Airlines to halt the service, Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Lee Lung-wen said Thursday.

The CAA has asked Mandarin Airlines to provide the service for at least one more month until the end of September because air travel demand from residents in the southern Kaohsiung and Pingtung regions remains high, Lee said, adding that "this is why the CAA has not approved the carrier's request to halt the service."
"Taipei-Kaohsiung flights will be maintained through September, " Lee stated.

The passenger load factor on the Taipei-Kaohsiung route still averages around 50 percent, he noted. Meanwhile, Mandarin Airlines, the sole operator on the route, announced that from Aug. 16, it will offer only a single daily round-trip flight between the two largest cities in Taiwan, down from the present seven round-trip flights per week.
The number of flights on the Taipei-Kaohsiung route exceeded 100 per day during its peak years, when it was the most profitable domestic flight.

Although the CAA did not approve Mandarin Airlines' request last week to halt the flight service, a company executive said a passenger load factor lower than 60 percent makes it very difficult for a carrier to maintain operations.
Air travel on the western Taiwan corridor has been hard-hit by the high speed train system that went into service in January 2007.

In the face of operating difficulties from the fierce competition from the bullet train, aviation companies have progressively chopped flights between Taipei and Taichung in central Taiwan and between Taipei, Chiayi and Tainan in the south.
In 1997, passengers took 18 million flights inside Taiwan, but the figure decreased to 8 million in 2006 and to 4 million in 2007, according to statistics.
Industry sources predicted that the number will drop even further this year.
In another development, UNI Airways Corp., which flies from Taipei to Pingtung and Hengchung in southern Taiwan, is also considering stopping its flights on the two routes.
But Lee said the CAA will not allow UNI Airways to stop flying the two routes, out of fear that the two local airports might be forced to close as a result.

According to Lee, the CAA will allocate preferential cross-Taiwan Strait and international flights to aviation companies that cooperate with the government in serving money-losing destinations at home.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academia Sinica announces new honorary academicians

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica, Taiwan's most prestigious research institution, announced eight new honorary academicians Thursday, including six Nobel laureates, according to a press release from the institution.

Three, in the division of mathematics and physical sciences, were named as Charles M. Vest, president of the National Academy of Engineering in the United States, who specializes in lasers and coherent optics, and Leo Esaki and Heinrich Rohrer, both Nobel prize winners in physics.
David Baltimore and Baruch S. Blumberg, both Nobel prize winners in physiology or medicine, were elected as honorary academicians in the division of life sciences.

The remaining three, who cross the division between life sciences, the humanities and social sciences are L. Luca Cavalli-Sforza, professor emeritus at Stanford University's Department of Genetics, and Leland H. Hartwell and Phillip A. Sharp, both of whom are Nobel laureates in physiology or medicine, the press release said.
The new honorary academicians, whose seats have been empty for more than 30 years, were elected by Academia Sinica's convocation, which is made of the institution's academicians in three divisions.
Related regulations that were amended last year stipulate that the life-tenure positions of honorary academicians have to be elected every two years.
The newly elected are tasked with promoting domestic and international academic cooperation and directing the research profile of the institution.
In addition to the eight honorary academicians, the Academia Sinica currently has a total of 249 domestic and foreign academicians.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA confirms Swiss request for help in money-laundering probe

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) confirmed Thursday that its representative in Switzerland had received a request from the Swiss Confederation's Department of Justice three weeks ago, seeking assistance about suspected money laundering by the daughter-in-law of former President Chen Shui- bian.
A spokesman for the ministry said that the request had been transferred to the Ministry of Justice (MOJ).

The MOJ also confirmed in a news release late Thursday that it had received the request from the MOFA through the Prosecutors Office of the Taiwan High Court and that the request had been relayed to the Taipei District Court's Public Prosecutors Office.
Earlier in the day, Chen had apologized to the nation, admitting that he lied about the election campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004.

Accompanied by his lawyer, Richard Lee, Chen told a press conference that he was unaware that his wife, Wu Shu-jen, had wired surplus funds from election campaign contributions abroad until early this year.
He said his conscience dictated to him that he could not continue to cheat himself and others, and that he had decided to make a clean breast.
"I did something that I should not have done," Chen admitted, adding that he was "willing to accept criticism and face an investigation."

Chen made the confession after Hung Hsiu-chu, a legislator of the ruling Kuomintang, revealed copies of documents showing that the Federal Department of Justice and Police of the Swiss Confederation was requesting assistance from the government in Taipei about suspected money laundering by Chen's son Chen Chih- chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching through two Swiss bank accounts.
The former president claimed that he did not touch any funds from the campaign contributions and that all the surplus funds were handled by his wife.
He admitted that the surplus did not belong to him and that it was intended for use to help Democratic Progressive Party candidates in future elections.

A day earlier, Chen had denied through his lawyer a claim by Next magazine that his daughter-in-law had laundered money for him by secretly wiring NT$300 million (US$9.63 million) into an overseas account.

Next magazine claimed that prosecutors learned from the Egmont Group, an international association of financial intelligence organizations, that Chen had used Huang and other members of her family to wire the NT$300 million out of Taiwan, and that the total could exceed NT$1 billion if other "suspicious" capital is accounted for.

DOC.HEADLINE: President declines to comment on former president's scandal

TEXT.P: Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Thursday in Paraguay that President Ma Ying-jeou had not commented on the latest scandal to beset his predecessor, Chen Shui-bian, in which Chen's wife is alleged to have been involved in wiring campaign funds into overseas bank accounts.
"So far, we have no comment on the incident, " Wang told reporters.
Ma, who is making his first state visit since taking office May 20, is in Paraguay to attend the Aug. 15 inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo.
He was scheduled to hold a news conference at 5: 30 p.m. local time, in which he was expected to be swamped with questions about the scandal.

Chen admitted Thursday said that his wife Wu Shu-jen had wired abroad un unspecified amount of cash that Chen had received as campaign contributions for his two Taipei mayoral elections and two presidential election campaigns.

In a televised news conference, Chen apologized to the public for not clearly accounting for his campaign contributions, admitting that the failure to make such a report was "something that is not permitted by the law."
The former president insisted his wife had made the wire transfers without his knowledge, in case Chen needed the cash after he stepped down from the presidency.
Chen, who said the funds wired abroad were left over from his campaigns, argued that at the time he received the campaign donations there was no law requiring that he should report them.
Under Taiwan's campaign laws, candidates are required to report campaign spending but were not required to report all political donations until the passage of the Political Contributions Act in 2004.

The announcement was made one day after the Next Weekly tabloid reported that the Egmont Group, an international anti-money laundering network, had alerted Taiwanese authorities that the former first lady had made large money transfers to several foreign bank accounts.

Shortly before Chen's news conference, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu said Swiss prosecutors had asked the Taiwanese authorities to verify the origin of a huge amount of funds in a Swiss bank account in the name of Chen's daughter-in-law, Huang Jui-ching.
Local news station TVBS reported that more than US$20 million was deposited in the Swiss account in Huang's name Feb. 8, 2007.
The Foreign Ministry later confirmed that the Swiss authorities had indeed requested Taiwan's cooperation in an unspecified case.

DOC.HEADLINE: Naturalization rules relaxed for foreign spouses

TEXT.P: Foreign spouses of local citizens intending to apply for naturalization will no longer be required to produce financial status statements, according to an amendment to the enforcement rules of the Nationality Act passed by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) Thursday.
The relaxed rules will be implemented after the Executive Yuan approves them later this month, an MOI official said.
According to the official, some 60,000 foreign spouses now residing in Taiwan can benefit from the new rules.

DOC.HEADLINE: Outgoing Paraguayan President lauds Taiwan for cross-strait peace

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeous effort in seeking peace with China was well received by outgoing Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Thursday during a bilateral meeting in which Duarte expressed gratitude offered by Taiwan during his five-year presidency.

I would like to express my appreciation toward President Mas efforts in seeking peace (with China) , Duarte was quoted as saying by Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi, who briefed the reporters after the two heads of state held a 45-minute meeting.
Describing the atmosphere of the meeting as harmonious, Wang said Ma elaborated his ideas of adiplomatic trucewith China and said that such approach was well- received by many people.

Under the precondition of diplomatic truce, we will strengthen relations with Paraguay and consolidate our friendship, Ma said, adding that the method has been well received in many Asian countries, as it is viewed as beneficiary in promoting regional peace.

The president said that a series of policies, such as the launch of direct weekend charter flights across the Taiwan Strait, are aimed to normalize the economic interactions and promote peace and prosperity between the two sides.
Cross-strait atmosphere already began changing with both Taipei and Beijing feel that such approach serves the interests of the two," Ma was quoted as having told Duarte.
According to Wang, Ma and Duarte also shared experiences in land reform and exchanged views on anti-drugs.
Ma, who arrived at Paraguay around midnight on Wednesday to attend the inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo on Aug. 15, expressed best regards to the outgoing Duarte.
Taiwan and Paraguay share a long friendship for 51 years and such friendship is very rare, Ma said.I will remember the friendship that President Duarte had offered to Taiwan.
In response, Duarte said that he is deeply grateful for the help offered by Taiwan during his five-year presidency.
Taiwan and Paraguay forged diplomatic relations in 1957 and Paraguay remains Taiwans only ally in South America.

Mas visit was viewed to strengthen ties with Paraguay given the fact that Lugo had said many times that he would like to switch diplomatic recognition to China -- a statement that spurred speculations that Taiwan might lose Paraguay.
However, Lugo told the Asuncion-based ABC Color daily news Tuesday that his government will maintain ties with Taipei, a message that was welcomed by Taiwan.

After attending the inaugurations of Lugo, Ma is scheduled to go to the Dominican Republic to attend the inauguration of President Leonel Fernandez for a new term on Aug. 16. He will return to Taiwan on Aug. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan bags 1st win in softball, but loses to Japan in baseball

TEXT.P: Taiwan beat Venezuela 3-0 in the Beijing Olympic softball game Thursday, marking its first victory after losing to Canada and Japan.
Taiwanese players pounded out six hits with no error throughout the game, while Venezuela scored three hits and had two errors.

Chang Chia-hsing, Taiwan team's coach, said he was satisfied with the Taiwanese players' performance in the game. "I'm hopeful that the momentum carrying the team's to today's victory will continue and will not peter out," he added.
The team will face the Australian squad Friday. Australia is one of the three teams considered to be medal favorities.
In baseball, Taiwan lost to Japan 6-1, following its victory over the Netherlands a day earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Friday.

The weighted price index was up 48.31 points at 7,374.38 on a turnover of NT$2.75 billion (US$88.03 million) at the open. The index gained 33.73 points, or 0.46 percent, to close at 7,326.07 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Friday.
The greenback was trading at NT$31.382 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.142 from Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA confirms Swiss request for help in money-laundering probe

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) confirmed Thursday that its representative in Switzerland had received a request from the Swiss Confederation's Department of Justice three weeks ago, seeking assistance about suspected money laundering by the daughter-in-law of former President Chen Shui- bian.
A spokesman for the ministry said that the request had been transferred to the Ministry of Justice (MOJ).

The MOJ also confirmed in a news release late Thursday that it had received the request from the MOFA through the Prosecutors Office of the Taiwan High Court and that the request had been relayed to the Taipei District Court's Public Prosecutors Office.
Earlier in the day, Chen had apologized to the nation, admitting that he lied about the election campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004.

Accompanied by his lawyer, Richard Lee, Chen told a press conference that he was unaware that his wife, Wu Shu-jen, had wired surplus funds from election campaign contributions abroad until early this year.
He said his conscience dictated to him that he could not continue to cheat himself and others, and that he had decided to make a clean breast.
"I did something that I should not have done," Chen admitted, adding that he was "willing to accept criticism and face an investigation."

Chen made the confession after Hung Hsiu-chu, a legislator of the ruling Kuomintang, revealed copies of documents showing that the Federal Department of Justice and Police of the Swiss Confederation was requesting assistance from the government in Taipei about suspected money laundering by Chen's son Chen Chih- chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching through two Swiss bank accounts.
The former president claimed that he did not touch any funds from the campaign contributions and that all the surplus funds were handled by his wife.
He admitted that the surplus did not belong to him and that it was intended for use to help Democratic Progressive Party candidates in future elections.

A day earlier, Chen had denied through his lawyer a claim by Next magazine that his daughter-in-law had laundered money for him by secretly wiring NT$300 million (US$9.63 million) into an overseas account.

Next magazine claimed that prosecutors learned from the Egmont Group, an international association of financial intelligence organizations, that Chen had used Huang and other members of her family to wire the NT$300 million out of Taiwan, and that the total could exceed NT$1 billion if other "suspicious" capital is accounted for.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academia Sinica announces new honorary academicians

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica, Taiwan's most prestigious research institution, announced eight new honorary academicians Thursday, including six Nobel laureates, according to a press release from the institution.

Three, in the division of mathematics and physical sciences, were named as Charles M. Vest, president of the National Academy of Engineering in the United States, who specializes in lasers and coherent optics, and Leo Esaki and Heinrich Rohrer, both Nobel prize winners in physics.
David Baltimore and Baruch S. Blumberg, both Nobel prize winners in physiology or medicine, were elected as honorary academicians in the division of life sciences.

The remaining three, who cross the division between life sciences, the humanities and social sciences are L. Luca Cavalli-Sforza, professor emeritus at Stanford University's Department of Genetics, and Leland H. Hartwell and Phillip A. Sharp, both of whom are Nobel laureates in physiology or medicine, the press release said.
The new honorary academicians, whose seats have been empty for more than 30 years, were elected by Academia Sinica's convocation, which is made of the institution's academicians in three divisions.
Related regulations that were amended last year stipulate that the life-tenure positions of honorary academicians have to be elected every two years.
The newly elected are tasked with promoting domestic and international academic cooperation and directing the research profile of the institution.
In addition to the eight honorary academicians, the Academia Sinica currently has a total of 249 domestic and foreign academicians.

DOC.HEADLINE: Naturalization rules relaxed for foreign spouses

TEXT.P: Foreign spouses of local citizens intending to apply for naturalization will no longer be required to produce financial status statements, according to an amendment to the enforcement rules of the Nationality Act passed by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) Thursday.
The relaxed rules will be implemented after the Executive Yuan approves them later this month, an MOI official said.
According to the official, some 60,000 foreign spouses now residing in Taiwan can benefit from the new rules.

DOC.HEADLINE: Outgoing Paraguayan President lauds Taiwan for cross-strait peace

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's effort in seeking peace with China was well received by outgoing Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Thursday during a bilateral meeting in which Duarte expressed gratitude offered by Taiwan during his five-year presidency.

"I would like to express my appreciation toward President Ma's efforts in seeking peace (with China) , "Duarte was quoted as saying by Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi, who briefed the reporters after the two heads of state held a 45-minute meeting.
Describing the atmosphere of the meeting as harmonious, Wang said Ma elaborated his ideas of a"diplomatic truce"with China and said that such approach was well- received by many people.

"Under the precondition of diplomatic truce, we will strengthen relations with Paraguay and consolidate our friendship, "Ma said, adding that the method has been well received in many Asian countries, as it is viewed as beneficiary in promoting regional peace.

The president said that a series of policies, such as the launch of direct weekend charter flights across the Taiwan Strait, are aimed to normalize the economic interactions and promote peace and prosperity between the two sides.
"Cross-strait atmosphere already began changing with both Taipei and Beijing feel that such approach serves the interests of the two," Ma was quoted as having told Duarte.
According to Wang, Ma and Duarte also shared experiences in land reform and exchanged views on anti-drugs.
Ma, who arrived at Paraguay around midnight on Wednesday to attend the inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo on Aug. 15, expressed best regards to the outgoing Duarte.
"Taiwan and Paraguay share a long friendship for 51 years and such friendship is very rare, "Ma said."I will remember the friendship that President Duarte had offered to Taiwan."
In response, Duarte said that he is deeply grateful for the help offered by Taiwan during his five-year presidency.
Taiwan and Paraguay forged diplomatic relations in 1957 and Paraguay remains Taiwan's only ally in South America.

Ma's visit was viewed to strengthen ties with Paraguay given the fact that Lugo had said many times that he would like to switch diplomatic recognition to China -- a statement that spurred speculations that Taiwan might lose Paraguay.
However, Lugo told the Asuncion-based ABC Color daily news Tuesday that his government will maintain ties with Taipei, a message that was welcomed by Taiwan.

After attending the inaugurations of Lugo, Ma is scheduled to go to the Dominican Republic to attend the inauguration of President Leonel Fernandez for a new term on Aug. 16. He will return to Taiwan on Aug. 19.
