DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 15, or the 15th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1057: Macbeth, King of Scotland who ascended to the throne after killing his cousin King Duncan in battle in 1040, is killed by Duncan's son Malcolm at Lumphanan, near Aberdeen. The legend of his rise to power and his reign are the basis of Shakespeare's tragedy "Macbeth."
1769: Napoleon Bonaparte, military leader and the emperor of France from 1804 to 1815, is born in Ajaccio, Corsica.
1900: The Kuang Hsu Emperor and his aunt, the Empress Dowager Tzu-hsi, flee to northwestern China from Beijing as the capital is captured by the forces of eight foreign powers during the Boxer Uprising.
1914: The 82-km-long Panama Canal, connecting the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, is opened after 35 years of construction.
1945: The Republic of China Legislative Yuan unanimously approves the United Nations Charter.
1947: India gains independence from Britain with Jawaharlal Nehru as the first prime minister.
1948: President Syngman Rhee formally proclaims South Korea as the Republic of Korea.
1949: A Southeast China Governor's Office is established in Taipei with Gen. Chen Cheng as governor.
1959: The ROC Army receives Nike-Hercules surface-to-air missiles from the United States under a military aid program.
1960: The Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan rules that, according to Article 77 of the ROC Constitution, courts of all levels shall be placed under the jurisdiction of the Judicial Yuan.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes the Congo (Brazzaville) Republic.
1962: The Netherlands signs a treaty agreeing to Indonesian rule of Irian Jaya (Netherlands New Guinea).
1967: Kung Hsiang-hsi, former ROC premier and finance minister, dies in the United States at the age of 88.
1974: South Korean President Park Chung Hee's wife is shot dead by an assassin in an attempt on Park's life.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo urges college students to contribute their wisdom and energy to the country as he presides over the closing ceremony of the summer vacation military training program of college students at the Cheng-kung base in Taichung.
1979: Direct dialing service to the United States, Hong Kong and Singapore is initiated by the Taiwan Telecommunications Administration.
1980: The wreckage of the Titanic, the British luxury liner which sank after hitting an iceberg during its maiden voyage to New York on April 14, 1912, is found laying on the ocean floor 3,657 meters below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean.
1981: The First ROC-Indian Cultural and Economic Seminar on India's 34th Independence Day is held in Taipei.
1981: The Republic of China and Saint Vincent establish formal diplomatic relations.
1985: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa accepts the resignation of Finance Minister Loh Jen- kong.
1986: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa, in an interview with Saudi Arabian journalists from the Okaz Daily and Al-Bilad Daily, points out that the achievements of the ROC over the past thirty-odd years has won the nation international recognition and made it an indispensable force against communist expansion in the Asia-Pacific region.
1990: President Mikhail Gorbachev restores Soviet citizenship to Nobel Prize- winning author Alexander Solshenitsyn, who was exiled to the West in 1974 for his novels attacking Stalinism.
1995: The Chinese mainland begins eleven days of tactical guided missile exercises by firing live artillery shells into the sea 136 kilometers north of Taiwan.
1999: Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Commission, donates US$100,000 and 20 computers to the Chinese Benevolent Federation in San Francisco.
2000: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture announces that beef imports from Argentina and Paraguay will be temporarily banned due to an outbreak of foot- and-mouth disease in the two South American countries.
2001: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party formally establishes the Taiwan-Japan Goodwill Association to further bolster bilateral ties between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who acquires truth is one who finds out what is good and holds fast to it."

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese pandas expected to arrive in Taiwan at year-end

TEXT.P: A pair of pandas offered by China are expected to arrive in Taiwan aboard a charter plane at the end of the year, Taipei Zoo Director Jason Yeh said Friday.
"Although the public is looking forward to an early arrival of the pandas, we think it would be best for the shipment to take place at the end of the year when the climate is more stable," Yeh said.
Yeh explained that abrupt changes of temperature are typical of the climate in October and November, making the shipment unsuitable.
However, the situation will improve in the winter, which will help reduce the possible negative impact from the movement on the health of the pandas, Yeh said.

He said the zoo is currently discussing with airline companies the issue of chartering a plane to ship the pandas and is consulting with the Chinese authorities on the proper delivery procedures, such as whether it is necessary to maintain a constant temperature and assign a keeper to escort the animals.

Yeh made the remarks one day after the zoo obtained Council of Agriculture (COA) approval to house the pandas, beating the Leofoo Safari Zoo in Hsinchu County, which was also competing to take charge of the animals.
The two pandas, named Tuan-tuan and Yuan-yuan by the Chinese, which means "reunion," were offered as a gift to Taiwan after a visit to China by then- Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan in 2005.
The offer, however, was rejected by the COA under the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration on the grounds that Taiwan did not have adequate conditions to raise the animals.

According to a survey conducted in July by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Executive Yuan, 56.1 percent of the Taiwanese are in favor of receiving the Chinese pandas, and 60.1 percent believe the pandas will help Taiwan's tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: President confident about ties with Paraguay

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday during a state visit to attend the inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo that relations between Taiwan and Paraguay are very solid and that he is investing great confidence in bilateral relations.
"I'm very optimistic about diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Paraguay, " Ma said at a news conference. "I believe bilateral relations are very solid and that they will continue," he added.
Lugo has said many times that he wants to establish full diplomatic relations with China, statements that have spurred speculation that Taiwan might lose its only diplomatic ally in South America.
Lugo, however, told the Asuncion-based ABC Color daily news Tuesday that his government will maintain ties with Taipei -- a message that was welcomed by Taiwan.

During a meeting with Ma earlier in the day, he vowed to "improve and consolidate relations with Taiwan," a statement that Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said "dissolves a lot of doubts on Taiwan-Paraguay ties."

Asked about foreign aid to Paraguay, Ma said he did not bring any new cooperation projects to discuss with Lugo, but added that Taiwan will evaluate the possibility of instigating new ones, as long as "the proposals have legitimate objectives and the granting procedures are in accordance with the law."

Noting that offering foreign aid to help allies is in line with international trends and expectations, Ma said that as long as Taiwan sticks to this principle, it can reverse its image of conducting so-called "checkbook diplomacy" -- which he said is a result of the "vicious diplomatic competition" between Taipei and Beijing.

Ma proposed a "diplomatic truce" aimed at terminating the longstanding diplomatic tug-of-war with China in which both countries try to lure each other's allies to switch diplomatic allegiance by offering large sums of money in foreign aid to developing countries.
He also touted the strategy of "modus vivendi" or "pragmatic diplomacy," aimed at leveraging more international space for Taiwan.
Ma said that if the policy of seeking a diplomatic truce with China succeeds, it is possible that the number of allies will remain at 23, without Taiwan losing any more allies.
"Although such a result might not be agreed upon by everyone, the point is what serves the best the national interests," Ma added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's U.N. bid will be `very careful': president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday in Paraguay that Taiwan's bid for membership in the United Nations this year will be "very cautious and careful, " as Taiwan has to take the reality of the international political situation into consideration.

"We will be very wary of this year's U.N. bid, given the fact that both referendums regarding the issue failed to pass in the March presidential election, " Ma said in his first news conference of his first state visit to South America and the Caribbean.

"No matter what the bid might be, it should be achievable and should uphold Taiwan's dignity, " the president said. "We will take this into consideration and then make a proposal that not only will achieve our goals but also will not affect other diplomatic interests or the interests of cross-Taiwan Strait relations," he added.

The controversial referendums, proposed by the then-ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , asked voters if they supported "joining the U.N. under the name Taiwan" or "returning to the U.N. under the name Republic of China, " respectively.
The DPP version brought severe criticism from Western countries such as the United States and the European Union, which said it was "provocative and unnecessary."
Ma said the result reflected the fact that the Taiwanese have strong will to participate in the U.N. and that the previous methods of the bid were not accepted by the general public.
He said the government will adopt a different strategy this year, taking into consideration the will of the people and the international reality, and will submit its bid within the next few days.
The 63rd regular session of the U.N. General Assembly is slated to be held in mid-September at U.N. Headquarters in New York.
The ROC has tried without success to re-enter the U.N. since 1993, after losing its seat to the People's Republic of China in 1971.
Last year marked the first time it had changed tactics by bidding to join the world body under the name Taiwan.

Asked if he will try to promote the U.N. bid at the inaugurations of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo and Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez, when he will be joined by heads of state from Taiwan's allies and other countries, Ma said Taiwan's allies all support the efforts the country regarding the issue and do not care much about the method used.

Speaking of Taiwan's international space, Ma said the government will continue its bid to participate in the World Health Assembly, as it is one of the international organizations in which Taiwan's efforts have made significant progress, but will also try to join other international bodies.

Ma has said many times that he would like to have a "diplomatic truce" with China, a strategy that he said means both Taipei and Beijing will stop their meaningless diplomatic tug-of-war in which each side tries to lure each other's allies by offering large sums of money in foreign aid.
He also proposed the "modus vivendi" approach for seeking more international space along with China in the global arena.

"A diplomatic truce does not only apply to bilateral relations but also to multilateral relations, " he said, adding that the fact that experts from both Taiwan and China were elected simultaneously into an influential World Trade Organization (WTO) group last month serves as a very good example of a win-win situation.
"Just as I said in my inauguration speech, Taiwan and China should help each other with respect, " Ma said. "I hope such an example can also happen in other international organizations, " he added.

The WTO announced last month that the Committee on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures elected four members of the Permanent Group of Exports, including Lo Chang-fa, a well-known scholar in international trade law in Taiwan and China's Zhang Yuqing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China resume oil exploration cooperation

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China have resumed cooperation on oil exploration off southern Taiwan after a year-long hiatus, sources from Taiwan's state-run oil company said Thursday.

The resumption marked a new development in the thawing cross-Taiwan Strait relations since the Kuomintang (KMT) , which favors closer ties with China, took power May 20 from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Taiwan opened to direct weekend charter flights and more tourists from China July 4.
It will also receive a pair of giant pandas with Chinese names suggesting reunion between the two sides by the end of this year.
China claims sovereignty over self-ruled Taiwan and vows war if it moves toward formal independence.

CPC Corp., Taiwan and China National Offshore Oil Corp. (CNOOC), one of the largest state-owned oil giants in China, recently continued a contract for an oil exploration project off southern Taiwan for an additional two years, the sources said.
CPC Corp., Taiwan has also obtained approval from the government for another new oil exploration project off northern Taiwan with the Chinese oil company, the sources said.

Taiwan's previous cooperation project with China to explore for oil off southern Taiwan came to a halt after the former DPP administration included "Taiwan" in Taiwan's oil company's name both in Chinese and English, according to the sources.
At the time, the DPP argued that the name change was aimed at preventing Taiwan's oil company from being mistaken for a Chinese company.
Critics, however, blasted the name change as highlighting Taiwanese identity to push for formal independence.
The Taipei-based oil company changed its English name from Chinese Petroleum Corporation (CPC) to CPC Corp., Taiwan, in February 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan renews bid to enter U.N.
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 15 (CNA) 08/15/08 13:21:40 (By Timothy Hwang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan renewed its bid to enter the United Nations Thursday by submitting a proposal to the U.N. Secretariat calling for the U. N. to reconsider the feasibility of meaningful participation in the world organization by Taiwan.

A proposal emphasizing the importance of Taiwan's "meaningful participation" in the U.N. and a cross-Taiwan Strait policy of "reconciliation and truce" was submitted to the U.N. Secretariat by representatives of St. Vincent and the Solomon Islands, two of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies.

It marks a fresh approach by the ROC government in pushing for U.N. admission for Taiwan since President Ma Ying-jeou was inaugurated May 20. The proposal does not mention the country's attempt to enter the U.N. under the name Taiwan, nor does it mention the ROC seeking to return to the U.N.

The previous Democratic Progressive Party administration for the first time in 2007 applied to join the U.N. as a full member under the name Taiwan. That proposal did not make the agenda of the U.N. General Assembly.
Since 1993, Taiwan's supporters have been trying to get the General Assembly to list the issue of its admission on the U.N. agenda, but Beijing's argument that Taiwan is part of China has prevailed.
Since Ma's inauguration, cross-strait relations have seen a thaw.

This year, 17 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies have endorsed the new proposal on principles of "dignity, pragmatism and flexibility, " according to a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official posted in New York.

"This year, our new proposal aims at not competing with China over the issue of representation, but at meeting Taiwan's desire to join the international community and take part in related activities," the official said.
Friday is the last day for U.N. members to submit proposals to make up the agenda of the General Assembly, which is scheduled to begin Sept. 16.

This year, three of Taiwan's diplomatic allies -- Nicaragua, Solomon Islands and Honduras -- entered the U.N. General Committee as members, the highest number of Taiwanese allies since 1993. The General Committee, made up of delegates from 28 nations, will make the decisions pertaining to the agenda of the next General Assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Canadian envoy encouraged by improved cross-strait relations

TEXT.P: A congressman and envoy of Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper attending the inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo Aug. 15 said Thursday after a meeting with President Ma Ying-jeou that he is encouraged by the thawing relations between Taiwan and China, which he said are moving in a very positive direction.
"I think that anyone, any thoughtful person in the world, would be encouraged with the dialogue, " Jim Abbott told CNA. "I think things are moving very positively."

He was referring to the fact that bilateral relations between Taipei and Beijing have improved significantly since Ma took office May 20 with the reopening of negotiations between the two sides, the launch of weekend direct cross-strait charter flights and the opening of Taiwan to more Chinese tourists.
Ties between China and Taiwan were frozen during former President Chen Shui- bian's eight years in office due to his pro-independence stance.

China views Taiwan as a renegade province and continuously suppresses Taiwan's international space by blocking its efforts to join international organizations and protesting its use of the title Republic of China or Taiwan to join any international entities.

Ma proposed a "diplomatic truce" in order to end the longstanding diplomatic tug-of-war with China in which both countries try to lure each other's allies to switch diplomatic allegiance by offering large sums of money in foreign aid to developing countries.
He also touts the strategy of "modus vivendi" or "pragmatic diplomacy" that aims to obtain more international space for Taiwan.

As chairman of the Canada-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group, Abbott described his meeting with Ma as a great opportunity to get together and get to know Ma personally, although they did not discuss Ma's diplomatic approaches in detail.
"I was asking primarily about the very positive things that are happening related to the cross-strait issues. It was more of a very personal getting acquainted situation," he said.

Ma left Taiwan Aug. 12 for his first state visit since he took office May 20 to attend the inaugurations of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo and Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez. He will return to Taiwan Aug. 19.

Abbott has served previously as chair of the Canada-Korea Parliamentary Friendship Group, co-chair of the Canada-Mongolia Inter-Parliamentary Association and Treasurer of the Canada ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taxi drivers earn NT$21,305 per month average: MOTC survey

TEXT.P: Despite their long work hours, taxi drivers earned an average of just NT$21,305 (US$680.7) per month in 2007, according to the results of a survey released Friday by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).

The figure marked a decrease of NT$1,698 from the amount recorded in a similar survey conducted in 2005, an MOTC official said, adding that the drop in earnings was mainly related to steep hikes in fuel prices over the past few years.

The ministry conducted the mail survey between February and April this year and collected 6,923 valid samples for a return rate of 48.6 percent. The survey had a confidence level of 95 percent, with a margin of error of 1 percent.

The results show that local cab drivers worked an average of 10.2 hours per day after deducting rest and meal times and that their cars were left empty for an average of 3.6 hours during their working hours.
According to the poll results, taxi drivers' average monthly earnings were lowest in eastern Taiwan, at NT$11,844, and highest in the north, at NT$23,975.

Amid continued increases in fuel costs, 12 counties and cities have raised taxi fares over the past year. However, 74.6 percent of the respondents said fare adjustments have led to a decline in the number of passenger rides and 61.3 percent said their revenues slid after the fare hikes.

The survey further found that fewer than 20 percent of the respondents pick up passengers via radio dispatch or GPS coordinates and that more than 70 percent still rely on traditional street cruising to get passengers. According to the survey, those who have installed radio or satellite communications systems in their cars earn NT$386 per day more than those who have not.

If a driver works 27 days per month, installation of a radio or satellite dispatch system will generate NT$10,422 in additional revenues per month. After deducting the monthly dispatch cost of NT$2,400, the driver can still secure an increase of NT$8,000, representing a 37.5 percent rise in his or her monthly earnings.

Chi Wen-chung, director of the MOTC's Department of Railways and Highways, said it is worth studying why cab drivers are unwilling to join the radio dispatch system, even though the service can bring them more income.

While the MOTC is planning to set up more taxi ranks to help lower the empty cab rates, the survey found that a majority of 73.7 percent of the respondents were dissatisfied with the quality of the existing taxi ranks.

Major reasons cited by the detractors included the fact that existing taxi ranks are often dominated by underworld rings or lack enough parking spaces, while the number of taxi ranks remains too few to attract passengers, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
5 shuttle bus lines planned for Kaohsiung MRT's new orange line

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government's Transportation Bureau said Friday that five shuttle bus lines are planned to serve passengers using the orange line of the Mass Rapid Transit system that is set to open before the Mid-Autumn Festival, which falls on Sept. 14 this year.

Buses on the five lines will be operated by the city government's Kaohsiung City Bus Service Administration, unlike shuttle bus services on the red line, which are operated by private bus companies, the bureau said.

Chang Shu-chuan, a section head at the Transportation Bureau, said that the bureau invited bids in March and May of this year for private bus companies to operate the orange line shuttle bus services, but no companies responded.
The city government's offer of NT$700,000 (US$22,330) per bus in subsidies as well as fuel subsidies of NT$40 per kilometer for the first one or two years of operations failed to attract any bidders.
The bureau therefore commissioned the Kaohsiung City Bus Service Administration to run the orange line shuttle bus services, according to Chang.

Noting that bureau surveys show that 82 percent of Kaohsiung residents support the shuttle bus services offered for the red line, Chang said that the bureau decided to provide the same services on the orange line.
Although there are 20 shuttle bus lines serving the red line at present, only five are currently planned for the orange line.
Chang said that this is due to the fact that the orange line is only half the length of the red line and has only eight stations within Kaohsiung City.
Shuttle buses on the five lines feeding the orange line will run every 15 minutes during rush hour and every 20 minutes during off-peak hours, she noted.

As for concerns that having the Kaohsiung City Bus Service Administration provide the shuttle bus service might draw buses away from the city's regular bus routes and reduce the quality of service, Chang said the Transportation Bureau has mapped out thorough plans and that the quality of service on regular public bus lines will be maintained.
She added that the administration will be able to receive fuel subsidies of NT$40 per kilometer from the municipal government's air pollution fund for providing the shuttle bus service.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen National Park extends service center hours

TEXT.P: The Kinmen National Park Administration on the outlying island of Kinmen said Friday that it has decided to extend the opening hours at its service centers within the park for the duration of the summer season in response to the needs of visitors.

From Friday, the hours of operation at service centers at the park's main attractions, including the Jhongshanlin Recreational Area, the Chingkuo Memorial Hall, Cih Lake, the Gunington Battlefield Museum and the Aug. 23 Battle Museum, will be extended from 8 a.m.-5 p.m. to 8 a.m.-5:30 p.m.

The administration said many visitors to the park have complained that because of the longer daylight hours during the summer and higher numbers of visitors to the park during the season, the service centers' hours of operation were not long enough.
The service centers' hours of operation will return to normal Sept. 16, the administration said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-first family members have left country

TEXT.P: The son and daughter-in-law of former President Chen Shui-bian, who are suspected by the Swiss authorities of laundering money for Chen, left Taiwan last Saturday, the Supreme Prosecutors Office said Friday.

Chen's son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching have not yet been listed as defendants in Chen's corruption case involving misuse of the special state affairs funds budgeted for his discretionary use as president, and the Supreme Prosecutors Office, which is handling the case, had not restricted the couple from going abroad, said Chu Chao-liang, spokesman for the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office.
Chu said the junior Chen and his wife left Taiwan on an Aug. 9 flight.

Chu said the Federal Department of Justice and Police of the Swiss Confederation requested assistance from Taipei three weeks ago about suspected money laundering by the junior Chen and his wife through two Swiss bank accounts.
The former president apologized to the nation Thursday, admitting that he lied about his election campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004.
However, he claimed to have been unaware until early this year that his wife, Wu Shu-jen, had wired surplus funds from election campaign contributions abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Bush sends Rice to conflict.
President Bush escalated the American response Wednesday to Russian military action in Georgia, ordering a humanitarian aid effort and dispatching Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice to the stricken region as pentagon officials announced plans to rebuild the Georgian military. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Next step for schools.
Singapore's education system has been very successful at the nuts and bolts - it churns out top students, and is ranked highly worldwide - but it is now time for it to evolve.
Parents these days are more educated and demanding, while children are more questioning and learn in different ways, and the system needs to keep up with rising expectations.
It needs to do more than simply churn out students with good grades, Education Minister Ng Eng Hen said yesterday in a speech at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Chen Shui-bian's families be suspected of money-laundering investigation.
Taiwan's Ministry of Justice confirmed it received the request of Swiss federal prosecutors passed from Ministry of Foreign Affairs to offer the related informations of former president Chen Shui-bian's son and his daughter-in-law who involved money laundering case.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times Double glory as Kitajima repeats feat
Fifteen minutes after repeating as a double gold medalist at the Water Cube on Thursday morning, theese were the final words of breaststroke specialist Kosuke Kitajima: "Ashita oyasumi."

DOC.HEADLINE: Creative workshop with MIT Media Lab held in Tainan

TEXT.P: A creative workshop instructed by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) Media Lab to inspire participants with unrestrained ideas was launched Thursday in Tainan City, southern Taiwan.

According to a spokesman for National Cheng Kung University in Tainan City, which organized the activity, the five-day "Nightmarket Workshop" encourages participants to create collections of life experience through a series of inspiring activities such as brainstorming, concept visualization and experiments.

The lab, part of MIT's School of Architecture and Planning, consists of faculty members and students of inter-disciplinary research projects ranging from psychology, music, graphic design and multimedia to technology, the spokesman said.
The lab cradles the world's outstanding designers and inventors, and recruits talented members every year, according to the spokesman.
The 150 participants -- college and graduate students -- will also visit different night markets on each evening during the activity to learn from the vitality of the country's nightmarket culture.

They are expected to come up with vigorous ideas such as skewering a turkey on a lightening rod to have it cooked by lightening in three seconds, the spokesman said, explaining that the turkey idea came from one of the workshop instructors Marisa Jahn, a member of the MIT Media Lab.

Jahn is also the inventor of many creations such as "Swan Song, " a percussive instrument that wraps 360 degrees around the trunk of a small apple tree, and the "Pleasure Craft, " an installation centered around a boat outfitted with all the parts "necessary to woo a potential lover."

The workshop will be guided by 21 MIT Media Lab members such as Jahn, the spokesman said, adding that there will be an exhibition on the final day for the participants to present their ideas and showcase their inventions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for August fell 140 points to close at 7,216, with 73,450 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September lost 135 points to finish at 7,193, with 4,229 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 132 points to close at 7,161, with 68 contract transactions.
March futures decreased 111 points to finish at 7,148, with 18 contract transactions, while June futures were down 119 to close at 7,120, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 7,356 for August, 7,328 for September, 7,293 for December, 7,259 for March and 7,239 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index lost 129.57 points to finish at 7,196.5, on turnover of NT$99.93 billion (US$3.19 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

August TE futures decreased 5.7 points to close at 293.4, with 4,678 contracts traded, while September TE futures decreased 5.1 points to finish at 292.4, with 368 contract transactions. December TE futures lost 7.1 points to end at 289.7, with four contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

August TF futures moved down 16.4 points to close at 893.8, with 2,819 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures decreased 17.8 points to finish at 891.4, with 199 contracts traded. December TF futures lost 12.4 points to end at 888.8, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices plunge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 129.57 points, or 1.76 percent, to close at 7,196.5.

Suffering a drop from the gains of the previous day, the local bourse opened at 7,374.38 and fluctuated between 7,376.69 and 7,181.69. A total of 3.85 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$99.93 billion (US$3.18 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 3.1 percent. Construction issues declined 3 percent, textile stocks and machinery and electronics shares both dropped 1.9 percent, banking and financial shares fell 1.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares lost 1.3 percent, and paper and pulp issues shed 1.1 percent.
Cement stocks gained ground, increasing 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,735 to 400, with 380 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Truce fragile in Caucasus.
The withdrawal of Russian troops from Georgia has not yet completed and sporatic conflicts were reported in Gori and the port of Poti, although the European Union-brokered ceasefire between Russia and Georgia was in effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier hails Taiwan as Chinese food paradise

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan hailed Taiwan Friday as a Chinese food paradise that can attract tourists from China and other parts of the world.
Liu made the remarks at the opening ceremony of this year's Taiwan Culinary Exhibition, now in its 19th year. The exhibition was previous known as the Taipei Chinese Food Festival.
The exhibition, organized by the Taiwan Visitors Association, features food from Taiwan and Chinese provinces of Anhui and Guizhou, as well as cooking contests.
Describing himself as a gourmand, Liu said that each Chinese province has its own special food.
In Taiwan, however, which is separated from China by the 160-km-wide Taiwan Strait, people can enjoy various types of food from both China and Hong Kong, Liu said.
He also said the exhibition has helped raise the level of cooking skills in Taiwan and that food in Taiwan has become a major tourism resource, attracting international tourists.

The exhibition has helped increase the public's awareness of delicious food available here and their respect for local chefs, said Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo at the ceremony.
Nineteen years ago, only a few schools in Taiwan offered programs related to the food and beverage industry, Mao went on, adding that the number has grown to more than 100.
The exhibition will run through Aug. 18 at Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) Exhibition Hall 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors probe alleged money-laundering by former first family

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Prosecutors Office has started an investigation into suspected money laundering by the former first family, based on information provided by the Swiss authorities, a spokesman said Friday.

The case was assigned to head prosecutor Ching Chi-jen as soon as the office received a request by the Swiss Confederation's Department of Justice seeking Taiwan's assistance in probing possible money-laundering in Switzerland by former President Chen Shui-bian's son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching, according to Prosecutor Lin Chin-tsun.
Lin said the office will do its utmost to cooperate with the Swiss authorities and will deal with the matter according to the law.
Ching departed Taiwan for Switzerland three days ago and is expected to review the deposits and withdrawals of accounts created under the name of Huang Jui- ching at Merrill Lynch Bank, sources said.

Also Friday, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Henry Chen admitted that there was "administrative negligence" on the part of the representative office in Switzerland for delaying the delivery to Taipei of a letter from the Swiss Confederation's Department of Justice, in which the request for assistance was put forth.

The letter, dated June 16, was received by the representative office in early July, but staffers there sat on it for nearly a month before forwarding it in late July to the MOFA, which later transferred it to the Ministry of Justice (MOJ).
On Thursday, the MOJ confirmed for the first time that it had received the request through the MOFA, in the wake of a revelation by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu.

Hung's revelation also prompted Chen Shui-bian to call a news conference that same day in which he admitted that his wife Wu Shu-jen had wired abroad an unspecified amount of money that he had received as campaign contributions.

Chen confessed that he lied about the election campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004 but claimed he was unaware that the surplus funds were wired abroad by his wife until early this year.

Chen rejected Hung's allegation that the funds wired overseas could be connected to his "state affairs funds" embezzlement case and a recent scandal involving a botched attempt to win Papua New Guinea as a diplomatic ally.
A day earlier, Chen denied through his lawyer a claim by Next magazine that his daughter-in-law had laundered money for him by secretly wiring NT$300 million overseas.

The weekly tabloid said that soon after the exposure of the "state affairs fund" case in 2006, the former first lady closed bank accounts belonging to herself and her husband, as well as several others created under the names of her son Chen Chih-chung and her daughter Chen Hsing-yu, which were used for stock trading.
Wu then remitted NT$300 million overseas through various bank accounts belonging to her daughter-in-law and other members of her family, according to the magazine.

Wu was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.
She has seldom been willing to appear in court to answer the charges, claiming "ill health."
Chen, who had immunity from prosecution while in office, was named as a co- defendant in the "state affairs fund" case as soon as he stepped down from the presidency May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Justice to decide if ex-president laundered money: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday in Paraguay that the judiciary will determine whether former President Chen Shui-bian committed the crime of money laundering after he admitted that his wife funneled campaign funds into overseas bank accounts.
"If it is money laundering, it is a criminal case, " Ma said in a news conference. "The truth should be determined by the judiciary rather than by the persons involved," he added.
According to Man, it will require further investigation to clarify the case and any statements made by the suspects are "only personal opinions."
"The key should be: what is the truth? Where did the money come from and where did it go?" said Ma.

Chen admitted a day earlier that his wife Wu Shu-jen had wired overseas an unspecified amount of money that Chen had received as campaign contributions for his two Taipei mayoral elections and two presidential election campaigns.

In a televised news conference, Chen apologized to the public for not clearly accounting for his campaign contributions, admitting that the failure to make such a report was "something that is not permitted by the law."
The former president insisted his wife made the wire transfers without his knowledge.

Under Taiwan's campaign laws, candidates are required to report campaign spending, but were not required to report all political donations until the passage of the Political Contributions Act in 2004.

The announcement was made one day after the Next Weekly tabloid reported that the Egmont Group, an international anti-money laundering network, had alerted the Taiwanese authorities that the former first lady had made large money transfers to several foreign bank accounts.

Shortly before Cheng's news conference, Kuomintang Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu said Swiss prosecutors had asked the Taiwanese authorities to verify the origin of a huge amount of funds in Swiss bank accounts under the name of Chen's daughter- in-law, Huang Jui-ching.
Local news station TVBS reported that more than US$20 million was deposited in the Swiss accounts in Huang's name Feb. 8, 2007.
The Foreign Ministry later confirmed that the Swiss had indeed requested Taiwan's cooperation in an unspecified case.
Asked about Chen's accusation that Ma also failed to fully report campaign funds, the president replied that "I always fully report all my campaign funds."
"It is unknown whether the case is really linked to election campaigns, " Ma went on, adding that Chen appeared to be making it seem that way on purpose.
Ma, who is making his first state visit since taking office May 20, is in Paraguay to attend the Aug. 15 inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Vision Taiwan to hold 'Hunger 30' drive in Taipei

TEXT.P: The Taiwan chapter of World Vision, a global Christian charity dedicated to helping poor children and families, will hold a "Hunger 30" drive in Taipei Saturday, in which participants will fast for 12 hours, the organizer said Friday.
First lady Chow Mei-ching is expected to attend the annual drive, to be held at the National Taiwan University Sports Center, World Vision Taiwan noted in a press statement.
This year, World Vision Taiwan has been organizing camp activities to help local residents experience hunger and raise their awareness of helping the hungry since March 1, the statement said.
More than 25,000 people around the country have taken part in the activities, the statement said, adding that these people will also attend the "Hunger 30" drive, now in its 19th year.
This year, the charity said, it has offered assistance to victims of the quake- hit Chinese province of Sichuan and of cyclone-ravaged Myanmar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mayor urges worshipers to replace incense with flowers

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin urged the public Friday to replace incense with fresh flowers as a means of tribute to the spirits during ghost month, the annual festival celebrated on the seventh lunar month in which the gates of hell are said to open, allowing ghosts to mingle with the living.
Hau made the call when he addressed a worship ritual that took place at the Taipei Flower Auction Co. to mark Ghost Festival, the 15th day of the month, which fell on that day.
At the ritual, the Taipei Flower Auction Co. for the first time offered freshly cut flowers instead of burning incense and paper "ghost paper" to appease the spirits and wandering souls.

Hau called for the residents of Taipei City, which is responsible for 45 percent of all Taiwan's cut flower sales and 70 percent of all pot plant sales, to use flowers as offerings in place of burning incense or ghost money, which is environmentally harmful.

The Department of Air Quality Protection and Noise Control under the Cabinet- level Environmental Protection Administration has called for the public to refrain from burning ghost money and incense because toxic chemicals such as benzene -- a known carcinogen -- and other pollutants are released during the burning.

DOC.HEADLINE: New U.N. bid `breaks Taiwan people's hearts': DPP caucus

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) deputy legislative caucus whip claimed Friday that the ruling Kuomintang's new U.N. bid has "broken the hearts of the Taiwan people."

Pan Meng-an was referring to a proposal emphasizing the importance of Taiwan's "meaningful participation" in the United Nations which was submitted to the U.N. Secretariat the previous day by representatives of St. Vincent and the Grenadines and the Solomon Islands, two diplomatic allies of the Republic of China, at the request of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The proposal marks a fresh approach by the government in pushing for U.N. entry for Taiwan since President Ma Ying-jeou assumed office May 20.

The previous DPP administration applied in 2007 to join the U.N. as a full member under the name Taiwan, the first time it had tried under that name. However, that proposal failed to make the agenda of the U.N. General Assembly, just as the previous ones since 1993 also failed.

The new proposal, submitted ahead of this year's U.N. General Assembly set to open Sept. 16, is significant in that it does not mention the name Taiwan nor the idea of the Republic of China seeking to return to the world body.
The ministry said the proposal was put forward on the principles of "dignity, pragmatism and flexibility."
Pan also claimed that Ma's proposed "diplomatic truce" with China is hypocritical and a sign of surrender and a downgrading of Taiwan's status.

The ministry's proposal put forward to the U.N. caters to "Ma's stance of capitulation" and by omitting the name Taiwan, does not demonstrate the Taiwan people's resolve to join the international community, according to Pan.
Meanwhile, DPP legislative whip Chang Hua-kan said Taiwan's sovereignty should be insisted upon at all times, regardless of the international situation.
Saying that membership of the U.N. gives a country "legitimacy, " Chang asked how the government can put forward a proposal that does not include the country's name.
"If we don't even insist on our name, then we can't be considered a country," he said.

"And if that's the case, then we don't need foreign relations, " he went on, asking whether the KMT's next step will be to abolish the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and downgrade the government's status to that of a local government.

DPP Legislator Chai Trong-rong said Ma's recent downplaying of his status as president during his transit stop in the United States was aimed at catering to China's demands, adding that the president has acted like "he wants to be a model student of Beijing's."
The new U.N. bid is the same in many respects in that it is based on a desire to avoid angering Beijing, Chai said, adding that the bid has "cheated the Taiwan people."

He claimed that by not insisting on using the country's name, whether it be Taiwan or the Republic of China, and deciding to settle the issue at a later date, Ma has effectively allowed for foreigners to decide Taiwan's designation.

"If the Taiwanese can't even be allowed to decide their country's name, how can they decide their own future? " he asked, adding that Ma has broken his election promise to act on behalf of the desires of the public.

The United States accused Russia yesterday of waging a campaign to cripple Georgiasability to defend itself in the future.
