DOC.HEADLINE: Assistance sought to reduce papaya farmers' losses

TEXT.P: A Chiayi County farmers' association official urged agricultural authorities Friday to help the county's papaya farmers cope with losses suffered as result of a tornado and hailstorm that struck the southern county's Jhongpu township the previous day.

Chang Han-ching, a secretary of the Jhongpu Farmers Association, said the tornado and hailstones damaged about 30 hectares of papaya plantations in villages that included Jinlan, Fushou, Longmen, and Sanceng, causing losses of millions of New Taiwan dollars.

The screens on the screen houses were blown away and the fruit trees were either snapped in half or toppled over, said Chang, adding that a whole year of hard work by the papaya farmers was laid waste.

Chang said that the Jhongpu Township Farmers' Association will help these farmers to apply for government's subsidies, and expressed the hope that the relevant agricultural units would also help to offset the farmers' losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan seeks meaningful participation in U.N. agencies

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced Friday that Taiwan, through its allies, will ask the 63rd U.N. General Assembly to pass a resolution that would allow Taiwan to participate meaningfully in specialized U.N. agencies, a fundamental shift in its diplomatic campaign that previously sought full membership of the world body.

Deputy Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia said at a press conference that the U.N. representatives of St. Vincent and the Grenadines and the Solomon Islands earlier in the day introduced a resolution co-sponsored by 17 of Taiwan's 23 allies to the agenda of the 63rd U.N. General Assembly slated to begin Sept. 16, kicking off Taiwan's latest effort to expand its international participation.

Unlike in previous years -- particularly the last eight years under Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rule -- the resolution, titled "Need to Examine the Fundamental Rights of the 23 million People of the Republic of China (Taiwan) to Participate Meaningfully in the Activities of the U.N. Specialized Agencies," does not request the assembly to consider Taiwan's membership or direct participation in the U.N.

"This is a more moderate, rational and feasible approach, " said Hsia of the new initiative, which he described as reflecting the thoughts and aspirations of the people of Taiwan for international participation, as well as the reality of the current political situation in the international community.

Noting that Taiwan's efforts to join the U.N. since 1993 received no support from any countries other than Taiwan's few diplomatic allies, Hsia said the pragmatism of the new initiative received positive responses from ambassadors and representatives stationed in Taipei during initial consultations.

Taiwan's seat in the U.N. was given to China in 1971, when the U.N. passed Resolution 2758, and the country has been denied access to all related U.N. agencies and conventions ever since. Taiwan launched its efforts to return the U.S. in 1993, but has had no success.

During the eight-year period of DPP rule, Taiwan's applications were often seen by the international community as moves toward Taiwan independence, particularly last year, when former President Chen Shui-bian decided to apply for membership under the name Taiwan.

At present, there are 16 specialized agencies under the U.N. framework involved in issues such as health, labor, intellectual property rights, meteorology and aviation. Hsia said Taiwan's seeking of participation is not a political appeal, but done out of humanitarian concerns.

Admitting the prospects for Taiwan's U.N. status hinge on the attitude of China, Hsia urged Beijing to understand the desires of the Taiwanese people, to show goodwill to Taiwan's proposal and to not obstruct, warning that "an isolated Taiwan is a disservice to relations across the Taiwan Strait."

The U.N. campaign will be a crucial test for President Ma Ying-jeou's advocacy of "pragmatic diplomacy, " or "modus vivendi" approach, and seeking a "diplomatic truce" with China on both the domestic and cross-strait fronts. Hsia said that under those concepts, the two sides should pursue co-operative co-existence rather than confrontation.

In light of strong criticism from the opposition DPP, which claims Ma's policy is tantamount to giving up sovereignty, Hsia pointed out that meaningful participation does not rule out membership in international organizations in the future and that Taiwan has not given up its appeal for formal membership in the future.

Even with what he called a moderate and practical approach, Hsia admitted that it still is an extremely challenging task and that if the resolution can successfully be included on the agenda it will be "big achievement." The U.N. General Affairs Committee makes a final decision on the opening day of the assembly when it discusses and reviews the draft agenda.

As for the sensitive name issue, Hsia said that will be dealt with only after the U.N. reaches consensus on the issue, and when each specialized agency starts arranging Taiwan's participation. However, he ruled out the name Taiwan, China, which is used by China and many international organizations, and emphasized that the country's national dignity must be kept intact.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.090 to close at NT$31.330.
A total of US$1.637 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.240 and fluctuated between NT$31.190 and NT$31.405.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumer foundation files complaint against Microsoft

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation, Chinese Taipei (CFCT) filed a complaint with the Fair Trade Commission (FTC) against Microsoft Friday, urging the commission to impose sanctions on the company for its termination of Windows XP in the Taiwanese market.
"We suggest that the commission penalize Microsoft with a heavy fine for impairing market fairness, " CFCT acting Chairman Hsieh Tien-jen said when he delivered the complaint to the FTC.

Microsoft stopped selling the XP operating system in Taiwan at the end of June. As the company has the lion's share of the local software market, estimated to surpass 90 percent, local consumers have been left with little choice but to purchase personal computers (PCs) bundled with Windows Vista, launched in 2007.

The foundation June 30 urged Microsoft Taiwan Corp., the local branch of the world's biggest software vendor, to reinstate sales of XP and to continue technical support for XP users. However the company did not meet the demands.

Officially submitting the complaint at the FTC office, Hsieh told reporters that over half of local users would prefer to replace Vista with XP when buying a Vista-bundled computer, citing a recent survey polled by his foundation.
"Sixty-seven percent of local users want a return of XP to the market, " he went on, citing the results of another poll and adding that Microsoft's marketing strategy is an abuse of consumer rights.
With fewer operating system options in the market, Hsieh went on, local consumers might be discouraged from replacing their old computers.
"This might also hurt the hardware business," he warned.

Chou Ya Shu, an FTC commissioner, told CNA that since Aug. 4, the commission has been investigating Microsoft's suspected exploitation of consumer choice by using its dominant market share to promote Vista over XP.
If the case is upheld, Microsoft will have to pay a maximum fine of NT$25 million (US$806,000) , said Chou, who is also FTC spokeswoman.
"We will review the CFCT's complaint and its suggestions on how we can facilitate our investigation, " she said, although she refused to comment on how long the investigation might last.
The CFCT also suggested compulsory licensing of XP to allow local manufacturers to fabricate the operating system, bringing the software back to the market.
"Since Microsoft no longer sells XP regardless of the market demand, such licensing could bring the option back to the consumers," Hsieh noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmentally friendly electric motorbikes to be mass produced

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Friday that the government-financed Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) will help domestic manufacturers churn out some 100,000 electric motorcycles in four years.

Liu made an inspection tour of the ITRI headquarters in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, where he was briefed on the progress of research and development of various high-technology products in general and on environmentally friendly electric motorcycles in particular.

He said the government will see to it that some 100,000 electric motorcycles, powered by replaceable batteries, are produced by private motorbike manufacturers around Taiwan in four years amid louder calls for energy-saving and carbon-cutting measures.

ITRI Chairman Chintay Shih, speaking at the briefing, said that with a gigantic team of 5,715 high-caliber people -- including 1,018 Ph.D. holders and 3,151 master's degree holders -- the institute has accumulated patent rights for 8,905 items.
"The ITRI also helped establish 148 new companies for high-tech manufacturing, with some 18,490 'friends of the ITRI' involved in the industries so far," Shih said.

Currently, he added, the ITRI is focusing its R & D efforts on five major fields -- how to help companies and the public reduce energy consumption and cut carbon dioxide emissions; biomedicine and healthcare; intelligent life; the Internet, and advanced technology production.

DOC.HEADLINE: Burning ghost money induces more asthma cases: doctor

TEXT.P: Burning incense and ghost money during "ghost month, " the seventh month of the lunar year, induces more asthma cases among children, a pediatrician said Friday.

Hsu Shih-ta, director of Mackay Memorial Hospital's Department of Immunology, Allergy and Rheumatology, said the number of asthma cases induced by allergy has increased by between 10 percent and 20 percent recently.

In "ghost month, " which falls this year in the entire month of August, the number of worship ceremonies is especially frequent and usually entails the burning of paper "ghost money, " which produces the carcinogenic benzene and other chemicals that are bad for the respiratory tract.
According to traditional Chinese folk belief, souls are released from hell during ghost month to mingle with the living.

Burning ghost money began as a ritual to appease these spirits so they do not create mischief or harm. Believers burn money year-round, but the activity reaches a peak during ghost month, and especially on the 15th day of the month, known as "ghost festival."
Hsu pointed out that those who set up altars and burn incense in their homes produce air pollutants that can accumulate.
"When the concentration of air pollutants rises, it induces allergic reactions among some children," he added.
Hsu said that allergic reaction can also be cumulative, noting that after years of living in an incense-burning environment, allergic reactions can become more apparent.

This, coupled with an average temperature difference of 7 degrees Celsius between air-conditioned indoor areas and outdoor areas, has also contributed to the rise in the number of asthma cases, he said.
For this reason, Hsu went on, a well-ventilated house will help children suffering from allergies and he advised opening windows for at least two hours daily, even during hot weather.
The Taipei city government's Department of Education recently announced that 20 percent of students at the city's junior high schools suffer from asthma.
Statistics show that as many as 50 percent of students attending elementary schools in the greater Taipei and greater Taichung areas suffer from allergy problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former president quits DPP in disgrace

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian announced Friday his decision to give up his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) membership together with his wife Wu Shu-jen, in a show of apology for the disgrace he has brought to the party by his dishonest management of his election campaign funds.

Chen made the move one day after confessing that he lied about the election campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004 and that his wife wired surplus funds from the election campaign contributions into overseas bank accounts.
During a news conference held Friday, Chen said he does not expect the public to forgive him for committing such a "serious mistake" and added that it was not his intention to hurt the DPP.

"Today, I have to sadly say `sorry' to all fellow party members and supporters, for I have disappointed and disgraced all of you, have failed to live up to your expectations and have done irreparable damage to the party," he said.
Chen said that despite his withdrawal from the party, he will accept investigation by the DPP's anti-corruption committee and will also face public criticism and judicial investigation.
He urged party supporters not to deny the DPP's efforts to protect Taiwan's sovereignty, deepen Taiwan's democracy and pursue social justice, just because of his personal mistake.

The former president made the shocking confession Thursday after ruling Kuomintang Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu revealed copies of documents showing that the Federal Department of Justice and Police of the Swiss Confederation was requesting assistance from the Taiwanese authorities over suspected money laundering by Chen's son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching through two Swiss bank accounts.
However, Chen claimed that all the surplus funds were handled by his wife and that he had no idea his wife had wired the funds abroad until early this year.

Hung's revelation came just one day after Next magazine reported that Chen's daughter-in-law had laundered money for the former first family by secretly wiring NT$300 million overseas in 2006, after the exposure of the "state affairs fund" case.

The former first lady was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.
Chen, who had immunity from prosecution while in office, was named as a co- defendant in the case as soon as he stepped down from the presidency May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Domestic oil prices drop for second consecutive week

TEXT.P: Domestic gasoline and diesel prices were lowered Friday by NT$0.9 and NT$1 per liter, respectively, for the second week in a row, thanks to recent a decline in average international oil prices over the five previous trading days.
According to a press statement issued by the state-owned oil company CPC Corp. Taiwan, the adjustment will bring down the price of 92 unleaded to NT$32.5 and that of diesel to NT$30.3 per liter.

The new floating price mechanism, introduced Aug. 7 to review prices weekly instead of monthly, adjusts domestic oil prices based on international average oil prices during the period from the previous Friday to Thursday. The changes become effective at 12 a.m. Saturday.

The company decided on its first adjustment last Friday after the new mechanism was introduced, cutting gasoline and diesel prices by NT$2 and NT$2.2 a liter, respectively, due to cheaper crude oil prices.
"Fuel prices in Taiwan remain the lowest among the country's Asian neighbors," the press release stated.

Compared with the pre-tax 92 unleaded gasoline prices in South Korea, Japan and Singapore, which stood Aug. 12 at NT$29.6, NT$32.27 and NT$28.71 per liter, respectively, the price in Taiwan was NT$23.35 a liter prior to Friday's adjustment.

Explaining the range for the most recent adjustment, the press statement noted that the international average price of US$118.35 per barrel from Aug. 1-7 had slumped by a considerable 5.8 percent to US$111.47, which was the average price for Aug. 8-14.

However, offset by the recent decline of the new Taiwan dollar against the U.S. dollar -- the domestic currency's weekly average fell to NT$31.167 from NT$30.728 during the two-week period -- the lowering rate was narrowed to only 3.57 percent.
Meanwhile, CPC Corp. Taiwan's chief rival, the privately owned Formosa Petrochemical Co., also lowered its gasoline and diesel prices by the same rate, to NT$32.5 and NT$30.9 per liter, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Olympic baseball team defeated by China

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Olympic baseball team suffered a surprise defeat by China Friday in Beijing, as it slipped from its 7-3 lead -- almost a sure win -- to lose the match 7-8 in a runoff competition in the bottom of the 12th inning..

Taiwan's team, known officially as Chinese Taipei, used Pan Wei-lun as its starting pitcher. Pan pitched seven perfect innings and allowed the Chinese team no runs. China used Wang Nan as its starting pitcher, but he was relieved in the sixth inning.

Chinese Taipei's strong hitter Lo Kuo-hui hit a solo home run in the top of the fifth inning, which was followed by another run in the sixth inning by Peng Cheng-min, who earned a walk, stole to second base and took advantage of a series of errors by the opposing team to reach the home plate.

China launched a counterattack in the bottom of the eighth inning, scoring three runs after Chinese Taipei's middle relief pitcher Lo Chia-jen made a wild pitch and then allowed two hits, which gave China a temporary lead of 3-2.

Chinese Taipei scored another run in the top of the ninth inning when Chang Chien-min contributed a two-base hit, resulting in a 3-3 tie that required a runoff. China then replaced its second relief pitcher with Lu Jiangang in the 10th inning.
The tie remained unbroken until the 12th inning, when Chinese Taipei used a sacrifice bunt, an intentional walk and a string of hits to score four runs and lead China by a score of 7-3.

The almost sure victory of Chinese Taipei turned into a surprise reversal in the bottom of the 12th inning, as its pitcher Yang Chien-fu, who took over in the 10th inning, allowed two hits that each resulted in two runs, followed by another run scored as a result of an error by an outfielder, and the game ended 8-7 in favor of China.
Commenting on Friday's match against China, hitter Lo said, "That is baseball -- you never know which team is going to win until the end of the game."

According to Lo, the game against Japan the previous night apparently had a negative effect on Chinese Taipei, because, delayed by rain, the game lasted until 11:30 p.m., which meant that many of the players did not go to bed until 1 a.m. Friday -- only to be woken up early in the morning to prepare for the game against China.
"The tight schedule might have taken a toll on our physical strength, but that should not be used as an excuse for our defeat by China," he said.

In its two previous matches, Chinese Taipei defeated the Netherlands 5-0 but lost to Japan 1-6. It will play four more games in the round-robin competition against Cuba, South Korea, the United States and Canada between Aug. 16 and 20. It will have to win at least two more matches to make it into the semifinals on Aug. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. supports Taiwan's meaningful international participation: AIT

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) made no direct comment Friday on Taiwan's new initiative to seek more international participation, but reiterated its long-held position that "the U.S. supports Taiwan's meaningful participation as appropriate in organizations in which full membership is not possible."

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced Friday that Taiwan, through its allies, will ask the 63rd U.N. General Assembly to pass a resolution that would allow Taiwan to participate meaningfully in specialized U.N. agencies, a fundamental shift in its diplomatic campaign that previously sought full membership of the world body.

AIT spokesman Thomas Hodges declined to comment on Taiwan's proposal being introduced to the forthcoming U.N. General Assembly, but referred to the long- held U.S. position on the issue of Taiwan's participation in international organizations.
-- The U.S. does not support Taiwan's membership in international organizations in which statehood is a prerequisite, including the United Nations.
-- As we have noted many times previously, the U.S. does support Taiwan's meaningful participation as appropriate in organizations in which full membership is not possible.
-- We do support Taiwan's membership in organizations in which statehood is not a requirement.

Asked if the U.S. position was taken into consideration in the decision-making process, Deputy Foreign Minister Andrew Hsia said at a Ministry of Foreign Affairs press conference that the ministry held consultations with ambassadors and representatives stationed in Taipei on the issue and that the initial response was very positive.

"This is a more moderate, rational, practical and feasible approach, " said Hsia of the new initiative, which he described as reflecting the thoughts and aspirations of the people of Taiwan regarding international participation, as well as the reality of the present international political situation.
However, Hsia admitted that foreign countries will not adopt an official position until they have studied and reviewed Taiwan's initiative.

The U.S. position on Taiwan's bids to enter the international arena can be best observed in terms of the World Health Organization (WHO), as it supports Taiwan's meaningful participation in the global health framework and the country's status as an observer in the World Health Assembly -- the highest decision body of the WHO -- but is opposed to Taiwan's full WHO membership.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan food firms to target wealthy on trip to China

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will organize three delegations to visit China after the end of Beijing Olympic Games later this month to promote sales of Taiwanese farm produce, a TAITRA official said Friday.
According to the TAITRA official, more than 100 companies in agricultural and food processing industries will target wealthy areas believed to have the most market potential.
The official said that although Taiwan's food products are more expensive than China's, Taiwan firms can attract more customers with their products' high quality and superior packaging.
Representatives from the 100-plus companies will be divided into three groups to tap markets in northeastern, eastern and western parts of China, respectively, the official said.

The TAITRA official said that Taiwanese firms will exhibit more than 200 products, including fruits from Taiji Store and Tainan County Musk Melon Federation Marketing; tea leaves from the Wen-shen Tea Extension Center, Lishan, Lushan, Alishan, and Lugu; and tan tsai noodles and minced meat from Tainan's famous Tu Hsiao Yueh.

Other products include Chyuan Jeou Rong Enterprise's kaoliang liquor series, thousand-year eggs from Shung G Shiang Company, mochi and cakes from the Royal Family Food Company and San Shu Gong Company, organic miso from Shih-chuan Company, concentrated health vinegar, fish snacks from Jia-tien Industrial Company and Jenyi Food Company, grass jelly drinks from Taisun Enterprise, and vegetable soup, burdock tea, rice noodles, and seaweed ginseng from King Kung Health Food Company.
The delegations will attend the 4th China Jilin-Northeast Asia Investment and Trade Expo from Sept. 2 to 6 in Changchun City, Jilin Province, China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Olympic medal hopefuls depart for Beijing

TEXT.P: Four award-winning taekwondo athletes, seen as Taiwan's Olympic medal hopefuls, left Taipei Friday to take part in the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games.

The four Taiwanese athletes, who will compete under the official name "Chinese Taipei," are Chu Mu-yen, Yang Shu-chun, Su Li-wen, and Sung Yu-chi. Each of them has won medals in international competitions.
Chu, fighting in the men's under-58kg division, won Taiwan's second gold medal in the 2004 Athens Olympic Games at the age of 22.

Yang, who is Chu's girlfriend, was the champion in the women's under-49kg event in the Asian taekwondo tournament in April this year. She is hoping for success in the women's competition in the Beijing Olympics.

Su captured a gold medal in the women's under-63kg event in the Doha Asian Games in August 2007, while Sung won the gold medal in the men's under-72kg category in the 2007 Beijing WTF World Taekwondo Championships.
As a team, they underwent a spiritual program in a Buddhist temple in southern Taiwan to reduce mental stress and get them in the best psychological state for the forthcoming competitions.

Chu told reporters before the team's departure that he will do his best to prove to the world that a former Taiwanese gold medal winner also has the ability to retain his title in Beijing. He acknowledged that his strongest opponents are from Germany, Spain and Iran.

Yang expressed confidence that she is now at her best. Acknowledging that each match will be important to her, she said she will put out her best performance, with her prime targets being the competitors from China, Cuba and Canada.

Su said that her immediate goal is to make it into the final-four competition, while Sung said his major opponents are from South Korea, and that he would try to turn pressure into a force in his favor.

Taekwondo is one of a few sports categories in which Taiwan has a good chance to win medals. In the Athens Olympics in 2004, three of the country's five medals, including two golds, were won in the taekwondo competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait economic negotiations hard task: SEF chief

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait economic talks will be a very difficult task, particularly for Taiwan, which is seeking to better protect its business interests in China and further sharpen its economic presence in Southeast Asia, said Taiwan's top negotiator with China Friday.

"Cross-strait economic talks, which probably would resume next year, would be the most 'difficult' part of the Taiwan-China negotiations," said Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung.
Chiang made the remarks during a speech at a seminar sponsored by the Taiwan Competitiveness Forum on the prospects of cross-strait relations.

According to Chiang, the SEF and Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) would rekindle bilateral negotiations by starting with economic issues before political issues. "Starting with less complex issues is our principle for negotiations," he said.

In line with this principle, the SEF and ARATS might resume economic talks on protecting Taiwan business interests and several key financial issues in 2009, he said. The industrial upgrade of Taiwan businesses in China is one of the critical issues to be discussed, he added.
In addition, he said, it is very important for Taiwan to discuss with China the "ASEAN Plus Three" forum, if Taiwan hopes to join the regional trade organization.
"ASEAN Plus Three" is a forum that functions as a coordinator of cooperation between the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and the three East Asian nations of China, Japan and South Korea.

Now that China, Japan and South Korea are absorbing as much as 65 percent of Taiwan's total exports, the establishment of "ASEAN Plus Three" will definitely have a huge negative impact on Taiwan if it cannot take part in the trade bloc, Chiang said.

"If Taiwan could first have talks with China over its possible role in ASEAN, other ASEAN member states would not have to worry about pressure from Beijing," he argued. "However, this would be the most difficult task in cross-strait economic negotiations."

Taiwan and China would have to discuss a broad range of issues to "normalize" two-way trade and commerce relations, as the two sides did not hold any bilateral talks prior to their admission to the World Trade Organization in 2002, Chiang said.

Apart from the recent economic measures implemented by President Ma Ying-jeou with the aim of boosting cross-strait exchanges, there are other relevant issues on which Taiwan and China need to negotiate, he added.

Concerning the establishment of full direct airlinks across the strait, Chiang said the SEF and the ARATS are set to negotiate on pending core issues such as destinations, flight numbers, route courses and cargo charter flights.

As current shipping links between Taiwan and China are conducted via Japan's Okinawa, the two sides will also discuss direct shipping services to help enterprises save some 500 million Japanese yen each year and effectively bolster their competitiveness, he said.
The SEF chief contended that Taiwan should use its economic clout and democratic values as a means of maintaining its distinctive image and its own identity on the world stage.
The SEF and ARATS are semiofficial bodies responsible for cross-strait dealings in the absence of official contacts since 1949, when Taiwan and China split amid a Chinese civil war.
The intermediary organizations clinched two historical deals in Beijing in June to set up direct weekend passenger charter flights and to allow more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan from July.

DOC.HEADLINE: Five Nigerians arrested on suspicion of fraud

TEXT.P: Five Nigerians -- four men and a woman -- were detained in Taipei and Tainan Thursday and Friday, respectively, by law enforcement officials for allegedly swindling money from so-called investors, Hsinchu City police said Friday.

Police officers from Hsinchu City and Hsinchu County in northern Taiwan arrested the five Nigerians, who included one naturalized Taiwanese, in separate raids in northern Taipei County and Tainan County in the south, a spokesman said.

Police tracked down the five suspects after receiving a telephone call from a Philippine woman who said she was the wife of a Taiwanese man and claimed to have been swindled by a foreign fraud ring that targeted both locals and foreigners.
Acting on the tip, police nabbed a woman from Nigeria and found that she had overstayed her tourist visa after she entered Taiwan last year.
Police investigation showed that the Nigerian woman also set up a dummy company in Taiwan and pretended to run a second-hand car business to defraud investors.

The Philippine woman told the police that she had been defrauded of some NT$500,000 (US$15,923) by the Nigerian woman and that she had only recently learnt that the Nigerian was a member of a fraud ring. The ring, composed of foreigners, asked her to remit an additional NT$250,000, the Filipina said.
Police also found that the Nigerian fraud ring had racked up profits by shipping used cars, which they had obtained illegally in Taiwan, to their country.
The police, suspecting that the five Nigerians may have been involved in other illegal activities, have launched an in-depth investigation into the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Industry delegation to recruit top talent in U.S., Canada
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 14 (CNA) 08/15/08 21:17:08 (By Lillian Lin and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: A delegation, composed of representatives of 29 Taiwanese technology firms and nine research institutes, will visit five cities in the United States and Canada later this month to recruit talent, sources close to Taiwan's representative office in New York said Thursday..

The recruitment mission was organized by Taiwan's Cabinet-level National Science Council and Ministry of Economic Affairs, the sources said, adding that the delegation will be led by Minister-without-Portfolio Chang Jin-fu.

The delegation is due to arrive in San Francisco on Aug. 17, where it will focus on attracting professionals in semiconductor and other information technology fields. Then the group heads to Raleigh, North Carolina on Aug. 19 to recruit talent in biotechnology.
It will then go to Boston on Aug. 21 to seek out professionals in the computer software and financial industries, and visit Toronto, Canada on Aug. 23 looking for talent in medicine and health care.
During its last stop in Seattle, the group will recruit professionals in aviation technology, telecommunications, and biotechnology, the official said.
The delegation is aiming to fill a total of 1,350 jobs, including posts as managers in research and development and project management, engineers, supervisors, accountants and marketing planners.

The delegation hopes to attract overseas Taiwanese to return to their homeland for work. It will also introduce alternative military service to overseas students. The program allows young men to complete their required military service while contributing to the nation's key industries.
A total of 18 enterprises and academic institutes have recruited 23 employees under such alternative service since it began last March, the official said.

The delegation will also introduce a National Science Council program that invites overseas Taiwanese professionals to return to Taiwan every year. The council covers the professional' airfare and expenses, in return for their assistance and counseling to government departments and private firms.
A total of 47 professionals have participated in the program in past three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Philippine city delegation visits Keelung City

TEXT.P: A Philippine city delegation has visited the Keelung city government in an effort to boost exchanges and cooperative ties between the two cities, a Keelung city official said Friday.

The three-member delegation, headed by Jude T. Sayson, deputy mayor of Bacolod City -- which has sister city ties with the northern Taiwan port city -- visited the Keelung city government Thursday, the official said.
Bacolod City, which is the largest city on the island of Negros, is the capital of Negros Occidental.

During its stay in Keelung, the delegation will visit the city's Harbor Bureau and departments in charge of construction, environmental protection, economic affairs and agriculture, fishery and police affairs, according to the official.

Keelung Mayor Chang Tong-rong reaffirmed while receiving the delegation that he has done his utmost to engage in "city diplomacy" since he assumed office. He also expressed hope that the two cities can send delegations to visit each other's cities on a regular basis.

Sayson praised Keelung as a "scenic international harbor city" and expressed hope that his city can follow Keelung's example of achieving success in promoting environmental protection. He also expressed desire to boost bilateral exchanges and cooperation in fishery development between the two countries.

The delegation was invited by the city government to attend a ritual held that day to usher in the annual Chungyuan Festival, which falls on Aug. 15 this year. The festival is one of various "ghost month" activities held around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's softball team defeated by Australia in Beijing Olympics

TEXT.P: Taiwan's softball team suffered its third defeat in the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games Friday, losing to Australia 1-3 in a seven-inning match.

The Taiwanese women, competing under the official name "Chinese Taipei," scored one run in the bottom of the first inning to take a temporary lead, but failed to follow up with any more runs thereafter.
The Australian team turned the tide in the top of the fifth inning by hitting two successive home runs.
Although Chinese Taipei used a relief pitcher in the sixth inning, Australia was able to maintain its offensive momentum with more hits and to score another run, keeping a 3-1 lead until the finish.
In its three previous matches played Aug. 12-14, Chinese Taipei lost to Canada and Japan, 1-6 and 1-2, respectively, but defeated Venezuela 3-0.
The Taiwanese softballers are scheduled to play three more matches in the next three days against the United States, China and the Netherlands.

Mo Cheng, secretary-general of the Chinese Taipei Amateur Softball Association, said he is now banking on victories over China and the Netherlands for the team to have a shot at fifth place in the tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: Justice minister calls for speedy probe in former first family case

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng on Friday urged prosecutors to accelerate their probe into the allegations of money laundering involving family members of former President Chen Shui-bian.
She said that a speedy investigation will help restore the public's faith in the justice system.

Wang made the remarks one day after it was reported that the Swiss Confederation's Federal Department of Justice Police had sought Taiwan's assistance in probing a possible case of money laundering in Switzerland by Chen's son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.
Wang said that she felt "sadness and regret" upon learning earlier in the day that Chen Chih-chung and his wife already left Taiwan last Saturday.

Wang said that as far as she knows, head prosecutor Ching Chi-jen, who is assigned the case, has compiled related documents and information, including the indictment of former first lady Wu Shu-jen in a high-profile "state affairs fund" case.
Ching left for Switzerland Aug. 12 to deliver the documents to the Swiss authorities and to provide other relevant information, she added.

Wu was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 on grounds that she had used receipts provided by the others to claim reimbursements totalling NT$14.8 million from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.
Former President Chen, who was named as a co-defendant in the case but had immunity from prosecution while in office, is now under investigation.

The former president apologized to the nation Thursday, admitting that he had not faithfully accounted for his campaign expenses in his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004, but claimed that he was unaware, until early this year, that the surplus funds had been wired abroad by his wife.

Meanwhile, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Taipei chapter convened an executive committee meeting Friday and all 13 members who were present unanimously agreed that Chen Chih-chung and Huang Jui-ching should be stripped of their party membership next Monday in a meeting of the party's Taipei city advisory committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Chinese intruders nabbed on Matsu Island

TEXT.P: Two Chinese smugglers and one local resident were arrested late Thursday by coast patrol officers on Taiwan's outlying Matsu Island and turned in to prosecutors Friday on charges of breaching nationals security and the country's immigration laws.
Coast Guard Administration (CGA) officers apprehended the three men on a tip which indicated that some people with Chinese accents had been seen hanging around the park near the island's Fuao wharf.
A local resident, identified by the surname Lin, was suspected of playing a role in two Chinese men's illegal entry into Matsu.

According to CGA investigation agents, the three men have been handed over to the local prosecutors office on Matsu for further investigation following an initial probe Friday morning. The men were all drunk when they were arrested the previous night, the CGA agents said.
The CGA's Matsu division said a crackdown on illegal immigrants and contraband rings will continue, in light of the growing number of cases involving illegal Chinese workers on Matsu since last year.

Patrols along Matsu's coastline and on its uninhabited islets will be stepped up to effectively wipe out human trafficking and poaching by Chinese fishing vessels near the island, which lies just off China's Fujian coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma attends inauguration of Paraguayan president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou, who is in Paraguay to attend the inauguration of Paraguayan President Fernando Lugo, was accorded the same high level of respect as other heads of state at the ceremony on Friday morning, and he interacted with some of them.
Ma, who arrived at the inauguration venue around 8:20 a.m. local time, traveled there behind the motorcade of Chilean President Michelle Bachelet and ahead of Ecuador President Rafael Correa.

A broadcaster on the local television channel "Tele futuro" introduced Taiwan as having the largest delegation among all countries attending the inauguration. There were more than 25 media groups at the parliamentary square where the ceremony was held.
Ma was escorted to his seat along with other heads of state, and placed between Venezuela President Hugo Chavez and Spanish Crown Prince Felipe with whom he exchanged greetings.
The ceremony commenced with the singing of the Paraguayan national anthem in both Spanish and the local Guarani language.

Lugo began his inauguration speech by thanking the 10 heads of state present for attending the ceremony. The leaders were from Brazil, Chili, Bolivia, Argentina, Uruguay, Ecuador, Honduras, Venezuela, Republic of China Taiwan and Spain.
Lugo vowed to do great things for the salvation of Paraguay's poorest people.
"Paraguay's era of corruption is going to end, " Lugo pledged. "I will continue to fulfill the dreams the country had when it was first established."
"The change in country will be not only in the political leadership, but also in the entire culture," he added.
Ma listened attentively to the 43-minute speech via an interpreter.
Later at a religious ceremony at the Metropolitan Cathedral of Asuncion, Ma showcased his diplomatic skills by conversing easily with Prince Felipe before the start.
Lugo, a former Roman Catholic bishop, won a historic victory in Paraguay's presidential election, ending more than six decades of rule by the central-right Colorado Party.

Dubbed the "bishop of the poor, " the 56-year-old Lugo vowed to improve the economy of the developing South American nation and to clean up practices that have given Paraguay a reputation as a corrupt country and a safe haven for smugglers.
Lugo retired as a Catholic bishop in December 2006 to sidestep Paraguay's constitutional ban on the clergy seeking public office.

Lugo had said during his campaign that he would like to establish relations with China if elected, giving rise to speculations that Taiwan might lose its only diplomatic ally in South America to China.
However, after meeting with Ma on Thursday morning, the two vowed to maintain and consolidate bilateral relations.

Ma, who is making his first state visit since he took office May 20, is scheduled to leave Paraguay at 4 p.m. local time for the Dominican Republic to attend the inauguration of President-elect Leonel Fernandez. He will return to Taiwan on Aug. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: Representative office showed lack of judgment: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday its representative office in Switzerland showed poor judgment in handling a letter requesting judicial assistance in a case of alleged money laundering involving members of the former first family.

An official from the ministry was referring to the representative office's method of forwarding the letter from the Swiss authorities to the MOFA. The official said that the representative office received the letter, dated June 16, in early July but the correspondence did not reach the MOFA until late July.
George Liu, Taiwan's de facto representative to Switzerland, told the CNA that the Swiss Department of Justice sent the letter to his office via ordinary mail, and did not mark it as confidential.
Liu said he therefore forwarded the letter to the MOFA via the ordinary mailing process, but unfortunately, it missed the weekly post and was delayed for another week.

In the letter, Swiss authorities requested judicial assistance in probing a case of possible money laundering in Switzerland by former President Chen Shui-bian's son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.

The MOFA official said that the ministry, after listening to the the explanations by Liu and other staff members, concluded that the letter had not been deliberately delayed, but that the representative office had shown a "lack of political judgment."
Nonetheless, the ministry announced Friday that Liu will be replaced by Vice Economic Affairs Minister Hsieh Fa-ta.
Liu, a former Taiwan Solidarity Union legislator, offered in June to resign and tendered a written resignation to Foreign Affairs Minister Francisco H. L. Ou in late July.
A Taiwan prosecutor departed for Switzerland Aug. 12 and is expected to review the deposits and withdrawals of accounts created under the name of Huang Jui- ching at Merrill Lynch Bank.

TEXT.P: 2. Event: News conference on support index for breastfeeding mothers. Date and Time: 09:00 a.m., Saturday, Aug. 16, 2008. Place: National Taiwan University International convention Center. Organizers: Bureau of Health Promotion. Press Contact: Tel.3366-3366. Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
