DOC.HEADLINE: CEC forms panel to study ex-president's campaign funding

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) has formed a special task force to study issues regarding former President Chen Shui-bian's confession that he had not faithfully declared his election campaign expenses, an official said Friday.

The commission took the step a day after Chen confessed that he had lied about the campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004 and that his wife had wired surplus funds from the election campaign contributions to overseas bank accounts.

"The nine-member task force will meet Aug. 20 to discuss whether the CEC is in a position to deal with the case under the current law provisions, " said CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-you after a CEC commissioners meeting.

According to Teng, the provisions related to campaign funding, stipulated in the Public Officials Election and Recall Law, were deleted in an amendment passed in November 2007. The campaign funding provisions prescribed in the President and Vice President Election and Recall Law were also frozen after the Political Contributions Act took effect in March this year.

However, as Chen's mayoral and presidential elections were held during periods when those regulations were still valid, Teng said, the CEC panel will consider whether Chen can be held accountable in accordance with the now-defunct regulations.
According to CEC data, Chen declared his 2004 presidential campaign expenses at slightly more than NT$1.2 billion and reported his 2000 campaign expenditures at NT$949 million.

Earlier in the day, Chen announced his withdrawal from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in a show of apology for the disgrace he has brought to the party by his dishonest management of his campaign funds.

"Today, it is with great sadness that I apologize to all party members and supporters. I let everybody down and did irreparable harm to the party. This was not my intention but I made mistakes, " Chen said in a statement. "To show my deepest remorse, my wife and I will leave the DPP now."
He also urged DPP supporters not to abandon the party's efforts to protect Taiwan's sovereignty, deepen Taiwan's democracy and pursue social justice, just because of his personal mistake.

Chen made the surprise confession Thursday after ruling Kuomintang Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu revealed copies of documents showing that the Federal Department of Justice and Police of the Swiss Confederation was requesting assistance from Taiwan in case of suspected money laundering by Chen's son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching through two Swiss bank accounts.
The confession is seen to add to Chen's legal woes, since it comes as the former president is already battling charges that he misused public funds.

Chen's wife was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.
Chen, who was immune to prosecution while in office, was named as a co-defendant in the case as soon as he stepped down from the presidency May 20. ENDITE

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 16, or the 16th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1777: Americans led by Gen. John Stark defeat the British at the Battle of Bennington during the American Revolution.
1825: Bolivia declares its independence from Spain.
1909: Japanese Chutaro Kido discovers an iron mine in Anshan, Liaoning Province, located in Manchuria, where Japan has extensive economic privileges. The Southern Manchuria Railway later sets up a steel plant in Anshan.
1913: Menachem Begin, Israeli prime minister from 1977 to 1983, is born in Russia. He shared the 1978 Nobel Peace Prize with Anwar Sadat of Egypt.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who had participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty, organizes a revolt in Tahu, Hsinchu County, against Japanese rule of Taiwan in the so-called Miaoli Incident. He was executed after the uprising failed.
1923: Lee Kuan Yew, prime minister of Singapore from 1959 to 1990, is born.
1923: Shimon Peres, Israeli prime minister from 1984 to 1986, is born in Poland.
1937: The Supreme National Defense Council decides at a meeting that the Nationalist government should authorize Chiang Kai-shek as generalisimo to lead the Republic of China armed forces in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1948: George Herman Ruth, known as "Babe" Ruth, the most famous baseball player of all time, dies in New York City at the age of 53. He broke the Major League home run record in three consecutive seasons (1919-21), and then again in 1927 with a staggering 60 home runs.
1949: Margaret Mitchell, the author of "Gone with the Wind," dies after being hit by a car two days earlier. She was 49.
1950: Taiwan, formerly comprising eight counties and nine cities, is re-divided into 16 counties and five cities.
1960: The new republic of Cyprus comes into being, with Archbishop Makarios as its first president.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Gabon.
1968: The first Poseidon missile is launched.
1974: Wu Kuan-hsiung, secretary-general of the China External Trade Development Council, and Ahmad Sowaidi, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of Qatar, sign a trade cooperation memorandum.
1975: The Republic of China and Nauru sign a civil aviation agreement.
1977: Elvis Presley, the king of rock and roll, dies of heart failure at the age of 42 after collapsing in his mansion in Memphis, Tenn.
1978: Cardinal Yu Pin dies of a heart attack in Rome at the age of 77.
1979: John G. Diefenbaker, Canadian politician who served as prime minister from 1957 to 1963, dies at the age of 84. The Progressive Conservative government he headed lost the 1963 general elections because of opposition to his proposals to build nuclear weapons in Canada.
1990: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq warns U.S. President George Bush that thousands of the troops he has sent to the Gulf will return home in coffins.
1996: Leonel Fernandez becomes the 100th president of the Dominican Republic.
1999: Two Republic of China warships, the Hui Yang and the Han Yang, are decommissioned after almost 30 years of service, bringing to 10 the total number of naval vessels decommissioned by the ROC.
2000: Visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation take part in the inauguration of Dominican Republic President Hipolito Mejia held at the Parliament Building.
2000: ROC Premier Tang Fei unveils a proposal to transform Taiwan into a knowledge-based economy that is on par with those of the world's most advanced nations within ten years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In order to acquire truth, it is necessary to obtain a wide and extensive knowledge of what has been said and done in the world; to critically inquire into it; to carefully ponder over it; to clearly sift it; and to earnestly carry it out."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan's softball team defeated by Australia in Beijing Olympics

TEXT.P: Taiwan's softball team suffered its third defeat in the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games Friday, losing to Australia 1-3 in a seven-inning match.

The Taiwanese women, competing under the official name "Chinese Taipei," scored one run in the bottom of the first inning to take a temporary lead, but failed to follow up with any more runs thereafter.
The Australian team turned the tide in the top of the fifth inning by hitting two successive home runs.
Although Chinese Taipei used a relief pitcher in the sixth inning, Australia was able to maintain its offensive momentum with more hits and to score another run, keeping a 3-1 lead until the finish.
In its three previous matches played Aug. 12-14, Chinese Taipei lost to Canada and Japan, 1-6 and 1-2, respectively, but defeated Venezuela 3-0.
The Taiwanese softballers are scheduled to play three more matches in the next three days against the United States, China and the Netherlands.

Mo Cheng, secretary-general of the Chinese Taipei Amateur Softball Association, said he is now banking on victories over China and the Netherlands for the team to have a shot at fifth place in the tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: Justice minister calls for speedy probe in former first family case

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng on Friday urged prosecutors to accelerate their probe into the allegations of money laundering involving family members of former President Chen Shui-bian.
She said that a speedy investigation will help restore the public's faith in the justice system.

Wang made the remarks one day after it was reported that the Swiss Confederation's Federal Department of Justice Police had sought Taiwan's assistance in probing a possible case of money laundering in Switzerland by Chen's son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.
Wang said that she felt "sadness and regret" upon learning earlier in the day that Chen Chih-chung and his wife already left Taiwan last Saturday.

Wang said that as far as she knows, head prosecutor Ching Chi-jen, who is assigned the case, has compiled related documents and information, including the indictment of former first lady Wu Shu-jen in a high-profile "state affairs fund" case.
Ching left for Switzerland Aug. 12 to deliver the documents to the Swiss authorities and to provide other relevant information, she added.

Wu was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 on grounds that she had used receipts provided by the others to claim reimbursements totalling NT$14.8 million from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.
Former President Chen, who was named as a co-defendant in the case but had immunity from prosecution while in office, is now under investigation.

The former president apologized to the nation Thursday, admitting that he had not faithfully accounted for his campaign expenses in his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004, but claimed that he was unaware, until early this year, that the surplus funds had been wired abroad by his wife.

Meanwhile, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Taipei chapter convened an executive committee meeting Friday and all 13 members who were present unanimously agreed that Chen Chih-chung and Huang Jui-ching should be stripped of their party membership next Monday in a meeting of the party's Taipei city advisory committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma attends inauguration of Paraguayan president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou, who is in Paraguay to attend the inauguration of Paraguayan President Fernando Lugo, was accorded the same high level of respect as other heads of state at the ceremony on Friday morning, and he interacted with some of them.
Ma, who arrived at the inauguration venue around 8:20 a.m. local time, traveled there behind the motorcade of Chilean President Michelle Bachelet and ahead of Ecuador President Rafael Correa.

A broadcaster on the local television channel "Tele futuro" introduced Taiwan as having the largest delegation among all countries attending the inauguration. There were more than 25 media groups at the parliamentary square where the ceremony was held.
Ma was escorted to his seat along with other heads of state, and placed between Venezuela President Hugo Chavez and Spanish Crown Prince Felipe with whom he exchanged greetings.
The ceremony commenced with the singing of the Paraguayan national anthem in both Spanish and the local Guarani language.

Lugo began his inauguration speech by thanking the 10 heads of state present for attending the ceremony. The leaders were from Brazil, Chili, Bolivia, Argentina, Uruguay, Ecuador, Honduras, Venezuela, Republic of China Taiwan and Spain.
Lugo vowed to do great things for the salvation of Paraguay's poorest people.
"Paraguay's era of corruption is going to end, " Lugo pledged. "I will continue to fulfill the dreams the country had when it was first established."
"The change in country will be not only in the political leadership, but also in the entire culture," he added.
Ma listened attentively to the 43-minute speech via an interpreter.
Later at a religious ceremony at the Metropolitan Cathedral of Asuncion, Ma showcased his diplomatic skills by conversing easily with Prince Felipe before the start.
Lugo, a former Roman Catholic bishop, won a historic victory in Paraguay's presidential election, ending more than six decades of rule by the central-right Colorado Party.

Dubbed the "bishop of the poor, " the 56-year-old Lugo vowed to improve the economy of the developing South American nation and to clean up practices that have given Paraguay a reputation as a corrupt country and a safe haven for smugglers.
Lugo retired as a Catholic bishop in December 2006 to sidestep Paraguay's constitutional ban on the clergy seeking public office.

Lugo had said during his campaign that he would like to establish relations with China if elected, giving rise to speculations that Taiwan might lose its only diplomatic ally in South America to China.
However, after meeting with Ma on Thursday morning, the two vowed to maintain and consolidate bilateral relations.

Ma, who is making his first state visit since he took office May 20, is scheduled to leave Paraguay at 4 p.m. local time for the Dominican Republic to attend the inauguration of President-elect Leonel Fernandez. He will return to Taiwan on Aug. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Crisis fuels U.S.-Russia animosities.
With Russia still defying U.S. demands to pull its troops from Georgia, the short, one-sided fight over two small mountain provinces widened Thursday into the sharpest exchanges yet between Washington and Moscow, threatening to unravel the post-Cold War consensus between them. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times Heavyweight Ishii grabs judo gold
Japan's men saved their bombshell for the heavyweight curtain closing act. Satoshi Ishii brought redemption to the men by capturing gold in the over 100-kg event Friday, defeating Abdullo Tangriev of Uzbekistan to follow in the footsteps of Athens champion Keiji Suzuki and give Japan back-to-back Olympic titles in the heaviest division.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: At last! S'pore assured of at least a silver after 48-year wait.
At precisely 6.10 pm yesterday, a slice of Singapore sports history was made.
A 48-year wait for an Olympic Games medal finally came to an end, thanks to the grit and tenacity of table tennis player Feng Tianwei.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Olympic Games medal dream comes truth after 48 years.
A 48-year long long wait for an Olympic Games medal finally came to end at August 15, women's team table tennis of Singapore: Lee Jiawei, Wang Yuegu and Feng Tianwei beat South Korea team yesterday and won a medal Singapore dreams of.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gasoline prices drop again

TEXT.P: The state-run oil refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan cut gasoline prices by NT$0.9 per liter and diesel prices by NT$1 per liter from midnight Friday, marking the second drop in fuel prices since last September.
The CPC announced the decrease earlier that day.

After the adjustment, the prices of 92-octane, 95-octane and 98-octane unleaded gasoline fell to NT$32.5 per liter, NT$33.2 per liter and NT$34.7 per liter, respectively, while the price of premium diesel was cut to NT$30.3 per liter.

Gas stations will decide their own retail prices, the CPC said, adding that the adjustment was made based on a floating pricing mechanism amended Aug. 7 that revises prices on a weekly basis based on fluctuations in the prices of Dubai and Brent crude oil as quoted on Platts, a leading global provider of energy information.
The privately owned Formosa Petrochemical Co., CPC's main competitor, also cut gasoline and diesel prices by NT$0.9 and NT$1, respectively, at the same time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan welcomes allies developing relations with China: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that Taiwan will be pleased to see Taiwan's allies developing substantive relations with China, just as Taiwan would like to do the same with China's allies.

Ma made the remarks during a meeting with Honduras President Manuel Zelaya aboard a charter flight they took along with Guatemalan Vice President Rafael Espada from Paraguay to the Dominican Republic after attending the inauguration of Paraguayan President Fernando Lugo.

In response to a question from Zelaya on how Taiwan's solid allies should react to the fact that relations between Taiwan and China have significantly improved, Ma vowed that nothing will change these longstanding friendships.

"The idea of 'diplomatic reconciliation and diplomatic truce' that I have proposed is aimed at improving cross-Taiwan Strait relations, " Ma was quoted as saying by Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi. "As for our allies who have supported us all this time, we will only consolidate bilateral friendships even more," he said.

"If our allies would like to develop substantive relations, such as economic or cultural relations, with China, Taiwan will be pleased to see that as well, just as Taiwan would like to do the same with China's allies," he added.

The frosty relations between Taiwan and China have been thawing since Ma took office May 20, and his proposal of a "diplomatic truce" is aimed at terminating the longstanding diplomatic tug-of-war with China in which both countries try to lure each other's allies to switch diplomatic allegiance by offering large sums of money in foreign aid to developing countries.
Ma also touted the strategy of "modus vivendi" or "pragmatic diplomacy," designed to leverage more international space for Taiwan.
He said the improved cross-strait relations have been well-received by the United States, Taiwan's allies and other countries in the region.

"Diplomatic truce is a strategy that serves multilateral interests, as not only relations between Taiwan and China are improved but relations between Taiwan and the U.S. are also improved," Ma stated.
"Allies of both Taiwan and China will all benefit from improved cross-strait relations," he added.
Wang said Ma and Zelaya had a 20-minute discussion in which they also promised to strengthen bilateral cooperation.
He told reporters that the arrangement for Zelaya and Espada to take the charter flight was made before Ma left Taiwan for his first state visit after assuming office.
Ma is scheduled to attend the inauguration of President Leonel Fernandez to a new term in office Aug. 16. He will return to Taiwan Aug. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: President receives warm welcome in Dominican Republic

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou received a warm high-level welcome Friday upon his arrival in the Dominican Republic, despite a tropical storm.

Before he disembarked from his charter plane, Ma was greeted by Republic of China Ambassador to the Dominican Republic Tsai Meng-hung and officials from the Dominican Republic Foreign Ministry's Department of Protocol. He then disembarked and was received formally by the Dominican Foreign Ministry's economic and trade deputy minister, as well as the director-general of the ministry's Asian department, along with a military honor guard and red carpet.

He arrived on a charter flight along with Honduras President Manuel Zelaya and Guatemala Vice President Rafael Espada from Paraguay after attending the inauguration of Paraguay President Fernando Lugo.
Ma was whisked away to his hotel, where over 100 Taiwanese expatriates lined up along a red carpet waving ROC national flags and calling out "Taiwan, go, go, go."
Some of the expatriates had come from as far afield as the United States to welcome the president.

Former ROC Ambassador to the Dominican Republic John Feng, who is accompanying Ma during his eight-day trip to South America and the Caribbean, also received a warm welcome from the Taiwanese expatriates.
Feng said he was very happy and excited to meet with all his "old friends."

The purpose of Ma's first state visit since taking office May 20 is to attend the inaugurations of Lugo and of Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez to a second term Aug. 16. He will return to Taiwan Aug. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: 24-hour marathon digital photography contest kicks off in Taipei

TEXT.P: A 24-hour photography contest kicked off in Taipei Saturday, with 460 amateur photographers from around the country competing to tell the best story of Taiwan's capital city with their digital cameras.

The contest is being held for the seventh consecutive year and is the largest to date, with over 60 more participants competing compared with last year, according to representatives of the organizer -- Fayaque Co.

The organizers said that amateur photographers of all ages, ranging from elementary school students to retirees, and from all walks of life, from medical professionals to IT industry workers, are competing in this year's event.

According to the contest rules, the participants must take photos of several of Taipei's major sites -- including the 228 Peace Memorial Park, the Taipei Museum of Contemporary Art, Ximending's Red House and the Taipei Film House -- and process the photos on computers set up by the event organizers within 24 hours of the start of the contest.
The contest results and winners are slated to be announced Sept. 16, the organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan welcomes strategic business alliance with Japan: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew said Friday that Taiwan welcomes the development of a strategic business alliance with Japan to establish a global business network.

Siew made the remarks during a meeting at the Presidential Office with Yorihiko Kojima, president of Japan's Mitsubishi Corp., the largest Japanese general trading company with over 200 bases of operations in approximately 80 countries worldwide. The company's Taiwan operation has 126 employees.

"Now is the best time for Japan to invest in Taiwan, which, with advantage of location and a more relaxed investment environment, can serve as a launch pad for Japan in seeking market expansion in Southeast Asia and China, " Siew told his guest.

He emphasized that after a series of lifting of restrictions, Taiwan and China will have more frequent trade contact and a more flexible platform for negotiations on logistics and personnel exchanges.
He noted that Japan has always been Taiwan's largest source of imports and the country's second-largest trade partner.
He continued that the reason Taiwan continues to seek closer cooperation with Japan despite decades of trade deficit is that it is hopeful of forming a bilateral strategic business alliance.
Kojima told Siew that he is well aware of Taiwan's importance in terms of business strategy and will promote bilateral or multilateral cooperation to help expand the two countries' business market.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to hold China investment seminars for local companies

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs is set to hold two seminars later this month to introduce strategies to Taiwanese companies planning to invest in China for dealing with disputes with the Chinese authorities and the assistance that is available to them in handling any problems they might encounter.

The ministry decided to offer the seminars following the lifting of several restrictions on cross-Taiwan Strait investment and trade exchanges in recent months by the ruling Kuomintang administration.
The seminars will be held in Taichung City in central Taiwan and in Taipei City on Aug. 28 and 29, respectively, according to the ministry.

Legal and business experts have been invited to the seminars to introduce some of the main problems faced by Taiwan-based companies operating in China, as well as response strategies for dealing with problems arising as a result of the recent rapid changes in the investment climate and regulations in China, the ministry said.

According to a recent survey by the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China of listed and over-the-counter companies in Taiwan, the five major areas of dispute involving Taiwanese companies operating in China are labor issues, tax administration problems, intellectual property rights disputes, friction with local governments and land issues.
The seminars are aimed at offering suggestions to Taiwanese companies on how to lower their business risks and ensure their rights when investing in China, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: Four Italian tourists were killed and another 15 were injured in a traffic accident Friday in the city of La Romana, some 130 kilometers north of Santo Domingo, the Dominican Republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's baseball medal hopes dim with 1-0 loss to Cuba

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei baseball team's Olympic medal hopes dimmed considerably with their 1-0 loss at the hands of the Cubans Saturday in Beijing, despite a strong pitching performance by starter Lee Chen-chang.
Lee pitched a solid six and two-thirds innings, giving up just three hits and striking out seven of the Cuban sluggers along the way.
Unfortunately, one of those hits was a lead-off homer by number five batter Frederich Cepeda in the seventh inning, which proved to be the winner in this tight pitching duel.

The Chinese Taipei batters were unable to solve Cuban starter Elier Sanchez, who pitched seven shut-out innings, giving up just three hits and three bases on balls. Norberto Gonzalez came on in relief to start the eighth inning and shut down the Taiwan squad the rest of the way, picking up his second save of the Beijing Olympics.
Chinese Taipei had been hoping to redeem themselves following their humiliating 8-7 extra-inning loss to lowly China the previous day.
The loss to Cuba dropped Chinese Taipei to a record of 1-3 in round-robin play and put them on the verge of elimination.

The team will now have to win its three remaining contests against South Korea, the United States and Canada over the next three days to have any hope of making it to the semi-finals and a chance at Olympic gold.

DOC.HEADLINE: Studio Classroom wins Asian Publishing Award

TEXT.P: Studio Classroom, an English-learning periodical publisher in Taiwan, has won the Asian Publishing Award, a prize that recognizes best publishing practices in Asia, for its creative Internet marketing, Studio Classroom General Manager Simon Hung said Saturday.

According to Hung, Studio Classroom won the award for content delivery, which refers to circulation- and audience-building activities, including the development of multimedia channels, in the category of Asian Magazine Management Awards.
The publishing company, founded in 1962 by Doris Brougham, known in Chinese as Peng Meng-huei, won another award in the same category last year.

As part of its eight-month marketing activities in celebration of its 45th anniversary, Studio Classroom successfully introduced its three magazines to a wider readership via Internet tools such as Yahoo! Kimo's Widget engine, a software system for running applets on Web pages or desktops with which users can interact.

The tool allows English learners to reach Studio Classroom's teaching resources easily and quickly. For example, they can listen to daily radio programs of its three magazines any time they like, and can learn new phrases and vocabulary from the magazine content, with a clock device that provides time management for learning.

The awarded marketing strategy also includes a blog that promotes an activity called "Give Me Ten, " which invites English learners to talk in English for at least 10 minutes every day to overcome their fear of using the language in daily life.

People can upload photos and articles about their practice of the activity to the blog and they can learn from other people's experience, and thus, a community of English learners is formed, Hung said.

"Tens of thousands of people have left messages on the blog within months to share their experience of learning English with others, " Hung said, adding that the publisher will soon launch its new "Mobile-magazine" that will allow people to read magazine content on their cell phones.
A total of 203 projects from 22 countries competed for 11 awards in the program this year, and the award ceremony was held in Singapore Friday, Hung said.

The honor in the Asian stage came one day after Advanced -- one of the publisher's three magazines -- won the 2008 Golden Tripod Best Language Learning Media Award, Taiwan's most prestigious award for publications, Hung said.
The magazine won the same domestic award four years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former president's house searched

TEXT.P: Law enforcement officials searched the Taipei home and office of former President Chen Shui-bian Saturday for evidence in connection with his public fund embezzlement case and his suspected money-laundering case.
Three prosecutors questioned Chen and his wife, Wu Shu-jen, at their home in the upscale Hsinyi district of eastern Taipei.
Chu Chao-liang, one of the three prosecutors, said "both Chen and Wu gave a frank explanation about their capital source and its flow."
But he said that because Wu pleaded ill-health, they did not put her words on record as an affidavit.
Chu said the prosecution will have to study the documents and information they gathered from the house.

According to media reports said the former first lady told the prosecutors that the funds she secreted in overseas bank accounts come from four sources: her own family; Chen's earnings as a lawyer before he went into politics; political contributions and earnings from investments.

However, Chen admitted in a news conference Thursday that he did not faithfully account for the election campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004. He claimed that he was unaware that the surplus funds of US$20 million were wired abroad by his wife until early this year.

The search came after the Ministry of Foreign Affairs confirmed Thursday that the Swiss authorities had requested judicial assistance from Taiwan in a probe into a possible money laundering case in Switzerland involving Chen's son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.

Taipei Head Prosecutor Ching Chi-jen left Taiwan for Switzerland Aug. 12, bringing with her related documents and information, including an indictment of Wu in the "state affairs fund" embezzlement case.
Ching is expected to review the deposits and withdrawals of bank accounts created under Huang's name at the Merrill Lynch Bank.
The prosecution barred Chen Chih-chung and his wife from leaving Taiwan Thursday, but both had already traveled to the United States last Saturday.
Prosecutors reportedly asked the former president and first lady to advise the two to return to Taiwan early to answer questions.

Wu was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.
However, she has attended only the first court hearing of the case and has since refused to appear in court to answer the charges, claiming "ill-health."
Chen, who was named as a co-defendant in the case but enjoyed immunity from prosecution while in office, began to be questioned as soon as he stepped down from the presidency May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Husbands' support greatest aid to breastfeeding: survey

TEXT.P: Husbands' support is the greatest aid for women who are breastfeeding their babies, while the absence of breastfeeding areas in public places is the top hindrance to their feeding options, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.
The survey of more than 1,000 breastfeeding mothers was conducted by the Taiwan Academy of Breastfeeding (TAB) between late July and early August.
The survey results found that more than half of the respondents cited their husbands as their No. 1 supporters in choosing breastfeeding.
More than 10 percent recognized counseling services and technical assistance of medical institutions as useful supports in feeding their babies with breast milk, according to the survey results.

The poll also found that nearly 30 percent of the respondents complained that public places are the most unfriendly to those wishing to breastfeed. The absence of dedicated breasfeeding rooms in most local public places often forces young mothers to breastfeed their children in restrooms, some respondents pointed out.

Mothers-in-law and neighbors were cited by many respondents as the two other factors discouraging them from breastfeeding, the survey results show. According to the respondents, many uninformed mothers-in-law do not want their grandchildren to be breast-fed because they think breast milk is "not nutritious" and might hinder their grandchildren's healthy development. Some mothers-in-law were also said to have no confidence in the breastfeeding skills of their daughters-in-law.
The survey further found that more women are willing to opt for breastfeeding amid the current economic downturn.

Analyzing the survey findings, a TAB spokeswoman said the government should push for a law revision to extend maternity leave or come up with new legislation to offer paid parental leave to encourage breastfeeding.
She also called for the government to install breastfeeding rooms in as many public places as possible to create a friendlier environment for breastfeeding.
Meanwhile, the academy has prepared free promotional postcards that the public can pick up and present to young breastfeeding mothers to encourage, support and thank them, the spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 6,600 people experience hunger in World Vision fast

TEXT.P: Some 6,600 people participated Saturday in the 19th fast organized by the World Vision Taiwan charity to "experience the pain of hunger" and raise social awareness of the global food crisis.
The rally, titled "30 Hour Famine", was co-sponsored by World Vision Taiwan and the 7-Eleven convenience store chain.

A total of 6,600 "famine heroes " from around the country -- from elementary school pupils to people aged 78 -- fasted for eight hours, from 10 a.m. through 6 p.m. -- at the event held at the National Taiwan University Sports Center, according to the organizers.
To date, 27,430 people in Taiwan have voluntarily experienced hunger from 12 to 30 hours in total, either in groups or as individuals, World Vision said in a statement.

"People living in Taiwan are among the lucky ones who do not know famine, while other people in the world do not enjoy normal life due to war, disaster or poverty, " Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said at the event, describing the participants as courageous in their willingness to experience others' misery and pain.

To encourage the fasters, singers and celebrities performed and shared their experiences of traveling to Afghanistan, Sudan and China's Sichuan Province, recently devastated by an 8-magnitude earthquake, the organizers said.
The participants were also asked to discuss in groups possible solutions to the worldwide food crisis.
Through the fast, World Vision was hoping to raise NT$150 million to help children and families suffering from famine, natural disasters and war, the statement said.
According to the World Vision, about 1 billion people in the world are suffering a food crisis, while famine and malnutrition kill about 25,000 children every day.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Russia in nuclear threat to Poland
Russia threatened Poland with a nuclear strike yesterday as the ripples of the Caucasus conflict spread through Europe and pitched West against East along new borders.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top prosecutor demands probe into information delay

TEXT.P: State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming demanded a probe Saturday into why information concerning possible money-laundering by members of the former first family did not reach him earlier.

Chen made the demand amid media reports that the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) received information from the Cayman Islands about possible money-laundering by former President Chen Shui-bian's son Chen Chih- chung and his wife Huang Jui-ching early this year.

The MJIB's Money Laundering Prevention Center obtained the information concerning Chen Chih-chung and Huang Jui-ching's remittances to overseas accounts and money transfers for setting up a company as long ago as Jan. 28, according to media reports.
The center reported to then-MJIB Director Yeh Sheng-mao immediately, and Yeh reportedly said that he would hand over the information directly to Chen Tsung- ming, the reports said.
However, Chen Tsung-ming said he never received such information, prompting him to order the probe into "who withheld the information."

The probe into the suspected money-laundering involving the former first family only came after the Ministry of Foreign Affairs confirmed Thursday that the Swiss authorities had requested judicial assistance from Taiwan in a probe into a suspected money laundering case in Switzerland involving Chen Chih-chung and his wife.

The ex-president admitted Thursday that he did not faithfully account for his election campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004, but he claimed that surplus funds to the tune of US$20 million were wired abroad by his wife without his knowledge until early this year.

Prosecutors searched Chen's house Saturday, during which former first lady Wu Shu-jen claimed that all the money she secreted in foreign bank accounts comes from four sources: her own family; Chen's earnings as a lawyer before he went into politics; political contributions; and earnings from investments.
Prosecutors also searched the home of Wu Ching-mao, Wu Shu-jen's elder brother, in Tainan county, southern Taiwan for evidence in connection with the alleged money-laundering case later in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's scandal said to have little impact on DPP

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian's campaign funding scandal should not have a lethal impact on the future of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the party's chairwoman predicted Saturday.

Tsai Ing-wen made the optimistic forecast at a DPP fundraiser in the central Taiwan city of Taichung, in which the party smoothly raised NT$5 million to help solve its financial woes. All of the NT$10,000-per-head tickets for the 50-table dinner were sold out.
"The sold-out dinner was an encouraging sign that Chen's election campaign fund incident should not have a grave impact on our party, " Tsai told fundraiser event goers.

Following resounding defeats in the Jan. 12 legislative elections and the March 22 presidential poll, the DPP is now in its most difficult time, Tsai said, adding that the exposure of campaign funding scandal involving former President Chen, who was a DPP founding member and twice served as its chairman, adds up to the party's woes.

"We are lucky as our rank-and-file members and grassroots supporters have not backed away from us at this critical moment, " an emotional Tsai said. "Our rank-and-file members remain firm and determined in pursuing our party's cause."

Noting that the DPP is obliged to provide alternative policy initiatives to local voters, Tsaid said the DPP should not let its supporters and rank-and-file members down and should strive to live up to their expectations.

In regard to Chen's recent confession that he didn't faithfully account for his campaign expenses in the two mayoral and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004 and that he didn't know until early this year that his wife Wu Shu-jen had wired a portion of surplus campaign contributions abroad, Tsai said the DPP should make an overall review of its supervisory system.

"A-bian (Chen's nickname) led our party to power. During the eight years in power, we placed too much trust in his authority and power while giving up our own thinking and judgment. As a result, his personal mistake now becomes our party's crisis. It's not A-bian's own duty. Every DPP member should shoulder the blame," Tsai said.
Admitting that the DPP has not fulfill its supervisory duty, Tsai said she was moved by the warmth and support shown by rank-and-file members and grassroots supporters at this difficult time.
"All party staff should never forget their generosity and should turn our gratitude into strength to serve our people and country, " Tsai said.

Tsai, who had served as vice premier and as the country's top China policy planner under Chen's administration, promised that the DPP will beef up its democratic decision-making mechanism to ensure that its policy decision reflects the whole party's common will and consensus.

In the face of domestic economic downturn and the impact of Chen's campaign funding scandal, Tsai said the DPP may have hard time raising funds to finance its development projects and campaign operations for next year's local government chiefs elections.
Nevertheless, Tsai said the party will not be daunted by such challenges as she believes that voters' support and expectations, not money, will determine the electoral outcome.
"We should give the public a DPP that i renewed and worthy of expectations," she added.

As to Chen and his wife's decision to withdraw from the DPP and Chen's desire to shoulder his responsibility for his actions as well as to accept an investigation by the party's anti-corruption committee, Tsai said the party respect it and accept it.

Stressing that anti-corruption and Taiwan-centric values are the DPP's only assets, Tsai said the DPP will start over and face all difficulties, protect Taiwan's sovereignty and democracy and continue to fulfill its role of supervising the Kuomintang government.

In the investigation of Chen's case, Tsai said the DPP will not be biased or cover anything up. "The DPP will support the courts, " she said, adding that Chen has the right and must offer the public a clearer explanation of the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma attends inauguration of Dominican president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou, who is in the Dominican Republic to attend the inauguration of President Leonel Fernandez, demonstrated diplomatic skills by interacting with some of the heads of state at the event.

Ma, who was accompanied by Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou and National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi, arrived 10 minutes earlier at the Parliament where the ceremony was held. He was escorted to his seat area to be placed between El Salvador President Antonio Saca on the right and Chilean President Michelle Bachelet on the left.
Given the fact that the official attire of the Dominican Republic is white, all heads of state attending the ceremony were dressed in white suit with black tie and shoes.
Prior to his departure from the hotel to the inauguration venue, Ma replied a reporters question on whether he is comfortable wearing the white suit, saying thatSi (yes).
This is my second time wearing white suit but I am quite comfortable in it,he added.

Ma, who sat at the second seat of the first row, exchanged greetings with Haitian President Rene Preval and Honduras President Manuel Zelaya upon arrival, who came to the Caribbean country by taking Mas charter flight from Paraguay after attending the inauguration of Paraguayan President Fernando Lugo.
The inauguration commenced with the singing of the national anthem of the Dominican Republic in Spanish.

Fernandez began his inauguration speech by thanking the 14 heads of state present for attending the ceremony. Ma was the second to be named by Fernandez, who addressed him ashis Excellency of the Republic of China Taiwan.
The new government will achieve a new economy situation, while will be more stable,he pledged in the speech.

Facing mounting pressure to steer the Dominican Republic clear of a deep economic slump threatening much of the Caribbean, analysts say Fernandezs deft handling of the economy, and his ability to pull it out of the sever crisis he inherited in 2004, were key to the victory of the New York-raised lawyer and academic in his re-election in May, according to a Reuters report.
But Fernandez has since been coping with fallout from the stumbling U.S. economy and high global oil and food prices.
Fernandez was sworn in for a third term in office on Saturday, a date also coincides with the celebration of the Restoration of the nations independence.

Other heads of state who have confirmed their attendance are Alvaro Uribe of Colombia, Oscar Arias of Costa Rica, Martin Torrijos of Panama, Spanish Crown Prince Felipe de Borbon and Prime Minister Dean Barrow of Belize.
However, the presence of Venezuelan leader Hugo Chavez was prevented due to the poor weather of a tropical storm, according to the countrys ambassador Francisco Belisario Landis on Saturday morning.
Ma, who is in his first state visit to South America and the Caribbean, will attend the religious ceremony of Fernandezs inauguration at 1: 00 p.m. local time and hold bilateral talks with Saca.
He will leave the Dominican Republic on Sunday and is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Aug. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president barred from leaving Taiwan over fund scandal

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian has been prohibited from leaving the country after he was found to have a large sum of cash deposited abroad, a Supreme Prosecutors Office (SPO) prosecutor said late Saturday.

Chu Chao-liang, one of the three prosecutors who searched Chen's home and office in Taipei earlier that day for evidence in connection with his suspected role in a public fund embezzlement case, said Chen's overseas travel ban was issued after extensive discussions among prosecutors at the SPO's Special Investigation Task Force.
"The main reason is that Chen has US$21 million deposited at overseas bank accounts owned by his family members," Chu explained.

Chen's wife, Wu Shu-jen, was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million (US$472,843) from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.
Chen, who was named as a co-defendant in the case but enjoyed immunity from prosecution while in office, began to be questioned shortly after he stepped down from the presidency May 20.

He has not yet been indicted over the "state affairs fund" case, but prosecutors decided to impose an overseas travel ban on him after he admitted Thursday that he lied about the campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004 and that his wife had wired surplus campaign contributions to overseas bank accounts.

Chen's confession came only after the Ministry of Foreign Affairs confirmed earlier that same day that Swiss authorities have sought Taiwan's help in a probe into a possible money laundering case in Switzerland involving Chen's son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.

Chu and his two colleagues searched Chen's home and office and questioned the former first couple Saturday to look into whether there were any links between the "state affairs fund" misuse case and the suspected money-laundering case.
According to Chu's three-member team, Saturday's operations were fruitful.

It was found that Chen had a total of four undisclosed bank accounts to receive political contributions for the 2000 and 2004 presidential elections -- three for the 2000 election and one for the 2004 election, the team said in a statement.
All of the four accounts were opened in Chen's name, but their cash flows were handled by his wife, according to the team.

It further revealed that the total sum of inbound and outbound cash flows involving the four accounts reached several hundreds of millions of New Taiwan dollars and that many inbound remittances were worth NT$10 million each. During the 2004 presidential campaign, Chen's secret account received a remittance of NT$50 million in cash. Prosecutors said they are tracking the source of the fund.

Initial investigations of all of Chen's bank accounts opened for his two legislative elections, two mayoral elections and two presidential elections also found that Wu Shu-jen had not only used her own bank account but also often used the accounts of her husband, son, daughter, son-in-law and daughter-in-law as well as her elder brother Wu Ching-mao for money transfers. Prosecutors said they will summon all of them for questioning to clarify the purposes of the money transactions.
Moreover, prosecutors said Wu Ching-mao might be the former first couple's figurehead in cross-border money transfers.

Chou Wen-hsiang, a prosecutor from the Tainan District Prosecutors Office, searched Wu Ching-mao's home in Tainan County's Matou township in southern Taiwan Saturday for three hours and seized a collection of documents and data, including a computer, for further analysis.
As Wu Ching-mao was not at home Saturday, Chu's team said it will summon him Monday for questioning.

Meanwhile, Chu said his team questioned the former first couple at their Taipei home mainly because of Wu Shu-jen's health. According to Chu, Wu's condition is not suitable for formal interrogations at the moment.

Wu has been paralyzed from waist down and confined to a wheelchair since she was hit by a truck in 1985. She attended only the first court hearing of the "state affairs fund" misuse case and has since failed to appear in court to answer the charges on grounds of ill-health.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 17, or the 17th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1424: The English defeat the Scots and the French at the Battle of Verneuil during the Hundred Years' War.
1786: Davy Crockett, American frontiersman and politician, is born. He was a U.S. representative from Tennessee who joined with Texan revolutionaries fighting against Mexico. He died at the siege of the Alamo in 1836.
1892: Mae West, American comedy actress and international sex symbol known for her sultry stage persona during the 1930s, is born. She wrote most of her own stage productions and film scripts.
1896: A massive influx of prospectors to the Yukon Territory of Canada is expected after the discovery of a major gold field at Bonanza Creek on the Klondike River.
1896: The first pedestrian to be killed by a car is knocked down in Croydon, England, by a car traveling at just 6.4 kilometers per hour.
1908: The world's first animated cartoon premiers in Paris.
1943: U.S. forces under Gen. George S. Patton liberate Messina, Italy, arriving just hours ahead of Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army.
1945: After the end of Japanese occupation, Indonesia declares itself a republic under the leadership of Dr. Sukarno.
1946: After ordering Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the government on Aug. 11, 1945, the communist Yenan General Headquarters issues a second mobilization order instructing all communist forces to launch a full- scale war against the Nationalists.
1960: Gabon gains independence from France.
1961: The polio vaccine developed by American researcher Albert B. Sarbin is approved for use in the United States.
1975: Europe's first particle accelerator is formally inaugurated in Geneva, Switzerland.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Mindanao in the Philippines, killing some 8,000 people.
1982: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement urging the United States to recognize Beijing's ambitious attempt to take over Taiwan, following the issue of the "Aug. 17 Joint Communique" by the United States and mainland China. The ministry also asks the United States to implement the Taiwan Relations Act.
1987: Rudolf Hess, Adolf Hitler's close friend and deputy leader of the Nazi party, commits suicide in his cell in Spandau Prison in West Berlin at the age of 93.
1988: Gen. Zia ul-Haq, Pakistan's iron-fisted ruler for the previous 11 years, dies at the age of 64 when his camouflaged C-130 Hercules plane crashes shortly after takeoff from Bahawalpur.
1989: An Australian airliner becomes the first commercial plane to fly nonstop from London to Sydney.
1993: The ROC and Australia sign two memoranda, one protecting industrial property rights and the second promoting investment and technical cooperation.
1995: A French supersonic jetliner completes a round-the-globe trip in 31 hours 27 minutes and 49 seconds, faster than the previous record by one hour and 20 minutes.
1995: ROC Control Yuan President Chen Li-an announces his candidacy for the 1996 presidential election, one day before renouncing his KMT membership, which he has held for 42 years.
2000: Chen Yi-song, leader of the Agriculture Technical Mission to the Republic of the Gambia, says that ROC agriculture technologists have transformed the Gambia River basin, which used to yield nothing but peanuts, into the "rice bowl of West Africa" over a period of five years.
2001: Taiwan's two major paper makers -- Yuen Foong Yu Paper and Chung Hwa Pulp -- sign a merger agreement and promise that there will be no layoffs in the new company.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you learn, but once learning a thing, you must never give it up until you have mastered it."

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma attends inauguration of Dominican president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou, who is in the Dominican Republic to attend the inauguration of President Leonel Fernandez, demonstrated diplomatic skills by interacting with some of the heads of state at the event.

Ma, who was accompanied by Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou and National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi, arrived 10 minutes earlier at the Parliament where the ceremony was held. He was escorted to his seat area to be placed between El Salvador President Antonio Saca on the right and Chilean President Michelle Bachelet on the left.
Given the fact that the official attire of the Dominican Republic is white, all heads of state attending the ceremony were dressed in white suit with black tie and shoes.
Prior to his departure from the hotel to the inauguration venue, Ma replied a reporters question on whether he is comfortable wearing the white suit, saying thatSi (yes).
This is my second time wearing white suit but I am quite comfortable in it,he added.

Ma, who sat at the second seat of the first row, exchanged greetings with Haitian President Rene Preval and Honduras President Manuel Zelaya upon arrival, who came to the Caribbean country by taking Mas charter flight from Paraguay after attending the inauguration of Paraguayan President Fernando Lugo.
The inauguration commenced with the singing of the national anthem of the Dominican Republic in Spanish.

Fernandez began his inauguration speech by thanking the 14 heads of state present for attending the ceremony. Ma was the second to be named by Fernandez, who addressed him ashis Excellency of the Republic of China Taiwan.
The new government will achieve a new economy situation, while will be more stable,he pledged in the speech.

Facing mounting pressure to steer the Dominican Republic clear of a deep economic slump threatening much of the Caribbean, analysts say Fernandezs deft handling of the economy, and his ability to pull it out of the sever crisis he inherited in 2004, were key to the victory of the New York-raised lawyer and academic in his re-election in May, according to a Reuters report.
But Fernandez has since been coping with fallout from the stumbling U.S. economy and high global oil and food prices.
Fernandez was sworn in for a third term in office on Saturday, a date also coincides with the celebration of the Restoration of the nations independence.

Other heads of state who have confirmed their attendance are Alvaro Uribe of Colombia, Oscar Arias of Costa Rica, Martin Torrijos of Panama, Spanish Crown Prince Felipe de Borbon and Prime Minister Dean Barrow of Belize.
However, the presence of Venezuelan leader Hugo Chavez was prevented due to the poor weather of a tropical storm, according to the countrys ambassador Francisco Belisario Landis on Saturday morning.
Ma, who is in his first state visit to South America and the Caribbean, will attend the religious ceremony of Fernandezs inauguration at 1: 00 p.m. local time and hold bilateral talks with Saca.
He will leave the Dominican Republic on Sunday and is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Aug. 19.
