DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan should accelerate deregulation of laws: top economic planner

TEXT.P: Taiwan should accelerate moves to deregulate many of the rules and polices that have dragged down the country's international competitiveness, the head of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Sunday.

CEPD Chairman Chen Tain-jy said the council might suggest the establishment of an independent agency to be exclusively responsible for deregulation of laws and policies to help raise Taiwan's competitiveness on the global economic and trade fronts.

Speaking to the media for the first time since he returned to Taiwan from a ministerial meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum held in Australia recently, Chen said there are many laws and regulations that must be relaxed or liberalized in order to meet the needs of the public and private sectors in terms of efficient growth and sustainable development.
"Taiwan is lagging far behind in deregulation efforts in comparison with other major economies in the Asia-Pacific region, " he said.
"Delegates of more than 20 nations have devoted their talks during the meeting to deregulation of business and trade laws, " he added.
Of the APEC economies, he said, Australia began the earliest -- in 1993 -- to deregulate laws so that barriers could be removed to raise its international marketing competitiveness.
South Korea followed in 1998, relaxing business and trade restrictions and removing barrier regulations, Chen continued.
In South Korea, an independent agency exists immediately under the prime minister's office to be in charge of deregulating irrational or outdated laws and mapping out new ones, he noted.

According to the CEPD, Cabinet-level agencies in this country have put forth 67 items waiting to be deregulated by the end of this year, while 142 other deregulation issues are expected to be discussed next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan medical aid team leaves for West Indies ally

TEXT.P: A mobile medical team organized by the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) departed for the country's West Indies diplomatic ally St. Lucia Sunday to launch a free medical service mission.

The nine-member team organized by the ICDF under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is expected to provide medical care and exchange views with medical professionals there on clinical experiences and techniques during its stay of between two and three weeks, the ICDF reported.

The team, composed of surgeons, physicians, pharmacists and nurses from Changhua Christian Hospital, the Chi Mei Foundation Medical Center and Mackay Memorial Hospital, will be serving at the St. Jude Hospital and Community Hospital located in southern St. Lucia.
Team members will also travel to Victoria Hospital in the north for clinical exchanges with doctors there, according to the ICDF.

In addition, the ICDF said, a doctor of traditional Chinese medicine has joined the team for the first time to promote traditional Chinese medication and therapies, including acupuncture and cupping, to the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei city, county guard against dengue fever outbreak

TEXT.P: The health agencies of the Taipei city and county governments are carrying on preventive measures against dengue fever following the confirmation of two recent indigenous cases in the Shilin district of the northern city.
In addition, three other dengue cases have been reported in the same district, said city government official Chen Cheng-cheng Sunday.

The city government has dispatched staff to implement indoor and outdoor mosquito insecticide spraying in areas within 200 meters of buildings with dengue fever cases, while conducting outdoor spraying in 10 boroughs near the areas, to reduce the numbers of mosquitoes in the district.
The two confirmed cases involve two residents of Shilin, while the other three involve people who had visited the district, according to Chen.

Meanwhile, the Taipei county government also ordered insecticide spraying in Jenyi, Jenchung, Wufu and Fukuei boroughs in Sanchung City, which are adjacent to Shilin district, although the Breteau index of dengue vector mosquito density there was zero.
The Breteau index, defined as the number of positive water containers for mosquito larvae, is a relatively sensitive indicator of transmission.

Chen added that health officials in the greater Taipei area have also been conducting an investigation into mosquito larvae breeding in the district and nearby boroughs in an effort to monitor and control the mosquito-born disease.
Dengue fever is transmitted to humans by infected Aedes albo pictus mosquito larvae, which mainly breed in containers holding stagnant water.

Chen urged residents in the greater Taipei area to strengthen efforts in cleaning up environmental black spots and eliminating standing water in water storage containers, such as flower pots, water buckets and discarded tires, to prevent mosquitoes from breeding.
He also reminded those who develop early symptoms of dengue fever, such as fever, joint pain and skin rash, to immediately seek medical treatment.

As part of efforts to prevent an outbreak of dengue fever, Taipei City residents who have received notification are required to open their doors so that cleaning personnel can spray insecticide inside their homes. Those who refuse will face fines ranging from NT$60,000 (US$1,950) to NT$300,000, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bicycle craze leads to calls for greater cyclists' rights, safety

TEXT.P: At an Aug. 2 bicycling event in Kaohsiung, Bai Yue, in his 20s, explained one important benefit he'd received from the activity: a new girlfriend. Bai met the young woman, Tzi Lin, through a folding bike blog, and they began going on dates together to biking events.
Now, the two are a couple. Both attended the Kaohsiung event, where more than 5,000 people turned out to tour two new bicycle paths.

Bai and Lin are among an estimated 600,000 bicycling enthusiasts nationwide, nearly double the 330,000 in 2006, according to a recent report released by the Council for Economic Planning and Development. Bicycle sales have shot up, as Taiwanese flock to enjoy the health and recreation benefits of the sport.
The fad has gotten a further boost with skyrocketing fuel prices, which have made bicycles an attractive, cheaper option to traveling by car or scooter.

Now, with Taiwan's love affair with the bicycle in full bloom, cities and counties are scrambling to meet cyclists' demands for more racks, bike paths and dedicated lanes on city streets. But cyclists say more needs to be done -- especially in the area of safety -- to make Taiwan a truly bicycle-friendly nation.

Asked in a survey conducted by Chinese Cultural University earlier in the year, cyclists cite bicycles being a "symbol of freedom, " helping conserve energy, reducing pollution and the number of cars on the road, and staying physically fit.

The growing popularity of recreational cycling can be seen in the many bicycle tour events in the past few months -- such as Kaohsiung's folding bike event in May -- which now attract hundreds or even thousands of people.

A survey released by the Taipei City government earlier this month showed that the number of city residents who rode bikes increased to 10.5 percent of the population in July, up from 6 percent in May. The city expects that if fuel prices increase another 30 percent, ridership will further rise to 16.5 percent.

Capitalizing on the current bicycle fad, Taiwan's Giant Inc, the world's largest Taiwan-based bicycle manufacturer, sold 140,000 bikes in Taiwan in the first half of the year, 40% more than in the same period last year.
The company's revenue for the first half of this year soared 60 percent to NT$1 billion (US$32 million) , according to company spokeswoman Irene Chen.
She said that Giant expects the number of cyclists to continue growing, hitting some 700,000 by the end of the year.

Governments are trying to keep up with the challenges presented by surging number of bicyclists demanding better facilities and rights. The central government announced Aug. 7 a plan to add more dedicated lanes alongside major city streets nationwide to better meet cyclists' needs.

In the pilot phase, the central government plans to add dedicated bicycle lanes to Taipei's Dunhua Road. According to the plan, the lanes will be two to 2.5 meters wide and separated from motor vehicle lanes by flexible plastic pylons.
The next stage of the plan will see Kaohsiung and Taichung cities add bicycle lanes to other major city thoroughfares.
The plan has already sparked complaints from motorcyclists, who already dodge cars, trucks and buses in heavy traffic on roads like Dunhua Road.

Chen Chin-pi, a white-collar employee, at the age of 45, who commutes daily by scooter from Zhonghe to his office in downtown Taipei, said there are more motorcyclists than bicyclists in Taiwan, and that the government should protect motorcyclists' rights, too.
Chen suggested that the government develop more bike routes rather than adding bike paths, which will take away space from already-crowded traffic lanes.
The controversial bike-lane plan comes after local governments have already added hundreds of kilometers of new bicycle trails, and thousands of new bicycle racks.
By the end of 2007, the central government had built 40 dedicated bicycle paths totalling more than 1,180 kilometers. It hopes to build a total of 2,600 kilometers of paths by 2011.

Taipei City and Taipei county now have more than 500 kilometers of dedicated bike paths. Taipei city provides 16,000 racks for parking bicycles, including 1,100 double-decker racks outside MRT stations. The city hopes to add bike parking with lockers to further help cyclists.

Kaohsiung City, the second largest city in Taiwan, now has more than 100 kilometers of bike trails, and hopes to have a total of 180 kilometers built the opening of the World Games in Kaohsiung next summer.
With the cycling boom has come increased concerns about more accidents.
According to a survey commissioned by the Department of Health, every years sees an average of 3,700 injuries from cyclists, with 3 percent to 5 percent of them fatal.

It's not yet clear how much mishaps are on the rise with the nationwide fad, but Tainan City statistics showed bicycle accidents in the southern city spiking 24.4 percent in the first half of this year as compared with the same period of last year.

The health department survey showed that the main cause of accidents was cyclist error, chiefly not yielding right-of-way to motorists or disobeying other traffic rules. Poor road design and bad visibility at night were also cited as main causes.
To keep accident numbers down, cyclists suggested in a recent interview with CNA that the government should create more dedicated bike lanes, as it already plans in Taipei, Kaohsiung and Taichung.

David Reid, in his 30s, a cycling enthusiast and Taipei County resident, said that there are plenty of recreational bicycle paths outside city centers, but that doesn't solve the problems many city commuters face.
He said the government should enact policies to reduce cars on the road, but did not give details.

However, Chang Ming-yuan, a 42-year-old cyclist and jouranlist covering transportation issues, said the goal could be reached by pushing forward car sharing schemes -share a ride with a colleague at work or rotate with other parents on school runs-- or designating a national car-free day.

Some cyclists also suggested that the government require all bicycles sold in Taiwan to meet higher safety requirements -- for example, by requiring that all bicycles have both front and rear reflectors.
They also advised the government to better enforce traffic rules and promote awareness of proper road use among cyclists.
For example, all cyclists are supposed to ride the same direction as traffic, and use hand signals to indicate when they are slowing, stopping or turning.
Cyclists also emphasized that all riders should wear helmets, to prevent sometimes fatal head injuries resulting from bicycle accidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Dominican Republic to work on FTA

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou and Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez agreed Saturday that the two countries will begin to push for the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) to consolidate bilateral economic exchanges.

In a reception with the media during his first state visit to the Dominican Republic to attend the inauguration of President Leonel Fernandez, Ma said he suggested that the two sides sign an FTA as soon as possible, noting that concrete results were observed immediately after Taiwan' s singing of FTAs with El Salvador and Honduras.

"I also proposed that Taiwan and the Dominican Republic should hold an annual economic cooperation seminar, " Ma said, adding that such a mechanism will not only expand economic relations but also better monitor bilateral cooperation.
Taiwan has FTAs with only five developing countries -- Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Panama and Guatemala -- all of which are the country's diplomatic allies.
Fernandez said that his country not only want to develop diplomatic relations with Taiwan but also to strengthen bilateral economic and investment relations.
"We don't want to always be the country receiving aid but hope to develop our trade relations (with other countries)," he was quoted as saying by Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi.
Describing the talks between Ma and Fernandez as "in-depth," Wang told reporters that the two also discussed Ma's proposal of a "diplomatic truce" with China.

He said Fernandez made very "insightful observations" regarding the issue, saying that he "understands" such change given the fact that cross-Taiwan Strait relations are different from what they used to be.

The frosty relations between Taiwan and China have been thawing since Ma took office May 20, with his proposal of a "diplomatic truce" aimed at terminating the longstanding diplomatic tug-of-war with China in which both countries try to lure each other's allies into switching diplomatic allegiance by offering large sums of money in foreign aid to developing countries.
Ma also touted the strategy of "modus vivendi" or "pragmatic diplomacy" aimed at leveraging more international space for Taiwan.
Prior to the meeting with Fernandez, Ma also held bilateral talks with El Salvador President Antonio Saca and Haitian President Rene Preval.
During those meetings, Ma and Saca discussed Taiwan's bids to participate in international organizations, as well as bilateral economic exchanges.
"Taiwan's (U.N. membership) bid this time is more low-profile and I believe the results will be better," Ma said.
In response, Saca pledged to support Taiwan's bid.

Taiwan's proposal this year, emphasizing the importance of the country's "meaningful participation" in U.N. specialized agencies, was submitted to the U.N. Secretariat Aug. 15 by representatives of St. Vincent and the Grenadines and the Solomon Islands, two diplomatic allies of the Republic of China, at the request of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The proposal marks a fresh approach by the government in pushing for greater participation in international organizations for Taiwan.

The previous DPP administration applied in 2007 to join the U.N. as a full member under the name Taiwan, the first time it had tried under that name. However, that proposal failed to make the agenda of the U.N. General Assembly, just as the previous ones since 1993 also failed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's new scandal reminds people of Marcos: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday in the Dominican Republic that he feels sorry about a scandal in which ex-president Chen Shui-bian is accused of depositing large sums of cash in overseas bank accounts, as it is disgraceful and reminds people of Ferdinand Marcos, the corrupt ex-president-dictator of the Philippines.

He made the remarks in a reception with the media during his first state visit to South America and the Caribbean to attend the inaugurations of Paraguayan President Fernando Lugo Aug. 15 and Dominican Republic Leonel Fernandez Aug. 16.
Noting that both Haitian President Rene Preval and Spanish Crown Prince Felipe de Borbon asked him about the scandal, Ma said he was too ashamed to talk about it.
"It is difficult to talk about the incident because it is so disgraceful, " he said, adding that "it reminds people of the former president of the Philippines, Ferdinand Marcos."

Marcos, who served as president of the Philippines from 1965 to 1986, was forced out of office in 1986 in a massive nonviolent protest known as the People Power Movement. His authoritarian regime is remembered for its rampant corruption at the highest levels of government.

Chen admitted Thursday that he lied about the campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004 and that his wife wired surplus campaign contributions into overseas bank accounts.

Chen's confession came only after the Ministry of Foreign Affairs confirmed earlier that same day that the Swiss authorities have sought Taiwan's help in a probe into a possible money laundering case in Switzerland involving Chen's son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.
The former president claimed that his wife Wu Shu-jen made the transactions without his knowledge.

Wu was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million (US$472,843) from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.

Chen, who was named as a co-defendant in the case but enjoyed immunity from prosecution while in office, began to be questioned shortly after he stepped down from the presidency May 20 but has not yet been indicted.
Prosecutors who searched Chen's home and office in Taipei earlier Saturday for evidence in connection with the case, said Chen has been prohibited from leaving the country.

Asked if the government should have had taken action against Chen Chih-chung given the fact that he is also involved in the case but has already left the country, Ma said he did not think that anyone had the right to prohibit him from leaving the country at that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: President receives Santo Domingo city keys

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou was given the keys Saturday to the city of Santo Domingo -- the capital of the Dominican Republic -- after attending the inauguration of Dominican President Leonel Fernandez earlier that day.
The ceremony commenced with the singing of the national anthems of both the Republic of China and the Dominican Republic.

After receiving the keys from Roberto Salcedo, mayor of Santo Domingo, Ma expressed his gratitude in Spanish, saying that he was glad to come to the Caribbean country but was sorry that he had only learned Spanish for four hours so could not speak much of the language.
"I hope President Ma will never have to use the keys, as the door of Santo Domingo is always open to him and the people of the ROC, " Salcedo said.
Noting that he also conferred city keys to various heads of state when he was Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006, Ma said this is the first time he has received the honor from another mayor.

The president said he used to tell the recipients of the Taipei City keys that they can get 20 percent discount at any department store in Taipei as long as they bring the ceremonial key with them and asked Salcedo if he would get the same treatment.
Salcedo replied that he can have a 15 percent discount, a statement that drew laughter.
On behalf of Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, Ma also invited Salcedo to visit Taipei and said that he will ask Hau to visit Santo Domingo to strengthen bilateral exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: MJIB ex-chief admits failure to pass on information

TEXT.P: A former chief of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) admitted his failure Saturday to convey information about suspected money laundering involving members of the former first family to the prosecution before his retirement.

Yeh Sheng-mao confessed to his mistake amid media reports that the MJIB's Money Laundering Prevention Center received information from the Cayman Islands in late January that former President Chen Shui-bian's daughter-in-law Huang Jui- ching had a bank account there, probably for money laundering purposes. The local prosecution, however, was not informed of the intelligence until recently by the Ministry of Justice (MOJ).

Yeh, who retired from the top MJIB post after the inauguration of the Kuomintang government in May, confirmed in a written statement that he did not deliver any formal documents concerning the sensitive information to the prosecution before his retirement because of what he claimed was his "personal negligence."
But he argued that he verbally informed State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming of the intelligence in a meeting in early February.

"At the time, Chen Tsung-ming said that if no concrete evidence was available, the MJIB could deal with it on its own. Therefore, I did not pass the formal document to him," Yeh said in the statement.
In the ensuing months, Yeh recalled that the issue was shelved because of the approach of the March 22 presidential election.

After the election, in which the former president's Democratic Progressive Party suffered a resounding defeat, Yeh said he was preoccupied with retirement formalities and thus did not bother to address the issue.

Claiming that he directed the Money Laundering Prevention Center to maintain contact with the source of the intelligence, Yeh said the issue was not tackled before his retirement, partly because no further information had been received from the Cayman Islands source.
Meanwhile, Yeh denied allegations that he leaked the information to the former first family and insisted that he kept the information confidential and did not expose it to anybody else.
Yeh also apologized to the public, the MOJ and MJIB staff and Chen Tsung-ming for his "personal negligence" in handling the matter.
Responding to Yeh's argument, Chen Tsung-ming denied that he had ever been briefed by Yeh on the sensitive information and he urged Yeh to face up to his own mistake squarely.

The prosecution did not get the information until after Swiss authorities recently sought Taiwan's help in a probe into another possible money laundering case in Switzerland involving the former president's son Chen Chih-chung and his wife Huang Jui-ching, both of whom left Taiwan Aug. 9, probably for the United States.
The suspected money laundering case adds to the former president's legal woes, as he is already battling charges that he misused public funds.

Prosecutors have barred Chen Shui-bian from leaving the country pending further investigations into his suspected roles in the "state affairs fund" embezzlement case and the alleged money laundering case.

Meanwhile, prosecutors investigating the suspected money laundering case said they will summon Yeh for questioning later this month to determine whether he breached any laws by failing to pass on the confidential information from the Cayman Islands to the prosecution in a timely manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: Diplomatic truce is not dual recognition: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday in the Dominican Republic that his proposal of a "diplomatic truce" with China does not mean that the government is trying to work on a "dual recognition" system.
"I'm not trying to work out `dual recognition, '" Ma said, adding that a "diplomatic truce would be aimed at giving a clear direction" to Taiwan's allies."
Due to the political differences and division between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, China refuses to allow countries to maintain diplomatic ties with both Taiwan and China.

He made the remarks during a reception with the media during his first state visit to South America and the Caribbean to attend the inaugurations of Paraguayan President Fernando Lugo Aug. 15 and Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez Aug. 16.

The frosty relations between Taiwan and China have been thawing since Ma took office May 20, with his proposal of a "diplomatic truce" aimed at terminating the longstanding diplomatic tug-of-war with China in which both countries try to lure each other's allies to switch diplomatic allegiance by offering large sums of money in foreign aid to developing countries.
Ma also touted the strategy of "modus vivendi" or "pragmatic diplomacy," aimed at leveraging more international space for Taiwan.
He also assured Taiwan's allies that such a diplomatic strategy will not have a negative influence and that his administration will continue to strengthen relations with the country's allies.

"There are a lot of people suffering in the world. We have to help them, as that is our responsibility, rather than conducting checkbook diplomacy, " the president said, adding that as long as Taiwan's foreign aid programs have "legitimate objectives, the granting procedures are in accordance with the law and the implementation is effective and efficient."

Asked about his thoughts on his eight-day trip as it approached its end, Ma said that he was "deeply moved" to see both Lugo and Fernandez talk about anti- corruption and bring change to their countries, statements that he said sound like his own words.
"These leaders are very keen to do something and we would like to help, " Ma said. "Seeing their ambition, I also want to offer my sincere blessings to them," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Olympic softball team defeats China 2-1

TEXT.P: Taiwan's women's softball team defeated China 2-1 in a seven-inning match Sunday at the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games, rekindling the team's hope for fifth place in the softball tournament.

Competing under the official name Chinese Taipei, the Taiwanese team earned one run in the top of the first inning after Lo Hsiao-ting reached first base with a two-out hit, rushed third base when the Chinese team made an error, and made it to home base on a hit by teammate Chiang Hui-chuan.

China launched a counterattack in the second inning. After getting to first base with a hit, Wu Di made it to second when teammate Guo Jiaji hit a sacrifice bunt. Another hit by Sun Li sent her to home base to score for a 1-1 tie.

Chinese Taipei scored another run in the fourth inning, leading the game 2-1, after strong hitter Chiang made first base with a hit and then made it to home base when teammate Lu Hsueh-mei followed with another hit. Neither team scored more runs thereafter.
Chinese Taipei used Wu Chia-yen as starting pitcher, who was relieved by Chueh Ming-hui in the bottom of the third. Together, they allowed the opposing team five hits.
China's starting pitcher Yu Huili was replaced by Li Qi in the fifth inning. They allowed Chinese Taipei six hits.
In its four previous matches played Aug. 12-16, Chinese Taipei defeated Venezuela 3-0, but lost to Canada 1-6, to Japan 1-2 and to the United States 0-7.
The Taiwanese softballers will play against the Netherlands at 9:30 a.m. Beijing time Monday.
Mo Cheng, secretary-general of the Chinese Taipei Amateur Softball Association, said the team needs a victory over the Netherlands to secure fifth place.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former representative to Switzerland negligent over fund scandal

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said Saturday in the Dominican Republic that Taiwan's former representative to Switzerland was "not watchful enough" over a fund scandal in which ex-president Chen Shui-bian and his family stand accused of funneling large sums of cash into Swiss bank accounts.
"I think they were lacking in alertness, " Ou said, adding that "incidents of this nature should be dealt with as an emergency."
He made the remarks in the Dominican Republic, where he accompanied President Ma Ying-jeou at the inauguration of Dominican President Leonel Fernandez Aug. 16.
"I think the handling of this matter was not proactive enough, " Ou said.

Asked if the Foreign Ministry will investigate the responsibility of Kuanping George Liu, former Republic of China representative to Switzerland, Ou said that there is no way to do that as Liu has already left his post.
Liu tendered his resignation July 29.

Chen admitted Thursday that he lied about the campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004 and that his wife had wired surplus campaign contributions to overseas bank accounts.

His confession came only after the Foreign Ministry confirmed earlier that same day that the Swiss authorities have sought Taiwan's help in a probe into a possible money laundering case in Switzerland involving Chen's son Chen Chih- chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.
The former president claims that his wife Wu Shu-jen made the wire transfers without his knowledge.

Wu was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million (US$472,843) from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.

Chen, who was named as a co-defendant in the case but enjoyed immunity from prosecution while in office, began to be questioned shortly after he stepped down from the presidency May 20 but has not yet been indicted.
Prosecutors who searched Chen's home and office in Taipei earlier Saturday for evidence in connection with the scandal said Chen has been prohibited from leaving the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors to track sources of ex-president's overseas deposits

TEXT.P: The Supreme Prosecutors Office (SPO) decided Sunday to track the sources of a large sum of cash deposited abroad by former President Chen Shui-bian and his family.

Members of the SPO Special Investigation Division searched Chen's residence and office the day before and questioned Chen and his wife, Wu Shu-jen, on money laundering allegations and their roles in a public fund embezzlement case.

The prosecutors were told by Wu during the questioning that US$21 million deposited in the family's overseas bank accounts was all legal income, including the balance of campaign funds from Chen's two mayoral races and his two presidential campaigns, his income as a lawyer prior to the 1980s, and her own dowry.

Wu said that for the convenience of investing overseas, she asked her elder brother, Wu Ching-mao, and her daughter-in-law, Huang Jui-ching, to open bank accounts in Singapore and Switzerland to facilitate the liquidity of their money.
The prosecutors believe that the sums deposited in the Singaporean and Swiss bank accounts are much larger than the "state affairs fund" that Chen possibly embezzled as president between 2000-2008.

They suspect that the deposits could be bribes that the first couple received from the "second financial reform" drive that was launched during Chen's tenure, in which a number of private banking institutions became major financial operations after merging with publicly run ones.

The deposits could also be bribes that the first couple received from a spate of personnel arrangements and shifts during Chen's tenure, particularly the change of chairmen of major state-run or state-controlled enterprises, according to one of the prosecutors.

"So long as the money was remitted abroad from Taiwan, all the funds' travel routes and who remitted the money can be traced via the international anti-money laundering Egmond Group, even if the remittances were made via offshore banking accounts, " the prosecutor went on.

Chen's wife was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million (US$472,843) from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.
Chen, who was named as a co-defendant in the case but enjoyed immunity from prosecution while in office, began to be questioned shortly after he stepped down from the presidency May 20.

Chen has not yet been indicted over the "state affairs fund" case, but prosecutors decided to impose an overseas travel ban on him after he admitted Aug. 14 that he lied about the campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections and that his wife had wired surplus campaign contributions to overseas bank accounts.

Prosecutor Ching Chi-jen left for Switzerland Aug. 15 to review the accounts under the name of Chen's daughter-in-law at Merrill Lynch Bank after the Federal Department of Justice and Police of the Swiss Confederation requested assistance from Taiwan in a case of suspected money laundering by Chen's son, Chen Chih- chung and his wife Huang Jui-ching, through two Swiss bank accounts.
The prosecutors also searched Wu Ching-mao's home in Tainan, southern Taiwan Saturday and barred him from leaving the country.
The SPO Special Investigation Division planned to send Ching to Singapore in late August to help probe the money laundering allegations.
Meanwhile, Chen Chih-chung and Huang Jui-ching left for the United States Aug. 9, taking their baby daughter and Huang's mother with them.
Huang's mother boarded a flight from New York with the baby Saturday to return to Taiwan.
At the airport, the mother told reporters that Chen Chih-chung will return to Taiwan next week to answer prosecutors' questions. He is currently enrolling at Virginia University's law school.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF chairman to visit Japan Aug. 25

TEXT.P: The top executive of Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , which handles exchanges with China, is scheduled to travel to Japan Aug. 25 to give a series of public speeches on the government's cross-strait policy and the prospects for relations between Taiwan and Japan.

SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung will make the visit at the request of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in an attempt to allay Tokyo's concern over the effects of the warming relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait as a result of President Ma Ying-jeou's more open and liberal policies toward China, according to informed ministry sources.

Japanese government officials and politicians, as well as members of the Taiwanese expatriate community in Japan, will be invited to hear Chiang speak on the development of cross-strait relations and its possible effects on the East Asian region.

Chiang is known for his cordial relations with Japan's political and economic circles. He served at the commercial attache's office of the Republic of China Embassy in Japan for five years from 1967 and continued to work as deputy head of the office for two years after Japan broke diplomatic ties with Taipei in 1972.

DOC.HEADLINE: No IBAF decision on Taiwanese hitter's doping test result
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/17/08 18:56:18 (By Wu Hsieh-chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The International Baseball Federation (IBAF) sponsored a hearing in Beijing Sunday on a positive doping test result of Chang Tai-shan, one of Taiwan's best hitters.

The IBAF did not announce a resolution after the hearing, and demanded that Chang provide further medical data as evidence to back his claim that he was taking male fertility pills rather than banned substances.
Chang said at the hearing that he had been taking male fertility pills but stopped using the medication before competing in the Olympics.
He issued a statement after the hearing apologizing to Taiwan for having damaged the image of the Chinese Taipei Olympic team because of the doping test controversy.

The Chinese Taipei Olympic baseball team decided Aug. 13 to appeal to the World Anti-Doping Agency -- commissioned by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to conduct a urine test on Taiwanese baseball players after the test result of Chang's urine tube A, collected July 27, was confirmed positive for doping Aug. 12, one day before Taiwan opened the Olympic baseball tournament against the Netherlands.
Chang, who was dismayed by the test result, denied taking any banned substances and said he followed his doctor's instructions for taking his fertility medication.
Chang, who has no children after being married for nine years, is the only member of the baseball team whose urine test result was positive.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Investigation Bureau chief suspected of withholding information

TEXT.P: A former head of the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice is facing investigation over his alleged concealment of information about suspected money laundering by former President Chen Shui-bian and his family.

Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng told reporters Sunday that she had presented all related information for the Taipei Public Prosecutors Office to investigate whether former Investigation Bureau Director Yeh Sheng-mao should be prosecuted.
The issue arose last week as new evidence emerged about the former president and his wife using their daughter-in-law to transfer large amounts of money through two Swiss bank accounts.

Chou Yu-yi, director of the Investigation Bureau's Money Laundering Prevention Center, confirmed that he had transferred intelligence from the Cayman Islands, located in the Western Caribbean, about a bank account held by a firm set up by the former president's son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.
According to Chou, although he reminded Yeh repeatedly about the vital information, Yeh did nothing.

Yeh issued a statement late Saturday in which he admitted that he had failed to send the written information to State Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung- ming, but claimed that he had made an oral report to Chen -- a claim that the prosecutor-general strongly denied.
If Yeh is found by the court to have concealed the vital information, he could face five years in prison.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign gourmets choose braised pork rice as top local delicacy

TEXT.P: Braised pork rice was picked as the tastiest Taiwanese dish by 10 gourmets from five countries and regions at a food tasting event held in Taipei Saturday.

The event was held as part of the 2008 Taiwan Culinary Exhibition in which the 10 gourmets from Japan, South Korea, the U.S., Europe, Hong Kong, Malaysia and Singapore were invited to taste and select their favorite Taiwanese delicacies.
In an effort to promote Taiwan's food industry internationally in a systematic way, the event organizers came up with 34 dishes recommended by local governments around the country for the tasting.
Braised pork rice provided by Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan was named as the favorite by all the testers apart from those from the U.S. and Europe.

The Japanese gourmets picked dantsu noodles (Tainan City) , braised pork rice (Kaohsiung City) and turkey rice (Chiayi City) as their favorites. The Koreans chose "pot-edge" noodle soup (Keelung City), braised pork rice and wonton soup (Hualien County), the U.S. and European connoisseurs selected beef noodles (Taipei City), while the gourmets from Hong Kong, Singapore and Malaysia picked dantsu noodles, braised pork rice and beef noodles as their favorites.

Among 27 sweet snacks selected for the tasting, taro ice (Taichung County) , mango and milk ice (Taipei City) and Taiwanese fruit ice cream (recently developed by the Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training) were picked as their favorite sweet snacks by the gourmets from Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore and Malaysia.
While Korean experts picked Taiwanese fruit ice cream, the U.S. and European gourmets chose taro ice as their favorite.

French gourmet Alain Cirelli, a chef and owner of a restaurant in France, said that it was the first time he had tasted Taiwanese food and that he believes Taiwanese delicacies will be accepted by foreign tourists visiting the country through information sharing and promotional campaigns.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutor probing ex-president's scandal returns from Switzerland

TEXT.P: A prosecutor who traveled to Lausanne, Switzerland Aug. 12 to render Taiwan's assistance to Swiss prosecutors in their investigation of suspicious money laundering involved former President Chen Shui-bian returned to Taipei Sunday night.

Ching Chi-jen, a leading prosecutor from the Taiwan District Prosecutors Office, told journalists on her return to the Taoyuan International Airport that she has brought some documents to her Swiss counterparts.

She refused to reveal what documents she had passed over to Swiss prosecutors Edmond Ottinger and Luc Leimgruber saying only that it included an indictment against former first lady Wu Shui-jen on the charge of corruption and forgery.

Wu was charged in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million (US$472,843) from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.

Ching said she also asked the two Swiss prosecutors to provide to Taiwan authorities the information they had gathered in their investigation into the funds stashed in the two accounts opened by Chen's daughter-in-law Huang Jui- ching with the Merrill Lynch Bank in Geneva.
The prosecutor said her Swiss counterparts responded to her request "positively", but she didn't elaborate on it.
Ching said she hoped a regular judicial assistance system could be set up between Taipei and Swiss through their cooperation in probing the case.

Ching also said she had requested the Swiss authorities to hand the funds in Huang's bank accounts, reported to be about US$21 million, to Taiwan authorities if they are the illegal gains of Chen Shui-bian.
Chen admitted on Aug. 14 that his wife had wired abroad an unspecified amount of money that he has received as campaign contributions during his four races for public offices.
He claimed the wire transfer were made without his knowledge, and he learned of it only early this year.

Chen made the statement hours after a legislator claimed that Swiss prosecutors Ottinger and Leimgruber had asked Taiwan authorities to help verify the origin of a huge amount of funds in Huang Jui-ching's bank accounts.
Chen's announcement added to his legal woes, as he is already battling charges that he colluded with his wife in misusing the "state affairs fund."
The prosecution in Taiwan is looking into the allegation that Chen and his wife are engaging in money laundering through bank accounts owned by their daughter- in-law.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 18, or the 18th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1227: The Mongol ruler Genghis Khan, who through conquest created a vast empire that extended from the Pacific to the Dnieper River, dies after falling from his horse. He was 65.
1503: Pope Alexander VI, originally Rodrigo Borgia, Spanish-born pontiff since 1492, dies in Rome at the age of 72 after succumbing to a fever. He was noted as a patron of the arts and for his corrupt papacy.
1759: The British led by Adm. Boscowen defeat a French fleet at Lagos, Portugal.
1825: Scottish explorer Alexander Gordon Laing becomes the first European to reach Timbuktu, located in present-day Mali.
1830: Franz-Joseph I, the Austro-Hungarian emperor who invaded Serbia and helped initiate World War 1, is born.
1917: Casper Weinberger, American statesman and secretary of defense for President Ronald Reagan, is born.
1932: Scottish aviator Jim Mollison makes the first westbound transatlantic solo flight, from Portmarnock, Ireland, to Pennfield, New Brunswick.
1945: Henry Pu Yi steps down as emperor of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed in China by the Japanese in 1932. He was nabbed by Russian troops two days later.
1946: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, declares that he had written a memo to President Franklin D. Roosevelt asking the president not to use the atomic bomb against Japan.
1966: Some one million Red Guards hold a huge demonstration in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in celebration of the "great proletarian cultural revolution" launched by Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong.
1974: Taiwan baseball teams for the first time win the Little League, Senior League and Big League world titles in the same year.
1984: South Africa is banned from taking part in the Olympic Games because of its policy of apartheid.
1985: A ship sinks near Harbin in northeastern China, leaving 171 people dead or missing.
1987: Terrorists throw grenades into the Congress of Sri Lanka, killing two people and injuring 16 others, including Prime Minister Ranasinghe Premadasa.
1988: The Mainland Affairs Task Force is established under the Republic of China Executive Yuan.
1989: Colombian presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan is assassinated. The Colombian government takes immediate action by launching a nationwide crackdown on drug dealers.
1991: Vice President Li Yuan-zu of the Republic of China leaves for a state visit to Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Honduras and to attend the 23rd Plenary Meeting of the World League for Freedom and Democracy in San Jose, Costa Rica.
1992: The Department of Anti-Corruption is established under the ROC Ministry of Justice.
1994: An earthquake rocks the Mascara region of western Algeria, killing more than 120 people.
1995: A referendum is held in Bermuda, with 73 percent of the voters in the British dependency voting against independence.
1997: Typhoon Winnie hits Taiwan, killing some 40 people and injuring 81 others.
2000: The Paraguayan embassy in Taipei requests that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs lift an import ban on beef from Paraguay, saying that there have been no cases of foot-and-mouth disease reported among the country's livestock.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you inquire into, but when you inquire into a thing, you must never give it up until you have thoroughly understood it."

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutor probing ex-president scandal returns from Switzerland

TEXT.P: A prosecutor who traveled to Lausanne, Switzerland Aug. 12 to render Taiwan's assistance to Swiss prosecutors in their investigation of possible money laundering involving former President Chen Shui-bian returned to Taipei Sunday night.

Ching Chi-jen, a leading prosecutor from the Taiwan District Prosecutors Office, told journalists on arrival at the Taoyuan International Airport that she took some documents to her Swiss counterparts.

She declined to reveal what documents she handed over to Swiss prosecutors Edmond Ottinger and Luc Leimgruber, saying only that they included an indictment against former first lady Wu Shui-jen on charges of corruption and forgery.

Wu was indicted in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million (US$472,843) from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.

Ching said she also asked the two Swiss prosecutors to provide the Taiwan authorities with the information they had gathered in their investigation into a case of funds stashed in two accounts opened by Chen's daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching at the Merrill Lynch Bank in Switzerland.
The prosecutor said her Swiss counterparts responded to her request "positively", but she did not elaborate on the nature of their response.
Ching said she hoped a regular judicial assistance system could be set up between Taiwan and Switzerland through their cooperation in probing the current case.

Ching also said she has requested the Swiss authorities to hand over to Taiwan authorities the funds in Huang's bank accounts, reported to be about US$21 million, if it is found that the money was obtained illegally by Chen Shui-bian.
Chen admitted on Aug. 14 that his wife had wired abroad an unspecified amount of money that he had received as campaign contributions during his four bids for election to public office.
He claimed the wire transfers were made without his knowledge, and that he learned of them only this year.

Chen made the statement hours after a legislator claimed that Swiss prosecutors Ottinger and Leimgruber had asked Taiwan authorities to help verify the origins of a huge amount of money in Huang Jui-ching's bank accounts.
Chen's announcement added to his legal woes, as he is already battling charges that he colluded with his wife in misusing the "state affairs fund."

DOC.HEADLINE: Tropical Storm Nuri likely to hit Taiwan: CWB

TEXT.P: Tropical Storm Nuri, forming east of the Philippines Monday morning, is likely to affect Taiwan by the end of the week, the Central Weather Bureau said.
A more accurate forecast on the scope of Nuri's impact on Taiwan will be available by Thursday, according to the bureau.
Wu Teh-jung, head of the bureau's Weather Forecast Center, said the weather system is moving in the direction of Taiwan and is expected to continue to increase in intensity.
Wu said chances are high that it will eventually strike the island and he advised the public to pay close attention.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education ministry holds university, college student affairs workshop

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education kicked off a seminar for university and college student affairs administrators Monday at Hsuan Chuang University to introduce to them the government's current and planned policies on related matters.

Nearly 200 staffers from the Guidelines for the Establishment of Coordinating Centers for Student Affairs, as well as from student affairs offices of higher education institutions around the country, are taking part in the workshop set to run through Aug. 20 at the Hsinchu City-based university.

Speeches by experienced education professionals on various topics, including "promoting student affairs and guidance counseling innovation," "student autonomy and schools' guidance on student self-discipline, "service education theories," and "analysis of intellectual property rights laws," will be given during the three-day symposium.
Various education workers will also share their experience in implementing related policies, with the aim of increasing the participants' professional knowledge, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Patients suffering from hair loss urged to seek treatment earlier

TEXT.P: Seventy percent of patients suffering from hair loss wait for up to one year and spend an average of NT$7,500 (US$246) before seeking treatment, a dermatologist said Monday.
Dermatologist Huang Yao-li of Chang Kung Memorial Hospital cited figures compiled by the Taiwan Dermatological Association, which surveyed 328 patients this year suffering from hair loss.

Huang said that he has seen some young outpatients in their 20s and 30s suffering from hair loss, adding that he knows of three patients who spent around NT$100,000 trying without success to save their hair.

He explained that finding 40 or more strands of hair on the pillow in the morning or losing 50 or more strands during a shampoo are signs of androgenetic alopecia, or male pattern baldness, which he said requires treatment.
He urged people who are bothered by hair loss to see a doctor to determine the cause of the problem.

If the hair loss is due to stress, delaying treatment could result in complete baldness, he warned. If the problem is male pattern baldness, then long-term treatment would be required while the patient is still young, he added.
People who experience hair loss for more than three months should seek treatment, which should start to produce visible results after six months, he suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ to push for legislation against unexplained wealth

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) will push for the enactment of a law that would make it a crime for government officials to hold unexplained wealth, Vice Justice Minister Huang Shih-ming said Monday.

Speaking at a news conference on the MOJ's latest resolutions pertaining to allegations of overseas money laundering involving former President Chen Shui- bian and his family, Huang said many nations have similar laws in place and the MOJ will seek to institute similar legislation so as to widen the net to monitor the illicit flow of money and combat money laundering.

Meanwhile, Huang said, the Justice Ministry will seek to broaden cross-border judicial cooperation with foreign nations, including Switzerland, Singapore and the United States, given that Chen and his wife Wu Shu-jen deposited large sums of cash abroad under the names of their family members.

Wu said last week during questioning at her residence by prosecutors that the US$21 million deposited in the family's various overseas bank accounts was "all legal income." The money is distributed in three accounts -- two in Switzerland held in the names of Chen's daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching and one in Singapore in the name of Wu's brother Wu Ching-mao.

The Justice Ministry is offering a reward of NT$10 million to persons who provide information leading to a break in the case related to the money- laundering allegations against the former first family, Huang said.
The MOJ also urged companies, organizations or individuals who were involved in the alleged money laundering operations to take a moral stance and come forward to help solve the case.

Chen's wife Wu Shu-jen was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million (US$472,843) from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006. Chen, who was named as a co-defendant in the "state affairs fund" case but enjoyed immunity from prosecution while in office, came under questioning shortly after he stepped down from the presidency May 20.

Chen has not been indicted in the "state affairs fund" case, but prosecutors imposed an overseas travel ban on him after he admitted Aug. 14 that he lied about the campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections and that his wife had transferred surplus campaign contributions to overseas bank accounts.

Prosecutor Ching Chi-jen left for Switzerland Aug. 15 to review the accounts under the name of Chen's daughter-in-law at Merrill Lynch Bank after the Federal Department of Justice and Police of the Swiss Confederation requested assistance from Taiwan in a case of suspected money laundering by Chen's son and his daughter-in-law, through two Swiss bank accounts.
Taiwan prosecutors searched Chen and Wu's home over the weekend.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Instant care' program benefiting needy households launched

TEXT.P: A program offering cash subsidies as "instant care" for households close to the poverty line but otherwise ineligible for government assistance was launched Monday.

The program, initiated by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI), is designed to benefit households whose main breadwinners are dead or unaccounted for or who have been jobless due to severe injury or other reasons in recent years, MOI officials said.

Under the program, about 96,000 households involving 290,000 people nationwide are expected to benefit to the tune of NT$10,000-NT$30,000 per family per month from the temporary cash subsidies that are part of the government's efforts to help the disadvantaged cope with inflation triggered by surging oil and commodity prices, according to the officials.
MOI officials said initial funds for the program have already been appropriated to local government offices.
In emergency cases, local offices are encouraged to first deliver NT$5,000 to the households most in need until such time as they can formally apply for the subsidies, the officials went on.
According to MOI tallies, of the 7.6 million households nationwide, the 10 percent at the bottom of the income distribution graph are most in need of government aid.

While 90,000 of these households are classified as low-income families and are already receiving various subsidies from the government, those who are "close to the poverty line" are not given any assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's IC industry production up 4.9% for Q2

TEXT.P: The Taiwan integrated circuit (IC) industry's production reached NT$359.6 billion (US$11.45 billion) for the second quarter of this year, marking an increase of 4.9 percent over the previous quarter, the Industry and Technology Intelligence Services (ITIS) said Monday.

Lee Pei-yin, an analyst at the ITIS, said the primer mover behind the growth was the IC design industry, which saw its preferential market share continue to increase and its production rise by 5.3 percent to NT$96.5 billion for the quarter.

This was followed by the IC testing industry, which experienced growth in production of 4.9 percent to hit NT$25.7 billion, the IC manufacturing industry, up 4.8 percent to NT$178.4 billion, and IC packaging, increasing 4.4 percent to reach NT$59 billion.
IC makers serving the notebook computer industry did not perform as well, as the second quarter is traditionally a slow one for laptop makers, according to Lee.

Lee said the ITIS has forecast that the Taiwan IC industry's production will grow by 14.3 percent in the third quarter to reach NT$411 billion, with IC design leading the way once again with expected growth of a whopping 25.4 percent to hit NT$121 billion.

The ITIS is a technology division of the Ministry of Economic Affairs responsible for strengthening domestic industry competitiveness, assisting in upgrading industry and implementing related service projects.
