DOC.HEADLINE: Prices plunge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 195.76 points to close at 7,000.74.
The local bourse opened at 7,189.68 and fluctuated between 7,213.69 and 6,996.78.
A total of 3.59 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$82.84 billion (US$2.69 billion).

All the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks as well as paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 5.2 percent. Textile stocks declined 5.1 percent, banking and financial shares shed 4.8 percent, construction stocks dropped 4.5 percent, foodstuff issues lost 3.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares shed 2.3 percent, and machinery and electronics shares decreased 2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,959 to 243, with 318 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of shares worth NT$9.09 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese baseball team knocked out of Olympic medal contention

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei baseball team's Olympic medal hopes officially came to a heartbreaking end in Beijing Monday with a 9-8 loss to South Korea in what almost turned into a miracle comeback by the Taiwanese squad.
The South Korean side came out slugging in the top of the first, knocking Chinese Taipei starter Yang Chien-fu around for five hits and seven runs to take a seemingly insurmountable lead.

Ni Fu-te came in at the start of the second to replace the shell-shocked Yang, giving up one run before settling down to keep the Koreans scoreless for the next five innings and give his teammates a chance to mount a comeback.
The Taiwan sluggers responded, picking up a pair of runs in the second before lighting up Korean starter Bong Jungkeun for four runs in the fifth to close the gap to 8-6.

In the sixth, Taiwan was able to put runners on first and second base with only one out on a pair of bases on balls, setting the stage for clean-up hitter Peng Cheng-min's two-run double to tie up the score.

Unfortunately, the Chinese Taipei squad hardly had time to celebrate before the Koreans struck back at the top of the next inning, with Lee Daeho advancing to first on a bases on balls and Lee Jinyoung hitting a single before Kang Minho's RBI single with none out to give Korea a 9-8 lead.

Chinese Taipei saw a glimmer of hope with Lin Chih-sheng's lead-off double to start the bottom of the seventh, but their hopes were quickly dashed with three straight strike outs by the Korean hurlers to close out the inning.

The Koreans were able to hang on to the lead for the rest of the way, handing Chinese Taipei its fourth straight loss of the tournament and ending its hopes of advancing to the semi-finals and a chance at Olympic gold.

All that is left now for the Chinese Taipei side is to redeem itself and gain back a little pride in its final two games against tough teams from the United States and Canada before heading back to Taiwan to watch the medal round.

DOC.HEADLINE: Office workers affected by Olympics: poll

TEXT.P: A majority of office workers in Taiwan are keeping a close eye on the Beijing Olympics, with some of them even changing their work schedules or skipping work altogether to watch the events on TV, a local online poll revealed Monday.

Seventy-three percent of local office workers surveyed Aug. 8-15 by the 1111 Job Bank, a major online human resource agency, said they are "very interested" in or paying close attention to the Olympics, the poll indicated.
According to the poll, 16.53 percent of the 73 percent said that they have changed their work schedules to watch the games.

In the same category, 46.07 percent said they have changed their work time or shifts, 16.29 percent said they have taken days off, 15.73 percent said they arrive late for work, 14.04 percent said they leave work early, while 8.43 percent skip work altogether.
Even those who have not changed their schedules also admitted that they are affected at work because of the games, the poll shows.

The poll adds that 22.33 percent said they peek at the competitions or scores while working, 14.53 percent said they are eager to get off work, while 11.93 percent said they often discuss the competitions, affecting their productivity.
1111 Job Bank spokesman Ryan Wu urged local companies to tolerate their employees' enthusiasm about the Olympics as long as company operations are not affected.
"Such tolerance will help companies win the support of their employees," Wu said, suggesting that companies use the opportunity to increase employee morale and esprit de corps.
However, he also urged employees not to let their passion for the Olympics undermine their performance.
The poll shows that 25.16 percent of the respondents interested in the Olympics said their companies have adopted open policies toward their employees in this regard.

These policies include allowing employees to watch events on TV at company restaurants or in the office, informing employees as results come in, letting employees get off work early to watch important competitions, or offering leave.

The top five popular sports among local office workers, who were allowed to make multiple choices, are baseball (76.51 percent) , taekwondo (36.12 percent), tennis (22.93 percent), basketball (21.73 percent) and water sports (19.87 percent), the poll indicates.
When the athletes or teams that they support lose, 78.3 percent said they felt "slightly disappointed, " while 7.26 percent disclosed that their great disappointments have affected their work.
Taiwan has taken two bronze medals in weightlifting so far. Its baseball team defeated the Netherlands in the first Olympic competition but then went on to lose to Japan, China, Cuba and South Korea.
The poll had 1,115 valid samples, with a margin of error of 2.9 percent and a 95 percent level of confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: Export processing zones draw record high investments

TEXT.P: Investments totalling an all-time high of NT$40.4 billion (US$1.29 billion) were channeled into the export processing zones across Taiwan in the first seven months of this year, the Export Processing Zone Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Monday.

During the January-July period, NT$23.5 billion worth of capital from 49 new investment plans was injected into nationwide export processing zones, while some NT$16.9 billion came from increased capital by another 54 companies which are already operating in these zones, statistics compiled by the administration showed.

The combined figure of NT$40.4 billion has surpassed the full-year target of NT$37 billion set by the MOEA for 2008, and is the highest investment sum ever recorded in the zones for the January-July period, administration officials noted.
The officials predicted that more than NT$50 billion worth of capital will be invested in the export processing zones throughout the country for the whole of this year.

The officials attributed the strong showing to the administration's success in attracting greater investment to these zones because of their stronger competitiveness driven by improved investment conditions and reduced operating costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for August fell 238 points to close at 6,980, with 76,947 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September lost 243 points to finish at 6,950, with 10,850 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 230 points to close at 6,920, with 98 contract transactions.
March futures decreased 233 points to finish at 6,915, with 26 contract transactions, while June futures were down 170 to close at 6,950, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 7,218 for August, 7,193 for September, 7,150 for December, 7,148 for March and 7,120 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index lost 195.76 points to finish at 7,000.74, on turnover of NT$82.84 billion (US$2.69 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

August TE futures decreased 7.8 points to close at 286, with 4,820 contracts traded, while September TE futures decreased 7.9 points to finish at 284.5, with 852 contract transactions. December TE futures rose 0.3 points to end at 290, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

August TF futures moved down 48 points to close at 844.8, with 4,558 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures decreased 55.6 points to finish at 835.8, with 1,576 contracts traded. December TF futures lost 54.2 points to end at 834.6, with nine contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ probes concealment in ex-president's money-laundering case

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has asked the Taipei District Prosecutors Office to help investigate the alleged concealment of information by officials regarding suspected money laundering by the former first family, Deputy Minister of Justice Huang Shih-ming said Monday.

The official determined to be responsible for withholding intelligence passed on to Taiwan by the Egmont Group, an international anti-money laundering organization, can be charged with obstruction of official duties under the Criminal Code, Huang said.

At issue is an Egmont Group report received in January by the Investigation Bureau's Money Laundering Prevention Center, which detailed the status of bank accounts created by members of then-President Shui-bian's family in other countries, including the United States, Cayman Islands, Singapore and Switzerland.

However, the prosecutorial authorities were unaware of the information until Next magazine, citing the contents of the report, reported last week that Chen's daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching had laundered money for the former first family by secretly wiring NT$300 million overseas in 2006, after the exposure of the "state affairs fund" embezzlement case implicating Chen and his wife Wu Shu-jen. The revelation was based on tips leaked to the magazine by investigators.

Over the weekend, Yeh Sheng-mao, a former head of the Investigation Bureau who retired from the post after the inauguration of the Kuomintang government in May, admitted that he did not deliver any formal documents concerning the sensitive information to the prosecution before his retirement because of what he claimed was his "personal negligence."
Yeh claimed that he made an oral report to State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming in early February -- a claim that the prosecutor-general strongly denied.

According to Huang, the case was assigned to the Taipei District Prosecutors Office, instead of the special investigation unit of the Supreme Prosecutors Office headed by Chen Tsung-ming, so as to avoid a conflict of interests.
Prosecutors can summon the state public prosecutor-general for questioning if necessary, Huang added.

Also Monday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said it was investigating whether officials of the country's representative office in Switzerland were responsible for delaying the delivery to Taipei of a letter from the Swiss Confederation's Department of Justice in which the Swiss authorities sought Taiwan's assistance in probing possible money-laundering in Switzerland by Chen Shui-bian's son Chen Chih-chung and Huang Jui-ching.

The letter, dated June 16, was received by the representative office in early July, but staffers there allegedly sat on it for nearly a month before forwarding it in late July to the MOFA, which later transferred it to the MOJ.
Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu revealed last Thursday that the Swiss authorities had put forth the request for assistance, one day after the release of the Next magazine report.

Hung's revelation prompted the former president to call a news conference that same day in which he admitted that his wife had wired abroad an unspecified amount of money that he had received as campaign contributions.

Chen confessed that he lied about the election campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004, but claimed he was unaware that the surplus funds were wired abroad by his wife until early this year.

However, he rejected Hung's allegation that the funds wired overseas could be connected to his "state affairs funds" case and a recent scandal involving a botched attempt to win Papua New Guinea as a diplomatic ally.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cab driver being hunted for dropping passengers on freeway

TEXT.P: Police in central Taiwan said Monday that they are searching for a local cab driver who was recently accused of dropping passengers off on a freeway.
The taxi driver reportedly forced four local college students out of his car on the freeway after the students refused to pay an additional charge.

The cab driver had agreed to take the students from Taichung City to a water park in Taichung County for a fare of NT$500 (about US$16), but later requested an additional fare after they got on the freeway, the students complained in a petition letter to a local newspaper.
The students recalled that after getting out of the taxi, they had to carry their luggage and walk for more than 10 minutes to get off the freeway to find other transportation.

At a city meeting, Taichung City Police Chief Yeh Kun-fu said that the police are currently looking for the driver by going through the city's surveillance camera footage because the students did not write down the taxi's vehicle number.
Noting that the driver has violated the Social Order Maintenance Act, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said at the meeting that relevant agencies should study ways to prevent recurrence of similar events.

"Taichung City government requires that local taxis charge according to meters, otherwise passengers should file a complaint with the city government by offering the taxi number, " said Chen Rui-chen, an acting section chief in the city's Department of Transportation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.023 to close at NT$31.307.
A total of US$1.43 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.340 and fluctuated between NT$31.306 and NT$31.432.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's new U.N. bid `thoughtless': former diplomat

TEXT.P: A former Republic of China representative to Switzerland described Monday the core idea of Taiwan's renewed U.N. bid as being "too thoughtless" because "it is meaningless" to let Beijing decide whether or not to allow Taiwan to join the United Nations.

Wang Shih-rong, who stepped down from the post in February after serving in the European country for nearly six years, made the criticism at a seminar on Taiwan's U.N. bid and foreign relations, organized by the Taipei-based Taiwan Thinktank -- a nonprofit public policy research organization.
Last week, President Ma Ying-jeou announced a policy under which Taiwan will call for the U.N. to consider the feasibility of "meaningful participation" in U.N. activities by Taiwan.

It marks a fresh approach by the government in seeking U.N. admission for Taiwan since 1993, when it began efforts to re-enter the U.N. after losing its seat to the People's Republic of China in 1971.
The latest proposal does not mention the country's attempt to enter the U.N. under the name Taiwan, nor does it mention the Republic of China seeking to return to the U.N.

According to Wang, his experience in fighting for Taiwan's space in the international community during his tenure as the country's top representative in Switzerland tell him that so-called meaningful participation is meaningless because Beijing will still be the key element in the U.N. as far as Taiwan's U.N. bids go.

"How could the government put the country's future in the hands of China while believing that China will treat Taiwan well? " Wang asked. Beijing claims sovereign over Taiwan and vows war if self-ruled Taiwan declares formal independence.

The previous Democratic Progressive Party administration for the first time in 2007 applied to join the U.N. as a full member under the name Taiwan, a proposal that did not make the agenda of the U.N. General Assembly.
The 63rd regular session of the U.N. General Assembly is slated to open Sept. 16 at U.N. Headquarters in New York.

Ma's proposal emphasizing the importance of Taiwan's "meaningful participation" in the U.N. has been submitted to the U.N. Secretariat by representatives of St. Vincent and Grenadines and the Solomon Islands, two of the country's 23 diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over-pumping of underground water worries EPA panel

TEXT.P: An environmental impact assessment panel deferred a decision on a plan by the state-run Taiwan Water Corp. to expand a desalination plant in outlying Penghu County, one of Taiwan's driest regions, and asked the company to provide a more detailed plan and agenda for stopping the use of underground water before approving the plan.

In order to convert more seawater to drinking water, the Taiwan Water Corp. is planning to expand an existing seawater desalination plant capacity to 13,000 cubic meters per day (CMD) from the present 8,500 CMD.

At present, the main water demand in the Makung area -- the most populous area of the Penghu archipelago -- is about 22,500 CMD. So far, with three reservoirs and an underground water supply, the water company can only just meet the demand, Wang Ming-yuan, representative of the corporation's public works department, said Monday after an environmental impact assessment meeting.

"But we are under pressure to supply more fresh water in the near future, " said another corporation worker, who added that the construction of six tourist hotels in the island county is expected to be completed this year, leading to an inevitable increase in demand.

However, the environmental impact assessment panel held off its decision and asked the company to provide a more detailed plan for stopping the use of underground water -- a condition to which the water company agreed when the original plant construction plan was given a green light -- as excessive pumping can lead to land subsidence, while lowering the underground water level can lead to salinization of the supply.

"We gave conditional approval to the original plan for the desalination plant on condition that the company would stop pumping underground water, and the company must not violate that condition, " said a member of the assessment committee at the meeting, adding that the underground water level is nearly 100 meters below ground.
In addition, in order to stabilize the desalinated water quality, it has been suggested that the underground water be mixed with desalinated water, the water company said.
About 6,000 CMD of underground water is consumed in the Makung area every day, according to the company.
The panel is committed to making a decision at its next meeting, but only after an on-site investigation and the submission of detailed plans by the water company.

The annual average rainfall in Penghu County is 1,000 mm, with an average 95 days of rain per year and an evapotranspiration level of as high as 1,600 mm per year due to strong wind and long hours of sunshine, according to the Penghu county government.
The central government began constructing seawater desalination plants in the outlying islands, including Penghu and Kinmen, in 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT chief advocates, prays for cross-strait peace on Kinmen Island

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Po-hsiung called Monday for eternal peace across the Taiwan Strait, as he presided over a ceremony on the outlying Kinmen Island in commemoration of the soldiers who died in the service of their country during the Artillery Bombardment on Aug. 23, 1958.

"Taiwan and China should seize the opportunity brought about by Taiwan's transfer of power in May to catch up with international trends of peace, friendship and progress, and to mend their rifts and make peace across the Taiwan Strait," Wu said.

Wu made the comments at a news conference held at the 823 Artillery War Museum on Kinmen, where he laid wreathes to pay his respects to the memory of the local residents and soldiers who died in fierce bombardments by Chinese communists 50 years ago.

Asserting that the KMT is committed to building peace and creating mutual benefits across the strait, the KMT chairman said that the two sides stand a good chance of moving towards that goal by "putting aside disputes" and "forging goodwill."

Wu, who attended the Aug. 8 opening of the Beijing Olympics at China's invitation, said the Chinese people should have learned more about the true meaning of peace, friendship and progress from the Games.
Wu expressed the hope that through two-way efforts, war would not erupt again between the two sides of the strait.
Accompanied by eight retired military generals and ranking KMT officials, Wu flew to Kinmen Island in the morning. The Taiwan-controlled island lies closer to China than to Taiwan proper.
After the commemoration ceremony, Wu visited a temple on Taiwu Mountain and prayed for cross-strait peace.
The KMT chief also visited in the afternoon a memorial hall dedicated to the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, who also once served as KMT chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP heavyweights named as recipients of election funds

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian's daughter Chen Hsing-yu claimed Monday that over the years, her father used the funds he mustered to help the election campaigns of many Democratic Progressive Party heavyweights, and she dared them to say that they were all clean about how the funds were used.

Chen Hsing-yu, a dentist, was on her way to work when she was beset by a group of reporters seeking to question her about her father's suspected money laundering through two Swiss bank accounts owned by his daughter-in-law, Huang Jui-ching.

Last week, the former president admitted that his wife had wired US$20 million in surplus funds from campaign contributions to his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections into his daughter-in-law's Swiss bank accounts.
An irate Chen Hsing-yu described the investigation into the former president's suspected money laundering as a "political struggle."
"Who among the Kuomintang and Democratic Progressive Party politicians dare say that they have filed honest reports about the surplus funds from their election campaign contributions?" she asked.
"Those DPP members who received election subsidies from my father, did they file reports honestly about those funds? Or did they report their surplus funds honestly?" she continued.

She specifically cited former Premier Su Tseng-chang, former Premier Frank Hsieh and Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu as among those DPP members who had received financial assistance from her father during their election campaigns.

Later in the day, Su's staff responded by saying that Su had never received any donations from Chen Shui-bian, although he was grateful for the former president stumping for him during several election campaigns.
Hsieh's office also issued a statement saying that it was a natural thing among party members to help one another seek financial contributions during election campaigns.
"However, regarding the latest presidential election, Frank Hsieh did not receive any donations from Chen Shui-bian," the statement said.
Interviewed by TV reporters, Chen Chu said the real issue is not about how Chen Shui-bian obtained the campaign contributions but about why his surplus funds were wired abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei uses subsidies to help phase out polluting motorcycles

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government presented a subsidy program Monday to help phase out two-stroke motorcycles more than seven years old in order to reduce air pollution in the northern Taiwan metropolis.

The city government's Department of Environmental Protection said in a news release that it will give a cash subsidy of NT$1,500 to each of the first 5,000 owners of such motorcycles who agree to turn in their old vehicles to licensed factories for recycling by the end of this year.
City environmental officials said that Taipei at present has 1.07 million motorcycles, of which 190,000 are two-stroke motorcycles over seven years old.

"These two-stroke motorcycles generate up to five times more air pollution than the four-stroke motorcycles of a similar age," according to an official who added that is why the city government is using the subsidy program to encourage their retirement.

To qualify for a subsidy, a motorcycle must be registered in Taipei. Application forms can be downloaded from the Web site of the Department of Environmental Protection at: http: //www.epb.taipei. gov.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: 38 forums slated to tap Penghu residents' opinions on casinos

TEXT.P: A total of 38 forums will be held around the Penghu Islands this autumn to tap the opinions of locals on the development of casinos, the Penghu county government said Monday.

The forums, scheduled to be held between Aug. 26 and Sept. 22 in places around Penghu, including the rural islets of Jibei, Hujing and Niaoyu, are targeted at consolidating a consensus of all Penghu residents on casino development in their hometown, officials from the Penghu County Tourism Bureau said.

Eight academics from National Penghu University and National Taiwan University of Science and Technology are expected to join officials from the Penghu county government and representatives of Penghu-based travel agencies at the forums to inform Penghu residents of the advantages and disadvantages of developing tourist casino hotels in Penghu.
The experts will also listen to the pros and cons of whether casinos should be built on the island chain located off the southwest coast of Taiwan proper.

The forums came soon after Premier Liu Chao-shiuan announced at a Cabinet meeting Aug. 14 that the enactment of a law decriminalizing gambiling in offshore areas of the country will be one of the administration's future policies.

Chen Meng, a representative of Penghu's travel agency association, welcomed the announcement as the latest "positive" development, saying that after more than 10 years' of waiting and expecting, Penghu seems to be seeing hope now.
"It seems that this time around they are playing it for real, " a pleased Chen intimated.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma arrives in San Francisco
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/18/08 20:50:12 (By Lin Yi-feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou telephoned and met with U.S. senators and congressmen during his transit stop in San Francisco Sunday on his way home after concluding his first overseas visit since his inauguration on May 20.
Ma traveled to Paraguay via Los Angeles to attend the inaugurations of Paraguay President Fernando Lugo on Aug. 15 and Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernadndez on Aug. 16.
Ma left the Dominican Republic for Austin, Texas for a refueling stop before arriving in San Francisco at 2 p.m.

He called and met with 18 U.S. senators and congressmen during his stay at the hotel, including Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi; Eni Faleomavaega, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Asia, the Pacific and the Global Environment; John D. (Jay) Rockefeller IV, chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence; and Lisa Murkowski, ranking member of the Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on East Asian and Pacific Affairs.
President Ma spoke with them about Taiwan-U.S. trade relations, cross-Taiwan Strait relations, a free trade agreement, and military procurement from the United States, sources close to Ma said.

In the evening, the president hosted a banquet for overseas expatriates to speak about his "workable diplomacy, " under which Taiwan would engage China in discussing the country's international space as the island cements diplomatic relations with its remaining 23 allies.
The top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan, Chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan Raymond Burghardt, lauded Ma's visit during the banquet.

Burghardt used temperature to describe Taiwan-U.S. relations, saying that San Francisco is traditionally more chilly than Los Angeles, but Sunday San Francisco had a higher temperature than Los Angeles.
Burghardt also lauded Ma for being able to "brilliantly" execute cross-Taiwan Strait and Taiwan-U.S. relations.

The U.S. welcomes President Ma's approach to improve cross-strait relations, which Burghardt deemed as in the interest of the U.S. and helpful in warming relations between Taiwan and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County makes gains in Japan's mango market

TEXT.P: Tainan County in southern Taiwan has made progress in selling mangoes to Japan, in terms of export volume, after years of effort in seeking better fruit quality and effective promotion measures, Magistrate Su Huan-chih said Monday.
The agricultural county is known for many types of agricultural produce, with the Irwin mango being one of its specialty strains. The county is also Taiwan's largest producer of mangoes.
According to Su, Tainan County's export of mangoes to Japan has increased from 100 tons in 2001 to 1,000 tons last year, and the volume for this year already surpassed 1,200 tons by the end of July.
The performance was brought by great efforts made by local mango growers and the county government.

Su said the county practices a strict traceability system that requires each exported mango carry a bar code representing its production origin and providing a warranty from the farmers to win consumers' confidence.

Moreover, in order to meet the requirements of advanced countries, like Japan, that ask for strict inspections on agricultural products, the county established vapor heat treatment facilities three years ago for insect sterilization of mangoes and tightly controls pesticide use in its contract mango orchards.

Only mangoes that pass strict inspections are competitive in Japan's market, and quality control, instead of quantity, which Taiwan has no problem at all meeting, is the challenge that Taiwan faces in promoting its fruits in foreign markets, Su said.

The county has 540 hectares of contract orchards producing 6,000 tons yearly for export, of which 30 percent can be shipped to Japan this year, Su said, adding that each mango grower has to be careful about quality control because a single bad sample would affect the whole image that the county has built.
The county government established the Tainan Agriculture Trading Co. four years ago to professionally promote the county's farm produce domestically and globally.
Better quality control helps increase selling prices in Japan, and the practice of the traceability system is expected to allow a mango to be sold at double its previous price, Su said.
However, he went on to say that Taiwan has great room for improvement.

The best price for a mango of top quality produced in Taiwan is US$19 in Japan, while a mango produced in Japan's Miyazaki Prefecture or in the Philippines can be sold at US$90 and US$63, respectively, Su said.

In addition, Taiwan exports 750 tons of Irwin mangoes to Japan every year, which demands 10,000 tons of the same strain, while the Philippines is responsible for exporting the rest of Japan's demand, Su said.
He expressed hope of having the export quantity and selling price grow with better approved quality.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City denies worsening air quality

TEXT.P: Taiwan's southern port city of Kaohsiung, which will host the 2009 World Games, denied an allegation Monday that the city's air quality is the worst in the entire country.

The denial came after a United Daily News report said earlier in the day that Kaohsiung City's Pollutant Standards Index (PSI) was 8.6 percent last year, which is even worse than the 8 percent recorded in 2001.

The report quoted statistics from the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) and wrote that the city's air quality has been the worst in Taiwan since the government began monitoring air quality in cities and counties in 1994.
The report noted that the EPA formulated a three-year plan to improve the air quality in Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County and Pingtung County, all in southern Taiwan.
The plan is aimed at lowering the PSI to 6.5 percent before the World Games kicks off next year, but three years on, there has been no improvement in the air quality, the report claimed.
Chen Kai-ling, acting director of the city's Environmental Protection Bureau, countered that the city's PSI dropped to 6.16 percent last year from 2006's 7.34 percent and 2005's 9.77 percent.
The 8.6 percent cited in the news report refers to the overall air quality of Kaohsiung City, Kaohsiung County and Pingtung County, not just that of Kaohsiung City, Chen explained.
Compared with Beijing, which is currently hosting the Olympic Games, Kaohsiung City enjoys much better air quality, Chen pointed out.

The Chinese authorities forced factories in Beijing to shut down operations and barred scooters and motorcycles from entering Beijing as a temporary means of solving the serious air pollution during the Olympics, he went on.

Beijing's measures were seeking 250 "blue sky days" and according to Beijing's standards, Kaohsiung City had at least 340 "blue sky days" last year, Chen noted, adding that Kaohsiung City also uses a much stricter standard than the one used by Beijing.

The news report also quoted Lee Ken-cheng, executive director of the environmental group Mercy on the Earth Taiwan, who blasted the government for allowing local power plants and oil refineries to expand their operations in recent years.
Lee attributed the major sources of air pollution to Taiwan's state-run oil, steel and electricity companies, which all have plants in the city.
Chen, however, argued that the accusation is false and that the Kaohsiung city government takes a firm stance on reducing pollution.

For example, he noted, former Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Chiu Tai-san recently rejected a new round of an environmental impact assessment for a major power plant expansion, effectively curtailing the expansion plan.
At the time, an environmental assessment commissioner lauded the city government for being committed to protecting the environment, Chen recalled.

Kaohsiung City has long had a poor environment because it is home to many heavy industry plants, Chen said, adding that despite this, the city government has been working to improve air quality over the years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade promotion body plans to open new offices in China

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) plans to open two new offices in China in a bid to help the many export-oriented Taiwan businesses there explore the China market, TAITRA Chairman Wang Chih-kang said Monday.
"TAITRA has an initial plan to open a new office in Dongguan in southern China's Guangdong Province and another new office in Dalian in Liaoning Province, northeastern China, " Wang said.

"As many China-based Taiwan businesses have been hard-hit by a new labor contract law and other measures implemented by the Chinese government in January, TAITRA has found it necessary to assist them to cope with their present operating difficulties," he explained.

"Taiwan's economy will also be affected if a large number of China-based Taiwanese companies go broke as a result of the rapid changes in the Chinese labor market, " he went on, adding that this is why TAITRA is seeking to open the two new offices to help them shift from the export-oriented sector and tap local markets to maintain their operations.
The semi-official TAITRA maintains five offices in China at present.

Wang said he will suggest to Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung that he include the new office issue in the next round of two-way negotiations with his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, president of the the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
The SEF and ARATS are intermediary organizations responsible for cross-strait negotiations and dealings in the absence of official contact between the two sides of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Aug. 30 protest to be held as slated: Taiwan Society

TEXT.P: A protest planned for Aug. 30 against President Ma Ying-jeou will be held as scheduled, despite a money-laundering scandal embroiling former President Chen Shui-bian and his family members that erupted over the weekend, protest organizers said Monday.
Wu Shu-min, chairman of the pro-independence group Taiwan Society, made the announcement at a news conference.
Wu said the demonstration will be held as slated to speak about their desires for adequate government policies to take better care of their livelihoods.

According to Wu, the demonstrators will ask the government, led by President Ma Ying-jeou, to return taxes, stabilize consumer product prices, protect Taiwan's independent sovereignty from China, build a clean and competent government and enact key bills to ensure clean politics and wipe out official corruption.

"The demonstration was projected to drive sustainable development in Taiwan's democracy, freedom and the people's interests, " he said, "which has nothing to do with the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) or the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)."

The money-laundering scandal embroiling Chen and his family is being investigated by prosecutors, but many Taiwanese people are more concerned about Ma's deeds and the government's policies, he claimed.
"The Aug. 30 protest will be just the start of a series of similar activities to speak out the people's anger against the 'misguided' government policies after Ma came to power May 20, " he said.

Taiwan Society Secretary-General Lo Chih-cheng said the people who will take part in the Aug. 30 march and rally made the decision to do so on their own and were not being mobilized by Taiwan Society.

Although Lo acknowledged that some of them, affected by Chen's scandal, have decided to skip the Aug. 30 demonstration, he urged the public to enthusiastically participate in the demonstration and ignore Chen's scandal.

Two groups of demonstrators will march separately from the shopping area on Zhongxiao East Road in eastern Taipei and from Lungshan Temple in western Taipei before joining up for a rally on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office Building, where they will stage a string of protest activities Aug.30.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to take part in 66th Tokyo International Gift Show

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese delegation will take part in the 66th Tokyo International Gift Show scheduled for Sept. 2-5 at the Tokyo International Exhibition Center.
The delegation will be headed by Lin Jeng-yi, director of the National Taiwan Craft Research Institute, located in Nantou County's Tsaotun township in central Taiwan.

Lin told a press conference Monday that the Taiwan pavilion at the show will have seven booths in which three categories of gifts will be on display: fashion gifts, environmentally friendly gifts and technology gifts.
Lin said that in addition to displaying a variety of Taiwan-made gifts, the Taiwan pavilion will invite Taiwanese craftsmen to demonstrate the techniques used in making glass corsages.
The Tokyo International Gift Show, established in 1976, is held twice a year each spring and autumn. It is one of the largest international gift trade fairs in the world.
Some 2,400 companies from around the world will man 4,200 booths during the four-day event, which is expected to attract 200,000 visitors

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City confirms 13 new indigenous dengue fever cases

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan confirmed another 13 cases of indigenous dengue fever Monday, bringing to 53 the total number of cases registered in the city this year, a local official said later that day.

Ho Chi-kung, director of the city's Department of Health, said all of the 13 cases were reported in the Nanzih district of the city, with seven in the district's Chintien borough, which has had a total of 29 confirmed cases of indigenous dengue fever so far.
The statistics on the new cases were compiled Aug. 7-18, Ho said.
Most of the 53 cases were in Nanzih, with only two in the Yencheng district. Other districts remained safe from infection, thanks to insecticide spraying and other control measures, Ho said.

But he expressed concern that the infections will get worse when more visitors come to the city for the National Athletic Games and a warm-up event for the 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung at the end of October.
The disease will also affect the city's tourism if it is not stamped out before the two events, Ho added.
He said the city will take enhanced control and prevention measures to eliminate the disease.

According to a press release from the central government's Centers for Disease Control, the country has had 70 confirmed cases of indigenous dengue fever and 112 of imported dengue fever from the beginning of this year to Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese gift pandas healthy: report

TEXT.P: Two giant pandas that have been offered as a gift to Taiwan by the Chinese government are healthy and living well at the Bifengxia Panda Base in Yaan City in China's Sichuan Province, China's official Xinhua news agency reported Monday.
The two pandas were moved to Bifengxia after their old quarters -- the Wolong Giant Panda Protection and Research Center was destroyed in a May 12 earthquake that devastated the area.
According to Xinhua, Bifengxia is categorized as one of China's 4A tourist spots, with forests and streams, and is a one-hour drive from Chengdu, the province's capital city.

The pandas, named Tuan-tuan and Yuan-yuan by the Chinese in a reference to "reunion" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, have open grounds in which to spend their time, as well as air-conditioned quarters in which they can cool off, according to a researcher at the panda center.
The pandas, which feed on five to six kg of bamboo, milk, apples and maize every day, each weigh more than 110 kg, the researcher added.
Lee Dersheng, deputy director of China's giant panda protection and research center, noted that the researchers maintain careful monitoring of the pandas' physical and mental health.
The pandas are expected to be flown to Taiwan at the end of this year, where they will be housed in the Taipei City Zoo.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan developing new industrial cluster in intelligent housekeeping

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has recently put together a business union to promote innovation and development in the so-called "intelligent housekeeper" service systems, MOEA officials said Monday.

The union is part of a government project aimed at promoting the formation of knowledge-intensive service industrial clusters, the officials told reporters, noting that 11 businesses have joined the union and will work together to create and market more thoughtful, professional and comprehensive housekeeping services.

In the early stages, the new organization will focus on technology innovation and development in four major fields -- household health care, household life, household security and household leisure -- the officials added.

They called for more relevant businesses in the field of security maintenance and property management to join the union to build an intelligent services industrial cluster that offers systematic services that are essential to an intelligent living space.

According to data of the Market Intelligence Center operated by the government- funded Institute for Information Industry, Taiwan's production value of intelligent housing units will have reached NT$333.1 billion (US$10.63 billion) by 2015, when the global output of intelligent housing units will have increased to US$256 billion.
The growing market reflects rising demand around the world for intelligent household services, the institute said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president listed as suspect in alleged money laundering case

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian and his wife Wu Shu-jen have been listed as suspects in a high-profile money laundering case and have been barred from leaving the country, the Supreme Prosecutors Office (SPO) confirmed Monday.

Other suspects are Wu's elder brother Wu Ching-mao, who has also been prohibited from leaving, and Chen's son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui- ching, who have already left the country but should have their movements reported should they ever return to Taiwan, according to Prosecutor Chu Chao- liang, a member of the SPO's Special Investigation Division.

Prosecutors questioning Wu Ching-mao that day found that he was instructed by the former first lady to wire money into various overseas bank accounts, some of which was transferred via an underground banking system.
Wu Ching-mao confessed that he "began to handle Wu Shu-jen's money" via his bank account in Singapore's ABN AMRO Bank when Chen Shui-bian served as Taipei mayor between 1994 and 1998.
If the money was remitted from Taiwan, it was through domestic banks, but sometimes wired through an underground banking system, according to Wu Ching- mao.

The prosecution was surprised by Wu Ching-mao's statement, as Wu Shu-jen claimed to prosecutors last Saturday during a search of her home that all overseas funds came from the balance of Chen's campaign election expenses, his earnings as a lawyer before entering politics, her dowry and her investment gains.
The prosecutors questioned why she would have felt the need to use the underground banking system if she was telling the truth and that all the money really had been obtained legally.

Chen Shui-bian admitted last Thursday that he did not faithfully report the election campaign expenses from his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004, but claimed he was unaware that the balance of the funds was wired abroad by his wife until early this year.
He rejected the idea that the funds wired overseas could be connected to his "state affairs fund" case and a recent scandal involving a botched attempt to win Papua New Guinea as a diplomatic ally.
A prosecutor said Monday he suspected the source of the money might be "more complicated" than originally thought.

Also that day, the prosecutors questioned Wu Ching-mao's wife Chen Chun-ying, two assets managers, three bank clerks at ABN AMRO bank and China Steel Co. Chairman Lin Wen-yuan, who is known to have played a key role in managing campaign funds for the former president.
All apart from Wu Ching-mao were named as witnesses in the case and all were released after questioning.
Meanwhile, the prosecutors questioned former Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau head Yeh Sheng-mao over alleged concealment of information regarding the suspected money laundering.

At issue is a report from the Egmont Group -- an international anti-money laundering organization -- that the Investigation Bureau's Money Laundering Prevention Center received in January, which details the status of bank accounts created by Chen's family members in other countries, including the United States, the Cayman Islands, Singapore and Switzerland.

Yeh admitted that he did not deliver formal documents concerning the sensitive information to State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming before his retirement last month because of what he claimed was his "personal negligence"
However, he claimed that he made an oral report to Chen Tsung-ming in early February -- a claim that the prosecutor-general strongly denied.

The SPO has listed Yeh as a person whose movements require monitoring and has said that any Taiwan entries or departures must be immediately reported because of his suspected concealment of information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan legislative group visits Thailand
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 17 (CNA) 08/18/08 23:35:35 (By Lin Ching-ping and Grace Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Legislative Yuan Vice President Tseng Yung-chuan arrived in Bangkok Sunday for a two-day visit at the head of a delegation of four ruling Kuomintang legislators.

During the visit, Tseng said, the delegation will meet with Thai lawmakers and push them to help lobby the Thai government to support Taiwan's participation in activities related to the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

According to Tseng, the world's economy is moving toward a trend of integration, such as the European Union and ASEAN. Taiwan should not be marginalized from this process of economic integration, he said.

Tseng noted that Taiwan has frequent trade dealings with ASEAN member states, with the annual trade volume reaching US$60 billion. Taiwanese companies have also invested more than US$53.85 billion, in 8,790 cases, in ASEAN countries, according to Tseng.
Noting that Taiwan and ASEAN countries are not only neighbors but also close business partners, Tseng said Taiwan should not be marginalized or exclude from regional economic integration.
According to Tseng, China, Japan and South Korea will join ASEAN as "ASEAN plus one," "ASEAN plus two" and "ASEAN plus three" in 2010, 2011, and 2012, respectively.

"These countries will sign free trade agreements (FTAs) and benefit from reduced tariffs, " Tseng said, adding that if Taiwan is marginalized from this economic integration, it will be greatly affected.
Tseng expressed hope that Thai lawmakers will assist in canvassing administrative departments to consider Taiwan's proposal of becoming an ASEAN dialogue partner at the next ASEAN summit.

In the past, China has always interfered with Taiwan's bids to join international organizations, said Tseng. Now that cross-Taiwan Strait relations have thawed somewhat, Taiwan hopes to seek more chances of joining such organizations, Tseng added.

The four KMT legislators accompanying Tseng are Chu Fong-chi, Hung Hsiu-chu, Pan Wei-kang and Chiu Ching-chun. After winding up their visit to Thailand, the delegation will visit Indonesia, visiting not only Taiwanese businessmen there but also local lawmakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Low birth rate might take toll on college student recruitment: CEPD

TEXT.P: The issue of local universities failing to recruit enough students could worsen increasingly in the coming years as a result of the declining birth rate, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials warned Monday.
The officials made the remarks after the council unveiled a draft estimate of the country's population for the period from 2008 through 2056.

Government statistics show that the numbers of those aged 6, 12, and 18 suitable to enter elementary schools, junior high schools and colleges or universities are 246,000, 321,000 and 333,000, respectively, this year.

According to the CEPD's draft estimate, such numbers will decline by 16 percent, 36 percent and 9 percent, respectively, 10 years from now, and the decrease rates will even reach 22 percent, 37 percent and 38 percent, respectively 20 years later.

In other words, the number of 18-year-olds will drop to 304,000 in 2018 and further slide to 201,000 in 2028. If the trend continues, the number of college freshmen could plunge to 125,000 by 2056, according to the CEPD estimate.

"Given this trend, the problem of universities unable to recruit enough students will become even more serious in the coming years, " said Wang Ling, a section chief with the CEPD's manpower power planning department.
Wang said the CEPD already urged the Ministry of Education 20 years ago to formulate a comprehensive mechanism for colleges and universities to shut down or suspend operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 19, or the 19th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Blaise Pascal, the French mathematician, physicist and religious philosopher, dies in Paris at the age of 39.
1871: Orville Wright, the American aviation pioneer, who, with his brother Wilbur, made the first powered and controlled flight, is born.
1878: Manuel Luis Quezon y Molina, first president of the Philippines Commonwealth established under U.S. tutelage in 1935, is born.
1901: Shang Tai, the last monarch of the Ryukyu Kingdom, dies in Tokyo at the age of 58.
1904: Japanese troops launch a disastrous attack on Russian-held Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China during the Russo-Japanese War. Of the 51,000 troops involved, only about 35,000 survived.
1934: Nearly 90 percent of Germans vote to give Adolf Hitler the presidency in addition to his position as chancellor.
1936: Kwangsi rebels in China set up an independent regime in Kweilin.
1936: A total of 16 senior members of the Soviet Communist Party are executed after Josef Stalin orders a purge of the party to get rid of followers of Leon Trotsky, a leader of the Bolshevik Revolution.
1945: Forces led by Ho Chi Minh and the Viet Minh begin the August Revolution against French colonial rule in Vietnam.
1946: Chinese Communist Party leader Mao Tse-tung announces that communist forces will launch a full-scale war against the Chinese government.
1946: Bill Clinton, the 42nd president of the United States, is born. He served as governor of Arkansas from 1978 to 1980 and again from 1982 until he was elected U.S. president in November 1992.
1960: The Soviet Union sentences U-2 spy plane pilot Gary Powers to 10 years in detention.
1966: An earthquake rocks eastern Turkey, killing more than 2,000 people.
1979: Pol Pot, ex-dictator of Cambodia, is sentenced to death in absentia for genocide by the Cambodian government.
1989: Poland becomes the first country in Eastern Europe to end one-party rule, as Solidarity's Tadeuz Mazowiecki takes office as prime minister.
1990: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein offers to release all Western hostages in exchange for a U.S. withdrawal from the Gulf region and an end to the blockade.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader who gave a nervous world two words of hope -- "glasnost" and "perestroika" -- is toppled, just one day short of the scheduled signing of the Union Treaty, a document hated by the hardliners because it signals the beginning of the end of the Soviet empire they know and love.
1995: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry issues a position paper entitled "Why the U.N. Resolution No. 2758 Adopted in 1971 Should be Re-examined Today." The paper stresses that the resolution, which excluded the ROC from the United Nations, is obsolete and unjust.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan visits the Ukraine.
1996: Niger switches diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
1999: The Taiwan Independence Party nominates its chairman, Cheng Pang-chen, as its candidate for the ROC's next presidential election slated for March 2000.
2000: An agreement sending International Cooperation and Development volunteers from the ROC to Nicaragua is passed during a regular meeting of the Executive Yuan.
2001: A 36-hour course on conducting election campaigns launched by the newly- established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), Taiwan's 95th political party, begins at the Grand Hotel Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to figure out, but once you try to figure out a thing, you must never give it up until you have got what you want."

DOC.HEADLINE: Weather bureau issues sea warning for Typhoon Nuri

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued Tuesday morning a sea warning for Typhoon Nuri, which was upgraded from a tropical storm the same morning, weathermen said.

At 11 a.m. Tuesday, Nuri was centered 740 km southeast of Eluanpi, Taiwan's southern-most tip, packing maximum sustained winds of 126 kph and moving west- northwesterly at 26-21 kph toward Taiwan, CWB data showed.
The typhoon is projected to reach a position 290 km south of Eluanpi at 11 a.m. Wednesday, the weathermen said, advising ships operating in the Bashi Channel to be extra cautious.
With the weather system moving at a fast forward speed and continuing to increase in intensity, the CWB will watch Nuri's movements closely to decide when to issue a land warning, they said.

The outer edges of the typhoon are expected to bring showers to the northern and eastern parts of Taiwan Wednesday, while thunder showers are likely in the southern regions and in the mountainous regions in central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: President returns from Latin America visit

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou returned to Taiwan Tuesday morning via San Francisco after concluding a week-long state visit to the Caribbean and South America.
He was whisked away from the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in a motorcade and did not speak to the waiting journalists.

The main purpose of Ma's Latin America visit was to attend the Aug. 15 inauguration ceremony of Paraguayan President-elect Fernando Lugo and the inauguration ceremony of re-elected Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez on Aug. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan to become aging society by 2017: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan is set to formally become an aging society in 2017, with the number of people aged 65 years and older accounting for 14 percent of the population, a Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) official said Tuesday.

Wang Ling, a CEPD section chief in charge of manpower planning, made the remarks one day after the Cabinet-level council unveiled a report on the country's projected demographic development for 2008-2056.
Quoting the report, Wang said Taiwan's population is aging far faster than in many advanced countries.
By the United Nations definition, Taiwan's population began graying in 1993 when the ratio of elderly citizens reached 7 percent of the total population for the first time.
"It is taking just an estimated 24 years for Taiwan to turn from graying to aging, compared to 50 to 100 years in advanced Western countries," Wang said.
According to the CEPD's forecast, Taiwan will even become an "ultra-aging society" by 2025 when those aged 65 and older will account for 20 percent of the total population.
With the population aging rapidly, Wang said, the country's aged dependency ratio could surpass the youth dependency ratio for the first time in five years.
The aged dependency ratio -- the number of actively working people divided by the number of aged dependents -- is a common measure for gauging the burden of an aging society.

The 2008 statistics show that on average there are seven active workers supporting one elderly person, according to the CEPD report. It forecasts that by 2026, the ratio will drop to 3.2 workers per elderly citizen. It has also predicted that the figure will drop further to 1.4 active workers for every "aged dependent" in the society.
The CEPD estimated that the ratio of citizens 65 and older will surge from this year's 10.4 percent of the total population to 14.7 percent by 2018, and to 37.5 percent by 2056.

Moreover, the number of "ultra old" persons -- over 75 years old -- will zoom from this year's 1.03 million to 4.55 million by 2056, according to the CEPD. The ratio of "ultra old" citizens to the elderly population -- aged 65 and older -- is also forecast to increase from 43.1 percent to 59.7 percent over the same period.
While the elderly population continues to grow, the CEPD report notes, women's total fertility rate has fallen below the replacement level.
According to statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI), the fertility rate dropped to 1.1 children per woman in 2007, from 1.77 a decade ago.
The contributing factors are late marriage and a declining marriage rate among women in the childbearing age group, which have resulted in shorter effective childbearing periods, MOI tallies show.

According to the MOI's latest demographic report, the marriage rate among women in the 35-39 age group declined from 82.6 percent in 1997 to 71.2 percent in 2007. During the same period, the average age of local women giving their birth to their first child rose from 26.3 years to 28.5 years.

In the face of growing the demographic imbalance, the CEPD, in its newly drafted demographic report, has come up with various policy initiatives such as encouraging marriage and childbearing and creating an environment favorable to the formation of households.
CEPD officials said the major target of the new policy initiatives is to gradually raise the fertility rate -- which has remained at 1.1 per woman for the past three years -- to 1.4.
If that goal can be met, the officials said, the zero growth in Taiwan's population will not occur until 2026 -- an eight-year delay compared to a prediction made two years ago.
It is also hoped that the current statistic of a 19 percent lifelong single state among women 45-49 years old will drop to 18 percent.
The latest CEPD report also forecast that Taiwan's population will peak at 23.837 million at the end of 2026, the officials said.

Other measures proposed by the CEPD to tackle demographic imbalances also include adjusting the allocation of educational resources and upgrading the quality of education, enhancing investment in human resources development, appropriately recruiting talent from abroad, improving job market mechanisms, offering better economic security to guarantee the lifestyle of the elderly, promoting "silver-hair" industry and care services, reinforcing counseling and assistance to new immigrants and building a society that respects cultural pluralism.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung says revised plan for MRT extension nearing completion

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung municipal government's Mass Rapid Transit Bureau said Tuesday that a revised plan for an extension of the southern port city's MRT lines is nearing completion and will be submitted to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) next month for approval.
If approved, the Kaohsiung MRT's Red Line and Orange Line will be extended by a total of 23.4 kilometers, according to the bureau.

Noting that the Red Line has already been in service for five months and that the Orange Line is set to be launched next month, Lee Yeong-kuen, a division chief at the bureau, said that as soon as both lines are up and running, the Kaohsiung municipal government will help the Pingtung County and Kaohsiung County government's push for the planned extension to create a comprehensive mass transit system linking these southern Taiwan regions.

The Red Line currently runs from Siagang Station in Kaohsiung City northward to Gangshan Station in Kaohsiung County, covering 28.3 kilometers, while the Orange Line will run 14.4 kilometers from Sizihwan Station in the city to Daliao Station in the county.

Lee said that because of calls by the Pingtung and Kaohsiung county governments, the Kaohsiung municipal government drew up extension plans in 2006 and sent them to the MOTC several times since then for approval.

Each time, the MOTC called for revisions to the plan to address its concerns that the extension might not be worth the investment as it would follow almost the same path as the national railway which links Pingtung and Kaohsiung, and would lead to a reduction in passengers numbers.

The bureau has therefore made revisions, with the new plan calling for an extension of the Red Line northward by 9.4 kilometers to the Luchu Science Park in Kaohsiung County, and an extension of the Orange Line southward by 14.4 kilometers to the Pingtung sugar factory in the Pingtung City.

Lee said that that the extensions would definitely lead to a significant increase in MRT passenger numbers, adding that the only question now is whether the benefits of the extensions will outweigh the massive investment needed to make the plan a reality.
The extension of the Red Line is expected to cost about NT$16.2 billion (US$516.6 million), while the Orange Line extension has an estimated price tag of NT$31.8 billion, according to Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flat panel industry production forecast to grow 7.1% for Q3

TEXT.P: Taiwan's flat panel display industry production is expected to reach NT$488.53 billion (US$15.58 billion) for the third quarter of this year, marking an increase of 7.1 percent over the previous quarter, the Industrial Technology Research Institute of Taiwan (ITRI) said Tuesday.

Of that total, large area flat panel display production is forecast to increase by 8 percent to reach NT$304.1 billion, while flat panel display components production is seen rising 3.3 percent to NT$130.2 billion, according to the ITRI's Industrial Economics Knowledge Center.
The center said that a rise in demand for information technology products spurred by the start of the new school year will help boost the flat panel display industry's production for the quarter.
The ITRI is a non-profit national research organization under the supervision of the Ministry of Economic Affairs whose aim is to strengthen Taiwan industry's technological competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait talks to resume after Beijing Olympics: SEF official

TEXT.P: A new round of cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations might resume after the Beijing Olympics and conclude in late October or early November, with Taiwan and China inking two agreements on setting up direct shipping links and cargo charter flight services, a Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) official said Tuesday.

Kao Koong-lien, vice chairman and secretary-general of the semi-official SEF, said the foundation has informed its Chinese counterpart -- the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- of its idea of re-opening planned two-way talks in Taiwan after the Olympics.
"The two intermediary bodies are expected to re-open bilateral negotiations after the Beijing Olympics and to wrap up the talks by late October or early November," he said.
Kao made the remarks to reporters on the sidelines of a forum on Taiwan's prospects of becoming an "Asia-Pacific financial hub."

Commenting on the possible negotiation topics in the coming round of bilateral talks, he said the two sides agreed in June talks in Beijing to discuss adding new destinations and new routes to the existing direct cross-Taiwan Strait weekend charter flights, as well as the signing of two new accords on the establishment of direct shipping and cargo charter flight services across the strait.

The SEF and ARATS clinched two historic deals in June agreeing to open direct cross-strait passenger charter flights on weekends and to admit a larger number of Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan from early July.

As to the question of whether ARATS President Chen Yunlin will visit Taiwan and make a round-the-island tour after the Olympics, Kao said only that "the SEF will definitely perform its duties as a host."

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for August fell 44 points to close at 6,936, with 70,745 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September lost 52 points to finish at 6,902, with 23,229 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 35 points to close at 6,885, with 56 contract transactions.
March futures decreased 36 points to finish at 6,879, with 14 contract transactions, while June futures were down 74 points to close at 6,876, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,980 for August, 6,954 for September, 6,920 for December, 6,915 for March and 6,950 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index lost 22.14 points to finish at 6,978.6, on turnover of NT$83.11 billion (US$2.65 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

August TE futures decreased two points to close at 284, with 5,046 contracts traded, while September TE futures decreased 2.4 points to finish at 282.05, with 2,298 contract transactions. December TE futures lost 1.85 points to end at 282, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

August TF futures moved up 6.2 points to close at 850.6, with 4,072 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures increased four points to finish at 839.8, with 2,263 contracts traded. December TF futures advanced 1.2 points to end at 835.8, with 12 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Teenage pregnancies occurring at younger ages

TEXT.P: A significant number of teenagers under the age of 16 have sought assistance via the national teenage pregnancy counseling hotline or Web site over the past year, indicating a trend in which teenage pregnancies are occurring at younger ages, the non-profit Garden of Hope Foundation said Tuesday.
The civic group has since June 2008 been contracted by the Ministry of the Interior to operate the 0800-257085 toll-free hotline and the www.257085.org.tw Web site.

Over the past year, 1,312 requests for help have been made through the hotline and 141 others made through the online mailbox provided by the Web site, which has seen 16,602 visitors so far, according to foundation CEO Chi Hui-jung.
While more than 50 percent of callers were girls in the 16-19 age group, 10 percent were under 16, Chi said.
In terms of those seeking help online, 30 percent were girls under 16, with more than 10 under the age of 12, she said.

Chi said her foundation discovered that the online service was especially popular among teenagers wishing to maintain their privacy and that most teenagers were turning to the hotline or Web site because they did not know how to tell their parents.
Also, there was a serious imbalance in terms of the gender of the persons seeking assistance, Chi said.
For example, 37.9 percent of the calls were made by girls, compared with only 8.6 percent by boys, she noted.
While 61 percent of families calling the hotline were from the girls' side, just 9.2 percent were from the boys' side, she said.
Meanwhile, 76 percent of those asking for help online were girls, and only 13 percent were boys, she said.

Chi urged the authorities to expand the reach of their publicity on teenage pregnancy prevention to students in senior grades of elementary school and to introduce legislation emphasizing the responsibility of men in teenage pregnancy.
Also, parents should pay close attention to their children's sexual development and react rationally in the event of their teenage children getting pregnant, she said.

The foundation has estimated that the number of teenage pregnancies are likely to total approximately 30,000 per year in Taiwan, with around 25,000 teenage abortions and 4,000-5,000 births to teenagers recorded per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference to promote new opportunities

TEXT.P: Taiwan has long played a key role in the global manufacturing supply chain and has gained recognition for technological innovation, strong research and development capability and outstanding high-tech products.

Now, as the country establishes new links across the Taiwan Strait and relaxes cross-strait regulations, Taiwan wants to be recognized in another light: as a haven for investment and a center of operations for companies in the Asia- Pacific region.

Taiwan's booming investment opportunities will take center stage at the annual "Taiwan Business Alliance Conference," to be held on October 6-8 with more than 600 business leaders from more than 30 countries attending.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), the event's organizer, is scheduled to hold two forums on October 6 and eight panel discussions on October 7, with the goal of helping business leaders earn better profits from their investments in Taiwan.

The first forum on October 6 will feature Vice President Vincent Siew, an economic technocrat and former premier, and Mr. Richard McCormack, vice chairman of Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc. It will analyze "Global investment perspectives and Taiwan's emerging opportunities."
The second forum will be moderated by Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation. The topic will be "Leveraging cross-strait resources for global markets."
Business leaders and CEOs from Europe, the United States, Japan, China and Taiwan are scheduled to join the two forums.

The eight panel discussions will focus on several sectors in which Taiwan shines -- including light-emitting diodes (LEDs), biotechnology, micro-electro- mechanical systems (MEMS), and the public infrastructure investment plan.

The other panel discussions will focus on the finance and insurance, tourism and hospitality and logistics industries, as well as on new investment opportunities arising from cross-strait deregulation.

Dr. Yiin Chii-Ming, the Minister of Economic Affairs, will sign letters of intent with foreign enterprises on October 7. Customized fact-finding trips will be arranged at the request of investors on October 8.

Warmer cross-strait relations under Taiwan's new government and the convenience of direct cross-strait links are expected to benefit economies on both sides of the Strait, and attract global capital, technology and talent to Taiwan's superior investment environment.

To enhance the nation's competitiveness, the government has also accelerated industrial deregulation, for example by announcing recently it would relax requirements on firms' establishment of headquarters or research and development centers in Taiwan.
Apart from investment in Taiwan's high-tech and service sectors, the government's US$130 billion infrastructure construction plan also creates many business opportunities.
Berton Chiu, director general of the Department of Investment Services, MOEA, urged investors to seize the opportunities provided by the conference.

Chiu said that even if the world economy is moving in an uncertain direction, Asia still contains many fast-growing markets, and Taiwan is the most convenient "springboard" into China and southeast Asia for global investors.

Chiu emphasized that one of the key relaxations of cross-strait investment regulations was the raising of the cap on China-bound investment from 40 percent or less of a firm's net worth, to the current 60 percent.
Taiwan welcomes Chinese business leaders to participate in its major development projects, Chiu said.
"Such structural changes will mean that it will be more convenient for enterprises to do business, to set up an operations center or to seek business partners in Taiwan, " he said.
The 12 major construction projects include upgrading the island's transportation network, and establishing a Taoyuan international "Air City" or logistics hub.
Chiu noted that the projects will require massive investment, cooperation and high-tech know-how from foreign firms, and said many such firms had already inquired about the projects.
More information about the upcoming conference is available at www.taiwantrade.com.tw

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan cuts tariffs on imported oil products to zero

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan decided Tuesday to cancel tariffs on imported diesel after lowering tariffs last week on imported gasoline, fuel oil for aircraft and coal oil.

Government Information Office Deputy Minister Lin Ching-hsiu announced the decision at a press conference following a meeting of an Executive Yuan task force devoted to seeking stabilization of domestic commodity prices.

Lin said Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung issued an instruction during the meeting to complete an amendment to the regulations related to tariff tax as soon as possible to allow the implementation of the new measure, which will relax the growing financial burden on the public due to international crude oil prices.

Lin also noted that the government has also decided to launch Sept. 1 a relief program subsidizing farmers for their spending on fuel for agricultural machinery. The move is part of the government's efforts to help tide the public over surging fuel prices caused by crude oil price fluctuations in the international market.

However, at the press conference, the official cited a report compiled by the Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) that points out that international crude oil prices fell from US$145 per barrel in early July to the current US$120 per barrel.
Because of this, there will be no large-scale rises in crude oil prices for the rest of this year, the CEPD forecast.
Citing an assessment by Global Insight Inc., Lin said the local consumer price index (CPI) has been predicted to post an annual growth of 3.5 percent in 2008.

Compared with other countries in East Asia, the CPI growth rate is higher only than that of Japan's 1.3 percent, but lower than those of Hong Kong, India and Vietnam, which range between 4.7 percent and 24.6 percent, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, increasing NT$0.082 to close at NT$31.389.
A total of US$990 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.307 and fluctuated between NT$31.291 and NT$31.414.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Nuri approaching Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau is likely to issue a land warning between late Tuesday and early Wednesday for Typhoon Nuri, which is approaching waters south of Taiwan, weathermen said Tuesday.
The typhoon is expected to be closest to Taiwan Wednesday and Thursday, they said.

According to a sea warning already issued by the bureau, the typhoon was centered 660 km southeast of Eluanbi -- Taiwan's southernmost tip -- at 2 p.m. Tuesday, packing maximum sustained winds of 137 kph.
With a radius of 200 km, the typhoon is expected to continue to increase in intensity.
Nuri is projected to reach a position 250 km south of Eluanbi at 2 p.m. Wednesday.
