DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 22.14 points, or 0.31 percent, to close at 6,978.6.

Suffering a drop from the gains of the previous day , the local bourse opened at 6,876.23 and fluctuated between 6,998.24 and 6,849.83. A total of 3.46 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$83.11 billion (US$2.65 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 2.8 percent. Construction issues advanced 1.1 percent and banking and financial shares increased 0.2 percent.

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 4.6 percent. Textile stocks declined 2.7 percent, paper and pulp issues dropped 2 percent, machinery and electronics shares lost 0.5 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares fell 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,247 to 802, with 418 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$13.02 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medal-winning weightlifter to be made Tainan's citizen of honor

TEXT.P: Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair paid a visit Tuesday to Taiwan's first medalist in the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games -- Chen Wei-ling, who won the bronze medal in the women's 48-kg class of the weightlifting competition.

Chen lifted 84 kg in the snatch event before moving on to lift 112 kg in the clean and jerk event for a total score of 196 kg. The bronze medal performance marked a significant improvement over her 11th place finish in the 2004 Athens Olympics, when she finished the 48-kg women's competition with a combined lift of 170 kg.

The mayor met with Chen at her home and presented her with a red envelope containing a cash award of NT$20,000, plus Koji pottery artwork as a gift. He said that the city government will present her with a citizen of honor award in recognition of her achievement as an outstanding member of the community.

Chen will be the 13th resident of Tainan to receive such an award. The other 12 individuals include two athletes -- Wang Chien-min, the Taiwanese pitcher on the New York Yankees baseball team; and Wu Hui-ju, a member of Taiwan's women's archery team that won the bronze medal in the team event of the archery competition during the 2004 Athens Olympics.
Chen returned to her home in Tainan from Beijing early Tuesday morning and received a hero's welcome from her family and neighbors.

She immediately received good news that National Taiwan Sport University has decided to hire her as an instructor, but said the teaching job will not affect her training to prepare for more international weightlifting competitions in the next two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese women to learn from Bangladesh microcredit

TEXT.P: In the midst of a serious "credit card slave" problem in Taiwan, the National Alliance of Taiwan Women's Associations (NATWA) held a workshop Tuesday on the idea of the microcredit system developed in Bangladesh in order to examine Taiwan's financial policies and inspire Taiwan's underprivileged women.

"The Grameen Bank (of Bangladesh) has proven that financial empowerment can be key for women to play a greater role in bringing about positive changes in society, " said Mujibul Alam Khan, a Bengali living in Taiwan and an activist in social movement and non-government organizations.

Microcredit, created by the economist Muhammad Yunus in Bangladesh in 1976, is an approach to combating poverty by lending small amounts of money, usually within US$200, to people considered " unbankable, " such as the unemployed and poor people, said Tseng Yu-hwei, who has translated Yunus' book "Banker to the Poor."
Of Grameen Bank's debtors, 93 percent are women, said Tseng, adding that the repayment rate was as high as 98.5 percent in 2006.

Compared to Yunus' contributions to alleviating poverty, Taiwan's financial businesses only focus on profits and have created "credit card slaves" who are unable to pay off their credit card debt, leading to unrecoverable loans and creating a negative impact on Taiwan's economic growth, NATWA said in a statement.
According to the Ministry of Justice, about 510,000 people in Taiwan are "credit card slaves."

The World Vision charity organization has also operated the financial system in 47 countries, serving 560,000 clients and helping 1.7 million poor children to improve their livelihoods, said Alice Chang of World Vision's public relations department.
"But in Taiwan, the system is still limited to discussion without concrete measures, due to restrictions created by the country's financial regulations," said Chang.

Yunus won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2006 for his contributions to improving poor people's living conditions through microcredit, which permits them to borrow money from his Grameen Bank (bank of the village) to set up small businesses and learn to be economically independent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lazurite glass local people's top gift choice to foreigners: survey

TEXT.P: Results of an online survey showed craftworks made with lazurite, or colored glass, are top choices of Taiwanese people as gifts for foreign friends, a survey conductor said Monday.

According to Lin Cheng-yi, director-general of National Taiwan Craft Research Institute, which conducted the survey recently, other top choices are pottery and ceramic works, and bamboo handicrafs, followed by tea leaves and local specialty foods.
Lazurite artwork is the most popular due to its oriental elements and delicate texture, Lin said.
Lin introduced the survey results at a news conference in which he announced Taiwan's participation next month in the Tokyo International Gift Show Autumn 2008, a first for Taiwan.
The four-day show will be held at the Tokyo International Exhibition Center from Sept. 2-5. Established in 1976, the show is one of the largest gift and decorative accessory trade fairs in the world.
Lin said Taiwan will have seven booths displaying handicrafts under three categories: fashion design, green design, and technology design.

The fashion design will showcase daily supplies of objects combining fashion elements and hand-made textures, like bamboo-made electric fans and spectacle frames, as well as many other items made with other craft skills like silver forging, indigo dye, and ceramic art.

Green design includes works made with recycled friendly materials. There will be miniatures of monkeys and owls made of iron or glass in the category, while technology design includes consumer electronic products, like earphones and mobile phones, made with crafts, Lin said.

Huang Pi-tuan, minister of the Council for Cultural Affairs, which operates the institue, said craft art is an important part of culture and creative industry, which the government views highly and has made efforts in promoting.
She expressed hope that Taiwan's participation in the Tokyo exhibition will help introduce local craft artists' works to the world and open up international channels for them.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City to host fair to boost labor-management ties

TEXT.P: Taichung City in central Taiwan will sponsor a fair Aug. 24 to help laborers better understand their legal rights and interests and help employers not to violate relevant laws, Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi said Tuesday.

The fair will be aimed at helping laborers gain knowledge of their work rights and interests by offering legal counselling, employment information and health checks, as well as massages, free coffee, games and lucky draws to attract visitors, Hsiao said.

According to Hsiao, many of the city's working class population lack sufficient knowledge of their own rights, which is why the city government is sponsoring the activity. The fair will also help employers become familiar with relevant regulations and laws regarding their workers' interests, he noted.
There are 489,000 working wave earners in Taichung City, accounting for nearly half of the city's total population.

Last year, the city's labor affairs bureau dealt with 1,629 labor dispute complaints, most of which concerned salary and severance fee payments, as a result of divergent interpretations of laws on the part of labor and management, Hsiao pointed out.

To help narrow the gap and offer better protection for laborers, the bureau now gives free legal consultations, serving more than 1,000 citizens in person and over 1,600 via phone calls per month, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's legal team ready for its first trade litigation in the WTO

TEXT.P: Taiwan's legal team in the Office of Trade Negotiations (OTN) is ready for its first trade dispute litigation in the World Trade Organization since its accession in 2002, as it formally requested Monday the WTO establish a panel to review a case on the European Union's alleged violation of the Information Technology Agreement.

"We have a strong case and are very optimistic about the future proceedings and outcome, " said a senior official of the OTN, admitting however that there is always pressure for any first trial, which requires tremendous professional work and experience.

The young OTN legal team, which has been in place less than year and is composed of four lawyers in Taipei and the legal council of Taiwan's mission to the WTO, so far has conducted all the legal work on the case independently, but during the decisive panel review and deliberation, it will hire an experienced trade litigator as an advisor, according to the OTN.

After the consultations with the EU failed to resolve their differences, Taiwan, together with the U.S. and Japan, decided to take the last resort by asking the WTO to establish a dispute settlement panel to review and rule whether the European Union (EU) has failed to accord duty-free treatment to certain products covered by the WTO Information Technology Agreement (ITA).

The high-profile trade dispute, a precedent-setting case for the implementation of the ITA, is of special significance to Taiwan, since, in addition to the huge commercial and trade interests, it represents Taiwan's very first trade litigation in the world trade body and a crucial test of Taiwan's legal capacity in an international arena.

According to the U.S. Trade Representative, the EU has adopted a series of measures that resulted in a new duty on imports of specific high-tech productsXcable boxes that can access the internet, flat panel computer monitors, and certain computer printers that can also scan, fax and copy. Global exports of these products were estimated at over US$70 billion in 2007.

The EU's violation of the ITA, a plural-lateral trade agreement among 71 WTO members, has brought serious damage to Taiwan's related IT products, LCDs in particular. The annual production value of Taiwan's LCD industry has exceeded NT$1 trillion (US$32.79 billion) since 2006 and is likely to generate NT$2 trillion by 2015, according to official statistics.
The tallies also showed that the EU has collected as much as NT$19.6 billion (US$650 million) in import duties on Taiwanese LCDs.
The OTN official stressed that they are ready for the challenge of the future trade litigation and are confident that Taiwan's trade interests as well as fair trade will prevail in the end.

The WTO Dispute Settlement Body will consider the joint request for the establishment of a panel at its meeting on Aug. 29. But due to its complex procedure, the panel could be set up in November at the earliest.

DOC.HEADLINE: 58% happy about their lives: poll

TEXT.P: Fifty-eight percent of the respondents to a recent poll said they feel happy about their lives, but many also voiced dissatisfaction with their income and the government's performance, according to the results of the happiness index poll published Tuesday.

The poll, conducted by the Taiwan Competitiveness Forum, a group of academics, asked the respondents about their happiness, family relations, jobs, social activities, health, religion and beliefs, political rights and views on the government's performance.
The results show that around 58 percent said they feel happy about their lives and that family relations are the biggest source of happiness.
But they feel most upset about their incomes and the government's performance, at a ratio of 47 percent and 55 percent, respectively.

Those with annual incomes of over NT$1.01 million tend to feel most happy in terms of income, while those who earn less than NT$1 million feel less happy. Those who earn less than NT$300,000 a year expressed the lowest satisfaction.
Hsieh Ming-huei, deputy secretary-general of the forum, noted that after the new administration was inaugurated May 20, it lifted a six-month freeze on petroleum prices.
"This, coupled with inflation and surging raw material costs, has led to greater discontent and the government has to address the issue squarely," Hsieh said.

He also pointed out that those who described themselves as "very happy" and "very unhappy" accounted for most of the survey respondents, in contrast with a small number of those with more moderate views, showing that the Taiwanese people have starkly differing views on various issues.
The survey was conducted Aug. 1-5, collecting 1,119 effective samples with a margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Musharraf Exits, but Uncertainty Remains
Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf's resignation Monday signaled the beginning of a new round of political uncertainty as the country's civilian government tries to reshape the legacy of nearly nine years of military rule.
The Washington Times:Musharraf leaves doubts
The long-anticipated resignation of President Pervez Musharraf on Monday may not hurt the U. S. war on terror because the Pakistani leader had not done a particularly good job of confronting al Qaeda and the Taliban, U.S. counterterrorism officials and Pakistan analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Philippines sign direct employment program guidelines

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the Philippines have signed guidelines for a direct employment program to enhance bilateral labor relations, Tsai Meng-liang, the director of the Foreign Workers Administration of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), said Tuesday.

Tsai said Taiwan's representative to the Philippines Donald C.T. Lee and his Filipino counterpart Antonio I. Basilio inked the agreement in Cebu late last month, witnessed by CLA Deputy Minister Pan Shih-Wei and Philippines' Department of Labor and Employment Secretary Marianito D. Roque.

Under the guidelines, direct employment coverage will expand from current caregivers to foreign workers in the manufacturing and construction industries, Tsai said, adding that application procedures will also be simplified.

In order to ensure the quality of health care, the Philippines "will also enhance pre-employment training for their workers before they leave for Taiwan, such as courses in language and cardiopulmonary resuscitation," Tsai added.

In addition, the two countries will collaborate to help reduce the number of repatriated and absconding Filipino workers, said Tsai, noting that as of the end of July, 2,700 Filipino workers were reported missing.
About 85,000 Filipinos out of a total 358,000 foreign workers are presently in Taiwan, working mostly as caregivers, according to the Ministry of the Interior.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:In Musharraf' s Wake, U.S. Faces Political Disarray
Facing imminent impeachment charges, President Pervez Musharraf announced his resignation on Monday, after months of belated recognition by American officials that he had become a waning asset in the campaign against terrorism.
The Wall Street Journal: Musharraf Resigns, Leaving A Shaky Pakistan in His Wake
Pakistan's President Pervez Musharraf resigned, handing leadership of this volatile nuclear-armed nation to a divided government that is struggling to tackle Islamic militancy and an economic downturn.

DOC.HEADLINE: 53 dengue fever cases confirmed in Kaohsiung this summer

TEXT.P: The southern port city of Kaohsiung has seen 53 cases of dengue fever confirmed so far this summer, the city's top health official said Tuesday.

Ho Chi-kung, director of Kaohsiung City Department of Public Health, told an interdepartmental meeting that the first dengue fever case in Kaohsiung this summer occurred on June 22, and that since then the number of confirmed cases has risen rapidly to 53, making Kaohsiung the city with the highest incidence of dengue fever in Taiwan this year.
Ho said most of these confirmed cases were concentrated in Kaohsiung's northern Nanzih District.

Worried about a further spread of the epidemic, Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu instructed that Nanzih District be thoroughly sprayed and sanitized. During the meeting she also ordered that all the uninhabited illegal buildings in the district be dismantled and their surroundings disinfected.
Ho said the city was asking the central government's Department of Health to earmark NT$17 million (US$541,117) from its reserve funds to help Kaohsiung place the dengue fever epidemic under control.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA to launch regular tourist railway 'cruises' on scenic lines

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railways Administration (TRA) is working to launch regular runs of "cruise liner-style" trains next month on three railroad lines that pass through scenic areas of Taiwan, the TRA deputy director general said Tuesday.

Chang Ying-huei explained that the idea of offering regular tourism-oriented rides came up after the TRA's first "cruise train" attracted a full train of passengers for a one-day sightseeing tour on the Hualien-Taitung Line along Taiwan's eastern coast Aug. 11.

A similar cruise on the Taipei-Suao Line along the scenic northeastern coast also saw packed tourists when it set off earlier in the day, while tickets for the first tourist train of its kind on the Kaohsiung-Taitung South Link Line, scheduled to run on Aug. 23, have sold out, according to the TRA.
Encouraged by the popularity of the experimental train services, the TRA plans to open one cruise train everyday from Monday to Thursday on each of the three railway lines, Chang said.

The planned new services are expected to generate additional revenues of around NT$400,000 (US$12,700) a day for the TRA, he added, bragging of the low cost for the one-day tourist railway cruise because passengers can save on lodging when traveling to sightsee scenic spots along the railway lines.

Unlike the usual trains that only stop for a short time at each station, the "cruise train" makes longer stops at certain stations to allow passengers to disembark and tour attractions, according to the TRA, which describes the way in which the train journey has been adapted to a form similar to that of an international cruise liner.
The trains also run at speeds as low as 35 kph to allow passengers good views of scenic landscapes along the railway lines.
Chang said the TRA will extend the time span of a stop at popular stations depending on tourist demand under the condition that such a longer stop won't affect other common trains.

The administration will also adjust the tourist cruises during different seasons; for example, the train will run at a low speed during a flower season to allow passengers to view blossoms along the railroad, Chang added.
On Wednesday, the TRA will begin sales of tickets for the second cruise train on the Hualien-Taitung Line, slated for Aug. 25.

The planned cruise will take passengers to travel between Shulin in Taipei County and Guanshan in Taitung. It is scheduled to set off from Shulin at 6: 39 a.m., making a 35-minute stopover in Hualien before arriving in Guanshan at 2:32 p.m.

The tourist train will then begin its return run from Guanshan at 5:10 p.m. that same day, the TRA said, noting that the round-trip ticket is priced at NT$1,016 for adult and lower for children and the senior citizens aged above 65.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hakka cultural festival to be broadcast live

TEXT.P: A Hakka TV channel will broadcast noontime news Wednesday live from I-min Temple in Hsinchu County, northern Taiwan, giving extensive coverage to activities surrounding the 2008 I-min Cultural Festival which coincides with the temple's 220th anniversary, a Hakka TV official said Tuesday.
According to the official, the god I-min, a hero revered for his loyalty to his leader and his fight against crime, has become one of the most important deities in the Hakka pantheon.

In celebration of the temple's 220th anniversary, Hakka TV will not only show Wednesday's live broadcast but will also report the activities of the festival in every news program, living up to its mandate and responsibility as a public media outlet and an ethnic channel, added the official.
The five-day I-min Cultural Festival opened Aug. 16 with activities including lion-dancing, along with a sacrificial pig parade and contest, a festival organizer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu County keen on creating smoke-free environment

TEXT.P: In line with the smoke-free campaign being promoted by the central government, the offshore county of Penghu is encouraging local businesses to join the drive and create a cleaner environment for the public, Penghu health bureau officials said Tuesday.
The Penghu county government urged local restaurants, hotels and inns to take part in the campaign so as to provide clients and the public a nicer environment, according to bureau officials.

Since 2004 when the Bureau of Health Promotion, under the cabinet-level Department of Health, began advocating the campaign to get rid of second-hand smoke in restaurants, 57 restaurants and 35 hotels and inns in Penghu have joined the campaign, the officials noted.

To encourage those who have not endorsed the drive, the bureau has set Sept. 15 as the deadline to push local businesses, particularly those in the tourism sector, to register with local public health stations for certification, they said.
Those qualified will be given a certification by the bureau as a safe and sound space where the public an enjoy clean air.

The Penghu Islands are located southwest of Taiwan and have been keen to develop itself into a popular tourist destination, especially after President Ma Ying- jeou agreed to allow more Chinese tourists to sightsee in Taiwan since early July.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lower tax rates beneficial to financial reform: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew said Tuesday that lower tax rates will benefit the country's financial reforms and contribute to a better investment environment.

Siew made the remarks in a speech at a forum on the vision of turning Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific financial operations center, organized by several financial institutes, including the Taiwan Academy of Banking and Finance and the Securities and Future Institute.
Siew said Taiwan has great room for improvement in lowering its tax rates, which are relatively high compared with those of its important competitors like Hong Kong and Singapore.

In terms of personal income tax rates, Taiwan's highest percentage was registered at 40 this year, while Hong Kong's was 17 percent and Singapore's was 20 percent, Siew went on, adding that inheritance and gift taxes, which have been abolished by both Hong Kong and Singapore, were registered at a maximum of 50 percent in Taiwan.

Despite its higher tax rates, Taiwan still has advantages in location, competitiveness in high tech, creativity and innovation, and capital, all of which will contribute to the vision of making Taiwan a financial operations center for the Asia-Pacific, according to Siew.

He said the government will focus on lifting investment restrictions, boosting more frequent financial interaction between Taiwan and China, enhancing personnel training and designing a light and fair tax system.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan told reporters after the forum that increasing the competitiveness of Taiwan's tax system will come before a more fair system is devised.

Morris Li, country officer of Citibank Taiwan, suggested that the government complete legislation of a financial services law soon and establish regulations on capital market integration to prepare domestic financial institutes for strong competition from foreign and Chinese institutes when the market expands and becomes more open in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung magistrate reminds public of enterovirus threat

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, at a news conference Tuesday afternoon, reminded county residents to be on the alert against a possible enterovirus resurgence following the start of the new school year on Sept. 1.
A total of 346 serious enterovirus cases have been recorded around Taiwan so far this year, including 39 cases in Kaohsiung County.

Yang said that although the outbreak has been brought under control with no new cases being reported in the county in the last six weeks, history shows that the start of the new school year often leads to a second wave of new enterovirus cases.

Accompanied by other top level officials, including Kaohsiung County Health Bureau Director Huang Ching-ching, Yang urged parents to cultivate the habit of frequent hand washing among their children to avoid infection, and to maintain a clean environment in and around their homes at all times.

Health bureau officials also called for all kindergartens and elementary schools to carry out disinfection work in their classrooms and to thoroughly clean all toys and teaching materials that students frequently use, ahead of the new school year, in order to ensure that another outbreak does not occur.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese hearing-impaired children get electronic ears in Taiwan

TEXT.P: A 7-year-old from China's Zhejiang Province who came to Taiwan last week to be given "electronic ears" after being diagnosed with large vestibular aqueduct syndrome was overjoyed with her new-found ability to hear when she attended a press conference Tuesday.

"I can hear! " exclaimed the child, identified only as Wen-wen, while hugging her mother at the press conference, which was also attended by 11-year-old San- san, who also traveled from China to Taiwan to receive the surgery at the Cheng Hsin Rehabilitation Medical Center in suburban Taipei.

The two young patients seldom talked to others and could not hear clearly ever since birth, said a doctor at the press conference, adding that the situation worsened for Wen-wen after a fall and a bump to the head.

According to Chen Kuang-chao, director of the otolaryngological department at the Cheng Hsin center, large vestibular aqueduct syndrome is a connatural disease of one or both ears, often accompanied by sensori-neural hearing loss the gradually leads to deafness.
The best way to improve the patient's hearing, said Chen, is to implant "electronic ears."

"It costs 250,000 Chinese yuan (US$36,400) for the electronic ear surgery in China, a procedure that leaves not only large wounds but also fails to preserve the remnants of original listening ability, while the surgery costs about 220,000 yuan in Taiwan, with more skillful surgeons and preservation of residual hearing, " said San-san's mother.
Chen said he used minimal invasive surgery on Wen-wen that does not require the shaving off of the hair and leaves a scar of only around 2.5 cm.

Moreover, the technique used in Taiwan takes only three hours, half the time of the traditional surgery, and requires only an overnight hospital stay, Chen went on, adding that he has performed the procedure more than 100 times with no complications.

Chen said the two children were so curious and excited by their new sense that they stomped on the ground and banged the lids of trash cans, creating a lot of noise they had never been able to hear clearly in the past.

DOC.HEADLINE: Better cross-strait ties in U.S. interest: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Tuesday that improved cross-Taiwan Strait relations are in the best interests of the United States.
Lai made the remarks when she received Eliot Engel, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on the Western Hemisphere.

She noted that the government has launched a series of measures to help contribute to peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, including direct weekend cross-strait charter flights and relaxed restrictions on visits by Chinese tourists.
The government has also begun to deregulate laws to help normalize cross-strait trade exchanges, she added.
"Both sides of the Taiwan Strait hope to resolve major issues of concern through continued dialogue and consultations," she continued.
The government also attaches great importance to the cooperative relations with the United States, and a better cross-strait relation will be in the interests of the United States, Lai said.

For his part, Engel said he has always supported the Republic of China as an independent, sovereign state, and he expressed hope that the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will resolve cross-strait issues in a pragmatic manner.

In related news, Lai will depart for Los Angeles Aug. 21 on her first overseas visit since assuming her post May 20, where she will attend the annual conference of the Taiwan Benevolent Association of America Aug. 23 and give a report on the development of cross-strait relations.
She will then travel to Washington, D.C. to exchange views with officials and academics on the cross-strait situation before returning to Taiwan Aug. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei police bust American currency counterfeiting ring

TEXT.P: Police in Taipei uncovered an American banknote counterfeiting operation last week and arrested 10 suspects, the Taipei City Police Department announced Tuesday.

A spokesman for the department said officers from the second brigade of the Criminal Investigation Division of the police department had had the counterfeit ring under surveillance for eight months prior to raiding two locations in Taichung and Kaohsiung counties Aug. 12, where they arrested three suspects.

During the raid, police seized US$260,000 in counterfeit hundred-dollar bills, US$221,000 in semi-finished hundred-dollar bills, computers, laser printers and other equipment, according to a police spokesman.

In a follow-up operation Aug. 18, police officers stormed six locations in Taichung City, Taichung County and Yilan County simultaneously, arresting seven more suspects and seizing more sophisticated counterfeiting equipment.

According to the spokesman, the counterfeit ring leader, identified by the surname Ou, along with his accomplices, will be referred to the Shihlin District Public Prosecutors Office in Taipei to face counterfeiting charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's diehard supporter revokes adopted name

TEXT.P: A "super fan" of former President Chen Shui-bian, who had his name changed to be the same as Chen's in 2000 to show his diehard support, has changed his name back to the one his parents gave him after the exposure of a money-laundering scandal involving the former first family last week.

Chen Puo-jen, a resident of Yonghe of Taipei County, northern Taiwan, asked his friends Tuesday to stop calling him "A Bian" -- a nickname of the former president, saying he had changed his name back at a household registration office the previous day.

A founding member of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Chen Puo-jen changed his name to Chen Shui-bian in May 2000 when the former president won the presidency, according to a local newspaper.

Chen Puo-jen is not the only person ashamed to be known as Chen Shui-bian. A nine-year-old boy living in Nantou, central Taiwan, has recently demanded that his parents -- also diehard Chen supporters -- give him back his original name after they changed his name to Chen Shui-bian several months ago, according to local press reports.
The boy said he was upset by his friends mocking him for "being corrupt."
The scandal-ridden former president has been battling charges since he stepped down May 20 that he misused public funds during his eight-year presidency.
They are not his only suspected transgressions to have come to light, as he is also mired in an alleged money laundering scam valued at several hundred millions of new Taiwan dollars.

DOC.HEADLINE: Veteran diplomat to serve as new envoy to Japan

TEXT.P: A retired diplomat with close ties to President Ma Ying-jeou has been tapped to serve as Taiwan's new representative to Japan, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

John C. T. Feng, a former ambassador to the Dominican Republic who received his elementary and middle school education in Japan, will be Taiwan's new representative in Tokyo, according to the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Noting that Feng is one of Ma's most trusted international affairs advisers, the official said his new appointment betrays the level of importance the government places on relations with Japan.
The Japanese government has already agreed to the appointment and the MOFA will formally announce Feng's assignation after completing administrative formalities, the official said.

Feng, the son of a career diplomat, lived in Japan with his family during his formative years. He traveled to the United States to continue his studies after completing his secondary education in Japan. He has a master's degree in public administration from Harvard University.

Feng's diplomatic career started with a position as a secretary at Taiwan's representative office in Washington, D.C. After returning to Taipei, he served as news department chief at the previously Kuomintang-owned Broadcasting Corp. of China and as editor-in-chief of the CNA. He later served as director of the MOFA's Protocol Department.

Feng was named the country's ambassador to the Dominican Republic in the Caribbean after the Democratic Progressive Party took power in 2000 and he retired from diplomatic service last year to help with Ma's presidential campaign.

Feng will fill the post left vacant by Koh Se-kai, a pro-independence advocate who resigned in June over differences of opinion with the Foreign Ministry on the handling of a diplomatic row between Taipei and Tokyo following a boat collision in waters near the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, which are claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.

The row subsided through high-level communications, with Japanese officials apologizing for the incident, in which a Taiwanese recreational fishing boat sank after colliding with a Japanese coast guard vessel, and promising to compensate the Taiwanese boat owner.
The Taiwan-Japan relations were close during Koh's tenure, with Japan agreeing to offer visa-free entry for Taiwanese tourists and recognizing Taiwan's driver's licenses.

Although Ma campaigned on a plaftform of rapprochment with China, He has assured visiting Japanese politicians over the past few months that cross-Taiwan Strait detente will not affect Taiwan's efforts to maintain good relations with Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. bid promotion to forgo large advertisements: GIO

TEXT.P: This year's U.N. bid promotion will replace large street-corner advertising with deep penetration into the world's elite circles in seeking public opinion favoring Taiwan, Government Information Office (GIO) Vice Minister William Yi said Tuesday.
Yi told CNA that GIO Minister Vanessa Yea-ping Shih will put Taiwan's strong will to participate in the international organization into words that will inform the world.

The GIO has asked all Taiwanese correspondents in foreign countries to provide information and background on Taiwan's U.N. bid to local media and will invite international media and think tanks to attend related seminars to give them a better understanding of Taiwan's relations with China and the country's need for U.N. membership, Yi said.

The promotion measures are aimed at arousing international awareness of Taiwan's exclusion from global issues like environmental protection, health, anti- terrorism, and of its being barred from joining international organizations, Yi said.

The Presidential Office confirmed Aug. 12 that Taiwan's U.N. bid this year will sidestep the thorny question of what name the country should use to apply, and instead focus on securing Taiwan's "meaningful participation" in the organization.

For the past 15 years, Taiwan has failed in its bids to become a U.N. member due to opposition from China. Last year's failed bid was the first time the previous administration had used Taiwan instead of the Republic of China -- the country's formal name -- in a move to highlight the nation's de facto independence.

This year's U.N. bid was delivered to the General Assembly by 17 of Taiwan's diplomatic allies Aug. 14, in the hope that it will be included on the assembly's agenda. The assembly will convene Sept. 16.

Yi said New York, where the U.N. General Assembly takes place, will not be the only target of the promotion and that capital cities of the other four U.N. Security Council permanent members -- Russia, Britain, France and the U.S. -- will all be covered.
This year's promotion will save money but will not necessarily be any less effective, Yi said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Court to rule on defamation suit against former president Sept. 9

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court said Tuesday that it will rule Sept. 9 on a defamation case against former President Chen Shui-bian filed by five retired navy officials in connection with the purchase of Lafayette frigates in early 1990s.

The two-and-a-half- hour court session saw Chen and two other co-defendants -- opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lai Ching-te and former DPP Legislator Hsu Kuo-yung -- face off with Lei Hsueh-ming, a retired vice admiral.
Security was tight, as Chen was kicked in the buttocks by an irate protester outside the building during his last court session in late July.

Making his first public appearance since the alleged money-laundering scandal by members of the former first family came to light last week, Chen was stony-faced. His request for leave from the court session was rejected.
Chen, Lai and Hsu all said that comments they have made on the Lafayette purchase in public places or on TV were "based on reasonable doubt."
Chen also said that the Lafayette frigate scandal still has to be solved, but this "does not mean there is necessarily no such thing (as Lei's connection with corruption)."
Lei for his part said the allegations by the trio have not been substantiated with evidence.

Lei, a former chief of the navy's Shipbuilding Office, said it was then- President Lee Teng-hui who approved the purchase of the Lafayette frigates from France instead of Korean frigates as had originally been planned.

He noted that when Capt. Ying Ching-feng died in 1993 -- widely believed to have been murdered when he was about to blow the whistle on colleagues taking kickbacks -- he had already been retired from the navy for more than two years.
Lei and the four other retired navy officers are demanding US$66 million in compensation from Chen and the other two defendants.
Chen alleged to reporters in 2005 that Lei and several other officers together took US$20 million in bribes in a US$2.8 billion deal to buy six Lafayette frigates.
The bribery scandal came to the forefront of local politics in 1993 following Ying's death.
After taking office in 2000, Chen pledged to seek out the officials believed to have received bribes in the deal. Lei was investigated but cleared due to lack of evidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 20, 2008

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3rd round of financial reform to focus on globalization

TEXT.P: Future financial reform will focus on globalization, Minister of Finance Li Shu- der said Tuesday.

Li made the remarks after Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung said earlier that day that the Kuomintang (KMT) government will not talk about the so-called "second round" of financial reform anymore amid allegations that the recently exposed money laundering case allegedly involving former President Chen Shui-bian's family might be related with bribes in the "second round" financial reform.

The "second round" of financial reform was a priority project launched by Chen's administration to streamline the bloated financial market by trimming the number of local financial holding companies through mergers and acquisitions within a specified period of time. Speculation had been rife that the reform process was tarnished by favoritism and bribery.
In an attempt to decouple the KMT government's policy direction with its predecessor's, Chiu said future financial reform should be code-named the "third round" of financial reform.
Li echoed Chiu's view, saying that the "third round" of financial reform will not set any time frame nor limits on the number of local banks or financial holding companies.

Instead, Li said, the Finance Ministry will focus on accelerating globalization of local financial institutions and service market. For instance, he said, the ministry will give priority to attracting foreign investors to take over a 20 percent stake in the state-owed Taiwan Financial Holding Co.
Priority will also be given to helping financial holding companies in which the government has stakes, such as First Financial Holding and Mega Financial Holding, to go global, Li added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Wednesday.
The weighted price index was down 51.14 points at 6,927.46 on a turnover of NT$1.95 billion (US$62.12 million) at the open. The index lost 22.14 points, or 0.31 percent, to close at 6,978.60 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Wednesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$31.392 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.003 from Tuesday.

In related news, Lai will depart for Los Angeles Aug. 21 on her first overseas visit since assuming her post May 20, where she will attend the annual conference of the Taiwan Benevolent Association of America Aug. 23 and give a report on the development of cross-strait relations.
She will then travel to Washington, D.C. to exchange views with officials and academics on the cross-strait situation before returning to Taiwan Aug. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 20, or the 20th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1741: Danish explorer Vitus Bering discovers Alaska on a mission sponsored by Russia.
1833: Benjamin Harrison, the 23rd president of the United States, is born. The first Pan-American Conference took place (1889) during his administration, which passed the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in 1890.
1860: Raymond Poincare, French statesman and president from 1913 to 1920, is born.
1905: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had been exiled for his involvement in the anti-Ching movement, organizes the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo. The organization, headed by Dr. Sun, sponsored an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1912: William Booth, British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army in 1878, dies at the age of 83.
1925: Liao Chung-kai, one of a 16-member steering committee that established a national government in July 1925, is assassinated in Canton, five months after the demise of Dr. Sun Yat-sen in Peking. Liao was 47.
1928: Both the Wen River and the Mi River in the province of Shantung overflow their banks, drowning 18,000 people and leaving some 30,000 others homeless.
1940: A total of 153 Japanese military aircraft carry out a heavy bombing raid on Chungking, the war-time capital of the Republic of China.
1940: Radar is used for the first time, with the British employing it during World War II.
1940: Leon Trotsky, one of the leaders of the Russian Revolution, is stabbed to death by a Spanish communist with an alpine ax in his home in Coyoacan, near Mexico City. He was 61.
1944: Representatives of China, the United States, the United Kingdom and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics meet in Washington, D.C., to discuss the establishment of a world organization after World War II.
1944: Rajiv Gandhi, former Indian prime minister, is born. The son of Indira Gandhi was assassinated on May 21, 1991.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a second invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting him to come to Chungking for a conference on Aug. 14, 1945.
1955: Gen. Sun Li-jen, chief military aide to the president, submits a request for disciplinary action against himself as a gesture of self-reproach in regard to a communist espionage case involving Kuo Ting-liang.
1967: A total of 247 people, including Taipei City Councilor Lin Shui-chuan, are arrested for attempting to stage an armed rebellion for Taiwan independence.
1968: Soviet and Warsaw Pact troops begin the invasion of Czechoslovakia in an attempt to crush the "Prague Spring" reforms.
1972: The Republic of China Mei Ho baseball team defeats a U.S. team from California 9-0 to win the Senior League world title.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Lugar, chairman of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Lugar says that the U.S. government has not changed its basic support of the Republic of China and that he hopes the ROC will open its markets to reduce the ROC-US trade deficit.
1988: A U.N.-mediated cease-fire between Iran and Iraq takes effect, ending nearly eight years of war.
1995: An express train collides with another train in northern India, killing nearly 300 passengers and injuring more than 200 others.
1999: The Central Bank of China announces that Taiwan's second-quarter balance of international payments surplus amounted to US$5.47 billion, the highest single-quarter total in 12 years.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation arrive in Gambia at the start of his one-week, three-nation African tour which will also take him to Burkina Faso and Chad.
2001: Taiwan's Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation makes its 300th bone marrow donation, with the recipient a college student in Hangzhou City, in mainland China's Zhejiang Province.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to sift out, but when you once try to sift out a thing, you must never give it up until you have sifted it out clearly and distinctly."

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Nuri threatening waters south of Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) continued to monitor the movement of Typhoon Nuri and might issue a land warning for some of Taiwan's outlying islands Wednesday as the weather system reached the Bashi Channel -- the strait separating Taiwan from the Philippines, weathermen said.
Chances are low that Nuri will hit Taiwan proper, although it remains possible that the typhoon may sweep across some of Taiwan's outlying islands, the weathermen said.
At 11 a.m. Wednesday, Nuri was centered 350 km south of Eluanpi -- Taiwan's southernmost tip, packing maximum sustained winds of 144 kph and moving northwest-west at 18-15 kph, according to CWB data.
Ships operating in the Bashi Channel, in waters surrounding the Pratas Islands and waters south of the Taiwan Strait are advised to be extra cautious.
Influenced by Nuri's outer edges, the eastern part of Taiwan and the southern Hengchun Peninsula are expected to experience heavy rain or extremely heavy rain Wednesday, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elderly woman killed by train in Chiayi

TEXT.P: An elderly woman died when she was hit by a train in the southern county of Chiayi Wednesday morning.
The train was heading south between Dalin Station and Shikuei Station when it struck the woman just after 6 a.m., according to the Railway Police Bureau.
Traffic on the north-south line was stopped for over half-an-hour after the accident.
Railway police said they are currently investigating what the woman, thought to be in her 60s or 70s, was doing on the railway tracks.
As of noon, the woman's identity and exact age had yet to be determined.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan develops technology to turn livestock waste into fuel oil

TEXT.P: A research institute under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) has successfully researched and developed a technique for turning livestock waste into fuel oil.

The COA Taiwan Livestock Research Institute based in the southern county of Tainan has distilled the animal waste into fuel oil using a thermal chemical conversion technology and facility that it developed recently, said Kuo Meng- teh, a researcher and project manager at the institute.

The distilled fuel oil contains an average 78 percent carbon, 10.4 percent hydrogen and 4.85 percent nitrogen -- a makeup that could yield nearly 6,000 calories of energy from every kilogram of "raw material," if the waste is from pigs, Kuo said.
The yield could be even higher -- 9,110 calories -- if the "raw material" is obtained from cattle, Kuo added.

The technology was researched and developed mainly because the procedures that have been used in the treatment of livestock waste are usually high energy consuming, particularly during the third stage of aerobic treatment, according to Kuo.
In addition to solving the "smelly" problem of livestock waste, the technology's major merit is helping turn animal waste, which usually contains 70-80 percent of water, into fuel oil, Kuo asserted.
Kuo's research team has secured patent rights from the Ministry of Economic Affairs for the technology.
Kuo said, however, that it is still too early to tell whether it would be economically viable to use the technology in commercial applications, as it is still in the developmental stages in the lab.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Number of older jobless workers rising

TEXT.P: The number of older Taiwanese workers who are unemployed has more than doubled over the past 10 years, which indicates increased employment barriers for this group, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Wednesday.
CLA statistics showed that 75,000 workers aged 45-64 in Taiwan were unemployed in 2007, compared with 34,000 workers in 1997.
In 2007, older employees were out of jobs for an average 28.2 weeks -- 3.6 weeks more than the average unemployment period for the entire workforce, according to the statistics.
Among the 75,000 older jobless workers, 26,000 or 37.27 percent were offered employment but turned down the jobs, mainly because the pay offered was too low.

Of the remaining 44,000 workers who failed to find any employment opportunities, 59.01 percent were hampered by age restrictions set by employers, while another 18.59 percent were not equipped with the skills required by employers.
The increase in the number of older unemployed workers was also partly attributed to the aging of Taiwan's population.

The statistics revealed that there were 5.51 million people aged 45-64 in Taiwan in 2007 -- up 1.8 million or 48.71 percent from 1997 -- with the labor force participation rate of people in this age group averaging 60.55 percent.

The labor force participation rate stood at 75.57 percent among those aged 45-49, 65.57 percent among the 50-54 age group, 49.64 percent among those 55-59, and 32 percent among those aged 60-64, according to the CLA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Aid for trade to become major foreign policy approach: ICDF

TEXT.P: An Aid for Trade Seminar was held Wednesday in Taipei by the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) to exchange views and experiences with other countries on the new trend in international cooperation, which will be an important part of Taiwan's foreign aid policy, according to the ICDF.

Aid for trade refers to assistance to developing countries, especially least developed ones, to build the trade capacity and infrastructure they need to benefit from trade openings, according to the ICDF.

In his keynote speech, Hsieh Fadah, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs, noted that the aid for trade concept has been gaining support in the global aid arena, and that Taiwan has gone from being a beneficiary to an aid provider.

As beneficiary of aid from international organizations and developed countries, Taiwan was able to carry out a series of economic development plans and lay the foundation, between 1950 and 1975, for future economic growth, Hsieh said.

At present, as a donor that has made economic strides, Taiwan provides aid, such as technical assistance, to other developing countries, he noted, citing the conversion of salt fields for highly profitable shrimp farming in El Salvador and assistance provided to Honduras in the area of Tilapia aquaculture.
"Through cooperation and sharing we are able to promote balanced development among regions," Hsieh said.

One of the foreign guests at the seminar, Esperanza Duran, executive director of the Agency for International Trade Information and Cooperation and an experienced economic analyst, was also invited to give a lecture.

The Taiwan ICDF was founded in 1996 with the objective of strengthening international cooperation and enhancing foreign relations by promoting economic development, social progress and the welfare of the people in partner nations around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's approval rating hits 47%: government poll

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou received an approval rating of 47 percent for his performance over the past three months, according to the results of a government poll released Tuesday.

However, the results of the poll, conducted by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission Aug. 14-15 with 1,094 valid samples and a margin of error of 2.96 percentage points, also showed that 36.3 percent of the respondents were displeased with Ma's performance to date.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan received an approval rating of 41.9 percent and a disapproval rating of 37.9 percent for the same period, the results showed.

Meanwhile, 44.1 percent of the respondents said they were pleased with the overall performance of the Cabinet, while 39.6 percent expressed dissatisfaction. In terms of the Cabinet's future performance, 57.4 percent of those polled said they were optimistic, and 13.9 percent indicated that they were not.
The results also showed that 55 percent thought that the Cabinet was doing a better job than two months ago, while 28 percent disagreed.
In addition, 52.5 percent of the respondents were optimistic about Liu's performance in the future, while 13.6 percent held the opposite view.
Minister of the commission Jiang Yi-huah said the poll indicated that the government has entered a better stage of administration.

In general, the government's policies on energy conservation, integrity, and environmental protection have won the public's approval, along with its achievements in improving cross-Taiwan Strait relations, developing diplomatic relations, and introducing measures beneficial to the disadvantaged, according to the poll,
The areas of dissatisfaction were the administration's policies on commodity prices, social security and education reform, the poll showed.
However, according to Hsiao Chuan-cheng, a political science professor at National Taiwan University, the poll does not reflect dramatic changes in the approval rating of the current government.

According to Hsiao, a poll conducted by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party two months ago showed that Ma's approval rating had plummeted to 37.1 percent, with his disapproval rating being 56.7 percent at a time when the public was uneasy over surging prices and the government's ineffective typhoon emergency response.
Hsiao said the newly released results of the government poll reflected the public's approval of lower oil prices and the government's efforts to strengthen typhoon response measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former ambassador's appointment as rep to Japan welcomed

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang legislators on Wednesday welcomed the administration's appointment of John C.T. Feng, former ambassador to the Dominican Republic, as Taiwan's representative to Japan.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced Tuesday that Feng, a seasoned diplomat, will serve as Taiwan's top representative to Japan and that the government of Japan has consented to his appointment.

Feng, 62, was a secretary at Taiwan's representative office in Washington, D.C. between 1974-1976 and served as ambassador to the Dominican Republic between 2000-2007. The son of a career diplomat, he received his elementary and middle school education in Japan.

KMT Legislator Lee Chia-ching, who studied in Japan and has paid close attention to Taiwan-Japan relations over the years, said that Feng is a high-caliber professional diplomat with rich career experience.

Lee said Feng's fluency in Japanese is a plus, adding that it is important for Taiwan's liaison officer in Japan to develop deeper and wider connections in Tokyo and gain a better understanding of the country's political environment.

Lee suggested that Feng try to consolidate Taiwan-Japan relations by tapping into the influential Taiwanese expatriate community in Japan, seeking to learn from the experiences of Taiwanese officials stationed in Japan, and following the lead of Japanese parliamentarians and Taiwanese legislators in their efforts to cement the bilateral ties between the two countries.

KMT Legislator Lee Hung-chun, who has visited Japan with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to promote parliamentarian exchanges, said he could not think of a better candidate than Feng to serve as Taiwan's representative to Tokyo.
"Feng is the best choice for such an important post since he is a veteran diplomat, speaks Japanese fluently, and most importantly, he maintains close ties with President Ma Ying-jeou," Lee added.
Feng, one of Ma's most trusted international affairs advisers, will be filling the post that was vacated by Koh Se-kai in June this year.

Koh, a pro-independence advocate, resigned in June over differences of opinion with the Foreign Ministry on the handling of a diplomatic row between Taipei and Tokyo following a boat collision in waters near the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, which are claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Japan should cooperate to tap opportunities in China: PM

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan expressed the hope Wednesday that Taiwan and Japan can cooperate in tapping business opportunities in China.

Liu made the remarks during a meeting with Masaki Saito, director of Japan's Interchange Association Taipei Office. The association is the de facto Japanese embassy in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Liu noted that Taiwan has a long-standing friendship with Japan, and that 2.5 million visitors travel between the two countries each year.
He expressed the hope that trade exchanges between the two countries will also be strengthened.
"If enterprises from both countries can cooperate in tapping business opportunities in China, this will create a win-win-win situation," Liu said.
The premier said that Saito studied Chinese at National Taiwan Normal University and is familiar with the island.
Noting that Japan offers scholarships to Taiwanese students each year, Liu said that Taiwan will also encourage more young students to study in Japan to learn more about the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for August rose 101 points to close at 7,041, with 44,015 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September gained 75 points to finish at 6,979, with 44,632 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 65 points to close at 6,950, with 213 contract transactions.
March futures increased 99 points to finish at 6,942, with 20 contract transactions, while June futures advanced 40 points to close at 6,916, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,940 for August, 6,904 for September, 6,885 for December, 6,843 for March and 6,876 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 62.3 points to finish at 7,040.9, on turnover of NT$82.53 billion (US$2.63 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

August TE futures rose 3.55 points to close at 287.55, with 3,465 contracts traded, while September TE futures increased 3.15 points to finish at 285.25, with 3,466 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

August TF futures moved up 10.2 points to close at 861, with 2,012 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures advanced 13 points to finish at 852.2, with 2,806 contracts traded. December TF futures advanced 14.2 points to close at 850, with four contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan drug industry production up 6.7% for first 5 months: ITIS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan pharmaceutical industry's production for the first five months of this year reached NT$23.84 billion (US$759.2 million) , up 6.7 percent over the same period a year earlier, the Industry and Intenology Intelligence Services (ITIS) said Wednesday.

One of the prime drivers behind that growth was production of active pharmaceutical ingredients, which increased by 34.7 percent year-on-year for the period to hit NT$4.5 billion, according to ITIS analyst Hsu Yu-chen.

Hsu noted that production of active pharmaceutical ingredients has been very strong over the past year, with monthly production hitting a record high of NT$1.16 billion in October of 2007 and breaking the NT$1 billion mark again twice during the January-May period of this year.
Meanwhile, the production value of western drugs, the main staple of Taiwan pharmaceutical companies, rose by only 0.9 percent for the January-May period to reach NT$16.96 billion, according to Hsu.

Hsu said that the one of the main reasons for the slow growth was that Taiwan pharmaceutical makers are still reeling from the 15 percent downward adjustment last September in National Health Insurance co-payments for drugs.

Nevertheless, Hsu forecast that the industry's overall production will likely continue to experience stable growth in the months ahead with an expected surge in exports of active pharmaceutical ingredients. enditem/ pc

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, increasing NT$0.001 to close at NT$31.390.
A total of US$766 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$31.379 and closed at the day's high of NT$31.425.

DOC.HEADLINE: Blueprint for Chinese investment in Taiwan due in September

TEXT.P: The government is expected to unveil a policy blueprint next month for allowing Chinese investment in Taiwan, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Fu Dong-cheng said Wednesday.

Relevant government agencies have been working on regulation amendments and arrangements and are likely to unveil an initial plan in September, with potential investment from Chinese market players eyeing Taiwan's manufacturing sector set to be approved first, Fu said.

Chinese investment in the manufacturing sector as well as issues related to two accords inked in Beijing by Taiwan and China in June on setting up direct weekend cross-Taiwan Strait passenger charter flights and Taiwan's admission of a larger number of Chinese tourists, and those linked to the opening of direct shipping links and cargo charter flights, will be listed as the top topics to be addressed, he explained.

The establishment of direct shipping services and cargo charter flights will be the prime discussion topics in the next round of bilateral negotiations, expected to take place in late October or early November, he noted.

A broad range of issues such as capital movement, the purchase of commercial property and offices by Chinese investors, as well as the entry to Taiwan of Chinese management personnel, all are implicated in the granting of permission for Chinese to invest in the local market, he pointed out.
According to the MAC vice chairman, the key point will be defining so-called "Chinese capital" -- both direct and indirect investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tatung U. students to head to Vietnam for volunteer work

TEXT.P: A group of students and instructors from Tatung University are set to head to Vietnam Aug. 23 on a volunteer mission to help improve the quality of the Southeast Asian nation's information education.

The university held a send-off ceremony Wednesday for the three doctoral students and two master's students who will be led by chief instructor Hung Wen- hua on the trip to Hue Province in central Vietnam.

During their stay in the province, the students will head to elementary and junior high schools and kindergartens to offer assistance in improving information education. They will provide instruction on simple computer maintenance and software use, and will training seed teachers in information education.
The university has also collected second-hand computers to donate to schools in the province in order to allow students there to continue receiving information education.

The volunteer mission to Vietnam is the first of its kind since the university implemented new regulations last year requiring new students to engage in at least 18 hours of volunteer work in one semester.
The regulation was implemented as part of the university's efforts to expand the students' international vision and encourage them to carry out their duties as global citizens.

The university said it is hoped that through such volunteer missions, the participating students will also gain a deeper sense of caring for the international society, use the professional skills and knowledge they have gained in a practical setting, and help improve Taiwan's exchanges and relations with other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sanchiao Fault in Taipei longer than expected: survey

TEXT.P: Recent seismological surveys of the Sanchiao fault in the Taipei Basin have revealed that the fault line is much longer than estimated and that the activities of such a long fault could result in earthquakes measuring 7.0 or greater on the Richter Scale, according to the Central Geological Survey (CGS).

CGS experts said that surveys in the past have produced an estimate that puts the total length of the Sanchiao fault at some 20 kilometers, stretching from Shulin City in the southwest of Taipei County to the Guandu Plain north of Taipei City. Some seismologists have also speculated that the fault has been inactive for some 11,000 years.
However, the latest surveys conducted by the CGS showed that the fault's actual extension is as long as 40 kilometers and that it extends beyond Datun Mountain to Jinshan on the north coast.

"Some evidence suggests that the fault structure may extend even further into the sea, and some theories suggest a fault that combines land and sea structures and could produce even bigger earthquakes," said Chiang Chung Jung, deputy director of the CGS.

Jung said that conventional means of measuring faults can be influenced by human activities and are less accurate than the new method. The new detectors are positioned underground to obtain greater accuracy and to allow for the detection of even small fault activities, he explained.

Meanwhile, experts at the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said that although a longer fault line can theoretically cause bigger earthquakes, northern Taiwan is relatively geologically stable, with only one percent of the total number of earthquakes that occur in Taiwan centered in this area.
"It might be too early panic simply because the Sanchiao fault has been found to be longer than expected, " said Kuo Kai-wen, director of CWB's Seismology Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier vows to boost animation industry

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Tuesday that the government will help local 3D animation and online game companies to resolve the issue of unfair trade treatment with China, expand their international market and nurture more talent.
Liu made the remarks in a statement released after he led a group of officials on a visit to four major local animation and online game companies earlier in the day.

During the visit, Wang Chin-po, president of the online game developer Soft- World International Corp., told Liu that China imposes many limits on foreign digital technology products, including those from Taiwan.
However, Taiwan has opened to similar products from China, Wang said, urging the government to discuss the issue with its Chinese counterparts in future business negotiations.
Liu supported Wang's suggestion and said that the quasi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will also help raise the international profile of Taiwan's 3D animation products.
In addition, Wang called for a resumption of tax incentives, which were canceled in 2007, for local game companies and continuous implementation of existing preferential measures.
Acknowledging the suggestions, Liu said the government's incentive measures will advance with time to better suit local companies' needs.
According to Wang, the online game industry has created the most successful business model in the digital content industry and he described it as "the locomotive engine" for the industry.
It is also the industry that generates the highest production value in the Chinese-speaking market, Wang noted.
He continued that last year, Taiwan's online game industry created NT$10 billion (about US$318 million) in output value, while relevant business opportunities amounted to NT$50 billion.

During a visit to CGCG, a local 3D animation studio that has many international clients, CGCG Chairman Shih Wen-hsiang told the premier that it is difficult to find animation talent and that there is a lack of quality local talent.
In response, Liu said he will ask relevant government agencies to review school curricula to help produce more talent in this field.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Pakistan faces rocky transition.
The resignation of President Pervez Musharraf will force Pakistan's untested new civilian government to confront a dizzying array of problems, chief among them an intensifying battle against Islamic insurgents in the nation's long-law-less tribal areas. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: Three Taiwanese orphan sisters adopted by U.S. couple

TEXT.P: Three orphan sisters flew Wednesday to the United States to begin new lives with their adoptive parents, a couple from Texas who have shown their love for the disadvantaged by taking them all, despite their ages -- 14, 16 and 17 years old, respectively.

A day earlier, Shiao-hua, Shiao-yi and Shiao-ping (all nicknames) spent their last night at the privately run Chung Yi Orphanage in Taipei City, which they have called home for 10 years since their mother died.

According to orphanage staff, Shiao-hua is the eldest and will soon turn 18. She has attended to her younger sisters since their mother got sick, they said, noting that she continued to do so even after they were taken in by the orphanage.

Shiao-hua did not want to be separated from her sisters, even though it would have been much easier for them to be adopted by different families. She had even said she "would rather die than be separated from her sisters, " they recalled.

Because of Shiao-hua's insistence, the three sisters stayed at the orphanage until George Lee and his wife Deborah received an e-mail that had been doing the rounds on the Internet, the Chung Yi workers said.
George, a Taiwan-born American, said at the orphanage that he and his wife spent just five minutes discussing the issue before deciding to adopt the trio.
"Society needs more public welfare and good hearts, not just indices suggesting economic growth, " he said. Besides, he went on, their own children have all grown up.

According to the Chung Yi management, it is a "miracle" that the trio was adopted by one family, because since 1995, only nine of 40 Chung Yi children successfully put up for adoption have been older than 6.

DOC.TEXT:
The Times: BAA under pressure to sell Gatwick and Stansted
Britains Competition Commission said today that it may force BAA to sell three of its UK airports, including two of its sites in London.

: The Straits Times: International schools get more room to grow.
