After Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the government will extend paid maternity leave to 16 weeks from 12 weeks in his National Day Rally speech three days ago, the small and medium enterprises (SMEs^have different views on this new measure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cold drink addiction a bad habit: foundation

TEXT.P: Addiction to cold bottled drinks on hot days is a bad habit in terms of both enviornmental protection and health, warned an official from the John Tung Foundation Wednesday.

Drinking and consuming excessive amounts of bottled cold drinks, particularly purchasing them from convenient stores, will only cause those franchises to consume more electricity in order to boost sales -- which is eventually detrimental to the environment, said Hsu Hui-yu, a foundation official in charge of nutrition and related affairs.
The John Tung Foundation is an anti-smoking group seen as one of the most effective nonprofit lobbying groups in Taiwan.

Hsu quoted tallies from the Ministry of Economic Affairs as indicating that electricity consumed by refrigeration storage facilities in Taiwan's convenient stores constitutes about one-third of all energy consumed by the stores.

The refrigerators in each of the 8,120 convenient stores nationwide consume an average of 51,000 kwhs each month, and as a result, the carbon dioxide that is discharged during the generation of the electricity consumed by all of the convenient stores in Taiwan each month could equal as much as the carbon dioxide taken in by 950,000 full-grown trees, Hsu said.

Aware that sales of cold drinks and dairy products have been one of the culprits of increased energy consumption, many advanced countries have taken measures to reduce electricity comsumption by related industries and services, Hsu related.

The United Kingdom is promoting the sale of preserved milk to replace fresh milk, as storage of the latter consumes more energy, Hsu said, adding that most of the soft drinks in Germany, Portugal and Spain are sold and stored at room temperature. He also noted that Wal-Mart Stores in the United States require its suppliers to provide the amount of greenhouse gas emission for each of their products.

The UK's Tesco grocery franchise has promised that all of the over 80,000 products on their stores' shelves will carry tags telling how much carbon dioxide emission is involved in producing and marketing the products, Hsu added.
"For the part of the consumers, they can help reduce energy consumption and carbon dioxide emission simply by drinking fewer cold bottled drinks," Hsu reiterated.
Meanwhile, Wu Chien-lung, a doctor of traditional Chinese medicine with Taipei City Hospital, said he does not think it's smart to consume cold drinks or ice excessively in the summertime.

"Gulping icy drinks probably cools people down and delights them on hot days, but people with weak stomachs could suffer diarrhea, those with weak kidneys could develop dydroncus, some could develop skin rashes, and black eyes and nasal problems could become worse after people drink their fill of cool liquids," Wu said.
Those who are on a diet should refrain from bingeing on cold drinks, as nearly all of those products could affect their metabolism if consumed excessively, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 62.3 points, or 0.89 percent, to close at 7,040.9.

Rebounding from losses the previous day, the local bourse opened at 6,927.46 and fluctuated between 7,053.56 and 6,898.29. A total of 3.44 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$82.53 billion (US$2.63 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 2.5 percent. Paper and pulp issues advanced 1.1 percent, textile stocks and banking and financial shares both rose 1 percent, machinery and electronics shares increased 0.8 percent, plastics and chemicals shares gained 0.5 percent, foodstuff issues were up 0.4 percent, and construction issues grew 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,196 to 801, with 499 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$6.57 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Telecommunication industry's Q2 production up 25 %

TEXT.P: The output value of the local telecommunication industry in the second quarter of this year reached NT$194.7 billion (US$6.20 billion), representing a 25 percent annual increase, according to a report released Wednesday by the Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center (IEK).
Of the amount, overseas production accounted for 70.4 percent of the total output value of the quarter, mostly from plants in China, the report shows.
The output value of the first six months was registered at NT$369.7 billion, up 17.3 percent from the year-earlier level.

According to Hsu Ai-ti, an analyst at the center, a drop in the mobile phone sector last year due to Motorola's business downturn was stopped this year thanks to manufacturers' strategies of having dispersed clients and developing private brands.
Increasing output volume of high-end mobile phones has also contributed to the industry's overall performance, Hsu said.
She added that mobile phones and Global Positioning System devices will still be the leading products in the wireless facility sector to boost performance in the third quarter.
Meanwhile, the broadband sector is expected to grow in the third quarter due to a high-season increase in demand for consumer electronic products, according to Hsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County police gearing up to improve social order

TEXT.P: The Taipei County Police Bureau has launched a five-month campaign to wipe out rampant car theft and home burglary as part of its effort to improve social order in the county in northern Taiwan, a spokesman said Wednesday.

According to the spokesman, the campaign, which kicked off Aug. 12 and is slated to run through Jan. 11, 2009, is aimed at cracking down on theft rings that steal cars and motorcycles, and those that break into private homes to steal from or rob them. Vehicle theft and home burglary are the most common complaints of local residents, he noted.

In a bid urging local police authorities to actively handle such cases reported by the public, the bureau will each month award a small colored flag to the best and the worst police precincts in the county, which will be divided into two groups, depending on their workload, he said.

The best-performing police precinct from each group will be awarded a red flag, while the worst-performing precinct will be given a purple one, he explained. Inspection unit chiefs at all of the county's police stations are required to place the flag they are given by the bureau on their desks to allow the public to immediately learn of their performance, he added.
According to the spokesman, there are 15 police precincts and more than 100 substations throughout Taipei County.

He denied allegations that exhibiting the flag would add more pressure to local police officers. Rather, he said, the measure is designed to boost their sense of honor and responsibility to help build a safe and sound living environment for local citizens.
Taipei County is Taiwan's largest administrative district in terms of both size and population.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's taekwondo medal hopeful loses chance to grab gold
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/08 19:22:11 (By Wu Shye-chang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The dream of taekwondo athlete Chu Mu-yen to win a gold medal for Taiwan in the Beijing Olympics was shattered after he was knocked out of the men's under-58kg quarterfinals Wednesday.
After the defeat, Chu said he will formally retire after the end of the Beijing Olympics.
Chu was a gold medalist in the 2004 Athens Olympics, becoming the second Taiwanese athlete and the first male to win an Olympic gold.
Earlier at the Beijing taekwondo contest area, Chu was defeated by Mercedes Yulis Gabriel from the Dominican Republic in the third round by a score of 2 to 3.
Under game rules for taekwondo, Chu will not have the chance to win a medal in Beijing unless Mercedes keeps winning and enters the finals. However, the best Chu can get is the bronze medal.
It was Chu's first time fighting with Mercedes.
Chu said he feels sorry for not being able to win a gold medal for the Chinese Taipei team in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to check if Singapore has passed information on money-laundering

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday that it will conduct a probe into reports that Singapore provided information about suspected money- laundering by members of the former first family as early as last year.
Foreign Affairs Minister Francisco H.L. Ou made the remarks amid reports by China Times, a local newspaper, that Singapore authorities alerted Taiwan in March 2007.

Reports said former first lady Wu Shu-jen transferred money to a bank account of her brother, Wu Ching-mao, in Singapore last year after Chao Chien-ming, former president Chen Shui-bian's son-in-law, was indicted for insider trading in a corruption scandal in 2006.
Wu Ching-mao then closed his bank account and transferred the money to a Swiss bank account under the name of Huang Jui-ching, Chen Shui-bian's daughter-in- law.
Due to the abnormal flow of the funds, Singapore alerted Taiwan via diplomatic channels and the Egmont Group, an international anti-money laundering organization, according to reports.
Ou said the Kuomintang administration was inaugurated on May 20, and the ministry only received a request for judicial assistance from Switzerland last month.

Asked if some officials have withheld information about the suspected money- laundering by the members of the former first family, Ou said "the ministry will be able to track it down if there were files."
Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Javier Ching-shan Hou also said the ministry will "embark on a probe."

Until now, the authorities have believed that a document sent by the Egmont Group to the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) in January of this year was the first to blow the whistle on the suspected money-laundering. In the document the Egmont Group detailed the status of bank accounts created by members of then-President Chen's family in other countries, including the United States, the Cayman Islands, Singapore and Switzerland.

Yeh Sheng-mao, former MJIB head who is a protege of Chen Shui-bian, admitted last weekend that he didn't give the document to State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming due to "negligence" because he was busy with his own retirement (in July).
Yeh is under investigation and he could be charged with obstruction of official duties under the Criminal Code.

A local magazine, Next, cited the contents of the document, reporting last week that Huang Jui-ching had laundered money for the former first family by secretly wiring NT$300 million overseas in 2006, after the exposure of the "state affairs fund" embezzlement case implicating Chen and his wife Wu Shu-jen.
Chen Shui-bian was forced to call a news conference last Thursday in which he admitted that his wife had wired abroad an unspecified amount of money that he had received as campaign contributions.

Chen confessed that he did not faithfully account for the election campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004, but claimed he was unaware that the surplus funds were wired abroad by his wife until early this year.

However, he rejected allegation that the funds wired overseas could be connected to his "state affairs funds" embezzlement case and a recent scandal involving a botched attempt to win Papua New Guinea as a diplomatic ally.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Economics Minister Chao Yao-tung dies at 93

TEXT.P: Former Minister of Economic Affairs Chao Yao-tung -- recognized for his role in helping Taiwan to become one of Asia's "four little dragons" in the 1980s -- died Wednesday at a hostel for the elderly in Taipei at the age of 93.
He is survived by his son and daughter-in-law, who were with him when he passed away peacefully.
Caretakers at the hostel -- the Kang Ning Serviced Apartments -- said Chao had suffered from amnesia in his final years and that he apparently died of organ failure.
Chao held a master's degree from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. From 1949 to 1970, he served as an engineer, manager in charge of design and vice chairman of several textile companies.
From 1971 to 1981, he served as president and later as board chairman of state- owned China Steel Corp. in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

His unique management style and ability to boost the morale of the workforce turned the government enterprise into a huge success. As a compliment, he was given the nickname "Iron Head Chao" and was considered the driving power behind China Steel.

In 1984, he was appointed minister of economic affairs -- a post he held for four years. His contribution to Taiwan's economic development during these years earned himself a niche at the same level as three of his predecessors -- Yin Chung-jung, Li Kuo-ting and Sun Yun-suan -- who are remembered for creating Taiwan's economic miracle.
From 1984 to 1988, Chao served as chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), Taiwan's highest economic planning agency.
After retiring from the CEPD at the age of 73, he became a national policy adviser for the Presidential Office -- a post in which he served until 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT vice chairman to visit Japan

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman Chiang Pin-kung will lead a delegation on a visit to Japan Aug. 25-27 in another effort to assure Japan that Taiwan does not favor its relations with China over those with Japan.

It will be the second delegation from Taiwan to visit Japan within a month. Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng returned from there Aug. 13, where he tried to clarify Taiwan's firm stance on its friendly ties with Japan.
Since the KMT took the reins of government May 20, Taiwan's efforts to warm up relations with China have prompted Japan to express concern that Taiwan-Japan relations might deteriorate.

In addition, Japan was surprised by the Taiwanese government's tough stance over a recent fishing boat collision incident near the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands that are claimed by Taiwan, Japan and China.
A Taiwanese fishing boat sank after colliding with a Japanese patrol vessel in June, sparking a diplomatic spat.
Taiwan maintained solid relations with Japan under Taiwan's previous eight-year Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration.
In recent years, Japan has offered a number of preferential policies to Taiwan, including visa-free privileges for Taiwanese tourists.
To allay Japan's concerns, President Ma Ying-jeou has repeatedly said that thawing Taiwan-China relations will not affect the friendship between Taiwan and Japan.
KMT Legislator Lee Chia-chin, a member of the delegation, told CNA that it is appropriate for Chiang to lead the delegation.

He noted that Chiang also serves as the chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , which is responsible for handling relations with China in the absence of formal ties between Taipei and Beijing.
During his visit, Chiang will represent Ma, to make it clear to Japan that Taiwan's foreign policy does not completely lean toward China and that Ma is not against Japan, Lee noted.

Meanwhile, Lee suggested that John C.T. Feng, a retired diplomat who was tapped as Taiwan's representative to Japan a day earlier, visit Japan with the delegation to learn more about Japan's Diet and political situation.

According to Lee, the delegation has planned the visit at the invitation of the Japan Interchange Association, a quasi-official organization authorized to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tax revenue down in Taipei City

TEXT.P: Taipei City collected NT$30.7 billion (US$97.77 million) in tax revenue in the first seven months of this year -- a fall of about 8 percent, or some NT$2.6 billion, year on year, the municipal tax office reported Wednesday.

Tax officials ascribed the drop to a cooling housing market and predicted that the market will continue to remain sluggish in the coming two or three years despite the optimistic view maintained by construction companies about the sector's prospects.
"Taiwan's property market, particularly Taipei's housing market, has not yet hit rock bottom," said Hsieh Song-fang, director of the Taipei Tax Office.

As a result of the slowing economy, caused by growing inflationary pressure brought about by high oil and consumer product prices and a plummeting stock market, the city's tax revenue for the whole of this year is also expected to decline from the 2007 level, with land added value taxes contributing the biggest drop, officials said.
Taipei, in northern Taiwan, is the country's largest city.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former military prison turned into rehearsal space for artists

TEXT.P: A former military prison and courthouse located in Taipei that is now the Jingmei Human Rights Memorial Park has been transformed into an artistic rehearsal space, giving grace to the old compound that was once used to incarcerate political prisoners.

At present, the world-renowned Cloud Gate Dance Theatre is rehearsing its latest work, "Whisper of Flowers, " for the world premiere in Taiwan Sept. 12, making the once-grim detention center resound to the cello music of Bach.
Since a fire destroyed their previous base in the Taipei County village of Bali in February, the dancers have been using the performance hall at the Jingmei Human Rights Memorial Park to rehearse.

As rehearsal places are in short supply in Taiwan, Lin Hwai-min, Cloud Gate's founder and choreographer, has suggested that the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) designate the memorial park hall as a permanent rehearsal space for artists, a proposal that was accepted by former CCA Minister Wang Tuoh.
"The government has not really made overall plans for domestic cultural development, " said Lin. "Can we win at the Olympic Games if we training just before the events?" he asked rhetorically.

The Jingmei Human Rights Memorial Park, located in southern Taipei, was originally a facility where political prisoners were tried and incarcerated by the authoritarian Kuomintang regime during the martial law period from 1949-1987.
Many politicians in the then-opposition forces served terms in the military prison, such as former Vice President Annette Lu and incumbent Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu.
In 2002, the CCA designated the desolate compound a historic landmark and started construction of the human rights memorial park, which was formally opened to the public Dec. 12 last year.
It is Taiwan's second human rights park. The first one was established on Green Island, 33 km off Taiwan's southeastern coast, where political prisoners were also detained during martial law.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taekwondo athlete grabs Taiwan's third bronze medal in Beijing
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/08 20:49:21 (By Wu Shye-chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese taekwondo medal hopeful Chu Mu-yen took Taiwan's third bronze medal of the 2008 Beijing Olympics Wednesday in the men' under-58 kg category of the event.
The Athens Olympics gold medalist defeated Chutchawal Khawlaor of Thailand in the third round 4-2 after they had tied at the end of the second round.

In the earlier quarterfinals, Chu was knocked out by Dominican rival Mercedes Yulis Gabriel, losing his chance to retain the title and breaking Chinese Taipei's glimmer of hope of grabbing Olympic gold in the event.
The bronze is Chu's second Olympic medal. He became the first Taiwanese male athlete to win an Olympic gold in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan fails to win medal in women's taekwondo
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/20/08 20:53:54 (By Wu Shye-chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taekwondo athlete Yang Shu-chun failed to win a medal for the Chinese Taipei team at the Beijing Olympics after being knocked out of the women's under-49 kg event Wednesday.

Yang, the champion in the women's under-49kg class in the Asian taekwondo tournament in April, made her Olympic debut in Beijing. She was one of Chinese Taipei's medal hopefuls in the Olympics, along with her boyfriend Chu Mu-yen, who won a gold medal for taekwondo at the 2004 Athens Olympics and took a bronze in Beijing earlier in the day.
In the bronze medal fight, Yang was defeated 3-2 by Daynellis Montejo of Cuba, who won by a point in an extra round after the score was tied 2-2 at the end of the third round.
A despondent Yang was placed fifth in the category.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Obama' s Ads in Key States Go on Attack
Senator Barack Obama has started a sustained and hard-hitting advertising campaign against Senator John McCain in states that will be vital this fall, painting Mr. McCain in a series of commercials as disconnected from the economic struggles of the middle class.
The Wall Street Journal: Rising Cost of Debt Stokes Fears On Freddie's Prospects
Freddie Mac was forced to offer unusually rich terms to investors in a $3 billion auction of its debt, raising anew concerns about the health of the mortgage giant, a vital prop for the U.S. housing market.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Citizens' U.S. Border Crossings Tracked
The federal government has been using its system of border checkpoints to greatly expand a database on travelers entering the country by collecting information on all U.S. citizens crossing by land, compiling data that will be stored for 15 years and may be used in criminal and intelligence investigations.
The Washington Times:Obama courts military voters
Sen. Barack Obama, edging away from a long-held position, tacitly acknowledged the success of the Iraq troop-surge strategy during an appearance Tuesday before the country's largest organization of combat veterans.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT to refer bill on officials with suspicious assets

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) will submit a draft bill aimed at punishing government officials who cannot explain the origin of their suspicious assets for screening in the legislature's next session, a KMT official said Wednesday.

Lin I-shih, director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee and also a lawmaker, said that to meet high public expectations that corrupt officials will be effectively penalized, the ruling party will work out the draft by late August to allow it to be reviewed as a priority bill by lawmakers in the coming session, which usually begins in early September.
According to Lin, the KMT will mainly adopt a version drawn up by the Ministry of Justice as an initial version of the bill.

He made the comments while answering questions from reporters at a time when a high-profile money-laundering scandal embroiling former President Chen Shui-bian and his family has caught the attention of the public since it was brought to light last weekend.
Lin said his party is now poised to push the bill through the legislature as soon as possible by listing it as the top priority issue for discussion on the agenda of the new legislative session.

The KMT has come under strong attack by some media outlets that have blamed the party for the long-delayed passage of such a bill, as it now controls more than two-thirds of the 113 seats in the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei gets spot in new Monopoly board game

TEXT.P: Taipei City has been selected by an online poll as one of the 22 cities to be named in the soon-to-be-launched world edition of the popular board game Monopoly, the U.S.-based game maker's Taiwan branch said Wednesday.

The iconic game is expected to raise the international profile of Taiwan's capital once it is launched Aug. 26 in more than 50 countries in 37 languages, said Judy Chen, marketing manager of Hasbro Taiwan.
Worldwide fans of the game cast more than 5.6 million votes early this year for 70 world-class cities, which determined 20 of the 22 cities featured in the game, Chen went on.

The two additional cities were selected in a bonus vote from among 20 cities, with Taipei and Gdynia the top two winners eligible to appear in the first-ever World edition of the game, according to Chen.
It is the first time the company has allowed fans to decide on such aspects of the game, she said.

"We are thrilled that the first-ever global game board includes an interesting mix of cities that showcases the dynamic cultures, sights and history of the planet, " said Helen Martin, vice president of global marketing for the Monopoly brand.
The game, invented in 1935, has been launched in 81 countries in 37 languages, Hasbro Taiwan said, estimating that more than 1 billion people have played it.

The complete list of cities represented in the game is Montreal, Riga, Cape Town, Belgrade, Paris, Jerusalem, Hong Kong, Beijing, London, New York, Sydney, Vancouver, Shanghai, Rome, Toronto, Kiev, Istanbul, Athens, Barcelona, Tokyo, Taipei and Gdynia.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Red Leaf Cup Little League Invitational to begin Aug. 23

TEXT.P: The five-day 2008 Red Leaf Cup International Little League Baseball Invitational Tournament will begin Aug. 23, organizers said Wednesday.
The tournament, held by the Taitung County Sports Development Fund, will pit 34 teams against one another at four baseball diamonds in the eastern Taiwan county.
Of the 34 teams, four will be from South Korea, while 11 will be from Taitung County, with the remaining 19 coming from eight other Taiwanese cities and counties.
Conspicuous among the Taitung County teams will be the relaunched Red Leaf (Hongye) team of the namesake elementary school that made history in 1969 by defeating a Little League world champion.

During that match played in Taipei, the aboriginal schoolboys trounced the Little League world champions -- Japan's Wakayama -- 7A-0, in a nine-inning game. The nationwide excitement the victory aroused turned baseball into Taiwan's national sport and set the stage for Taiwan to win 13 World Little League championships between 1969 and 1982.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-vice transport minister to head China Steel

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has approved the nomination of Chang Chia-chu, a former vice transportation and communications minister, to serve as chairman of Kaohsiung- based China Steel Corp., Cabinet officials said Wednesday.
The officials expressed hope that Chang will make use of his management abilities to further improve the company's performance.
Chang, 58, who holds a doctorate from Purdue University in the United States, will take over from Lin Wen-yuan.

Chang served as director of the Institute of Transportation under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) in 1995 and was promoted by then- Transport Minister Liu Chao-shiuan, who is now premier.
Chang served as vice MOTC head for a decade until 2005 before becoming president of Chung Hua University.
Although China Steel has been privatized, the government still controls more than 20 percent of the stakes. As the biggest shareholder, it has a substantial say in the company's management.
The company's board of directors will hold a meeting Aug. 27 in which Chang's nomination is expected to be approved.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kidney transplant recipient encourages other patients

TEXT.P: A young woman who received a kidney transplant at the Tzu Chi General Hospital's Dalin Branch in Chiayi County in September 2003 has become a volunteer at the hospital, encouraging patients waiting for kidney transplants to keep their hopes up.
Lee Rou-yi, who is now third-year student at the Chung Shan Medical University in Taichung City, encourages patients to have faith while waiting for a suitable kidney to become available.
"If there is a chance for a kidney transplant, don't let it slip by, " said Lee Wednesday to an 18-year-old boy who is awaiting a kidney at the hospital.

Lee said she was diagnosed with urine occult blood when she was in sixth grade. However, she did not take the diagnosis seriously until constant poor appetite and bloody urine led to a kidney biopsy and the discovery of renal failure.
Despite this, she refused dialysis until one evening six years ago when she suffered an emergency and was rushed to hospital for the dialysis treatment.
"I took 20 steroid pills every day during my stay at the hospital, with side effects such as hair loss and itching," said Lee.

"The process of waiting for a kidney did not go very well, " she went on, noting that in July 2003, the hospital notified her of a potential donor kidney, which later proved an unsuitable match. Two months later, a suitable kidney was ready for her and the surgery was very successful, said Lee, stating that "being able to have a kidney transplant is the most wonderful thing that ever happened to me."

DOC.HEADLINE: Indigenous father and son to take graduate courses together

TEXT.P: A father and son of the indigenous Tsou tribe of Chiayi County in southern Taiwan will pursue master degrees in the same school, holding the same ambition of protecting tribal cultures with better knowledge.

Chuang Hsin-sheng, the 57-year-old father, and his son Chuang Chih-cheng, 28, will begin their study at National University of Tainan's Graduate Institute of Taiwan Culture in southern Taiwan during the new academic year.
The father, a respected elder tribesman, told CNA that he took the entrance admission exam for three consecutive years and finally passed it this year.

He served as the chief executive of officer of the Cultural and Art Development Fund for the Tsou in Chaiyi County. He is also a Tsou culture guide for visitors in the county and has made efforts to compile and organize cultural and historical documents.

The Tsou, numbering more than 6,300, are distributed in central and southern Taiwan. They are know for having a strict tribal organization in which men's meeting houses, farming, fishing, and hunting rituals play key roles in passing on education and beliefs.

Proud of the culture of the tribe, Chuang expressed hope that the graduate training will help him do a better job of establishing an archive of the tribal culture and art and revitalize and preserve its language, in the hope that society will gain a better understanding of his tribe.
The son, a teacher at Dapang Elementary School in Chiayi County, took the exam twice and passed the second time.
He said he hopes that the studies will better his teaching skills and resources in delivering knowledge about the tribe's culture to the school's students, most of whom are also Tsou.

They are the first father and son pair to study in the graduate institute since it was established 11 years ago, a school spokesman said, adding that the institute has encouraged the father to enhance training and theories in field survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumer group urges specifying degradable levels of toilet paper

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation suggested Wednesday that the government develop a new national standard that clearly categorizes biodegradable levels of toilet paper and facial tissues and that all manufacturers strengthen labeling on their products, including providing biodegradable level.

According to a survey conducted by the foundation between Aug. 12-17, of 1,340 respondents, 77 percent of the respondents said they favored adopting the practice of flushing away used toilet paper, with 55 percent of those proponents saying they already did so, and another 23 percent of the respondents expressing their opposition to doing so.
The survey was conducted in light of the controversy over the appropriateness of urging people to flush their used toilet paper instead of placing it in waste bins as a way to save on disposal costs.

As toilet paper is made mainly from wood pulp, it breaks down easily in water, while facial tissues are made not only out of wood pulp but also other paper additives--such as paper wet-strength agents--which make it difficult to break down, said Wu Chia-cheng, a foundation member and professor in the Department of Chemistry at National Taiwan Normal University.

Generally speaking, used toilet paper can be disposed of by flushing, Wu said, but given the fact that it is difficult to differentiate toilet paper from facial tissues by their package appearances, manufacturers of the products should improve packaging and labeling of their products to highlight the differences between the two types of paper products and enable consumers to distinguish the difference easily, he added.

Taiwan's household sewer connection rate, as of April, had reached only 18.38 percent, Wu said, adding that toilet paper should only be flushed down in areas where toilets are connected to sewage treatment systems or where sceptic tanks are emptied frequently, in order to avoid negatively impacting the environment.

Toilet paper in many other countries is made from short-fiber pulp and free from bactericides, as well as whitening and bleaching agents, Wu noted. He said this kind of paper is the main food source for microscopic organisms that can aid in pollution control by metabolizing organic matter in sewage and help with environmental protection.

He added that the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection, under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, should formulate criteria for the classification of degradable levels of toilet paper products so as to help consumers distinguish products that can be flushed in toilets from those that cannot.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prostate cancer mortality rate climbing

TEXT.P: The occurrence rate and mortality rate of prostate cancer among Taiwanese males has increased over the past few years, a doctor at the Department of Health's (DOH's) Keelung Hospital in northern Taiwan said Wednesday.

Hsu Wen-chang, a urologist at the hospital, said that according to DOH statistics, prostate cancer ranked No. 10 as cause of death in 1994 and No. 7 in 2001, accounting for for 2.4 percent and 3.6 percent of the total deaths, respectively.

Hsu urged men aged over 50 years of age to have rectal touch and prostate specific antigen (PSA) tests annually for early detection and treatment, which can increase a five-year survival rate to 90 percent.

The cause of prostate cancer is still unclear. However, age, heredity and diet are viewed as important risk factors, said Hsu, adding that men with a family history of prostate cancer should undergo examinations from the age of 40.

According to Hsu, symptoms of early-stage prostate cancer include micturition, nocturia and small urinary stream due to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) . Symptoms of the later stages include bone pain or paralysis of the lower limbs due to metastasis, he added.

Hsu noted that rectal touch, prostate specific antigen (PSA) test, and prostate ultrasound (TRUS) are the current diagnostic methods, with treatments including surgery, hormone therapy, radiation therapy and chemotherapy.
Hsu said an early stage prostate cancer patient who undergoes laparoscopic radical prostatectomy now has a much better chance of recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Forestry Bureau solicits applications for wildlife films

TEXT.P: The Forestry Bureau has launched a program aimed at soliciting applications from people wishing to shoot wildlife films in Taiwan in an effort to present the country's natural beauty and ecology, bureau officials said Wednesday.
The purpose of the program is to encourage individuals and civic groups to submit applications before Sept. 15 to shoot documentary films on the country's species and habitats, the officials added.

The bureau under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture will provide a maximum of NT$1 million (US$31,862.35) in subsidies per year to individuals and civic groups whose applications are approved by the bureau. The subsidy period ceiling is two years, according to the officials.
A total of 40 films were screened during the first Ecological Film Festival in 2006, which was the first of its kind launched by the bureau.
The festival is designed to allow the public to gain a better understanding of the country's biological and ecological diversity.
The Forestry Bureau is tasked with helping preserve ecological conservation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's first group of professional indigenous porters certified

TEXT.P: Thirteen Bunun aboriginal people living in the mountains of eastern Taiwan were certified Wednesday by Taitung county government as professional porters and guides for mountain climbing parties, making them the first group of officially certified aboriginal porters in the country.

According to the county's Haiduan township office, which issued the certification, the office began to recruit and train professional porters last September as part of efforts to help tourists enjoy the mountains more easily and to increase the Bunun people's employment opportunities.

Haiduan, located in the northern region of Taitung, has many scenic tourist spots and attractions, including forest-covered gorges along the South Cross- Island Highway, hot springs in the mountains and the scenic Chiaming Lake, which have attracted thousands of mountain hikers over past years, officials said.

Among the Bunun porters, the eldest is the 58-year-old leader of Lidao village, Yu A-yun, while the youngest is aged 20. All were required to pass a tough training program, including climbing up to Chiaming Lake -- Taiwan's second- highest mountain lake at the altitude of 3,310 meters -- with 30 kg of gear on their backs.

Other training included learning their Bunun ancestors' wisdom in how to treat nature and the environment, and learning how to deal with ice and snow on Jade Mountain, the country's highest peak, the officials noted.

Chiu Chun-yen, who is in charge of tourism and leisure agriculture affairs at the office, said he hopes the professional porters, who know the mountains and forests in the township intimately, will help attract more tourists to Haiduan, home to 4,500 people, most of whom are Bunun, one of Taiwan's 14 officially recognized indigenous tribes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Olympic baseball team defeats Canada 6-5 to place 5th

TEXT.P: Taiwan's national baseball team pocketed its second victory Wednesday in the 2009 Beijing Olympic Games, defeating Canada 6-5 in a run-off competition.
With a record of two wins and four losses, the Taiwanese team, officially called Chinese Taipei, placed fifth in the tournament.
The game against Canada lasted 12 innings, as a 5-5 tie at the end of the ninth required extended play.
Chinese Taipei earned one run in the top of the first, but starting pitcher Chen Wei-yin allowed the opposing team two runs in the same inning.
In the top of the second, Chinese Taipei scored four more runs, followed by one run by Canada for a 5-3 lead by Chinese Taipei.

Chinese Taipei's starting pitcher was relieved by Pan Wei-lun in the fourth inning after Canada scored another run. Pan pitched three- and-a-half innings before being replaced by Ni Fu-teh in the seventh when Canada's Stubby Clapp hit a solo home run for a 5-5 tie, which continued until the end of the ninth, requiring a run-off.

Ni pitched four-and-a-half innings until the 11th, allowing Canada no runs, while Canada also held its line until the 12th, when Chinese Taipei hitter Chiang Chih-hsien contributed a timely hit -- with the first and second bases loaded -- to send a teammate back to home base for a 6-5 lead.
Pitcher Chang Chia-chih took over from Ni in the bottom of the 12th and together they struck out three Canadian hitters, ending the match 6-5.

In its previous matches, Chinese Taipei won only its first match against the Netherlands 5-0. It lost the four subsequent games to Japan 1-6, to Cuba 0-1, to South Korea 8-9 and to the United States 2-4, dashing the team's hopes of coming home with an Olympic medal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Typhoon Nuri expected to bring heavy rainfall to southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: The rim of Typhoon Nuri had reached waters off Eluanpi on the southernmost tip of Taiwan late Wednesday, but unless the medium typhoon diverts sharply northward, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) will not issue a land warning for the storm, weathermen said late that evening.

The CWB issued a sea warning for Nuri the previous morning, but weathermen said the typhoon took a more northerly track than originally expected, probably because of the influence of the area's topography. As a result, its strength is expected to weaken and unless the typhoon take a more northerly course, no land warning will be issued.

At 8 p.m. Wednesday, Nuri was centered 260 kilometers south of Eluanpi, packing maximum sustained winds of 144 km and moving northwesterly at 15 kph toward Taiwan-controlled Dongsha Island (Pratas) in the South China Sea and the southern part of the Taiwan Strait.

Chen Yi-liang, a section chief at the CWB's Weather Forecast Center, said if Nuri takes a more northerly course, the bureau will not rule out the possibility of issuing a land warning for the typhoon.

According to Chen, Nuri will be closest to Taiwan from midnight Wednesday through Thursday. Ships navigating or operating in the Bashi Channel, waters surrounding the Dongsha Islands and the Taiwan Strait should keep alert, Chen said, adding that residents in eastern and southeastern Taiwan and Hengchun area as well as in mountainous regions in southern Taiwan should take precautionary measures against downpours.
Taiwan sustained heavy human casualties and agricultural losses when Tropical Storm Kalmaegi struck the island in July with torrential rains that caused serious flash flooding in some areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumer group urges specifying degradable levels of toilet paper

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation suggested Wednesday that the government develop a new national standard that clearly categorizes biodegradable levels of toilet paper and facial tissues and that all manufacturers strengthen labeling on their products, including providing biodegradable level.

According to a survey conducted by the foundation between Aug. 12-17, of 1,340 respondents, 77 percent of the respondents said they favored adopting the practice of flushing away used toilet paper, with 55 percent of those proponents saying they already did so, and another 23 percent of the respondents expressing their opposition to doing so.
The survey was conducted in light of the controversy over the appropriateness of urging people to flush their used toilet paper instead of placing it in waste bins as a way to save on disposal costs.

As toilet paper is made mainly from wood pulp, it breaks down easily in water, while facial tissues are made not only out of wood pulp but also other paper additives--such as paper wet-strength agents--which make it difficult to break down, said Wu Chia-cheng, a foundation member and professor in the Department of Chemistry at National Taiwan Normal University.

Generally speaking, used toilet paper can be disposed of by flushing, Wu said, but given the fact that it is difficult to differentiate toilet paper from facial tissues by their package appearances, manufacturers of the products should improve packaging and labeling of their products to highlight the differences between the two types of paper products and enable consumers to distinguish the difference easily, he added.

Taiwan's household sewer connection rate, as of April, had reached only 18.38 percent, Wu said, adding that toilet paper should only be flushed down in areas where toilets are connected to sewage treatment systems or where sceptic tanks are emptied frequently, in order to avoid negatively impacting the environment.

Toilet paper in many other countries is made from short-fiber pulp and free from bactericides, as well as whitening and bleaching agents, Wu noted. He said this kind of paper is the main food source for microscopic organisms that can aid in pollution control by metabolizing organic matter in sewage and help with environmental protection.

He added that the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection, under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, should formulate criteria for the classification of degradable levels of toilet paper products so as to help consumers distinguish products that can be flushed in toilets from those that cannot.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prostate cancer mortality rate climbing

TEXT.P: The occurrence rate and mortality rate of prostate cancer among Taiwanese males has increased over the past few years, a doctor at the Department of Health's (DOH's) Keelung Hospital in northern Taiwan said Wednesday.

Hsu Wen-chang, a urologist at the hospital, said that according to DOH statistics, prostate cancer ranked No. 10 as cause of death in 1994 and No. 7 in 2001, accounting for for 2.4 percent and 3.6 percent of the total deaths, respectively.

Hsu urged men aged over 50 years of age to have rectal touch and prostate specific antigen (PSA) tests annually for early detection and treatment, which can increase a five-year survival rate to 90 percent.

The cause of prostate cancer is still unclear. However, age, heredity and diet are viewed as important risk factors, said Hsu, adding that men with a family history of prostate cancer should undergo examinations from the age of 40.

According to Hsu, symptoms of early-stage prostate cancer include micturition, nocturia and small urinary stream due to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) . Symptoms of the later stages include bone pain or paralysis of the lower limbs due to metastasis, he added.

Hsu noted that rectal touch, prostate specific antigen (PSA) test, and prostate ultrasound (TRUS) are the current diagnostic methods, with treatments including surgery, hormone therapy, radiation therapy and chemotherapy.
Hsu said an early stage prostate cancer patient who undergoes laparoscopic radical prostatectomy now has a much better chance of recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Forestry Bureau solicits applications for wildlife films

TEXT.P: The Forestry Bureau has launched a program aimed at soliciting applications from people wishing to shoot wildlife films in Taiwan in an effort to present the country's natural beauty and ecology, bureau officials said Wednesday.
The purpose of the program is to encourage individuals and civic groups to submit applications before Sept. 15 to shoot documentary films on the country's species and habitats, the officials added.

The bureau under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture will provide a maximum of NT$1 million (US$31,862.35) in subsidies per year to individuals and civic groups whose applications are approved by the bureau. The subsidy period ceiling is two years, according to the officials.
A total of 40 films were screened during the first Ecological Film Festival in 2006, which was the first of its kind launched by the bureau.
The festival is designed to allow the public to gain a better understanding of the country's biological and ecological diversity.
The Forestry Bureau is tasked with helping preserve ecological conservation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Olympic baseball team defeats Canada 6-5 to place 5th

TEXT.P: Taiwan's national baseball team pocketed its second victory Wednesday in the 2009 Beijing Olympic Games, defeating Canada 6-5 in a run-off competition.
With a record of two wins and four losses, the Taiwanese team, officially called Chinese Taipei, placed fifth in the tournament.
The game against Canada lasted 12 innings, as a 5-5 tie at the end of the ninth required extended play.
Chinese Taipei earned one run in the top of the first, but starting pitcher Chen Wei-yin allowed the opposing team two runs in the same inning.
In the top of the second, Chinese Taipei scored four more runs, followed by one run by Canada for a 5-3 lead by Chinese Taipei.

Chinese Taipei's starting pitcher was relieved by Pan Wei-lun in the fourth inning after Canada scored another run. Pan pitched three- and-a-half innings before being replaced by Ni Fu-teh in the seventh when Canada's Stubby Clapp hit a solo home run for a 5-5 tie, which continued until the end of the ninth, requiring a run-off.

Ni pitched four-and-a-half innings until the 11th, allowing Canada no runs, while Canada also held its line until the 12th, when Chinese Taipei hitter Chiang Chih-hsien contributed a timely hit -- with the first and second bases loaded -- to send a teammate back to home base for a 6-5 lead.
Pitcher Chang Chia-chih took over from Ni in the bottom of the 12th and together they struck out three Canadian hitters, ending the match 6-5.

In its previous matches, Chinese Taipei won only its first match against the Netherlands 5-0. It lost the four subsequent games to Japan 1-6, to Cuba 0-1, to South Korea 8-9 and to the United States 2-4, dashing the team's hopes of coming home with an Olympic medal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 21, or the 21st day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1754: Scottish engineer William Murdoch is born. He pioneered the use of coal- gas for lighting in 1792 while working with James Watt and Matthew Bouton on their steam engines.
1902: Manufacturer Martin Leland starts his luxury car venture by naming his new automobile after Antoine de la Motte Cadillac, the French colonial administrator and Detroit's founding father.
1908: Orville Wright, American aviation pioneer, and his brother Wilbur make the first military aircraft for the United States.
1930: Princess Margaret, sister of British Queen Elizabeth II, is born.
1944: Representatives from China, Britain, Russia and the United States meet at Dumbarton Oaks near Washington, D.C. to plan for the formation of the United Nations.
1937: The Treaty of Non-Aggression between China and the Soviet Union is signed in Nanking.
1959: The Baghdad Pact is formally renamed the Central Treaty Organization (CENTO) following Iraq's withdrawal earlier in the year.
1959: Hawaii becomes the 50th state of the United States.
1963: South Vietnam declares martial law after raids on Buddhist pagodas and the arrest of hundreds of Buddhist monks.
1976: Prince Maphevu Harry Dlamini, prime minister of the Kingdom of Swaziland, accompanied by Madame Dlamini and a party of eight, arrives in the Republic of China for a seven-day visit.
1982: King Sobhuza II of Swaziland dies at the age of 83. He was one of the world's longest-reigning monarchs, having been on the throne sine 1921.
1982: Republic of China Economics Minister William Y.T. Chao announces the partial lifting of an import ban on 842 types of Japanese consumer goods.
1983: Benigno Aquino, leader of the anti-Marcos faction in the Philippines, is gunned down as he steps onto the asphalt at Manila Airport after returning from a three-year sojourn in the United States. He was 51.
1984: A massive demonstration is held in Manila to mark the first anniversary of the assassination of Benigno Aquino.
1985: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Robert C. Chien as the new finance minister, succeeding Loh Jen-kong who resigned on Aug. 15.
1986: A cloud of toxic gas is released from the volcanic Lake Nyos, near Wum in northwest Cameroon, killing more than 1,200 people.
1990: An ROC Air Force B-1900 air transport plane crashes in Tungshih Village in Yunlin County, killing all 16 people aboard, including three major-generals and nine colonels.
1990: The Indian Parliament approves presidential rule in Jammu and Kashmir and gives the armed forces special powers in the riot-torn state.
1991: President Mikhail Gorbachev arrives back in Moscow after the collapse of a coup attempt by hardliners.
1991: Latvia declares its independence from the Soviet Union.
1997: Abdur Rahim Gaffurzai, the newly appointed prime minister of Afghanistan, is killed along with 13 others in a plane crash.
1999: Over 96 percent of the Kuomintang's party delegates vote to support Vice President Lien Chan as the party's candidate in the following spring's presidential election.
2000: Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui proposes the establishment of an Asian monetary fund to promote economic cooperation in Asia.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his Gambian counterpart Yahya Jammeh sign a joint communique pledging to continue enhancing close cooperation between the two countries.
2001: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterates while meeting with visiting Paraguayan Foreign Minister Jose Antonio Moreno Ruffinelli that the ROC government will abide by the memorandum of trade and investment signed by the ROC and Paraguay to further cement the established ties between Taipei and Asuncion.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to carry out, but when you once try to carry out a thing you must never give it up until you have done it thoroughly and well."

DOC.HEADLINE: Rains expected around most of Taiwan in wake of typhoon

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) forecasted rains around most parts of Taiwan Thursday as it lifted a sea warning for Typhoon Nuri.

CWB forecasters said the weather over Taiwan will be unstable Thursday and Friday due to Nuri's outer edges, with showers expected all day in the southeastern and southern regions and thunder showers expected in the afternoon in the central and northern regions.
These areas are also likely to experience heavy rains or extremely heavy rains, the weathermen said.

At 8 a.m., Typhoon Nuri was centered 140 km east-southeast of the Pratas Islands in the South China Sea, packing maximum sustained winds of 137 kph and moving northwesterly at 17-14 kph toward Hong Kong, CWB data showed.

Despite Nuri's departure from Taiwan's territorial waters, the bureau advised ships operating in the Bashih Channel and waters surrounding the Pratas Islands to remain watchful of high waves caused by the typhoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
MOFA completes internal investigation of ex-president case

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it has completed its internal investigation of the handling of money-laundering allegations involving former President Chen Shui-bian and will submit its report to its disciplinary committee.

"The internal investigation found that the related officials were indeed guilty of dereliction of duty, therefore, Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou has given instructions for the case to be sent to the ministry's merit evaluation and disciplinary committee, " said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen at a regular press briefing.
"The case will also be referred to the Control Yuan, as will Taiwan's representative to Switzerland, Kuanping George Liu, " the spokesman said.
Liu, who tendered his resignation July 29, is now in the process of handing over his duties, as his newly appointed replacement Hsieh Fa-dah prepares to assume office.

Since Liu was a political appointee, his role in the case will be determined by the Control Yuan, the MOFA spokesman said, but he declined to reveal how many MOFA officials had come under investigation.

According to Henry Chen, Ou was enraged at the fact that foreign ministry officials had not been watchful enough, as alertness and a sense of judgment are emphasized in the basic training of career diplomats.

"We think they were not alert enough, but we do not think they deliberately procrastinated on the matter, " Henry Chen said in response to reporters' questions on whether the delivery of a letter from the Swiss Confederations Department of Justice seeking Taiwan's assistance in probing the case had been delayed.

The letter, dated June 16, was received by the representative office in early July, but staffers there allegedly sat on it for nearly a month before forwarding it to the MOFA, which later sent it to the Ministry of Justice.
Chen said the foreign ministry will also prepare a statement for all its representative offices and embassies to explain the money-laundering scandal, in a bid to protect the nation's image.
Foreign Minister Ou has instructed us to formulate a single statement for damage control, as our national image has been marred in the international media's reports on the case," the spokesman said.

"We will direct all our embassies and representative offices to use the uniform statement to explain the matter, " he said. "The foreign ministry does not want to see the country's image keep being hurt."
Former President Chen and his wife Wu Shu-jen have been listed as suspects in a high-profile money laundering case and have been barred from leaving the country.

Other suspects in the case are Wu's elder brother Wu Ching-mao, who has also been prohibited from leaving the country, and the ex-president's son Chen Chih- chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching, who have left the country but would have to report their movements if they return to Taiwan, according to prosecutors.

Chen admitted last Thursday that he did not faithfully report the election campaign expenses from his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004, but claimed he was unaware, until early this year, that the balance of the funds had been wired abroad by his wife.
He rejected the idea that the money wired overseas could be connected to a "state affairs fund" embezzlement case and a botched attempt by Taiwan to win Papua New Guinea as a diplomatic ally.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cattle embryo transplants raise pregnancy rate and milk production

TEXT.P: A set of refined cattle embryo transplant techniques has helped to raise the pregnancy rates among sexually mature cows and to increase their milk production, according to the government-run Livestock Research Institute (LRI).

The techniques were first developed by foreign animal husbandry experts, and the institute later improved and tested the effects in Taiwan, said researchers at the institute, an affiliate of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture.

Yang Der-uei, an assistant researcher at the institute, explained that the technique involves collecting ova from cows during the cooler seasons -- usually November to April in Taiwan -- and transplanting the artificially fertilized embryos into the same cows or others in summer.

"The reason for separating the ovum collection and embryo implantation is that milk cows tend to have lower conception rates in summer, " said Yang. "Through the help of in-vitro fertilization and cryostorage of early-stage embryos, conception rates in summer can be raised by 17.2 percent to 36.4 percent."
Milk cows have to remain in a state of pregnancy in order to continuously produce milk, thus higher pregnancy rates mean higher milk production capability, said one researcher.

The LRI said it has conducted two stages of technology transfer during the past two years and the results have shown some promising signs. The institute hopes that the techniques can be transferred to ordinary dairy farmers in the coming years, according to an LRI official.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices plunge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 122.42 points, or 1.73 percent, to close at 6,918.48.

Suffering a drop from the gains of the previous day, the local bourse opened at 6,989.94 and fluctuated between 7,017.1 and 6,918.48. A total of 3.31 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$74.07 billion (US$2.36 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 3.9 percent. Construction issues declined 3.6 percent, banking and financial shares dropped 2.3 percent, foodstuff issues lost 2 percent, machinery and electronics shares shed 1.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares were down 1.2 percent, paper and pulp issues fell 1.1 percent, and cement stocks dropped 0.7 percent.

Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$8.72 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fewer children entering elementary schools: Taipei city government

TEXT.P: A total of 24,452 children are expected to be admitted into elementary schools in Taipei City this fall, nearly 4,000 less than the previous year, the Education Department under the Taipei city government reported Thursday.
The number of 2008 first graders marked the greatest decline in this group in 20 years, the Education Department said.
Given the declining number of pre-school children, the number of first grade classes is also expected to shrink -- by 133 classes this fall -- a department official said.
"Only 12 elementary schools around Taipei City are expected to have full recruitment this year," said the official.
Attributing the obvious decline in enrollments mainly to the country's declining birth rate in recent years, the official said the figure is forecast to drop further next year.
Meanwhile, he said, declining enrollment means that there is a need for fewer first-graded teachers, whose numbers are expected to decrease by 226 citywide this year.

To tackle the issue, the city's Education Department has several resolutions, including cutting the number of first-grade classes and helping "out of work" teachers to become on-campus academic consultants or research teachers.
As to whether elementary schools in Taipei City should be merged or closed, the official said it is too early at this stage to speculate on such questions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese artist to hold exhibition in Britain
DOC.DATELINE: London, Aug. 20 (CNA) 08/21/08 16:55:50 (By Jennifer Huang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Feng-lu Milee Lee, a Taiwanese artist living and working in Birmingham, will launch an exhibition Aug. 27 at the New Art Gallery Walsall in central Britain, under the sponsorship of the Arts Council of England.

Lee, one of five artists and the only non-native English one to receive the council's grants to artists this summer, said Wednesday that each recipient will be givenG5,000 and the option to choose a sponsored institution that offers workshops, exhibition facilities and other assistance for implementing art projects.
The program is aimed at encouraging the creation of art, bringing art into communities, encouraging the public to get involved in art activities and promoting the acceptance of all forms of art.

Lee, who has picked the New Art Gallery Walsall as the venue for her "Sunshine Mountain" exhibition, said she has already installed three round pieces of turf enclosed by white fences in the art gallery. This is to create an area with the best mountain views from any modern downtown property, which would allow visitors feel close to nature and to rest on the turf, she added.
During the exhibition, Lee will portray a sheep in a range of different situations, dressed in costumes she created, as part of her live art show.

Helen Jones, curator of the Art Gallery Walsall, praised Lee for creating a new image for the gallery by putting fresh turf in the building. She said Lee's innovative ideas would allow visitors to enjoy cozy afternoons, to relax and view the exhibitions in the gallery.

The 33-year-old Lee is an outstanding new emerging artist from Taiwan who holds a bachelor's degree in Fine Arts from National Kaohsiung Normal University in southern Taiwan and a master's degree in Fine Arts from Birmingham Institute of Art and Design in the UK.

Lee works in various media, often incorporating installation, performance and video works. She has an international reputation, having exhibited extensively throughout the UK, Taiwan, the U.S. and Middle East.
Lee was selected as a member of a residency program in Berlin in 2007 which was funded by the Arts Council England.

One of her projects was included in the 2005 annual Kaohsiung Fine Arts Museum's Intertidal Zone Art Monitoring Station. Another of her projects was nominated as one of the top five art shows in the Taihsin Arts Award Exhibition in Taiwan in 2006.
Lee obtained an artist residency in Mount Zionin Jerusalem, Israel in 2001 in an artist exchange program between Taipei and Jerusalem, after winning the prestigious Taipei Prize 2000 in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Laptops, PDAs most popular wireless devices for accessing Internet

TEXT.P: Notebook computers and personal digital assistants (PDAs) remain the two devices most commonly used by Taiwan Internet users to go online wirelessly, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by the Taiwan Network Information Center (TWNIC).
The places most commonly used to connect to the Internet wirelessly were coffee shops, after homes and offices, the results showed.

The survey on the status of wireless Internet use in Taiwan was conducted via telephone interviews between April 23 and May 8 polling 1,417 adults as well as online questionnaires of 4,563 others between March 13 and June 10.
The survey revealed that 79.31 percent of online respondents have accessed the Internet wirelessly, with 72.21 percent having done so in the past six months.
Among telephone respondents, 42.56 percent have experience using wireless services, with 36.33 percent having done so in the past six months.
The most commonly used functions of wireless Internet services cited by respondents were searching information, browsing information and Web pages, and sending and receiving e-mails.
Unstable or poor Internet connections were the most common problems encountered by wireless Internet users.

While more than 60 percent of the telephone respondents who have used wireless Internet services expressed satisfaction with the quality of wireless connections, only 26 percent of the online respondents were satisfied.

When asked about their reasons for not using wireless Internet services, the 58 percent of telephone respondents who have never tried the services said there is no need for them to use the services, and 43 percent of online respondents said they seldom use the Internet out of their homes or offices.

However, if this group of respondents goes online wirelessly in the future, they will most likely do so in coffee shops, restaurants, MRT stations, airports, train stations and homes, according to the results.
