DOC.HEADLINE: Officials congratulate family of Olympic bronze medalist

TEXT.P: Executive Yuan Secretary-General Hsieh Hsiang-chuan conveyed congratulatory messages to the family of taekwondo bronze medalist Chu Mu-yen in recognition of Chu's outstanding performance in the ongoing Beijing Olympics, an official said Thursday.

Hsieh and Taoyuan County Magistrate Eric Liluan Chu, on behalf of Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, presented a congratulatory tablet and prize money to the athlete's family during a visit to his home in the county's Pingjhen City, according to the official.

Hsieh expressed great admiration for Chu Mu-yen's outstanding performance in the 29th Olympics, saying that he hopes all Taiwanese athletes will do their utmost to clinch more medals in other international sports competitions so as to lift the international profile of Taiwan, the official related.
Magistrate Chu praised the medalist as not only the pride of Taoyuan, but of Taiwan.

Chu Mu-yen won Taiwan's third bronze medal of the 2008 Beijing Olympics Wednesday in the men's under-58 kg taekwondo division. The bronze is his second Olympic medal. He became the first Taiwanese male athlete to win an Olympic gold in 2004. He is slated to return to Taiwan later this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Transit stops in U.S. opportunities for bilateral dialogue: President

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has said that his brief transit stops in the United States, during his just-concluded state visit to Latin America in mid-August, created opportunities for dialogue between Taiwan and America despite receiving little media coverage.

Ma made the remarks Wednesday at a meeting with Eliot Engel, a member of the United States House of Representatives, at the Presidential Office. Engel is the chairman of the U.S. House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on the Western Hemisphere.

The main purpose of Ma's Latin America visit was to attend the Aug. 15 inauguration ceremony of Paraguayan President Fernando Lugo and the inauguration ceremony of re-elected Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez on Aug. 16.

During his visit, Ma made a low profile transit stop, ahead of his six-day trip through Latin America, in Los Angeles on Aug. 12 and a second one in San Francisco on Aug. 17. He returned to Taiwan on Aug. 19.
According to Ma, he contacted 31 U.S. senators and congressmen during the two stops. He said he exchanged opinions with eight of them in person and the other 23 over the telephone.
Engel was one of the congressmen with whom Ma spoke over the telephone. The discussion with Engel on the phone was quite pleasant, leaving a deep impression, Ma said.

At Wednesday's meeting, Ma expressed gratitude to Engel for his long-term attention to issues regarding Taiwan and his encouragement of Taiwan's Latin American allies to maintain their strong friendships with the island.
Ma said Engel is one of Taiwan's best friends in the House of Representatives.

Engel told Ma that Taiwan has strong economic strength and admirable achievement in democratization and that he has always had afondness for Taiwan, where local people moved him with passion and friendliness.
He also assured Ma that he will continue his support for Taiwan and make contributions to relations between Taiwan and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA keeping close watch on Chinas reaction to Taiwan's U.N. bid

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that so far China has not yet reacted to Taiwan's latest bid to ask the United Nations to reconsider the feasibility of Taiwan's meaningful participation in the world body, but added that the ministry will keep close watch on any response from China.

At least there has been no reaction by China so far, as the Olympic Games are still in progress there," said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen at a regular press briefing in response to a reporter's question. "But we will continue to observe China's reaction."
Noting that the foreign ministry has notified its embassies and representative offices overseas to start promoting the U.N. bid, Chen said the responses from other countries have been "good so far."
"Everyone is being very proactive in promoting Taiwan's bid to the governments in the countries where they are posted, " he said. "That is the main support we are trying to win."

Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations was renewed last Thursday when two of its diplomatic allies -- St. Vincent and the Grenadines and the Solomon Islands -- submitted a proposal to the U.N. Secretariat emphasizing the importance of Taiwan's "meaningful participation" in the world body and of a cross-Taiwan Strait policy of "reconciliation and truce."

This marked a fresh approach by the ROC government for the country's admission to the U.N., under the new presidency of Ma Ying-jeou. The proposal did not mention the country's attempt to enter the U.N. under the name Taiwan or the possibility of returning to the U.N. as the ROC.

The previous Democratic Progressive Party administration, for the first time, applied in 2007 for Taiwan to join the U.N. as a full member under the name Taiwan. That proposal did not make the agenda of the U.N. General Assembly.
Since 1993, Taiwan's supporters have been trying to get the General Assembly to list the issue on the U.N. agenda, but Beijing's argument that Taiwan is part of China has prevailed.
Last Friday was the last day for U.N. members to submit proposals for consideration as part of the agenda of the General Assembly, which is scheduled to begin Sep. 16.

This year, three of Taiwan's diplomatic allies -- Nicaragua, the Solomon Islands and Honduras -- entered the U.N. General Committee as members, making up the highest number of Taiwan allies on the committee since 1993. The General Committee, comprised of delegates from 28 nations, will make the decisions pertaining to the agenda of the next General Assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Sanyi International Woodcarving Camp opens

TEXT.P: Eight international wood carving artists have joined six of their Taiwanese counterparts in the Sanyi International Wood Carving Camp, which opened Thursday at the West Lake Resortopia in Miaoli County, as part of the Sanyi International Woodcarving Art Festival.

The eight international artists are: Emil Adamec from the Czech Republic, Mikako Tomotari from Japan, Yong Tae-don from South Korea, Sigurgeir Thordarson from Iceland, Yeo Chee Kiong from Singapore, Martyn Barratt from the United Kingdom, Zhao Lei from China, and Javier Astorga from Mexico.
The six Taiwanese wood carving masters are: Lin Hsin-yi, Chen Teh-lung, Tseng An-kuo, Tsai Yao-cheng, Tung Ming-chin, and Tuan Tsun-tseng.

During the wood carving camp, which will last until Aug. 31, the 14 artists will demonstrate their carving skills to the public by doing on-site creations in the plaza of the West Lake Resortopia in Sanyi township.
The event is sponsored by the Miaoli County International Culture and Tourism Bureau to promote the exchange of creative ideas in wood carving.

Miaoli County is well-known for its wood carving industry in Sanyi township. The craft has existed in Sanyi for more than 100 years. The township's woodcarving museum serves as a showroom for top Taiwanese wood sculptors who have gained prominence in Sanyi.

The government established Kuangsheng Village at Sanyi in 1995 and invited about 50 of Taiwan's best wood carving artists to live there. The village, together with the Sanyi Wood Sculptor Museum, is the focal point for the annual Sanyi International Woodcarving Art Festival, which opened Aug. 9 and will run 10 more days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan seeks Swiss, Singaporean help in money-laundering probe

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng said Thursday that her ministry has received a positive response to its requests for judicial assistance from Switzerland and Singapore in the investigation of a case of suspected money laundering by members of the former first family.
The Swiss government expressed the hope that Taiwan would provide more detailed information, and said that it would assist Taiwan in the probe, Wang said.
Singapore's trade representative to Taiwan Stanley Loh, responding to the request for judicial assistance, also said his country would help Taiwan, she added.
Wang also encouraged businesses that had helped in the alleged money laundering to come forward "to provide clues or information" that would shed light on the case.

Wang said Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has issued a directive that the judicial probe should focus on evidence and proper procedure and that no one should go unpunished once they are found to have violated the law.
"If public functionaries violated the law, that will not be condoned. The public should know that the Cabinet's promise of a clean government is not a slogan," Wang quoted Liu as saying.

Prosecutors last Saturday searched former President Chen Shui-bian's residence and questioned him and his wife, Wu Shu-jen, about the sources and flow of sums of money reportedly stashed in overseas banking accounts.

The former president and his wife, as well as Wu's elder brother Wu Ching-mao, Chen's son Chen Chih-chung and his daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching, have been listed by prosecutors as suspects in the case. The former president, his wife and Wu Ching-mao have also been barred from leaving the country.

A local magazine, based on a report by an international anti-money laundering organization the Egmont Group, stated last week that Huang Jui-ching had laundered money for the former first family by secretly wiring NT$300 million overseas in 2006, after the exposure of a "state affairs fund" embezzlement case that implicated Chen Shui-bian and his wife.
The report allegedly detailed the status of bank accounts created by members of Chen Shui-bian's family in other countries, including the United States, Cayman Islands, Singapore and Switzerland.

The former president was forced to admit last Thursday that he did not fully account for the election campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004, but claimed that he was unaware, until early this year, that the surplus funds had been wired abroad by his wife.

Chen Shui-bian rejected allegations that the funds wired overseas could be connected to the "state affairs funds" embezzlement case and a botched attempt by the Taiwan government to win Papua New Guinea as a diplomatic ally.

Wu Shu-jen stressed during a search of her residence that all the money deposited overseas had been obtained legally from four sources -- surplus campaign funds, Chen Shui-bian's practice as a lawyer before he went into politics, her own dowry and her investments.

The Ministry of Justice launched an investigation last week after it was revealed that Swiss authorities had sought Taiwan's assistance in probing a case of possible money laundering in Switzerland by Chen Chi-chung and Huang Jui- ching.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT to hold seminar on U.S. National Electrical Code

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said Thursday in a press release that it will organize a seminar in collaboration with Underwriters Laboratories Taiwan (UL Taiwan) on the U.S. National Electrical Code (NEC), in celebration of the 20th anniversary of UL Taiwan.

AIT said that the seminar is offered free of charge to local manufacturers to express UL's gratitude for their long-term support and patronage of UL's testing and certification serves. UL Taiwan has invited an American standards expert to lead the seminar.

A privately owned and operated U.S. product safety testing and certification organization, UL develops standards and test procedures for products, materials, components, assemblies, tools and equipment. UL Taiwan was founded in 1988.

"UL Taiwan has been cooperating and growing with Taiwan manufacturers for 20 years. The company has not only made significant investments in facilities and human resource cultivation, but has also continuously provided training seminars to share the latest global product safety knowledge and skills with local firms, " AIT said in the press release.
"This seminar will be a good opportunity for Taiwan firms to thoroughly understand U.S. electric standards requirements, " it added.

NEC is a safety standards code that is used by U.S. government agencies for electric facilities. The code is also the main foundation upon which UL develops its standards. The code mainly regulates requirements for electric circuits for facilities and buildings while installing electric products.

The seminar is slated to be held on Sep. 8 from 9 a.m. to 4: 30 p.m. at UL Taiwan. The press release said that detailed information about the seminar's agenda and registration is available on UL's Web site at www.ul.com.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City steps up disinfection as dengue fever spread

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government has stepped up environmental cleanup and disinfection efforts as the number of dengue fever cases in the southern port city had risen to 54 as of Aug. 19, a municipal Department of Health (DOH) official said Thursday.

Chen Chao-dong, a division chief in charge of disease control and prevention, said that most of the cases occurred in the Houjing Area in the city's Nanzih District, and out of the 54 cases, 46 cases were reported in the area's Jintien and Rentien boroughs, with one diagnosed as dengue hemorrhagic fever.

A 70-year-old patient, identified only by his family name Lin, was diagnosed with dengue fever in July, which at one time threatened his life. However, the patient recovered gradually after receiving treatment at Kaohsiung Veterans General Hospital, and was moved to a general ward, said Chen.

According to Chen, there is a great possibility that the mosquitoes that breed the fever breed in old abandoned buildings in the area. Therefore, the DOH and the Public Works Bureau have begun tearing down the buildings with excavators and disinfecting the area Thursday, said Chen.

Chen noted that there are 16 houses to be torn down on Houjing North Road and Houjing Central Street, and that the owners of the houses have all agreed to the action to prevent further spread of the disease.
Huang Shuen-ming, chief of the Nanzih District Office, said that the office will continue disinfecting the environment to prevent the further spread of dengue fever.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislators push for Taiwan's integration in ASEAN

TEXT.P: Parliamentarians of several Southeast Asian countries have expressed support for Taiwan's bid to take part in activities related to the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislators said Thursday.

Legislative and political party leaders from Vietnam, Thailand and Indonesia have all voiced their support for Taiwan in its efforts to participate in the ASEAN grouping and related economic activities, according to Legislative Yuan Vice President Tseng Yung-chuan.

Tseng said at a news conference held immediately after returning from visits to the three ASEAN member states with four other KMT legislators that Taiwan should not be excluded from ASEAN, given that the country is geographically close to these nations and is an important business and trade partner with the group.
Tseng noted that China, Japan and South Korea will join ASEAN as "ASEAN plus one, " "ASEAN plus two" and "ASEAN plus three" in 2010, 2011 and 2012, respectively.
Noting that the world's economy is moving toward a trend of integration, such as the European Union and ASEAN, Tseng said Taiwan should not be marginalized from this process.

"These countries will sign free trade agreements (FTAs) and will benefit from reduced tariffs, " Tseng said, adding that if Taiwan is marginalized from this economic integration, its international economic competitiveness will be greatly affected.

He noted that two-way trade between Taiwan and ASEAN member states has topped US$60 billion over the past 49 years, with the number of two-way investment projects totaling 8,790, involving some US$53.85 billion.

KMT Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu said that due to the independence ideology espoused by the previous Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration and China's persistent containment policy against Taiwan, the country's economic development and global engagement has lagged behind over the last eight years of DPP rule.

"With cross-strait relations beginning to thaw since President Ma Ying-jeou's May 20 inauguration, ASEAN member states seem to be somewhat relieved over their relations with the two sides of the Taiwan Strait," Hung said.

"The KMT-dominated legislature therefore hopes to take this opportunity to expand Taiwan's international horizons to prevent Taiwan from being marginalized in the international community, " Hung added.

According to Hung, during the group's visit to Vietnam, Chen Huang-tan, head of the Ho Chi Minh delegation to Vietnam's 10th legislature, promised to relay Taiwan's intention of becoming an ASEAN dialogue partner to the Vietnamese government.
Sanoh Thienthong, leader of the Royal People Party of Thailand, said he will be glad to assist Taiwan to achieve its goal of seeking closer engagement with ASEAN, Hung added.

She also said Indonesian parliamentary leader Theo L. Sambuaga told the Taiwanese delegation that he will do his utmost to help Taiwan take part in ASEAN activities, as it is imperative for Taiwan to get access to ASEAN's 10-country, 550-million person market, which is expected to form a unified economic community by 2015.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taipei International Robot Show kicks off

TEXT.P: Speaking Thursday at the first Taipei International Robot Show (TIROS) , Vice President Vincent Siew said that the show not only serves as an important milestone but also indicates that robotics will be the next big industry.

"Given the fact that robots are expected to be applied in many industries in the future, Bill Gates predicts that robotics is the next big industry, " Siew said. "The prospects present in the robotics industry are the same as those in the personal computer industry when it was about to boom."
He said thirty years ago it was hard to imagine that PCs would be in almost every home and that what Gates said -- "robots in every home" -- can be expected in thirty years.

The vice president encouraged Taiwan's semi-conductor, photonics, engineering and electric components industries to staunchly support the robotics industry so Taiwan can seize the opportunity to become a leader in another industry with billions of dollars in revenue.

Chen Chao-yi, director-general of the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Industrial Development Bureau, said that the show is aimed at showcasing robot technology and attracting more companies and talent to join the robotics industry as well as promoting the robotics industry in Taiwan and offering product platforms for facilitating interaction among supply companies to help build the robotics industry.

"Compared to other countries, Taiwan has the advantage to edge into the robot market in a short time, as it has a complete industrial supply chain and the ability to adjust to the fast-changing industry," he said.

The Industrial Development Bureau has already invested NT$35 million (US$1.11 million) to help companies develop robots and the investment is expected to generate an output value of NT$1.4 billion, according to Chen.

He added that the latest statistics show that Taiwanese companies have invested NT$5.83 billion in developing intelligent robots and the government is aiming to make Taiwan the design and manufacturing center for robots by 2015, generating output revenues of NT$250 billion.

Organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Taiwan Society of Manufacture Engineering and Automation Technology, the Industrial Technology Research Institute, and Precision Machinery R&D Center, the 2008 TIROS is slated to be held from Aug. 21-24 at the Taipei World Trade Center Exhibition Hall 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC gets drug certification for Russell's viper antivenin

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) announced Thursday that certification has been issued for antivenin for envenomation by the Russell's viper, one of the most venomous snakes found in Taiwan.

CDC Deputy Director-General Shih Wen-yi said at a press conference that the CDC has been conducting clinical experiments on antivenin for the Russell's viper since 1999, but added that certification was only issued recently, as only a few people are bitten each year, making human clinical trials difficult.

With the certification of the antivenin, the CDC will be able to distribute it to major hospitals in eastern and southern Taiwan, as well as health stations in mountainous areas, where envenomation is more likely to occur, Shih added.

One of Taiwan's most venomous snakes, the Russell's viper is relatively less studied locally as it has a limited habitat and has a smaller population compared to the other venomous snakes found in Taiwan, said Lien Wei-cheng, chief of the vaccination center under the CDC, adding that no more than 10 people here are bitten by the snake every year.
According to the CDC, the Russell's viper's venom is of high toxicity and has a high fatality rate, as it is both a neurotoxin and a hemotoxin.

"Results of clinical experiments show that if people bitten by the snake receive the antivenin within three to six hours, symptoms of hemorrhage and renal failure can be effectively alleviated, " said Hung Dung-zung, director of the department of toxicology of the China Medical University Hospital, who was in charge of the clinical experiments.

He added that the fatality rate of people bitten by the Russell's viper was 17 percent before the antivenin was manufactured, and that those who survive can suffer from muscle necrosis, renal failure or cerebral embolism.
The antivenin has already saved more than 50 people's lives, according to the CDC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fourth site of Central Science Park to be in Changhua County

TEXT.P: The government has decided to select Erlin in Changhua County as the fourth site for the Central Taiwan Science Park, according to the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC), which administrates and manages all of the country's science parks.

According to the NSC, the new location in Erlin was selected from among seven candidate sites by a review committee that visited all the areas in the three days before the final decision was made at an Aug. 20 meeting.

Yang Wen-ke, director-general of the park's administration, said that the Erlin location has around 800 hectares, which can be expanded to over 1,000 hectares. Of the total area, 600 hectares could be developed first to settle the factories that have already been assigned to the site, he noted.

According to the park administration, after the government appropriates the construction funding of some NT$40 billion, the construction of the park's infrastructure will start by July 2009 and is expected to be completed by 2013.
After 2014, the administration said, the park might be able to help create some 40,000 jobs and generate annual production value of NT$500 billion.

In response to the NSC decision, Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan said the new site will introduce more high-tech manufacturers to the county, helping change it from agriculture-based to technology-based.

The government decided to establish the central science park in 2000, with the aim of replicating the success achieved in the Hsinchu Science Park and the Southern Taiwan Science Park. To date, the park has three separate sites located between Taichung City, Houli in Taichung County and Huwei in Yunlin County.
As of the end of July, the 765-hectare park has 90 registered companies, compared to 444 companies in Hsinchu and 157 companies in the southern science park.

In 2007, the central science park generated revenue of some NT$265.7 billion (about US$8.47 billion) and employed 21,446 people. In 2008, the NSC estimates, the park's revenues will reach NT$360 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: `I-Taiwan projects' receive NT$170 billion for 2009: premier

TEXT.P: The Cabinet has earmarked NT$170.3 billion (US$5.43 billion) for the "i-Taiwan 12 major infrastructure projects, " a major election promise of President Ma Ying-jeou, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Thursday.
Ma's election platform proposed putting NT$3.99 trillion into the ambitious "i-Taiwan 12 projects" over the next eight years to boost the economy.

The 12 infrastructure projects include linking rapid transit networks in cities and counties across the country, enhancing flood control measures, forestation, revitalizing farmland and marine areas, and turning Taoyuan into an "airport city."
Of the budget to be dpent on the projects, Liu said, the transit networks will take the lion's share at NT$65.3 billion, followed by the flood control project at NT$37.9 billion.

In addition, Liu went on, next year's government income under the total budget plan will be NT$1.7 trillion, an increase of NT$84.9 billion from this year's figure, while annual expenditure will be NT$1.83 trillion, up NT$118.3 billion compared with this year's level.
The increased expenditure will be used on projects relating to education, technology, culture, taking care of the disadvantaged, economic development and subsidies to local governments, Liu said.

According to Shih Su-mei, head of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, projects related to economic development will receive the highest budget at NT$50.9 billion of the added expenditure, followed by the budget for social welfare at NT$29.2 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign aid to be sought to crack money-laundering case: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Thursday that Cabinet agencies have been collaborating to solve the alleged money-laundering case involving former President Chen Shui-bian and his family.
"We will seek international help to facilitate the probe into the case if necessary," Liu said during an inspection tour of Ministry of Justice operations and establishments in Taipei County.
He reiterated the administration's resolve to break the case "in order to return justice to the country."
Chen, his wife Wu Shu-jen and Wu's elder brother Wu Ching-mao were listed earlier this week as suspects in the case and have been barred from leaving the country.

The Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office decided Thursday to summon Chen's son Chen Chih-chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui- ching -- who have already left the country -- for questioning as suspects within days.

At issue is a report from the Egmont Group -- an international anti-money laundering organization -- that the Investigation Bureau's Money Laundering Prevention Center received in January, which details the status of bank accounts created by Chen's family members in other countries, including the United States, the Cayman Islands, Singapore and Switzerland.

Wu Shu-jen claimed last week during questioning at her residence by prosecutors that US$21 million deposited in the family's various overseas bank accounts was "all legal income." The money is distributed among three different accounts -- two in Switzerland held in the name of Huang Jui-ching and one in Singapore in the name of Wu Ching-mao.

Chen admitted several days ago that he did not faithfully report the election campaign expenses from his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004, but claimed he was unaware that the balance of the funds was wired abroad by his wife until early this year.
He rejected the idea that the funds wired overseas could be connected to his "state affairs fund" case and a recent scandal involving a botched attempt to win Papua New Guinea as a diplomatic ally.
An anonymous prosecutor said Monday he suspected the source of the money might be "more complicated" than originally thought.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taipei International Robot Show opens

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taipei International Robot Show opened Thursday at the Taipei World Trade Center's Exhibition Hall 1 for a four-day run.
More than 90 companies, organizations and universities are displaying their robotics products and research results in 209 booths.
The products on display include more than 100 industrial and service robots.

According to the organizer -- the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs -- the event is intended to be a platform upon which Taiwan's robotics manufacturers can exchange market information and build connections with domestic and overseas buyers.

More than 20 universities and research organizations are also taking part in the exhibition to present their latest research results in robotics, while 24 teams from Taiwanese universities will take part in a robotics competition to be held during the exhibition.

An International Workshop on Intelligent Robot Applications and Business will be held Aug. 23-25 at the Taipei International Convention Center, while the 2008 Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) International Conference on Advanced Robotics and its Social Impact will also take place at the same venue Aug. 23-25.

DOC.HEADLINE: People's right to rally respected: Presidential Office

TEXT.P: Addressing the issue of a rally to be held Aug. 30 by the pro-independence Taiwan Society, the Presidential Office said Thursday that it respects the people's right to rally but hopes the demonstrators will remain "rational" during the activity.
Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi called for the demonstrators to exercise their civil rights in a rational and peaceful manner.

Taiwan Society officials said the rally -- to be held on the 100th day in office of President Ma Ying-jeou -- is aimed at demanding that the Ma administration offers tax rebates to low-income taxpayers, stabilize consumer product prices, protect Taiwan's independent sovereignty and enact bills for the building of a clean and competent government.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to express views on 100th day of administration

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will not give a press conference on the 100th day of his administration but will speak on the occasion, officials at the Presidential Office said Thursday.

The pro-independence Taiwan Society has said it will sponsor a demonstration Aug. 30, the 100th day of Ma's administration, to highlight their cause, which includes a call for the government to address public woes amid surging consumer prices.
The Presidential Office said it "will respect the people's right to rally, " but added that the demonstration should be conducted in a rational and peaceful way.
The pro-independence protesters want to call for tax rebates to low-income taxpayers and the stabilization of consumer prices.

They are also angry with the administration's tilt toward China, especially its easing of a cap for local businesses wishing to invest in China. They will also demand that Ma's administration insist on Taiwan's sovereignty to safeguard the nation.
The protesters will also call for clean politics.
The opposition Democratic Progressive Party has said it will help sponsor the event, focusing on a better economy, Taiwan's sovereignty and the introduction of sunshine bills.
Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu of the DPP said she will encourage and assist people wishing to take part in the protest.

The performance of Ma's administration has been a focus of attention since his May 20 inauguration. It was given a high rating in the beginning, but the latest survey by the government's Research, Development, and Evaluation Commission put Ma's approval rating at just 47 percent after three months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan takes bronze in men's 68-kg taekwondo
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/08 22:11:19 (By Wu Shye-chang, Chris Wang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan bagged another bronze medal Thursday when Sung Yu-chi beat Daniel Manz of Germany 4-3 in the bronze medal competition in the men's taekwondo 68 kg class at the Beijing Olympics, bringing Taiwan its fourth bronze medal of the games.
Sung's victory came one day after Taiwan's Chu Mu-yen, a 2004 Athens Olympics gold medalist, took the country's third bronze medal in the men' under-58 kg category of the event.
Sung fell to his knees and thanked his coach and his father, Sung Ching-hung, soon after he was announced the winner of the match.
Despite his victory, Sung said he felt the bronze medal was "not good enough."
"I am in perfect condition, " he said, expressing regret that he lost to Son Taejin of South Korea 6-7 in a semifinal match, thereby missing the opportunity for gold.
Taiwan's taekwondo fighters took two golds in the 2004 Athens Olympics.
In a quarterfinal match earlier in the day, Sung edged out Dmitriy Kim of Uzbekistan 3-2.

Meanwhile, in the women's 57 kg class, Taiwan's Su Li-wen, who had suffered from an injury to her left knee since the preliminary round of 16 earlier in the day, was defeated by Croatia's Martina Zubcic 4-5 in the bronze medal match.
Su tied with Zubcic 4-4 after the first three rounds, but lost a decisive point in the fourth round.
During the match, Su managed to continue fighting after falling several times in obvious pain, as she did in previous competitions.
Her perseverance earned her rounds of applause and cheers from the audience in Beijing, as well as from members of the press from various countries.
The 27-year-old -- who won gold at the 2006 Asian Games in Doha, the 2007 World University Games in Bangkok and the 2008 Asian Taekwondo Championship -- was taken to hospital soon after her defeat.
Prior to the competition, Su was described by the U.S.-based Sports Illustrated as the only Taiwanese athlete capable of winning a gold for the country. It was her first Olympics.
Her defeat came after she beat Robin Cheong of New Zealand 1-0 in the repechage section of the event, but lost the round of 16 to Lim Su-jeong of South Korea 0-1.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA attempts damage control over ex-president's fund scandal

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) released a statement Thursday for use by the country's overseas representative offices and embassies to explain a money- laundering scandal in which former President Chen Shui-bian and his family stand accused of funneling large sums of cash into Swiss bank accounts, in a bid to protect the nation's image.

"The Republic of China sternly holds the stance of opposing money-laundering, a behavior that harms social justice and abuses international financial freedom, " the MOFA statement said, adding that President Ma Ying-jeou has stressed many times that promoting clean and honest government is his top priority and that no-one, even former heads of state, should be above the law.

The Foreign Ministry said Taiwan's international image has been deeply tarnished since the breaking of the scandal in which the former first family is involved, as it has sparked a lot of news reports from local and international media.

"Given the fact that the case has entered the judicial process, the ministry, along with its embassies and overseas representative offices, will fully cooperate with the investigation and ask for assistance from related governments and international anti-money- laundering organization in order to clarify the truth as soon as possible, " it stated.

Noting that there have been four presidential elections and two transfers of political power between political parties since 1996, the ministry said it is because Taiwan has experienced such rapid democratic progress compared to other newly democratized countries that the case was exposed and brought under investigation so quickly.
However, the ministry admitted that laws regarding regulating public servants' political funds have failed to keep pace with Taiwan's democratic progress.
It said a consensus was reached across party lines at the Legislative Yuan recently that a draft "Property with Unknown Source Act" will be reviewed in the next legislative session.

Chen admitted last Thursday that he lied about the campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004 and that his wife wired surplus campaign contributions into overseas bank accounts held by members of his family.

His confession came only after the Foreign Ministry confirmed earlier that same day that the Swiss authorities have sought Taiwan' s help in a probe into a possible money laundering case in Switzerland involving Chen's son Chen Chih- chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui- ching.
The former president claims that his wife Wu Shu-jen made the wire transfers without his knowledge.
Prosecutors who searched Chen's home and office in Taipei last Saturday for evidence in connection with the scandal said Chen has been prohibited from leaving the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Catholic university sends medical volunteers to India

TEXT.P: Fu Jen Catholic University in northern Taiwan sent a medical group of 19 volunteers to the eastern Indian city of Kolkata Thursday for a 10-day mission.
University President Bernard Chien-chiu Li told the volunteers prior to their departure that they should deeply understand what other people need and accumulate some life experience during the trip.
Second-year students Yang Ya-ching and Tsai Wan-ying described the trip as a rare opportunity to experience life and said they hope to grow personally through serving others.
University Vice President Michael Wei-Hsia Kwo, who is leading the group, lauded the students for spending their summer vacation in a meaningful manner.
He said he hopes they will "learn from doing" and learn to cherish life during the trip.
The group members will serve as medial volunteers at five centers in the city, where they will serve poor and seriously ill street people and children.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese vegetables thrive in Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/21/08 22:53:32 (By Yang Ming-chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A variety of Taiwanese vegetables are growing well on the southern Japanese island of Kyushu thanks to the promotion of a Taiwanese restaurateur in Tokyo.

Tang Kun-yu, who operates a Taiwanese-style restaurant in Tokyo's Meguro district, held a news conference in Tokyo Wednesday to introduce the dazzling array of popular Taiwanese vegetables grown by Japanese farmers in Kyushu with seeds and know-how provided by him.
On display were Taiwanese bamboo shoots, amaranth, taro, clery, luffa gourd, chives and chaylte vine.

To meet the demands of his restaurant, Tang said he began to cooperate with farmers in Kyushu in cultivating vegetables popular in Taiwan on an experimental basis five years ago, as Kyushu's climate and clay soil are similar to Taiwan's.
"The initial results were encouraging, as the Taiwanese seeds grew well on the Kyushu farms and our restaurant patrons welcomed the locally grown produce," Tang recalled.

The cooperative project has since expanded, with the total acreage of contracted farmland reaching scores of hectares, Tang went on, adding that more Japanese farmers are expected to take part in the venture in the future.

"Many Kyushu farmers are interested in cooperating with me because growing Taiwanese vegetables is like exploring a `new frontier' that they believe offers a promising future, " Tang explained, adding that Taiwanese vegetables grown in Kyushu are treated as locally grown produce.

According to Tang, the cooperation project got a boost after the poisoned gyoza (Chinese dumpling) incident in Japan in January this year in which 10-plus Japanese citizens fell ill after consuming frozen gyoza from China.

"The incident aroused Japanese concerns for food safety and attracted more attention to my project of planting Taiwanese vegetables in Kyushu, " Tang said, adding that the collaboration has helped increase the diversity of vegetables available on the Japanese market.

Lamenting that many Japanese farmers intend to seek government subsidies because farming is not often profitable, Terajima said cooperating with Tang makes his life meaningful as the project offers fresh experiences and the chance of making a profit.

"Planting Taiwanese vegetables, such as bamboo shoots and leafy vegetables, are different from growing native Japanese species. It interests me and makes my life meaningful," he said, adding that some Taiwanese vegetables, such as tomato and luffa gourd, taste better than Japanese ones.

DOC.HEADLINE: 65% of executives in Taiwan suffer from poor heart-lung endurance

TEXT.P: Some 65 percent of the middle- and high-level executives in Taiwan lack regular exercise and as a consequence, suffer from poor heart and lung endurance, according to the results of a study released Thursday.

The study, conducted by the Lian An Preventive Medicine Organization, analyzed the physical examination results of 6,093 middle- and high-level executives who had visited the organization between 2000 and 2007, and interviewed them recently via questionnaire.

The results show that they worked an average 9.5 hours per day, that most of them were sedentary office workers, and that 55 percent of them admitted they were not in the habit of taking regular exercise.
The study also found that most of the executives suffered from physical fatigue due to their long working hours and preferred to spend their leisure time sleeping rather than exercising.
The physical results show that 65 percent of them had poor heart and lung endurance, while 58 percent had weak leg muscles, with another 52 percent failing to meet standards for waist suppleness.

Tsai Mei-wen, a lecturer at the Department of Physical Therapy and Assistive Technology of National Yang-Ming University, said poor heart and lung endurance can cause fatigue and poor concentration and increase the risks of coronary artery disease and metabolic diseases by up to five times higher than those with better heart and lung endurance.

She said a person who has little time for daily exercise must try to find time to exercise at least three times a week, with each session lasting at least 30 minutes and with enough exertion to increase the heart rate to 130 beats per minute.
According to Tsai, swimming and jogging are ideal forms of exercise because they are not too demanding and can improve heart and lung function.

DOC.HEADLINE: New location needed to ease overcrowding at detention center: PM

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Thursday that a new location for the Taipei Detention House in Tucheng, Taipei County is urgently needed to solve an overcrowding problem.
The detention house is used to incarcerate lawsuit suspects and people serving short prison sentences.
According to Lee Mung-tung, director-general of the detention house, the inmates numbered around 3,600 as of the end of July, while the capacity should be only about 2,100.
Lee said overcrowding in the women's section is even more serious, with an excess ratio of 198 percent, which is lower than the 302 percent recorded in 2007.
Many female inmates have to sleep at a nearby vocational training plant because there is not enough space in the detention center, Lee said.

Liu said an earlier government plan of moving the detention house to a former Ministry of National Defense ammunition depot in the county has raised objections from local residents, but he said the government will continue to communicate with local residents to seek their consent and cooperation.
He also asked the Taipei county government and the Ministry of Justice, which supervises the detention house, to work together on measures to carry out the move.

Liu said the government will promote the idea of replacing penalties for petty crimes with alternative punishments like community service or fines to ease the problem of overcrowding, which he said is affecting the environment around the detention house.

Before Liu went to the detention house, he also reviewed the environment of the Hsindian Drug Abuse Treatment Center in the county's Hsindian City and issued instruction for improving the center's treatment efficiency, including increasing supervisory personnel and renovating and updating the facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: City gov't honored award-winning boy with chromosome abnormalities

TEXT.P: A boy with chromosome abnormalities who has outlived doctors' predictions of a 12-year life expectancy and who received the President's Award for Educational Excellence earlier this year, was honored by the Tainan city government Thursday.

The boy, Hsu Jun-jie, has had a rough life so far. Born with chromosome abnormalities, his parents divorced when he was young, said a city government official. While his father worked part-time, the boy went ragpicking with his grandmother in an effort to make ends meet.

According to the official, Hsu was not only diagnosed with chromosome abnormalities but also with serious heart problems. He underwent heart surgery at the age of 6 and was back in hospital for brain surgery at 12.

Nevertheless, Hsu conquered all the difficulties that beset him and outlived doctors' expectations that he would die by the age of 12. He has not only learned to play the drums, rollerblade and paint, but has also maintained top academic performance, the official noted.
The official said the boy, now aged 13, will begin studying at Tainan Municipal Yen-ping Junior High School this September.
No one knows how much longer Hsu will live, but he has proved himself full of miracles, noted the official, who added that the family is waiting hopefully for more miracles.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC head departs for U.S. visit

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan departed for the United States late Thursday for her first overseas trip since assuming office in May.

High on Lai's itinerary will be attending a meeting of the Taiwanese Association of America to be held in Chicago this weekend. As government's top China policy coordinator, Lai will deliver a speech on the current state of relations across the Taiwan Strait and relevant future development.
In addition, Lai said prior to her departure that she will visit Washington, D.C. to meet with American politicians, academics and think tank researchers.

"I'll brief them on the basic framework for development of cross-strait relations under the leadership of President Ma Ying-jeou and exchange views with them on related topics, " Lai explained, adding that she will help her American hosts better understand Ma's visions and concepts for the cross-strait ties and on development of Taiwan-U.S. relations.

As for the much-anticipated second round of cross-strait talks, Lai said the two quasi-official intermediary bodies on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will definitely hold a new round of negotiations before the end of this year to settle several major pending issues, including expansion of weekend direct cross-strait chart flights and redemarcation of cross-strait flight paths to make them more straight to save time and fuel costs.
Also high on the agenda for the second round of talks will also include launch of direct cross-strait cargo charter flights and cooperation in cross-border crime fighting, Lai said..

Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait held their first round of talks after a nine-year hiatus in June, in which they signed deals on the launch of weekend passenger charter flights and on allowing more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan.
Cross-strait tensions thawed after the inauguration of Ma's administration in May as Ma adopted a reconciliatory approach toward sensitive Taipei-Beijing ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan takes bronze in men's 68-kg taekwondo
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 21 (CNA) 08/22/08 10:37:19 (By Wu Shye-chang, Chris Wang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan bagged another bronze medal Thursday when Sung Yu-chi beat Daniel Manz of Germany 4-3 in the bronze medal competition in the men's taekwondo 68 kg class at the Beijing Olympics, bringing Taiwan its fourth bronze medal of the games.
Sung's victory came one day after Taiwan's Chu Mu-yen, a 2004 Athens Olympics gold medalist, took the country's third bronze medal in the men' under-58 kg category of the event.
Sung fell to his knees and thanked his coach and his father, Sung Ching-hung, soon after he was announced the winner of the match.
Despite his victory, Sung said he felt the bronze medal was "not good enough."
"I am in perfect condition, " he said, expressing regret that he lost to Son Taejin of South Korea 6-7 in a semifinal match, thereby missing the opportunity for gold.
Taiwan's taekwondo fighters took two golds in the 2004 Athens Olympics.
In a quarterfinal match earlier in the day, Sung edged out Dmitriy Kim of Uzbekistan 3-2.

Meanwhile, in the women's 57 kg class, Taiwan's Su Li-wen, who had suffered from an injury to her left knee since the preliminary round of 16 earlier in the day, was defeated by Croatia's Martina Zubcic 4-5 in the bronze medal match.
Su tied with Zubcic 4-4 after the first three rounds, but lost a decisive point in the fourth round.
During the match, Su managed to continue fighting after falling several times in obvious pain, as she did in previous competitions.
Her perseverance earned her rounds of applause and cheers from the audience in Beijing, as well as from members of the press from various countries.
The 27-year-old -- who won gold at the 2006 Asian Games in Doha, the 2007 World University Games in Bangkok and the 2008 Asian Taekwondo Championship -- was taken to hospital soon after her defeat.
Prior to the competition, Su was described by the U.S.-based Sports Illustrated as the only Taiwanese athlete capable of winning a gold for the country. It was her first Olympics.
Her defeat came after she beat Robin Cheong of New Zealand 1-0 in the repechage section of the event, but lost the round of 16 to Lim Su-jeong of South Korea 0-1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Catholic university sends medical volunteers to India

TEXT.P: Fu Jen Catholic University in northern Taiwan sent a medical group of 19 volunteers to the eastern Indian city of Kolkata Thursday for a 10-day mission.
University President Bernard Chien-chiu Li told the volunteers prior to their departure that they should deeply understand what other people need and accumulate some life experience during the trip.
Second-year students Yang Ya-ching and Tsai Wan-ying described the trip as a rare opportunity to experience life and said they hope to grow personally through serving others.
University Vice President Michael Wei-Hsia Kwo, who is leading the group, lauded the students for spending their summer vacation in a meaningful manner.
He said he hopes they will "learn from doing" and learn to cherish life during the trip.
The group members will serve as medial volunteers at five centers in the city, where they will serve poor and seriously ill street people and children.

DOC.HEADLINE: 65% of executives in Taiwan suffer from poor heart-lung endurance

TEXT.P: Some 65 percent of the middle- and high-level executives in Taiwan lack regular exercise and as a consequence, suffer from poor heart and lung endurance, according to the results of a study released Thursday.

The study, conducted by the Lian An Preventive Medicine Organization, analyzed the physical examination results of 6,093 middle- and high-level executives who had visited the organization between 2000 and 2007, and interviewed them recently via questionnaire.

The results show that they worked an average 9.5 hours per day, that most of them were sedentary office workers, and that 55 percent of them admitted they were not in the habit of taking regular exercise.
The study also found that most of the executives suffered from physical fatigue due to their long working hours and preferred to spend their leisure time sleeping rather than exercising.
The physical results show that 65 percent of them had poor heart and lung endurance, while 58 percent had weak leg muscles, with another 52 percent failing to meet standards for waist suppleness.

Tsai Mei-wen, a lecturer at the Department of Physical Therapy and Assistive Technology of National Yang-Ming University, said poor heart and lung endurance can cause fatigue and poor concentration and increase the risks of coronary artery disease and metabolic diseases by up to five times higher than those with better heart and lung endurance.

She said a person who has little time for daily exercise must try to find time to exercise at least three times a week, with each session lasting at least 30 minutes and with enough exertion to increase the heart rate to 130 beats per minute.
According to Tsai, swimming and jogging are ideal forms of exercise because they are not too demanding and can improve heart and lung function.

DOC.HEADLINE: New location needed to ease overcrowding at detention center: PM

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Thursday that a new location for the Taipei Detention House in Tucheng, Taipei County is urgently needed to solve an overcrowding problem.
The detention house is used to incarcerate lawsuit suspects and people serving short prison sentences.
According to Lee Mung-tung, director-general of the detention house, the inmates numbered around 3,600 as of the end of July, while the capacity should be only about 2,100.
Lee said overcrowding in the women's section is even more serious, with an excess ratio of 198 percent, which is lower than the 302 percent recorded in 2007.
Many female inmates have to sleep at a nearby vocational training plant because there is not enough space in the detention center, Lee said.

Liu said an earlier government plan of moving the detention house to a former Ministry of National Defense ammunition depot in the county has raised objections from local residents, but he said the government will continue to communicate with local residents to seek their consent and cooperation.
He also asked the Taipei county government and the Ministry of Justice, which supervises the detention house, to work together on measures to carry out the move.

Liu said the government will promote the idea of replacing penalties for petty crimes with alternative punishments like community service or fines to ease the problem of overcrowding, which he said is affecting the environment around the detention house.

Before Liu went to the detention house, he also reviewed the environment of the Hsindian Drug Abuse Treatment Center in the county's Hsindian City and issued instruction for improving the center's treatment efficiency, including increasing supervisory personnel and renovating and updating the facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday Aug. 22, or the 22nd day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat, according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1834: Samuel Pierpoint Langley, American astronomer and aviation pioneer, is born. He built the first successful heavier-than-air flying machines in 1896.
1849: Amaral, the Portuguese governor of Macao, is assassinated for practicing anti-Chinese politics.
1910: Korea is formally annexed by Japan after five years as a Japanese protectorate.
1911: Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa, one of the world's most famous paintings, is stolen from the Louvre in Paris. It was returned two years later.
1919: Some 5,000 Jews are massacred in the Ukraine.
1932: Japanese troops attack Jehol in northern China.
1937: The Chinese Communist Party issues a statement calling on the people to obey the National government and join the War of Resistance Against Japan, and changes its "Red Army" into the Eighth Army.
1941: German troops reach the outskirts of Leningrad.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States for a visit at the invitation of President Franklin D. Roosevelt. FDR announced on March 30 the establishment of the Pacific War Council in Washington, comprised of China, the United States, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Australia, Canada and the Netherlands.
1968: Warsaw Pact tanks enter Prague, the Czech capital, to crush the first flowering of Alexander Dubcek's reforms.
1973: Henry Kissinger is named U.S. secretary of state, succeeding William Rogers.
1981: A Boeing 737 passenger plane owned by the Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes near Miaoli in central Taiwan, killing all 110 people aboard.
1983: China Airlines suspends its CI811 flight to Manila on orders of the Philippine civil aviation authorities. Manila had warned international airlines not to allow opposition leader Benigno Aquino to board their aircraft for a return to the Philippines on the grounds that he did not have legal travel papers.
Aquino was gunned down on Aug. 21 while soldiers were escorting him from his China Airlines flight from Taipei upon his return to Manila after three years of self-exile in the United States.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the appointment by President Chiang Ching-kuo of Ronald H. C. Ho (Ho Hsien-chung) as the new finance political vice minister.
1985: A British Airtour Boeing 747 bound for Corfu catches fire at Manchester Airport shortly after engine failure had forced the pilot to abandon the takeoff. The fire killed 54 people aboard.
1986: Francisco Zepeda Andino, the new Honduran ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1986: Wang Han successfully swims across the Strait of Gibraltar, becoming the first Chinese person to do so.
1986: Typhoon Wayne blasts across central and southern Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu), killing or injuring 256 people and causing property losses estimated at NT$11.5 billion. The typhoon damage is the heaviest in the past twenty years. The Executive Yuan allocates NT$1 billion to help victims.
1995: The KMT convenes its 14th National Congress and Lee Teng-hui, party chairman, announces he will seek the party's presidential nomination. Lin Yang- kang, a KMT vice chairman, declares his intention not to seek the party's nomination and to instead run as an independent.
1996: The 61-nation Conference on Disarmament in Geneva ends in failure after India blocked an agreement on a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
1999: A China Airlines passenger plane with 315 on board crash-lands at Chek Lap Kok airport in Hong Kong during a typhoon, killing two and injuring 211.
2000: Opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong says that it is still too early to talk about overhauling the Guidelines for National Unification as the government has yet to demonstrate consistency regarding its cross-strait policies.
2000: Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore decorades visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian with the Order of Grande Croix in recognition of his contribution to promoting bilateral ties.
2001: Republic of China Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya, along with a 20-strong delegation, attends the 2001 Women's Leaders Meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Beijing.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If another man succeeds through one effort, use a hundred efforts. If another man succeeds though ten efforts, use a thousand efforts. Let a man really proceed in this manner, and, though dull, he will surely become intelligent; though weak, he will surely become strong."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Ex-MJIB head's homes searched in document concealment probe

TEXT.P: Prosecutors raided three houses belonging to former Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) Director Yeh Sheng-mao late Thursday in a probe into the alleged concealment of documents related to suspected money laundering by the former first family.

Prosecutors searched Yeh's homes in Taipei City and Taoyuan County for documents regarding a report received by the MJIB's Money Laundering Prevention Center in January that said the daughter-in-law of then-President Chen Shui-bian maintained a bank account in the Cayman Islands.
The report was passed on to Taiwan by the Egmont Group -- an international anti- money laundering organization -- of which the MJIB is a member.

However, the local prosecutorial authorities were not made aware of the information until the Swiss authorities approached Taiwan recently for assistance in probes into suspected money laundering in Switzerland by Chen's daughter-in-law, Huang Jui-ching.

Yeh, who retired from the top MJIB post after the inauguration of the Kuomintang government in May, admitted last weekend that he did not deliver any formal documents concerning the sensitive information to the prosecution before his retirement because of what he claimed was his "personal negligence."

Yeh, who is one of the former president's proteges, claimed that he made an oral report to State Public Prosecutor-General Chen Tsung-ming in early February -- a claim that the prosecutor-general strongly denied.
The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) directed the Taipei Prosecutors Office early this week to investigate who should be held accountable for withholding the critical intelligence.

On Thursday, the prosecution summoned Chou You-yi, director of the MJIB's Money Laundering Prevention Center for questioning. Chou was quoted as having told prosecutors that the center had documented the intelligence from the Egmont Group and passed it to Yeh in the form of an official file.

In March, Chou said, he again asked Yeh whether he had forwarded the information to the prosecution. "Yeh told me at the time that he had forwarded the document to the state public prosecutor-general, " Chou told prosecutors.
In Thursday's raids on Yeh's three homes, prosecutors reportedly did not discover any of the official records or documents in question.

While searching Yeh's residence in Taipei's suburban Muzha district, prosecutors reportedly questioned some of Yeh's family members and scrutinized community security monitoring videos in an effort to verify a recent report about Yeh hiring a truck to move cases of articles out of his home there.

Yeh did not come home until after the prosecutors had concluded their search. Lin Chin-tsun, a spokesman for the prosecutors office, was tight-lipped on the issue and declined to brief the press on the latest prosecutorial operations on the grounds that the case is still being investigated in accordance with the law.

Anonymous prosecutorial sources said they suspect the critical documents might have been destroyed. Prosecutors are scheduled to summon Yeh for further questioning in the coming days, the sources added.
Yeh has been listed as a person whose movements require monitoring and whose entries into or departures from Taiwan must be immediately reported because of his suspected concealment of information.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 drug development investment hits NT$2.72 billion

TEXT.P: Investment in new drug development for the first six months of the year amounted to NT$2.72 billion, 18 times higher than the year-earlier level, according to a report released Friday by the Industry and Technology Intelligence Services (ITIS).
The ITIS is a Web site operated by the Ministry of Economic Affairs to provide timely business information and analysis for the reference of the public.

The total investment amount of the biotechnology industry was registered at NT$10.7 billion, of which NT$5.33 billion, or 49.8 percent, went into the pharmaceutical manufacturing sector, including new drug development, according to the report.

Investment in the agricultural biotechnology sector for the same period registered NT$2.5 billion, accounting for 23.4 percent of the total investment in the biotechnology industry and representing an increase of 3.8 times over the year-earlier level, the report said.
Investment in general biotechnology and the medical-related industry for the first six months was NT$11.89 billion, slightly higher than NT$11.87 billion of the same period of last year

The report also noted that the export value of biotechnology products in six major categories -- plant seedlings, vaccines, experiment reagents, biomedical materials, antibodies and food biotechnology -- for the first six months was estimated at NT$1.74 billion, up 16.4 percent from the year-earlier level, while import value was estimated to reach NT$3.1 billion, up 6.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: President meets visiting U.S. congressional delegation

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that his government has been working hard to mend fences between top-level officials of Taiwan and the United States following eight years of strained relations under the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration.

Ma made the comments while meeting with a U.S. congressional delegation headed by Carolyn Bartholomew, vice chairwoman of the U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission (USCC) , at the Presidential Office.
The president expressed confidence that with continued efforts, friendly relations between top officials from the two countries will soon be restored.
He also noted that his administration has been working hard to improve cross- Taiwan Strait ties since assuming office three months ago, with fruitful results.
Tension between Taiwan and China has been significantly reduced as a result of these efforts, he added.

The president noted that during his recent stopover in Los Angeles en route to Latin America for a state visit to two of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the region, he had conversations in person or over the phone with 31 members of the U.S. Congress, who all said that the positive development of cross-strait ties is in America's national interest.

The government will continue to hold talks with China on a variety of trade and transport issues, Ma went on, expressing hope that besides seeing a normalization in economic relations across the strait, the two sides will come to a truce on the international relations front for everyone's benefit.
Noting that many members of the delegation have been to Taiwan before, Ma said this visit is different from previous ones because of the fundamental changes in the cross-strait situation.

The president also expressed the hope that the U.S. administration will approve as soon as possible the sale of seven weapons systems to Taiwan that has already received the green light from Congress.

The list of arms in question includes P-3C Orion anti-submarine planes, anti- tank missiles, PAC-3 missiles, Apache helicopters, diesel powered submarines, sea-launched Harpoon missiles, and F-16 C/D fighters.
Ma called for Washington to approve the transfer in order to allow Taiwan to maintain proper defensive capabilities.

In order to show Taiwan's resolve in living up to its obligations to provide for its own defenses, the nation's defense budget will not drop to below 3 percent of gross domestic product in the future, he added.

The USCC, created in 2000 by an act of Congress, monitors, investigates and submits to Congress annual reports on the national security implications of the bilateral trade and economic relationship between the United States and China, and provides recommendations to Congress for legislative and administrative action when necessary.
Bartholomew was re-appointed to the commission for a fourth term in December last year by U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, for whom she has previously served as chief of staff.

DOC.HEADLINE: President lauds taekwondo fighter for courage, perseverance

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called Taiwanese taekwondo fighter Su Li-wen Friday to offer his admiration for the courage and perseverance she demonstrated in her fights at the Beijing Olympic Games Thursday despite injury, according to Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi.

In a phone call to Beijing, Ma told Su, who battled to the end in the women's 57kg taekwondo bronze medal competition in defiance of a painful knee injury, that her courage and perseverance have tremendously touched his heart and those of all the people in Taiwan, Wang told reporters.
"The sportsmanship you demonstrated provides an exemplary model for the country's youth to emulate that is worth far more than any gold medal," Ma told Su.

Su, 27, champion of the 2006 Asian Games in Doha, the 2007 World University Games in Bangkok and the 2008 Asian Taekwondo Championship, suffered an injury to her left knee in the preliminary round of 16 earlier Thursday.
She tied with Croatia's Martina Zubcic 4-4 after the first three rounds of the bronze medal match, but was defeated after losing a decisive point in the fourth round.
During the match, Su continued battling till the end despite falling 11 times -- in obvious pain -- as she did in previous competitions.
Her perseverance earned her rounds of applause and cheers from the audience in Beijing, as well as from members of the international press.
Su was carried from the mat by her coach after her defeat and was taken to hospital for immediate treatment.
Prior to the competition, Su was described by the U.S.-based Sports Illustrated as the only Taiwanese athlete capable of winning a gold for the country. It was her first Olympics.
Meanwhile, according to Wang, Ma also phoned Su's father in Taishan, Taipei County, Friday to tell the senior Su how proud the country is of his daughter.
Ma asked Su's father to tell his daughter not to be daunted by the defeats that she suffered in the Olympics and to carry on with her career as a professional taekwondo fighter, according to Wang.

TAIEX Index futures for October lost 12 points to finish at 6,843, with 402 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 25 points to close at 6,815, with 75 contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to write to foreign media if nation's image continues to worsen

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday that the ministry will instruct all embassies and overseas representative offices to write to local media to explain the government's stance if the nation's image continues to be marred by the scandal involved the former first family's alleged funneling of large sums of cash into foreign bank accounts.
Officials indicated that the Foreign Ministry is raising its alert on the international response to the scandal and is ready to take more action to protect the country's image.

"If the international media continues to report on the matter, I think our MOFA officials will have to write to the media, " MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said. "The basic stance will be that the government is determined to tackle corruption."
The ministry released a statement a day earlier for use by the country's overseas representative offices and embassies to explain the scandal.

The statement said the Republic of China holds a firm stance of opposing money- laundering, an offense that harms social justice and abuses international financial freedom, adding that the ministry will fully cooperate with the investigation and ask for assistance from related foreign governments and international anti-money-laundering organizations in order to clarify the truth as soon as possible

Noting that laws regulating public servants' political funds have failed to keep pace with Taiwan's democratic progress, the MOFA stressed that consensus has been reached across party lines at the Legislative Yuan recently that a draft "Property of Unknown Source Act" will be reviewed in the next legislative session.

"These principles are aimed at letting the international media know that our government is doing a lot, " Chen said. "We hope that the international community will understand that the government is not only hard-working but also proactive in fighting corruption, as it is something it finds completely unacceptable," he added.

He confirmed that the Control Yuan sent two of its committee members and an investigator to the Foreign Ministry Thursday, saying that the ministry offered its full cooperation and provided information related to the case.

Former President Chen Shui-bian admitted last Thursday that he lied about the campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004 and that his wife wired surplus campaign contributions into overseas bank accounts held by members of his family.

His confession came only after the Foreign Ministry confirmed earlier that same day that the Swiss authorities have sought Taiwan's help in a probe into a possible money laundering case in Switzerland involving Chen's son Chen Chih- chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.
The former president claims that his wife Wu Shu-jen made the wire transfers without his knowledge.
Prosecutors have banned Chen from leaving the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese capital deregulation to be Cabinet's 2009 policy priority

TEXT.P: Easing restrictions on Chinese investment in Taiwan's stock market will be one of the government's policy priorities for the coming year, according to a package of policy guidelines approved by the Cabinet Thursday.
Under the guidelines, the government will gradually allow Chinese investment in the local bourse and will set up a monitoring mechanism to oversee financial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
Meanwhile, the government will amend laws to facilitate local financial institutions' investment and business expansion in China.
In addition, the government will encourage foreign companies, including overseas Taiwanese companies, to list on Taiwan's stock exchange to enhance the country's international competitiveness.
The measures are part of the government's goal of building Taiwan into a regional financial operation center in the Asia Pacific, the Cabinet said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 30%-40% hospital patients suffer from malnutrition: survey

TEXT.P: Up to 40 percent of hospital inpatients suffer from malnutrition, with the ratio as high as between 50 percent and 60 percent for patients in gastroenterology and oncology wards, National Cheng Kung University Hospital said Friday.

Kao Ai-wen, director of the hospital's nutrition support service, said that if patients are malnourished before being admitted to the hospital, 80 percent of them will deteriorate after being admitted, according to the results of a survey.
Kao cited her hospital as an example, saying that "among the inpatients, 30 percent of them suffer from malnutrition, while 26 percent of colorectal patients have serious malnutrition."

Kao noted that nutrition plays a major role in treatment and that malnutrition not only add risks of complication and mortality but also dramatically increases the chances of infection, the number of days spent in hospital, and the medical costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX
