According to an MOE official, Yang, a silver medalist in last year's IOI, graduated from the Taipei Municipal Jianguo High School in June and has been admitted to the Department of Electrical Engineering at National Taiwan University (NTU).
Wu is set to enter the National Tainan First Senior High School, the official went on, while Hsu will enter his third year at the Affiliated Senior High School of National Taiwan Normal university.

Hsu recalled that his interest for program designing was sparked one day in elementary school when a computer virus destroyed all his documents and a favorite computer game. Since then, he has vowed to design his own computer games.

Chen graduated from the Kaohsiung Municipal Kaohsiung Senior High School this year and will enter his freshman year at the NTU's Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering in September, said the MOE official.

According to the MOE official, gold medalists Yang and Wu, silver medal winner Hsu and bronze medalist Chen will be awarded NT$200,000 (US$6,370), NT$100,000 and NT$50,000, respectively, after they return to Taiwan Aug. 28.
The eight-day Olympiad was scheduled to end Aug. 23 and next year's competition will be held in Bulgaria, the official noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Jan-July inward FDI down 41.53% year-on-year

TEXT.P: Both inward and outward foreign direct investment (FDI) decreased in the first seven months of 2008, according to a report released this week by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

During the January-July period, inward FDI approved by the government amounted to US$4.2 billion, down 41.53 percent from the same period last year, and registered outward FDI amounted to US$2.41 billion, a drop of 18.25 percent year-on-year, statistics from the ministry's Investment Commission showed.

New securities issued overseas by Taiwan-based listed companies amounted to US$1.07 billion during the same period, and foreign investors remitted a net amount of US$5.97 billion into Taiwan for investment in the stock market, according to data from the Securities and Futures Bureau under the Financial Supervisory Commission.

In terms of major China-bound investment projects worth over US$200,000, a total of 335 such projects were approved by the commission during the first seven months of this year, with a total value of US$5.16 billion, the report stated.
Although the number of such projects dropped 43.51 percent compared with the same period last year, their total value marked a year-on-year increase of 6.77 percent, the report said.
The approved projects included 26 investments worth US$387.65 million in July, it said.
For China-bound projects worth no more than US$200,000, Taiwanese businesses reported 144 such investments worth US$18.97 million in the first seven months of the year, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Disabled population rising in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The number of citizens with physical or mental disabilities has continued to increase in Taiwan, having climbed to 4.47 percent of the country's population as of the end of June 2008, according to a report released Friday by the Ministry of the Interior.
The figure rose from 4.37 percent at the end of June 2007 and 3.37 percent at the end of 2001, the report stated.
At the end of June 2008, the number of registered disabled individuals totaled 1.027 million, up 26,000, or 2.6 percent, over the year-earlier level.

Of these disabled individuals, those with limb disorders formed the largest group, accounting for 38.9 percent of the total disabled population, followed by those with hearing impairments at 10.7 percent and those suffering loss of important organ function at 10.37 percent.

Multiple disabilities accounted for 9.7 percent, chronic mental disorder accounted for 9.6 percent, mental retardation for 8.98 percent, sight impairments 5.34 percent, dementia 2.46 percent, speech disorders 1.27 percent, and other disabilities 2.64 percent.

Compared with the same time last year, the number of people suffering loss of important organ function increased by 6,245, which represented the biggest rise, followed by an increase of 4,261 among persons with chronic mental disorders.
In terms of percentage, the largest growth, 13.8 percent, was recorded for people with dementia.

Meanwhile, 36.15 percent of the disabled population was determined to have mild disabilities, 34.3 percent moderate disabilities, 18.26 percent serious disabilities, and 11.29 percent extremely serious disabilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Party celebrates 15th anniversary

TEXT.P: The small pro-unification New Party celebrated its 15th founding anniversary Saturday in Taipei City, with the party's chairman expressing the hope that Taiwan can become "an island of peace and a place without war."
Speaking at the gathering held at the Civil Service Development Institute, Yok Mu-ming noted that President Ma Ying-jeou has also said he wants the Taiwan Strait to be free of military conflict.
However, creating an island of peace cannot be easily achieved and requires the concerted efforts of all the parties involved, Yok said.

The New Party has therefore decided to employ innovative thinking and obtain the public's opinion before working to influence the government's policies and to realize its goal of lasting peace, he said.
Also speaking at the gathering, Robert Tsao, honorary chairman of chipmaker giant United Microelectronics Corp., reiterated his call for a "peaceful co- existence law" on cross-strait relations.
Tsao said that although the Republic of China on Taiwan is sovereign and independent, unification with China should not be ruled out.
However, unification must first be approved by the people of Taiwan through a referendum, and China must clearly state beforehand its conditions for unification, he stressed.
"Taiwan could move toward independence or it could pursue unification with China, but military conflict is not necessary in either scenario," Tsao said.

Several top central and local government officials attended the New Party's anniversary gathering, including Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, Presidential Office Secretary-General Chan Chun-po, and Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin.
KMT legislators Hung Hsiu-chu, Alex Tsai, and Lai Shyh-bao were also at the gathering.

Although the New Party has held a limited number of seats in the Legislative Yuan in the past, it failed to pass the 5-percent threshold to qualify for representation in the legislature in the most recent election held this January, in which it fielded 10 legislator-at-large candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: Business group criticized over Taipei Dome construction plan

TEXT.P: The construction plan for the Taipei Dome Complex proposed by the Farglory Group was strongly criticized by local residents at a seminar Saturday morning, as they asserted that the real intention is to make a profit from the commercial facilities that have been included in the plan.

According to Farglory's plan, the Taipei Dome Complex, or Taipei Culture and Sports District, will occupy about 18 hectares in the bustling Xinyi district and will include a 40,000-seat indoor stadium, hotels, department stores, shopping center and office buildings.

The complex, located on the site of the Songshan Tobacco Factory, is scheduled to be completed in 2010. But opposition to the projects and doubts expressed by local residents have made it difficult for the group to proceed.

Although the Farglory Group said at the seminar that Taiwan needs an indoor baseball park to foster the development of the sport, residents living close to the project rebutted that the area designated for commercial buildings is about double that for the sports dome.

"We are not opposed to the construction of a sports arena, but we do not want those commercial buildings," said Lin Hsue-fang, a member of an alliance that is advocating the Songshan Tobacco Factory site should be converted into a forest park instead of a shopping area.
But the Farglory representatives insisted that in order to maintain the proper operation of the stadium, a larger area would have to be dedicated to commercial enterprises.
The Songshan Tobacco Factory was constructed in 1937 under Japanese colonial rule. It was designated as a historical monument by the Taipei City Government in 2001.

"Farglory should not use baseball as an excuse. If we suffer a setback in our baseball games at the Olympics, a sumptuous dome is not what would make a difference, but rather an open space for everyone," Lin argued.

Local residents also worry that the establishment of a stadium in that area will result in heavy traffic congestion in the already busy district, and are contenting that the choice of location was poor.

"Currently, parking lots within 300 meters of the planned dome are already about 80 percent full on holidays, how can you expect that there will be no problem with tens of thousands people getting out in the future? " asked Lee Chin-yuan, a Kuomintang Taipei City Councilor, who was at the seminar.

The Farglory Group signed a contract with the Taipei City Government in 2006 for the BOT (build-operate-transfer) project. With the price of raw materials on the increase, the cost of the project is expected to reach NT$25 billion (US$800 million), according to the Farglory Group.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seven-year-old completes 1,000 km cycling tour in Europe

TEXT.P: Seven-year-old Chiu En-chia from the southern Taiwan city of Tainan recently completed a cycling tour that took him across Germany and Netherlands and earned him the title of the youngest Taiwanese to complete a cycling trip of more than 1,000 km.

Chiu, along with his parents, were part of a special tour group that cycled along the Rhine River from Germany's Frankfurt to Amsterdam in Holland in 29 days, starting June 29, a local newspaper reported Saturday.
Chiu's parents said they still could not believe that their son, who graduated from kindergarten this summer, completed the 1,000 km journey in Europe.
Chiu broke the record of Hsu Chan-jen of Taiwan, who cycled 1,022 km in 30 days across Germany and Denmark, at the age of nine, with his parents last summer.

After he returned home, Hsu published an account of his journey, entitled "Family Travel by Bike -- A Boy's Cycling Diary." The book has inspired many parents, said Chou Yiao-chue, a teacher at Tung Fang Institute of Technology in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan. Chou organized the cycling tour group that was comprised of more than 60 members, 10 of whom were elementary school students.

Cycling has become more and more popular in Taiwan over the last few years, with the biking population reaching 650,000 in 2007 and expected to surge to 1 million this year, according to statistics provided by Giant Bicycle Inc. -- Taiwan's largest bicycle maker.

A local cycling film, "Island Etude, " directed by En Chen and released in April 2007, further spurred a cycling craze around Taiwan. Inspired by the film, Giant founder King Liu cycled around the island that year in 15 days, at the age of 73.

DOC.HEADLINE: Leasing industry business volume up due to tough economic times

TEXT.P: Taiwan's leasing industry business volume reached NT$6.3 billion (US$200.6 million) for June, marking an increase of 13.84 percent over the figure for the same month a year earlier, according to the latest statistics released Saturday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The ministry said that amid tough economic times and shrinking real incomes in Taiwan, more and more consumers with tighter budgets are opting to lease instead of buy new products to reduce their spending.

By sector, the construction machinery equipment leasing industry saw the largest increase in business volume for June, rising 17.34 percent year-on-year to reach NT$2.7 billion, followed by consumer products, up 13.99 percent to NT$1.2 billion, and automobile leasing, up 10.22 percent to NT$2.5 billion, according to the ministry's tallies.

For the first half of 2008, the leasing industry's business volume amounted to NT$35.5 billion, up 10.2 percent over the previous year's level, with consumer product leasing leading the way with a 10.45 percent increase in business, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Magistrate takes part in activity to promote cycling

TEXT.P: Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei joined hundreds of residents of Taipei County and Taipei City in in a cycling promotion activity in the Hebin Riverside Park in Yonghe City Saturday morning.

Speaking at the activity, Chou said that cycling is not only a good way to help reduce carbon emissions and conserve energy, it is also a healthy form of exercise that the whole family can enjoy together.

Also taking part in the cycling activity was Kuomintang Legislator Lin Teh-fu, who said that the new government has been working hard to clean up and protect the environment, and has seen positive results so far.

Nearly 600 people joined the magistrate and lawmaker in cycling along the riverside park's bike path to promote the bicycle as an environmentally-friendly transportation alternative as well as a means of having fun in a family activity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-money laundering group says it's not involved in probe

TEXT.P: The Egmont Group, an international anti-money laundering network that played a key role in alerting Taiwan authorities to a high-profile case of possible money laundering embroiling Taiwan's former first family, commented for the first time on the matter Saturday, saying that its aim is to combat money laundering but that it is not involved in the probe.
In response to a CNA inquiry by e-mail, the group, headquartered in Canada, finally broke its silence 10 days after a scandal that embroiled former President Chen Shui-bian's family members broke.

"One of the main goals of the Egmont Group is to create a global network by promoting international cooperation between 'financial intelligence units' (FIUs) , " the Egmont Secretariat said in the e-mail, adding that for any information relating to a specific operational matter the FIU in the relevant country should be contacted.
"The Egmont Group does not get involved in such operational matters," the Secretariat said.
According to the Egmont Group, FIUs, which provide an important avenue for information exchange, are entities created by countries around the world to deal with the problem of money laundering.

It said operational case matters within a country or between countries may involve one FIU, or a number of FIUs getting together to follow the money trail, and is up to each FIU to determine whether it is appropriate for it to seek the involvement of other FIUs, or for it to be involved in this process.

Chen admitted last Thursday that he had lied about the campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004. He said that his wife had wired surplus campaign contributions to overseas bank accounts held by members of his family.

His confession came only after the Foreign Ministry confirmed earlier that same day that Swiss authorities had been seeking Taiwan's help in a probe into a possible money laundering case in Switzerland involving Chen's son Chen Chih- chung and daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.
The former president, who has been prohibited by prosecutors from leaving the country, claimed that his wife Wu Shu-jen made the wire transfers without his knowledge.

The matter came to light when a local magazine, based on a report by the Egmont Group, claimed that Huang had laundered money for the former first family by secretly wiring NT$300 million (US$10 million) overseas in 2006 after the exposure of a "state affairs fund" embezzlement case that implicated Chen and his wife.

The Egmont Group was established in 1995 to stimulate international cooperation between financial intelligence units, meeting regularly to find ways to cooperate, especially in the areas of information exchange, training and the sharing of expertise.
There are currently 108 countries that are members of the Egmont Group. Taiwan's Money Laundering Prevention Center under the Investigation Bureau joined the network in 1998.

Noting that governments around the world recognize the "corrosive dangers" that unchecked financial crimes pose to their economic and political systems, the Egmont Secretariat explained that FIUs, at a minimum, receive and analyze information from financial institutions and other reporting entities and after analyzing the data received, the FIUs may then disclose information relating to suspicious or unusual financial transactions to the competent authorities.
The Chen scandal was exposed under such cooperation.
Taiwan is now actively seeking judicial assistance from Switzerland, Singapore and the United States in the investigation of the scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan taking cautious approach to carbon storage

TEXT.P: Taiwan is still assessing the feasibility of developing the carbon capture and storage (CCS) technique, due to high costs and the possibility of leaks, even as neighboring Japan is taking steps to launch a huge CCS experiment.

According to a Japanese newspaper, the Japan government, along with electricity and oil companies, will initiate a large-scale experiment to store carbon dioxide, emitted from a coal-fired power plant, in a depleted undersea natural gas field.
Under Japan's plan, the carbon dioxide emitted by the coal-fired power plant will be recycled and piped to the gas field 70 kilometers off Japan's Pacific coast, the newspaper reported.
In Taiwan, CCS is also considered by some experts as feasible, given that Taiwan will continue to depend on traditional fossil fuels, according to the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research.
However, businesses and the government have so far been reserved about developing the costly CCS technique.
"The CCS technique is not a problem. The question is whether the technique will be of economic benefit to us," said an employee of the CPC Corporation, Taiwan's largest petroleum company.

Speaking on condition of anonymity, the CPC employee added that the cost of moving carbon dioxide from the emission source to a storage location would be high, and that the possibility of leaks is another concern.@

"Foreign petroleum companies can profit from developing the CCS technique, because when greenhouse gases are pumped into depleted oil wells, deposits of oil at the bottom of the well can be extracted, " Yeh Fung-luh, a senior specialist of the EPA Department of Air Quality Protection and Noise Control, told CNA, implying that Taiwan does not have this option.
In addition, violent earth movements may also cause leaking of stored carbon dioxide, he said.
CCS is seen as a means of helping to fight global warming by capturing carbon dioxide from large sources such as fossil fuel power plants and storing it instead of releasing it into the atmosphere.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. helped Taiwan to locate former president's son: top envoy
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 22 (CNA) 08/23/08 19:21:51 (By Lillian Lin, Chiehyu Lin, Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative to the United States said Friday that the U.S. has assisted Taiwan in locating former President Chen Hsui-bian's son, who reportedly is a key figure in a case of suspected money laundering involving the former first family.

Jason Yuan said that according to his understanding, Chen Chih-chung came to the United States on a student visa, but because he did not register with the University of Virginia's law school, his student visa has been revoked.
Yuan stressed that the United States acted in accordance with the ROC government's wishes to help locate Chen Chih-chung.
Meanwhile, an official of the University of Virginia said Friday that the school will refund Cheng Chih-chung's tuition.

Jeffrey G. Hanna, senior director of the school's public affairs, confirmed that Chen Chih-chung called Aug. 18 to say that he could not take part in orientation, and the school told him that his enrollment had been revoked.
Asked whether the Taiwan media had influenced or pressured the university into withdrawing Chen Chih-chung's enrollment, Hanna said that as far as he knows, this was not the case.

Chen Shui-bian, addressing a Rotary meeting in Taipei Friday, said his son had already registered with the school, paid the tuition and received a student ID, but because the Taiwan media kept harassing the university, his son's study plans fell through.
Hanna said an enrolled student can pay tuition by means of by checks, wire transfers or online payments, but since Chen Chih-chung did not register, he could not have had a student ID.
Hanna explained that after a student pays the tuition, the school will issue a "computer digital ID" to the student to select courses, but explained that this is by no means a "student ID."
Meanwhile, sources said the University of Virginia has notified the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services that Chen Chih-chung has not registered at the school.

The sources also said that since Taiwan prosecutors have issued a subpoena to Chen Chih-chung, he would probably return to face the probe because his student visa has been revoked and his stay in the United States is now illegal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan designer to be showcased at Olympics closing ceremony

TEXT.P: Great Britain, which will host the next summer Olympics in 2012, will make an eight-minute presentation Sunday at the closing ceremony of the Beijing Olympics, and one of the performers will wear a gown designed by a young Taiwan woman.
Venus Chen, who is now in London, told CNA that she designed and made the outfit for Leona Lewis, an English pop and R&B singer.
Chen was born in Taipei in 1985, but moved to New Zealand in the first year of junior high school. She was admitted to the famous London College of Fashion five years ago and graduated this July.

Chen said that during a commencement exhibition in May, the school's designs drew the attention of the London Olympics organizing committee and it was decided that the college would take charge of designing the performers outfits for Sunday night's closing ceremony.
Chen was chosen as one of the designers on the team, which she said has been a "great honor and a big challenge."
Chen also said the BBC has produced a program chronicling the
work of the design team and including an interview with her. The program will be aired after the Beijing Olympics, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan, Taiwan should seek closer cooperation: scholars

TEXT.P: Several researchers from Japan's nongovernmental Defense Research Center (DRC) said Saturday in Taipei that Taiwan is Japan's "life line" and that Japan's security could be at stake if Taiwan were to be annexed by China.

As Taiwan is situated at a strategic point that is critical to securing the sea lane on which Japan's survival and prosperity depend, they said, the Japanese government should seek bilateral political, economic and military cooperation.

Ueda Naruhiko, DRC executive director and retired lieutenant- general of Japan's Ground Self-Defense Force; Gomi Mutsuyoshi, DRC researcher and retired Vice Admiral of Japan's Maritime Self-Defense Force; and Sugiyama Katsumi, DRC researcher, made the remarks at a seminar held by Taiwan's National Security Institute and Japan's Asian Security Forum.

"Whether Taiwan will be annexed by China is a life and death issue to Japan, " Gomie said. "Taiwan plays the most important role in securing the sea lane on which Japan's survival and prosperity depend, " he added, referring to Japan's reliance on the sea lane for the import of energy and various other resources.

Gomi contended that Taiwan, which holds a significant strategic position, is crucial to further expansion by China to gain access to the Pacific and Indian oceans, and therefore China views Taiwan as a must-take place in order to realize its military ambitions.
"After swallowing up Taiwan, China will make it an 'anti-access station' against the United Sates," he said.
Sugiyama said China covets Taiwan's great economic, financial and industrial strength and that is why it wants to take Taiwan under its reign.

He added that in order to achieve that goal, China is not forcing its "one-China policy" on the Ma Ying-jeou administration, but rather is turning to increased bilateral economic exchanges so as to gradually dissolve the "psychological barriers" to reunification.
"Being both ocean countries, Taiwan and Japan share a 'common destiny' and should therefore seek dovetailed political, economic and military cooperation," Sugiyama said.

Contending that Taiwan should seek independence in order to help push the democratization of China and to play an active role in solving regional conflicts, Sugiyama suggested that Japan become a proactive staunch supporter of Taiwan in order to achieve regional peace.

"For that to happen, Taiwan has to be allowed to return to the international community," he said. "I believe if Taiwan is determined to contribute to world peace, Japan and the U.S. will also offer their full support for Taiwan to join the United Nations."
The Republic of China has tried without success to re-enter the U.N. since 1993, after losing its seat to the Peoples Republic of China in 1971.

Noting that Japan's national security is closely linked to Taiwan, Gomi suggested politicians and the people of Japan should recognize that fact and work closely with the U.S. in order to protect Japan's national security.

"If Taiwan is annexed by China, Japan will suffer tremendous economic and military pressure from China, " Gomi said. "As far as Japan's geopolitics is concerned, cooperating with the Anglo-America world is the best choice to safeguard the safety and prosperity of the Japanese people."
Ueda also advised Japan to maintain close governmental and civil cooperation and exchanges with Taiwan and the U.S. in order to overcome factors of possible instability.

"I am convinced that international relations based on civil cooperation between Japan, the U.S. and Taiwan -- countries which all value basic human rights -- will be the new motive power of the next generation," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP lawmakers blast 'war-free zone' proposal

TEXT.P: A proposal to build Taiwan into a "war-free zone" and an "island of peace" was harshly criticized Saturday by opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators, who said it would amount to robbing Taiwan of its statehood.
Legislator Lin Shu-fen said she believes that "peace is built on the ground with full preparation, " not under conditions that see a country "surrender its arms."

The person who proposed the "war-free zone" is a "fool" thinking about his own wishes, she said. Lin blasted the proposal as an attempt to seek Taiwan's "progressive unification" with China, and argued that unification is "against the will of most people in Taiwan."

Yok Mu-ming, chairman of the pro-unification New Party which is part of the Kuomintang-led "pan-blue alliance, " raised the proposal at an activity held earlier in the day to celebrate the New Party's 15th founding anniversary.
Yok said he hopes President Ma Ying-jeou will devote his efforts to turning Taiwan into a war-free area and an island of peace.

Once there is no threat of war between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and there is peace in the region, Taiwan should stop purchasing high-performance weapons from other countries and should disband its air and marine forces, Yok suggested.
The savings from Taiwan discontinuing its weapons procurement program could be used to develop the economy, technology, education and social welfare, he proposed.
Yok went public with the proposal in an interview with reporters the previous day, mentioning the president's pledge of "not seeking unification, independence or war."

As a war-free zone, Taiwan would need only to maintain an army -- a basic military force -- because the National Police can take care of social order, while the country's coastlines can be secured by the Coast Guard, Yok said.

In response, DPP Legislator Chiu Yi-ying said that no country in the world would voluntarily disband its air and marine forces. Besides, she added, China is not "totally friendly" toward Taiwan, as evidenced by Beijing's reluctance to dismantle its missiles targeting Taiwan.

Yok's proposal means surrendering Taiwan's dignity as a country -- in effect "denationalizing" Taiwan, said Chiu's legislative colleague Chang Hwa-kuan. Chang described the proposal as "naive, " while Chiu said it was "ridiculous."

DPP Legislator Huang Sue-ying also criticized the suggestion, saying that the question of peace in the strait is not up to Taiwan to decide, and noted that China has never stopped trying to squeeze Taiwan out of the international community.
If the so-called "war-free zone" proposal was workable, Taiwan would have declared itself a "neutral state" long time ago, she said, adding that Yok's remarks were "senseless."

DOC.HEADLINE: Three witnesses say former first lady managed campaign funds

TEXT.P: Three people who were involved in dealing with former President Chen Shui-bian's campaign funds stated Saturday that Chen's wife Wu Shu-jen was in charge of managing the funds, and that Chen might not have known how the money was being used.

The trio -- Huang Fang-yen, Wu's confidant and deputy superintendent of the Shin Kong Wu Ho Su Memorial Hospital; former National Security Council Secretary General Chiou I-jen; and Huang Wei-sheng, chairman of Bian Mao Factory and a big donor to Chen -- made the statements during questioning by prosecutors from the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office.
The prosecutors were trying to determine the source and the flow of the campaign funds, in their investigation into a case of suspected money laundering involving members of the former first family.

Chen said last week that the NT$700 million deposited in overseas accounts held by members of his family was surplus funds from his two mayoral campaigns and two presidential campaigns in the period from 1993 to 2004. Chen said that his wife had wired the money overseas without his knowledge, and that he did not learn of the transfers until early this year.

The prosecutors learned that Chen would set up a finance committee during each election campaign, with the campaign contributions handed over to Huang Fang-yen and Wu. Former China Steel Chairman Lin Wen-yuan was in charge of the campaign expenses, the prosecutors found.
In the 2004 presidential election, as Lin was then head of China Steel, a cashier at the Presidential Office -- Chen Cheng-hui -- was put in charge of the campaign expenses, the prosecutors said.

They said that during the presidential campaigns, several large political donations were turned over directly to Wu in cash, while some donations that required receipts were given to the Democratic Progressive Party and later transferred to Chen's campaign headquarters.
The prosecutors cited Huang as saying that he was not sure about the surplus campaign funds, and that "only Wu knew how much money was in the fund."
The reports Chen filed with the Central Election Commission stated that his campaign expenses in the two presidential elections amounted to NT$900 million in 2000 and NT$1.2 billion in 2004.
Chiou also said that Wu was in charge of the use of the funds in the election campaigns, and Chen "was very likely not aware of how the money was being used."
Huang Wei-sheng, who was in charge of the spending in Chen's two Taipei mayoral election campaigns, said that surplus donations amounted to NT$10 million in 1994 and NT$30 million in 1998.

The high-profiled case came to light when a local magazine, based on a report by the international anti-money laundering organization, the Egmont Group, claimed last week that Chen Shui-bian's daughter-in-law, Huang Jui-ching, had laundered money for the former first family by secretly wiring NT$300 million overseas in 2006 after the exposure of a "state affairs fund" embezzlement case that implicated Chen Shui-bian and his wife.

The report detailed the status of overseas bank accounts allegedly held by members of Chen Shui-bian's family, in countries that include the United States, the Cayman Islands, Singapore and Switzerland.

The former president and his wife, as well as Wu's older brother Wu Ching-mao, Chen's son Chen Chih-chung and Huang Jui-ching, have been listed as suspects by prosecutors in the alleged money-laundering case. Chen Shui-bian, Wu Hsu-jen and Wu Ching-mao have also been barred from leaving the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor departs on U.S. visit

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin departed for the United States Saturday on an eight- day trip aimed at learning from the U.S. experience in waterfront urban development and municipal administration.
City government officials said Hau will visit Boston and New York to study their urban rejuvenation projects, urban beach management, crime-fighting drives and welfare service programs.

Hau is traveling with a delegation of city government officials and councilors. His entourage includes city government Deputy Secretary-General Chen Yung-jen, Department of Urban Development Commissioner Ting Yu-chun and Emile C. J. Sheng, head of the city's Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.

According to the itinerary released by the city government, Hau and his entourage will first visit Boston where they will pay a courtesy call on Mohsen Mostafavi, dean of the Graduate School of Design at Harvard University, who is also a member of a panel screening an international design contest for Taipei's new arts center construction project.
The delegation will also visit Boston's noted "Big Dig" express road tunnel construction project as well as its waterfront development project and an old market reconstruction project.
On Aug. 27, the group will travel to New York City to get see for themselves operations of its city government and city council.

Hau will meet with New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg to exchange views on urban environmental protection issues and invite the city to take part in the 2010 Taipei International Flower Exhibition. He will also invite Bloomberg and former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani to attend the opening ceremony for the 21st Deaflympics to be held in Taipei next year.

During their three-day stay in New York, Hau and his entourage will visit the city's 311 Citizen Service Center, urban beach and the Harlem urban renewal area as well as its famous waterfront parks, including Battery Park, Hudson River Park and Brooklyn Bridge Park. They are scheduled to wrap up their two-leg visit Aug.31 and return to Taipei Sept.2.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 24, 2008

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: President will hold out olive branch in marking 823 battle

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will hold out an olive branch in his speech to be delivered on the outlying island of Kinmen Sunday to mark the 50th anniversary of the 1958 artillery battle between Taiwan and China, Ma's aides said Saturday.

Ma's speech, titled "from killing field to peace square, " will stress the need for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to nurture good will and mutual trust to lay a foundation for future negotiations of a cross-strait peace agreement, Presidential Office staff said.

According to his aides, Ma's speech will be delivered at a commemorative rally to be held at Chingtien Hall -- a towering hall built inside a mountain -- in Kinmen where the artillery battle took place. Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and many other civilian and military officials will also attend the rally.
"Ma will focus on three key points in his address, " said one of his close aides who preferred anonymity.
First, Ma will recognize the artillery battle, which is more commonly known as 823 battle as it began on Aug. 23, 1958, as a "turning point in Taiwan's history."
The battle lasted for 44 days during which Communist Chinese artillery troops hammered the 148 square-kilometer Kinmen island with 500,000 shells.

Besides expressing his admiration for the late President Chiang Kai-shek's strategy and determination and for the generous U.S. assistance which combined to enable Kinmen to withstand the fierce attack, Ma will also reaffirm his administration's determination to transform Kinmen from a battlefield into a symbol of peace and make every effort to prevent recurrence of cross-strait war.

In the second part of his speech, Ma will pitch for deepening of peaceful way of thinking and strengthening of defense capabilities. Ma will vow to expand cross- strait exchanges and cooperation in trade, education, cultural development and international affairs in order to lay a solid foundation for future talks on the signing of an agreement to perpetuate peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Nevertheless, Ma will simultaneously reiterate his commitment to contribute 3 percent of Taiwan's annual GDP to beefing up its defense arsenal. Ma will stress that the expansion of defense capacity is aimed at deterring, not provoking, war.
In conclusion, Ma will express his gratitude for the hardships Kinmen residents have endured during the artillery battle and their sacrifice in the ensuing years.
He will also reaffirm his promise of turning Kinmen into "a peace square of the 21st century" from "a cross-strait killing field of te 20th century."

To attain that goal, Ma will unveil mid- and long-term development plans which will integrate Kinmen's tourism, industrial and cultural resources to revamp its economy. Concrete stimulus measures will include review the feasibility of building a bridge between Kinmen and Xiamen in China's southeastern Fujian province and allowing imports of water from Xiamen to resolve its water shortage problems. Kinmen lies closer to Xiamen than to Taiwan proper.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier rules out Cabinet reshuffle

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Saturday he has no plan to replace any Cabinet member at the moment, even though he feels there is still room for improvement in its overall performance.
Liu made the remarks in an interview broadcast live on TVBS, a cable TV channel, late Saturday.
Amid the approach of the Cabinet's 100th day in office, criticism has arisen that Liu's Cabinet has not lived up to public expectations, particularly in inflation control.

Asked whether the Cabinet's lineup is likely to be adjusted anytime soon, Liu said that although the Cabinet's performance was less than ideal or fell short of expectations in some aspects, the overall policy direction is correct.

"When it comes to Cabinet performance, I care most about direction of policy initiatives and about whether those initiatives have been executed in the right direction and are moving closer to projected goals, " Liu explained.

Generally speaking, Liu went on, the current administrative team is not bad. "All Cabinet members have worked hard and performed fairly well, even though there is still some room for improvement, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 24, or the 24th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The small but very bitter war being fought between Britain and the United States continues, with British forces razing many Washington, D.C. landmarks, including the White House.
1923: A "Dr. Sun Yat-sen mission" led by Chiang Kai-shek leaves Harbin for Moscow on a fact-finding tour.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's Nationalist government, signs the ratification instrument of the U.N. Charter.
1945: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China ratifies the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: Communist China sends troops into Tibet.
1954: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs into law the Communist Control Act, outlawing the Communist Party.
1954: Brazilian President Getulio Vargas shoots himself to avoid scandal as well as demands that he relinquish power. He was 71.
1968: Taichung's Golden Dragons baseball team defeats the U.S. West team 5A-0 to win the 23rd Little League World Championship.
1981: A Manhattan Supreme Court judge jails Mark David Chapman for 20 years to life for shooting dead John Lennon the previous December.
1983: The auditorium of Fengyuan High School in Taichung County collapses, killing 27 students and injuring 83 others.
1983: Communist Chinese pilot Lt. Col. Sun Tien-chin, who flew to South Korea from mainland China in a MiG-21 jet fighter Aug. 7, arrives in Taiwan.
1985: Communist Chinese pilot Hsiao Tien-jun, 33, flies an H-5 torpedo attack bomber to South Korea and requests political asylum in the ROC.
1986: The ROC Little League baseball team "Kungyuan" defeats Tucson, Arizona, and recaptures the Little League World Series title after four years.
1991: The Ukraine declares independence from Moscow.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as head of the Soviet Communist Party and urges its leadership to disband the party.
1992: Communist China and South Korea establish diplomatic relations.
1995: President Juan Carlos Wasmosy of Paraguay leads a delegation to Taipei for a four-day visit.
1995: Beijing expels Chinese-American human rights activist Harry Wu shortly after he was sentenced to a 15-year prison term for spying and leaking state secrets.
1996: The ROC wins the 1996 Little League World Series in the U.S. city of Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
1999: A UNI Air plane from Taipei crash-lands at Hualien Airport in flames, injuring 28 passengers.
1999: Ever Decent, a Panamanian-flagged container ship owned by Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp., is hit by Norwegian Dream, a Bahamas-registered cruise ship, injuring three people aboard the cruise ship.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian wraps up his visit to Chad ahead of schedule after issuing a joint communique with Chadian President Idriss Deby.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian officiates at the opening of the plenary session of the much-anticipated Economic Development Advisory Conference Friday, a series of meetings and discussions designed to invigorate Taiwan's floundering economy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses great moral qualities will certainly attain a corresponding high position, a corresponding great prosperity, a corresponding great name, and a corresponding great age."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor departs on U.S. visit

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin departed for the United States Saturday on an eight- day trip aimed at learning from the U.S. experience in waterfront urban development and municipal administration.
City government officials said Hau will visit Boston and New York to study their urban rejuvenation projects, urban beach management, crime-fighting drives and welfare service programs.

Hau is traveling with a delegation of city government officials and councilors. His entourage includes city government Deputy Secretary-General Chen Yung-jen, Department of Urban Development Commissioner Ting Yu-chun and Emile C. J. Sheng, head of the city's Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.

According to the itinerary released by the city government, Hau and his entourage will first visit Boston where they will pay a courtesy call on Mohsen Mostafavi, dean of the Graduate School of Design at Harvard University, who is also a member of a panel screening an international design contest for Taipei's new arts center construction project.
The delegation will also visit Boston's noted "Big Dig" express road tunnel construction project as well as its waterfront development project and an old market reconstruction project.
On Aug. 27, the group will travel to New York City to get see for themselves operations of its city government and city council.

Hau will meet with New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg to exchange views on urban environmental protection issues and invite the city to take part in the 2010 Taipei International Flower Exhibition. He will also invite Bloomberg and former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani to attend the opening ceremony for the 21st Deaflympics to be held in Taipei next year.

During their three-day stay in New York, Hau and his entourage will visit the city's 311 Citizen Service Center, urban beach and the Harlem urban renewal area as well as its famous waterfront parks, including Battery Park, Hudson River Park and Brooklyn Bridge Park. They are scheduled to wrap up their two-leg visit Aug.31 and return to Taipei Sept.2.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three witnesses say former first lady managed campaign funds

TEXT.P: Three people who were involved in dealing with former President Chen Shui-bian's campaign funds stated Saturday that Chen's wife Wu Shu-jen was in charge of managing the funds, and that Chen might not have known how the money was being used.

The trio -- Huang Fang-yen, Wu's confidant and deputy superintendent of the Shin Kong Wu Ho Su Memorial Hospital; former National Security Council Secretary General Chiou I-jen; and Huang Wei-sheng, chairman of Bian Mao Factory and a big donor to Chen -- made the statements during questioning by prosecutors from the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office.
The prosecutors were trying to determine the source and the flow of the campaign funds, in their investigation into a case of suspected money laundering involving members of the former first family.

Chen said last week that the NT$700 million deposited in overseas accounts held by members of his family was surplus funds from his two mayoral campaigns and two presidential campaigns in the period from 1993 to 2004. Chen said that his wife had wired the money overseas without his knowledge, and that he did not learn of the transfers until early this year.

The prosecutors learned that Chen would set up a finance committee during each election campaign, with the campaign contributions handed over to Huang Fang-yen and Wu. Former China Steel Chairman Lin Wen-yuan was in charge of the campaign expenses, the prosecutors found.
In the 2004 presidential election, as Lin was then head of China Steel, a cashier at the Presidential Office -- Chen Cheng-hui -- was put in charge of the campaign expenses, the prosecutors said.

They said that during the presidential campaigns, several large political donations were turned over directly to Wu in cash, while some donations that required receipts were given to the Democratic Progressive Party and later transferred to Chen's campaign headquarters.
The prosecutors cited Huang as saying that he was not sure about the surplus campaign funds, and that "only Wu knew how much money was in the fund."
The reports Chen filed with the Central Election Commission stated that his campaign expenses in the two presidential elections amounted to NT$900 million in 2000 and NT$1.2 billion in 2004.
Chiou also said that Wu was in charge of the use of the funds in the election campaigns, and Chen "was very likely not aware of how the money was being used."
Huang Wei-sheng, who was in charge of the spending in Chen's two Taipei mayoral election campaigns, said that surplus donations amounted to NT$10 million in 1994 and NT$30 million in 1998.

The high-profiled case came to light when a local magazine, based on a report by the international anti-money laundering organization, the Egmont Group, claimed last week that Chen Shui-bian's daughter-in-law, Huang Jui-ching, had laundered money for the former first family by secretly wiring NT$300 million overseas in 2006 after the exposure of a "state affairs fund" embezzlement case that implicated Chen Shui-bian and his wife.

The report detailed the status of overseas bank accounts allegedly held by members of Chen Shui-bian's family, in countries that include the United States, the Cayman Islands, Singapore and Switzerland.

The former president and his wife, as well as Wu's older brother Wu Ching-mao, Chen's son Chen Chih-chung and Huang Jui-ching, have been listed as suspects by prosecutors in the alleged money-laundering case. Chen Shui-bian, Wu Hsu-jen and Wu Ching-mao have also been barred from leaving the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Kinmen will be turned from killing field to peace square: Ma
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Aug. 24 (CNA) 08/24/08 15:59:13 (By R.H. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou promised Sunday that the outlying island of Kinmen, a former killing field in a battle between Taiwan and China, will be turned into a peace square, as cross-strait relations have been thawing.
Ma held out an olive branch to China in his speech delivered at a ceremony held on Kinmen to mark the 50th anniversary of the 1958 artillery battle between Taiwan and China.
He reaffirmed his administration's determination to transform Kinmen from a battlefield into a symbol of peace and to make every effort to prevent a recurrence of cross-strait war.

In his speech, titled "From killing field to peace square, " Ma stressed the need for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to nurture goodwill and mutual trust so as to lay the foundation for future negotiations on a cross-strait peace agreement.
Ma also announced several governmental policies to help expedite Kinmen's development and further cement cross-strait relations, via Kinmen.
To attain that goal, Ma said, his administration is planning to offer landing visas or multiple visas to Chinese visitors to Kinmen.
The government will also unveil mid- and long-term development plans which will integrate Kinmen's tourism, industrial and cultural resources to revamp its economy, he added.
"The idea, talked about by many Kinmen residents, of building a bridge between Kinmen and Xiamen in China's southeastern Fujian province could also been discussed," Ma said.
"The issue pertaining to allowing imports of water from Xiamen to resolve Kinmen's water shortage problems will also be assessed by the government," Ma told the Kinmen residents.
Kinmen lies closer to Xiamen than to Taiwan proper.

Pitching for a deepening of peace across the Taiwan Strait, Ma said that Kinmen and Xiamen -- literally two "doors" in mandarin -- should be developed in the future into "doors of reconciliation, " "doors of peace," and "doors of cooperation."
The president delivered his speech at Chingtien Hall, a towering hall built inside a mountain, where the Taiwan military command was deployed during the 1958 Artillery Battle.

The battle -- more commonly known as the 823 Battle as it began on Aug. 23, 1958 and marked a "turning point in Taiwan's history -- lasted for 44 days during which communist Chinese artillery troops bombarded the 148 square-kilometer Kinmen island with 500,000 shells.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's son, daughter-in-law returning to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 23 (CNA) 08/24/08 16:15:25 (By Timothy Hwang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian's son and daughter-in-law, who reportedly are key figures in a case of suspected overseas money laundering involving the former first family, boarded a flight at New Jersey's Newark Liberty International Airport Saturday night to return to Taiwan.
Chen Chih-chung and his wife, Huang Jui-ching, boarded Eva Air Flight BR031 and are scheduled to arrive in Taiwan around 6 a.m. Monday Taipei time.
The couple's decision to fly home squashed rumors over the past 15 days that they had disappeared in the United States amid the money laundering scandal.
A calm Chen Chih-chung said at the airport to members of several Taiwanese media outlets that he and his wife are returning to Taiwan to face the judiciary because they are clean and innocent.
Chen Chih-chung confirmed that he had registered at the law school of the University of Virginia Aug. 11, but had not completed the enrollment procedures nor taken part in orientation.
"The school authorities told me to 'come back next year' because they had 'received some information,'" he told the reporters.

For her part, Huang said that only after she arrived in the United States Aug. 9 did she become aware that she had been used as a "figurehead" to open accounts at two banks in Switzerland for cash deposits.

According to Jason Yuan, the Republic of China's representative to the United States, the U.S. assisted Taiwan in locating Chen Chih-chung and his wife, at the request of the ROC government. The young couple had been technically "missing" since their entry into the United States Aug. 9, he said.

A University of Virginia source said Friday that since Taiwan prosecutors have subpoenaed Chen Chih-chung, he would probably return to face the probe because his student visa has been revoked and it would be illegal for him to remain in the United States.
Former President Chen Shui-bian, his wife Wu Shu-jen and Wu's elder brother were listed last week as suspects in the case and have been barred from leaving the country.

At issue is a report by the Egmont Group -- an international anti-money laundering organization -- that the Investigation Bureau's Money Laundering Prevention Center received in January, which detailed the status of foreign bank accounts created by members of Chen Shui-bian's family in countries such as the United States, the Cayman Islands, Singapore and Switzerland.

Chen's wife claimed last week during questioning by prosecutors that the US$21 million deposited in the family's various overseas bank accounts was "all legal income." The money is reportedly distributed among three different accounts -- two in Switzerland held in the name of Huang Jui-ching and one in Singapore in the name of her elder brother Wu Ching-mao.

DOC.HEADLINE: NGOs hold closing ceremony for 'Bloody Olympics'

TEXT.P: Several non-governmental groups held a satiric closing ceremony for what they called the "Bloody Olympics" Sunday, in which awards were presented to Chinese President Hu Jintao and business sponsors of the Beijing Olympics, exposing what the groups described as suppression and violations of human rights during the Games.

With the Beijing Olympics slated to officially close Sunday evening, groups such as Friends of Tibet, Taiwan Free Burma Network, Taiwan Association for Human Rights, Taiwan Labor Front, Taiwan Guts, Judicial Reform Foundation, Taiwan Alliance to End the Death Penalty and Taiwan Youth for Democracy in Asia, held a spoof closing ceremony, calling on the world not to be deceived by the "illusion of piping times of peace" created by the Chinese government.
In the mock ceremony, awards were given to people depicting Taiwanese and Chinese politicians and international companies that sponsored the games.

The lifetime achievement award was conferred on Chinese President Hu Jintao for his long involvement in the suppression of Tibet since he was the Party Secretary in Tibet, while McDonald's received the "I'm lovin' it -- the money" award for being the biggest sponsor of the Games,
Also, International Olympic Committee President Jacques Rogge won the "blind award" for turning a blind eye to the fact that China's check -- its promise to improve human rights -- had bounced.

President Ma Ying- jeou was awarded the "finally showing his true colors" prize for embracing Beijing immediately after being elected although he had promised during his campaign to boycott the Olympics if the situation in Tibet got worse.
Chinese dissident Cai Lujun said that he was very disappointed at Ma.
"Acting obsequiously toward China will not give Taiwan dignity and equality," he said.

Wu Yu-hsiang said that by encouraging people to use VISA, the company is saying it is okay to keep suppressing Chinese workers. Several participants cut their VISA credit cards into pieces on the spot to express their anger.

These groups said that what lies behind the grandeur of the Beijing Olympics are the suppression of Tibet, violation of human rights, and oppression of workers. Moreover, China's "peaceful rise" is a complete lie, they said.
"We do not believe China at all because we have been lied to so many times, " said Tashi Tsering, president of the Regional Tibetan Youth Congress Taiwan.

"A rising China should not be a totalitarian Communist regime that exports rule by terror to the world, but rather a country that values democracy, freedom and human rights, " said Yang Chang-cheng, vice chairman of the Friends of Tibet.

Huang Mou, director of the Chang Fo-chuan Center for the Study of Human Rights at Soochow University, said that he disagreed with the view held by many people that the Beijing Olympics answered many questions the world had about China and set the future path on which the country will embark.

If China was really focused on its ancient history, great inventions and the Confucius idea that "peace is the most valuable thing," as was projected in the opening ceremony, wouldn't that mean that the communist revolution is over and there is no need for a one-party dictatorship? he asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: Peruvian envoy delivers APEC summit invitation to Taiwan

TEXT.P: Senior officials confirmed Sunday that an official invitation has been delivered to Taiwan to participate in an informal summit of economic leaders of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Lima, Peru Nov. 22-23 -- a development that could reveal the status of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

It was disclosed that APEC Executive-Director Juan Carlos Capunay delivered the invitation in person to President Ma Ying-jeou before Ma left Taiwan Aug. 12 on his first state visit to attend the inauguration ceremonies of Paraguayan President Fernando Lugo and Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez.
"Capunay came to Taiwan in late July and left in early August, " said the foreign ministry official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, in response to CNA's inquiries.

Capunay is the 16th Executive Director of the APEC Secretariat for the 2008 APEC Year hosted by Peru. He has served as a senior diplomat in the Peruvian Foreign Service since 1972 in a number of positions around the Asia-Pacific, with postings in China, Singapore, Japan and the United Nations.
Based on precedent, the envoy from the host nation will visit Taiwan again before the informal summit to confirm the delegate designated by the president.
Under a special arrangement made for Taiwan to participate in APEC, the country's president has to designate a special envoy to the summit on his behalf.

Recent reports claimed that Lien Chan, former vice-president and the honorary chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), has been chosen as Taiwan's special envoy to the APEC summit, but the MOFA denied the report, saying that the ministry is still in discussions with the Presidential Office on the matter and no decision has yet been made.
"It is too early to say who will represent Ma, as the summit is slated for late November, " the MOFA official said, adding that the candidate will be named closer to the date of the meeting.

Since the first APEC informal summit in 1993, Taiwan has been trying to send officials at the highest posible level to the meeting, but its efforts have been blocked, in large part, due to objections from China.
Taiwan has instead sent Nobel laureate Lee Yuan-tseh and well-known entrepreneurs, among others, to join the summits.

This year Taiwan's choice of envoy to the APEC summit will be an indicator of the status of cross-Taiwan Strait ties, as Taiwan to date has not succeeded in sending a top-level representative to the meeting.
Moreover, the choice of delegate will also test China's goodwill regarding Ma's new diplomatic approach since he took office May 20.

Ma has proposed a "diplomatic truce" aimed at terminating the longstanding diplomatic tug-of-war with China in which both countries try to lure each other's allies to switch diplomatic allegiance by offering large sums of money in foreign aid to developing countries.
Ma has also touted the strategy of "modus vivendi" or "pragmatic diplomacy," aimed at leveraging more international space for Taiwan.

Taiwan's latest bid to ask the 63rd United Nations General Assembly to reconsider on Sept. 16 the feasibility of Taiwan's meaningful participation in the world body's specialized agencies will serve as the first indicator of the success of Ma's new strategy.

APEC has 21 members -- referred to as "Member Economies" -- which account for approximately 41 percent of the world's population, approximately 55 percent of world GDP and about 49 percent of world trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT vice chairman to visit Japan as President Ma's messenger

TEXT.P: Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman Chiang Pin-kung is scheduled to visit Japan Aug. 25-27 in another effort to give the assurance that Taiwan does not favor relations with China over its ties with Japan.

Chiang, at the head of a six-member KMT delegation, is expected to meet with Taro Aso, secretary-general of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), and other Japanese political and parliamentary heavyweights to update them on the KMT administration's stance on Taiwan's relations with Japan and China under the new presidency of Ma Ying-jeou.

Chiang, who doubles as chairman of the intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation, will represent Ma in clarifying Taiwan's firm stance on maintaining friendly ties with Japan, according to KMT Legislator Lee Chia-chin, one of the four KMT lawmakers who will accompany Chiang on the three-day visit to Japan.

It will be the second delegation from Taiwan to visit Japan within a month. Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng returned from Japan Aug. 13, after giving the neighboring country the assurance that Taiwan's diplomatic relations are not tilting toward China.

During their visit to Tokyo, Chiang and his group will also discuss with the Japanese political and parliamentary leaders the issue of fishing rights and the possibility of the two countries signing a free trade agreement, according to Lee.

Chiang and his delegation are expected to meet with other Japanese political heavyweights such as former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe; Nobuo Kishi, a ruling LDP member in the upper house of the Diet of Japan; and Takeo Hiranuma, president of the pro-Taiwan Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council.

Other members of Chiang's entourage will include KMT legislators Lee Hung-chun, Lee Fu-hsing and Lin Yu-fang, as well as Tsai Ming-yao, head of the Committee on Japanese Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Lee said.
Chiang, who studied in Japan, is scheduled to deliver a speech in Japanese on cross-Taiwan Strait relations and Taiwan's economic prospects, in Tokyo Aug. 26, Lee said.
The delegation will visit Japan at the invitation of the Japan Interchange Association, a quasi-official organization authorized to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: President thanks U.S. for support during 1958 shelling of Kinmen

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed appreciation Sunday on behalf of the people of Taiwan to the United States for its assistance in defending the outlying island of Kinmen during the 1958 bombardment by China.

The president made the remarks during a luncheon at the headquarters of the Kinmen Defense Command. Kinmen, also known as Quemoy, is a small island under Taiwan's control. It lies closer to China's Fujian Province than to Taiwan.

Ma asked Lloyd V. Evans, chairman of the 823 Badge of Honor Association USA, to convey the gratitude of the Taiwan people to the U.S. government and people. He also expressed the hope that Taiwan and the United States will work together to further cement their friendship.
Evans and more than 30 representatives from his association were invited to Kinmen to mark the 50th anniversary of the 1958 bombardment.

Also present at the luncheon were Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Minister of National Defense Chen Chao-min, former Premier Hau Pei-tsun, veterans who fought in the battle of the Taiwan Strait, families of officers and solders who perished during the shelling, journalists who covered the bombardment and Taiwan's counterattack, and military leaders and soldiers of the Kinmen Defense Command.
The heavy bombardment began Aug. 23 and lasted 44 days, during which China tried but failed to pound the small island into submission with 475,000 shells -- about 3,100 for every square kilometer.
The bombardment resulted in some 3,000 civilian and 1,000 military causalities. The army on Kinmen countered by firing back 128,000 shells.

On Sept. 11, 1958, U.S. President Eisenhower strongly reaffirmed his country's support for the ROC, saying that the bombardment and blockade of Kinmen and another outlying island Matsu were not so much a genuine attempt to conquer the Formosa Strait Islands, as part of a plan "to liquidate all of the free world positions in the Western Pacific."

The 823 Badge of Honor Association USA was formed in 1998 and has 5,000 members. Up to 2006, the association each year recommended a list of American candidates to the Republic of China's Ministry of National Defense for the Honor Medal for the 1958 Bombardment and the Commemorative Badge for the 1955-1979 US-ROC Mutual Defense.

In an open letter to the people of Taiwan Saturday, Evans said, "We of America's military past are proud to have served Taiwan, but none is as proud as those in your valiant military. For it is they and the citizens of Kinmen who in 1985 sacrificed, bled and died in order to secure this ephemeral concept called freedom."

Evans added, "Taiwan's democratic republic has shown the world that a free people can transfer political power without bloodshed, that no despot, tyrant, or any 'ism' can dictate to Taiwan's people how they should live. It is the citizens of Taiwan that will make that decision as they continue to choose their path in the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: President envisions broader cross-Strait cooperation

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said on the outlying island of Kinmen Sunday that reconciliation between Taiwan and China has already laid a foundation for peace in the Taiwan Strait, and that he expects to see further broadening of the cooperation between the two sides, from the existing basis.

Speaking at a gathering to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the 44-day bombardment of Kinmen by China from Aug. 23, 1958, Ma said his government will try to change Kinmen from "the killing field of the 20th century" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to a "peace square" in the 21st century.
"However, while our minds are focused on working for peace, we cannot believe ignorantly that this is an earth free from war," he said.
Ma reiterated that Taiwan must strengthen its defense capability by setting its defense budget at 3 percent of its gross domestic product in order to prevent war, not to provoke its neighbors.

Turning to the 1958 bombardment of Kinmen by China, Ma noted that the bravery of the defense troops on Kinsmen and the assistance from the United States had made the island unshakable, and that as a result, the battle served as a turning point for Taiwan, leading to peace and security for half a century.
"In war there are no winners, only regret," he said, adding that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should have learned a lesson and realized that they had paid a heavy price.

The president said that to those who fear that the cross-strait relationship is developing too rapidly, he would like to remind them that the two sides already wasted 50 years because of the confrontation and should stop hesitating and procrastinating any further.

Ma said all the people of Taiwan should be grateful to those solders and civilians on Kinmen who died in the battle, because it was their sacrifice that made it possible for Taiwan to have freedom and prosperity today.

More than 3,000 civilians and 1,000 garrison troops in Kinmen perished during the 44-day bombardment during which Chinese artillery fired 475,000 shells -- about 3,100 shells for every square kilometer of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Penghu fishermen rescued after drifting at sea for seven days

TEXT.P: Two fishermen from Penghu island were rescued and brought to Taichung Port Sunday after drifting at sea on their powerless boat for seven days.
Su Yao-shun and his son Su Chia-chang landed at Taichung Port at 4 p.m. aboard a Taichung Coast Guard Squadron patrol.
Meanwhile their fishing boat, with its dead engine, was towed to the port by another Taiwan fishing vessel that had spotted it about 20 nautical miles off the coast of Hsinchu at 9 a.m.
The boat alerted a local fishing radio station, which then appealed to the Taichung Coast Guard Squadron for help.
The Sus left their home port in Penghu on Aug. 18 to go fishing off the coast of that island, but their boat engine developed problems and died later that day.
Their family asked the Penghu Coast Guard Squadron for help after the men failed to return as expected on Aug. 21.
The two Sus were in good condition when they arrived at Taichung Port where 14 family members were waiting for them after being notified by the Coast Guard of their rescue.
The senior Su said they had encountered nine fishing boats during their seven- day ordeal at sea and had fired signal flares, but they were ignored until Sunday morning.
They said they survived by eating instant noodles and drinking water that melted from ice blocks they had onboard.
