DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 25, or the 25th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1718: The city of New Orleans, named in honor of the Duke of Orleans of France, is founded.
1819: Allan Pinkerton, Scottish-born founder of the famous Pinkerton National Detective Agency in the United States, which specialized in railroad theft, is born.
1822: Sir William Herschel, the German-born English astronomer who discovered the planet Uranus in 1781, dies at the age of 84. He also cataloged more than 800 double stars and 2,500 nebulae.
1825: Uruguay declares independence from Spain.
1867: Michael Faraday, the English chemist and physicist who invented the first electrical cell (battery), dies at the age of 76.
1875: Englishman Matthew Webb makes history by becoming the first person to swim the English Channel. The 27-year-old master mariner covers the 34-km stretch from Dover to Calais in 21 hours 45 minutes.
1900: Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche, the German philosopher whose written works include "Thus Spake Zarathustra," dies at the age of 55. He reasons that Christianity's emphasis on the afterlife makes its believers less able to cope with earthly life.
1912: The Chung-kuo ke-ming tung-meng hui (Society of the Common Cause) is reorganized as the Kuomintang (Nationalist Party) and holds its inauguration meeting in Beijing.
1917: Dr. Sun Yat-sen forms a military government in Canton, southern China.
1919: The first scheduled international air service begins between Paris and London.
1921: Germany and the United States sign a peace treaty ending the state of war between them.
1930: Sean Connery, the Scottish actor who played the leading role as "007" in seven James Bond movies and won an Oscar for best supporting actor in "The Untouchables," is born.
1940: Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania are incorporated into the Soviet Union.
1943: Lord Louis Mountbatten is appointed Supreme Allied Commander in Southeast Asia.
1944: Paris is liberated when the local German commander, General von Choltitz, surrenders to the Allies, ending a four-year long ordeal that Paris and her citizens suffered at the hands of the Nazis.
1945: Vietnamese communist leader Ho Chi Minh announces the formation of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam (DRV).
1989: The spacecraft Voyager 2 beams back to earth pictures of Neptune.
1960: The Republic of China Olympic team carries a large sign reading "Under Protest" in the opening procession of the Olympic Games in Rome to protest the International Olympic Committee's ruling compelling ROC athletes to compete under the name of "Taiwan" instead of the "Republic of China."
1961: The second phase of the Yangmingshan Forum opens to study the ROC's educational and cultural issues.
1968: Lesotho Premier Leabua Jonathan arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1986: ROC-US trade talks on wine and tobacco imports open in Taipei. Both sides failed to settle disagreements on pricing and advertising for American products during the nine-day talks, and a new round of negotiations was planned.
1991: Byelorussia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1992: Niger's Prime Minister Amadou Cheiffou arrives in the ROC to advance mutual understanding between the two countries.
2001: The opposition People First Party (PFP) unveils the theme of "respect for history, acknowledgment of reality and joint efforts for peace" as the guidelines of its mainland China policy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "For God in giving life to all created things is surely bountiful to them according to their qualities. Hence the tree that is full of life He fosters and sustains, while that which is ready to fall He cuts down and destroys."

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen welcomes President's promise on visas for Chinese citizens

TEXT.P: Travel agencies operating on the outlying island of Kinmen expressed welcome Monday to President Ma Ying-jeou's promise made the day before to offer landing visas or multiple visas to Chinese visitors to Kinmen.
"The travel incentives represent a shot in the arm for all the tourism operators in Kinmen," said Yang Tsai-ping, chief secretary of the Kinmen Association of Travel Agents.

President Ma said in his speech delivered in Kinmen Sunday that to accelerate Kinmen's economic development and facilitate Chinese tourists' traveling to Kinmen, the administration is planning to offer landing visas or multiple visas to Chinese visitors to Kinmen.

Yang said seeking to host more Chinese tourists to Kinmen -- which lies closer to Xiamen in China's southeastern Fujian Province than to Taiwan proper -- has been the top goal of Kinmen travel agents since 2004 when residents of Kinmen and Fujian Province were allowed to begin tourism exchanges via the "mini three links."

However, Yang pointed out, only 2,729 Chinese tourist groups, or 58,214 people, traveled to Kinmen from Fujian over the past four years between Dec. 7, 2004 and July 31, 2008 -- a figure far lower than originally expected.
Yang attributed the low number mainly to the fact that paperwork is too much troublesome and time-consuming for potential Chinese tourists.

He said Ma's promise Sunday is greatly welcomed, given that if the entry and exit restrictions involving the "mini three links" are removed, Kinmen would be in a much better position to attract tourists from Xiamen, which sees the entry and exit of an average of 20 million people a year.
He suggested that Taiwan emulate Hong Kong's offering landing visas not only to groups, but also to individuals, so as to facilitate visits to Kinmen by Chinese citizens of all walks of life.

According to Yang, China currently allows only residents from Fujian Province to visit Kinmen for sightseeing trips, but it has been considering relaxing the restriction to allow residents from 13 other cities and provinces to visit Kinmen via the "mini three links" should Taiwan begin offering landing visas to Chinese visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chi Mei expands building of petrochemical wharves in Tainan

TEXT.P: Chi Mei Corp., one of Taiwan's major manufacturers of LCD display panels, has decided to invest an additional NT$420 million (US$13.38 million) to expand the development of petrochemical wharves at Anping Harbor in Tainan City, southern Taiwan, the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau (KHB) said Monday.

When the third and fourth wharve development projects are completed, the cargo throughput capacity of the Chi Mei wharf operations at Anping Harbor will be increased by 140,000 tons annually to a total of 814,000 tons, a KHB official said.

In order to reduce delivery distance, lower potential risk to petrochemical vehicles and improve the flow of materials, Chi Mei invested NT$500 million several years ago to construct two 200 meter long, 11 meter deep petrochemical wharves as well as 16 storage tanks and related facilities.

Chi Mei's 16 storage tanks, constructed in conjunction with KHB in the first and second wharve development projects, were completed in October 2007, allowing a cargo throughput capacity of 674,000 tons annually.
Six petrochemical storage tanks are expected to be built in the third and fourth wharve development projects, the KHB official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 119.08 points to close at 7,030.72.

Rebounding from losses last Friday, the local bourse opened at 6,974.07 and fluctuated between 6,935.59 and 7,050.31 during trading. A total of 3.05 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$65.73 billion (US$2.09 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 5.0 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 4.3 percent, textile stocks at 4.2 percent, banking and financial shares at 2.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.7 percent, paper and pulp issues and construction stocks both at 1.6 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 1.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,361 to 678, with 452 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyers of NT$6.60 billion worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Timely air quality information available at government Web site

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has recently established a Web site that provides timely air quality information to the public, an EPA official said Monday.

According to Chu Yu-chi, director-general of the EPA's department of environmental protection monitoring and information management, the Web site utilizes the user-friendly service of Google Maps and provides instant air quality information, both nationwide and for local regions.
People can acquire information on the air quality around their residences or travel destinations if they enter specific addresses at the Web site, Chu said.

In addition to timely information, the system also provides air quality predictions for the following 24 hours, as well as an introduction to all of the country's air quality inspection stations, Chu said.
The public can also download historical air quality inspection data from the Web site for reference, Chu said, adding that the system can be accessed via the EPA's homepage.
To access the Web site, visit http: //taqm.epa.gov.tw/ emc/default.aspx?mod=PsiAreaHourly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former president's son, daughter-in-law claim innocence

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian's son and daughter-in-law claimed innocence in a case of suspected money laundering involving the former first family upon their return to Taiwan from the United States early Monday.
Chen Chih-chung and his wife, Huang Jui-ching, who have been listed by prosecutors as suspects in the case, are expected to respond to a summon for questioning now that they are home.

Chen Chih-chung told a large crowd of reporters waiting at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport that the family's finances have always been managed by his mother, Wu Shu-jen, and that he and his wife were only being "dominated" to offer some help.
"We just did whatever mother told us to do. It was impossible for us to question (the origin of the money)," Chen said.

Huang stressed that she was only a "figurehead" used by her mother-in-law to open bank accounts overseas for cash deposits and that she and her husband had never thought of evading judicial investigation by refusing to return to Taiwan, as some Taiwanese media had speculated.
"Since our roles in the case are so obvious, we have no need to flee and make ourselves fugitives," she said.

Chen Chih-chung, who had gone to the United States together with his wife to enroll in the law school of the University of Virginia, said he requested that the enrollment be postponed for one year in the wake of the exposure of the alleged money-laundering case, but the university turned down his request and asked him to file an application next year if he still wishes to study at the school.

The couple departed Taiwan for the United States just a few days before Next magazine, a weekly tabloid, ran a story Aug. 13 claiming that Huang had laundered money for the former first family by secretly wiring NT$300 million (US$9.55 million) overseas in 2006, after the exposure of the "state affairs fund" embezzlement case implicating the former president and his wife.

The story was suspected to have been based on information leaked to the magazine by Taiwanese investigative authorities, which received a report in January from the international anti-money laundering organization Egmont Group that detailed the status of overseas bank accounts held by members of the former first family in other countries, including the United States, the Cayman Islands, Singapore and Switzerland.

However, allegedly due to concealment by the former head of the Investigation Bureau, prosecutors investigating the "state affairs fund" case were unaware of the existence of the report until the publication of the story by Next magazine.

The release of the story also coincided with the recent reception by Taiwan of a request by Swiss authorities for assistance in probing alleged money laundering by Chen Chih-chung and Huang Jui-ching in Switzerland.
Last Monday, prosecutors listed the former president and his wife, as well as Wu' s older brother Wu Ching-mao, Chen Chih-chung and Huang Jui-ching, as suspects in the alleged money-laundering case.

Questioned by prosecutors Friday, the former first lady said the US$21 million in overseas bank accounts under the name of her elder brother and daughter-in- law was the balance of political contributions for the campaigns of her husband in two mayoral elections and two presidential elections from 1993 to 2004.

Wu's statement was consistent with that of Chen Shui-bian, who openly confessed Aug. 14 that he had lied about his election campaign expenses and that his wife wired surplus funds from the election campaign contributions into overseas bank accounts.
However, Chen claimed that all the surplus funds were handled by his wife and that he had no idea his wife had wired the funds abroad until early this year.

The former president denied the money had any connection with the "state affairs fund" case, in which the former first lady was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.
Chen, who had immunity from prosecution while in office, was named as a co- offender in the case and was probed as soon as he stepped down from the presidency May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: President's approval rating drops to 36.9%: DPP poll

TEXT.P: Only 36.9 percent of the people are satisfied with the performance of President Ma Ying-jeou over the three months since his inauguration, with as many as 57 percent expressing disapproval, according to the results of a survey released Monday by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
The results also showed that the approval rating of Premier Liu Chao-shiuan stood at only 33.2 percent, with 56.5 percent of respondents displeased with his performance.

Chen Chun-lin, director of the DPP's opinion poll center, noted that although the DPP's support rating has dropped slightly following the exposure of alleged money laundering implicating former President Chen Shui-bian and his family, the ruling Kuomintang's approval rating has not increased as a result.
"This indicates that DPP supporters have not shifted their loyalty to other parties," Chen Chun-lin said.
The survey, conducted Aug. 20-22 among 1,348 citizens, had a margin of error of 2.72 percent.

The results revealed that while the respondents in Keelung, Yilan, Hualien, Taitung and Penghu were split in their opinions over Ma's performance, over half of the respondents in other areas were unsatisfied with his performance.

By age, Ma's disapproval rating registered 62.6 percent among the 30-39 age group, 62 percent among the 50-59 age group, 42.6 percent among the 20-29 age group, and 40.7 percent among the 40-49 age group.

According to Chen Chun-lin, between April 7 and Aug. 22. the DPP carried out a total of seven surveys on the public's perception of Ma's performance and found that Ma's approval rating has dropped below 40 percent since late June.
Over the past two months, Ma's disapproval rating has ranged between 53.5 percent and 57 percent, he said.

The results of the DPP's latest survey are differebnt from those of a similar survey conducted Aug. 14-15 and released Aug. 19 by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, in which Ma received an approval rating of 47 percent.

Meanwhile, the results of another survey conducted Aug. 22 and released Monday by the China Times showed that Ma's approval rating rose to 46.3 percent from a low of 35.5 percent recorded one month ago.
Still, 60 percent of the respondents in the China Times survey were unsatisfied with the Ma administration's failure to present any effective solutions to boost the economy and curb inflation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for September rose 128 points to close at 6,988, with 58,897 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October gained 128 points to finish at 6,971, with 193 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 138 points to close at 6,953, with 44 contract transactions.
March futures increased 124 points to finish at 6,942, with 11 contract transactions, while June futures advanced 188 points to close at 6,935, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,860 for September, 6,843 for October, 6,815 for December, 6,818 for March and 6,747 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 119.08 points to finish at 7,030.72, on turnover of NT$65.73 billion (US$2.09 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

September TE futures rose 4.15 points to close at 283.5, with 2,820 contracts traded, while October TE futures increased 5.45 points to finish at 283.7, with four contract transactions. December TE futures gained 3.05 points to finish at 280, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

September TF futures moved up 20.6 points to close at 856, with 1,884 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures advanced 17.6 points to finish at 850.8, with seven contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese spouses' financial solvency requirement to be relaxed

TEXT.P: A requirement that Chinese spouses of local citizens must provide documented proof of financial solvency when applying for a Taiwanese identity card is to be significantly relaxed, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday.

MAC spokesman Liu Te-shun said the new relaxed measures, which were drafted by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) and have been approved by Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi, will be put into force as soon as the Executive Yuan gives the go- ahead.

Liu quoted an MOI proposal indicating that because some Chinese spouses do not work outside the home because they have to take care of their husband's elderly family members or young children, the financial solvency proof of families with Chinese spouses should be lowered from the current level of NT$34,560 (US$1,100.64) per month, or twice the country's minimum wage, to some NT$19,000, or 1.1 times the minimum wage.

The MOI proposed that local families with Chinese spouses should produce documented proof of movable or personal property worth NT$120,000 -- a figure much lower than the NT$414,000 -- a staggering 24 times the minimum wage -- that was put in place over the past four years by the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration, Liu said.
The MOI proposed that local families with Chinese spouses should produce documented proof that they own real estate worth at least NT$800,000, according to Liu.

If the Chinese spouse, her Taiwanese husband or other members of their family have difficulty producing the documented proof, related non-profit organizations could do it for them, so long as the organizations find that the family is not under financial strain, Liu said.

The MOI also proposed the cancellation of a requirement that local families with Chinese spouses should produce documented proof that the household's savings deposits in financial institutions exceeding NT$414,000 over the most recent one year, Liu added.
Meanwhile, he noted, the Council of Labor is also planning to relax regulations governing Chinese spouses' employment in Taiwan and their right to work in Taiwan.

According to the MOI, 399,000 foreign spouses were registered in Taiwan as of the end of 2007 -- 262,000 from China and 137,000 from other countries. The swingeing restrictions do not apply to spouses from other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan seeking foreign assistance for missing fishing boat: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has instructed its offices in Palau, the Philippines and Indonesia to ask for assistance from the governments of these countries to help locate a Taiwanese fishing boat that has been missing since Aug. 19, MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said Monday.

The Foreign Ministry made the instruction several days ago after being informed by the Fisheries Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture that the Taiyihsiang, a fishing boat based in Liouciou, Pingtung, went out of touch about one week after it sailed from Liouciou to fish, Chen said.
"So far we have received no information from our offices in these three nations," Chen noted.

According to a local newspaper report, the Taiyihsiung departed from Liouciou Aug. 12, with Taiwanese skipper Lee Feng-bao and eight other Indonesian crew members aboard. The report quoted Lee's family in Pingtung saying that Lee talked with his family via a radio system everyday, but had not done so since Aug. 19.
Neither Lee's family nor fishermen's radio in Pingtung could come into contact with Lee since Aug. 19, according to the report.
Analyzing via the satellite Vessel Monitoring System (VMS) , Fisheries Agency officials deduced that the Taiyihsiang could now be sailing in open seas near the Philippines, Chen said.
"The Foreign Ministry will continue to render help to Lee's no matter what happens," Chen promised.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, increasing NT$0.06 to close at NT$31.430.
A total of US$815 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.370 and fluctuated between NT$31.308 and NT$31.434.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City traffic signals blasted for too much red

TEXT.P: Several Taipei city councilors blasted some of the city's traffic lights Monday, claiming that they are operated in an "inhuman" way as half of the devices in the capital city signal red -- a stop signal -- for at least 100 seconds, forcing people to breathe the exhaust of cars and motorbikes as they idle while waiting for the lights to change.

City Councilors Chien Yu-yien, Chen Chien-min and Lee Ching-feng criticized what they described as the "inefficiency" of the city's traffic signals at a press conference at the City Council, with Chien pointing out that 1,026 of the 2,184 sets of traffic lights in the city have "a long red light, " while 42 of them force motorists to wait for at least three minutes during rush hour.

On the intersection of the Mengjia Boulevard and Siyuan Road, people must wait for a long time -- long enough for the intersection to remain clear of traffic for "a while" -- to get a green light, according to Chien.

One taxi driver, she went on, has complained that the traffic lights on the Songkao Road behind the City Council remain at red for so long that his fare meter shows three increases in a single traffic light cycle.
Citing data she collected, Chien said she found that German people will tolerate red lights for a maximum of 60 seconds, while she claimed that the maximum red light in Britain is 45 seconds.
In comparison, it is "inhuman" for road users in Taipei to have to wait at least 100 seconds before they can cross the road, Chien said.

Addressing the complaint, city official Lee Kung-chen responsible for traffic control explained that the traffic signals are installed based on traffic load and the need for pedestrians to cross the road safely. Their operations are adjusted to different timings on different intersections, road sections and districts.

Rush hours and holidays are also factors that decide how long a signal will remain red, Lee noted, pointing out that the longer signals are mostly located on intersections with heavy traffic flow. Any shorter and they would lead to traffic gridlock, he pointed out.

Lee went on, however, that the city traffic control department has decided to conduct an overall check of road traffic in the city in the first half of next year and that the study results will be used as reference for a possible adjustment to traffic light operations around the city.

DOC.HEADLINE: LDR rooms introduced for more mother-friendly childbearing

TEXT.P: Shuang Ho Hospital, an affiliate of the Taipei Medical University in Taipei County, announced Monday that it has introduced the labor-delivery-recovery (LDR) room concept widely adopted in Western countries, with the aim of providing women with a friendly and more soothing delivery environment.

According to a hospital spokesman, the LDR room provides pregnant women with a greater degree of privacy and comfort, allowing them to complete the entire birthing experience -- labor, delivery and recovery -- in the same room, accompanied by family members if so desired.
The spokesman pointed out that this can reduce the mother-to-be's feelings of nervousness and anxiety.

He said that normally in Taiwan, women are first taken to a labor room while they wait for the cervix to fully dilate, after which they are then taken to the delivery room for the actual birth, which means that the woman can experience a greater degree of discomfort than is necessary, due to having to be moved from bed to bed.

According to the spokesman, LDR rooms follow the modern trend in allowing mother and baby to be in the same room, adding that this not only provides consumers with more choices but also reduces medical costs.
Chou Szu-yuan, a gynecologist at Wanfang Hospital in Taipei, said that most women would prefer a more soothing childbearing process.

He said that the introduction of LDR rooms centers on the notion of humanity, as they not only make women feel respected during the process of childbearing but also provide family members with an opportunity to participate in the process.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hospital solves mood change from deep brain stimulation

TEXT.P: Doctors at the Buddhist Tzu Chi General Hospital in Hualien County, northeastern Taiwan, reported Monday that they have solved the problem of mood changes suffered by eight patients after they received deep brain stimulation (DBS) surgery to treat Parkinson's disease.
Chen Shih-yuan, convener of the hospital's Parkinson's Clinical and Research Center, said Tzu Chi has treated 99 Parkinson's disease patients since 2002 using the DBS therapy.
He said that while most of the patients saw their quality of life improved because of the surgery, a few showed adverse changes of mood and often quarreled with their family members.

Chen said that in order to find out why the mood changes occurred, he and Tsai Sheng-tzung, chief resident at the hospital's Department of Neurosurgery, undertook a study in which 38 patients who received DBS surgery were placed under observation for more than one year. It was established that altogether, eight of the test subjects were affected by mood changes.
The two doctors then compared the data on the DBS treatment for the eight patients with the data on the other patients who did not show any mood changes.
Their analysis led to the finding that the the electrodes implanted in their brains were in apparently different areas of the thalamus than those patients who had no mood change problems.

According to Chen, all of the eight patients received additional surgery to adjust the positions of the electrodes in their brains, while medicine was also used to stabilize their conditions. As a result, the mood change problems were completely solved.
DBS has become a standard treatment for patients with Parkinson's disease. In 2006, it was estimated that 30,000 to 40,000 people worldwide with Parkinson's disease underwent the procedure.
Tzu Chi Hospital has performed 99 such operations, accounting for 46 percent of the DBS operations conducted by hospitals in Taiwan.

DBS therapy requires two surgical procedures -- surgery on the brain to implant electrodes and another operation in which a neurostimulator is implanted under the collarbone. When activated, the stimulator sends signals to the brain through the electrodes to treat the movement disorders that are a symptom of the disease.

Previous studies in other countries have reported scattered cases in which changes in mood or behavior occurred after DBS treatment in people with Parkinson's disease, but could not establish the cause. A few subsequent studies raised the theory that some of the electrodes might be off-target and stimulating the wrong part of the brain.

DOC.HEADLINE: Internet shopping-related fraud peaks in summer

TEXT.P: Fraud related to Internet shopping has become the major crime of deception in July and August of this year, accounting for about 70 percent of such crime, police authorities said Monday.

Citing statistics compiled by the 165 anti-fraud hot line center run by the Ministry of the Interior, Criminal Investigation Bureau officers said the center received 855 inquiry telephone calls last week from the public, with some 70 percent of them, or nearly 600 calls, relating to Internet shopping.

The number far surpassed the average 20 Internet sex-related criminal cases reported each week during the same two months, the officers said, noting that the number of sex-related crime cases in this summer's peak period has not risen markedly over the numbers of the past several years.

According to police officers, the growth in alleged fraud cases relating to Internet shopping might be because these crimes are less time consuming than sex-related trickery, despite the fact that fraud rings usually use a similar approach by luring targeted victims into sending money to them through automated teller machines.

DOC.HEADLINE: Saturday protest unrelated to former president: DPP

TEXT.P: A protest organized by the Taiwan Society Aug. 30 in Taipei is meant to highlight Taiwan's independent sovereignty and to speak to the government about the people's strong desire for a better life, an opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official said Monday.

The protest to be staged this coming Saturday on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office Building has nothing to do with former President Chen Shui-bian, DPP public relations department director Cheng Wen-tsang said.

Chen and several family members, including his wife, his son and his daughter- in-law, have been dogged recently by a money-laundering scandal, which came to light after a magazine broke the story earlier this month.

"It is extremely improper to link the Aug. 30 protest, initiated by a civic group before the scandal was exposed, to Chen's scandal, "he argued, explaining that the DPP was only playing an auxiliary role in the event.

According to Cheng, Saturday's activity is aimed at pursuing a guarantee from the Kuomintang (KMT) government for national sovereignty, a good economy and several key sunshine bills to build clean politics.

Commenting on Chen's claim that he donated NT$340 million (US$10.82 million) in government subsidies to the DPP for some 11.45 million votes he garnered in the 2000 and 2004 presidential elections, he said the party's financial affairs committee, at the request of DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, will soon come up with a clear explanation of how much money Chen contributed to the party over the past eight years.
Chen claimed that in line with the DPP's regulations, he had donated one third of the sum to the party's central committee and the remaining two-thirds to its local committees.

On the same day, Koo Kuan-min, honorary chairman of Friends of Taiwan and a staunch supporter of Taiwan independence, told a news conference that Saturday's demonstration was designed to protest against the KMT government and push it to better understand the Taiwan people's deep concern for national sovereignty and security and for its future, on the 100th day since President Ma Ying-jeou's inauguration.
He urged members of the public to cast aside Chen's corruption allegations and take concrete action to relay their discontent with the KMT government's pro- China stance.
According to Koo, the KMT government's edge toward China on both the economic and political fronts has created grave concern among the Taiwanese people over the nation's future.
"But Saturday's activity won't become a gathering to display some people's backing for Chen, " he asserted, "as the former president was not a factor in the consideration of the event."
Friends of Taiwan is one of the organizations that is co-sponsoring the Aug. 30 march and protest.

Demonstrators will march separately from the shopping area on Zhongxiao East Road in eastern Taipei and from Lungshan Temple in western Taipei before joining up for a rally on Ketagalan Boulevard Saturday in front of the Presidential Office Building, where they are slated to stage a string of protests.

Meanwhile, the DPP's Kaohsiung City branch said that public response to Saturday's demonstration in Taipei has been enthusiastic and that more than 2,400 people have registered with it to take part in the activity before the deadline expires Monday.

"Each one applying to participate in the demonstration has to pay a NT$600 traffic fee," branch head Chen Cheng-wen stressed, adding that over 60 tour buses carrying the demonstrators will depart for Taipei City Saturday morning.
Southern regions in Taiwan are traditional strongholds of the pro-Taiwan independence DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourist destinations to get improved translation services

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau is to make sure tourist spots around Taiwan have information and help in Japanese and Korean, as more and more people from these countries are coming to Taiwan as tourists, the bureau chief said Monday.

Lai Seh-jen announced the policy while revealing that the number of Japanese tourists to Taiwan reached 1.16 million in 2007, while tourists from South Korea numbered over 200,000 people that same year.

The figures mean that one in three foreign tourists who came to Taiwan last year was either from Japan or South Korea, Lai said, noting that offering language services in tourists' native tongues is one of the ways to make foreign guests feel welcome here.
Under the idea, the bureau began a measure in February to assist local tourism operators to improve their language services targeting Japanese and South Koreans.

To show businesses how to build foreign language services, representatives of travel agencies, business associations and the management of hotels and entertainment parks were invited that day to visit Jiufen, a popular tourist destination in the northern county of Taipei.

The attendees were shown how Jiufen -- once a bustling gold mining town -- has been equipped with Japanese and Korean language services, bureau officials said, noting that tourists from those countries have accounted for the lion's share of foreign visitors to Jiufen in recent years.
According to the bureau, the broadcasting system, warning signs, instructional signs, tour guides and films are all offered in both languages, and should serve as a model for other tourist spots.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor receives integrity award from Global View magazine

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu received an Integrity Award from the founder of Global View monthly Monday after the magazine, in a 2008 annual survey, rated him No. 1 in terms of integrity among the 25 city mayors and county magistrates in Taiwan.

Charles Kao presented the award to Hu at Taichung City Hall. Those who witnessed the award presentation included Global View publisher Cora Wang, editor-in-chief Yang Ma-li and city government officials.

Hu also received two other awards from the magazine on behalf of Taichung for being one of three cities that received the magazine's highest five star approval rating and for having what the magazine considers the "best quality of life" in Taiwan.

The Taichung mayor thanked the magazine and its executives for bestowing the honors on him and the city government, saying that they will serve as an encouragement for Taichung to seek more breakthroughs.

DOC.HEADLINE: University to set up branch in Southern Taiwan Science Park

TEXT.P: A university with a strong background in opto-electronic research will set up a branch near the Southern Taiwan Science Park in Tainan County to help cultivate high-tech talent, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih said Monday.

National Chiao Tung University, based in Hsinchu City in northern Taiwan, will create a southern branch located on a 50-hectare property in the southern county, whose three major industries are optoelectronics, biotechnology, and semiconductors, Su said.

The university branch, expected to enroll 1,920 students and house 580 staff members after the construction project, which will take more than two years, will solve southern Taiwan's problem of insufficient human resources in high- technology fields and will also create greater business opportunities for local tourism, Su said.

The science park started to house incubation centers for National Chung Cheng University, based in the southern county of Chiayi, and National Cheng Kung University, based in Tainan City, in 2002, an effort by the county government to improve the park's research and development and enhance personnel training, Su said.

He went on to say that Academia Sinica, Taiwan's prestigious research institute, established its Biotechnology Center in Southern Taiwan in the park three years ago, and in April the county government started to build a research building to house the institute's 200 researchers.
Currently, about 70 researchers work at the institute's existing research center in the park, carrying out experiments in the fields of biomass fuel, orchid genes, and plant stress resistance.

The research to be carried out in the new building is expected to help solve technology problems encountered by the local agricultural industry, as Tainan County is the powerhouse behind Taiwan's agricultural production, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung City wants no barbecues for Mid-Autumn Festival

TEXT.P: Although the annual Mid-Autumn Festival is still some 20 days away, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu called on city residents Monday not to have traditional outdoor barbecues that day, as part of the city's efforts to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.

"Cutting back on emissions of carbon dioxide has been a goal of the Taichung city government since last year, and the municipal authorities will from now on take concrete action by asking citizens not to have barbecues in parks or other public open spaces on the festival," Hu said.
The mayor said he has asked relevant municipal agencies to start promoting the campaign. The mid-Autumn Festival falls this year on Sept. 14.

"Barbecuing is absolutely not good for the health and goes against global eco- friendly efforts," he said. "The city government will do its best to stop the public having barbecues in parks, streets or green areas during the Mid-Autumn Festival."
Last year, the city government banned barbecues in parks on the holiday, and only a few public venues were opened to members of the public wishing to have barbecues, he explained.

According Hu, just 30 percent of Taiwanese people barbecuing for one hour at the same time will produce an estimated 6,000 tons of carbon dioxide -- far above a reduction of 187 tons of greenhouse gas emissions that would be saved should all Taiwan's residents in the northern, central and southern regions switch off their lights for 70 minutes at the same time.
Packaging for traditional moon cake gift boxes should also be trimmed, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: University ranks 2nd in Asia in online marketing race

TEXT.P: A technology university in southern Taiwan ranked second in Asia and among the top 10 in the world in a global online marketing competition organized by Google, the world's largest search engine, the university said in a statement Monday.

More than 1,600 student teams from 47 countries took part in the competition, which was divided into three regions: the Americas; Europe, Africa and the Middle East and the Asia-Pacific region, according to Google's Web site for the competition.

The Department of Information Management of National Kaohsiung University of Applied Science (KUAS), based in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, had four teams taking part in the competition, the statement said.
One of the teams, led by Craig Chao, an assistant professor, won second place in the Asia-Pacific, while the other three were also among the top 50 in the region, the statement said.
The KUAS team was followed by a team from Taiwan's top university, National Taiwan University, based in the northern city of Taipei, according to the Web site.
KUAS President Fang Chun-hsiung expressed pleasure at the result, saying that the ranking will raise the visibility of the university in the international information technology academic field.
Chao said the competition gave a "valuable and hands-on experience" to the participating students.
The team chose to work with a 12-year-old local bakery, Chao said, adding that during the competition period of three weeks, the team attracted 1,262 hits to the bakery's Web site.
In addition, 40 large deals totalling more than NT$50,000 (about US$1,590) were struck, he noted.
Under the competition rules, the teams received online advertising spending via Google AdWords worth US$200. Google displays relevant AdWords ads above and alongside search results.
The teams were asked to recruit a small-to-medium-sized business with under 100 employees, which has a Web site but does not use AdWords.
Each team worked with the business to set up an AdWords account and design an online marketing campaign during the three-week competition.
Winners were chosen based on the effectiveness of their campaigns.
According to Chao, the top three teams in Asia will head to Sydney to receive their awards in October, while the students involved might have the opportunity to work for Google.
Two teams from Australia were announced as the global winner and Asia-Pacific region winner of the competition, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: July export order growth drops to record low since 2003

TEXT.P: Export orders received by local businesses in July were valued at US$31.36 billion, representing a year-on-year growth of 5.52 percent -- the lowest on record since April 2003, when local business was affected by Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) outbreaks, according to statistics released Monday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
In April 2003 -- when Taiwan was being badly hit by SARS -- the year-on-year growth of export orders was just 4.32 percent.
According to the latest tallies, China continued to be Taiwan's largest buyer, placing US$8 billion-worth of orders with local manufacturers in July.

However, the year-on-year growth of Chinese export orders dropped to 1.73 percent last month, the lowest since March 2005, while the recession was also seen in slower growth in orders from the United States and Japan.
In July, the annual growth rate of U.S. orders recorded only 3.21 percent while that of orders from Japan registered 1.69 percent, the statistics show.

MOEA Statistics Department Director-General Huang Chi-shih attributed the marginal growth in Chinese orders to several factors, including China's ability to now make some of the products for which it formerly relied on imports.
In the first seven months of this year, Taiwan received US$213.8 billion-worth of orders from overseas, registering a year-on-year growth of 12.95 percent, according to the MOEA statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sends vessel on search for possibly hijacked fishing boat

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration has dispatched a vessel on a search for a possibly hijacked Taiwanese fishing boat that has been missing since Aug. 19, Fisheries Agency officials said Monday.

The agency has pinpointed the fishing boat on the open sea more than 900 nautical miles off Taiwan, 600 nautical miles off Indonesia and 300 nautical miles off the Philippines and Palau, the officials said.

The boat was sailing south, apparently heading for Indonesia, the officials said, adding that they suspect the Taiwanese captain, Lee Feng-bao, might have lost command of his boat following a mutiny by his eight Indonesian crewmen.

The agency has asked Taiwan's offices in Indonesia, the Philippines and Palau to offer assistance through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, as it will take several days for the coast guard vessel to reach the fishing boat, the officials went on.
The relevant authorities in Palau and Indonesia have responded to Taiwan's requests and are ready to stop the boat, the officials said.
The boat, named the Taiyihsiang, has not been communicating and has cut off all radio contact, they noted.
The agency is monitoring the boat around the clock and has asked other Taiwanese fishing boats in the area to help find the boat through the country's fishery radio station, the officials went on.
The Taiyihsiang, based out of the post of Liouciou in the southern county of Pingtung, lost contact Aug. 19 after embarking from Liouciou July 12.

Last month, another Taiwanese fishing boat with a Taiwanese captain and 12 Indonesian crewmen went missing and was later found run aground on the Indonesian island of Bali. The boat's equipment and fish were gone, and the captain remains missing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president contributed NT$390 m. to DPP over two terms: party

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian contributed more than NT$390 million (US$12.78 million) to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) during his eight years in office, a DPP official said Monday.
Cheng Wen-tsang, director of the DPP's Department of Culture and Information, said the party acted on a request from DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen to check on Chen's contributions over the years.
Tsai ordered the check after Chen, mired in a suspected money-laundering case involving his family members, said last week that he has contributed more than NT$340 million to the party.
Cheng noted that most of Chen's contributions came from subsidies for Chen's presidential elections in 2000 and 2004. Calculated at NT$30 per ballot he received, Chen contributed NT$340 million.
The party stipulates that one-third of the subsidies must be turned over to DPP headquarters, with the remaining two-thirds going to local DPP chapters to help finance local elections.

In addition, and in line with the DPP's practice that requires every DPP official to solicit a certain amount of money in proportion to their party or government rank, Chen solicited NT$58 million for the party over the past eight years.

The former president also helped solicit donations in every election and party activity by targeting enterprises or individuals, Cheng went on, adding that these funds were reported to the authorities as required by law.

"The publication of this financial information related to Chen is mainly to tell the public that the party's financial and accounting system is open, transparent and can withstand any scrutiny, " Cheng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD defers scheduled completion of five MRT lines in Taipei

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) decided Monday to defer by one year the scheduled completion of five mass rapid transit (MRT) lines of Taipei's second-stage MRT plan.

The 11 members of the CEPD approved a motion at a regular meeting to defer the planned completion of the Neihu Line, the Xinyi Line, the Xinzhuang Line, the Luzhou Branch Line and the Songshan Line by one year from the originally scheduled launch dates.
However, the Nangang Line's eastward extension will become operational by the end of this year as scheduled, according to the CEPD.

The Taipei rapid transit system currently has eight lines totaling 76.6 km -- the Muzha Line, the Danshui Line, the Zhonghe Line, the Xindian Line, the Banqiao Line, the Nangang Line, the Tucheng Line and the Xiaonanmen Line.

Under the second-stage plan, construction on six more lines has been underway for five years, but a number of unfavorable factors have caused various degrees of delay in these projects, the CEPD said.
As a result, the CEPD decided to defer the launches of the five lines, originally scheduled for between 2009 and 2013.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 education budget to increase by NT$21.4 billion

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Educational Funding Committee has decided that next year's national education budget will amount to NT$469.4 billion (US$15 billion) , up NT$21.4 billion from this year's figure, a Ministry of Education (MOE) official said Monday.
The committee, which is responsible for computing the national education budget, is chaired by Education Minister Cheng Jei-cheng.

According to Ke Jeng-feng, executive secretary of the MOE's Department of Educational Research, the budget plan will be submitted to the Executive Yuan for review before being sent to the Legislative Yuan for approval.

Most of the increased amount goes to subsidies for disadvantaged students -- accounting for NT$20.8 billion -- Ke said, adding that the figure represents an increase of NT$4 billion from this year's level.

Meanwhile, NT$17.4 billion will be used for fundamental education, NT$8.7 billion for advanced education and NT$60.1 billion will be used as subsidies to local governments to help cover general expenditures such as school lunches, along with water and electricity fees, said Ke.

He pointed out that NT$7.5 billion that should have been part of this year's education budget but was appropriated for a government's program to boost domestic demand, will be distributed next year, plus an additional NT$1.2 billion.
Cheng said next year's education budget will have an overall increase of NT$24.2 billion if funds raised by individual schools themselves are included.

According to Su Te-hsiang, director-general of the MOE's Department of Secondary Education, the MOE plans to set stricter graduation standards for senior high school students by amending the regulations, which stipulate that a senior high student has to get at least 48 credits to get a high school diploma.

The new regulations will set the minimum requirement at 60 credits, said Su, adding that the MOE will come up with complementary measures at the end of August and will have settled the plan by the end of October after several public hearings.
The implementation of the new regulations is expected to take effect next August at the earliest time, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's son, daughter-in-law barred from leaving Taiwan

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian's son and daughter-in-law have been barred from leaving Taiwan pending investigations into their roles in a suspected money laundering case embroiling the former first family, prosecutors said Monday.
The overseas travel ban was issued after the young couple were questioned as suspects in the high-profile money scandal for nearly three hours that afternoon.

Prosecutors from the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office issued subpoenas to the couple -- Chen Chih-chung and his wife Huang Jui-ching -- about 10 hours after their return from the United States.

Chu Chao-liang, the spokesman for the team investigating the suspected money laundering case, said the prosecution took into consideration the couple's health state before summoning them for questioning just 10 hours after their flight arrived.
"Neither of the couple asked for a break in the interrogations for fatigue during the nearly-three-hour session," said Chu.
While the couple were still in the United States, the prosecution served subpoenas demanding them to come forward for questioning Aug. 29.
"As they came back earlier than expected, we decided to summon them for questioning today, " said Lin Chi-hui, another prosecutor involved in the investigation.

Asked why the prosecution did not arrest them at the airport immediately upon their return, Lin said that because the case happened more than six months ago, they would have had ample opportunity had they decided to collude in perjuring themselves and that there was therefore little point in detaining and separating them.
During the questioning, according to media reports, the couple refused to sign authorization letters allowing the prosecution to scrutinize their Swiss bank accounts.

The refusal could slow progress in investigating the case, but legal experts said that the prosecution will still be able to get the documents they need through judicial assistance from Swiss authorities.

Chen Chih-chung told a large crowd of reporters waiting at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport early Monday that the family's finances have always been managed by his mother, Wu Shu-jen, and that he and his wife were only being "dominated" to offer some help.
"We just did whatever mother told us to do. It was impossible for us to question (the origin of the money)," Chen said.

Huang stressed that she was only a "figurehead" used by her mother-in-law to open bank accounts overseas for cash deposits and that she and her husband had never thought of evading judicial investigation by refusing to return to Taiwan, as some Taiwanese media had speculated.
"Since our roles in the case are so obvious, we have no need to flee and make ourselves fugitives," she said.

Chen Chih-chung, who had gone to the United States together with his wife to enroll in the law school of the University of Virginia, said he requested that the enrollment be postponed for one year in the wake of the exposure of the alleged money-laundering case, but the university turned down his request and asked him to file an application next year if he still wishes to study at the school.

The couple departed Taiwan for the United States just a few days before Next magazine, a weekly tabloid, ran a story Aug. 13 claiming that Huang had laundered money for the former first family by secretly wiring NT$300 million (US$9.55 million) overseas in 2006, after the exposure of the "state affairs fund" embezzlement case implicating the former president and his wife.

The story was suspected to have been based on information leaked to the magazine by Taiwanese investigative authorities, which received a report in January from the international anti-money laundering organization Egmont Group that detailed the status of overseas bank accounts held by members of the former first family in other countries, including the United States, the Cayman Islands, Singapore and Switzerland.

However, allegedly due to concealment by the former head of the Investigation Bureau, prosecutors investigating the "state affairs fund" case were unaware of the existence of the report until the publication of the story by Next magazine.

The release of the story also coincided with the recent reception by Taiwan of a request by Swiss authorities for assistance in probing alleged money laundering by Chen Chih-chung and Huang Jui-ching in Switzerland.
Last Monday, prosecutors listed the former president and his wife, as well as Wu' s older brother Wu Ching-mao, Chen Chih-chung and Huang Jui-ching, as suspects in the alleged money-laundering case.

Questioned by prosecutors last Friday, the former first lady said the US$21 million in overseas bank accounts under the name of her elder brother and daughter-in-law was the balance of political contributions for the campaigns of her husband in two mayoral elections and two presidential elections from 1993 to 2004.

Wu's statement was consistent with that of former President Chen Shui-bian, who openly confessed Aug. 14 that he had lied about his election campaign expenses and that his wife wired surplus funds from the election campaign contributions into overseas bank accounts.
However, Chen claimed that all the surplus funds were handled by his wife and that he had no idea his wife had wired the funds abroad until early this year.

The former president denied the money had any connection with the "state affairs fund" case, in which the former first lady was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.
Chen, who had immunity from prosecution while in office, was named as a co- offender in the case and was probed as soon as he stepped down from the presidency May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Tuesday.
The weighted price index was down 85.58 points at 6,945.14 on a turnover of NT$1.76 billion (US$56 million) at the open. The index gained 119.08 points, or 1.72 percent, to close at 7,030.72 Monday.

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Tuesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$31.536 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.106 from Monday.
