DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 26, or the 26th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1789: The French Assembly adopts the Declaration of the Rights of Man.
1850: Louis Philippe, the "Citizen King" of France who abdicated rather than face a middle-class revolt, dies.
1858: Britain and Japan sign the Treaty of Edo (Tokyo), opening up Japan to British trade.
1873: Lee De Forest, American radio and television pioneer and inventor of the Audion vacuum tube, which made broadcasting possible, is born.
1906: Albert Bruce Sabin, American microbiologist and physician, is born in Poland. He developed a live-virus vaccine against polio in 1957, replacing the killed-virus vaccine invented by Jonas Salk.
1910: American physicians verify that the X-ray, discovered in 1895 by German physicist Wilhelm C. Roentgen, can help detect lung disease.
1920: The US legislature ratifies the 19th Amendment, giving American women the right to vote.
1926: Warner Brothers, an American movie company, is successful with its premiere sound picture.
1936: Egypt and Great Britain agree to a treaty that reaffirms Egypt's independence. This treaty also reduces the number of British troops stationed in Egypt and restricts them to the Suez Canal region.
1952: The Soviet Unions announces that the first successful Intercontinental Ballistic Missile (ICBM) tests have taken place.
1961: Burma becomes the world's first Buddhist republic.
1972: Sir Francis Chichester, English yachtsman who was the first senior citizen to sail around the world alone in his 53-foot yacht in 1966, dies at the age of 71.
1974: Charles Lindbergh, American aviator who made the first solo non-stop flight across Atlantic in 1927, dies at the age of 72.
1977: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Holbrooke, US assistant secretary of state for Asian and Pacific affairs, at the Executive Yuan for a briefing on Secretary of State Cyrus Vance's trip to Peking.
1978: Cardinal Albino Luciani of Venice is elected as Pope John Paul I. He died of a heart attack on Sept. 28.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo decorates visiting vice president of the Republic of Costa Rica Jose Miguel Alfaro Rodriguez with the Order of the Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon.
1987: A sex-crazed elephant "urgently in search of a mate" runs amuck in Bangkok, killing two people and flattening a radio center.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin signs a friendship treaty with the Czech Republic after condemning the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.
1996: Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, formally divorces Princess Diana Frances Spencer, ending 15 years of marriage.
1996: A court in Seoul sentences former President Chun Doo Hwan to death on charges of masterminding a 1979 coup and his successor, Roh Tae Woo, is sentenced to 22 years and six months in prison for playing a supporting role. Their prison terms were reduced later.
2001: Seven Democratic members of the U.S. House of Representatives write a letter to State Secretary Madeleine Albright, requesting that the State Department "take the necessary steps to end the inappropriate ban on high-level visits between elected Taiwanese officials and U.S. officials, including the democratically-elected president of Taiwan."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses exceedingly great moral qualities will certainly receive the divine call to the Imperial throne."

DOC.HEADLINE: 64% of fresh college graduates haven't been hired: survey

TEXT.P: Sixty-four percent of college graduates who left school this summer have not found jobs in the three months since, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by an online employment broker.

The survey conducted by 104 Job Bank found that of the 36 percent of graduates who have been employed, more than half began distributing their resumes before April, again proving true the belief that those who apply early have a better chance of landing jobs.

The starting salaries for this group of graduates averaged NT$41,250 for doctorate degree holders, NT$33,254 for master's degree holders, NT$23,088 for bachelor's degree holders, and NT$21,887 for polytechnic graduates, the results showed.

Among the fresh graduates who are still in search of employment, 16 percent said they had been offered employment but decided not to accept for reasons such as discrepancies between the job content and what they imagined, differences between job content and job description, low possibility of growth, and lower than expected pay offers.

While 7 percent of fresh graduates have not found a job because they have not started distributing their resumes, 19.2 percent have sent out 1-5 copies of resumes, 17.6 percent have sent 6-10 copies, and 17.3 percent have sent more than 40 copies.
However, 40.6 percent of job seekers have been offered 1-3 interview opportunities, and 22.5 percent have never been given a chance for interviews.
Meanwhile, approximately 60 percent of businesses responding to the survey said they are offering employment opportunities for fresh graduates this year.
On average, businesses screened 18 resumes this year for each candidate they interviewed. They decided in 40 seconds on average on whether a job applicant met their requirements.

The responding businesses said that in addition to work experience, they pay attention to the biographies written by the applicants, whether the applicants have a clear career objective, and whether the applicants are trained in the required fields.

Negative behaviors observed by businesses among fresh graduates looking for jobs this year included failing to keep interview appointments, quitting within a short period of time, accepting employment but backing out later, providing incomplete information in resumes, and setting wrong or unclear career objectives.
The survey was conducted Aug. 8-15 among 1,652 fresh graduates and 1,113 businesses. It had a margin of error of 2.94 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Kinmen tech institute to forge ties with Russian university

TEXT.P: The National Kinmen Institute of Technology is to forge sisterhood ties with the Far Eastern State Technical University located in Vladivostok, Russia, the president of the Kinmen school said Tuesday.
Lee Chin-chen made the announcement during a symposium on the Russian language held at the institute on the Taiwan-held outlying island of Kinmen.
During the seminar, participants exchanged views and shared their experiences on teaching the Russian language, while six Taiwanese and Russian scholars presented their theses on related subjects.
The seminar is the first on the subject of the Russian language held at the school since it launched a plan to increase exchanges and cooperation with foreign education institutes.

Speaking at the seminar, Lee said that as Kinmen had been on the frontline in the battle against communists regimes, including the Soviet Union, for over 60 years, the island had no contact with the Russian language.

However, under the current situation, with Kinmen's warming ties with China and the establishment of the "mini three links, " the island has been working to increase its ties with Russia, which shares a 4,000-kilometer border with China, Lee explained.
He said he will travel to the Far Eastern State Technical University on Sept. 23 to conclude the sisterhood arrangement.

Lee said that the exchanges with the Vladivostok-based school under the sisterhood agreement would mean that the Kinmen technical institute's practical foreign language curriculum will not be restricted to English.
"Establishing a Russian language learning environment at the school will open up another door of knowledge for Kinmen students, " he added.

Participants in the one-day symposium included professors Natalia S. Milyanchuk and Julia A. Gunko from the Far Eastern State Technical Institute, as well as Lee Hsi-mei, head of Chinese Culture University's Russian language department, and Yeh Hsiang-ling, an assistant professor in National Chengchi University's Slavic language department.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA postpones decision on minimum wage increase

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) decided Tuesday to delay its decision for month on whether to increase the country's minimum wage, based on the recommendations of a special committee assigned to examine the issue.

Government representatives on the committee argued that a minimum wage increase at this time of economic stagnation could push businesses to close down, said Mike Jen, president of the National Trade Union Confederation and a labor representative on the committee.
Committee members representing employers said they understood the workers' situation but agreed that the decision on a minimum wage increase should be postponed, according to Jen.
However, Jen argued that it is precisely because of the current economic slowdown that the government should move to help low-income workers.
The CLA said that a decision can be expected in month's time, after the Chung- Hua Institution for Economic Research presents a report on the impact of last year's minimum wage increase.
The 22-member committee was composed of scholars and representatives from labor, the private sector and government.

Taiwan's minimum wage was raised last year from NT$15,840 (US$502) to NT$17,280 (US$548) per month. But the labor unions argued that the increase was not sufficient to cover the daily basic needs of workers.

On the day when the committee meet, representatives of labor unions demonstrated outside the CLA building, asserting the right of workers to live with dignity and demanding that the minimum wage be raised at least 38 percent to NT$23,870.

We want to earn our livelihood with our own strength. How can we live with dignity if our salary cannot even allow us a minimum subsistence? " Wang Chuan- ping, Chief Executive Officer of the Labor Rights Association, said to the CNA.

Her association said that the minimum wage should allow a worker's family to at least meet its living expenses. As the prices of raw materials and energy continue to rise, the growth rate of the minimum wage should not be lower than that of the consumer price index (CPI), she said.
According to Chen Pao-chan, executive director of the Chinese Federation of Labor, about 1.43 million of the 8.8 million workers in Taiwan receive a monthly salary below the current minimum wage.

However, business representatives on the committee insisted that a minimum wage increase would only be beneficial to foreign workers, and that it would not necessarily be advantageous to Taiwanese workers.

"Most Taiwanese workers already earn more than the minimum wage, therefore, (increasing the minimum wage) would not make much of a difference to them, and it would not do any good for the country's economic development, " said K. P. Chang, one of the business representatives, adding that personally he expected the hike to be limited to less than 10 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan, Taiwan should shelve sovereignty issue in fishery talks: FM

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said Tuesday that Taiwan and Japan should set aside the sovereignty dispute over the Tiaoyutai Islands and work out a mechanism to jointly manage and develop the controversial territory, adding that the long-stalled fishery talks with Japan will resume next month.

"Given the fact that neither Taiwan nor Japan is likely to make any concession on the sovereignty (of the Tiaoyutai Islands) , we should try to see if the model of shelving sovereignty disputes with China can be applied to the fishery talks with Japan, " said Ou in an interview with the CNA.

"This is not entirely impossible, if we can think along the lines of setting up a committee for joint management and development of the disputed waters, while setting aside the sovereignty issue, "he added.

A Taiwanese recreation fishing boat sank after colliding with a Japanese patrol vessel June 10. The collision, which occurred near the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, sparked renewed controversy over the sovereignty of the island group, known as the Senkaku Islands in Japanese.
As Taiwan, Japan and China all claim rights to the Tiaoyutai Islands, this has complicated fishing disputes between Taiwan and Japan.
The two sides held a 15th round of fishery talks in July 2005 to try to resolve the disputes and both sides agreed to hold another round of dialogue in March 2006, but the talks never took place.
"If the fishery rights issue cannot be resolved, there's no telling if we have another incident like this whether it will interfere with our relations with Japan," Ou said.

He proposed that both Taiwan and Japan pay an "access fee" when fishing boats of either country enter the disputed waters -- a method used by Japan in dealing with its disputes with Russia over "four northern islands."
Now that both Taiwan and Japan have agreed to resume the fishery talks, Ou said, he hopes that the next round of negotiations will start in the next month.
He however admitted that Taiwan has not yet discussed its new proposal with Japan and does not know how Japan would respond.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fair Trade Commission watches for price rigging of school supplies

TEXT.P: The Fair Trade Commission said Tuesday that it will closely monitor the market for any signs of price rigging of school supplies and related items as students prepare to head back to class in less than a week.

The commission said that ahead of the Sept. 1 start of the new school year, it will keep an eye out for retailers colluding to raise the price of school items such as uniforms and textbooks, in the interests of consumers.
It will also issue reports to give parents of school children accurate information about the market for back-to-school items to allay their concerns and help them make wise purchase decisions.
Any businesses found to be in violation of the commission's price manipulation and anti-monopoly regulations will face fines ranging from NT$500,000 (US$15,850) to NT$25 million, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pursuit of diplomatic truce to create win-win-win situation: VP

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying- jeou's pursuit of a "diplomatic truce" with China will not only lead to lasting peace in the Taiwan Strait and global stability, but will also help to attract more investment to Taiwan and strengthen the country's move toward globalization, Vice President Vincent Siew said Tuesday.
Siew made the comments in a speech at the opening of a two-day Taiwan-U.S. forum on modern China, at National Chengchi University's Institute of International Relations.
This year's forum, which is the 37th of its kind, will focus on the themes of "a new order, new identity, and democratic transition."

According to Siew, the closed-door policy pursued by the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration over the last eight years not only hurt Taiwan's economic development, but also negatively affected regional economic development.
This insular policy also resulted in the loss of major opportunities for Taiwan in terms of strengthening economic cooperation with other countries, he added.

Siew said all the data on cross-strait economic exchanges clearly shows that Taiwan's closer economic integration with China since Ma's administration took office in May has created a winning situation for both sides, adding that Taiwan must grab the opportunities presented by closer ties with China.

As for those who are concerned about the potential threat that China poses, Siew said that the new government has been actively working to turn this threat into opportunity and to realize the goal of creating peace in the Taiwan Strait.
The only way to achieve this goal is through liberalizing and normalizing economic relations across the strait, he stressed.

Pointing out that the government was able to reach agreements with China on implementing regular cross-strait weekend charter flights and opening Taiwan to more Chinese tourists, Siew said the government is also actively pushing several mid- and long-term cross-strait policies that are aimed at liberalizing and internationalizing Taiwan's economy in order to attract more investment to the country and link it closer with the global market.

In addition to developing economic ties, President Ma has also actively advocated a cross-strait diplomatic truce of setting aside controversial issues, building mutual trust, and ending the longstanding tug-of-war in which each side tries to poach the other's diplomatic allies by offering large sums of money in foreign aid.

Siew said the president's "more practical and flexible" foreign policy is aimed at rebuilding Taiwan's international reputation and turning the country into a responsible stakeholder, and not a troublemaker, in the global community.

The vice president stressed that the diplomatic truce policy does not disregard Taiwan's international space, arguing that Taiwan will continue to maintain good relations and exchanges with other countries, especially the United States and Japan.

The government's new foreign policy, Siew said, will help create a "win-win-win situation" for Taiwan, China and the global community by establishing peace in the Taiwan Strait and contributing to international stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 66.12 points, or 0.94 percent, to close at 6,964.6.

Suffering a drop from gains of the previous day, the local bourse opened at 6,945.14 and fluctuated between 6,980.85 and 6,917.31. A total of 2.54 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$59.7 billion (US$1.89 billion).

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 2.9 percent. Textile stocks declined 2.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares dropped 1.8 percent, foodstuff issues fell 1.4 percent, banking and financial shares lost 1.2 percent, construction issues shed 1.1 percent, machinery and electronics shares were down 0.3 percent, and paper and pulp issues lost 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,414 to 598, with 445 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$2.5 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to increase investment in sports sector: president

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou pledged Tuesday that his administration will inject more funds into the sports sector by redistributing the government's financial resources.
According to Ma, an excessively large proportion of the country's educational resources is being placed in mental training while very little is being invested in physical training.

He urged the Ministry of Education and the Sports Affairs Council to work to improve physical education and sports development in the country and to pay more attention to sports competitions and the training of top athletes.

The president made the remarks while receiving members of Taiwan's national team on their return from the just-concluded 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing. Taiwan won four bronze medals and was ranked 72nd among the 204 countries and regions that participated in the event.

Ma recalled that during his terms as Taipei mayor from 1998 to 2006, the city government's investment in the sports sector was second only to its budget for the construction of the city's metro system.

Over the eight-year period, the city built or renewed a total of 80 swimming pools, and more than 85 percent of elementary school students and 75 percent of secondary school students passed swimming tests, Ma noted.
Ma said the efforts made by the city government may not be widely known to everyone, but he was trying to send the message -- anyone studying in Taipei must be able to swim.
"I was trying to define what constitutes a 'sound citizen, ' and having basic physical abilities is part of that," he said.
Ma said he is sure that it is worthwhile for the government to invest more in promoting sports in light of the potential benefits to the health of the country's citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fertilizer export ban to remain: agriculture council

TEXT.P: A ban on fertilizer exports will remain in place to help meet local demand amid rising fertilizer prices on the world market, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Tuesday.

"Fertilizer prices on the domestic market will not be increased until the end of this year, but the ban on fertilizer exports will be kept in place to avoid exports of cheap Taiwanese fertilizer at a time when global fertilizer prices are still rising," the COA said in a press release.

Thanks to government subsidies, Taiwan's urea is priced at NT$11,250 (US$358) per ton, which is only 30 percent of Japan's price, 50 percent of South Korea's price and 70 percent of China's price, it noted.
The COA predicted that international fertilizer prices will be unlikely to drop in the near term due to increased demand from developing countries, including China and India.

The COA's Agriculture and Food Agency also said the government will do its best to stabilize domestic fertilizer prices by the end of this year and to fully satisfy local farmers' needs through well designed distribution channels.
COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung announced May 28 that state-run Taiwan Fertilizer would absorb some 70 percent of the hikes in fertilizer prices that would take effect May 30.

But after heavy protests by farmers who complained that the price increases would drive them off their farms, Chen announced two days later that the fertilizer company would absorb up to 85 percent of the overall price increase and that there would be no fresh price adjustments before the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for September fell 43 points to close at 6,946, with 47,757 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October lost 48 points to finish at 6,923, with 179 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 39 points to close at 6,914, with 25 contract transactions.
March futures decreased 49 points to finish at 6,893, with six contract transactions, while June futures were down 41 points to close at 6,894, with 16 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,989 for September, 6,971 for October, 6,953 for December, 6,942 for March and 6,935 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index lost 66.12 points to finish at 6,964.6, on turnover of NT$59.7 billion (US$1.89 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

September TE futures increased 0.75 points to close at 284. 45, with 2,985 contracts traded, while October TE futures decreased 0.7 points to finish at 283, with nine contract transactions. December TE futures gained 0.65 points to end at 282.5, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

September TF futures moved down 10.8 points to close at 843.8, with 1,814 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures decreased 10.6 points to finish at 840.2, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Global workshop on human trafficking to be held in Taiwan

TEXT.P: The National Immigration Agency (NIA) under the Ministry of the Interior will host a two-day international workshop in Taipei from Wednesday on the prevention of cross-border human trafficking, an official said Tuesday.
"Cross-border human trafficking has in recent years become a big challenge to all nations and the international community, " said NIA Acting Director-General Chien Tai-lang.
Rampant human smuggling and trafficking have seriously eroded Taiwan's image in terms of human rights and the rule of law, he said.

"Establishing global cooperative mechanisms would be the most effective way to stamp out international human trafficking, apart from integrating and consolidating legal resources at home, on the part of the government," he suggested.

To broaden the flow of information and the range of international contacts, senior U.S. immigration officials, local law enforcement agents, researchers and non-governmental organization experts will share their experience through group discussions on a wide range of related issues at the two-day workshop, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Milk powder prices not expected to increase further

TEXT.P: The price of milk powder, which has been constantly rising since last year, is not expected to increase further in the coming months because production prices have dropped from their peak in February, according to a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) report released Tuesday.

Government Information Office Deputy Minister Lin Ching-hsiu revealed the report after a meeting of the Executive Yuan's special team devoted to seeking and achieving stable domestic commodity prices.
Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung presided over the meeting.

Lin told reporters that New Zealand has been Taiwan's main source of milk powder, followed by China and the Netherlands. The wholesale price of milk powder imported from New Zealand and the international fresh milk price both have been sliding over past two months, he added.

Citing the MOEA report, Lin said the international fresh milk price began dropping after it climbed to a peak of US$21.40 per pound on July 21, 2007. The price dropped even further from US$20.50 per pound Jan. 2 this year to US$17.15 per pound Aug. 20, a drop of 16.34 percent.

Lin further said that the price of milk powder imported from New Zealand has declined over the past two months to the February 2007 level, and that between Aug. 1-20, the price of domestic fresh milk decreased 1.2 percent from the July level but the price of milk powder recorded a slight increase of 0.5 percent.

Lin noted that the moderate fluctuations reflect the stabilization of prices of essential products. There should be no factors to cause the price of milk powder to go up in the coming months, he added.
Significant growth in milk prices began in late 2006, due to skyrocketing international crude oil and raw material prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign Minister urges China to show goodwill on Taiwan's U.N. bid

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco Ou urged China Tuesday to show goodwill on Taiwan's latest bid to participate in the United Nations and expressed hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can conduct dialogue on the issue.

Under President Ma Ying-jeou's concept of "modus vivendi" diplomatic strategy and a "diplomatic truce" with China, Taiwan made a fundamental shift in its U.N. campaign this year by asking the U.N. General Assembly to consider Taiwan's "meaningful participation" in U.N. specialized agencies instead of seeking full membership in the world body as it has done unsuccessfully in previous years.

In an interview with CNA, Ou said that the more moderate and pragmatic approach has received a very good response from the international community and that he believes the bid will win more support during the Sept. 16 U.N. General Assembly.

However the fate of Taiwan's new initiative hinges on China's attitude. Ou said that even though he cannot predict whether China will let the bid be included on the U.N. agenda given the fact that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have not yet negotiated the issue, he still hopes Beijing will give it a green light.
"Although the two sides have not discussed the issue, I think there is the need to negotiate with China on the matter, " Ou said.

"I hope that the issue of Taiwan's international space can be included in cross- strait talks as soon as possible, " he added, saying that economic negotiations between Taipei and Beijing, for example, under the framework of the World Trade Organization, will inevitably tap the issue of Taiwan's international space.

Talks between Taiwan and China re-opened June 11 for the first time in 10 years, involving Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) . The two sides agreed to focus on economic and trade issues in the beginning, setting aside political issues such as sovereignty and Taiwan's international space.

The fresh approach by the government for the country's participation to the U.N. is seen as the first crucial test for Ma's diplomacy, which has been criticized by the opposition as giving up Taiwan's sovereignty.
Since 1993, Taiwan's allies have been trying to put the issue of Taiwan's participation on the agenda of the U.N. General Assembly, but Beijing's argument that Taiwan is part of China has prevailed.

Noting that the Foreign Ministry has done a lot of work in pitching this year's bid to its allies and other important countries such as the United States, the European Union and Japan, Ou said that the more pragmatic approach is in line with the government's policy of seeking reconciliation and a "diplomatic truce" with China.

The frosty relations between Taiwan and China have been thawing since Ma took office May 20, with his proposal of a "diplomatic truce" aimed at terminating the longstanding diplomatic tug-of-war with China in which both countries try to lure each other's allies to switch diplomatic allegiance by offering large sums of money in foreign aid to developing countries.

Ou also said positive results have been observed in terms of multilateral relations, as well as cross-strait relations, citing as an example Ma's recent first state visit to South America and the Caribbean.
He said changes in the attitudes of Taiwan's allies Paraguay, Panama and the Dominican Republic can serve as an indicator that China has shown goodwill toward Ma's diplomatic strategy.
"We have made sufficient manifestation to the international community and the response has been very good, " the Foreign Minister said. "They all think the bid is very reasonable."
Ou admitted that it is a daunting task to get the bid listed on the U.N. agenda, but said the most important thing is that the international community has a positive response to Taiwan's approach.

"The case is impossible without international support, " he noted. "Even if the case fails to be listed on the agenda, I believe many countries will speak for us at the General Assembly or will express their support in other less direct ways," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Urban renewal investment to reach NT$280 billion

TEXT.P: Public and private investment in urban renewal projects will amount to an estimated NT$80 billion (US$8.9 billion) over the next four years, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Tuesday.

According to the ministry, 50 potential urban rejuvenation projects on mostly government-owned land might be launched over the coming four years. If the government can succeed in soliciting enough investment in 20 of these projects, the total investment will reach NT$124.9 billion.

During the same period, the government is also scheduled to approve 100 private urban renewal projects, for a total investment NT$150 billion, with each case receiving an average investment of NT$1.5 billion.
With all these projects combined, an MOI official said, private and government investments in urban rejuvenation could top NT$280 billion in the coming four years.

Pointing out that the urban renewal programs are part of the "i-Taiwan 12 projects" proposed by President Ma Ying-jeou in his campaign platform, the official said they will be referred to the Executive Yuan for review and implementation step by step.
To quicken the pace of the urban renewal, the official went on, the ministry has stepped up preparations for bidding procedures, with 12 areas now in the pre- processing stage of calling for tenders.

Meanwhile, the official said the Executive Yuan authorized Aug. 14 the establishment of a Central Urban Renewal Fund using NT$40 million of the 2009 budget to attract private investment in the redevelopment of government-owned urban land plots.
A unit has also been entrusted to establish an office to assist in encouraging and integrating interest in urban renewal and calling for tenders, added the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese crewman dies in fall from gravel ship

TEXT.P: A crewman from China working on a gravel ship docked at Tainan's Anping harbor in southern Taiwan died Tuesday after falling five meters to the ground from the ship's deck.

Firemen with the Tainan City Fire Brigade said they responded to a call for help at around 6 a.m. and rushed Liu Shunguo, 22, from the No. 2 wharf to a local hospital, where he was pronounced dead on arrival.
A harbor official said the fall occurred at 5: 35 a.m. and that harbor police were still investigating how it happened.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet to review athletic training system

TEXT.P: The Sports Affairs Council (SAC) will submit a review on the national delegation's performance in the Beijing Olympics to the Executive Yuan for its reference when reviewing the current athletic training system in pursuit of a better one, a SAC official said Tuesday.
The delegation of 80 players participated in 15 events and brought home four bronze medals, two in taekwando and two in weightlifting.

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan met with delegation members that same day to give his regards for their performance, which allowed Taiwan to rank 80th among 204 countries and areas. The medal count was the country's worst since 1988.
The official said the SAC will submit the report to the Cabinet Aug. 28, and will expect improvements to the whole training system to be made by the Cabinet.
The official pointed out that many players only received training in Taiwan and do not have enough experience participating in international sports events.

This weakness has caused players who are unmatched in Taiwan to win no medals in international events, the official said, adding that the report will suggest hiring more coaches who meet international standards to contribute to future training.

The report will also suggest beginning athletic training earlier, when potential athletes are in elementary school, the official said. He emphasized that this change is a must because it takes at least six to 10 years of training to help an athlete achieve peak performance.

Also according to the official, the SAC has communicated with the Ministry of Education about assisting potential players in choosing majors and schools that will be most beneficial to their future performance in international games.
The future training should be aimed at long-term performance in more arenas, not just focused on winning medals in the Asian Games in two years and in the 2012 Olympic Games, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q2 consumer confidence in housing prices down sharply: survey

TEXT.P: Consumer confidence in Taiwan's housing prices declined sharply in the second quarter of 2008, indicating the country's housing market has begun to undergo a downward correction, according to the results of a quarterly survey released Tuesday.
The survey was conducted by the Institute for Physical Planning and Information for the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

The composite housing price confidence index stood at 90, down from 124 in the previous quarter. Meanwhile, the confidence index for housing prices in the future stood at 80, down from 120 in the previous quarter, the results showed.
An index below 100 is indicative of pessimism, while one above 100 is indicative of optimism.

Among those looking to buy a home in Taipei City -- where housing prices are the highest in the country -- the confidence index for housing prices in the future dropped almost by half from 129.47 in the first quarter to 65.79 in the second quarter.
The survey found that 31 percent of potential home buyers thought home purchases would cause a very heavy or extremely heavy burden on their living expenses.
On average, potential home buyers expected to find a home ranging between NT$3 million and NT$6 million, lower than the average final selling price of NT$6.26 million recorded in the second quarter.
In Taipei City in particular, the potential demand for housing properties costing more than NT$12 million decreased by 7 percent in the second quarter.
The survey was conducted July 1-15 among the clients of 16 banks and nine real estate brokerage companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: President asks FM to establish task force on the SE Asian region

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said Tuesday that President Ma Ying-jeou asked the foreign ministry to establish an inter-agency task force on the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) , a strategic move aimed at strengthening relations with the region and preventing Taiwan from being marginalized.

"Located in the Southeast Asian region, how is Taiwan going to survive if it is marginalized (by the ASEAN countries), " Ou said in an interview with the CNA. "We have to find ways to cut into ASEAN."

Ou said the task force will be set up following the model of the Taiwan-Japan Relations Task Force, which reports regularly on foreign policy to the National Security Council before making suggestions to the president, as Ma attaches great importance to relations between Taiwan and ASEAN countries.
He added that Ma issued the directive after listening to the foreign ministry's report on work with the Middle East a day earlier.

In his visit to the foreign ministry Aug. 4, Ma also contended that Taiwan should be included in the expansion of ASEAN Plus One and ASEAN Plus Three, asking "why not ten plus four? " Ma was referring to the fact that ASEAN countries are engaging in serious negotiations with China, Japan and South Korea to form Free Trade Agreements.

Established in Thailand in 1967, ASEAN is made up of 10 member countries including Thailand, Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Brunei, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, and Myanmar. Its objectives include the acceleration of economic growth, social progress, cultural development among its members, and the promotion of regional peace.
Ou said if Taiwan does not work on strengthening relations with ASEAN countries, it will be marginalized, as will its national interests.

The Foreign Minister also noted that the ministry is considering setting up a special unit in charge of handling relations with ASEAN and increasing representative offices in the Southeast Asian region, adding that the unit would also be responsible for coordination with other ministries.

Noting that Taiwan does not have representative offices in two ASEAN member countries, Myanmar and Laos, Ou said that the ministry is planning to set up representative offices in those two countries in order to have full presence in all 10 ASEAN nations.
He said the foreign ministry will submit a statement outlining the concrete ideas of the task force to the president and premier in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT offices to close Sept. 1 for holiday

TEXT.P: The American Institute (AIT) in Taiwan said Tuesday that all its offices will be closed Sept. 1 in observance of U.S. Labor Day.

The AIT made the announcement in a press release in which it also said that its Consular Section, the Commercial Section, the Agricultural Trade Office, the American Cultural Center and the AIT Kaohsiung branch office will all be closed for the holiday and will re-open Sept. 2.
The AIT functions as the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of official diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei-Yilan highway cycle race to take place Saturday

TEXT.P: A bicycle race will be held on the Taipei-Yilan provincial highway Saturday to promote tourism, organizers said Tuesday.
Ever since the Beiyi Freeway opened to traffic in 2006, the traffic flow on the provincial highway has been reduced greatly, and the road has become a favorite among cyclists and motorcyclists.
The race, aimed at promoting tourism in the northeastern county of Yilan, is being organized by the Yilan county government, the Taiwan Cyclist Federation and the Yilan Cycling Association.
It will consist of two categories -- a race and a fun run -- so that non- competitors can enjoy a more leisurely pace and enjoy the stunning views along the way, the organizers said.

According to the organizers, the racers will have to complete a 20-km section of the road starting from the Wushih Harbor Visitor Center in Yilan county's Toucheng township to the Shihpai Park which straddles the border between Taipei and Yilan counties, while the fun run will be an 18 km loop starting and finishing at the Wushih Harbor Visitor Center.
The organizers added that traffic controls will be in place from 7: 40 a.m. to 10 a.m. Aug. 30, and urged cooperation from the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung-Guangzhou weekend charter flights might be halted

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu urged the central government in Taipei Tuesday to help hold off a planned halt to weekend charter flights between Kaohsiung and Guangzhou in China's Guangdong Province from September.

Speaking at a municipal meeting, Chen urged the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou to help reverse the decision by Taipei-based UNI Airways, which has operated direct cross-Taiwan Strait weekend charter flights between the two destinations from July 18, as a result of operating losses.
"The Ma administration should do something in the face of the situation, as the direct flight service has been implemented for less than two months," the mayor said.

Chen reminded Ma of his presidential campaign promise that "one third" of the Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan would enter and leave Taiwan via Kaohsiung International Airport to help boost business opportunities in the southern port city.

According to pacts signed in mid-June by Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, Taiwanese and Chinese carriers are allowed to operate up to 36 weekend charter flights and up to 3, 000 Chinese tourists are allowed to visit Taiwan per day from July 18, following several test runs on July's first weekend.

Director of the municipal Economic Affairs Bureau Liu Hsin-cheng suggested that the central government allow the opening of more direct flights from Kaohsiung to other Chinese destinations such as Beijing or Shanghai.

"The Kaohsiung-Guangzhou weekend charter flights lack sufficient passengers, as most of the China-based businessmen from southern Taiwan have their operations in Guangdong's Dongguan or Shenzhen rather than in Guangzhou," Liu pointed out.
"Those businessmen still prefer to travel between Taiwan and China via Hong Kong or Macau," he added.

Lin Shang-chih, chairman of the Kaohsiung Travel Agency Association, complained that only a few Taipei-based travel agencies are permitted to take on Chinese tourists as clients, while those headquartered in other parts of Taiwan are excluded.

This unfair practice makes it very difficult for carriers and travel agencies outside Taipei City to make a profit, he said, adding that the central government should hold new talks with China to re-allot the cross-strait weekend charter flights and destinations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutor to head for Singapore for alleged money-laundering case

TEXT.P: A chief prosecutor in Taipei will depart for Singapore Wednesday to seeks its help in Taiwan's probe into a suspected money laundering case embroiling former President Chen Shui-bian and his family members, prosecutorial sources said Tuesday.

Ching Chi-jen, chief prosecutor of the Taipei District Prosecutors' Office, will ask her Singaporean counterparts to file an application with a local court to help look into the former first family's bank accounts in Singapore, the sources said.

At present, Taiwan and Singapore have no agreements on judicial assistance. However, the sources said, Singapore's chief prosecutors' office has long maintained a friendly relationship with Taiwan's prosecutorial authorities.
Taiwan plans to seek help from Singapore because evidence has shown that the former first family's overseas capital was wired to banks in Singapore and Switzerland, the sources noted.
Ching will return home Sept. 1, according to the sources.

Former first lady Wu Shu-jen has previously told prosecutors that the overseas bank accounts were opened for fund investment and that the money transfers were made since Chen was elected as a lawmaker 20 years ago.
She noted that two bank accounts are registered in the name of her older brother Wu Ching-mao, and two other in the name of her daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching.
Her son, Chen Chih-chung, is an authorized proxy on all the bank accounts, Wu said.

Wu has denied corruption accusations and contended that the money, totalling US$21 million, came from Chen's previous political election contributions, previous income savings and investment earnings as well as Wu's dowry.
The former president openly confessed Aug. 14 that he did not correctly report his expenses from previous mayoral and presidential elections between 1993 and 2004.

He also said that all the surplus funds were handled by his wife and that his wife wired surplus funds from the election campaign contributions into overseas bank accounts without informing him until early this year.

Chen Shui-bian denied the money had any connection with the "state affairs fund" case, in which the former first lady was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.
Chen, who had immunity from prosecution while in office, was named as a suspect in the case and was probed as soon as he stepped down from the presidency May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Phelps' Olympic achievement kindles hope for hyperactive children

TEXT.P: The unprecedented achievements by American athlete Michael Phelps in the swimming events of the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games has given hope to many Taiwanese parents with hyperactive children, a doctor in central Taiwan said Tuesday.

Chen Chin-hung of the Chung Shan Medical University Hospital's Department of Psychiatry, said Phelps -- who had attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) when he was a child -- has set an example with his eight Olympic golds for swimming of what a hyperactive child can achieve if his or her energy can be channeled constructively.
Chen pointed out that ADHD is most commonly diagnosed in children and that the best time to treat its symptoms is during the elementary school period.
The disorder is still considered a chronic condition for which no medical cure is available, although medication and behavioral therapy can treat the symptoms.

About 4 percent to 12 percent of the world's children are affected by ADHD and domestic studies show that between 7.5 percent and 9.9 percent of the children born in Taiwan have the condition, according to Chen.
Chen added that 30 percent of these hyperactive children can have their conditions stabilized during their adolescence, while another 30 percent do not improve until during their college years.

As for the remaining 30 percent, he went on, they remain hyperactive in adulthood, and can tend to display such symptoms as poor concentration, running red lights and driving under the influence of alcohol.

The psychiatrist also said that new medicines developed in recent years can improve concentration in 80 percent of hyperactive children, and that with appropriate treatment, 60 percent of the children he has treated have shown progress in their academic performance.

Phelps, 23, was a hyperactive child who was unable to contain his energy, according to his mother. "He never sat still, never closed his mouth, was always asking questions, always jumping from one thing to another," she is reported as having said.

Although Phelps started taking medication and undergoing behavior modification at 9, he stopped taking his medication two years later and had his ADHD symptoms controlled by channeling his energy into swimming, so that by the time he was 16 he became a top-class athlete.
In his Beijing triumph, Phelps captured eight gold medals, breaking Mark Spitz's seven golds achieved at the Munich Olympics in 1972.

DOC.HEADLINE: National security top priority in Kinmen-Xiamen bridge plan: MND

TEXT.P: National security should be top concerns in evaluating the feasibility of constructing a bridge connecting the Taiwan-controlled island of Kinmen and the nearby Chinese city of Xiamen, despite increasing exchanges between the two sides, Defense Minister Chen Chao-min said Tuesday.
Chen made the declaration to reporters in response to questions on the proposed project, about which President Ma Ying-jeou said during a visit to Kinmen Sunday he has adopted an open attitude.

Ma said that policy will be formed to decide whether or not to build the bridge, proposed by the Kinmen county government as part of efforts to promote local economic development, after all relevant evaluations have been carried out.

Addressing the Ministry of National Defense's (MND's) evaluation, Chen said that "it is not possible to achieve the goal at present" because Beijing has never displayed "goodwill, " a reference to China's refusal to dismantle thousands of missiles targeting Taiwan.
Without taking national security into consideration, "we would be caught off guard" if the communists take military action to invade Taiwan, Chen said.
He reiterated that the MND's top task is to safeguard national security.

Asked why the MND allows military officers and soldiers to believe that communist China remains their targeted enemy despite the thawing of relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Chen said that it is the government's policy to pursue peace in the strait.
However, since China remains reluctant to show goodwill toward Taiwan, now is not the time for the military to be off-guard in the face of Beijing's continued military threat, Chen noted.
Premier Liu Chao-shiuan described the Kinmen-Xiamen bridge construction proposal as "forward looking" Sunday when he inspected the planned site for the bridge with Ma.
Liu said he will include the proposal in future cross-strait talks. When construction might be likely to begin, however, will be dependent on the future development of cross-strait ties, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government might grant visa privileges to Chinese citizens: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) expects to negotiate with China on easing visa restrictions on Chinese visitors following President Ma Ying-jeou's announcement Sunday that the government plans to offer landing visas or multiple-entry visas to Chinese visitors to the islands of Kinmen and Matsu.
MAC spokesman Liu Teh-hsun said Tuesday that the administration came up with the plan after thorough assessments by the government.

The measure was proposed based on the principle of reciprocity, as 11 Chinese cities, such as Haiko, Shanya, Xiamen, Fuzhou, and Shanghai, allow entry of Taiwanese tourists on landing visas, Liu added.

He also said the measure is aimed at attracting more Chinese tourists to Kinmen and Matsu by granting them preferential visa treatment and lessening the impact of the July 4 opening of direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights and direct transport links between the two islands and the Chinese province of Fujian, according to Liu.

While the procedures of visa application will be simplified and will take less time, Chinese tourists will still need to submit applications to the National Immigration Agency and obtain its approval before they can get landing visas or multiple-entry visas, Liu added.
Noting that the measures will be implemented on a trial basis, Liu downplayed concerns that they might pose a threat to national security.

He said that in an effort to attract more Chinese tourists to the two islands, the government will negotiate with the Chinese authorities on locations for offices that will handle visa matters, to minimize the time Chinese tourists will have to wait for visa approval.

Ma, who made the announcement on Kinmen Sunday while marking the 50th anniversary of the 823 Artillery Battle, said the proposal is aimed at boosting the outlying islands' economic development and making travel to Kinmen and Matsu more convenient for Chinese tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County group to attend travel fair in Shandong Province

TEXT.P: A tourism promotion group composed of Taipei County officials and local business executives will depart Wednesday for Shandong Province in northern China, where it will attend an international travel fair in the provincial capital to entice Chinese tourists, a county official said Tuesday.

Apart from the county's natural landscapes and tourism facilities and resorts, the delegation will focus on wedding photos and medical tourism to woo potential Chinese visitors at the international travel fair in Jinan City, the county's Tourism Bureau Director Chin Hui-chu said at a news conference prior to departure.

The Taipei county government decided to send the delegation to the event in anticipation of a new wave of Chinese tourists coming to Taiwan now that the Beijing Olympics have finished, despite the current low numbers of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan, said Chin.
"The county hopes to cash in on the potential business opportunities that might emerge along with expected larger numbers of Chinese tourists to Taiwan after the Olympic Games," she explained.

In line with two landmark pacts signed by Taiwan and China in mid-June in Beijing, Taiwan agreed to permit up to 3,000 Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan per day and to establish direct weekend charter flights between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait from July 18.
Chin predicted that travel costs for visits by Chinese tourists might be substantially slashed after the two sides hold the next round of two-way talks, slated for late October or early November.
Shandong Province, due to its growing economic clout, was among the first Chinese cities and provinces authorized by Beijing to allow its residents to travel overseas, she noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Percentage of Kaohsiung County's elderly population rises to 10%

TEXT.P: The percentage of elderly people in the population of Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan had reached nearly 10 percent as of the end of July, according to statistics released Tuesday by the county government's Bureau of Social Affairs.
According to the bureau, figures from a recent census show that Kaohsiung County had 124,100 people aged 65 or over at the end of July.
The figures also show that the percentage of elderly people in Kaohsiung County rose from 7 percent in 1993 to 9.99 percent in July this year.
Of them, 52 were centenarians -- 36 women and 16 men -- the oldest of whom was 107 years old.

Bureau officials said the county government will present each of the centenarians with a red envelope containing NT$10,000 (US$315) on Chong Yang Festival, observed on the ninth day of the ninth month on the Chinese calendar.

The festival, also known as Double Nine Festival, falls on Oct. 7 this year. In 1966, the central government rededicated the festival as Senior Citizens' Day -- a time for society to show its appreciation for the elderly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Coal-fired power plant project in central Taiwan raises controversy

TEXT.P: An environmental impact assessment panel postponed Tuesday its decision over the construction plan for a coal-fired power plant located in the Changhua Coastal Industrial Park in central Taiwan, after environmentalists accused the Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) of submitting a thinly disguised previously rejected plan.

The review meeting, originally convened to review the construction plan, was interrupted when environmentalists claimed that the plan was turned down in April last year due to the considerable carbon dioxide emissions and the potential impact on local residents' health that the plant would have. The plan was withdrawn by Taipower two months later.
Taipower, however, introduced a similar plan this year to the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) , a plan that the environmentalists described as "old wine in a new bottle."

"If the environmental impact assessment panel creates a precedent (by recognizing the Taipower's construction plan as a new one) , all construction plans can be approved this way, " said Thomas Chan, an attorney representing the environmentalists at the meeting.

According to the Environmental Impact Assessment Law, Taipower is entitled to withdraw the plan and submit a new one. However, because of the controversy, the EPA will now request the Ministry of Justice to interpret the related clauses in the law.
However, Taipower representatives insisted that the plan is new, as supplementary information about protected animals and migratory birds have been included.
They also said that even with the new power plant's carbon dioxide emissions, the total emissions of the industrial park will not exceed emission quantities permitted by the EPA.
They argued that the power plant is necessary in order to ensure electricity supplies and raise the park's energy efficiency.

The construction of the power plant might help boost industrial development and create jobs in the region, said Huang Chiu-ming, leader of a community association in Changhua County's Lukang township.

The environmentalists are strongly opposed to the project, insisting that the new plant will emit at least 8 million tons of carbon dioxide per year, accounting for 3 percent of Taiwan's total annual carbon dioxide emissions.

They also said that the Taichung coal-fired power plant, located only 15 km from the designated site of the new plant, has caused serious acid rain in central Taiwan, inflicting considerable damage not only on residents' health but also on local historic monuments.

The Taichung coal-fired power plant has been listed by the international scientific journal Nature as the most polluting power plant in the world, emitting 37 million metric tons of carbon dioxide in 2007 alone.

In addition, environmentalists claimed that sousa chinensis, a rare species of white dolphin, are living under threat due to coastal industrial development. The dolphins, indigenous to Taiwan, were classified by the International Union for Conservation of Nature as "critically endangered" Aug. 13 this year.
According to the Wild at Heart Legal Defense Association, the dolphins live mainly around the island's western coast and at present number only about 70.

DOC.HEADLINE: Group hosts seminar to train volunteer legal interpreters

TEXT.P: A local human rights group in Taipei kicked off a seminar organized with the help of Taiwan's top judicial body Tuesday to train volunteer legal interpreters in 10 languages.

"The accuracy of legal interpreters have an impact on investigations into cases involving foreigners in Taiwan and the impartiality of trials," said Zhang Xue-hai, director-general of the Taiwan Association for Legal Education.
The seminar is aimed at enhancing volunteers' legal knowledge to help them accurately interpret in court, Zhang said at the seminar's opening ceremony.
Accurate interpretation will help protect the human rights of parties concerned in legal cases, the long-term human rights activist went on.
Wu Chiu-hung, a judge in the Judicial Yuan, described the interpreter's job as one that requires "professionalism" and noted that local courts are in dire need of legal interpreters.
The two-day seminar attracted 40 local and foreign participants from the Taipei- based Thailand Trade and Economic Office, the Korean Mission in Taipei, local schools and social groups.

The seminar focused on nine languages -- English, Japanese, Thai, Myanmarese, Vietnamese, Spanish, Korean, Arabic, Hakka and Taiwan's Amis tribal language -- and offered legal courses taught by judges of the Judicial Yuan, as well as tours of local courts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Art Taipei 2008 to open Friday

TEXT.P: Art Taipei 2008, an international art trade fair, is slated to open at the Taipei World Trade Center Friday in an effort to promote arts appreciation among the general public and to enlarge the local support base for the arts, Council for Cultural Affairs officials said Tuesday.
The five-day arts event is jointly sponsored by the Cabinet-level council and the Art Galleries Association of the Republic of China, according to the officials.
Art works from 111 art galleries -- 63 domestic galleries and 48 international galleries -- will be displayed in the annual event, the officials went on.
A special area, titled "Made In Taiwan," will be created for eight gifted young Taiwanese artists to present their artistic creations, the officials said.
The council selected the eight artists from among 108 young applicants who presented their creative works during a recent screening process, the officials explained.
The forms of the works to be displayed in the special area include photography, painting, collage, paper sculpture, paper-cutting and digital-image self- portraits.
The number of visitors and art galleries taking part in the art event has grown each year since the event was launched three years ago, the officials added.

The value of business transactions gained as a result of the event has also increased annually, said the officials, adding that the value of business transactions for 2007 reached NT$450 million (US$14.27 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan seeking help from Palau to intercept hijacked fishing boat

TEXT.P: Taiwan has asked the Palau government to send a patrol boat to waters near the island to intercept a Taiwanese fishing boat that is suspected of having been hijacked by its Indonesian crew, the Fisheries Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture disclosed Tuesday.
Fisheries Agency officials said the request for help was made through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Meanwhile, the agency also informed 11 Taiwanese fishing boats operating in the vicinity to provide assistance to the boat, the Tai Yi Hsiang, if they see it, the officials said.
The boat's captain, Li Feng-bao, is the only Taiwanese national aboard the vessel, which is manned by an eight-strong Indonesian crew.

Information provided by a ship position monitoring system showed that the Tai Yi Hsiang -- a 69.4-ton longliner registered with Pingtung County's Liouciou township in southern Taiwan -- was located about 200 nautical miles east of the Philippines within Palau's economic exclusion zone and was sailing south in the direction of Indonesia.

The boat left Pingtung County's Donggang harbor July 12 to operate in international waters west of Guam, but Li's family said they had lost contact with him since Aug. 19 and feared that the boat might have been hijacked by its Indonesian crew, who were hired through a labor brokerage firm and were working for Li for the first time.

Officers aboard two Coast Guard Administration cutters dispatched early Tuesday to chase the boat, reported that the boat had entered Palau's economic exclusion zone, prompting the Ministry of Foreign affairs to seek help from the Palau government.
Taiwan and Palau maintain cordial diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows resumption of diplomatic war if China rejects truce

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that Taiwan will immediately resume its diplomatic war with China if Beijing does not accept a truce with Taipei in the diplomatic arena.
Ma said in an interview with the local Chinese-language magazine Global Views Monthly that it will soon be clear if China has rejected the truce proposed by Taiwan when he took office May 20.
He dismissed criticism that the government is engaged in wishful thinking in the thawing relations with China and said that "it takes two to tango."
He also said it is impossible to make a great leap in cross-Taiwan Strait relations and that advancement should be done incrementally.
He argued that the two sides already enjoy mutual trust, otherwise cross-strait weekend charter flights would not have been implemented July 4, less than two months after he was sworn in.
China claims sovereignty over self-ruled Taiwan and threatens war if Taiwan moves toward formal independence.

Contrary to his predecessor Chen Shui-bian, who favors formal independence for Taiwan, Ma has proposed pragmatic diplomacy, which he said focuses on workability and flexibility while maintaining the country's interests and dignity.

Ma said that during his first state visit to Paraguay and the Dominican Republic between Aug. 12-19, he met the heads of state of Taiwan's six diplomatic allies in Central and South America and eight presidents of countries friendly toward Taiwan but which do not have diplomatic relations with Taipei.
The results of the visit were far better than he had been expecting, he said.

During his visit, Ma said he did not talk about financial aid and added that under the cross-strait diplomatic truce, Taiwan no longer needs to engage in the widely criticized "checkbook diplomacy" to buy new allies.
In the future, Taiwan's financial aid will not focus on seeking to establish ties with other countries but on fulfilling its responsibility as a member of the international community, he went on.

He added that the Netherlands' and Japan's foreign financial aid accounted for 0.7 percent of their GDP, a figure set by the United Nations, when their per capita income reached US$17,000-US$18,000, the level of Taiwan's present per capita income.
At present, however, Taiwan's financial aid only accounts for 0.15 percent of its GDP, Ma said, adding that its financial aid only focuses on the 23 countries that recognize Taiwan's statehood.

DOC.HEADLINE: No landing visas for Chinese tourists to Penghu: MAC

TEXT.P: The Penghu county government has recently asked the central government to allow Chinese visitors to Penghu to be granted landing visas to help boost local tourism, but the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday that the visa issue will only be addressed after regular direct transport links between Penghu and China are opened.

President Ma Ying-jeou recently revealed a plan to offer landing visas or multiple-entry visas to Chinese travelers to Kinmen, a Taiwan-controlled island close to the southeastern coast of China, as part of efforts to accelerate local economic development and increase the number of Chinese tourists traveling to Kinmen.
The initiative prompted Penghu residents to call for similar treatment for Chinese visitors to their offshore county.

In his response, MAC Deputy Chairman Fu Don-cheng said that at present, the first thing to do is to overhaul the regulations governing travel between Penghu and China via Kinmen or Matsu to make regular direct links possible.

Efforts began in July to try to expand the links, Fu revealed, noting that it is expected that direct transport links between Penghu and China will be achieved before the two sides of the Taiwan Strait sign an agreement on the launch of overall direct cross-strait maritime links.
At the moment, direct maritime links with China exist only for Kinmen and Matsu -- two outlying islands that are closer to China than to Taiwan proper.

Speaking of the planned granting of landing visa privileges to Chinese visitors to Kinmen and Matsu, Fu said the new measure will be carried out on a trial basis, after which an evaluation will be conducted before the government decides whether or not to expand the visa privileges.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait talks to touch on exchange of rep offices: SEF head
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/26/08 23:45:11 (By Yang Ming-chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A new round of negotiations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait slated for this autumn will discuss issues regarding an exchange of visa-issuing offices, Taiwan's top negotiator with China said in Tokyo Tuesday.

"The proposed exchange of visa offices is aimed at attracting more Chinese tourists to Taiwan and offering easier access for Taiwan businessmen seeking to tap into the vast Chinese market," said Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Chiang, a vice chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , is visiting Japan in his capacity as head of the SEF, a quasi-official intermediary body authorized to handle negotiations and exchanges with China in the absence of official ties between the two sides.

Chiang told a group of Japanese journalists that the SEF and its Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- will hold a new round of talks in Taipei in October or November.
The agenda items will also include issues regarding turning the existing weekend direct cross-strait charter flights into regular flight services, Chiang went on.

Predicting that the exchange of visa offices and expansion of flight services will boost civic exchanges, Chiang said such interaction will boost mutual understanding, which might eventually inspire China to think about overhauling its political system and to refer to Taiwan's political and economic development formula for adopting democracy.

Earlier in the day, Chiang delivered a speech on the latest developments in cross-strait relations at the headquarters of the Nippon Keidanren (Japan Business Federation) , one of the largest economic organizations in Japan.

In his speech, Chiang said the coming five to 10 years will be crucial to Taiwan's development and that whether the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will enjoy lasting peace will rely on their leaders' visions and determination, particularly President Ma Ying-jeou's courage and wisdom.
Chiang is accompanied by four KMT lawmakers Lee Hung-chun, Lee Chia-chin, Lee Fu-hsing and Lin Yu-fang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open marginally lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened marginally lower Wednesday.
The weighted price index was down 13.72 points at 6,950.88 on a turnover of NT$1.52 billion (US$48.27 million) at the open. The index lost 66.12 points, or 0.94 percent, to close at 6,964.60 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Wednesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$31.523 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.034 from Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 27, or the 27th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1813: France's Napoleon Bonaparte, with a force of 130,000, wins his last great battle at Dresden, Germany, against a superior Austrian, Prussian and Russian allied force of 200,000.
1859: The world's first oil well is drilled by Edwin L. Drake at Titusville, Pennsylvania.
1883: The 1,800 meter Krakatoa on the Indonesian island of Rakata erupts with a fury that is heard in Australia, more than 3,541 km away, and gigantic tidal waves of up to 36 meters devastate the coastal towns of Java and Sumatra, leaving an estimated 36,000 people dead, and making the eruption the most catastrophic volcanic event ever recorded.
1891: Russia and France sign an entente cordiale.
1908: Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th president of the United States, is born. He succeeded to the office after John F. Kennedy was assassinated. He won the 1964 election but faced increasing criticism over the mounting US involvement in Vietnam, and did not stand for reelection in 1968.
1910: Thomas Alva Edison, the American inventor who patented more than a thousand inventions, shows his "talking picture" for the first time at his New Jersey laboratory.
1910: Mother Teresa of Calcutta, the Yugoslavian-born Albanian nun dedicated to the poor and sick, particularly in India, is born. She won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, in an attempt to impose dictatorial rule after assuming the provisional presidency in Beijing in March, 1912, orders the arrest of eight members of a constitution-drafting committee.
1916: Italy declares war on Germany.
1916: Romania declares war on Austro-Hungary, thus entering World War I.
1928: The Kellogg-Briant Pact, or Pact of Paris, an international agreement to condemn all war as a means of settling dispute, is signed by representatives of 15 nations.
1939: The world's first jet-propelled aircraft, the He-178 developed by German manufacturer Ernst Heinkel, makes its first flight at Marienehe, in northern Germany.
1946: A pilot's ejector seat prototype is successfully demonstrated at Wright Airport in the United States.
1946: France and Laos conclude an agreement establishing a kingdom under French domination.
1952: Israel and West Germany reach agreement in their negotiations on Nazi war crime indemnity. Under the agreement, the West German government will pay 3 billion Reichsmarks in 12 years to compensate Israeli people for their loss of lives and properties caused by the Nazi regime during World War II.
1962: The International Amateur Athletic Federation issues statement revoking its ratification for Indonesia to hold the Fourth Asian Games following the southeast Asian country's rejection of the Republic of China delegation to the games.
1972: The Taipei Little League baseball team wins the world title.
1977: The ROC's Lih Teh Little League baseball team wins the world title. Both Senior League and Big League baseball teams from Taiwan also won the 1977 world titles in earlier competitions.
1979: Lord Louis Mountbatten, former admiral and viceroy of India, is murdered by a bomb planted by the Irish Republican Army as he and members of his family enjoy an outing on his 30-ft. fishing boat off Mullaghmore, County Sligo in the Irish Republic. He was 79.
1986: The ROC Ministry of Finance decides to lower the highest tariff rate to 57.5 percent and reduce duty rates on products with high import tariffs but limited import volume.
1987: A 13-year-old Chinese girl who was left to live with a family of pigs returns to normal life after three years of special training.
1991: Moldova declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1995: Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization sign an agreement in Cairo to expand Palestinian autonomy from Gaza to the West Bank.
1999: Actress-singer Bai Guang dies at her home in Kuala Lumpur at the age of 79.
2003: A three-day six-nation meeting on North Korean nuclear weapon program opens in Beijing.
2004: Taekwondo athlete Chen Shi-hsin wins the ROC's first-ever Olympic gold medal in the Athens Olympic Games.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The power of spiritual forces in the Universe -- how active it is everywhere! Invisible to the eye and impalpable to the sense, it is inherent in all things, and nothing can escape its operation."
