DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutor to seek help in Singapore in money-laundering probe

TEXT.P: A local prosecutor departed Wednesday for Singapore to seek assistance in Taiwan's ongoing investigation into a case of suspected money laundering involving former President Chen Shui-bian and his family.

Ching Chi-jen, head prosecutor of the Taipei District Prosecutors Office, who is scheduled to attend the 13th annual conference of the International Association of Prosecutors Aug. 27-31 in the city state, is expected to request Singaporean authorities to help look into the bank accounts in Singapore created under the names of members of the former first family.

The former president's daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching and his wife's elder brother Wu Ching-mao -- two nominal holders of the former family's overseas bank accounts -- as well as his son Chen Chih-chung -- an authorized proxy on the accounts -- have all refused to sign authorization letters allowing prosecutors to scrutinize the accounts.

Ching told the media shortly before her departure that while it will help speed up the collection of evidence if the prosecutors are authorized by the holders to check the accounts, evidence obtained through international judicial assistance will be more comprehensive although it may take longer.
Ching had traveled to Switzerland before on Aug. 12 for a similar purpose.

Taiwan authorities were informed in January by the international anti-money laundering organization Egmont Group that members of the former first family had created a number of bank accounts in other countries, including the United States, the Cayman Islands, Singapore and Switzerland.
In July, Taiwan further received a request by Swiss authorities for assistance in probing alleged money laundering by Chen Chih-chung and Huang Jui-ching in Switzerland.

Suspecting that the money wired overseas could be connected to the "state affairs fund" embezzlement case implicating the former president and his wife Wu Shu-jen, prosecutors last week listed Chen Shui-bian, Wu Shu-jen, Chen Chih- chung, Huang Jui-ching and Wu Ching-mao as suspects in the case of alleged money laundering.

However, Wu Shu-jen, said to be the manager of the family's finances, claimed that the US$21 million deposited overseas had been obtained legally from four sources -- surplus of political contributions for the campaigns of her husband, her husband's practice as a lawyer before he went into politics, her own dowry and her investments.

Wu's statement was consistent with that of Chen Shui-bian, who openly confessed Aug. 14 that he did not honestly account for his election campaign expenses and that his wife had wired surplus funds from the election campaign contributions into overseas bank accounts.
Chen claimed that all the surplus funds were handled by his wife and that he had no idea until early this year that his wife had wired the funds abroad.

The former president denied the money had any connection with the "state affairs fund" case, in which the former first lady was charged with corruption and forgery in November 2006 for using receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.
Chen, who had immunity from prosecution while in office, was named as a co- offender in the case and was probed as soon as he stepped down from the presidency May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-aides subpoenaed in former president corruption scandal

TEXT.P: Three close aides of former President Chen Shui-bian who were involved in handling Chen's campaign funds between 2000-2008 were subpoenaed Wednesday for questioning.

The three former Presidential Office staff members -- Chen Chen-hui, head cashier; Ma Yung-cheng, deputy secretary general; and Kuo Wen-ping, a secretary -- were summoned for questioning regarding the flow of Chen's campaign funds and the first couple's suspected embezzlement of "special state affairs funds" budgeted for Chen's discretionary use as president, the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office said.
The trio was still being questioned as witnesses as of press time.

The prosecutors also subpoenaed other people closely related to Chen over the past several days for questioning after Chen and his wife, Wu Shu-jen, their son Chen Chih-chung, daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching, and Wu's elder brother Wu Ching-mao were listed as suspects and banned from leaving the country in a case of suspected overseas money laundering.

The others who had been summoned for questioning included Huang Fang-yen, Wu's confidant and deputy superintendent of the Shin Kong Wu Ho Su Memorial Hospital; Chiou I-jen, former National Security Council secretary general; and Huang Wei- sheng, chairman of the Bian Mao Factory and a big donor to Chen's campaigns.

During questioning by prosecutors last Friday, the former first lady said the US$21 million in overseas bank accounts under the name of her elder brother and daughter-in-law was surplus funds from political contributions for the campaigns of her husband in two mayoral elections and two presidential elections from 1993 to 2004.
During questioning Monday, Chen's daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching said that she was used as a "figurehead" by her mother-in-law to open bank accounts overseas to facilitate cash deposits.

Meanwhile, Chu Chao-liang, spokesman for the Special Investigation Division, confirmed Wednesday that the Supreme Prosecutors Office has received a tip-off by Chang Chi-ming, chairman of Taipei's Pacific Life Co., accusing that Far Eastern Group Chairman Douglas Hsu had donated some US$10 million to Chen in 2004 to gain help in an attempt to acquire the store.
The donation was remitted to Chen's overseas bank accounts held under the names of "figureheads," according to Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumer confidence index down slightly for August: RCTED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer confidence index for August registered a slight decline over the previous month's level, according to the results of the latest survey by National Central University's Research Center for Taiwan Economic Development (RCTED) released Wednesday.

The index slid by 0.24 points to stand at 55.84, with four of the six sub- indices, which reflect consumers' expectations of economic conditions over the next six months, showing declines, the center said.

The steepest drop was in the category of "whether it would be a good time to buy durable goods over the next half year," which fell 1.5 points to stand at 97.65, followed by "family economic conditions," down 0.25 points to 45.7,"domestic economic conditions," dropping 0.15 points to 44.85, and "job opportunities" over the next six months, also down 0.15 points to stand at 68.7.
In the survey, a score of between 0-100 for a sub-index is classified as "pessimistic," while a score of 100-200 is considered "optimistic," according to the center.

Two of the sub-indices registered increases over the previous month's levels, with the "price levels" category up 0.45 percent to reach 20.25, and "whether the next six months would be a good time to buy stocks" sub-index rising 0.2 points to stand at 57.9, the center said.

The survey was conducted by telephone on randomly selected adults aged 20 and over between Aug. 19-22, with a total of 2,402 valid samples being collected. The survey has a confidence level of plus or minus 2 percentage points 19 times out of 20, according to the center.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1/3 of executives hope to live overseas after retirement: poll

TEXT.P: About 33 percent of business executives hope to live overseas after they retire, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday by the Internet-based 1111 Job Bank.
Shanghai, China was the top retirement city among this group, followed by Sydney, Toronto, Geneva and Los Angeles, in that order, according to 1111 Job Bank.
However, 66.8 percent of business executives with an annual salary in excess of NT$810,000 (US$26,130) said in the survey that would choose to remain in Taiwan after retirement, the 1111 poll found.

Of this group, 16.67 percent said they would rather live in the capital Taipei located in northern Taiwan, followed by Taichung in central Taiwan (11.9 percent) and Hualien on the east coast (11.31 percent), according to the survey.
The respondents listed "good quality of living, " "convenient medicare, " and "low crime rate" as the top three factors that would inform their choice of a retirement location.
As for what the conditions they would least like to face during retirment, the executives surveyed cited "illness," "loneliness, "and "aimlessness," in that order.

On the question of what activities they thought would best contribute to a fulfilling retirement, 45.7 percent of the respondents said leading a life of full of leisure and healthy activities; 38.6 said volunteering to help people in need; 32 percent said living in the countryside, 29 percent said staying close to their family and 26 percent said traveling around the world.
"A total of 21.67 percent of the respondents said they would choose to continue working and never retire if possible, " the pollsters reported.

Of those who would prefer not to retire, 49.9 percent said they would like to work as corporate consultants after they reach retirement age, 32 percent said they hope to create their own businesses, and 26.6 percent said they would like to lecture young people in the business sector, the survey found.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for September rose 138 points to close at 7,082, with 65,941 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October gained 137 points to finish at 7,062, with 410 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 136 points to close at 7,053, with 45 contract transactions.
March futures increased 147 points to finish at 7,040, with 16 contract transactions, while June futures advanced 150 points to close at 7,044, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,944 for September, 6,925 for October, 6,917 for December, 6,893 for March and 6,894 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 116.37 points to finish at 7,080.97, on turnover of NT$94.53 billion (US$3 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

September TE futures rose 6.7 points to close at 291.1, with 3,777 contracts traded, while October TE futures increased 6.15 points to finish at 289.15, with 28 contract transactions. December TE futures gained 6.2 points to finish at 287.2, with six contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

September TF futures moved up 20.2 points to close at 863, with 2,768 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures advanced 20 points to finish at 860.2, with 65 contracts traded. December TF futures rose 22 points to end at 861.2, with two contracts traded, while June TF futures were up 7.2 points to close at 860, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 116.37 points, or 1.67 percent, to close at 7,080.97.

Rebounding from losses the previous day, the local bourse opened at 6,950.88 and fluctuated between 7,106.64 and 6,929.87. A total of 3.43 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$94.53 billion (US$3 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares and construction issues both moving up the most at 2.2 percent. Foodstuff issues advanced 2 percent, banking and financial shares rose 1.7 percent, paper and pulp issues gained 0.8 percent, plastics and chemicals shares were up 0.7 percent, and cement stocks grew 0.6 percent.
One other major stock category lost ground, as textile stocks moved down 0.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,624 to 441, with 417 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net buyer of shares worth NT$8.01 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Polish students conclude Chinese language study in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Twenty-four Polish students who concluded a month-long Chinese-language study camp at I-Shou University in the southern county of Kaohsiung Wednesday said that day that they hope to return to Taiwan.

The study camp, organized by the university's Chinese Language Center and Polish teachers tasked with promoting Chinese culture in their country, offered a wide variety of courses, including Chinese language, Chinese festivals, Chinese calligraphy, divination, seal-carving, Chinese diet, golf, appreciation of classical Chinese string music, qigong, Chinese opera, Chinese tea art and meditation.
The students expressed particular interest in the art of carving personal seals and curiosity about local folk practices such as burning incense to the gods.

Magdalena Senderowska, who studies at the Warsaw University of Economics, said that when she watched Taiwanese people praying to their gods, it seemed to her that it was a very good method of relieving stress.
"The dazzling sunlight and clean shining sand beaches at Kenting in the southernmost county of Pingtung were also unforgettable," she added.

Meanwhile, Margaret Wawrzak, a student at the same university, expressed her love for Taiwan's art and culture, and was especially complimentary when describing the aroma and flavor of Taiwan's renowned high mountain tea.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, decreasing NT$0.008 to close at NT$31.481.
A total of US$1.164 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.479 and fluctuated between NT$31.470 and NT$31.543.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public invited to collect clams at lagoon in Tainan

TEXT.P: Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih invited the public to collect clams this weekend at the Chiku Lagoon, Taiwan's largest, on the last two days of the county's annual tourism and ecology promotion activity.
The county government extended the activity, which was supposed to take place every weekend from July 26-Aug. 7, because it proved far more popular than originally predicted, Su said.

The activity, which began in 1997, is aimed at introducing the lagoon's diverse ecological resources to the public in the hope of drawing more support for the county government's efforts to preserve the wetland area.

The lagoon is bounded by four offshore sandbanks that are habitats for many wetland species such as crabs, oysters, clams, shrimps and fish. The lagoon is also known for being the winter habitat of the migratory black-faced spoonbill.
Su said the public can be ferried on bamboo rafts to the sandbanks, where they can wade in the shallow water and collect clams.
While there, they will have great opportunities to observe all kinds of flora and fauna, and can also enjoy water activities such as pedal boating, canoeing and riding banana boats, Su said.
Su also said the county government plans to set up a tourist service center at the lagoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Missing Taiwanese fishing boat found, but not captain

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese fishing boat that has been out of contact for more than a week has been found, but only the eight Indonesian crew members were on board, not the skipper, a foreign ministry official said Wednesday.
Authorities in Palau are currently questioning the crew members about the whereabouts of the Taiwanese captain, said Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Henry Chen.
The announcement came after a military vessel sent by Palau, at the request of Taiwan, found the Taiwanese fishing boat, named the Taiyihsiang, earlier in the day.
The ministry asked Palau authorities to help search for the fishing boat after the captain's family members lost contact with the captain on Aug. 19.
The Fisheries Agency later located the boat through a satellite monitoring system and discovered that the boat had been sailing south, apparently heading for Indonesia.
The agency suspected that the captain, Lee Feng-bao, might have lost command of his boat following a mutiny by the Indonesian crewmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA responds to Uni Air cancellation of Kaohsiung-Guangzhou service

TEXT.P: Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Lee Long-wen said Wednesday, in response to Uni Air's decision to cancel charter service on the Kaohsiung-Guangzhou route, that the CAA does not have the authority to tell airlines on which routes they should offer flights.
The Taipei-based carrier said that it has decided to halt its service on the route due to low passenger numbers.

Service on the route began July 4 with the launch of weekend charter flights that same weekend under an accord signed in Beijing between the heads of Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.
Uni Air said that despite the fact that the average passenger load on the Kaohsiung-Guangzhou flights reached about 70 percent, the figure for the return flights was a lowly 40-50 percent.
As a result, based on considerations of operating costs, the airline said it decided to temporarily halt the charter service.
It stressed, however, that it could reopen the service in the future if there is sufficient demand.
On Uni Air's decision, Lee said that the CAA could not force airlines to operate services on specific routes, pointing out that the decision is dependent on market forces.
"Wherever there are passengers, airlines will offer flights," he added.

Since the launch of cross-strait weekend charter services, only one flight per week has been offered on the Kaohsiung-Guangzhou route, with the exception of the second week in July when China Airlines offered one flight.

After the accord between the SEF and ARATS was signed, eight airports in Taiwan, including Taipei's Songshan, Taoyuan International Airport and those in Taichung, Kaohsiung, Hualien and Taitung, were designated to handle the cross-strait charter flights.
However, none of the airlines applied to fly from Kaohsiung International Airport until the last minute when Uni Air stepped in to offer flights between the southern port city and Guangzhou.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor arrives in New York
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 26 (CNA) 08/27/08 18:08:30 (By Hwang Chao-ping and Grace Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin arrived in New York City from Boston Monday for a five-day visit, his first since assuming office in 2006, aimed at exchanging municipal administrative experiences with his New York counterpart.
Hau said he will meet with Mayor Michael Bloomberg and invite him to visit Taipei. If possible, Hau said, he will express interest in having Taipei form sisterhood ties with New York.
During his stay, he will also meet with former Mayor Rudy Giuliani.
Hau will exchange administrative experience with them, as well as survey the city's transport system, public security, urban renewal areas and waterfront parks.

Hau has praised the long-term development of New York's urban renewal projects and has noted Giuliani's efforts in promoting public security on Manhattan's 42nd Street, which he said sets an example for Taipei.

Hau said he believes that environmental protection work in Taipei, which are to be showcased at the 2010 World Expo in Shanghai, will be of valuable reference for Bloomberg, who has put a lot of effort into promoting the reduction of waste gases.
When asked about the possibility of Taipei and New York becoming sister cities, Hau said the two cities have close interactions and that Taipei would like to become one of New York's sister cities.

Hau, who is traveling with a delegation of city government officials and councilors, including Taipei City Deputy Secretary-General Chen Yung-jen, Department of Urban Development Commissioner Ting Yu-chun, Emile C.J. Sheng, head of the city's Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, and city councilor Chiang Nai-shin, will wrap up his trip Aug. 31 and return to Taipei Sept. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan begins preparations for 2012 Olympics in London

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Sports Affairs Council (SAC) has proposed a new preparatory program for the 2012 London Olympics, as part of its 2009 budget plan which was submitted to the Legislative Yuan Wednesday.
The SAC's NT$1 billion (US$31.73 million) proposal came in the wake of what was seen as a disappointing performance by Taiwanese athletes in the recently concluded Beijing Olympics.
Of the total budget planned for the 2012 Olympics preparation program, NT$100 million will be allocated for spending in the first fiscal year, the SAC said.

The SAC proposed spending NT$5.6 billion in 2009 on projects such as increasing the sports population, reinforcing training for athletes, constructing premium sports facilities, and bidding to host international sports events and to join international sports organizations.
The SAC also said it hopes that Taiwanese athletes will achieve inspiring performances in international games, which would mean more medals.

In its proposal, the SAC listed plans to construct 10 sports centers around the country in 2009 in an effort to realize President Ma Ying-jeou's election promise of building 70 sports centers during his four-year tenure that began May 20.

Taiwan won four bronze medals in the Beijing Olympics which ended last Sunday. The achievement did not impress the Taiwan public, which had hoped for at least a repeat of Taiwan's best performance ever in the Olympics when it snagged two gold, two silver and one bronze medals in the 2004 Games.

DOC.HEADLINE: Business conglomerate energy saving service corps established

TEXT.P: A business conglomerate energy saving service corps was established Wednesday under the sponsorship of the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Bureau of Energy.

The core purpose of the group is to help leading manufacturing companies, which are also major energy consumers, save energy and cut carbon dioxide emissions by providing training to staff members in these companies to become "seeded trainers" responsible for promoting these efforts in their companies, said Yeh Hui-ching, director of the Bureau of Energy.

At an inaugural ceremony, representatives of 12 conglomerates -- including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) , Formosa Plastics Group, Yuen Foong Yu Paper Mfg. Group, Lee Chang Yung Chemical, Silconware Precision Industries, Macronix International and Walsin Technology -- vowed to cut energy use by six percent in three years, a volume equivalent to 781,000 kiloliters of oil equivalent (approximately 4.9 million barrels of oil).

"The amount of the energy saved can also be expressed as NT$16.6 billion (US$535 million) saved or a reduction of carbon dioxide emissions by 2.14 million tons that would require trees equivalent to 5,502 Ta-an Forest Parks to absorb," Yeh said.

The 12 participating conglomerates, involving 116 companies, consume almost 76 million barrels of oil a year, constituting about 19.2 percent of all the energy consumed by all industries in Taiwan, or 9.9 percent of all the energy consumed by all sectors in the country, Yeh added.

He stressed that the administration has set goals to reduce the carbon dioxide emissions of Taiwan -- which is currently ranked the 11th major emission country in the world -- to 2008's levels by 2016 and to 2000's levels by 2025.

Meanwhile, Huang Tsung-ching, a manager of the Formosa Plastics Group, who represented all the participating companies to receive a banner from the Bureau of Energy marking the launch of the emission-cutting service corps, said Formosa Plastics began to make similar efforts immediately after the Kyoto Protocol went into effect in February 2005, even though Taiwan was not a signature party nor a United Nations member.

"Formosa Plastics established its own energy saving and emission-cutting task force in 2005 and asked for help from BSI British Standards to facilitate the company's efforts to save water and reduce consumption of carbon-emitting fuels, such as coal, oil and natural gas," Huang said.
"We have even trained 309 seeded specialists to beef up the energy-saving drive," Huang added.

Taking the Sixth Naphtha Cracking Plant run by Formosa Plastics as an example, he said, a total of 708 programs have been put forth in the plant complex, targeted at cutting carbon dioxide emissions by 5.05 million tons.
"So far 435 programs have been implemented, contributing to a reduction of 3.05 million tons of greenhouse gases," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of tourists flying Shanghai-Taiwan route up: China customs
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Aug. 27 (CNA) 08/27/08 18:20:03 (By Chiao Hsing-hua and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: The Shanghai to Taiwan flight route has been the most popular since the launch of weekend charter flights between Taiwan and China in early July, according to Chinese customs statistics released Wednesday.

As of Aug. 25, a total of 6,976 passengers had traveled to destinations in Taiwan from Shanghai Pudong International Airport since the launch of the flight services, according to tallies compiled by the airport's customs officials.

The direct weekend flights were launched July 4 under an accord signed in Beijing by the heads of Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.

Up to Aug. 25, passenger numbers for the year to destinations outside China from the Pudong airport were recorded at over 560,000. Hong Kong was a prime destination because of the the Olympic equestrian event which was held there, with 84,900 passengers flying from Shanghai to Hong Kong, according to the statistics.
Other top destinations were Japan, South Korea and Australia, the tallies showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City Government launches first Taipei shopping festival

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government launched the first Taipei shopping festival slated for Aug. 30 to Oct. 12 in a news conference Wednesday, in an attempt to attract more domestic and international tourists and to revitalize the economy.

The main purpose of theShopping in Taipeifestival is to let the world know that Taipei is the city that can fulfill all your needs and desires in terms of shopping, said Chen Hsiung Wen, commissioner of Taipei City Governments Department of Economic Development, at the news conference.
We hope that this event will stimulate consumption and revitalize the stagnant economy,he added.

Noting that this is the first shopping festival organized by the government, Chen said that Taipei citizens are the first to benefit from the event and the city also hopes to attract consumers from other cities and counties around Taiwan, as well as international tourists.
Taipei has some of the newest and largest department stores in South East Asia along with a variety of other shopping choices, said Liu Chug-chun, chief manager of the Taipei City Office of Commerce.

He added that the Shopping in Taipei festival highlights plenty of incentives to guarantee the most enjoyable shopping experience to everyone, with 2,500 shops offering discounts up to 50 percent, daily lucky draws and an online lottery.

According the Liu, with only the serial number on the shopping receipt, one can participate in all lucky draw activities with prizes totaling NT$20 million (US$ 635,180) including a NT$200,000 camera, NT$500,000 bedding, a NT$700,000 wedding package, and two down payments for a luxury apartment each worth NT$500,000.
Lan Hsin-mei, event spokeswoman and noted television hostess, said that as a shopping-maniac, she can now justify her propensity with the shopping festival.
Taipei has various kinds of different shopping areas to accommodate different needs and this event will provide a wonderful shopping experience without hurting one's pocketbook,Lan said.
Event sponsors, such as Easy Travel and Google, also provide shopping information for people, giving them easy access to all the discount offers and shop locations.

The Shopping in Taipei festival is divided into four themes, each lasting for 10 days -- Aug. 30-Sep. 9 Luxurious Brands and Fashion Week; Sep. 10-Sep. 20 Living and Creativity Week; Sep. 21- Oct. 1 3C Gadgets Week and Oct. 2-Oct. 12 Wedding Week.
Chen said he hopes that with the Shopping in Taipei event, everyone will discover the fashionable, creative, high-tech and romantic aspects of Taipei city.

DOC.HEADLINE: Green light for Taipower nuclear waste dump in Taipei County

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) gave conditional approval Wednesday to the Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) to build an interim dump in Taipei County for spent nuclear fuel rods from the neighboring First Nuclear Power Plant.

An environmental impact assessment panel under the EPA gave the green light on condition that Taipower promises not to make the repository a final disposal site and that the company should "try to purchase" residents' properties near the designated repository.
In addition, a supervisory commission organized by residents can be set up to monitor construction of the repository, according to the panel.
Unsatisfied with the panel's decision, however, residents said they will stage large-scale protests against Taipower.
The First Nuclear Power Plant, located in the county's Shihmen township, has been operational since 1978 and is expected to be decommissioned in 2018.

According to the panel's decision, spent nuclear fuel rods can be stored in the planned repository for maximum of 40 years, after which Taipower will have to relocate the waste to a final disposal site.
As the current waste dump can only store spent fuel from nuclear reactors for 30 years, Taipower must present a construction plan to the EPA for a 0.45-hectare spent fuel rod repository.
Taipower representatives claimed that if the plan is postponed, Taiwan's electricity supply might be affected in the near future, as the spent fuel rod repository will be full by March 2010.
However, local residents questioned Taipower's intention to build in their hometown a repository that will have a lifespan of 50 years.

"If the First Nuclear Power Plant will be decommissioned in 10 years, why not find a permanent disposal site right away? " asked Shihmen township head Liang Yu-hsue, claiming that Taipower might be intending to use the repository as a final dumping site.

According to the Nuclear Materials and Radioactive Waste Management Act, Taipower should have the final disposal facility for its nuclear waste built and in operation by 2055, but the company is still looking for an appropriate location.

Meanwhile, about 500 Taipei County residents protesting outside the EPA building claimed that their health is being threatened by radioactivity and that cancer is more prevalent in their townships than in other parts of the country.
In response, the Taipower representatives argued that an increasing cancer rate is a nationwide phenomenon and that cancer rates in townships near the nuclear plant are no higher than elsewhere.

"The barrels of the type used to store the spent nuclear fuel rods have been used in the United States for over 20 years, and their stability and strength are proven, " Tu Yueh-yuan, chief engineer and Taipower spokesman, told CNA.

Taiwan has three nuclear power plants with a fourth under construction. President Ma Ying-jeou has expressed his support for nuclear energy development in order to reduce Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions while meeting the increasing demand for electricity.

DOC.HEADLINE: 50 more Taiwanese youth volunteers to join overseas service

TEXT.P: Fifty young volunteers who completed a six-week training program at Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) will participate in overseas service using their expertise to help various developing countries, the ICDF announced Wednesday.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco Ou presided over a ceremony to mark the completion of the training program at the Civil Service Development Institute in Taipei in his capacity as chairman of the ICDF.
The 50 volunteers are equipped with different specialties, including the teaching of the Chinese language, physical education, culinary arts, agricultural consultation and environmental protection.

Speaking at the ceremony, Ou said this will be the 13th group dispatched by the government to help developing countries that maintain friendly relations with Taiwan. Ou pointed out that since the overseas volunteer assistance program was created in 1993, Taiwan has sent 320 long-term and short-term volunteer workers with different specialties to help developing countries all over the world.
The foreign minister encouraged the new volunteer group to convey to the world the message that Taiwan is willing to participate in cooperation with the international community.

As for the volunteers themselves, they can also benefit from the overseas service by broadening their horizons, improving their foreign language proficiency and enriching their life experience, Ou said.
The ICDF is a semi-official organization combining government and private-sector resources to carry out Taiwan's international aid programs -- similar to the role of America's USAID.
The fund's overseas assistance covers four areas: investment and lending operations, technical cooperation, international human resource development, and humanitarian assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan arts to be on South American and European stages

TEXT.P: Supported by the Government Information Office (GIO) , two Taiwanese artistic groups will perform in Europe and South America, respectively, in the hope of enhancing cultural exchanges and expanding diplomatic space, said GIO Minister Vanessa Yea-ping Shih Wednesday.

"Taiwan has always been proud of its democratic and economic achievements, but another precious asset of the country, Taiwan's beautiful culture and art, is often neglected," said Shih at a press conference.
The two groups are the Taiyuan Puppet Theater Company and the Formosa Aboriginal Song and Dance Troupe.
Chen Xi-huang, the 78 year-old performer of the Taiyuan Puppet Theater Company, has performed in foreign countries for more than 20 years, said Wu Shan-shan, the company's director-general of art.
"Overcoming linguistic barriers, master Chen has successfully helped foreigners appreciate the beauty of Taiwan's puppet theater through rhythm and various actions," she said.

The Formosa Aboriginal Song and Dance Troupe, founded in 1991, is composed of young indigenous people from different tribes in Taiwan. Its past performance in the United States won favorable comments from the New York Times, which paid high tribute to the "authority, simplicity, and radiant humanity" emitted by the performers.

According to the GIO, the Taiyuan Puppet Theater Company will perform in Europe from late September to late October, appearing in France, Hungary, Germany and the Czech Republic, while the indigenous troupe will leave for the South America in early September for cultural exchanges with local indigenous people in Nicaragua, Guatemala, Peru and the Dominican Republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait negotiations needed on landing visas issue: SEF

TEXT.P: It would take cross-strait negotiations to facilitate the implementation of Taiwan's granting landing visas or multiple entry visas to Chinese visitors to Kinmen, an official of the intermediary body Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Wednesday.

SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Kao Koong-lien said it would be difficult for Taiwan to realize the landing visa treatment by unilaterally planning for it because it "takes two to tango, " meaning that if China does not work actively on the matter, the plan would only be a plan.

Kao said the SEF has talked with its Chinese counterpart, the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), on expanded application of the "mini three links" -- direct postal, trade and transport links between Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the cities of Xiamen and Fuzhou in China's Fujian Province -- but had been told by ARATS that "currently it is difficult for China to implement it."

Kao said as far as he knows, potential Chinese tourists to Taiwan need to apply for an entry permit from Taiwan's National Immigration Agency first, before approching Chinese authorities to apply for travel documents to Taiwan.
"It takes three to five days for the Chinese tourists to obtain a Taiwan entry permit, but it takes one to two weeks for them to obtain approval from Chinese authorities," Kao noted.
"There will be a long way to go for Chinese tourists to be issued landing visas to visit Kinmen if the Chinese side does not do something positive quickly," Kao asserted.

President Ma said in a speech delivered in Kinmen Sunday that to accelerate Kinmen's economic development and facilitate Chinese tourists' traveling to Kinmen, his administration is planning to offer landing visas or multiple entry visas to Chinese visitors to Kinmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interior Ministry holds anti-human trafficking seminar

TEXT.P: The Interior Ministry opened a two-day international anti-human trafficking seminar Wednesday with the goal of consolidating a campaign against human trafficking by establishing a comprehensive government system.

"Anti-human trafficking is not only work that takes long term efforts but is also a challenge that requires international cooperation and attention, " said Deputy Interior Minister Chien Tai-lang, who is also acting director-general of the National Immigration Agency.

He made the remarks in his opening speech at the seminar, titled the "2008 Anti- Human Trafficking International Workshop, " which took place at the National Taiwan University Hospital International Convention Center in Taipei.

Noting that Taiwan has been listed as a Tier 2 country for the second straight year by the United States in its annual anti-human trafficking report, Chien said the ministry has completed a draft proposal on anti-human trafficking to be submitted to the Executive Yuan at the end of August and that it is expected to be enacted by the Legislative Yuan in its next session.

He added that the government is determined to fight human trafficking, evidenced by the "anti-human trafficking project" launched by the Executive Yuan in November 2006, an inter-governmental agency task force on anti-human trafficking that was established in 2007, and a chapter on anti-human trafficking that was added to the immigration law.
"I hope that Taiwan will be upgraded to a Tier 1 country because of these efforts on anti-human trafficking," Chien said.

The Trafficking in Persons Report 2008 (TIF 2008) , released by the U.S. Department of State June 6, places Taiwan on a list of "Tier 2" countries in terms of human trafficking, the same level it was ranked at last year.

The TIF 2008 describes Taiwan as a destination for men, women and children trafficked for the purposes of forced labor and sexual exploitation. Taiwan is also a source of women trafficked to Japan, Australia, the United Kingdom and the U.S., according to the report.

Participants in the international seminar include officials from the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and Customs Bureau. Among them are Tatum S. King, posted in Hong Kong, Katerina Karousos from Washington, D.C. and Gabriel Gonzalez from Florida.

Other participants are representatives from the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, the Taiwan End Children Prostitution Association, prosecutors from the Ministry of Justice and Sandy Yeh, an associate professor of the Central Police University.

During the two-day seminar, they will exchange views on how to effectively tackle human trafficking and drug trafficking and Yeh, representing non- government organizations, will present an essay titled "The State of Taiwan's Anti-human Trafficking and the Role of NGOs."

DOC.HEADLINE: Child sexual abuse more prevalent than thought

TEXT.P: The problem of child sexual abuse may be more prevalent than the public realizes, with the actual number of victims estimated at approximately 20,000 per year, although only around 3,000 cases are reported, the non-profit Garden of Hope Foundation said Wednesday.

The estimate is based on the belief that sexual abuse cases tend to be under- reported at a ratio of seven to one, said Chi Hui-jung, CEO of the foundation dedicated to ending sexual abuse, sexual exploitation and domestic violence.
Criminal Investigation Bureau statistics show that police received more than 3,000 reports of sexual assault in 2006 and more than 4,000 reports in 2007, with 59 percent of the victims aged under 18.

However, the number of sexual assaults reported to domestic violence and sexual assault prevention centers around the country are markedly higher, with 4,900 cases reported in 2005, 2,786 of which involved a victim under 18. In 2006, the total number increased to 5,638, of which 3,276 involved minors. The number was even higher in 2007, with 3,727 of the total of 6,530 cases reported involving a minor.

The results of an online survey conducted July 24-29 and released Wednesday by the foundation show that 87 percent of respondents had no idea that a child sexual abuse case could be occurring as frequently as once every 27 minutes in the country.

The survey of 1,075 people aged 16 and older found that 76 percent of the respondents said they would be willing to help sexually abused children, but nearly 50 percent did not know who they can turn to or what services are provided by the authorities.

Approximately 70 percent of the respondents said they would tend not to encourage sexually abused children to ask for help for fear that the children might be hurt a second time in the process, while 50 percent of the respondents said they would be concerned about washing dirty linen in public.
Meanwhile, 35 percent of the respondents expressed doubt as to whether asking the authorities for help would do any good.
According to Chi, neglect of the problem by the public is a major barrier impeding the victims' possible rehabilitation from their trauma.

What makes matters worse is that victims have even less access to assistance in the event of incest, she went on, noting that the number of survey respondents supporting private mediation increased by 40 percent if the abuser is a member of the family.
Chi urged the public to pay attention to the victims' need for professional counseling to help them overcome their trauma and to report cases of possible child sexual abuse to the authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should improve export structure, upgrade economic quality: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew said Wednesday that Taiwan should improve its export structure and upgrade its economic quality if it wants to expand its economy amid a global financial crisis and high consumer prices.
Siew made the remarks while delivering a keynote speech at an economic forum organized by a local think tank, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, earlier in the day.
Siew, a former chairman of the institution, said exports have been the driving force for the country's economic growth over the past years.

Taiwan's economic growth rate was 5.72 percent last year, the highest for the past eight years, he said, adding that exports contributed 3.89 percentage points to the country's economic growth, while domestic demand contributed 1.83 percentage points.
However, a decline in the world economy due to the fallout from the U.S. subprime mortgage crisis and high inflation has also had an impact on Taiwan's economy, Siew observed.
This July, Taiwan's export orders growth rate fell to 5.52 percent from the same period of last year, the lowest since May 2003, when severe acute respiratory syndrome hit Taiwan, he said.
The growth rate in export orders from China also dropped to a new low of 1.73 percent, he continued.
To boost the economy, Taiwan should not rely only on exports by the manufacturing industry but should also focus on enhancing exports of the country's services, he suggested.

For example, he said, Hong Kong underwent an economic transition after it was handed over from Britain to China in 1997, and its economy greatly improved after Hong Kong inked a Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA) with China.
Siew attributed the economic growth mainly to Hong Kong's focus on finance, logistics, tourism and back-up services for industry and commerce.
In addition, Taiwan needs to enhance the quality of its economy by easing regulations, investing in human resources and improving infrastructure, he pointed out.

He added that Taiwan should also encourage private consumption, expand domestic demand and capitalize on trade opportunities derived from the thawing relations between Taiwan and China over the last three months.

Taiwan opened up to greater numbers of Chinese tourists and to weekend direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait July 4 after the Kuomintang (KMT), which favors closer trade ties with China, took the reins of government May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly 2,000 tons of kitchen waste retrieved daily: EPA

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Wednesday that nearly 2,000 tons of kitchen leftovers were picked up daily around the country in the first half of the year.

EPA officials noted that in the first six months, the average daily kitchen leftovers collected reached 1,941 tons, among which, compostable kitchen leftovers accounted for 24 percent, or 450 tons per day.
The officials said that the amount means that the government will be able to shelve plans to construct two more garbage incinerators.
With the good results of the kitchen waste recycling program, the government will continue to help local governments promote the collection of kitchen leftovers, the officials went on.
They touted the merits of recycled kitchen leftovers, pointing out that in addition to serving as animal feed, it can also be turned into organic compost to enrich the soil.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tycoon defends name after being implicated in scandal

TEXT.P: Far Eastern Group (FEG) -- one of Taiwan's largest business groups -- has become embroiled in the high-profile money laundering scandal involving former President Chen Shui-bian and his family after its chairman was accused of bribing the family for business interests, making him one of the alleged donors that allowed the Chens to amass their huge wealth.

On Wednesday, FEG Chairman Douglas Hsu filed a lawsuit against Legislator Chiu Yi of the ruling Kuomintang, political commentator Lee Sheng-feng and four reporters working for Next Magazine, a weekly tabloid, on charges of defamation after they publicly accused him of bribery.
Hsu's lawyer Chiang Ju-jung told reporters that the accusations are false and that their public comments have harmed Hsu's reputation.
In addition to those lawsuits, Chiang said Hsu has also sued Chang Chi-ming, general manager of Pacific Construction Co., for making a "groundless accusation" against him.

Chu Chao-liang, spokesman for the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office, confirmed earlier in the day that the office had received a tip-off by Chang, accusing Hsu of having donating some US$10 million to Chen's wife, Wu Chu-jen, in 2004 in return for help in an FEG attempt to acquire the right to take over a popular department store.

The alleged donation was reportedly remitted to several of the Chen family's overseas bank accounts suspected of containing a huge amount of money connected to Chen's "state affairs fund" embezzlement case.
Chen claimed Aug. 14 that all the money in the bank accounts is surplus funds from election campaign contributions, all of which were handled by his wife.

At a press conference following his filing of the legal actions, Hsu said his move was aimed at defending the FEG's business reputation and the stockholders' interests, as well as protecting his own name.

The FEG, consisting of more than 180 affiliated companies, runs businesses that cover the fields of petrochemicals and energy, textiles, cement and building materials, retail and department stores, financial services, sea and land transport, communications and the Internet, construction, and hotels.

DOC.HEADLINE: President confers medal on Mexican newspaper tycoon

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has conferred a medal on a Mexican newspaper tycoon in recognition of his significant contributions to ties between Taiwan and Mexico, the Presidential Office announced Wednesday.

Ma decorated Mario Vazquez Rana -- president of Sol de Mexico, a leading Mexican newspaper -- with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon during a ceremony at the Presidential Office Tuesday, the Presidential Office said in a statement.

Also present at the ceremony were Vazquez's wife, daughter and a grandson as well as Reynaldo Gonzalez, a member of the International Olympic Committee, and several Taiwan officials, including National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi and Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Hou Ching-shan.
Vazquez expressed gratitude to Ma for the medal, adding that as "one of Taiwan's best friends," he felt greatly honored.
Vazquez also praised Republic of China Representative to Mexico Jaime Chen for his efforts to boost Taiwan-Mexico ties, a Presidential Office officials said.

Afterwards, Ma exchanged views with Vazquez on a wide range of topics -- including Taiwan-Mexico ties, cross-Taiwan Strait ties, Taiwan's international status and the worldwide energy crisis, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitung team wins Red Leaf Cup Little League international tourney

TEXT.P: The 2008 Red Leaf Cup International Little League Baseball Invitational Tournament concluded Wednesday after five days of competition, with the Feng Nian Elementary School team in Taitung City crowned as the champions.

In the final match, the Fuyuan Elementary School team from Ruisui township in Hualien County lost to Feng Nian 2-5 to place second, while the Jung Shiao Elementary School team from Chengkung township in Taitung County defeated a South Korean team from Seongham, a city near Seoul, to win third place.

The tournament, using the single elimination system, took place at four baseball diamonds in the eastern Taiwan county, with 34 teams taking part -- four teams from South Korea, 11 from Taitung County and 19 from eight other Taiwanese cities and counties.

The annual international tournament was founded in 2005 by the Taitung County Sports Development Fund to commemorate the spirit of the Red Leaf (Hongye) Little League team from its namesake elementary school that made history in 1968 by defeating a Little League world champion.

During that match, played in Taipei, the aboriginal schoolboys trounced the Little League world champions -- Japan's Wakayama -- 7A-0, in a nine-inning game. The nationwide excitement the victory aroused turned baseball into Taiwan's national sport and set the stage for Taiwan to win 13 World Little League championships between 1969 and 1982.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity group sets up support center for family caregivers

TEXT.P: A charity organization has set up Taiwan's first support center for family caregivers to provide them with professional psychological counselling and assistance in caregiving.

The Taiwan Association of Family Caregivers made the announcement at a news conference Wednesday in which Wang Tsen-yung, president of the association, said the center will provide counselling in a variety of aspects, including psychological distress, family relations, stress relief, adjustment to lifestyle and emotional disturbance.
All the counselling will be free, with the costs covered by profits of the social welfare lottery, Wang said.
Those who are no longer caregivers are also welcome to use the center's resources, as they might need counselling on how to cope with grief over losing a family member, Wang noted.
Family caregivers are classified as people who take care of mentally or physically disabled or senior family members who cannot take care of themselves anymore.
According to the association's statistics, Taiwan has about 580,000 people in need of family caregiving, including 180,000 senior citizens and 400,000 mentally or physically disabled people.

Wang said the traditional view of Taiwanese society takes responsibility for taking care of disabled family members for granted but too often neglects family caregivers' stress and the difficulties they face adjusting to their lives as caregivers.

Citing association statistics, Wang said 78 family caregivers have committed suicide in the past two years and that 47 percent of them did so due to psychological problems, while 31 percent killed themselves due to declining health, Wang said.

Many domestic and foreign studies have shown that family caregivers have their health and psychological condition undermined by their caregiving, and that most of them suffer nervous breakdowns, Wang said, adding that local research shows that 65 percent of caregivers have a tendency toward depression.

Research conducted by the association last year found that 30 percent of the respondents expressed the need for professional psychological counseling, while 26.7 percent just wanted somebody to listen to them.
An association executive called on family caregivers not to bear their burden alone and to call 0800-580-097 to reach the center for assistance.
They can also visit the center on Chang An East Road in Taipei City to talk with social workers or listen to music and relax a little, the executive said.
The public should also give more care and support to those who take care of disabled family members, the executive added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier welcomes LCD maker's huge investment in central Taiwan

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan Wednesday welcomed a massive investment plan by AU Optronics Corp., the world's third-largest maker of liquid-crystal displays (LCDs), to build four panel display plants in central Taiwan over the next 10 years.

Liu welcomed the company's response to the government's i-Taiwan 12 infrastructure projects that are partly aimed at forming a new cluster of high- tech industries in central Taiwan, to bring the area into better balance with northern and southern Taiwan.
Liu made the remarks in a statement issued after he had a one-hour meeting with AU Optronics Chairman K.Y. Lee.

The company plans to earmark NT$400 billion ($12.7 billion) over the next decade to construct the plants in the central county of Changhua branch of the Central Taiwan Science Park, the statement said.
Construction of the first plant is slated to begin in the second half of next year and to begin operations in 2011 or 2012, according to the statement.
AU Optronics will employ more than 10,000 workers by the time the plants are finished, the statement read.
AU Optronics' investment plan follows a major investment plan recently unveiled by Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., the world's largest contract maker of consumer electronics.
After a meeting with the premier early this month, Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Guo promised to expand the operations and R&D of the company's headquarters in Taiwan.
He also vowed to create 30,000 jobs and to invest more than NT$100 billion to build a town featuring high-tech and eco-friendly life.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA sees goodwill from China despite opposition to U.N. bid

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday that it sees some goodwill from China in a letter from Beijing to the U.N. secretary-general regarding Taiwan's latest proposal for participation in the world body, despite the fact that Beijing's basic stance of opposing Taiwan's bid remains unchanged.
"We are not too surprised by China's opposition, as its basic stance is the same as before," MOFA spokesman Henry Chen told CNA.
"But some goodwill can be seen, given the fact that China has said things it has not mentioned before," he said.

The U.N. posted Taiwan's proposal to participate in the world body along with a letter written by Wang Guangya, U.N. permanent representative of the People's Republic of China, on the Web site of the U.N. Journal, to be circulated among member states.

In the letter dated Aug. 18, Wang noted that relations between Taiwan and China have shown "a good momentum of improvement and development" since March, thanks to the concerted efforts of both sides of the Taiwan Strait, and that both sides should continue to work on further peaceful development.

"Under the new circumstances, we will firmly adhere to the theme of peaceful development in cross-strait relations, and will continue to enhance our exchanges and cooperation in all areas," Wang said.

Admitting that there are still some outstanding questions left over from history and that some of them are "hard nuts to crack for the time being, " Wang contended that both Taipei and Beijing "will make joint efforts under the one China principle toward the establishment of a framework for peaceful development of cross-strait relations and strive for new prospects in the relationship."

"We are fully confident that so long as the two sides work together in a spirit of `building mutual trust, putting aside differences, seeking common ground and striving for a win-win result, ' we will surely be able to create conditions and find an appropriate solution through consultation," he said.

However, Wang told the U.N. that by raising the so-called proposal on "Taiwan's participation in the activities of U.N. specialized agencies," Nauru, the Gambia and a few other countries that submitted the proposal on Taiwan's behalf, intend to create "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan," which is firmly opposed by the Chinese government and people because the U.N. and its specialized agencies are intergovernmental organizations composed only of sovereign states and as a part of China, Taiwan is not a sovereign state.

He stated that as "an internal affair of the Chinese people," the participation of Taiwan in international activities should be resolved through consultation "by the Chinese people across the Taiwan Strait."

In response to Wang's letter, the MOFA released a statement reiterating that the basic rights of the people of the Republic of China to participate in international organizations and activities should be respected.

"The ministry thinks Taiwan's participation in the international community will have positive effects on the consolidation of the peaceful development of cross- strait relations, " the press release said.

The Foreign Ministry disagreed with Wang, who claimed in his letter that Taiwan has "unfettered access" to the health and medical information of the World Health Organization (WHO) , as Beijing has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the WHO Secretariat.

"Under the terms of the MOU, Taiwan still cannot fully participate in WHO conferences and activities, nor can it have direct contact and interaction with the WHO, which leaves a gap between the reality and our expectations," the statement said.

Taiwan renewed its bid to enter the U.N. Aug. 14 by submitting a proposal to the U.N. Secretariat through its allies calling for the world body to reconsider at the Sept. 16 U.N. General Assembly the feasibility of Taiwan's meaningful participation in U.N. specialized agencies.

In an interview with CNA Tuesday, Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said that the more moderate and pragmatic approach has received a very good response from the international community and that he believes the bid will win more support during the U.N. General Assembly.

A senior Western diplomat in Taipei told CNA recently that he found Taiwan's U.N. proposal to be "well thought-out" and "cleverly worded, " fully reflecting the expectations of the international community and Taiwan's domestic situation.

Since 1993, Taiwan's allies have been trying to put the issue of Taiwan's participation on the agenda of the U.N. General Assembly on Taiwan's behalf, but Beijing's argument that Taiwan is part of China has always prevailed.

DOC.HEADLINE: President hopes to visit St. Vincent and the Grenadines

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed hope Wednesday that he will be able to visit the Caribbean nation of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines to boost relations between the two countries.
Ma made the remarks during a meeting with Luis Straker, deputy prime minister and foreign minister of the Caribbean ally, at the Presidential Office.

Taiwan and Saint Vincent have enjoyed diplomatic ties for more than 20 years, Ma noted, expressing hope that Starker's visit will create more cooperation opportunities for the two countries and further improve bilateral ties.

Starker, along with Glen Beached, Saint Vincent's tourism minister, also met with Premier Liu Chao-shiuan that same day. Liu said the two countries not only will strengthen relations but should also have more exchanges, especially in the areas of tourism and education.

Education played a crucial part in Taiwan's transformation to a technology- oriented country from an agrarian one, Liu said, adding that education is worthy of investment, although its effects might not be immediately apparent.
He said the two countries should discuss cooperation in the two fields for the benefit of both sides.
Starker and Beached arrived in Taiwan a day earlier for a six-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's economic growth suffers worst slowdown since 2003

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy went into recession in July, with the monitor score dropping to 15, the lowest since June 2003, when the country was hit by an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, according to a report released Wednesday by the Council for Economic Development and Planning (CEPD).

Economic indicators flashed a blue light signalling recession in July for the first time since January 2007, while the composite index of leading indicators -- a barometer for the economic outlook in the coming three months -- stood at 107.4, marking the ninth consecutive monthly drop, the report shows.
Meanwhile, the composite index of coincident indicators, which reflects the current economic situation, stood at 109.6, registering a drop of 0.7 percent from the previous month.

At a press conference, Hung Jui-bin, director-general of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, attributed the recession to a variety of factors, including the fact that the increased opening to Chinese tourists has attracted far fewer visitors than expected, while domestic consumption has remained stagnant as a result of the global economic slowdown.
Hung admitted that Taiwan is in a challenging economic situation, with rising commodity prices, dropping real incomes and weak domestic investment.

However, the government's new measures aimed at boosting domestic demand are expected to see good results by September, Hung said, noting that if the measures work as well as hoped in pumping up civic investment in the fourth quarter, the government will respond to the investment with necessary assistance to help economic growth recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Elderly veterans mark 60th anniversary of 1958 shelling of Kinmen

TEXT.P: A group of 660 elderly veterans from Taiwan who endured the bombardment of the island of Kinmen by China in 1958, returned to their old battlefields Wednesday to reminisce about their experiences during the shelling and to honor those who perished in the battle.

The veterans, most of whom are in their 70s, arrived at the harbor in Liaolo Bay aboard a naval supply ship from the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung. They were originally scheduled to arrive in Kinmen Aug. 23 -- the anniversary of the start of the bombardment -- but the trip was delayed because of rough seas.

After receiving a warm welcome from their hosts, the military leaders and soldiers of the Kinmen Defense Command, the veterans took part in a ceremony to pay their respects to the war dead by laying wreaths at a public cemetery on Dawu Mountain.

Upon seeing that the island has evolved from a former battlefield into a peaceful park, some of the veterans expressed hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will learn from history and never engage in war again.
Kinmen is controlled and governed by Taiwan, although it lies closer to China's Fujian Province than it does to Taiwan.
The 1958 artillery battle went on for 44 days, during which China tried but failed to pound the small island into submission with 475,000 shells -- about 3,100 for every square kilometer of land.
The bombardment resulted in some 3,000 civilian and 1,000 military causalities. The army on Kinmen countered by firing back 128,000 shells into China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Inattention prevalent among local office workers: poll

TEXT.P: Inattentiveness is more prevalent among local office workers than may have previously been imagined, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.

The online survey was conducted by a chewing gum company and 104 Job Bank from Aug. 1-4 to explore local office workers' ability to concentrate on their work. A total of 1,236 valid samples were collected, with a 95 percent confidence level and a margin of error of 2.78 percent.
The survey results show that 94 percent of the respondents confessed that they were not attentive enough or did not concentrate enough while at work.

Up to 78 percent said they were in good spirits for less than six hours during each work day, while 33 percent said they could concentrate for less than four hours at a time and around 44 percent said they were most prone to negligence after lunch.

The lack of concentration takes its toll on the quality of work produced, with 86 percent of the respondents saying they have made mistakes because of inattentiveness or lack of concentration, according to the survey.

The most common errors cited in the poll were forgetting their bosses' directives, failing to complete their day's work, dozing, inability to concentrate during meetings and keying in incorrect figures, in that order.
In the survey, more than 90 percent of corporte management staff said workers' ability to concentrate on their work is a key factor in evaluation of their work performance.
Up to 88 percent of those surveyed said they believe that concentration will boost work efficiency, and 63 percent said attentiveness will enable them to better deal with their work.

The survey further found that local office workers have many means to enhance their concentration, including massage, exercise, stretching, doing only one thing at a time, drinking tea or coffee, taking naps, chewing gum and listening to music.

An expert involved in the survey suggested that if an individual experiences difficulty concentrating over the longer term, the person should consider the possibility that it might be caused by a medical condition and that they should seek professional advice and treatment.

According to a study by the International Institute for Management Development in Lausanne, Switzerland, each Taiwanese white-collar worker works up to 2,256 hours per year, or an average of nine hours each day, making it the world's fifth longest.
Analyzing the survey results, a 104 Job Bank manager said the long work hours of local officer workers might be related with their inability to concentrate on their work. NDITEM/J

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 28, 2008

TEXT.P: 2. Event: President Ma Ying-jeou receiving John Perry, head of a pro-Taiwan group in the Irish Parliament. Date and Time: 04:30 p.m., Thursday, Aug.28, 2008. Place: Presidential Office, No.122, Chongqing S. Road, Sec.1, Taipei City. Press contact: Tel. 2311-3731. 3. Event: Opening of Art Taipei 2008 exhibition. Date and Time:06:40 p.m., Thursday, Aug. 28, 2008. Place: Taipei World Trade Center No. Exhibition Hall, No. 5, Xinyi Road, Sec. 5, Taipei City. Host and/or main speakers: Vice President Vincent Siew. Press Contact: Tel. 2311-3731.
Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open marginally higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened marginally higher Thursday.

The weighted price index was up 9.35 points at 7,090.32 on a turnover of NT$2.45 billion (US$77.82 million) at the open. The index gained 116.37 points, or 1.67 percent, to close at 7,080.97 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Thursday.
The greenback was trading at NT$31.486 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.005 from Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former chief of Investigation Bureau indicted

TEXT.P: Yeh Sheng-mao, former chief of the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice, was indicted for withholding information about ex-president Chen Shui- bian's alleged involvement in money laundering, local cable television SET reported Thursday.
SET said prosecutors are seeking jail term of two years and six months for him.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier welcomes LCD maker's huge investment in central Taiwan

"Under the terms of the MOU, Taiwan still cannot fully participate in WHO conferences and activities, nor can it have direct contact and interaction with the WHO, which leaves a gap between the reality and our expectations," the statement said.

Taiwan renewed its bid to enter the U.N. Aug. 14 by submitting a proposal to the U.N. Secretariat through its allies calling for the world body to reconsider at the Sept. 16 U.N. General Assembly the feasibility of Taiwan's meaningful participation in U.N. specialized agencies.

In an interview with CNA Tuesday, Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou said that the more moderate and pragmatic approach has received a very good response from the international community and that he believes the bid will win more support during the U.N. General Assembly.

A senior Western diplomat in Taipei told CNA recently that he found Taiwan's U.N. proposal to be "well thought-out" and "cleverly worded, " fully reflecting the expectations of the international community and Taiwan's domestic situation.

Since 1993, Taiwan's allies have been trying to put the issue of Taiwan's participation on the agenda of the U.N. General Assembly on Taiwan's behalf, but Beijing's argument that Taiwan is part of China has always prevailed.

DOC.HEADLINE: President hopes to visit St. Vincent and the Grenadines

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed hope Wednesday that he will be able to visit the Caribbean nation of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines to boost relations between the two countries.
Ma made the remarks during a meeting with Luis Straker, deputy prime minister and foreign minister of the Caribbean ally, at the Presidential Office.

Taiwan and Saint Vincent have enjoyed diplomatic ties for more than 20 years, Ma noted, expressing hope that Starker's visit will create more cooperation opportunities for the two countries and further improve bilateral ties.

Starker, along with Glen Beached, Saint Vincent's tourism minister, also met with Premier Liu Chao-shiuan that same day. Liu said the two countries not only will strengthen relations but should also have more exchanges, especially in the areas of tourism and education.

Education played a crucial part in Taiwan's transformation to a technology- oriented country from an agrarian one, Liu said, adding that education is worthy of investment, although its effects might not be immediately apparent.
He said the two countries should discuss cooperation in the two fields for the benefit of both sides.
Starker and Beached arrived in Taiwan a day earlier for a six-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's economic growth suffers worst slowdown since 2003

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy went into recession in July, with the monitor score dropping to 15, the lowest since June 2003, when the country was hit by an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, according to a report released Wednesday by the Council for Economic Development and Planning (CEPD).

Economic indicators flashed a blue light signalling recession in July for the first time since January 2007, while the composite index of leading indicators -- a barometer for the economic outlook in the coming three months -- stood at 107.4, marking the ninth consecutive monthly drop, the report shows.
Meanwhile, the composite index of coincident indicators, which reflects the current economic situation, stood at 109.6, registering a drop of 0.7 percent from the previous month.

At a press conference, Hung Jui-bin, director-general of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, attributed the recession to a variety of factors, including the fact that the increased opening to Chinese tourists has attracted far fewer visitors than expected, while domestic consumption has remained stagnant as a result of the global economic slowdown.
Hung admitted that Taiwan is in a challenging economic situation, with rising commodity prices, dropping real incomes and weak domestic investment.

However, the government's new measures aimed at boosting domestic demand are expected to see good results by September, Hung said, noting that if the measures work as well as hoped in pumping up civic investment in the fourth quarter, the government will respond to the investment with necessary assistance to help economic growth recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 28, or the 28th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: The Scots defeat royalist English forces at the Battle of Newburn, near Newcastle.
1774: Elizabeth Ann Seton, American educator and religious leader who founded the Sisters of St. Joseph, is born. She was canonized as the first US-born saint in 1975.
1828: Lev Nikolayevich Tolstoy, also known as Count Leo Tolstoi, Russian writer and philosopher, is born. His great novels "War and Peace" and "Anna Karenina" offer extraordinary detail and profound psychological insights. His later theories of ethics and morality recommended non-participation in and passive resistance to evil.
1830: Peter Cooper, American inventor who built the first American locomotive, displays his latest creation, a steam-driven locomotive called Tom Thumb.
1849: Venice surrenders to the Australians, having been under siege since July 20 after proclaiming independence from Austrian rule.
1884: Peter Fraser, prime minister of New Zealand from 1940 to 1949 , is born in Scotland.
1910: Montenegro proclaims independence from the Ottoman empire.
1916: Germany declares war on Romania.
1919, Sir Godfrey Hounsfield, British inventor of the EMI medical scanner, is born. He was winner of the Nobel Prize for Psychology in 1979.
1927: The Eighth Far East Games is held in Shanghai.
1929: The Kuomintang (KMT) branch in Shanghai asks the Nanking government to punish Professor Hu Shih, a former student of John Dewey, for publishing an article criticizing Dr. Sun Yat-sen and the KMT.
1931: The Mexican government orders all ethnic Chinese to leave Mexico before Sept. 2.
1945: Mao Tse-tung, accompanied by US Ambassador Patrick Hurley, arrives in Chungking from Yenan to hold a meeting with the KMT to discuss such issues as national unity.
1963: US civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his "I have a dream" speech to some 200,000 people after an interracial march on Washington, a peaceful demonstration in favor of furthering the cause of civil rights.
1973: Princess Anne arrives in Kiev for an equestrian event, becoming the first member of the British royal family to visit the Soviet Union.
1974: The Republic of China and Thailand conclude a maize trade agreement.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Bolivian Vice Foreign Minister Hernando Garcia Vespa and his wife.
1980: Premier Y.S. Sun leaves for Costa Rica, Panama and the Dominican Republic for official visits.
1983: Menachem Begin resigns as prime minister of Israel.
1988: Three jet planes belonging to an Italian Air Force aeronautics display team collide during an exhibition in front of a crowd of 300,000 at the US Air Force base at Ramstein in West Germany, killing 47 people and injuring some 500 others.
1990: Iraq declares Kuwait the 19th province of Iraq.
1993: Ong Teng Cheong, chairman of the ruling People's Action Party, is elected president of Singapore.
1996: El Salvador President Armando Calderon Sol visits the Republic of China.
1999: The ruling Kuomintang convenes the second plenary session of its 15th National Congress to formally approve Lien Chan and Vincent Siew as the party's nominees for the 2000 presidential election of the Republic of China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Like the rush of mighty waters, the presence of unseen powers is felt -- sometimes above us, sometimes around us. Such is the evidence of things invisible that it is impossible to doubt the spiritual nature of man."
