DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Prices lower on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for September fell 39 points to close at 7,041, with 55,649 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October lost 36 points to finish at 7,023, with 307 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 50 points to close at 7,003, with 24 contract transactions.
March futures decreased 41 points to finish at 6,999, with 19 contract transactions, while June futures were down 54 points to close at 6,990, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 7,080 for September, 7,059 for October, 7,053 for December, 7,040 for March and 7,044 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index lost 47.6 points to finish at 7,033.37, on turnover of NT$99.43 billion (US$3.16 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

September TE futures decreased 2.25 points to close at 288.8, with 3,536 contracts traded, while October TE futures decreased 0.6 points to finish at 288.55, with nine contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

September TF futures remained unchanged at 863.4 points, with 2,208 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures decreased 2.4 points to finish at 857.8, with 34 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former chief of Investigation Bureau indicted (update-1)

TEXT.P: Yeh Sheng-mao, former chief of the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice, was indicted for withholding information about ex-president Chen Shui- bian's possible involvement in money laundering, a spokesman for the Taipei District Prosecutors Office said Thursday.
Lin Chin-chun said prosecutors are seeking a jail term of two years and six months for Yeh, which is harsher than usual because the defendant is a government official.
Lin said Yeh, who stepped down from his post as chief of the Investigation Bureau on July 16, withheld information about overseas bank accounts held in the names of Chen Shui-bian's family members.

Lin said Yeh was supposed to relay the information -- which the the bureau's Anti-Money Laundering Center obtained on Jan. 27 from the global anti-money laundering association Egmont Group -- to the Supreme Prosecutors' Office.
However, the Supreme Prosecutors Office never received the information, Lin added.

The director of the Investigation Bureau's Anti-Money Laundering Center asked Yeh about the information in March and was told that Yeh would hand it over to Prosecutor General Chen Tsung-min in person, Lin related.
Lin quoted the prosecutor general as saying that he never received the information.

Yeh later claimed that he had forgotten to pass on the information to Chen Tsung-min because the country was embroiled in a fiercely contested presidential election at the time and he stepped down two months after the new administration took office on May 20.
Lin said a search of Yeh's home in Muza in Taipei on Aug. 21 yielded a photocopy of the information from Egmont but not the original document.
"The fact that Yeh carefully kept a photocopy of the information belies his claim that he totally forgot about the whole matter, " Lin said.

The news broke in late July after two Swiss prosecutors asked Taiwan authorities for help in the investigation of a case of possible money laundering, which involved a reported sum of US$21 million lodged in Swiss bank accounts under the name of Chen Shui-bian's daughter-in-law.
Lin indicated that it was not the first time Yeh, who was appointed in 2001 by then-President Chen Shui-bian to head the Investigation Bureau, had withheld information about the former first family.
In 2006, the Investigation Bureau failed to pass on to prosecutors information it had obtained about possible money laundering by then first lady Wu Shu-jen, Lin said.
According to Lin, Yeh maintained that he had conveyed the information in 2006 to then Prosecutor General Wu Ying-chao, a claim Wu denied.

Regarding the more recent information from Egmont about the ex-first family's bank accounts in Cayman Islands, many political observers have suggested that Yeh gave Chen Shui-bian the original copy, which investigators have not yet found.
They have also urged the prosecutors to look into the possibility that Yeh may have tipped off the ex-president about an imminent probe of his family's overseas bank accounts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has no information on U.S. Harpoon missile sales: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has not received any information on the possible sale of Harpoon Air-Launch missiles by the United States to Taiwan, military spokeswoman Lisa Chi said Thursday.

Chi was responding to a Reuters report published a day earlier, which stated that the United States will sell 60 Harpoon Air-Launch missiles worth NT$90 billion to Taiwan. According to the report, the decision will end a freeze on U.S. arms sales to Taiwan.

However, Chi said the request to procure the Harpoon Air-Launch missiles from the United States was put forward by the ROC Air Force last year and Taiwan does not expect a positive response until 2009.
"We have not received any formal notification from the U.S.
side," Chi said.
The Bush administration is still sitting on US$11 billion worth of additional weaponry requested by Taiwan.

The list of military hardware reportedly being held up includes anti-tank missiles, Apache helicopters, Patriot PAC-3 missile batteries, diesel-powered submarines, P3C anti-submarine aircraft and sea-launch Harpoon missiles.

Taiwan fears that if the notifications are not sent to the U.S. Congress a month before it adjourns in late September, approval of the sale will be pushed back to 2009 under a new U.S. administration.
Responding to speculations surrounding the delay in processing the deal, the U.S. Department of State reiterated last month that Washington has not changed its policy on arms sales to Taiwan.

State Department spokesman Sean McCormack said July 18 that the administration "faithfully implements the Taiwan Relations Act" and that there is an "internal interagency process" for the U.S. government to consider all military exports, including sales to Taiwan.
"When the interagency process achieves a final decision for specific arms sales, we will notify Congress," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, decreasing NT$0.002 to close at NT$31.479.
A total of US$910 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.470 and fluctuated between NT$31.425 and NT$31.528.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City confirms another case of indigenous dengue fever

TEXT.P: Another case of indigenous dengue fever has been confirmed, bringing the number of confirmed cases in the capital city to 20, the Taipei City Department of Health reported Thursday.
The latest case was a 47-year-old woman from the Yonglun Borough in Taipei City's northern Shilin District, according to the municipal Department of Health.
The department has been stepping up measures to prevent dengue fever, following the confirmation of five indigenous cases in Shilin District recently.

The city government has dispatched mosquito eradication units to spray indoor and outdoor areas within 200 meters of buildings where dengue fever cases were reported, and to spray 10 boroughs near the Shilin area.

In the northeastern Songshan District, blood samples of 215 residents have been collected for testing. Of the total, 211 samples were confirmed as negative, while four were inconclusive, according to the department.
Dengue fever is transmitted to humans by infected Aedes albo pictus mosquitoes, which mainly breed in stagnant water.

Department officials therefore urged residents in Taipei City to step up efforts to clean up environmental black spots and to get rid of standing water in containers such as flower pots, buckets and discarded tires.
People who develop early symptoms of dengue fever, such as fever, joint pains and skin rashes, should immediately seek medical attention, the department advised.

DOC.HEADLINE: The U.S. has no presumptions about Taiwans international

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that the United States never had any preordination regarding Taiwans participation in international organizations, rebutting media reports that the U.S. hoped that Taiwan, in its talks with Beijing, will not give any impression that China has sovereignty over Taiwan nor that China should be the one to have the final say.

Through our continuous contact and communication with the U.S. government, the U.S. has expressed great appreciation for the proposal regarding Taiwans meaningful participation in the U.N. specialized agencies, MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said at a regular press briefing in response to a reporters question.
The U.S. never had any preordination (regarding Taiwans U.N. bid), the report is totally untrue,he added.

The local newspaper Liberty Times reported Thursday that on President Ma Ying- jeous pro-China stance and his recent moderate approach in pitching Taiwans participation in the United Nations, the U.S. expressed its position by saying that in the talks with Beijing, Taiwan should not imply that China has sovereignty over Taiwan and that China should not be the one to determine whether Taiwan can participate in international activities.

The message was delivered to Ma by American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond Burghardt during Mas transit stops in the U.S. en route to South America and the Caribbean Aug. 12-19, the report added.

The frosty relations between Taiwan and China have been thawing since Ma took office May 20, with his proposal for adiplomatic truceandmodus vivendi, aimed at terminating the longstanding diplomatic tug-of-war with China and winning more international space for Taiwan.

Asked if Taiwan's new diplomatic initiative was not favorably received by China given the fact that Aug. 18 China reiterated its opposition to Taiwans U.N. proposal, Chen said the ministry is not surprised, as it is the same basic Chinese stance as before, but stressed that Taiwan will continue to push the bid.

Diplomatic ties with our allies are the most important indicator of diplomatic truce while participation in international organizations is the long-term goal that the ministry will continue to work on,Chen said, urging China to demonstrate more goodwill on the issue of ending the competition to lure each othersdiplomatic allies.

Taiwan renewed its bid to enter the U.N. Aug. 14 by submitting a proposal asking the U.N. General Assembly at its Sep. 16 meeting to reconsider the feasibility of Taiwans meaningful participation in the U.N. specialized agencies. However, Chinese Ambassador to the U.N. Wang Guangya wrote to the U.N. secretary-general Aug. 18, saying that China opposes Taiwans bid because as part of China, Taiwan is not a sovereign state that can participate in the U.N. specialized agencies, which are composed only of sovereign states.

In response to Wangs letter, MOFA released a statement Wednesday reiterating that the basic rights of the people of the Republic of China to participate in international organizations and activities should be respected.
Asked if the MOFAs response wastoo weak, Chen rebutted the accusation, saying that the ministry was simply responding to the facts of the issue.
One should not draw the conclusion thatthis is the endfrom a single incident, as participation in international organizations is our long-term goal,Chen said.
He stressed that the pragmatic and meaningful proposal has won an overwhelmingly positive response from the international community, including the U.S., Japan and many important European countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker calls for stiffer penalties on personal data leaks

TEXT.P: A lawmaker has called for stiffer punishments for public and private organizations that leak local citizens' information to fraud rings after the police busted the country's largest personal data theft case earlier this week.

The ruling and opposition political parties should soon reach an agreement on a draft amendment to the Computer Processed Personal Data Protection Act, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Wong Chin-chu said in a news release Wednesday.

Under the amendment, the total compensation amount offered by government agencies and companies to individuals for failing to protect their personal data would be increased to NT$50 million (US$1.6 million) from the current NT$20 million, Wong said.
In addition, agency or company employees who sell personal data will face five year prison terms, rather than the current two year terms, Wong said.
Even those who leak personal data for motives other than profit will no longer be free of punishment, but will face sentences of two years or less, she noted.
Wong said that leaking personal data to fraud rings has seriously breached personal privacy and has a serious impact on social order.
Wong recalled that earlier this year, a local textbook publisher allegedly leaked the personal data of 310,000 national high school exam takers.
Moreover, she added that on Tuesday, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) busted a ring that stole more than 50 million pieces of personal data from government agencies and telecom companies.
The police found that Chinese hackers also were involved in the case and have requested the assistance of Chinese police through a joint crime-combating channel between Taiwan and China.
The police began investigating the ring after state-run Chunghwa Post Co. reported last April that a group of hackers stole more than NT$3 million from the savings of postal company's clients.
The police later discovered that the ring hacked into the databases of the Bureau of National Health Insurance, the Ministry of Education and local telecom companies.
The ring collected the information and set up a database containing the information on government officials, business people and the general public, the police disclosed.
The police said that they arrested the main suspect, a 32-year-old with the surname Chen, and five other accomplices on Tuesday in Taipei City and Taipei County in northern Taiwan.
The suspects also sold the data to other rings for NT$300 per inquiry on each piece of personal data, the police said.
Employees and dealers in the telecom companies have been found to have collaborated with the ring, the police revealed, adding that they are still searching for other accomplices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suspected motorbike thieves nabbed

TEXT.P: Police in central and southern Taiwan on Wednesday arrested five suspects who allegedly smuggled stolen heavy motorbikes from Japan and made an illegal profit of more than NT$50 million (about US$1.6 million) from the sale of the bikes.
The arrests ware made as a result of collaboration with Japanese police and the International Criminal Police Organization, police in Taiwan said.
Japanese police also nabbed two Taiwanese suspects at Tokyo Narita International Airport on Aug. 11 in connection with the same scam, Taiwan police said.

Local police caught other suspects in the case in the central city of Taichung and southern city and county of Kaohsiung. The suspects confessed that they had smuggled stolen motorbikes from Japan on four occasions, bringing dozens of bikes each time.
The police said that they found 14 stolen large-engine bikes, some of which were reported in Japan as stolen between 2002 and early this year.
The evidence indicates that Japan-based Taiwanese expatriates and Japanese gangsters were helping the suspects, the police said, adding that the case is still under investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices lower on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 47.6 points, or 0.67 percent, to close at 7,033.37.

Suffering a drop from gains of the previous day, the local bourse opened at 7,090.32 and fluctuated between 7,127.84 and 7,025.3. A total of 3.8 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$99.43 billion (US$3.16 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down the most at 2.8 percent, textile stocks declined 1.9 percent, machinery and electronics shares dropped 0.9 percent, banking and financial shares lost 0.6 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares were down 0.2 percent.
The three other major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1 percent. Foodstuff issues advanced 0.4 percent, and paper and pulp issues rose 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,154 to 794, with 531 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$2.25 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet drafts measures to spur economy

TEXT.P: The government has come up with eight economic stimulus measures, including offering subsidies and preferential taxes to enterprises and individuals, in an effort to boost private investment and consumption.
The measures were unveiled Wednesday at a Cabinet meeting chaired by Vice Premier Chiu Cheng-hsiung, Minister without Portfolio Chen Tain-jy said Thursday.

Chen said that although the recent fall of international oil prices has helped to ease domestic inflationary pressure, the country faces yet another challenge: slower exports amid a global econmic downtown.
For this reason, the government decided to shift its economic policy from battling inflationary pressure to expanding domestic investment and consumption to stimulate the sagging economy, he added.

According to Minister without Portfolio Chu Yun-peng, one of the main stimulus measures is the launch of a short-term preferential tax system for enterprises. Currently, the government offers tax cuts or tax exemptions to specific industries, such as high technology companies, on the basis of the Statute for Upgrading Industries which will expire at the end of next year.

Chu said that before the statute expires, the government will introduce an amendment that will include a provision for other businesses, such as manufacturing and service industries, to be given preferential tax treatment on a short-term basis. The draft amendment is scheduled to be proposed in September, Chu disclosed.

The government also plans to raise the cap on construction and home loans. Under the existing Banking Law, the total value of bank loans for the purpose of constructing residential or commercial buildings may not exceed 30 percent of the lending institution's balance of time deposits. Chu said that the government plans to finalize the details concerning that stimulus measure within one month.

Meanwhile, Chu noted that several preferential home loan programs launched by the Ministry of the Interior have not proved effective, given that private banks, with an eye to attracting clients, have launched many more similar programs in response. Thus, the government is considering raising preferential interest rates for home loans, although the details have not yet been finalized, he said.

Other measures include allocating NT$13.5 billion to provide subsidies to 450,000 employees living near the poverty line; assisting local governments to more effectively implement infrastructure projects; offering subsidies to the disadvantaged and expanding and promoting trade and investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: International art exhibition to kick off in Taipei

TEXT.P: An international art exhibition, featuring collections from 111 art galleries around the world, will open Friday in Taipei, with the aim of luring art collectors and giving more exposure to local artists, the organizers said Thursday.

Art Taipei 2008 will showcase contemporary art works from 49 galleries in Europe, North America and Asia, as well as from the local art industry, said Taiwan's Art Galleries Association which is organizing the show.
The exhibition will be divided into seven thematic sections, with an eye to meeting the increasingly multi-dimensional and special demands of art collectors, the association explained in a statement.
The seven sections are Art Gallery, Asia Live, Ela-Asia, Year Project-Art and Tech, Made in Taiwan-Young Artists Discovery, Art Now-Japan and International Art Media.

"Eight Taiwanese artists under the age of 35, who have been selected by the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA), will be specially introduced at the exhibition to raise the international visibility of Taiwanese artists, " said CCA Minister Huang Pi- twan at a press conference.

The exhibition will also include a display entitled "Wandering, " which will feature six renowned new media artists whose work depict humans' reactions and emotions during the process of urban modernization, said Sean Hu, curator of the art fair.
Art Taipei 2008 will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center, Exhibition Hall 1 from Aug. 29 to Sep. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan leaves NBA stars with indelible memories

TEXT.P: Their first ever visit to Taiwan may be short, but four former NBA stars will be left with indelible beautiful memories of the country, according to L. A. Lakers shooter Glen Rice Thursday.
"It's all about people -- we love them, and they love us, " said Rice, reflecting on what he saw as the best part of their experience in Taiwan.

Six-time NBA championship winner, Batman Scottie Pippen, however, was more taken with Taipei's "karaoke" culture, disclosing that he had already twice tried the unique social activity in Taipei and "drank a lot."

The four basketball players engaged in their first exercise in Taiwan Thursday morning -- following their arrival in the country earlier this week -- though not on the familiar basketball court, but at the Ta Shee Golf and Country Club.

Pippen, a former Chicago Bulls forward who is also a big golf fan, jokingly told the CNA reporter that his level of golf is probably the same as that of world No. 1 player, Tiger Woods, or "maybe better."

But he declined to reveal how good he really is, opting to keep his handicap a secret. And there was still no telling when the four players finished 18 holes in the scorching sun, as no official scores were kept.

Both Pippen and Rice said that they were having a great time on their first visit to Taiwan, and that they were overwhelmed by the hospitality and enthusiasm of the Taiwan people. In reciprocation, the U.S. baseball ambassadors reached out to the local people and basketball fans without any airs.
Rice said modestly while they are in the country to offer some advice on basketball, they also want to hear something from Taiwan.

Pippen and Rice, along with Clyde Drexler of the Rockets and B.J. Armstrong of the Bulls, are in Taipei on the 2008 NBA Madness Taiwan Tour, which will feature two exhibition matches in Taipei and Hsinchu County Friday and Saturday, respectively.
Pippen and Armstrong, teaming up with players from the local Super Basketball League, will play a team led by Drexler and Rice.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former President to visit Okinawa in September

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui will visit Okinawa in late September on an itinerary that will include a speech at Okinawa University, according to Japanese sources Thursday.
The trip will be Lee's first to Okinawa and his fourth to Japan since 2000 when he left office.

According to the sources, Lee will arrive Sept. 22 in Okinawa where he will hold a news conference to explain the objectives of his trip. He will also visit several World War II memorials and sites that same day.

At the invitation of Okinawa University's alumni association, Lee will give a speech on Japanese culture, on the second day of his trip. On the following day he will do more sightseeing and is scheduled to return to Taiwan Sept. 25, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Aug. 30 protest not related to ex-president: non-government group

TEXT.P: Pro-independence Taiwan Society reiterated Thursday that the Aug. 30 rally is not an event to support ex-president Chen Shui-bian, who is embroiled in a money-laundering scandal with his family members, but rather an outcry from the people to safeguard the sovereignty of Taiwan.

"This event is not about whether one supports the Kuomintang (KMT) or the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), " said Wu Shuh-min, president of Taiwan Society, in a press conference to announce the Aug. 30 "Outcry from the People" march and rally for foreign journalists stationed in Taiwan.
"The Ma Ying-jeou administration, which is desperate to make progress on cross- strait issues, has yielded too much to Beijing, " he stated.

The frosty relations between Taiwan and China have been thawing since Ma took office May 20, with the launch of direct weekend charter flights and the allowance of more Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan, as well as the relaxation of investment restrictions in China. Ma also proposed a "diplomatic truce" and "modus vivendi" aimed at terminating the longstanding diplomatic tug-of-war with China.

"Unilateral concession on the part of the Kuomintang government has received very little positive response from China, " Wu said. "What is worse is that Ma's concessions have been made at the expense of Taiwan's sovereignty and security."
He therefore urged that people should speak out their deepest feelings to Ma, including protecting Taiwan's sovereignty, improving the economy for a better life and swiftly enacting sunshine laws.

Refusing to comment on Chen's calling on those who support him to participate in the march, Lo Chih-cheng, secretary-general of Taiwan Society, said that he believes that people will join the rally because they believe in the three demands, among which safeguarding Taiwan's sovereignty is the most important message the group wants to send out to the world.

Chen admitted Aug. 14 that he had lied about the campaign expenses for his two mayoral elections and two presidential elections between 1993 and 2004 and that his wife had wired surplus campaign contributions into overseas bank accounts held by members of his family. Chen and his family, who were prohibited from leaving the country by prosecutors, are currently being investigated.
"Over the past three months, Ma's policies have taken Taiwan in the opposite direction from before and betrayed our traditional allies such as the United States and Japan, " Lo said.
The group also demanded a formal apology from Ma for failing to deliver his campaign promises of six percent economic growth, three percent unemployment, and US$30,000 GDP per capita.

"We criticize, as most people do, because we see the nation moving in a dangerous direction, but so far none of our words are accepted by the government, " said Winston Yu, vice president of Taiwan Society. "Ma makes no confession of his mistakes, no apology. He even ridiculously fought back by calling those who criticize him 'cynical'."

Participants at the press conference unanimously called for early passage of more "Sunshine bills" to combat corruption by public functionaries. The enactment of such laws will oblige senior officials and civil servants to account for their private assets.
Lo said at least 22,500 people from central and south Taiwan have signed up to join the Aug. 30 rally and he expected that many more from Taipei city will participate in the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office mum on Examination Yuan head nomination

TEXT.P: Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi would not comment Thursday on a daily news' speculation regarding ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman John Kuan's possible nomination to head the Examination Yuan.

Wang said the new legislative session would not begin until mid-September and that the Presidential Office will submit the nomination for new Examination Yuan presidency for legislative confirmation by then.

According to a United Daily News (UDN) report, President Ma Ying-jeou is likely to nominate Kuan, 68, who served as vice president of the Examination Yuan between 1996-2000, to head the Examination Yuan after Chang Chun-yen, former president of National Chiao Tung University, withdrew from screening after he was nominated Examination Yuan president by Ma in June.

Chang withdrew for personal reasons only days before the Legislative Yuan was supposed to review and approve Ma's Examination Yuan nominees June 23 to allow those selected to bring new prospects for the Examination Yuan, which is in charge of recruiting and managing the country's civil servants.

The legislature reviewed and approved the list of the other 20 nominees, including Wu Chin-lin, then a KMT deputy secretary-general, who was nominated by Ma to serve as vice president of the Examination Yuan, and 19 others to serve as Examination Yuan members.
UDN speculated that if nominated and approved by the legislature, Kuan would resign his post as a KMT vice chairman and quit all KMT activities to "champion the neutrality as an administrator."
Kuan's alleged nomination drew mixed reaction by the ruling KMT and opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Thursday.

Ker Chien-ming, a DPP legislative caucus whip, said Ma had promised during his campaign that if elected he will nominate non-KMT people to head the Examination Yuan and the top watchdog agency, the Control Yuan.
"Is Ma going to eat his own words or something now by appointing a hardcore KMT member to head the Examination Yuan?" Ker said.

"Kuan's nomination will receive zero votes from DPP legislators if Ma indeed does so, " a determined Ker claimed, adding that the KMT is only aimed at misusing the mammoth budget the Examination Yuan controls for public functionaries' retirement payments.

KMT Legislator Chu Feng-chih, however, has completely different views on Kuan's possible nomination, saying that Kuan would make a good Exmaination Yuan president, not just because he is very familiar with the operations of the organization, but also because of his professional abilities and morality.
"Kuan is a man of integrity with strength of character who would be an impartial and capable leader if authorized to head the Examination Yuan," Chu added.
Also welcoming Kuan's possible nomination as Examination Yuan president, KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung said he would respect the president's decision.
"I think Kuan is a good choice, given his experience with the Examination Yuan's operations, and his studies and research done in the past," Wu noted.
The tenure of the incumbent Examination Yuan members will expire Aug. 31 and Wu, the new Examination Yuan vice president, and the 19 other new members are expected to assume office Sept. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Subsidy for households near poverty line to be issued from October

TEXT.P: The government will issue a temporary subsidy of up to NT$6,000 (US$190) per month to households living near the poverty line starting in October, in an effort to help the disadvantaged cope with inflation, the Cabinet announced Thursday.
The program will run through March 2009, benefiting an estimated 450,000 households that are not receiving any aid from the government at present, according to the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).

Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said the program has been worked out to complement the existing social aid network that covers only low-income households at the lowest end of the income distribution graph, but fails to cover those living near the poverty line.

According to Liu, a high employment rate -- averaging 4.26 percent during the 2000-2007 period -- has fueled the country's widening wealth disparity, with the number of low-income earners having increased by 640,000 over the past 10 years, including a large number who sank from the middle-class.

"These citizens living near poverty, who cannot afford to save any money, suffer an especially great impact from the ongoing inflation, particularly in food and oil prices, " Liu said during a weekly Cabinet meeting.
Interior Minister Liao Liao-yi said after the program expires in March next year, the govenrment will review the country's economic situation to decide whether to extend it for another six months.
The program will target citizens aged 20-65 who are the main income earners of their families and who make no more than NT$300,000 per year.

Other requirements that the subsidy applicants must meet are: they are not from a low-income household; they are full-time workers; their spouses or immediate dependents under 65 earn no more than NT$300,000 per year; the combined income of the applicants, their spouses and immediate dependents under 65 did not reach the minimum threshold for paying income tax in the most recent fiscal year; and the total value of real estate owned by the applicants, their spouses and immediate dependents under 65 does not exceed NT$3.9 million.
Liao said the applicants will be grouped in five brackets according to the average annual income of the applicants and their spouses.

The subsidized amount will be NT$6,000 for those receiving an average annual income below NT$140,000; NT$5,000 for those in the NT$140,000-NT$180,000 bracket; NT$4,000 for those in the NT$180,000-NT$220,000 bracket; NT$3,500 for those in the NT$220,000-NT$260,000 bracket; and NT$3,000 for those in the NT$260,000-NT$300,000 bracket, Liao said.
For individuals with no dependants, the subsidized amount will be NT$3,500 if they earn less than NT$220,000 per year, and NT$3,000 if they make between NT$220,000 and NT$250,000 per year, he said.

MOI officials said potential subsidy recipients will be shortlisted via computer-aided screening of the government's income tax returns database, after which they will receive an application form and be asked to sign it to declare they truly meet all the requirements listed above.

Liao pointed out that the screening may inaptly include some people who live comfortably but file only a small amount in their income tax returns, and he urged community officials to help exclude this group of people.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI invents multi-viewer auto-stereoscopic display technology

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) has developed technology that allows auto-stereoscopic display for multiple viewing, sources at the Hsinchu-based institute announced Thursday.

Stereoscopic display is a method that enables viewers to see stereoscopic images; however, such a display requires the viewer to wear special goggles or glasses to see the images properly. Auto- stereoscopic displays create a stereoscopic effect that the viewer can perceive without glasses, but the existing technology allows only one person to see the image at a time.

The ITRI researchers who developed the technology said the conventional auto- stereoscopic display devices have a limited viewable angle of 5 degrees, which limits the total viewership. "The new technology widens the viewable angle up to 60 degrees, allowing multiple individuals to view the images simultaneously," they said.

The researchers estimated that a commercial multi-person auto- stereoscopic display will cost about NT$60,000 (US$1,900) to NT$80,000 for a 42-inch TV screen, while an auto-stereoscopic set of the same screen size usually costs up to NT$139,566 on the European market.

The research group said that a couple of private companies have already contacted the ITRI to discuss cooperation in technology transfer, and that commercial versions will enter the market in two to three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Zoo loses two koalas in 40 days

TEXT.P: The director of the Taipei Zoo said Thursday that the zoo management has no immediate plans to bring in more koala bears from their native Australia, although the zoo has lost two of its seven koala bears in 40 days.

Jason Yeh told reporters that the zoo will not consider bringing in additional koalas because the Australian government has temporarily suspended the export of wild koalas and because the zoo is now busy preparing for the arrival of two giant pandas from China.
Two female koalas -- Ligi and Eve, both 11 years old -- died of malignant tumors July 18 and Aug. 27, respectively.

The zoo still has one female koala, named Pearl, and four male koalas: Patrick, Milk Tea, Qubi and Qudi. Pearl and Milk Tea were given by Australia to the Taipei Zoo in 2004, while Qubi and Qudi were born in captivity in 2003 and 2005, respectively, as offspring of Patrick and Ligi, who was sent to the zoo by an Australian sanctuary in 2001, according to Yeh.

In an unprecedented so-called "wedding ceremony" attended by 500 well-wishers in Taipei in October 2001, then-Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Gary Balidon, mayor of Australia's Gold Coast, "married" Ligi to Patrick and Eve to Harley.
In 2004, the zoo euthanized Harley after a malignant tumor was found in his nose.
Yeh said that zoo keepers are anxious to find out within the next few days if an Aug. 3 mating between Pearl and Milk Tea will produce an offspring. Koala gestation is about 30 days.
The zoo's koalas are a children's favorite because of their cute and cuddly appeal.

Although koalas are not endangered, the Australian federal government strictly controls exports of live animals. At present, only a few zoos outside Australia -- in the United States, Japan, Germany and Taiwan -- have the marsupials.
According to the Australian Koala Foundation, the number of wild koalas in Australia is estimated at between between 40,000 and 80,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Vietnamese universities sign pact on sisterhood ties

TEXT.P: National Taiwan Ocean University (NTOU) in the northern port city of Keelung signed an accord with a Vietnamese counterpart Thursday to forge sisterhood ties paving the way for further exchanges, an NTOU official said later that day.

NTOU President Kuo-Tien Lee and Le Viet Dung, deputy president of Can Tho University (CTU) in southwestern Vietnam, signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) during a ceremony held on the NTOU campus to help promote sisterhood ties between the two schools, the NTOU official explained.
Dung attended the ceremony on behalf of CTU President Nguyen Anh Tuan.

The official added that according to the MOU, the two schools will beef up exchanges in various fields, including teacher-and-student exchange, academic information exchange, publication of collaborative research achievements and joint participation in academic symposiums and activities.

The two schools will also set up a dual degree program in which students pursuing a master's or doctoral degree in one of the schools can also obtain an equivalent degree from the other school after having gained the necessary credits in both schools.
According to the MOU, NTOU will help cultivate talent for Taiwanese and Vietnamese businesses in Vietnam by providing CTU students with educational training programs.
NTOU's cultivation of talent is expected to help boost substantive ties between Taiwan and Vietnam, the official remarked.
The CTU is a state university located in Can Tho City, the fifth largest city in Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: 80% of people commute via private transport: Consumers' Foundation

TEXT.P: Nearly 80 percent of the respondents to a recent poll said they use private transport to get to and from work and 57 percent said there is a lack of public transport near their homes, according to the results of the online survey released Thursday by the Consumers' Foundation.

The survey, aimed at exploring consumers' use of public transport and their satisfaction regarding public transport and commuting fares, ran from the beginning of July to Aug. 25, with 3,295 valid replies collected, said a foundation official.

According to the survey results, 78 percent of the respondents use private transport when commuting, followed by 17 percent who commute via public transport and 3 percent who use both, while 2 percent of the respondents said they walk to work.

The results also indicate that 57 percent of the respondents feel that public transport near their homes is inadequate, with 22 percent saying there are not enough public transport vehicles and 14 percent complaining of too few stops, especially in rural areas.

Meanwhile, 35 percent of the respondents said they have to walk for 5 to 10 minutes to reach the closest bus stop to their home, followed by 21 percent who have a 20-minute walk and 14 percent who have a 30-minute walk, which reduces their willingness to commute via public transport.

With regard to fares, respondents that use both public and private transport said they spend an average of NT$2,782 (US$88.40) commuting per month, accounting for 7.5 percent of their monthly incomes, the highest in the survey.

Those who commute via private transport spend NT$1,971 per month (6.2 percent of their monthly income) , while respondents using only public transport spend NT$1,703 per month, representing 6.1 percent of their monthly income, the lowest in the survey.
The Consumers' Foundation said the government should adopt energy-saving transport policies to improve the traffic situation, reduce air pollution and promote the use of public transport.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiayi City invites visitors to attend Double Ten festivities

TEXT.P: Chiayi Mayor Huang Ming-hui has invited visitors from Taiwan and abroad to take part in the Double Ten National Day celebrations in the southern city, as the city government is preparing a series of festivities for the Oct. 10-12 weekend holiday.

Huang told reporters Thursday that the city government has already selected a location -- a farm belonging to the Chiayi Agricultural Station, which is adjacent to Chiayi Park -- for the official Oct. 10 fireworks display.
A giant red balloon with a diameter of five meters is now tethered 100 meters above the farm as a reference to inform the public where they can see the fireworks.
The mayor urged the public to find a good spot in advance for watching the fireworks. "If you can see the balloon, then you will be able to see the Double Ten fireworks," she said.

This will be the first official National Day fireworks show to be staged in Chiayi by the central government. The show is considered a major event, as the city government has expressed the hope of exposing Chiayi to the world when hundreds of thousands of visitors, including tens of thousands of overseas Chinese and foreign tourists, flood into the city to witness the festivities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 70% of citizens favor economic before political exchanges

TEXT.P: A majority of Taiwanese citizens who responded to a recent poll think Taiwan should first discuss economic exchanges with China in cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations before moving on to political issues, according to the poll results released Thursday.

The poll, authorized by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), found that 73 percent of the respondents feel the two sides of the strait should tackle issues related to economic exchanges first and leave political issues for discussion at a later date.

The poll, conducted by telephone Aug. 22-24, found that 52.2 percent of the respondents think cross-strait relations are now much more eased than they were a year ago, and 50.6 percent said they are confident in the Ma Ying-jeou administration's ability to maintain cross-strait peace and stability.

A total of 51.8 percent of the respondents said they support the administration's policy of relaxing restrictions on cross-strait business and investment exchanges, but 65.5 percent said the government should have tighter standards in terms of the management of such exchanges, the poll found.

Commenting on the findings, MAC spokesman Liu Te-shun said most of the respondents are positive toward the government's relaxed economic policy toward China, but apparently they also hope the government will come up with well- designed coping measures to prevent undesired scenarios.
Meanwhile, 51.6 percent of the respondents said that "securing equality and dignity" for Taiwan in cross-strait negotiations is as important as "achieving substantive interests."
However, 53.1 percent of the respondents said Beijing is not friendly toward the Ma administration, while 45.1 percent said Beijing is not friendly toward the people of Taiwan either, Liu said.
He called for the Chinese authorities to understand that despite thawing cross- strait relations, the people of Taiwan are still skeptical toward political interaction across the Taiwan Strait.
"China should not constrain Taiwan's political maneuvering space in the international community," Liu added.
The poll of adults randomly selected nationwide obtained 1,094 valid responses, with a confidence rate of 95 percent and a margin of error of 2.96 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indigenous college students leave for Hawaii on exchange visit

TEXT.P: A group of 20 indigenous young men and women selected from colleges and universities around the country left for Hawaii Thursday on a 12-day exchange visit, the Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) announced that day.

Wang Chiu-yi, director of the CIP's Department of Education and Culture, said the students are the "cream of the young indigenous elite" because they were selected after passing a host of challenging tests, including tests of their various mother tongues, a verbal English language test and a written test of aboriginal cultures and knowledge.
"The visit to Hawaii is aimed at honing their abilities in exchanges with indigenous peoples from around the world," Wang said.

According to CIP Minister Chang Jen-hsiang, the administration has planned to inject some NT$10 billion (US$322.58 million) over four years to improve infrastructure development in aboriginal communities and narrow the gap between aboriginal communities and Taiwan's mainstream society.

In addition to international exchange activities, the CIP has also sought financial subsidies from the government to enable 10 outstanding indigenous students to seek advanced studies abroad each year to help raise aboriginal peoples' social status through education, Chang noted.

Professor Lee A-yi from Catholic Fujen University, who is in charge of the students during their visit to Hawaii, expressed hope that the CIP will invite delegates from the Office of Hawaiian Affairs (OHA) to visit Taiwan for exchanges in the future.
The students are visiting Hawaii at the invitation of the OHA.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI unveils draft bill on combating human trafficking

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) announced a draft bill Thursday on the prevention of human trafficking.

"The legislation will facilitate a crackdown on human trafficking, better protect the rights of the victims in the human trade and improve Taiwan's international image, " the ministry said in a press statement.

The draft bill clearly defines what constitutes human trafficking, including recruitment, transportation, harboring of people for the purposes of slavery, forced labor and servitude. According to the bill, those convicted of being involved in human trafficking operations should be given the severest possible penalties in accordance with the law.

For instance, those who are convicted of forced labor, including bonded labor or debt bondage, should be given a maximum seven-year prison sentence plus a fine of no more than NT$3 million. An even longer prison term should be given to any public servant found guilty of covering up such criminal acts.
An official of the MOI's National Immigration Agency (NIA) said the harsher punitive measures are designed as a deterrent.

The draft bill also outlines the powers and duties of government agencies in charge of combating human trafficking, as well as protective and sheltering measures for victims in human trafficking cases.

Noting that human trafficking has emerged as a crucial challenge faced by the international community in the era of globalization, the NIA official said Taiwan is one of the major countries to have seen an influx of migrant workers and marriage immigrants from Southeast Asia.

"Against this backdrop, Taiwan has become a popular destination for criminal rings engaged in the human trade or trafficking in recent years, tarnishing Taiwan's international image and affecting Taiwan's public order and human rights records," said the official.
To cope with the situation, the official went on, the government decided to enact a new set of regulations to facilitate its fight against human trafficking.

Since July 2007, he continued, the MOI and the NIA have convened many rounds of cross-department meetings to draft the bill, which will be sent to the Executive Yuan for further review before being referred to the Legislative Yuan for priority screening and approval.
"It is hoped that the bill can clear the legislative floor during the legislative session that will begin in mid-September, " the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President reiterates `diplomatic truce' with China idea

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Thursday his hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can stop competing to lure each other's allies with offers of cash aid -- so-called "checkbook diplomacy."
Ma made the remarks at a meeting at the Presidential Office with John Perry, chairman of the Ireland-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Society.
He pointed out that all European countries, except for the Vatican, have diplomatic relations with China, while the Holy See is Taiwan's only European ally.

Due to concern over the tension between Taiwan and China, European countries tend to be cautious about developing further relations with Taiwan, even though the country has set up economic and cultural offices in most European countries, Ma said.
He explained that under the notion of seeking a "diplomatic truce" with China, Taiwan will strive to strengthen relations with Ireland but will not seek full diplomatic ties.
This will give Ireland more space in developing relations with both Taiwan and China at the same time without the concern that would otherwise be caused, Ma said.
Ma told Perry that during a trip he made to Ireland two years ago, he learned that the country's rapid development was closely related to its pragmatic and flexible policies.

Ma said his efforts to cement relations with China since assuming office are aimed at seeking an end to the "vicious competition" in the diplomatic field, giving Taiwan more international space for development.
He expressed hope that Perry and other friends in Ireland will help introduce his idea of the "diplomatic truce" to more people when dealing with related issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait weekend charter flights record high occupancy

TEXT.P: Airlines on both sides of the Taiwan Strait saw record passenger volumes on their cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights last weekend, with the average occupancy rate reaching 92 percent, breaking the 90 percent mark for the first time, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) announced Thursday.

CAA Director-General Lee Lung-wen told reporters that eight weeks after Taipei and Beijing began to allow cross-strait charter flights on weekends, the average passenger occupancy rate for the six Chinese carriers operating the routes reached a record 92.5 percent last weekend, up 5.2 percent from the previous weekend, surpassing for the first time the average occupancy rate of the five Taiwanese airlines plying the routes, recorded last week at 91.6 percent

Lee said the carriers have proposed that the scope of the cross-strait air services be expanded by allowing them to increase the number of flights from the current ceiling of 36 and to add new routes and destinations.

"Taiwan will ask that the proposal be included on the agenda for the next round of cross-strait talks and will not rule out the possibility of discussing the opening of regular flights between the two sides," he added.

Lee also said that because most airline companies flying cross-strait charter flights on weekends have expressed hope that they will be allowed to carry some cargo for additional revenue, the Taiwanese delegation will also raise this issue in the next round of dialogue.

The five Taiwanese carriers operating cross-strait charter flights are China Airlines, EVA Airways, Mandarin Airlines, TransAsia Airways and Uni Air, while the six Chinese companies are China Eastern Airlines, Shanghai Airlines, China Southern Airlines, Xiamen Airlines, Hainan Airlines and Air China.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP calls for developing Taiwan into island of arts and culture

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew said Thursday that he looks forward to an early realization of moves to turn Taiwan into not just an island of prosperity but also an island of arts and culture.
Siew revealed his vision at a welcome reception for foreign participants in "Art Taipei 2008, " an art trade fair, on the eve of the inauguration of the annual event.

Noting that artworks tend to become an important line of trade when national economic development reaches a certain stage of maturity, Siew said he keenly hopes the Art Taipei exposition can help make Taipei an important arts trading center in Asia and help upgrade Taiwan's "soft power."
"Art Taipei, " organized by the Council for Cultural Affairs and the Art Galleries Association of ROC, provides a platform for artists from home and abroad to showcase their creative works.

For the first time this year, a new section will be created for promising local young artists to exhibit their brainchildren, calling it "Made in Taiwan - Young Artist Discovery." Eight finalists were selected from 108 young hopefuls to join the exhibition.

A total of 63 local art galleries and 48 ones from the United States, France, Spain, the Netherlands, Japan, Singapore, South Korea, China and Hong Kong are participating in the event that will open Friday at the Taipei World Trade Center's Exhibition Hall 1 and run until Sept. 2.

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Friday.
The weighted price index was up 59.48 points at 7,092.85 on a turnover of NT$2.93 billion (US$93.08 million) at the open. The index lost 47.60 points, or 0.67 percent, to close at 7,033.37 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Friday.
The greenback was trading at NT$31.521 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.042 from Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 29, or the 29th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1475: The Truce of Picquigny is signed, under which King Edward IV of England agrees to withdraw his invading troops from France in return for gold and a yearly pension.
1782: The Royal George, a first-rate ship of the British fleet, sinks while undergoing repairs at Spithead, killing more than 900
1831: Michael Faraday, British physicist and chemist, successfully demonstrates the first electrical transformer in London. He also proposed the field theory later developed by Maxwell and
1842: The Treaty of Nanking is signed by Britain and the Ching Court, ending the Opium War. Among the treaty's stipulations were the opening of five ports to British trade and the ceding of Hong Kong to
1835: John Batman and associates buy land from Australian Aborigines and officially establish Melbourne.
1877: Brigham Young, Mormon leader and founder of Salt Lake City, dies at the age of 76.
1885: The first motorcycle is patented in Germany by Gottlieb Daimler, German engineer and pioneer automobile manufacturer who produced the first high-speed internal-combustion engine.
1910: Japan takes complete control of Korea and begins governing it as a colony to benefit its own interests.
1926: Nepal abolishes slavery, freeing some 55,000 slaves.
1929: The giant airship Graf Zeppelin returns to Lakehurst, New Jersey, after completing a 21-day trip around the world.
1932: A Chinese volunteer army in northeast China launches a surprise attack at Shenyang (Mukden), capital of Liaoning province, during the night. They burned the airport and destroyed 27 Japanese
