DOC.HEADLINE: 'Tempo' of cross-strait exchanges could be improved: MAC head
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/29/08 13:34:41 (By Michelle Tsai and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top China policy planner said Thursday that she does not think Taiwan has been engaging with China over the past three months at too rapid a pace, although she added that the "tempo" of the engagement could be improved.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan, who is visiting Washington, D.C. in a bid to publicize Taiwan's stance on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, explained that finding a "better tempo" means allowing the people to better understand what the government is doing and to what purpose in its efforts with regard to cross-strait relations.

She explained that many policies that have been criticized by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as "too rash" are in fact issues that were discussed by negotiators across the Taiwan Strait during the previous DPP administration, with consensus actually reached on some of the issues.

These issues include the institutionalization of cross-strait negotiations, allowing Chinese tourists to enter Taiwan, exchanges of charter cargo flights and direct cross-strait shipping links, she noted.
As a matter of fact, she went on, some economic and trade measures, such as lifting the ceiling on Taiwan investment in China, were agreed upon two- and-a-half years ago.
"Those measures were not implemented due to Taiwan's elections and other political reasons," she explained.
Lai said of her visit to the U.S. capital that visiting in person contributes to increasing friendship and trust -- two elements she said are desperately needed in U.S.-Taiwan relations.

Noting that she has helped handle many cases related to the United States when she worked in the DPP administration prior to 2004, Lai said she feels sad that U.S.-Taiwan relations have taken such a downward turn over the past eight years under DPP rule.
"It is crucially important that the new administration under the leadership of President Ma Ying-jeou is resolved to rebuilding mutual trust with the United States," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Price floor for rice exports to ensure domestic supplies: official

TEXT.P: A Council of Agriculture (COA) official reiterated Thursday that minimum price restrictions on rice exports will help reduce export volume and ensure sufficient domestic supplies.
COA Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung made the remarks to explain a decision taken by the COA in April to impose a price floor of US$1,200 per ton for exported rice.

Taiwanese rice has gained more opportunities for export recently due to its relatively stable prices compared with international rice price hikes, according to Yu Sheng-feng, deputy director-general of the COA's Agriculture and Food Agency.
Yu noted that Taiwan exported 6,634 tons of rice during the January-June period, more than 20 times the amount exported during the whole of last year.
Under the price floor restrictions, the only export destinations will be countries with high consumption ability and the ability to pay, such as Japan, Chen said.
The government has also taken measures to increase domestic rice production, Chen went on.

Policies aimed at revitalizing 60,000 hectares of fallow land and increasing rice coverage by 20,000 hectares are expected to increase the national rice reserves from this year's 300,000 tons to 400,000 tons in 2009, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Doctor offers tips on avoiding back-to-school syndrome

TEXT.P: With the new school year set to begin Sept. 1, a doctor at Chi Mei Medical Center offered tips Friday to parents on how to help their children avoid "back- to-school" syndrome.

Lin Chien-he, a doctor at the Tainan-based medical center's psychiatry department, said that symptoms of the syndrome include lack of energy, sore muscles, rapid heartbeat, general tiredness and upset stomach.

There are two main reasons why a student might experience the syndrome, Lin continued -- difficulty adapting to a new environment and difficulty getting out of "holiday mode" in terms of habits and routines.
Those most at risk of falling victim are new students and students who are starting classes at a new school, according to Lin.
Lin suggested that parents can do several things to guide their children as the new term approaches to ease the transition and prevent them from being afflicted.

These include gradually reducing the number of hours their children watch television and surf the Internet, slowly adjusting their sleep hours, and spending some time with their kids to discuss their plans in the coming days in order to prepare them for the daily school routine and reduce the stress of making the transition back to class, Lin explained.
"Being well-prepared is the most effective way of avoiding back-to-school syndrome," she added.

Lin also noted that exercise is the best method of helping a person adjust to a new situation, adding that it is also helpful for students in making the adjustment back to regular sleeping hours ahead of the start of the new school year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-first lady's sister-in-law subpoenaed in money laundering scandal

TEXT.P: Chen Chun-ying, a sister-in-law of former President Chen Shui-bian's wife Wu Shu-jen, was subpoenaed again Friday for questioning as a witness over her possible role in a suspected overseas money laundering case involving the former first family.

The Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office said Chen Chun-ying was summoned again as a witness mainly so prosecutors could gain a better understanding of how and when Wu remitted huge amounts of money to ABN AMRO Bank and Standard Bank of South Africa branches in Singapore.

Chen Chun-ying and her husband, Wu Ching-mao, who is the elder brother of the former first lady, were summoned for questioning Aug. 18, but Chen appeared to faint during questioning and was rushed to the nearby National Taiwan University Hospital for emergency treatment.
The prosecutors thus decided to subpoena her again Friday for further questioning.

Meanwhile, the Special Investigation Division also summoned other friends and relatives of Wu Shu-jen to find out whether they were also used by the former first lady as figureheads to facilitate money laundering via overseas bank accounts.
The former first couple and their son Chen Chih-chung, daughter-in-law Huang Jui-ching and Wu Ching-mao were listed last week as suspects in the case and banned from leaving the country.

During questioning by prosecutors last Friday, the former first lady argued that the US$21 million in overseas bank accounts under the name of her elder brother and daughter-in-law were surplus funds from political contributions for the campaigns of her husband in two mayoral elections and two presidential elections from 1993 to 2004.
During questioning Aug. 25, Huang Jui-ching said she was used as a figurehead by her mother-in-law to open overseas bank accounts to facilitate cash deposits.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor meets with former New York mayor
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/29/08 15:31:24 (By Lillian Lin and Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin met with former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani at the latter's security consulting business in New York Thursday to exchange municipal administrative experiences.
During their nearly one-hour meeting, they discussed a wide range of issues, focusing primarily on crimefighting and municipal social welfare projects.
Giuliani, who served as mayor between 1994-2001, is widely lauded for his success in reducing the amount of crime in New York during his time in office.

He rose to international prominence for his inspirational handling of the aftermath of the 911 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center in 2001 and was named Time magazine's "Person of the Year" for that year.
Giuliani went on to run for the Republican Party's nomination for the 2008 presidential election and led in national polls for most of 2007 until his campaign faltered.
At Thursday's meeting, the former mayor praised Taiwan's democracy and asked Hau several questions on the current cross-Taiwan Strait situation.

Hau explained recent developments in cross-strait affairs, including an accord between the two sides on launching cross-strait weekend charter flights and opening Taiwan to more Chinese tourists from early July.

Hau arrived in New York Aug. 26 at the head of a delegation of city government officials and councilors for a five-day visit aimed at learning from the U.S. city's experience in waterfront urban development and municipal administration.

The delegation includes Taipei City Deputy Secretary-General Chen Yung-jen; Department of Urban Development Commissioner Ting Yu-chun; Emile C.J. Sheng, head of the city's Research, Development and Evaluation Commission; and city councilor Chiang Nai-shin.

Hau's itinerary includes meetings with New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg, as well as visits to the city council, the police, fire and technology development departments, the 311 Citizen Service Center, the Harlem urban renewal area, and the city's famous waterfront parks, including Battery Park, Hudson River Park and Brooklyn Bridge Park.
The delegation is slated to depart New York for Taiwan Aug. 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor urges president to keep promise on Chinese tourists

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu urged President Ma Ying-jeou Friday to keep his campaign promise to boost the number of Chinese tourists visiting southern Taiwan.
The mayor of the southern port city made the call just days after Uni Air announced its decision to cancel its charter services on the Kaohsiung-Guangzhou route due to low passenger numbers.

The service began July 4 with the launch of weekend charter flights under an accord signed in Beijing between the heads of Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.

In response, Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Lee Long-wen said Wednesday that the CAA does not have the authority to tell airlines what routes they should fly, pointing out that this is entirely up to the market to decide.

However, Chen claimed that the issue is not just about market forces, that negotiations on flight rights cannot just be handled by local governments, and that the Mainland Affairs Council should intervene.

According to the agreement on opening Taiwan to more Chinese tourists, which was signed at the same time as the weekend charter flights accord, a maximum of 3,000 Chinese citizens can visit Taiwan for sightseeing purposes per day.

Chen said that since early July, the actual number of Chinese tourists has been far lower than the allowed limit and she urged Ma to keep his campaign promise to help boost southern Taiwan's economy by bringing in more Chinese tourists rather than just asking local governments to work harder to attract more tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: No Taiwan stores haved applied for crab imports from China: DOH

TEXT.P: No discount chain stores or seafood companies have yet filed for permits for the import of hairy crabs from China so far this year, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) reported Friday.

As the high season for hairy crabs from China -- also known as Dazha crabs, which are considered a delicacy -- is approaching, importers should have started preparing for paperwork, including import permits and quarantine documents, to pave the way for their imports, said Hsieh Ting-hung, deputy director of the DOH Bureau of Food Safety.
No Chinese hairy crabs were imported via legal channels last year as the Chinese authorities would not issue safety documents for China's hairy crab exports to Taiwan, according to Hsieh.

After traces of cancer-causing substances were detected in crabs imported from China in 2006, the DOH began in 2007 to impose stricter entry screening measures for such imports -- measures including that official quarantine certificates must be issued by Chinese authorites to prove that hairy crabs supplied by the 42 officially-recognized Dazha crab farms in China are safe to eat, and that imports should cease if residues of cancer-causing substances are detected in three batches of crabs.
Hsieh said Taiwan will maintain the same import screening standards this year to oversee the safety of imported crabs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices mostly higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for September rose 12 points to close at 7,054, with 59,224 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October gained 10 points to finish at 7,033, with 335 contracts traded, while December futures moved down five points to close at 6,998, with 31 contract transactions.
March futures decreased two points to finish at 6,997, with nine contract transactions, while June futures advanced 72 points to close at 7,062, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 7,042 for September, 7,023 for October, 7,003 for December, 6,999 for March and 6,990 for June.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 12.74 points to finish at 7,046.11, on turnover of NT$90.86 billion (US$2.88 billion).
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

September TE futures lost 1.3 points to close at 287.4, with 4,108 contracts traded, while October TE futures decreased 2.5 points to finish at 286.05, with 10 contract transactions. December TE futures dropped 0.65 points to finish at 285.7, with five contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

September TF futures moved up 12.2 points to close at 875.2, with 3,132 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures advanced 9.4 points to finish at 867.2, with 30 contracts traded. December TF futures rose 7.8 points to end at 868.6, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese tennis players knocked out in U.S. Open
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/29/08 17:06:44 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Grace Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tennis players Lu Yen-hsun, Chan Yung-jan and Hsieh Su-wei were all knocked out in the second round of the 2008 U.S. Open Tennis Tournament Thursday, putting an end to their hopes of victory.

Although Chan and Hsieh performed well at the beginning of their matches, they quickly crumbled and lost in straight sets. Chan lost 3-6, 2-6 to Sweden's Timea Bacsinszky, while Hsieh was defeated by Russia's Nadia Petrova 4-6, 2-6.
Lu managed to hold on for longer until finally losing 1-6, 6- 4, 6-7, 4-6 to Italy's Flavio Cipolla.
Having three Taiwanese players making it into the second round set a new record for Taiwanese U.S. Open efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei bourse

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 12.74 points, or 0.18 percent, to close at 7,046.11.

Rebounding from losses of the previous day, the local bourse opened at 7,092.85 and fluctuated between 7,111.7 and 7,021.32. A total of 3.49 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$90.86 billion (US$2.88 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 2.1 percent. Plastic and chemical shares advanced 1.3 percent, banking and financial shares rose 1.2 percent, foodstuff issues gained 0.3 percent and textile stocks increased 0.2 percent.
The three other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down 0.4 percent and paper and pulp issues and construction issues both declining 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 998 to 970, with 548 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors were net sellers of shares worth NT$5.57 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
New construction head offers new pro-bicycle ideas for city traffic

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new construction head proposed during his swearing-in speech Friday that mass transport and bicycles should be prioritized before private vehicles in future urban planning decisions.

Yeh Shih-wen was sworn in by Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi as director-general of the Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interioir. Yeh is aformer deputy director-general of the ministry's Architecture and Building Research Institute.

Taking Taipei City as an example, Yeh said future road design schemes should consider scaling down car lanes to make room for parking areas and turning existing parking areas into bike lanes or pedestrian walkways.

Yeh emphasized that the controversial idea is only his personal view and the agency would have to review related regulations and communicate with the relevant authorities and local governments before anything more concrete could be proposed.
He expressed hope that the current road planning, which is done primarily with private cars as the major focus, will be changed in the future.

Yeh gave the example of London to better illustrate his thoughts. In preparation for the 2012 Olympic Games, Yeh said, the city has reduced the number of car lanes from four to two to make room for bikes and pedestrians and stipulates that private cars have to carry four people to be allowed on roads in certain areas, with a fee that must be paid to enter certain areas by car.
Road design should provide comfortable space for bike users so that more people will be encouraged to cycle to contribute to energy saving, said Yeh.
In addition, he went on, shower facilities in office buildings would allow bike riders who have sweated all the way to the office to start work dry and clean.

The agency will consider including shower facilities in office building as part of the "green architecture index" in the future, and will also communicate with the High Speed Rail System and Taipei City's Department of Rapid Transit Systems to lift restrictions on taking bikes on trains.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County fighting to protect lagoon from environmental damage

TEXT.P: A beach cleaning drive in which 120 volunteers worked to clear trash from a sandbank in the Chiku lagoon in the southern county of Tainan Aug. 24 has highlighted the environmental threat to the area.

The volunteers, mobilized by the Taipei-based Good Neighbor Foundation, engaged in two hours of training before taking boats to the sandbank to clear trash in scorching-hot weather, in the hope of restoring the lagoon's pristine beauty.
The lagoon, Taiwan's largest, is located in the county's Chiku township on the west coast of the island, and is bounded by four offshore sandbanks, covering 1,600 hectares.

"The volume of garbage on the sandbank was far greater than I had imagined, and I was surprised to discover, based on our analysis of the trash, that a lot of it had washed up there from other countries," said a volunteer known by the last name Huang.

The lagoon and its sandbanks, which serve as a natural barrier along the county's coastline and helps prevent flooding during heavy rains, host many wetland species such as crabs, oysters, and clams, and are also the winter habitat of the migratory black-faced spoonbill.
"It was heartbreaking to see such a beautiful sandbank covered with Styrofoam, all kinds of bottles and other trash, " said Lai Tung-ming, president of the foundation.
According to Chen Kun-ho, director of Chiku township's coastal protection association, manmade pollution in the area is not just an environmental problem.
"It also impacts on nearly 6,000 local fishermen's means of livelihood, Chen said.
The lagoon wetlands, abounding with flora and fauna, have been a lifeline for local residents for hundreds of years, Chen said.
Pollution is not the only threat to the wetlands. According to Chen, the shrinking of the sandbanks further overshadows the future of the lagoon's topography.

Forces of nature like wind erosion and rains brought by tropical storms are the main cause of the shrinking sandbanks, Chen said, adding that tropical storms have tended to be stronger in recent years because of dramatic global climate changes.
In an attempt to prevent erosion of the sand by northeastern winds, the volunteers in the beach cleaning drive built a bamboo fence along the sandbank.
The county government's efforts to save the lagoon's resources and topography have been in effect for many years, according to Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih.

Su said he prevented industrialization of the area 10 years ago when he was a legislator and that the county government, over the past decade, has been trying to preserve the lagoon's ecological resources by protecting the wetland species and migratory birds.

The county government also launched an annual tourism and ecology promotion activity in summer 1997 to introduce the lagoon's diverse ecology to the public in the hope of attracting more support for its preservation efforts.
People were invited to wade into the shallows to collect clams and to engage in water sports such as pedal boating and canoeing.
This year, the county government extended the activity for an additional two weeks because its popularity exceeded expectations, Su said.
The efforts of the county government to protect the lagoon has yielded some encouraging results, but the road ahead is still a long one, Su said.
"Our challenge over the next 10 years will be how to save the shrinking sandbanks and prevent the topography from disappearing, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: European lawmaker backs Taiwan's new U.N. bid
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Aug. 28 (CNA) 08/29/08 18:51:41 (By P.C. Tang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: A senior European Union lawmaker expressed full support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations' specialized agencies this year and urged the European Parliament to show goodwill toward the new bid, a Brussels-based magazine said in a report Thursday.

Center-right parliamentarian Georg Jarzembowski, chairman of the parliament's Taiwan Friendship Group, was quoted by the Parliament Magazine on its Web site as saying he "fully endorsed" Taiwan's new move.

"It is a perfectly reasonable and well-founded request and the very least China can do. After the success of the Olympics, it would represent an appropriate goodwill gesture on the part of Beijing, " he said.

Pointing out that Taiwan's inclusion in such organizations is vitally important not just for Taiwan but for the rest of the world, Jarzembowski said that Taiwan's exclusion from the WHO has been detrimental to the health rights of the 23 million people of Taiwan and foreigners residing in and traveling to Taiwan.

The World Health Organization (WHO) , the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and the International Maritime Organization (IMO) are among the 16 U.N. specialized bodies that Taiwan cites in its latest bid for meaningful participation in U.N. activities.

Taiwan failed in its previous annual bids over the past 15 years to seek full membership in the world body due to obstruction by China. China claims sovereignty over self-ruled Taiwan and vows war if necessary.

This year, Taiwan's Kuomintang (KMT) government, which took office on May 20 and favors closer ties with China, changed its strategy to focus on meaningful participation in one or more of the U.N. specialized agencies.
Two of Taiwan' 23 diplomatic allies -- St. Vincent and the Solomon Islands -- submit Taiwan's bid proposal to the U.N. Secretariat on Aug. 15.
The report also quoted Edward McMillan-Scott, a vice president of the European Parliament, the EU's legislative arm, as saying that "I still think Taiwan should push for full membership of the U.N."
Taiwan's new bid is widely seen as a crucial test to see if China accepts Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou's olive branch to have a diplomatic truce with Beijing.

Chinese Ambassador to the U.N. Wang Guangya, however, has already blasted Taiwan's diplomatic allies for striving to put Taiwan's U.N. participation bid on the agenda for the 2008 General Assembly session slated to open Sept. 16. in New York.
"As a part of China, Taiwan is not a sovereign state," Wang said in a letter dated Aug. 18 to U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon.
"The claim by a very few countries that specialized agencies should allow the Taiwan region to 'participate' in their activities under the 'principle of universality' is unfounded," he added.
On Thursday, Presidential Office Spokesman Wang Yu-chi described Wang's remarks as "an accidental situation, " which he said could not be directly interpreted as "no goodwill."
The government will not change its course on the diplomatic truce with China and will continue to push for Taiwan's participation in the international community, he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC Air Force increases mission capable rate of Mirage 2000-5s

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Air Force has significantly raised the combat readiness of its Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters, with the average mission capable rate rising to nearly 70 percent from last year's 54 percent, an Air Force general said Friday.

Briefing journalists invited to the Hsinchu Air Base in northern Taiwan to watch an air maneuver by Mirage fighters, Maj. Gen. Wang Hsuan-chou, commander of the 499th Wing of the Republic of China Air Force, attributed the improved readiness of the aircraft to an increased government budget for Air Force maintenance and supply.
The mission capable rate is used to identify the percentage of aircraft able to perform their missions. It is one of the indicators of combat readiness.

Taiwan bought 60 Mirage 2000-5s -- 48 single-seaters and 12 two-seaters -- for its Air Force from France in the late 1990s, but lost three two-seaters and one single-seater in recent years during routine training flights.

In 2007, the mission capable rates of the Mirage jet fighters dropped to 54 percent for the single-seaters and 75 percent for the two-seaters, mainly because insufficient budget appropriations in 2005 and 2006 created difficulties in acquiring parts needed for the maintenance of the fighters, according to Wang.
He expressed confidence that as the maintenance budget for next year has been increased, the mission capable rate of the Mirage fighters will be maintained at least at this year's level.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense budget for 2009 lower than this year: MND

TEXT.P: A total of NT$315.2 billion (US$10.17 billion) will be allocated as the defense budget for 2009, NT$10.4 billion lower than the 2008 level, according to a national defense budget plan published Friday.

According to the plan, which is part of a central government budget plan for next year referred to the Legislative Yuan for approval that same day, "reinforcing bilateral relations and rebuilding mutual trust with the United States" will be one of the top goals of the Ministry of National Defense (MND) next year.

The ministry will continue to push its "all voluntary forces" program next year as part of its efforts to adjust the organization of the country's defense system and the structure of the armed forces, which will be another of its priorities for 2009.
According to the defense budget plan, as of the end of this year, the number of military personnel will be reduced to a total of 275,000, including 250,000 on the regular MND payroll.

Of a five-year national defense buildup plan for 2009-2013, roughly NT$1.708 trillion is expected to be allocated by the central government as military expenditure, constituting 3 percent of the gross domestic product.
Meanwhile, the budget plan also proposes a budget of NT$325.6 billion allocated by the central government in 2009 for the procurement of necessary defensive weapons.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, increasing NT$0.041 to close at NT$31.520.
A total of US$851 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's low of NT$31.479 and closed at the day's high of NT$31.556.

DOC.HEADLINE: New ambassador to Holy See named

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to the Netherlands Larry Yu-yuan Wang will replace Tou Chou-sheng as the country's ambassador to the Holy See, according to a statement released by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Thursday.
MOFA Spokesman Henry Chen said Tou will retire after having served in the post for four years and eight months.
Tou will step down formally Sept. 15, Chen added, noting that the Holy See has approved Wang's succession.
The Holy See is the only country in Europe that maintains diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
In a CNA report from Rome, the outgoing ambassador described the ROC-Vatican relations as stable, saying the Holy See has always opened doors for Taiwan.

Tou also said that the Vatican regards the ROC as one of its best partners in international humanitarian relief programs because Taiwan has always been among the nations that first answered the Pope's call for aid to suffering people.

Although it has been the Vatican's basic policy to seek normalization of its relationship with Beijing, the Vatican will not act to pursue the ties until freedom of religion is allowed in China, Tou said. He stressed that the Holy See cares about the religious life and safety of believers in underground Catholic churches in China.

The Holy See will not tolerate Beijing's continued efforts to suppress underground churches and punish their members, as well as Beijing's attempts to organize a church that does not follow the Holy See's leadership, Tou said.

Tou, born in 1942, is the ROC's 12th ambassador to the Holy See. Before his appointment, he served in various MOFA departments and as ambassador to Senegal, which severed diplomatic ties with Taiwan in 2005. He also once served as vice minister of foreign affairs.

According to MOFA, 61-year-old Wang has served in the MOFA departments of North American affairs and protocol, and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Washington D.C. Before taking office in Holland in 2006, he was director general of the MOFA department of European affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan urged to join world heritage conservation through NGO
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/08 20:24:36 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan could collaborate with other countries in the area of world heritage preservation through non-government organizations even though the country lacks membership of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), a visiting UNESCO official said in a recent lecture in Taipei.

According to the World Heritage nomination process, only countries that have signed the World Heritage Convention can submit nomination proposals for sites on their territories to be included on UNESCO's World Heritage List.

"But this does not mean you are out of the world, " said Dieter Offenhausser, deputy secretary-general and spokesman of UNESCO's German Commission during the lecture held Thursday at the German Cultural Center in Taipei.

He encouraged Taiwan to work with non-government organizations (NGOs) in the field, such as the International Council on Monuments and Sites (ICOMOS) , an organization that aims to conserve historic monuments around the world. The CCA has been an ICOMOS member since 2003.
Taiwan would be able to draw up its own national heritage list and discuss it with international experts through cooperation of this type, he went on.
In 2003, the CCA listed 12 cultural and natural sites around Taiwan that have potential to be designated as world heritage sites.

These sites include the Taroko National Park in eastern Taiwan, renowned for its magnificent gorge, and the Yushan National Park in central Taiwan, which features Mount Jade, the highest peak in Northeast Asia.
The CCA also established the Administration of Cultural Heritage last year as part of its efforts to protect Taiwan's heritage and raise public awareness of the country's historical assets.

Besides domestic efforts, Taiwan has taken part since 2005 in a plan to restore La Antigua, an ancient city designated as a world heritage site in Guatemala, one of the 23 countries with which Taiwan has diplomatic relations.

In his lecture, Offenhausser noted that in recent years, transboundary applications filed jointly by either two or three countries tend to have been more easily approved by the World Heritage Committe.

Asked if it would be possible for Taiwan to submit a joint world heritage site nomination proposal with other countries, Offenhausser only replied that the UNESCO accepted transboudary nomination proposals among its members states.
He gave as an example the Frontiers of the Roman Empire, which was added to the World Heritage List in 1987 as the result of a collaboration between Germany and Britain.
To date, the UNESCO World Heritage List includes 878 sites, covering 679 cultural, 174 natural and 25 mixed ones, considered by the World Heritage Committee as having outstanding universal value.

DOC.HEADLINE: First indigenous measles case reported this year

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced Friday Taiwan's first case of indigenous measles this year, saying that the patient was a 10-month old baby girl who had been infected by a family member who recently returned from an overseas trip.

Chou Jih-haw, deputy director general of DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said that the 25-year-old male family member, from northern Taiwan, had visited Thailand for business between July 26 and July 30. After his return, he sought medical treatment, complaining of muscle pains, and was diagnosed with tonsillitis, Chou related.

Shortly after the man returned home, he developed a skin rash and a fever -- typical symptoms of measles. As the symptoms persisted, he was forced to check into a hospital, which confirmed that he had measles -- the sixth imported case this year, according to Chou.
Chou said that six adults and two children -- a three-year-old and the 10-month- old baby girl -- live with the man.
A check of the family found that, to date, only the baby girl has contracted measles. On Aug 19. she was found to have a skin rash, fever, cough, inertia and was vomiting, he disclosed.
The MMR vaccine against measles, mumps and rubella is still "the most effective way to prevent measles," Chou said.
Children should be given the first dose at between 12 months and 15 months, and the second dose in the first grade of elementary school, he advised.
"Overall, the MMR inoculation rate is as high as 95 percent," he said, noting that indigenous cases of measles have been rare in Taiwan in recent years.

People who wish to travel to China, Southeast Asia, Japan or Europe, where there are currently risk of measles outbreak, can pay to have the measles vaccine if they are not sure whether or not they have immunity or if they wish to take children under one year of age there, he suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: Domestic oil prices hiked by NT$0.5 per liter

TEXT.P: The state-run oil refiner CPC Corp., Taiwan (CPC) announced Friday that it will raise its prices of gasoline and diesel by NT$0.5 per liter, effective midnight.

Under the change, the price of 92-octane unleaded gasoline will rise to NT$32.8 per liter, while that of 95-octane unleaded will be NT$33.5 per liter and that of 98-octane unleaded will go up to NT$35 per liter.
The super diesel price will increase to NT$30.6 per liter.

It is the first time fuel prices have been hiked since the CPC adopted a floating pricing mechanism Aug. 7 that reviews prices on a weekly basis based on fluctuations in the prices of Dubai and Brent crude oil as quoted on Platts, a leading global provider of energy information.
Formosa Petrochemical Co., the country's only private petroleum company, also took similar action, raising gasoline and diesel prices by NT$0.5 per liter from midnight that day.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC head to highlight Taiwan's wish for more international space
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug.28 (CNA) 08/29/08 21:00:06 (By Jorge Liu and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top China policy coordinator said here Thursday that one of the major objectives of her trip to the United States is to convey President Ma Ying- jeou's determination to expand Taiwan's international space.
Lai Shin-yuan, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), is visiting Washington, D.C. in a bid to publicize Taiwan's stance on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Lai said that before her departure, Ma asked her to tell Washington that, for Taiwan's new government, expanding the nations's international space is as important as improving cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Lai said the Taiwan government's national policies are being developed based on public opinion. Therefore, the government has to address the issue of expanding Taiwan's international space, no matter how big the challenge, as there is a wide domestic consensus on this matter, she added.

She expressed the hope that Washington will assist Taiwan in this area, and called on China to respect the Taiwan people's will and stop blocking Taiwan's efforts to participate in international organizations.
Lai was referring to an objection by China's Ambassador to the U.N., Wang Guangya, to Taiwan's bid to access U.N.'s specialized agencies.
Wang stated in a letter to the U.N. secretary-general Aug. 18 that China opposes Taiwan's bid because Taiwan is part of China, not a sovereign state eligible to join U.N.-affiliated organizations.
But Lai said Taiwan and China have experience of each participating in international organizations, such as the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum and the World Trade Organization.

This experience has allowed the two sides to minimize misunderstandings and avoid conflicts, Lai said, adding that relations between the two sides will benefit from an expanded role by Taiwan in other international bodies.

Asked whether Taiwan will be able to join the World Health Assembly -- the World Health Organization's decision making body -- as an observer next May, Lai said this is hard to forecast as Taiwan and China need more time to put more issues on the negotiation table.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier pushes for comprehensive sports planning

TEXT.P: Premier Liu Chao-shiuan has given a directive for the Cabinet- level Sports Affairs Council (SAC) to come up with mid- and long-term plans for the training of athletes.

Liu made the request Thursday after the SAC gave a review of the national Olympic team's participation in the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games and the SAC's vision for the future of sports in Taiwan, at a regular Cabinet meeting.
According to Liu, the national team's performance in the 2008
Beijing Olympics -- winning four bronze medals -- indicates a need to reform the country's physical education system and its training of athletes.

Liu suggested that for the country's athletes to perform better in international events, it would require a breakthrough in sports training systems, strategies, management, quality of coaches and athletes' long-term planning.
Liu designated Minister without Portfolio Ovid J. L. Tzeng to supervise the plan, with the assistance of the SAC and the Ministry of Education.
He said that the plan should focus on the training and care of athletes, refurbishing sports equipment, developing key-point sports items and schools, and nurturing sports coaches.

According to Liu, the nurturing of athletes and a sports environment calls for time and a long-term commitment to hard work. The SAC should cooperate with local governments to promote exercise and gradually shape Taiwan into a "sport- loving island, " he suggested.
"Though the team did not meet the people's expectations in the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games, their efforts and spirit are still worthy of a big round of applause from us," said Liu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Atmospheric phenomenon 'elf' more frequent than 'sprite': survey

TEXT.P: The occurrence rate of the high-altitude atmospheric phenomenon "elve" was found to be at least eight times that of another luminous event called "sprite," academic sources said Friday, citing the results of a three-year survey.
The findings contradicted an existing hypothesis that sprites are the most prominent phenomena among all "transient luminous events, " they added.

The group of U.S., Japanese, and Taiwanese scientists who conducted the survey also discovered that most elves -- rapidly expanding disk-shaped flashes -- occur over the sea, while sprites -- large yet weak flashes above active thunderstorm systems -- mainly congregate over land.

The "hotspots" of elves are found over the Caribbean Sea, South China Sea, east Indian Ocean, central Pacific Ocean, west Atlantic Ocean, and southwest Pacific Ocean, while sprite hotspots are found over central Africa, around the Japan Sea, and regions close to the west Atlantic Ocean, the academics said in an interview with the news service of the weekly New Scientist.

"Elves may have an important global effect on the lower ionosphere and the total electron content, " said Alfred Bing-chin Chen, a team member and an assistant professor at National Cheng Kung University.
"Elf hotspots may increase the electron density of the ionosphere by five percent or more, which could interfere with ground and space communication as well as navigation systems, " he added.

Using a piece of equipment called the Imager of Sprites and Upper Atmospheric Lightning (ISUAL) on board the FORMOSAT-2 satellite, the team's original goal was to observe and better understand the polar aurora, upper atmospheric airglow, and lightning-induced atmospheric flashes -- especially sprites.

"But in the end, we found many more elves instead, " said Chen, adding that in the three years of observation, from July 2004 to June 2007, some 5,434 elves were spotted around the globe, while only 633 sprites were seen.
The team also recorded 657 halos and 13 gigantic jets, both of which are also transient luminous events that occur in the upper atmosphere or lower ionosphere.
According to the team, the elve occurrence rate will rise sharply once the sea surface temperature exceeds 26 degrees Celsius.
"A warm ocean surface can provide the heat source needed to drive intense oceanic lightning with very high peak currents, which usually generate elves in the ionosphere," Chen said.
Meanwhile, Chen said that the sprites require lightning with a higher overall charge, and since such lightening mostly occurs over the land, sprites are more frequently found there.

DOC.HEADLINE: NGOs seek to fund after-school classes for underprivileged children

TEXT.P: About 160,000 underprivileged children in Taiwan encounter difficulties with their school work due to deficiencies in the family, the Eden Social Welfare Foundation and the Global Views Monthly said Friday, urging people to donate and "give underprivileged children a chance."
Underprivileged children are defined as children aged 6 to 12, from single- parent, recomposed, divorced, cross-generational or low-income families.
The lack of economic or family support can easily lead to academic under- achievement or even personality defects among these children, according to the Global Views Monthly.

The magazine and the foundation cited the example of Wang Yi-hsiung, a young boy in central Taiwan who recently received an award from his elementary school principal for his outstanding academic performance.
Three years ago, the child, who is from a single-parent family, had fallen into the habit of fooling around on the streets, they said.

One day, after he got into a street fight, Chue Dai Shu-wei, a pastor's wife, took him home and began to help him with his lessons. This was the beginning of the child's road to academic excellence, Chue Dai indicated.

"All social problems result from family issues, " said Chue Dai, adding that her after-school class is not just a place for her 40 students to learn and review their school work, but also provides a sense of family..

"When children get good grades, they will have confidence and dignity, and after-school classes will be more than just extra lessons," said Wang Li-hsing, publisher of the Global Views Monthly, at a press conference.

In order to give Taiwan's 160,000 underprivileged children a chance, a NT$10 million target has been set in a fundraising program aimed at funding community organizations, such as churches and community development associations, to provide children with free or low-lost after-school assistance, the magazine and the Eden Foundation said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan comfortable with thawing Taiwan-China ties: KMT vice chair

TEXT.P: Japan responded positively to Taiwan's recent efforts to improve its ties with China and viewed them as conducive to peace in Asia, Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said Friday.
Chiang made the remarks at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport upon his return earlier in the day from a visit to Japan Aug. 25-27.
Chiang's visit was aimed at helping Japanese politicians better understand Taiwan's new KMT government 's diplomatic policy.
Japan has had concerns that Taiwan might ignore its close ties with Tokyo as President Ma Ying-jeou has been focusing on shoring up ties with China.
China considers Taiwan a local province and has vowed war if the self-ruled island moves towards formal independence.
During his Japan visit, Chiang gave a speech to the country's business sector on the prospects of relations across the Taiwan Strait and met with Japan's major political parties and groups.

Chiang, who is also head of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) that handles cross-strait exchanges with China in the absence of official ties, said Japan had responded positively to the new developments in the relations between Taiwan and China.

For example, Taro Aso, secretary-general of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, responded positively to Ma's cross-strait policy and said he believed Taiwan's pragmatic policy would help maintain peace in Asia, Chiang related.
Chiang also said that Japan welcomed Taiwan's appointment of veteran diplomat John Feng as its new representative to Japan.
Meanwhile, Chiang said, he also discussed future cooperation with Japanese companies.
Some Japanese companies suggested that it would be the best if Taiwanese enterprises collaborated with Japanese firms to develop business in China, he said.

On the fishery talks between Taiwan and Japan, Chiang said he told Japanese officials that he hoped both sides would soon complete the talks by shelving political issues and focusing on economic matters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's budget for secret diplomatic missions cut by 6%

TEXT.P: Taiwan has slashed its proposed 2009 annual budget for secret diplomatic missions, in light of the President Ma Ying-jeou's policy of seeking a diplomatic "truce" with China.
In its 2009 budget plan, released Friday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) cut the allocations for secret diplomacy to NT$3.8 billion (US$120.4 million) from the previous year's NT$5.7 billion.
The 2009 budget for secret missions was slashed from the previous year's 12 percent to 6 percent of the MOFA's total diplomatic allocations, said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen.
"We believe that the cut is what the Legislative Yuan would expect," he added.

Given that the new administration's diplomatic policy is focused on solidifying Taiwan's relations with its 23 diplomatic allies, it is logical for the MOFA to reduce the budget that was used to entice other countries to establish diplomatic relations with Taiwan, Chen said.

The MOFA's budget plan for 2009 focuses on solidifying ties with Taiwan's existing diplomatic allies, deepening friendship and cooperative relations with countries that have no diplomatic ties with Taiwan, making active efforts to join international organizations, and expanding humanitarian relief work in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chairman of Far Eastern Group acquitted in Pacific Sogo trial

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court on Friday acquitted Far Eastern Group chairman Douglas Hsu of charges of forgery and breach of trust in the ownership transfer of Pacific Sogo Department Store in 2002.

The court ruled that Hsu did not obtain ownership of Pacific Sogo through the help of then first lady Wu Shu-jen because his meeting with her at the presidential residence came after the ownership transfer.
Two other defendants -- lawyer Huang Mao-teh and financial consultant Champion Lee -- were also acquitted.

The court, however, sentenced Walter Lin, former chief of Waterland Financial Holding Co., to two years in prison on charges of breach of trust because he had not only failed to fulfill his promise to help the former Pacific Sogo owner to obtain bank loans, but had done exactly the opposite to hurt his interests.

Pacific Group former Chairman Chang Min-chiang, who claimed that he had lost Pacific Sogo in a scam and was still counting on a civil lawsuit for justice, expressed regret over the court rulings. He urged the prosecutors to appeal the case in order to let the truth prevail.
"If Lin is guilty, how come the person who took over Pacific Sogo from him is not guilty?" Chang asked.
In October 2006, Taipei prosecutors indicted the four men on charges of forgery and breach of trust in the ownership fight over Pacific Sogo -- one of Taiwan's most successful department stores.

In a separate civil action still pending in the Taiwan High Court, Chang is trying to have 600,000 shares in the Pacific Distribution Investment Co., which owned Pacific Sogo, returned to him from his former landlord, Lee Heng-lung, who was deputy chairman of the Pacific Group at the time.

Chang said he had entrusted the shares to Lee in May 2002 after Lee and Lin promised to help him get bank loans to tide Pacific Sogo over financial difficulties caused by a flood in the typhoon season of 2001.

Lee became chairman of Pacific Distribution Investment after the shares were transferred to him. However, instead of helping Chang to obtain the needed loans, Lee and Lin stripped Chang of his ownership of Pacific Sogo and replaced the entire management team.

Sensing that Lee and Lin might have ulterior motives, Chang began to let the word out that he wanted to sell Pacific Sogo. Tsai Chen-yang, head of My Humble House Group, was among the first to respond, offering to buy the department store for NT$10 billion (US$317 million). But Lin and Lee, who were in full control of Pacific Sogo then, rejected the offer, saying that someone at "a high level" had a specific buyer in mind.
The ownership fight became a tug-of-war among several business leaders, with each claiming to have the support of either the Presidential Office or the first lady.
Chang claimed that Lee and Lin sold Pacific Sogo to Hsu by signing a secret agreement in September 2002.

The secret agreement came to light in 2006 after Lee claimed that the Pacific Sogo deal had not yet been completed because Hsu had not fulfilled his part of the agreement by giving Lee 33 percent of the department store's shares -- estimated to be worth more than NT$15 billion.

Lee insisted in the High Court that it was Pacific Sogo, rather than Chang, that had entrusted the 600,000 shares of Pacific Distribution to him. He maintained that there was no written trust agreement between him and Chang regarding the transfer of the shares and that Chang had no right to them.
The High Court is scheduled to announce its ruling on the case next January.

Throughout the court proceedings, there was wide media publicity of allegations that the former first lady had been given millions of dollars-worth of Pacific Sogo gift vouchers during the ownership fight over the department store.

Taipei prosecutors, however, did not indict the former first lady because they said in a report that although Wu, her daughter and son had spent NT$277,000 worth of gift vouchers they had obtained from Lee, there was insufficient evidence to prove she had played any role in the Sogo ownership transfer deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education, R&D spending will take lion's share of 2009 budget

TEXT.P: Education, science-technology research and cultural development will take the lion's share of the government's budget for 2009, according to a Cabinet-drafted budget plan referred to the Legislative Yuan Friday for screening and approval.

The draft budget plan allocates NT$343 billion (US$10.96 billion) for education, research and cultural spending for the coming year, accounting for 18.5 percent of the government's total annual budget.
The amount marks an 8.4 percent increase from the 2008 level and the ratio registers a marginal growth of 0.2 percentage point.
The ratio surpasses that of the defense budget for 2009, which will account for 17.2 percent of the total, ranking third in the government's various spending items.

Social welfare spending comes in second in terms of the ratio to the total annual budget, accounting for 17.9 percent of the total and marking an increase of 0.5 percentage points from this year's ratio.
In terms of amount, social welfare budget is projected at NT$327.5 billion, up 9.8 percent from the current level.
In contrast, defense budget for 2009 will decrease 3.2 percent to NT$315.2 billion. In 2008, defense spending accounts for 19 percent of the government's total budget.

According to the draft budget plan, the government projects its tax revenues at NT$1.75 trillion and expenditures at NT$1.83 trillion. As a result, the government will have to issue state bonds in the coming year to make its ends meet.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma urges China to dismantle missiles in interview with L'espresso
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Aug. 29 (CNA) 08/29/08 23:58:50 (By Huang Kwang-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has appealed to China in a recent interview with an Italian weekly to remove its bulk of missiles targeting Taiwan as a gesture of good will to facilitate detente across the Taiwan Strait.

Speaking in the interview in Taipei with L'espresso, Ma said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should seriously consider reconciliation and peaceful solution to their disputes after many decades of confrontation.
As Taiwan is unwilling to negotiate a cross-strait peace agreement under the threat of a Chinese missile attack, Ma said Beijing should first dismantle its missiles targeted at Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 30, 2008

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 30, or the 30th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
30 B.C.: Mark Antony, the ruler of the eastern part of the Roman Empire, commits suicide at the court of his lover, Cleopatra, queen of Egypt, who later commits suicide by allowing an asp to bite her breast.
1483: Louis XI, king of France who was responsible for the unification of his country after the Hundred Years War, dies and is succeeded by his son, Charles VIII.
1862: Thomas Jonathan Jackson, known as "Stonewall," American Confederate general, leads his forces to victory against the Union Army at the Second Battle of Bull Run in Virginia. He was accidentally killed by his own troops at Chancellorvile in 1863.
1901: The vacuum cleaner is patented by Scotsman Hubert Cecil Booth.
1916: Turkey declares war on Romania.
1918: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, known as "Nikolai Lenin," first head of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, is shot and wounded by Fanya Kaplan and her sister Dora in Moscow.
1928: Jawaharlal Nehru founds the Independence of India League.
1932: Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Nazi politician and military leader, is elected president of the German Reichstag. He was responsible for the buildup of the German air force, directed Germany's wartime economy and was designated Hitler's successor in 1939.
1937: American boxer Joe Louis flattens Britain's Tommy Farr to win the heavyweight title at Madison Square Garden in New York.
1940: Sir Joseph John Thomson, British physicist, dies at the age of 84. He won a Nobel Prize in 1906 for investigating the electrical conductivity of gases.
1945: Hong Kong is liberated when the British Navy under Rear Adm. Cecil Harcourt sails into Victoria harbor to accept the Japanese surrender.
1949: The Southeast China Governor's Office, which was established in Taipei on Aug. 15, appoints Gen. Sun Li-jen as commander-in-chief of the Taiwan Garrison Command.
1958: Mainland China's Resolution Concerning the Establishment of People's Communes in the Rural Areas is promulgated. In a period of less then three months, 26,578 people's communes involving 127 million peasant household were established all over the mainland.
1963: The "hot line," a direct telephone line between the White House and the Kremlin linking the US president with the Soviet leader, becomes operational.
1974: A bomb planted by leftist guerrillas explodes in the main office of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries at Marunouchi in Tokyo, killing eight people and injuring 376 others.
1979: Ding Mou-shih, former vice minister of Foreign Affairs, leaves for Seoul to assume his post as ROC ambassador to the Republic of Korea.
1981: Muhammad Ali Rajai, president of Iran, and his prime minister, Mohammed Javad Bahonar, become victims of a bomb planted in the premier's office in Teheran.
1981: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives US Senator John Glenn.
1988: Republic of China-US talks on finance and banking open in Washington. The ROC negotiators agree to open the Taiwan market to credit card companies and to expand credit for foreign banks.
1989: Guatemalan President Marco Vincicio Cerezo Arevalo arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1990: Chien Mu, a great master in the study of Chinese classics, dies in Taipei at the age of 96.
1991: Azerbaijan declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1999: New Salvadoran Ambassador Francisco Ricardo Santana Berrios presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew leaves Taipei for Los Angeles en route to Panama to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mireya Moscoso on Sept. 1 as the special envoy of President Lee Teng-hui.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian receives Brisbane Mayor Jim Soorley, and welcomes his visit aimed at strenthening exchanges between the ROC and Australia.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is truth, there is intelligence; where there is intelligence, there is truth."
