DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
EPA advises against barbecuing during Mid-Autumn Festival

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) on Saturday urged the public to take pleasure in the beauty of the moon, instead of focusing on having barbecues during the Mid-Autumn Festival, which falls on Sept. 14 this year.

Chang Shun-chin, a senior technical specialist at the EPA's Department of Environmental Monitoring and Information Management, noted that the festival has become a national barbecue day, which he said is disastrous to the environment.

EPA statistics show that the air quality around the island is usually poor during the Mid-Autumn Festival, and the huge volume of of garbage that accumulates during the festival period continues to be a nagging problem.

Chang urged the public to "return to the core of the festival"-- an occasion for family reunions and a time for family members and friends to chat and eat delicious mooncakes and pomelos while appreciating the beauty of the full moon.

He cited 2006 statistics, saying that barbecues that year contributed to 32 percent of the carbon monoxide concentration, 14 percent of the nitrogen oxidant concentration, and 11 percent of the suspended particles in the air on the festival day.

Barbecuing also undermines the nation's efforts to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, he said, noting that the EPA has estimated that if a family of four burns 1 kg of charcoal during a two-hour period, this will produce 3.7 kilograms of carbon dioxide. If 30 percent of the nation's population hold barbecues, this will result in nearly 6,400 tons of carbon dioxide, he added.

He recalled that during a "lights out day" activity June 21, more than 130,000 residents around Taiwan went outdoors to lend support to a campaign to mark the annual summer solstice in an eco-friendly way.

This helped to cut carbon dioxide emissions by 178 tons, which means that "a total of 36 lights-out activities would be needed to offset the volume of carbon dioxide produced during the Mid-Autumn Festival," he said.

Discarded peripheral barbecue supplies, such as grills, paper plates and disposal chopsticks also create an extra workload for cleaners, the EPA said, adding that barbecues are also harmful to public health.
Yuan Shao-ying, director of the EPA's Department of Environmental Sanitation and Toxic Substance Management, said it has been confirmed that burning charcoal produces the carcinogen PAHs.
The charcoal sold in Taiwan markets is mostly from China and other Southeast Asian countries and is of substandard quality, which means it could produce higher concentrations of PAHs, Yuan warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait situation different from that in Georgia: president
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Aug. 30 (CNA) 08/30/08 14:13:29 (By Huang Kwang-chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou told an Italian weekly magazine that the situation across the Taiwan Strait is different from that of Georgia and Russia, thanks to thawing ties with China and the U.S. commitment to helping Taiwan maintain adequate defense capability.

Ma made the remarks when asked by L'espresso if the fact that the United States sat by and watched the Russian occupation of Georgian territory was an indication the U.S. cannot protect its lesser allies.
The interview was conducted Aug. 22 in Taipei and was published Friday in the latest issue of the magazine.
Ma said the policy choice by the United States in dealing with the Georgia issue is not new, and pointed out that Washington responded similarly to Russia's attack on Chechnya in the 1990s.
However, the cross-strait situation is different, Ma argued.

He noted that the Taiwan Relations Act enacted by the United States in 1979 is a piece of formal legislation under which the United States makes available items necessary for Taiwan to maintain adequate defense capability.

Furthermore, over the past 20 years, a wide-ranging socio-economic network has been established across the Taiwan Strait, which is sufficient to repair any form of hostility between the two sides, according to the president.
Both sides have also expressed the desire to forge a peace treaty if possible, he said.
He said it is time for Taiwan and China to seriously consider working out a peaceful resolution to their differences after decades of confrontation.
Ma renewed his proposal that China remove its missiles targeted at Taiwan as a gesture of goodwill to pave the way for cross-strait peace talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP to visit Swaziland as special envoy

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew will visit Swaziland as special envoy on behalf of President Ma Ying-jeou to attend a dual celebration in the southern African ally in September, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official said Friday.
Swaziland will celebrate its 40th founding anniversary and also the 40th birthday of its King Mswati III Sept. 6.

Siew and Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou, at the head of a delegation, will depart Taiwan Sept. 4 for Swaziland, where they will join the leaders of many African states such as Uganda, Rwanda, Angola, Botswana, and Mozambique in the celebrations.

Siew will meet with Mswati III to exchange views on bilateral cooperation as well as pay a courtesy call on the king's mother Indlovukazi Ntombi. The vice president will visit Taiwan's embassy in Swaziland and meet with medical care and technology aid groups in the African country, according to the official.

Siew's itinerary also includes meetings in Swaziland with Taiwanese businesspeople based in other African countries, such as South Africa and Lesotho, to gain a better understanding of their lives to learn more about their investments there.
Siew and his delegation will leave Swaziland Sept. 7 and arrive in Taiwan the following day, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yilan picked to host 2009 Taiwan Lantern Festival

TEXT.P: Yilan County has won the right to host the 2009 Taiwan Lantern Festival, a county official said late Friday night.

Yiu Wen-hsiang, head of the county government's Department of Business and Tourism, said that the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Tourism Bureau has chosen the Yilan Sports Park in Yilan City as the site of next year's festival to be held in February.

The bureau launched the Taiwan Lantern Festival in 1990 to foster local culture and bring the traditions of Taiwan onto the international stage. Since its launch, the festival has grown to become one of Taiwan's largest and internationally best-known tourism events.
Yiu said that Yilan Magistrate Lu Kuo-hua had been actively striving since early this year for the eastern county to win the right to hold the festival.
Lu sent a group of county officials to the 2008 festival held in Solar City, Southern Taiwan Science Park in Tainan County to learn more about hosting such an event, according to Yiu.

The county magistrate also recently led a delegation on a visit to the Tourism Bureau to promote its bid, Yiu said, adding that Yilan was able to beat out bids by four other counties, namely Hsinchu, Taoyuan, Nantou and Changhua.

The Yilan Sports Park was chosen because it met the Tourism Bureau's requirements that the site of the festival should have at least 1,500 parking spaces, a road of at least 400 meters in length and 15 meters in width for the staging of the event's float parade, as well as adequate shuttle bus services.

The park also met the bureau's requirement that the area in the vicinity of the festival site have sufficient lodging, Yiu said, noting that Yilan City has over 8,000 hotel rooms available to meet the accommodation needs of visitors to the festival.
According to Yiu, Lu welcomes the holding of such a major national festival in Yilan and hopes that it will help promote the eastern county's tourism industry and give a boost to the local economy.

Yiu further said that Premier Liu Chao-shiuan is expected to formally announce Yilan Sports Park as the site of next year's Taiwan Lantern Festival, during a visit to the county Saturday to inspect local building projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: Meals for seniors potentially big industry: EPD

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) is encouraging people to invest in the business of food service for seniors, reasoning that the industry has great potential, according to a statement released by the council late Friday.
The statement pointed out thatin 2007, citizens over the age of 65 accounted for more than 10 percent of the population, which indicates a move toward an aging society.

In light of this situation, the Executive Yuan launched a program last year to provide long-term care to disabled and low-income seniors, but the program does not cover the needs of all senior citizens, the CEPD said.

Citing data from a recent survey conducted by the Ministry of the Interior on the lives of seniors in the country, the CEPD noted that 35 percent of people over the age of 65 live alone or with their spouses. Some 62 percent of the respondents, between 50-64 years old, said they think that the service of providing nutritious food to the elderly is important, the council added.

This potential market, coupled with higher buying power of seniors in the future thanks to the national pension insurance system that will take effect in October, will make it worthwhile to invest in the industry of food service for seniors, the council projected.
People who are interested in developing this type of business can learn from the experience of the Hondao Senior Citizen's Welfare Foundation in Taichung City, the CEPD advised.

The foundation, on a CEPD commission, designed meal boxes specifically for senior customers. The light and nutritious meals turned out to be quite popular, drawing customers who ranged from 90-year-old grandmothers to office workers, the CEPD said.
The care shown by the delivery staff is another reason why the elderly appreciate the service so much, the council added.
The council suggested that people work with social welfare groups, related college departments and local diners to come up with more creative ideas for a business model.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Vision, If Kids Theater teach children self-protection

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan and If Kids Theater have teamed up to stage play on an islandwide tour to teach children how to protect themselves from abuse.

The organizations held a press conference at the Taipei Youth Activity Center Saturday afternoon to announce the launch of the tour, with Ministry of the Interior Children's Bureau Director Chien Hui-chuan and several young T.V stars participating.

After staging the play at the center's performance hall Saturday afternoon and night, the troupe will hit the road to perform at 40 locations around the island over the coming weeks to teach children how to avoid domestic abuse and how to respond if they fall victim to such abuse. One of the options advocated is to call the 113 hotline for counseling.

The play is about a young girl who, after being physically abused by her father, retreats into a fantasy world where she pretends to be a princess imprisoned in a tower by a fire-breathing dragon and awaiting rescue by a handsome prince.
The hero in the story is a bear who teaches the young girl how to muster the courage and properly face the dragon, which represents domestic violence.
The morale of the story, which is that the rescuer is actually the young girl herself, teaches children the importance of self-protection.

In addition to the performance tour, World Vision Taiwan is releasing a 15-minute DVD of a puppet show about children who face neglect, physical abuse and psychological abuse, and the proper response measures to end such mistreatment.
The non-profit organization is also releasing a set of four comic books with similar themes to teach children how to protect themselves.

World Vision urged educators around the country to contact the organization by phone or email to borrow copies of the DVDS and comics for their schools to help spread the message to all young children in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma helps promote mooncakes made by social welfare organizations

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou urged the public Saturday to buy mooncake gift boxes made by social welfare organizations, as the Mid-autumn Festival is two weeks away and the sale of the mooncakes made by these groups has been particularly slow this year.

"If we buy mooncakes made by the underprivileged and offer them to other underprivileged people, such as the elderly and children housed in care centers, that will be double assistance," said Ma at a press conference held jointly by 21 social welfare organizations.

He also promised that the Presidential Office will set an example by purchasing 4,200 boxes of the mooncakes. Other government agencies under the Executive Yuan will be also be encouraged to buy the mooncakes made by the social welfare groups, he added.

The Mid-Autumn Festival will fall on Sept.14 this year. The sale of mooncake gift boxes has become in recent years one of the major economic resources for social welfare organizations that care for mentally and physically challenged people and those with Down syndrome.

However, this year, sales have been slower as people are more reluctant to spend money, due to the economic downturn and a crowded-out effect regarding donations following the May 12 earthquake in Sichuan, China, the organizations said.

According to Tsui Pin, director of the Eden Social Welfare Foundation's public relations department, some enterprises that used to place mooncake orders have hesitated this year on grounds that they have made donations to people in the disaster areas in China.
The Mainland Affairs Council said recently that Taiwan has donated more than NT$1 billion (US$32 million) to survivors of the earthquake in China.
To help promote the sale of mooncakes made by underprivileged people, Premier Liu Chao-shiuan and Interior Minister Liao Liou-yi have been actively involved in advertising campaigns.

The organizations said they have tried hard to keep the sale prices at the same level as last year -- even though the cost of raw materials has risen -- for fear that their customers might hesitate to buy this year.

"This is the 12th year that we are making mooncakes for sale, Su Kuo-chen, executive director of the Children Are Us Foundation said recently. "We will continue to make mooncakes under the pressure of soaring costs, in order to give these children with Down syndrome a chance. "

DOC.HEADLINE: Local government heads brainstorm on tourism promotion

TEXT.P: Administrators of four cities and counties in central Taiwan proposed Saturday to allow Chinese visitors to Kinmen, an outlying island close to China southern coast, to fly to Taiwan proper via the Kinmen-Taichung air route, in the hope of attracting more Chinese tourists to the central region.

The proposal was raised at a meeting in Taichung City among Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng, Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan and Nantou County Magistrate Lee Chao-ching.

Hu convened the meeting to brainstorm on measures to attract more Chinese tourists to central Taiwan, as the direct charter air route between Taichung and Xiamen, southern China, has been inactive since the July 4 grand launch of charter flight services between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

President Ma Ying-jeou, who has introduced polices for broader cross-strait exchanges and advocated an end to the decades of tensions between the two sides, has expressed concern over the low demand for the weekend direct charter flights, Hu said.
Hu related that Ma had called him to voice concern over the matter and to ask that local government heads make an effort to boost the tourism-oriented flight services.

During their discussions, the four local government leaders outlined plans to improve the cross-strait direct flight services and upgrade the facilities at the Taichung Ching Chuang Kang Airport, according to Hu.

The mayor said many tour and hotel operators in central Taiwan, which boasts green forests and scenic mountains, hope that Chinese tourists who visit Kinmen via the "mini three-links" would be permitted to travel further afield to the central region.
Hu also said that some shipping businesses have been advocating the launch of direct passenger boat services between Xiamen and Taichung.
"It would take only four hours to travel by sea from Xiamen to Taichung Harbor," Hu said.

The admission of larger numbers of Chinese tourists to Taiwan is regarded as a possible stimulus to the sluggish local economy, and the mainland is seen as a vast market for Taiwan's agricultural products.

At the meeting Saturday, Hu proposed that the four cities and counties make inroads into Macau, a special administrative region of China, with their distinctive farm products. They four municipalities have therefore decided to organize a promotional delegation to Macau in December, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'People's Outcry' march held in downtown Taipei

TEXT.P: A protest march was held Saturday in Taipei City with the participation of top members of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , including party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen.
Reiterating that the central purpose of the march was to "defend Taiwan's sovereignty, " Chen said "Taiwanese want to cry out loud their depression."

The march was followed by a rally on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office, where tens of thousands of protesters shouted slogans against policies introduced by President Ma Ying-jeou during his first 100 days in office.
Chen said the demonstrators denounced the Ma administration's "unilateral" promotion a "diplomatic truce" in the longstanding confrontation with China, which sees Taiwan as part of its territory.
Chen described Ma's approach as a sellout of Taiwan's sovereignty.

The march also attracted several other prominent figures such as former Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen and his wife, World United Formosans for Independence (WUFI) Chairman Ng Chiau-tong, DPP Legislators Chai Trong-rong and Kao Jyh-Peng, former DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and former DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung.

The march, called "The People's Outcry, " was organized by the pro-independence Taiwan Society to highlight its call for the protection of Taiwan's sovereignty, improvement of the economy and the enactment of sunshine laws.
Society President Wu Shuh-min complained in public last week that the Ma administration, which is keen to make progress on resolving cross-strait issues, has yielded too much to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vietnam Culture Festival to be held in Taipei

TEXT.P: The Department of Labor under the Taipei city government will hold a Vietnam Culture Festival Sunday in Taipei, with the aim of inviting Vietnamese workers, spouses and local residents to celebrate Vietnam's Independence Day.

In an expression of gratitude to these workers for their contribution to the city and in celebration of Vietnam's Independence Day on Sept. 2, the Taipei City Government will host the event from 11:30 Sunday at the 228 Memorial Park, the Department of Labor stated in a press release.

A series of activities, such as a competition to wrap spring rolls and dance and singing performances, will be staged to pay tribute to Vietnamese expatriates and to help Taiwanese people learn more about neighboring cultures, the department said.

The event was organized under an annual program to highlight Southeast Asian cultures. The Thailand Culture Festival was held in April on the occasion of the "Songkran, " and the Filipino Culture Festival was held in June to celebrate the Philippines Independence Day.
According to the Department of Labor, more than 5,000 Vietnamese work in Taipei, mostly as caregivers, among a total of 37, 000 foreign workers in the city.
Statistics from the Ministry of the Interior show that a total of 125,000 Vietnamese, including 69,000 workers, were living in Taiwan as of the end of 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung Harbor proposed as free trade area

TEXT.P: Local government heads in central Taiwan proposed Saturday that a free trade area be set up at Taichung Harbor in Taichung County to attract foreign investment.
The proposal was made at a regular meeting of the local heads in response to a request by a Japanese trading enterprise, Itochu Corp., Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu disclosed.
Itochu Corp.'s representative in Taiwan had expressed the hope that a free trade zone could be established in central Taiwan to create a convenient investment hub, Hu said.

Itochu Corp. deals in products in various industries such as textiles, machinery, information and communications, metals, oil and other energy sources, general merchandise, chemicals, and provisions and food. It has 17 domestic and 139 overseas offices.

Hu said Itochu has invested heavily in China and that a free trade area in Taiwan would allow it to save logistics costs between China and Japan. The area would also create great business opportunities for central Taiwan, and thus benefit all three countries, Hu said.

He said the newly developed Central Taiwan Science Park and the weekend direct charter flight service between Taiwan and China that began in July are mainly what prompted Itochu to look at central Taiwan as a potential free trade area.
Lai Ying-hsi, director-general of Taichung County's Department of Construction, said the Taichung Harbor will be a good free-trade location, given its size and convenient marine transportation.
Investors can also utilize the air services at the Taichung Airport which is near the port and is located within the county, Lai said.

Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan said that many foreign enterprises may hesitate to invest in a free trade zone, as the current regulations stipulate that at least 5 percent of a foreign company's workers must be aboriginal.
Cho suggested that the central government study the possibility of revising this regulation in order to create an investment environment that would be more favorable to foreign enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: New measures adopted to ensure safety of Sun Moon Lake swimmers

TEXT.P: The Nantou County government said Saturday that it has adopted several measures, including an underwater GPS system, to ensure the safety of participants in an annual swim across Sun Moon Lake activity, which will take place Sunday.

County government officials said that in view of the two deaths that occurred last year during the activity, they have taken special precautions this year. The activity, which draws thousands of enthusiasts to attempt the swim across the scenic lake in central Taiwan, is now in its 26th year.

The officials said that they will deploy 20 top-notch diving professionals and equip them with propulsion equipment and underwater GPS systems for the first 100 meters, which is known to be the most dangerous stretch.
The officials said the total distance is about three kilometers, and any "unexpected physical problems" experienced by the swimmers usually occur during the first 100 meters.
A 72-year-old man died of a stroke soon after he jumped into the water last year.

The Nantou government, which sponsors the event, has moved up the activity to the end of August, instead of in mid-September or later when it was usually held, in consideration of colder water temperatures later in the year.
This year, an electronic board will be erected at the starting point to show the temperature of the water for the reference of the swimmers.

The organizers have also introduced a color-coded system this year so that the lifeguards can easily identify different groups of people, with physically challenged swimmers and those over 65 years of age required to wear pink swimming caps, while other participants will be required to wear red ones.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO head gains highest approval rating among Cabinet members: poll

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Vanessa Yea-ping Shih responded mildly Saturday to the results of a recent poll that put her approval rating above that of all the other Cabinet members.
Shih said she had "no comment on the results of the survey," adding that polls "can go up and down, and I will take them as reference."
The poll, conducted Aug. 12-15 by the monthly magazine Global Views, asked respondents to rate the performance of President Ma Ying-jeou and the new Cabinet.

The results showed that 36.1 percent of the respondents were satisfied with Ma's performance, and they were mostly optimistic about Ma "breaking the cross-strait stalemate." Some 47.6 percent, however, said they were not satisfied with the president's performance.
Meanwhile, 34.2 percent of those polled said they were satisfied with Premier Liu Chao-shiuan's performance, compared with 45.9 percent who said they were not.
In comparison, Shih's name recognition and approval ratings were higher, at 34.8 percent and 53.2 percent, respectively.
In terms of name recognition, Justice Minister Wang Ching-feng and Minister of the Interior Liao Liou-yi placed second and third.
In terms of approval rating, Shih was followed by Justice Minister Wang and Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo.

Asked about the biggest challenges faced by the Ma administration, 41.9 percent of the respondents cited inflation, followed by overreliance on China, and communication and coordination problems within the administrative team. The poll collected a total of 1,003 effective responses with a margin of error of 3.1 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police crack crime ring, seize US$3 million worth of drugs

TEXT.P: Police from the central Taiwan county of Nantou cracked a drug ring in Kaohsiung City Saturday, seizing 14 kg of amphetamine and five kg of ketamine, which had a total street value of over NT$100 million (US$3.17 million), according to a police report from Nantou.

The report said the ring was a joint operation between local and Chinese drug dealers. The Chinese dealers smuggled narcotics from China by boat, while the local smugglers transported the drugs from northern Taiwan to be sold in Kaohsiung, the report stated.

After a three-month investigation, the police on Friday night arrested the local ringleader, identified as Huang Sheng-feng, and two buyers in Kaohsiung City, as the men were engaged in a deal. The police also seized NT$7.7 million in cash during the raid.
The case has been turned over to the Kaohsiung District Prosecutors Office for an in-depth investigation, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma optimistic about U.S. arms sales to Taiwan

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed optimism for the first time Saturday about the possibility of the United States giving the green light for the sale of a package of weapon systems to Taiwan.

In recent weeks, Ma has repeatedly taken advantage of his meetings with visiting American congressional members and think tank scholars to urge the U.S. government to quickly approve the sale of seven categories of weapons that Taiwan intends to buy.

Addressing a gathering of retired generals Saturday to mark the upcoming Armed Forces Day and Mid-Autumn Festival, Ma said that judging from recent developments, he is convinced that the United States will give a nod to Taiwan's arms procurement bid in the not too distant future.
"Recent signs show that the U.S. administrative department would notify Congress of its approval of our arms procurement package that covers seven types of weaponry," Ma told his audience.

The pending items are anti-tank missiles, Apache helicopters, Patriot PAC-3 missile batteries, diesel-powered submarines, P3C anti-submarine aircraft and sea-launched Harpoon missiles and Black Eagle helicopters.

In his speech, Ma also said that recent improvements in relations across the Taiwan Strait should by no means be interpreted as a government attempt to give up efforts to enhance the country's defense capabilities.
Emphasizing the importance of honing the military's combat prowess and improving its defense arsenal, Ma said combat preparedness is not to wage war, but rather to deter war.
"Only with powerful defense muscle can we negotiate with strength in future cross-strait talks, " Ma explained, adding that Taiwan cannot afford to negotiate with weak military capabilities.

While Taiwan is more than willing to champion cross-strait reconciliation and pursue permanent peace on both the military and diplomatic fronts, Ma said, such lofty goals cannot be realized unilaterally.

Noting that upholding peace is at the core of commemorating the country's Sept. 3 Armed Forces Day, Ma said his administration will not miss any opportunity or possibility to advance or maintain permanent cross-strait peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH defends easing of criteria for confirming severe enterovirus

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) defended its decision to ease the criteria for confirming severe enterovirus cases this year, saying that the move will help to accelerate epidemic control and prevention.

The department made the remarks after a pediatrician said a sharp increase in the number of confirmed severe enterovirus cases in contrast to low death rate this year was mainly the result of the DOH's move to ease the criteria for confirming severe cases.

Noting that fighting epidemics is like fighting fire, Shih Wen-yi, deputy director-general of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said timing is a crucial element in epidemic control and prevention.
Against this backdrop, Shih argued that it is necessary to adopt less stringent criteria for the confirmation of severe enterovirus cases.

This year, 349 confirmed severe enterovirus infections were recorded, accounting for 74 percent of the overall suspected cases reported by local medical institutions. However, only 10 related fatalities were documented this year, representing 2.8 percent of the confirmed severe cases, a 10-year low ratio.
Since the first enterovirus outbreak struck Taiwan in 1998, the death rate generally ranged between 10 percent and 20 percent, according to official records.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office vows to step up reachout to opposition

TEXT.P: The government will step up communications with the opposition camp on various policy initiatives and exchanges of opinions on major public issues, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Saturday.

Wang made the remarks after tens of thousands of local citizens marched in downtown Taipei earlier the same day to protest what they called President Ma Ying-jeou's embrace of China and his administration's failure to improve the economy and people's livelihood.

Acknowledging the people's rights to assembly and demonstration, Wang said the government will increase dialogue with grassroots people and opposition parties to solicit their opinions in policy planning and seek their understanding and support for major initiatives.

Wang also argued that the Ma administration's major policies are on the right track. To live up to people's high expectations, he added, the governing team will work even harder and adopt innovative measures to cope with the changing global economic situation and revamp the sluggish domestic economy.

The protest was the first rally against Ma since he took office 100 days ago. Besides marching down major streets in the capital city, the demonstrators also rallied at Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office to chant slogans against Ma's government and calling for early passage of a package of "sunshine" bills to ensure clean politics.
The rally, organized by the pro-independence group Taiwan Society, ended peacefully in the evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Aug. 31, 2008

TEXT.P: Disclaimer:
The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st protest rally since Ma's inauguration ends peacefully

TEXT.P: The first massive-scale protest rally in downtown Taipei since President Ma Ying-jeou's May 20 inauguration concluded smoothly and peacefully Saturday evening, with demonstrators calling for economic stimulus measures and more cautious policies toward China.

Tens of thousands of Ma's opponents from around Taiwan marched through major Taipei streets before rallying on Ketagaland Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office. They banged drums, waved "Taiwan Yes, China No" banners and chanted slogans appealing for a better livelihood, protection of national sovereignty and early passage of "sunshine bills" to wipe out corruption.

Organized by the pro-independence group Taiwan Society, the rally came amid worries among some people that Ma's efforts to boost Taiwan's sluggish economy with China's help could erode and threaten Taiwan's sovereignty.
The crowd included opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators, local officials and citizens from around Taiwan and offshore Penghu County.
Lo Chih-cheng, secretary-general of the Taiwan Society, said the number of participants was far larger than expected. "The crowd was more than 10 folds of our original estimate," he added.

The protest, which coincided with Ma's 100th day in office, was also the first mass rally since the DPP lost power. An ongoing graft probe into former President Chen Shui-bian and his family didn't deter demonstrators, many of whom were staunch supporters of the DPP.

DPP Legislator Yeh Yi-jin said the cash-strapped DPP didn't give any financial support for the protest march and follow-up rally. "I was moved by enthusiastic support shown by grassroots supporters, all of whom have paid for travel fares out of their own pockets, " an emotional Yeh added.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen also took part in the parade from Lungshan Temple in western Taipei to Ketagalan Boulevard in central Taipei, receiving hearty welcome from thousands of DPP fans.
Addressing the rally, Tsai said she was pleased to see the street parade and rally proceed orderly and peacefully without any hitch.

Noting that the smooth proceeding of the demonstration signifies maturity of Taiwan's democracy, Tsai said she will lead the DPP to move into a brand new stage of development following the protest rally.
Before the rally, some ruling Kuomintang lawmakers speculated that the rally could be turned into an event to support what they called "corrupt A-bian" (the former president's nickname).

Tsai said she felt a relief from such worry as participants were all rational and adhered to the themes of the rally. She promised to give supporters a better DPP and work for a more democratic and prosperous Taiwan where "clean and sunshine politics" prevails.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 31, or the 1st day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
12AD: Caligula, originally Gaius Caesar, Roman emperor remembered for his murderous reign, is born. He succeeded his adopted father Tiberius. After a severe illness, he displayed the ruthlessness, extravagance and megalomania that led to his assassination.
1422: Henry V, King of England, who reopened the Hundred Years' War, defeating the French at Agincourt in 1415 and capturing all of Normandy by 1419, dies of dysentery in France at the age of 35. His son Henry VI accedes to the throne at the age of nine months.
1907: The Anglo-Russian Convention is signed in St. Petersburg, settling differences between the two over Tibet, Afghanistan and Persia.
1907: Ramon Magsaysay, president of the Philippines from 1953 to 1957, is born.
1939: Adolf Hitler announces the invasion of Poland. Three days later, both Britain and France declared war on Germany, marking the outbreak of World War II.
1945: The Nationalist government divides the three northeastern provinces in Manchuria into nine provinces.
1957: Malaysia achieves independence from Britain with Tengku Abdul Rahman as its first president.
1961: President Chiang Kai-shek tells 70 visiting American reporters that Kinmen and Matsu "are as important as West Berlin."
1962: The former British possessions of Trinidad and Tobago become an independent nation.
1962: The Republic of China recognizes the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago.
1965: Pakistan and India threaten war over Kashmir.
1968: A strong earthquake rocks northeastern Iran, killing 12,000 people and injuring over 100,000 others.
1974: The first plant to produce high-density polyethylene resins in the Republic of China is dedicated at Toufen in Miaoli County.
1976: Little League, Big League and Senior League teams return to Taipei after winning world titles in the United States.
1980: The ROC Mulan soccer team wins the championship at the first International Women's Soccer Tournament held in the United States.
1989: Buckingham Palace officially confirms that the marriage of Queen Elizabeth II's daughter, Anne, and Captain Mark Phillips is on the rocks.
1990: Premier Hau Pei-tsun advises the Legislative Yuan that ROC relations with mainland China will operate under the concept of "one country, two areas."
1992: Former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expresses support for the ROC's entry into the GATT during her visit to Taipei.
1993: Beijing makes public a white paper reiterating its position of solving the Taiwan problem by "peaceful reunification" and "one country, two systems," while refusing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
1994: Russian President Boris Yeltsin and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl jointly preside over a farewell ceremony marking an end to half a century of military presence on German soil by troops of the former Soviet Union.
1994: The IRA declares an unconditional end to its 25-year armed struggle for a united Ireland and its war against British rule of Northern Ireland.
1995: The ruling Kuomintang nominates incumbent President Lee Teng-hui as its presidential candidate.
1997: Britain's Princess Diana and her millionaire companion Dodi Al Fayed are killed in a Paris car crash.
1999: Raymond F. Burghardt, the newly appointed director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
2000: ROC Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen says that the military will continue to try to obtain an early warning system after recent war games revealed Taiwan's limited means to counter mainland Chinese missile attack.
2001: Compaq Computer Inc. and Taiwan's Academia Sinica, the highest academic researrch institute in Taiwan, sign a cooperative memorandum to engage in gene and biotechnology research in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only he, in the world, who possesses absolute truth who can get to the bottom of the law of his being. He who can get to the bottom of the law of his being will be able to get to the bottom of the law of being of other men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office vows to step up reachout to opposition

TEXT.P: The government will step up communications with the opposition camp on various policy initiatives and exchanges of opinions on major public issues, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Saturday.

Wang made the remarks after tens of thousands of local citizens marched in downtown Taipei earlier the same day to protest what they called President Ma Ying-jeou's embrace of China and his administration's failure to improve the economy and people's livelihood.

Acknowledging the people's rights to assembly and demonstration, Wang said the government will increase dialogue with grassroots people and opposition parties to solicit their opinions in policy planning and seek their understanding and support for major initiatives.

Wang also argued that the Ma administration's major policies are on the right track. To live up to people's high expectations, he added, the governing team will work even harder and adopt innovative measures to cope with the changing global economic situation and revamp the sluggish domestic economy.

The protest was the first rally against Ma since he took office 100 days ago. Besides marching down major streets in the capital city, the demonstrators also rallied at Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office to chant slogans against Ma's government and calling for early passage of a package of "sunshine" bills to ensure clean politics.
The rally, organized by the pro-independence group Taiwan Society, ended peacefully in the evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Thousands join annual mass swim across Sun Moon Lake

TEXT.P: Over 18,500 participants in 1,202 teams from home and abroad joined the 26th annual mass swim Sunday across Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County in central Taiwan.
The swimmers included 246 people from Australia, Britain, China, Hong Kong, Holland, Japan, Singapore and the United States, and 297 physically challenged participants, the organizers said.
Swimmers jumped into the water in separate batches, with some 300 physically challenged participants kicking off the event at 7: 00 a. m.

It took most of the participants 90 to 120 minutes to complete the approximately 3,000-meter swim from the starting point at the Chaowu Wharf to the finish line at the Itashao Wharf on the other side of the lake.

The event was proceeding smoothly in comfortable weather conditions, except for two minor incidents involving one swimmer with "breathing difficulties" and another who sustained a slight injury to his right eye.
The annual swimming event has in recent years become a major attraction in the Sun Moon Lake area, drawing more and more foreigners and adding greater fanfare each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education ministry offering emergency aid for school children

TEXT.P: School children from underprivileged families are entitled to apply for NT$1,000 (US$32) in emergency aid from the Ministry of Education (MOE) each semester, MOE Secretary-General Pan Wen-chung announced Sunday.

According to Pan, the MOE will provide a subsidy of NT$1,000 each to elementary and senior high school student in need in the case of unexpected difficulties, as the country's overall economic situation remains sluggish amid soaring consumer prices and a global economic downturn.
"The measure is aimed at preventing teenage students from dropping out of school," Pan said. "It has helped many students since it was put in place."

Under another program, the MOE has asked schools to open dedicated bank accounts and post the pertinent information on the ministry's Web site to facilitate members of the public who wish to make donations to the project, according to Pan.
Donors would thus be able to immediately access the data and information from the Web site about the students in need, he added.
As of Aug. 25 this year, a total of 984 students had received monetary assistance from a fund of nearly NT$2 million collected in 2,461 small donations by the public, he disclosed.
The new semester at Taiwan's primary and senior high schools will begin Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: President joins world's biggest road run

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou joined some 20,000 people in a 10-km road run in Taipei Sunday, which was the first leg of a global running event touted as the largest of its kind in the world.

Ma, accompanied by a host of professional runners, athletes from Taiwan's Olympic team, professional basketball players and officials from the Cabinet- level Sports Affairs Council, hit the road around 6: 00 a.m. in the race, which started from Taipei City Hall and ended at the Dajia Riverside Park in Taipei City's northern suburb of Dazhi.

Wu Wen-chien, 31, who represented Taiwan in the men's marathon competition at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, won in the men's division in Sunday's race with a time of 30 minutes, 35 seconds, while Taiwan's Hsu Yu-fang, 26, a marathoner in the 2004 Athens Olympics, won in the women's division in a time of 36:06.

The road run, dubbed "the Nike + Human Race" and sponsored by global sportswear giant Nike Inc., will move from Taipei to Shanghai, London, Paris, New York and 20 other "race cities" around the world.

The 25 cities were selected by Nike based on the geographical locations that it saw as best suited to showcase some of the most famous landmarks and unique race courses in the world and on the fact that those cities host the largest numbers of runners.

The other 20 cities are Austin, Bogota, Buenos Aires, Caracas, Chicago, Istanbul, Los Angeles, Lima, Madrid, Melbourne, Mexico City, Munich, Quito, Rome, Sao Paulo, Seoul, Singapore, Tokyo, Vancouver and Warsaw.
At the end of the race in Taipei, a live concert was held at the Dajia Riverside Park to fete the runners and their sport.
Meanwhile, the head office of Nike Inc. donated US$1 million to ninemillion.org, a U.N. refugee agency campaign that provides help for refugee children, and other public interest organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most reporters want to change jobs due to low pay, long hours: poll

TEXT.P: More than 70 percent of reporters are considering changing their jobs due to dissatisfaction with their low pay and long work hours, according to a survey conducted by the online 1111 job bank.
The survey was conducted Aug. 25-29 ahead of national journalists' on Sept. 1, and included incumbent and former reporters.
On the issue of salary, 34.61 percent of the respondents said they were dissatisfied with their pay, while 15.63 percent said they were very dissatisfied.

Among that group, 66.44 percent said their dissatisfaction was based on wages being disproportional to long working hours, 55.56 percent cited heavy workload, and 37.14 precent said their income was just not enough to cover their living expenses, according to the survey.
According to a cross analysis of the results of the survey, Web site reporters were most dissatisfied with their pay, followed by radio, TV, magazine and newspaper reporters, in that order.
Among reporters in this group, the main reason for their dissatisfaction with their wages was long work hours.
Some 40.5 percent of the reporters polled said they are required work 11 to 12 hours a day, and 35.09 percent work nine to 10 hours, with the average being 11 hours per day among all reporters.
Moreover, 23.6 percent of the respondents said that they usually work 21 days or more before having a day off. On average, they work 14 days before they could have break, they said.

The results of the survey also showed that not all reporters are please with their work. Some 17.87 percent said that they were unhappy at work, with TV reporters being the most unhappy, the poll found.

The reasons cited by the respondents for choosing to work as reporters included, personal interest (50.72 percent) , wanting to apply what they had studied (46.41 percent), a desire to widen their perspectives (36.36 percent) , seeking to develop connections (28.71 percent), wanting to change their work routine (26.79 percent), and hoping to maintaining social justice (14.35 percent).

The survey revealed that 70.97 percent of the respondents had already changed jobs or planned to do so, 18.34 percent of them had already left the job, 27.91 percent wanted to quit the media, and 24.72 percent wanted to change their jobs but still remain in the field.
The three main reasons cited for changing their jobs were a poor outlook for the media industry, dissatisfaction with pay, and loss of motivation.
The newspaper industry had the highest ratio of reporters who had quit their jobs, according to the survey which collected 627 valid samples.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan working to boost medical tourism

TEXT.P: Shen Jia, a property development executive from Shanghai, impulsively added a physical checkup to his itinerary on a business trip to Taiwan in early August.

Shen was no stranger to routine annual health exams in China. But, he said, his first experience with health care across the Taiwan Strait was surprisingly impressive, especially with what he called the "humanized" and "civilized" service.
His health check at Shin Kong Wu Ho-Su Memorial Hospital in suburban Taipei included a PET scan -- a cancer screening test that uses a positron emission tomography (PET) scanner.

Since the hospital introduced Asia's first PET scanner in 2001, the device has been so widely used in physical checks in Taiwan that it has almost become basic equipment in major medical institutions around the country. Currently, there are more than 20 such machines in use nationwide.
"There are not that many PET scanners on the mainland, and only two in Shanghai," Shen noted.

Shen's observations are not confined to the casual visitor. The British research and advisory firm Economist Intelligence Unit in 2000 ranked Taiwan's healthcare system as the second best in the world, behind Sweden.

With such recognition under its belt, Taiwan is trying to take advantage of its cutting-edge medical resources to reach out to international medical travelers, in an attempt to break into a growing business worth an estimated US$30 billion a year globally.

The health care industry is advertising Taiwan's congenial hospital environment as one that "emits no smell of medicine" and is promoting top-end physicals as one of the country's pioneer products. Affluent, health-conscious travelers like Shen are an obvious target group.
The China market is a primary target in light of its geographical and cultural proximity to Taiwan.

The potential for medical business from the mainland has grown since July following Taiwan's move to admit larger numbers of Chinese tourists and the launch of weekend cross-strait charter flights, which has made travel between the two sides much more convenient.
More significantly, Chinese tourists will soon be allowed to engage in individual activities for a day and a half while on group sightseeing tours of Taiwan.

"This regulation will be a major breakthrough, as Chinese tourists, under the current regulations, cannot have medical checks in Taiwan, " said Walter Yeh, executive vice president of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).
"We have been preparing, and now we can finally take off, " Yeh added.

Tourism Bureau statistics show that from July 18, when Taiwan officially opened it doors to larger numbers of Chinese tourists, to Aug. 26, a total of 10,228 Chinese tourists had entered the country, with daily arrivals averaging 244. The number of arrivals are expected to rise significantly when China eases its controls on outbound travel in the wake of the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing.

A spike in the number of visitors from China will swell the 3 million visitor arrivals to Taiwan every year. TAITRA has estimated that if 10 percent of these visitors each spend NT$20,000 (US$635) on physical examinations in Taiwan, this will help to generate revenues of NT$6 billion a year.
In June, Yeh led a delegation of representatives of 12 Taiwanese hospitals on a medical tourism fact-finding tour of Shanghai, Quanzhou and Xiamen.
The results were encouraging, according to a survey conducted by Taipei Veterans General Hospital among Chinese industry players during the tour.

The hospital -- the only public one represented on the delegation -- found that 90 percent of the respondents were interested in visiting Taiwan for pleasure, and 50 percent were willing to travel to Taiwan for medical care.
It was found that most respondents had formed a good impression of Taiwan's health care service, through information channels such as the media and the Internet.

The respondents said they thought Taiwan's medical institutions had an edge in terms of facilities, technology and services. They indicated that they were most interested in seeking health care in Taiwan in the areas of physical examination, dentistry and cosmetic medicine.
According to Yeh, Taiwan can use physical checks and cosmetic medicine to "build a brand, " until its other specialized health care services become better known internationally.
"We have many excellent products, but we need more publicity to reach a wider group of people, " said Yeh, who will lead another larger delegation to Beijing and Guangzhou in November.

Taiwan hospitals are promoting packages that incorporate regional tourism and physical examinations. They are offering top-end, state-of-the-art routine services such as cardiac computed tomography (CT) scans, cerebral magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans and whole-body PET scans, which cost between NT$18,000 and NT$54,000.

According to Hung Tzu-jen, vice president of the Shin Kong Medical Club HUng Tzu-jen, only a limited number of the three types of devices used for these scans are available in China, and they are employed mainly for diagnostic purposes.
"Unlike China, Taiwan is using the devices for routine health checks, " Hung said, expressing confidence that Chinese business travelers will find the customized services highly attractive.

Another group of potential clients are the owners and executives of Taiwanese businesses based in China. In March, Shin Kong Hospital served more than 100 business owners and executives who had returned from China for physicals, with each spending an average NT$35,000, Hung said.

Focusing on this target group, TAITRA recently held a seminar for Taiwanese business people based in China, encouraging them to add sightseeing and health examinations to their itineraries when they hold training programs in Taiwan for their Chinese executives.

Taiwan's ultimate goal in this field is to introduce to international medical tourists other high-end value-added medical services in which it excels, such as liver transplants, cardiac surgery, hip joint replacements, assisted reproduction and craniofacial surgery, Yeh said.

Every year, hundreds of thousands of foreign nationals travel to Asian countries such as Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia and India, for medical care. Taiwan, which provides high-quality medical care at more competitive prices, is a slow starter.

According to the Taiwan Non-governmental Hospitals and Clinics Association, which has been contracted by the Department of Health to help promote medical tourism, liver transplant surgery costs half as much in Taiwan as in Singapore. Plus, the survival rate in Taiwan for that procedure is the highest in the world, the association said.

Also, the cost of coronary artery bypass surgery is 30 percent cheaper in Taiwan than in Singapore and 20 percent cheaper than in Thailand. Hip replacement surgery in Taiwan costs 50 percent of what it does in Singapore or Thailand, data provided by the association shows.
With an eye on the revenue from medical tourism, Taiwan in May 2007 officially listed medical care as a category under which visitor visas could be granted.

Since then 292 foreign nationals from countries other than China have been granted medical visas to visit Taiwan for cancer therapy and organ transplants. In this group, 164 applicants were Filipinos, 59 were Indonesians, and 20 were from Malaysia and Vietnam, statistics from the Bureau of Consular Affairs showed.
From August 2007 to August 2008, 20 Chinese citizens were also granted permission to visit Taiwan for medical care, according to the National Immigration Agency.
The figures did not include visitors who traveled to Taiwan for physical examinations, cosmetic medicine or dental services -- categories that do not require a medical visa.

Lee Wui-chiang, director of the International Medical Service Center under the Taipei Veterans General Hospital, agreed that complex specialized surgery is the area in which Taiwan is most competitive. The top priority of Taiwan's medical institutions is to gain the trust of international medical tourists, a process that could take at least a couple of years, he added.
"It is not an easy decision put one's life in the hands of an overseas hospital," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairwoman to visit U.S.

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen is scheduled to depart for the United States Tuesday on a two-week visit, a DPP spokesman said Sunday.

On her first U.S. visit since she took over the helm of the DPP May 21, Tsai is expected to deliver a speech at her alma mater Cornell University and to meet with aides and advisors of U.S. presidential candidates Barack Obama and John McCain, said Cheng Wen-tsang, director of the DPP Department of Culture and Communications.
Tsai is expected to visit Washington, D.C., San Francisco and Los Angeles, where she will also meet with U.S. think tank members and with Taiwanese expatriates, Cheng said.

Tsai, who served as vice premier in the former DPP administration, was pleased to witness Saturday the first massive rally held in Taipei since President Ma Ying-jeou's May 20 inauguration, according to Cheng.

Tens of thousands of protestors from around Taiwan marched through the streets of Taipei Saturday before assembling at a rally on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office. They banged drums, waved banners that read "Taiwan Yes, China No" and chanted slogans appealing for a better life, protection of the nation's sovereignty and early passage of "sunshine bills" to wipe out corruption.
The mass rally scored high points for Tsai's leadership, as it was the first successful "people's movement" that she led since she assumed the DPP chairmanship, Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visits to China by offshore county chiefs to be posted on Web sites

TEXT.P: Elected local chiefs from the country's three offshore counties will now be subject to the same regulations as their counterparts from Taiwan proper, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Sunday.

Under the new rules, all elected local chiefs from the counties of Kinmen, Lienchiang, and Penghu are required to post their plans for any visits to China on a National Immigration Agency Web site prior to their departure, and within one month of their return to Taiwan, must submit a report to the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) , as are their counterparts on Taiwan proper, said a MAC official.
The RDEC will post their reports on its Web site.
"This would allow the general public to better monitor the activities of the elected mayors and magistrates," the official said.

On July 3, the Executive Yuan eased the regulations on visits to China by city and county chiefs from Taiwan proper, in tandem with the launch of nonstop weekend charter flights between Taiwan and China.

Since July 4, many Taiwanese mayors and magistrates have traveled to China at the head of delegations to promote bilateral exchanges, taking advantage of the convenience of the weekend charter flights.

Previously, Taiwan's local government heads were not permitted to visit China except to take part in international events. In mid-August, the MAC and the Ministry of the Interior decided that Taiwan's mayors and magistrates must publicize their plans to visit China and must submit a report to the Executive Yuan and publicize the report on an RDEC Web site within one month of their return.
The new regulations have been made retroactive to July 3, the official said.

Exchanges between Taiwan and China have been expanding since the May 20 inauguration of President Ma Ying-jeou, who is taking a more pragmatic stance towards relations with China. The two sides reached historical agreements in mid-June to launch nonstop charter flights on weekends and to increase the number of Chinese tourists to Taiwan from 1,000 to 3,000 a day.

DOC.HEADLINE: New ferry route opens between Kinmen and Xiamen

TEXT.P: Ferry services on a new route linking Shuitou wharf on Taiwan-controlled Kinmen island and Wutong wharf in Xiamen, southern China were launched Sunday.

The new route, which is the third to be opened between Kinmen and Chinese mainland, will reduce the travel time by sea between Kinmen and Xiamen from one hour to thirty minutes, according to Ho Chin-chang, owner of the Kinmen-based Golden Star ferry which will ply the 8-mile route.
Furthermore, Wutong is only a 10-minute ride away from Gaochi International Airport in Xiamen, from which passengers can fly to other Chinese cities, Ho noted.

In order to provide passengers with easy access to downtown Xiamen, Ho said, the Xiamen authorities have launched two bus routes linking Wutong, Xiamen International Convention Center, the city's railway station, and its main bus station.
During the formal opening of the sea route at 12 noon Sunday, 82 passengers boarded the Golden Star on its maiden trip to Wutong, amid the deafening sound of firecrackers.
At the same time, 230 passengers left Wutong for Shuitou on the Xiamen-based ferry Wu Yuan.

Yang Ting-piao, director of the Kinmen Harbor Department, said the four additional ferry trips on the new route will bring the total number of boat services between Kinmen and Chinese mainland to 28 per day.
The other 24 services include 20 trips between Shuitou and Dongdu wharf in Xiamen, and 4 between Shuitou and Shijin harbor in Chuanzhou.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cell phone users find corruption, unemployment most vexatious issues

TEXT.P: Taiwan citizens expressed their concern Sunday about various issues, via a mobile phone text messaging competition, with skyrocketing consumer prices and the former first family's alleged money laundering topping the list.

Through cell phone messaging, or short literature, the Taiwan people lamented the economic slowdown, voiced their expectations of President Ma Ying-jeou, and vented their anger over corruption among officials.
The winner in the "Message to the President" category said, "Mr. Ma, isn't it time for you to look for employment for us after we found you a job?"
Another contestant wrote to Ma, "You had better not turn yourself into the head of Taiwan's largest con ring."
A total of 5,076 items were submitted in the Second Myfone Mobile Phone Competition of Creativity sponsored by the Taiwan Mobile Foundation.
Of the total, 4,745 items were entered in the text messaging competition, and 331 in the creative mobile phone tunes contest.
Chen Mei-chieh won the top prize of NT$200,000 (US6,452) in the creative mobile phone tunes category.
The winner in the "Message to the President" category, Wei Hung-chun, won a cash prize of NT$70,000.
Fa Nuo-xin, who placed first in the "Message to Lover" segment, won a cash prize of NT$70,000 for her pithy note -- "I'm not in your heart, I'm downstairs."

Commenting on this message, novelist Chang Ta-chun said the line was crisp and cute, especially as most people tend to ask "Where are you" when they phone their lovers and most the lovers usually respond "I'm in your heart."

DOC.HEADLINE: China's worsening investment climate a challenge to Taiwan firms

TEXT.P: China's worsening investment climate and a series of government austerity measures to cool down the economy after the Beijing Olympics have emerged as a severe challenge to many Taiwan businesses that were pioneers in that vast market two decades ago, analysts said.

With China's investment conditions rapidly deteriorating due to the implementation of a string of a new policies relating to better labor protection, stricter land acquisition and more vigorous corporate tax laws, most Taiwan companies in that country have been driven to rethink their business development strategies, analysts observed.

According to the results of the latest survey conducted by the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association among China-based Taiwan businessmen, China's 2008 index in terms of investment climate has dropped for the first time, while its index for investment risks has increased -- the first such negative development in China's investment sentiment.
During the 2000-2005 period, China posted a rise in the two areas, as the association's past surveys had found. In 2006 and 2007, both indexes grew year on year.
The sharp changes in the Chinese market have pushed more and more China-based Taiwanese investors to retool their development strategies, analysts said.

Many of them have shifted their operations to Southeast Asian countries and India -- reflecting an altered mindset among Taiwan businessmen that China is no longer the "sole" target of their investment projects, the analysts noted.
In the meantime, Vietnam has been listed by Taiwanese enterprises as one of their top 10 potential investment destinations.

Lu Hung-teh, a professor at Chung Yuan Christian University in charge of the association's 2008 survey, suggested that China-based Taiwan companies revamp their risk management and investment diversification strategies in order to better deal with unexpected losses.

As a result of mounting operating difficulties in the Zhujiang Delta and Yangzijiang Delta areas in China's southern and central coastal provinces, Taiwanese businessmen clustered there are facing ever-increasing competition from multinationals and China's private firms, with the Taiwan enterprises' "first-mover" or "preemptive" advantages being eroded over time.

In view of the huge changes in the Chinese market, Taiwan businesses should not only forge new operating models, but also engage in industrial upgrades to drive their sustainable growth, Lu contended.

While many Taiwan businessmen might still remain undecided on whether relocate to China's west or north regions or even to Southeast Asian countries, Lu said, forming joint venturas with their Chinese private-sector counterparts might be the most feasible approach to making a profit across the world.

"This type of mutually beneficial strategy, rather than head-on competition, will help create a 'win-win' situation for both sides, " he recommended. He pointed to famous Taiwanese business groups, such as Master Kang, the top instant noodle maker in China, Acer Computer, and Giant Inc., a leading bike manufacturer, as examples.

As Beijing's austerity policies encourage Chinese companies to build their own distinguished brands and develop value-added sectors, it provides a good opportunity for Taiwanese industries to team up with their Chinese counterparts, Lu suggested.

In 1987 when the Taiwan government removed long-term restrictions on cross- Taiwan Strait exchanges, many of the Taiwan businessmen who edged into the Chinese market around that time are now over 60 years old and are troubled by inheritance problems -- a critical factor in their pursuit of sustainable growth, Lu said,

Citing the results of a survey made public in 2006 by a Taipei-based business management research institute, Lu said 87 percent of the 161 Taiwanese enterprises with operations in China's eastern and southern regions questioned had inheritance problems.

According to a poll released in 2007 by Britain's Cass Business School on global top executives, the world's five most efficient CEOs under the age of 45 were all from China. Eight among the world's top 10 CEOs were Chinese, while 37 of the best 50 CEOs were from China, the poll found.
The results of the two polls showed a contrast between China-based aging entrepreneurs from Taiwan and the thriving young Chinese CEOs, analysts observed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics minister projects economic boost from deregulation

TEXT.P: Taiwan's private investment and consumption indices are expected to rise in the first half of next year following the deregulation of trade and investment across the Taiwan Strait, Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming said Sunday.

In an interview with the CNA to mark the new Kuomintang administration's 100th day in office, Yiin said there is no specific way to bolster the sluggish domestic economy because Taiwan, as an open economy, is vulnerable to the global economic slowdown and cannot resist the pressure of oil and commodity price hikes.

Taiwan's 2009 national economic growth was forecast at 5.08 percent -- lower than the 6 percent target set by President Ma Ying-jeou during his election campaign, according to a report released Saturday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported recently that the monitoring indicators flashed "blue" in July for the first time since the outbreak of SARS in 2003, signaling a continued slowdown of the economy.

Moreover, Taiwan's export orders in July showed only 5.52 percent growth year- on-year, the slowest in over five years, with export orders from China posting a meager 1.73 percent growth compared with the same month a year earlier, according to statistics issued by the government.

Commenting on the figures, Yinn said that the government faced many challenges, such as soaring oil and commodity prices and the U.S. mortgage crisis, in the its first 100 days in office. However, he said he believes that Taiwan can overcome these difficulties, given the fact that it weathered the termination of formal diplomatic relations with the U.S. in 1979, its withdrawal from the U.N., two oil crises, and the Asian financial storm.

Yiin said that Taiwan stands a good chance of developing its economy, given its advantageous geographic location. The island is bounded by the world's main economic entities, with the U.S. in the east, Japan in the north, China in the west, and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) in the south, he noted.

Yinn also said that although inflationary pressures have gradually eased recently, the country's economic performance is determined by many other factors. He noted that almost every economy in the world is facing the dilemma of balancing the objectives of sustainable economic growth and price stability.

As Taiwan is unable to resist imported inflation, what it can do is strive to achieve economic growth and work to take better care of the disadvantaged to help them cope with surging commodity prices, he said.

Yinn said that although various economic figures for the second quarter reflect a weakening economy, he is more concerned about the figures for the third quarter, as the Beijing Olympics are over and that could possibly have a negative impact on Taiwan's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, DPP share number of best lawmakers at legislature: civic group

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) share evenly the number of best lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan in an assessment made by a civic group.
In an assessment of lawmakers' performance at the eight committees in the Legislature, Kuo Chung-hwa, chief of the Citizen Congress Watch said Sunday the KMT and DPP each has for four best lawmakers.

KMT Legislators Wu Chih-yang, Chao Li-yun, Lu Shiow-yen and Chiu Ching-chun were considered lawmakers with the best performance in Home Affairs Committee, Education and Culture Committee, Finance Committee and Economic Affairs Committee respectively.

Meanwhile DPP Legislators Twu Shiing-jer, Yeh Yi-jin, Wong Chin-chu and Lai Ching-te were ranked as the bests in Foreign Affairs and National Defense Committee, Transportation Committee, Judiciary, Organic Laws and Statues Committee and Sanitation, Environment and Labor Affairs Committee separately.

On the end, the civic group also named eight lawmakers with the poorest performance in these committees, with KMT, which controls 81 out of the 113 seats in the legislature, took the lion's share of seven.
They are Tsai Chin-lung, Hung Hsiu-chu, Fu Kun-chi, Tsao Erh-chung, Chiu Yi, Hsu Shao-ping and Chang Chia-chun.
The remaining one is Lin Bing-kun of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union.
Ku said the assessment was made by a jury of 98 based on the lawmakers' performace in last legislative session which concluded on July 18.
The lawmakers' performance was measured by the ratio of their absence from sittings, the number of times they spoke in the sittings and the number of motions they initiated.
Lawmakers who committed themselves to the cause of clean politics in the Legislature were given performance in the assessment, according to Ku.
He said he hopes the assessment will drive lawmakers to improve their performance on the job.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Sept.1, 2008

TEXT.P: The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.
Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information.
The CNA is not responsible for any cancellations or last-minute changes made in the scheduling of these events.
